column2: ALBANY, April 14. -- Gov. Roosevelt today signed the bill of Assemblyman Collins prohibiting six-day bicycle and other races. The bill provides that "in a bicycle race or other contest of skill, speed, or endurance, wherein one or more persons shall be a contestant or contestants, it shall be unlawful for any contestant to continue in such race or contest for a longer time than twelve hours during any twenty-four hours."

A useful and timely volume is this coherent and interesting narrative of the political events in one of the most important eras of our National history. The author's avowed object is a critical survey of the political history of the United States from the beginning of Jackson's Administration until the beginning of Tyler's. He gives also a preliminary view, not too greatly condensed, of previous history from Jackson's triumph at New Orleans.

Coroner Fitzpatrick, before whom the inquest into the death of the victims of the Windsor Hotel fire was to have been begun yesterday, adjourned the inquiry for a week after swearing the eleven jurymen selected. The adjournment was caused by the serious illness of one of the witnesses, said to be Mrs. Joseph Howard, Jr., and the absence of another on business.

Moore's remarks, published in your issue of to-day, it now seems to be the opportune moment to point out that the trouble began some years ago, when the more modern fire-proofing systems came into competition with the terra cotta block system.

PHILADELPHIA, April 14. -- Argument between District Attorney Rothermel, on the one side and Messrs. Watson, Shapley, and Shields on the other, upon the admission of testimony which may go a long way to establish the guilt or innocence of ex-United States Senator Quay, was the feature of his trial to-day, and it culminated in a decided victory for the prosecution.

The morning and afternoon yesterday were so tempting and promised to be so ideally Springlike that every one who could get out of town went country junketing and golfing. The tournament at Garden City was well attended, and at Ardsley there were the same overcrowded golf links until the late afternoon brought an April shower.

Now that the imposing task of reporting and higher criticism of the many events of an unusually brilliant musical season is over, you might perhaps be disposed to listen to the pleadings of an emotional musical enthusiast in reference to a subject which has not been touched upon in our growing musical literature and is vital enough to arouse earnest discussion, and thus lead to a higher plane of musical culture.

LONDON, April 15. -- The Franco-Italian demonstrations of friendship at Cagliari, Island of Sardinia, this week are considered to be fully in accord with the impulsive natures of the Latin races. A few weeks ago the Italians and French were yearning for an opportunity to engage in hostilities, but now they are engaging in exhibitions of the utmost friendliness.

HAVANA, April 7. -- In going to a strange country one does not as a rule think beforehand what he will eat while there. He assumes as a matter of course that he will live much as he does at home. To rid one's mind of any idea of this kind, it is only necessary to visit Havana. At once the item of eating rises from one of slight importance to one of great moment.

There is a good old lady in one of the Western towns who prides herself upon discrimination in giving charity. She will not listen long to one of the stock tales of woe, but is liberal in giving when convinced that her generosity is deserved. A strapping fellow, long of beard but short of clothing, appeared at her back door recently.

Another fight for the baseball championship is under way, and in every city but New York the clubs began the season under favorable conditions. In New York the team, instead of being stronger than last season, is weaker because of the absence of Rusie and Seymour, the two star pitchers.

J. CAMPBELL PHILLIPS, some of whose society sketches and drawings are reproduced herewith, is a young New York artist whose work in some of the illustrated weeklies has attracted attention. Mr. Phillips is self-taught, and has a natural knack of seizing amusing or characteristic situations in social life and transferring them with his pencil to paper.

WASHINGTON, April 15. -- Ambassador Aspiroz, who has recently succeeded Mr. Romero as the representative at Washington of the United States of Mexico, has become the subject of exciting gossip in the diplomatic circle. Ambassador Aspiroz had been greeted by the President, the Cabinet, and by his peers in the diplomatic body with every mark of courtesy and politeness, and in some instances with more than merely formal assurances of welcome.

CANTON, Ohio, April 15. -- The trial of Mrs. George for the murder of George D. Saxton opened to-day with Miss Mattie Grimes on the stand for cross-examination. Miss Grimes said she especially observed Mrs. George's flushed face when she saw her an hour after the murder, because she had heard of Saxton's death and had been told of the relations between Saxton and Mrs. George.

"We Americans are snobbish about our purchases," said Mrs. Horace C. Wait, a clever water-color artist, a member of Sorosis and a woman who has taken much interest in pottery for the last few years, talking to the members of the New York Society of Keramic Arts, one day last week. "We won't buy things that are American, because they are American, though they may be more meritorious than similar things that come from abroad.
HARRISBURG, April 15. -- The seventy-sixth ballot for United States Senator, taken to-day, resulted: Quay, (Rep.,) 6; Jenks, (Dem,) 33; Calvin Wells, (Rep.,) 2. There was no quorum.

SOME account has already been published in these pages of the production by the Comedie Francaise of Jean Aicard's translation of "Othello," and Jean Mounet-Sully's acting of the title role. The translator sticks closely to Shakespeare, and all good Frenchmen are bound to believe that he has improved upon the original.

The passenger lists of the outgoing Atlantic liners and the telegraph and mail news from Newport and Southampton, with numbers of men and women in outing costumes, with golf bags or bicycles, seen on trains and boats to the suburbs, tell the story of present conditions in the New York society world more forcibly than can the pen or printed word.

Complaint is made by citizens of the Borough of the Bronx that since the consolidation of the sections comprising the present city, public improvements in the Borough above the Harlem River have come to a standstill. For years the district made rapid strides under the administration of the Department of Street Improvements, in charge of the late Louis J. Heintz, and later under Louis F. Haffen, now Borough President.

LONDON, April 15. -- A premiere at the Lyceum Theatre is always one of the most brilliant social functions of London. To-night's production of Sardou's "Robespierre" was made doubly interesting on account of Sir Henry Irving's return to the stage after a long absence. The theatre was filled with the most notable personages of to-day.

The United States cruiser Raleigh arrived at Quarantine at 11:55 o'clock last night. She was met by a small flotilla of newspaper tugs and a police boat, which extended a hearty greeting to the warship.

Prof. Hays of the Minnesota Agricultural College has been experimenting with the cultivation of flax, and has found a means of producing a fibre plant that will, he thinks, bring about a revival of that industry in his State. Some years ago there was a rush into flax raising in Minnesota, and five factories were built in the State for the manufacture of the fibre.

Money market conditions improve. Bad bank statements have stopped. Surplus reserves are no longer decreasing. Yesterday's statement had in it more encouragement than even most hopeful expectants counted upon. In many ways it reflected healthful conditions. Not only have reserves ceased to shrink, they increase.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., April 15. -- The Legislature of two years ago appointed a committee to investigate the alleged abuses in the Chicago Police Department and Justices' courts. The report of the committee, which for several weeks held sessions in Chicago, was decidedly condemnatory, and another "Lexow" committee has been appointed with instructions to report its findings and representations to the next General Assembly.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 15. -- Attorney General Frank S. Monnett fulfilled general expectation to-day by filing in the Supreme Court an information relating that he and ex-Attorney General Watson had been approached with offers of bribes to discontinue prosecution of the Standard Oil cases.
The annual concert of the Philharmonic Society Orchestra of Columbia University takes place on Friday evening, April 21, at Mendelssohn Hall.

"The Highways and Hedges of Puerto Rico" is to be the subject of a lecture by Miss Anne Rhodes at the Berkeley Lyceum Saturday, April 22, 8.t 11 o'clock. Miss Rhodes is the Secretary of the Woman's National War Relief Association, and during the early part of the Winter visited Puerto Rico, carrying supplies to the United States military hospitals of the island.

BRISTOL, R.I., April 15. -- While considerable work was done this week on the new cup defender, Columbia, at the Herreshoff works, it appears now very doubtful if the boat will be ready for her first trial sail on June 1. The entire underbody of the boat amidships is plated, and the plating also extends well out to the bow and back to the stern.

During the first part of last week business at private contract was undoubtedly affected in some measure by the Eno estate auction sale on Wednesday. The last three days, however, have furnished a number of transactions which are fully up to the standards of recent weeks, and which justify a belief that the effects of the approaching Summer season need not yet be the cause for serious alarm.

WASHINGTON, April 15. -- The instructions to the American delegates to the Czar's Disarmament Congress are in the hands of the President, and they will be communicated to Messrs. White, Low, and Newell, and Capts. Mahan and Crozier at an early day. There will be no concerted meeting of the delegates on this side, the only purpose being to arrive at The Haugue about the same time -- on or about May 18.

WASHINGTON, April 15. -- The pay corps officers of the army in the Philippines have been instructed to continue the payment of the 20 per cent. extra allowed to enlisted men during time of war. It has been suggested that this payment would be discontinued when the peace proclamation was issued, but the department has decided that the men in the Philippines shall continue to receive war pay.

The house of a great hacienda is imposing in appearance, on account, usually, of its size rather than of its architectural proportions. It is generally built around a large court, and, whether of one or two stories, conveys the impression of having been erected solely with a view to durability and spaciousness.
RICHMOND, Va., April 15. -- Harvard won from the University of Virginia, at Charlottesville, to-day, by a score of 9 to 3.

PARIS, April 7. -- M. Loubet, the new President of the Republic, has been able for the first time since his elevation to the highest position in the State to clasp his aged peasant mother in his arms. The ceremony took place without much display or pomp, for M. Loubet, unlike his predecessor, Felix Faure, is opposed to outward show as being contrary to democratic principles.

CHICAGO, April 14. -- Chicago is deeply disappointed that her eager and non-partisan attempts to secure Greater Chicago -- which means the inclusion of all Cook County within the municipal limits -- have been frustrated by the obstructing methods of Senator Humphrey at Springfield. Quite regardless of party, even regardless of officeholding, men from the city and from the adjacent villages which expected annexation, went to Springfield to urge the benefits of unification.

In her "Metaphysics" Mrs. Eddy says: "Like the rules of mathematics," are proved by the "rule of inversion," and of this rule she gives us the following memorable examples: "There is no pain in truth, and no truth in pain; no matter in mind, and no mind in matter; no nerves in intelligence, and no intelligence in nerves."

In spite of the great success of "Rupert of Hentzau" at the Lyceum, the play cannot be performed after May 6, owing to Mr. Hackett's appearance with Maude Adams in "Romeo and Juliet." Arrangements have been made, however, for Mr. Hackett to appear in "Rupert of Hentzau" in New York next September.

WASHINGTON, April 15. -- A revival of the rumor that ex-Speaker Reed is to retire from political life was in circulation here to-day, but it could not be verified. In most respects it was in form similar to a report brought some time ago to the attention of Mr. Reed, when he met it with only profuse ridicule.

HAVANA, April 15. -- News has been received from Marianao that twelve or fifteen mounted bandits, one dressed as a woman, raided the Pinellos plantation, owned by Senora Puri, two miles south of Caimito, and ten miles from Havana, at twilight yesterday. The bandits took $100 in silver from the owner's residence, and afterward burned the house of the overseer, and a warehouse containing $5,000 worth of tobacco.

LONDON, April 15. -- The budget contains no feature to evoke enthusiasm, even among supporters of the Government. The Spectator, whose opinions usually differ from those of everybody else, alone welcomes it as statesmanlike. For weeks past The Times has been calling upon the Government to undertake a much needed and thorough reorganization of the national finances, but the Cabinet evidently thinks it has enough on its hands, without raising another huge problem.

CLEVELAND, April 15. -- Almost half the block of business houses bounded by Lake, Bank, Academy, and St. Clair Streets was wiped out by fire this afternoon, the damage amounting to nearly $1,000,000. The flames broke out in a straw-goods factory where a large number of girls were employed, and that none of them lost their lives is remarkable.

PHILADELPHIA, April 15. -- The prosecution to-day in the trial of ex-United States Senator Quay succeeded in having admitted as evidence the three books found in Cashier Hopkins's desk after the People's Bank failure, and on the pages of which, the Commonwealth alleges, will be found the evidences of conspiracy between Mr. Quay, the late ex-State Treasurer, Benjamin J. Haywood, and John R.S. Hopkins, the dead cashier.

NEWPORT, April 15. -- Mrs. Robert Garrett of Baltimore has rented for the coming season the Travers villa on Narragansett Avenue. Mrs. Garrett was until 1893 a well-known cottager here. She occupied that season Reef Point, on the cliffs, but has since then been absent from Newport.

WASHINGTON, April 15. -- Senator Platt and Senator Depew are understood to have won their fight for ex-Representative Fischer, who, according to a White House report this afternoon, will soon be appointed Appraiser, notwithstanding the protest sent here against the selection of a candidate not acquainted with the details of Custom House business.

Chief Bonner of the Fire Department subjected the standpipe system of the Manhattan Life Building to a successful test yesterday. The standpipe system has been advocated by the New York Board of Fire Underwriters as affording facilities for extinguishing fires in high buildings. Chief Bonner was assisted by Deputy Chief Croker and Battalion Chief Callahan.

The membership of the organization is decreasing more every month and the anti-racing element avers that the League's attempt to control racing and fight the National Cycling Association is the cause of it all.

NEWPORT NEWS, Va., April 15. -- The sister ships El Norte and El Sud of the Morgan Line, building at the plant of the Newport News Steamship Building and Dry Dock Company, were successfully launched here to-day in the presence of several thousand spectators, including Assistant Secretary of War Meiklejohn and Assistant Secretary of the Treasury Taylor, many naval officers' from Washington, and other distinguished guests.

THE later end of the musical season does not lack serious interest. The voice of the opera singer is not heard in the land to quite the same extent and that gives the more serious things in music some opportunity for consideration.

LAKEWOOD, April 15. -- A more attractive or beautiful spot than the Land o' Pines is just now could scarcely be imagined. April is the most delightful month of the year at this resort, and Spring is proving a formidable rival to the Winter season. Lakewood is deservedly popular at all times.

LOUISVILLE, April 15. -- A gigantic liquor combination, an amalgamation of whisky and distillery interests, with a united capital of $200,000,000, will be practically completed in all but minor details to-morrow in Chicago, when the men now controlling the Kentucky Distilleries and Warehouse Company finish arrangements for the purchase and absorption of many of the largest distilleries of rye whisky in the United States.

WITHIN the last few years books which bring common man nearer the nature which surrounds him have increased in number to a wonderful degree. In other words, an attempt has been made to give popular interpretation to the sciences which concern themselves with the animals and birds of the fields and woodlands, with the insects, and with the flowers and trees.

Herbert M. Harriman of the Meadowbrook Hunt Club won the championship of the Metropolitan Golf Association yesterday, at the conclusion of its four-day tournament, on the Garden City links. He won it in a match that was a fitting ending to a championship contest. Reginald Brooks, the Newport and Meadowbrook golfer, was the victor's opponent.

Lady Randolph Churchill, whose portrait is presented on the first page of the Magazine, has lately been placed more in evidence than had formerly been her position through the fact that she has undertaken to edit guinea magazine called The Anglo-Saxon. Only the "chosen" of America and England will contribute to the periodical, which, it is supposed, will do much to increase the bond of amiability between the two countries.

NEWPORT, April 15. -- Attached to the rear of the regular train due from Boston at 3 o'clock this afternoon was a combination palace car from New York, which was occupied by Mr. and Mrs. William K. Vanderbilt, Jr. They were met at the station by one of W.K. Vanderbilt's new open carriages, and driven to Belvoir, where they will pass the Summer.

William Jennings Bryan was the hero of the hour at the dinner given by the Chicago Platform Democrats at the Grand Central Palace last night in honor of Thomas Jefferson. In fact, the dinner had more the character of a campaign meeting than a feast in honor of the departed founder of a political party.

LONDON, April 15. -- The marriage of the Earl of Crewe to Lady Margaret Primrose, the youngest daughter of the Earl of Rosebery, in Westminster Abbey next Thursday, will be the most notable event in society here for many years. The Earl of Rosebery will entertain a large party at The Durdans, Epsom, for the Epsom races, on Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, April 15. -- Mortgage obligations in Cuba will he further extended for another year. This extension, however, will be limited to debts secured by mortgage or ground rents.

VICTORIA, B.C., April 15. -- According to the Peking and Tien-Tsin Times, copies of which were received here by the steamer Glenogle, it is generally believed among the foreign element at Peking that the seizure of Kiao-Chau in November, 1897, by Germany, was a first step toward the realization of a scheme of the Emperor to place a German King on Chinese soil.

Mayer and Naumburg, in your excellent paper, have greatly interested me. I quite agree with Mr. Mayer in his reply to your music editor's very harsh criticism, and his recommendation to the orchestra to take heed of Mr. Henderson's usually just fault-finding.

THE old-fashioned photograph album has had its day, and, perhaps, it has done its duty in the World. It is doubtful if Hogarth ever appealed to the sense of humor of so many people as does the old-fashioned photograph album. It required a sense of humor to appreciate either, but the album came within the range of the mental equipment of a larger class of people.

The annual meeting of the comparative Literature Society was held yesterday in Carnegie Lyceum, and at the close of the business session Prof. Charles Sprague Smith, the managing Director of the society, delivered the annual address. He took as his subject "Dante's Vita Nuova."

CITY OF MEXICO, April 15. -- The report received here from Washington that Ambassadors and foreign Ministers at the capital were disposed to slight Mexican Ambassador Aspiroz on account of his prosecution of the so-called Emperor Maximilian, has aroused much interest here in official and social circles.

IN every one of the seventy-odd residences facing Central Park along Fifth Avenue, between Sixtieth and Eightieth Streets, lives a millionaire. This is the richest mile in the world. Include the intersecting streets and you have what might be called the Court End of the town.

SEVILLE, March 24. -- The civilization of Spain, streaked as it is with Oriental barbarisms, belated and discouraged as the end of the nineteenth century finds it, is still in many respects finer than our own. In everything that relates to courtesy, to grace and charm of social intercourse, to the dignified expression of reverence, compassion and acknowledgment, Spain puts us to the blush.

APRIL is the great month for fencing. Practically all of the championship events are held during the present month, and at the Fencers' Club, the New York Athletic Club, and the Racquet Club, where the graceful French short flourishes must successfully in this city, the fencing rooms present an animated appearance nearly every afternoon and evening.

BERLIN, April 1. -- The Winter theatrical and musical season in Berlin has been a particularly prolific one, productions of operas, dramas, comedies, concertos, and symphonies following one another with bewildering rapidity. The quality, to be sure, has by no means kept pace with the quantity, but, although no new genius has arisen, Hauptmann, Sudermann, Ignaz Brull, and d'Albert have all brought out new pieces of importance.

Mr. George Paish, associate editor of The London Statist, is at present in this country engaged upon a study of existing financial conditions here. From week to week Mr. Paish is sending to his paper articles embodying his opinions as gathered from close observation of American affairs.

Thomas Creighton, a lineman of the Northern Electric Company, fell from an electric light pole where he was repairing a wire last night at One Hundred and Fifty-fifth Street and Third Avenue, and died shortly after from his injuries. The cause of his fall is not known, but it is supposed he received a shock which, while not strong enough to leave any visible sign, was sufficient to loosen his grasp.

ALBANY, April 16. -- Superintendent of Insurance Louis F. Payn is having some trouble in getting through the Legislature certain measures of a remedial nature which were introduced at his instance and were recommended in his first report, transmitted in February, but which are being "held up" in committee through the influence, it is alleged, of the companies at which they are aimed.

CHICAGO, April 16. -- "The Chicago Platform Democrats" is the name adopted yesterday by followers of John P. Altgeld for their party. Under it a permanent organization was effected, as far as Cook County is concerned, and the promise is that it will soon be extended to cover the entire State.

WASHINGTON, April 1. -- While the exportation of manufactures in the fiscal year 1809 is likely to show an increase of more than $30,000,000 over that of last year, the shipment of iron and steel alone will supply more than one-half that increase.

PARIS, April 16. -- The Figaro, continuing to-day its publication of the testimony offered before the Court of Cassation in the Dreyfus revision proceedings, prints some fourteen columns of matter. A good part is devoted to a further statement of Col. Picquart's evidence.

CHICAGO, April 16. -- Before a select audience in the studio of Miss Anna Morgan yesterday, Henry B. Fuller, the Chicago novelist, delivered a pessimistic paper on "Art in America," Mr. Fuller is noted as the author of many of the cleverest epigrams uttered in the West.

ALBANY, April 16. -- Is Theodore Roosevelt to be the apostle of a new National crusade for tax reform, with the taxation of franchises as its keynote? That is a question that is being asked here, and the Governor's utterances on the subject in Chicago, taken in connection with some things he has said in private at home in the last few days, are held by many of his admirers to furnish its affirmative answer.

The Rev. Dr. Anthony H. Evans of the West Presbyterian Church has decided to continue as pastor of the church, and at yesterday morning's service he announced the withdrawal of his recently tendered resignation. So pleased were his supporters at the announcement that at the conclusion of the service they flocked about Dr. Evans, congratulating him on his decision and assuring him of their hearty support.

ALBANY, April 16. -- The report of the findings of the court of inquiry in the Seventy-first Regiment case is expected to be made public this week. Gov. Roosevelt will give a hearing to-morrow to Col. Bacon, as counsel for Messrs. Smith and Whipple, but as he has already had the papers in his possession for ten days, his decision probably will not be long delayed thereby.

The first official trial trip of one of these cars was made yesterday morning in Twenty-third Street from the Metropolitan Street Railway Company's stables at the North River to the ferry at East River, and back again.

There is a rumor afloat that Mrs. Althouse, the missing witness, wanted by both sides, is in the city and will be in court to-morrow, but this cannot be substantiated.

Profit taking, rather aggressive selling by some of the larger traders, and the execution of stop-loss orders which were reached on the decline, were the influences in Brooklyn's weakness.

Mr. CROKER, as he sits awaiting the summons to the witness stand, has the air of a successful bank President in a considerable country town -- an air of conscious equality with the best and of superiority to most of his associates. His personal appearance first suggests the comparison.

WASHINGTON, April 17. -- In the United States Supreme Court an opinion was handed down to-day by Justice Peckham, pronouncing invalid a portion of the Michigan statute regulating the sale of thousand-mile railroad tickets. The part of the law affected is that providing that these tickets shall be good for two years and shall be sold at a reduced rate.

WASHINGTON, April 17. -- The Wade Court of Inquiry spent the forenoon inspecting a miscellaneous collection of canned roast beef which had been accumulated at the Washington Barracks from various points in Cuba and Puerto Rico. The 650 cans inspected represented nearly all of the various brands in use during the island campaigns.

VALDOSTA, Ga., April 17. -- Robert Miller, supposed to be a plumber originally from Toronto, but lately working at Birmingham, Ala., and Jacksonville, Fla., committed suicide in a sensational manner here to-day. He arrived here last night from Jacksonville. His actions attracted the attention of the Chief of Police, and he was locked up pending an examination into his mental condition.

BERLIN, April 17. -- The Reichstag began to-day the consideration of the Meat Inspection bill with a small attendance. SCHENECTADY, April 17. -- Col. William Jennings Bryan addressed an audience of 4,000 persons in the Central Opera House here to-night.

NEWARK, April 17. -- Rear Admiral Schley was the guest of the Newark High School Alumni last night. Weeks of the Alumni Association, and the male pupils of the High School.

WASHINGTON, April 18. -- The Cabinet to-day devoted the entire session to the consideration of the Cuban debt question. The delegation of Cubans representing the Cuban Planters' Association has asked for a general extension of all credits for from three to six years, and for some amelioration of interest rates. The necessity for some action is recognized by the President and Cabinet.

BALTIMORE, April 18. -- The New Yorks to-day showed a reversal of form from the game of yesterday. They were keyed up to the top notch, while the Baltimores appeared to be nervous. With the score 4 to 0 in favor of the visitors, a shut-out was predicted when the home team went to bat in the eighth inning.
RICHMOND, Va., April 18. -- The Harvard baseball team defeated Fredericksburg College, 5 to 1, at Fredericksburg this afternoon.

LONDON, April 18. -- At the first day's racing of the Epsom Spring Meeting to-day Lord Penrhyn's four-year-old bay colt King's Messenger, by King Monmouth, out of Swiftsure, won the Great Metropolitan Stakes. "Tod" Sloan rode Lord Ellesmere's four-year-old bay filly Fairmile, but was unplaced.

The reconstructed cruiser Chicago, flagship of Rear Admiral Howison, commanding the South Atlantic Squadron, sailed from the Brooklyn Navy Yard yesterday on a six months' cruise to important ports in Africa and South America. There was an inspiring scene as the white cruiser left the yard.

WHITE PLAINS, April 19. -- The distribution of the Frederick C. Havemeyer estate, which had been thrice delayed by the arrival of new heirs, has been once more deferred by the advent, since the last citations to a settlement, of Lillian F. Potter, daughter born to Mr. and Mrs. E. Clarkson Potter, (Emily Havemeyer.) Consequently the machinery of the Surrogate's office has had to be started all over again.

There was a decided improvement in the quality and character of the racing at the Aqueduct track yesterday. The horses were of a far better class, and they were so well matched in several of the events as to warrant a liberal backing for several of the contestants, so that things were very lively in the betting ring.

WASHINGTON, April 19. -- Herbert Putnam, Librarian of Congress, who has just begun his work here, stated to-day that he does not intend to make any radical changes in the force, but that he may make some changes in the disposition of the persons now employed, and that he will fill the eight vacancies in the library, either by original appointment or by transfer or promotion.

WASHINGTON, April 19. -- A conference held at the White House to-day between the President, Secretary Alger, Secretary Long, and Adjt. Gen. Corbin resulted in the confirmation of the original decision of the Administration to at present refrain from availing itself of the authorization conferred by Congress to organize a volunteer army of 35,000 soldiers in addition to the present regular army.
ALBANY, April 19. -- Gov. Roosevelt signed the Civil Service bill to-day, immediately upon receiving it from the Legislature.

LANCASTER, Penn., April 19. -- The warrants for the arrest of Jacobs, his two bookkeepers, Henry Brallier and Simon Kleinordlinger; W.L. Kendig and his foreman, James Burns; "John Doe," and "B.F. Zercher," were sworn out by United States Commissioner Henry F. Edmunds of Philadelphia.

ALBANY, April 19. -- Nathaniel A. Ellsberg, the youngest member of the Senate, to-day led a successful revolt against Senator Ellsworth's unpopular leadership of the majority which has made him the lion of the hour on the Republican side and may have far-reaching effects on the fate of the State Police bill.

HARRISBURG, Penn., April 19. -- The Nyce resolution, calling upon the Attorney General to prosecute all those, including ex-Senator Quay, who had been charged with receiving interest on the State's money, almost precipitated a riot in the Senate today. It was a bitter fight between two factions, and finally the resolution was laid on the table by a vote of 33 to 6.

NEWPORT, April 19. -- Lispenard Stewart has presented to Trinity Church a magnificent window as a memorial to his mother, Mary Rhinelander Stewart, which will be placed in one of the north windows within the next two weeks. The window is from the Tiffany studios of New York.

HAVANA, April 19. -- Gen. Maximo Gomez has determined to announce to the people of Cuba his support of an American protectorate until such time as a stable, independent government may be founded. This announcement would have been made tomorrow had he been able to work upon the manifesto to-day; but that was impracticable because he passed the entire time with his two sons and his daughter, who sails for San Domingo to-morrow.

LONDON, April 19. -- At the second day's racing of the Epsom Spring meeting to-day, Sir J. Miller's three-year-old bay gelding Korosko, ridden by "Tod" Sloan, won the Copthorne Plate. This race is a handicap of 150 sovereigns, for three-year-olds and upward, the second to receive 10 sovereigns out of the plate; entrance, 3 sovereigns.

LONDON, April 19. -- John Barrett, ex-United States Minister to Siam, who has just arrived from Manila, emphatically declares that the gloomy forebodings expressed in some quarters relative to the Philippines are not justified by the facts.

In point of numbers and enthusiasm it was not nearly as successful as was the dollar dinner of the Chicago Platform Democrats.

SYRACUSE, April 19. -- Until certain differences which grew out of the preparations for the reception of William Jennings Bryan here to-morrow were adjusted there was a prospect that the situation would be attended by complications embarrassing to the local Democratic organization.

Capt. Joseph B. Coghlan of the Raleigh has come into the heritage of his glory. It was like a presentation at some Continental Court yesterday afternoon, when nearly 800 women trooped past the returned hero of Manila, in the gayly decorated rooms of the Transportation Club, to pay him his due and to shake his hand. Capt. Coghlan looked as if he enjoyed the change from the heated waters of Manila Bay.

Adams, on the ground that other than legal evidence had been submitted to the Grand Jury which found the indictment.

ALBANY, April 19. -- On the floor of the Assembly to-day Mr. Mazet, Chairman of the New York Investigating Committee, denied that he had said that the committee would make Mr. Croker and Mr. Carroll perjure themselves.

One of the burglars, whose identity is unknown, fired a shot at the policeman, who was struggling with the other robber.

This morning at five minutes past 9 I waited four minutes at Sixth Avenue and Twenty-eighth Street for a train. When it came it was jammed to the gates. It was three minutes before another arrived. At 5 o'clock, at Cortlandt Street, waits of three minutes occur daily.

Wilkie and his agents, when they arrested Arthur Taylor and Baldwin S. Bredell, the makers of the famous counterfeit "Monroe head" one-hundred-dollar silver certificates.

New York again played championship ball in the field, and while Miller's pitching would have won an ordinary game, the visitors were too fast at all points for the locals. The young woman is Miss Lillian C. Moeran of 55 Irving Place, and she appealed to Judge Wauhope Lynn.

PHILADELPHIA, April 19. -- A sensational arrest was made in this city to-night in connection with the capture of the counterfeiting gang. Harvey K. Newitt, who was Assistant United States District Attorney in this city during the Administration of President Harrison, was taken into custody by Secret Service men on a warrant sworn out by Chief Wilkie, charging him with bribing Detective McManus of the Philadelphia office.

ALBANY, April 19. -- The appointment by Gov. Roosevelt to-day of Thomas Sturgis of New York City, Ansley Wilcox of Buffalo, and Henry G. Danforth of Rochester as members of the Board of Managers of the Elmira State Reformatory, is generally accepted here as meaning the breaking up of the local control of that institution, which has been a subject of frequent scandals, and the removal of H.H. Brockway as Superintendent.

LONDON, April 19. -- Primrose Day, otherwise the anniversary of the death of Lord Beaconsfield, (Benjamin Disraeli,) who died April 19, 1881, was generally celebrated here to-day. About two-thirds of the people in the streets wore primroses in their buttonholes. Queen Victoria sent from Nice a large wreath of primroses to be placed on the grave of the statesman, in Hughendon Churchyard.

He will enter on legal work here as a member of the law firm of Simpson.

CHICAGO, April 19. -- "As a sewer the drainage canal will be a failure. Sanitary engineers anywhere but in Chicago will acknowledge that. It may take a few years to convince people here that it is a failure, but Chicago should be prepared to acknowledge it. Methods of disposing of sewage have improved since the canal was projected. So far as that purpose is concerned we have spent $35,000,000 for nothing."

WASHINGTON, April 19. -- The beef court of inquiry was engaged steadily to-day in going through the testimony which has accumulated as the result of the three months' investigation and in the preparation of the report of its findings. The report will be comparatively brief, but the work of collating the essential facts is a task of no small magnitude, and will require several days.

A number of distinguished Americans --bankers, lawyers, politicians, and merchants -- met yesterday afternoon in the Lawyers' Club, at 120 Broadway, to attend a luncheon given by Isaac N. Seligman, the hanker, in honor of Henry Peartree, President of the American Chamber of Commerce in Paris.
Date fixed for the opening of the Erie, Champlain, Oswego, and Cayuga and Seneca Canals next Wednesday.

BOSTON, April 19. -- The National League baseball season in this city was opened this afternoon, when the champions met the new Brooklyn team and shut them out for the second time this season before 12,000 persons. The visitors were unable to do anything with Nichols's pitching and only once did a Brooklyn man reach third base.

Douglas Robinson Co. have sold for St. Luke's Hospital the plot on the south side of Fifty-fifth Street, 350 feet west of Fifth Avenue, 50 by 102.2. The buyer's name is withheld. The only part of its former site which is now owned by St. Luke's Hospital is the plot, 125 by 102.2, at the southwest corner of Fifty-fifth Street and Fifth Avenue.

BOSTON, April 19. -- Lawrence Brignoli of the Cambridge Gymnasium Athletic Association won the third Boston Athletic Association's Marathon twenty-five-mile road race to-day, leading his nearest rival, "Dick" Grant of the Knickerbocker Athletic Club of New York, by over half a mile. Owing to the heavy easterly gale, against which the men ran all the way, the race was more severe than the two preceding, and Brignoli was over twelve minutes behind the record.

The New York City Chapter, Daughters of the American Revolution, held its annual birthday celebration yesterday afternoon at Sherry's, in commemoration of the anniversary of the battle of Lexington, and of the victorious issue of the war with Spain. The managers of the Forepaugh and Sells Brothers' Circus have sent to 500 actors and actresses in this city invitations to attend the afternoon performance at Madison Square Garden to-day. The afternoon performance on April 25 has been set aside for the children of many charitable institutions in the city.

LONDON, April 20. -- Large crowds of people gathered within the precincts of Westminster Abbey to-day in order to witness the marriage of Lady Margaret Primrose, youngest daughter of the Earl of Rosebery, to the Earl of Crewe. Among those present in the abbey were 600 invited guests, all wearing wedding favors of marguerites and primroses, representing the bride's name.

SOUTHERN PINES, N.C., April 20. -- The business men of the Southern States are in convention here in an effort to give publicity to the advantages of the South as a field for safe investment. The attendance is large, North and South Carolina, Georgia, and Florida sending strong delegations. The railroads also have representatives in attendance.

DES MOINES, Iowa, April 20. -- Iowa has two candidates for the Speakership of the House of Representatives. Congressman Henderson's friends here are confident that he will have the support of the full State delegation. At Clarinda, the home of Congressman Hepburn, it is claimed that he has the solid support of Iowa. Capt. Hull of Des Moines, Chairman of the Military Committee, says he will not be a candidate.

NEWPORT, April 20. -- The election of officers of All Saints' Memorial Chapel resulted as follows; Senior Warden -- Frederick W. Rhinelander; Junior Warden -- Dr. E. Linzee Cunningham; Vestrymen -- Dr. William C. Rives, Admiral Stephen B. Luce, Frederick W. Rhinelander, R.C. Derby, Leslie Pell-Clarke; Clerk -- William C. Rives; Treasurer -- J. Truman Burdick.

A row was precipitated yesterday between physicians of the Coroners' office and those of Bellevue Hospital It began when Coroners' Physician Weston expressed his opinion of some of the hospital physicians. It was in regard to the case of a woman patient upon whose body he had performed an autopsy.

ALBANY, April 20. -- Although both branches of the Legislature stand ready to pass the Rapid Transit bill as it is, and the approval of the Mayor is assured by the withdrawal of Tammany's opposition, the measure is by no means sure of becoming law. Gov. Roosevelt is to be reckoned with, and he declared to-day that he was still opposed to the perpetual franchise feature of the bill.

ALBANY, April 20. -- In a bill passed by the Assembly to-day, after a sharp fight on party lines, the law relative to the individual liability of stockholders of banks is amended, it was charged by the Democrats, in the interest of the receivers of the Murray Hill Bank. Of these receivers is B.B. Odell, Jr., Chairman of the Republican State Committee, while Edward H. Hobbs of Brooklyn is the other.

Daily transactions on the Stock Exchange do not now run beyond the average of half a million shares. This cuts about half in two the aggregates ruling in recent activity. Some contrary theories are current to explain this.

VIENNA, April 21. -- The Neue Frele Presse asserts that the estate left by the late Baroness de Hirsch, who died April 1, has been valued at 25,000,000, ($125,000,000,) of which 20,000,000 ($100,000,000) will be expended in carrying out the various charities founded of fostered by the Baron and Baroness.

The important feature of Mr. PEARTREE'S little speech on the question of reciprocity with France is his announcement that M. CAMBON, the French Ambassador, and Mr. KASSON, the special Commissioner for the United States, have agreed upon a basis for a treaty.

NEWPORT, April 20. -- Negotiations for the lease of new grounds for the Westchester Polo Club were completed to-day. Work will be begun on the land immediately, so that it may be in order for play during the coming season. A handsome clubhouse will be erected. The property is of such ample proportions that there is abundant room for buildings, driveways, , without encroaching upon the polo ground proper.

Ida Lesser, nineteen years old, and Mrs. Rose Grey, fifty years old, were burned during a slight fire at 29 Essex Street last night. Miss Lesser was inspecting some rooms at the above number which her mother had rented during the day. She was seen to go up the stairs carrying a candle.

ALBANY, April 20. -- A hearing was given this afternoon by Gov. Roosevelt on the report of the court of inquiry which investigated the conduct of the Seventy-first Regiment in the Santiago campaign. The report of the court is now in the hands of the Governor, and the hearing was given at the request of Col. Alexander S. Bacon of Brooklyn, as counsel for certain officers of the regiment.

The prison hospital of the penitentiary on Blackwell's Island was destroyed by fire yesterday afternoon, and all that remains of the old building, which has stood since 1828, and which has been repeatedly condemned, is the four stone walls. One of these walls prevented the flames from igniting the prison building, which adjoins the hospital.

Mr. Cheseborough was the President of the Cheseborough was Manufacturing Company, and the proprietor of the Beechwood Hotel, in Summit.

BOSTON, April 20. -- It is announced that Miss Florence E. Smith is soon to marry President G. Stanley Hall of Clark University. Miss Smith is well known in educational circles in Boston and in social circles in this city and Newton, her native city. She was born in Newton Centre. Although she is not a college graduate, Miss Smith is a finely educated woman and one of remarkable intellect.

WASHINGTON, April 20. -- The most expert pathologist of the Agricultural Department, Dr. Zwingle, is now in Morocco on a mission which the department hopes will launch a new and profitable industry in the most arid sections of our Southwest. It has been found that date palms, with some irrigation, will grow as well in Arizona as in Arabia.

ALBANY, April 20. -- Just as victory seemed to be in sight for the State Police bill it was snatched away to-day. Parsons and William W. Armstrong, to vote for it.

MANILA, April 20. -- Spain's evacuation of the Philippine Islands will be practically completed by the withdrawal of the Spanish garrison from Zamboanga, Island of Mindanao, and from the Sulu Islands, and if the United States assumes control of Mindanao and the Sulu Islands on the Spaniards withdrawing, the military authorities here must, in order to garrison those islands, diminish the forces of American troops, which are already too small.

They are thinking all the time of the delights of laziness.

Your daily issue is read by me with much interest and pleasure since it is now put beyond a doubt that reduction in its price does not mean in any sense reduction of its standing, namely, that of a first-class newspaper. The wide range of subjects embraced by its correspondence columns encourages me to present one that I have not yet seen referred to -- the building contractor's night watchmen.

NEW ORLEANS, April 20. -- Archbishop Chapelle was to-day officially informed by Cardinal Rampolla, the Papal Secretary of State, that his Holiness had granted the Archbishop's request concerning the Episcopal See of Puerto Rico, by appointing the very Rev. James H. Blenk, S.M., of New Orleans, to fill it.

The family troubles of Baron Attokaron von Rosenbaum Reinsberg, formerly of Hungary, but now a decorative artist at 315 Willis Avenue, and his wife, who was once the beautiful Fraulein Melitta Hirschberg, daughter of Herr Wilhelm Hirschberg, an engineer officer in the German Army, were aired in Morrisania Police Court before Magistrate Wentworth yesterday morning.
John N. Golding has sold for Sheriff Thomas J. Dunn to Gen Egbert L. Viele the four-story dwelling 342 West Eighty-eighth Street.

The first meeting of the Psychic Study Society, organized by the Rev. Henry Frank, was held last evening in St. Stephen's Hall, 57 West Forty-sixth Street. It was a public meeting, and the hall was crowded to the doors. In the audience were clergymen, physicians, and other professional men. The speakers were the Rev. Henry Frank, who presided, and Dr. Paul Gibler, head of the Pasteur Institute in this city.

PARIS, April 20. -- The Figaro, continuing to-day its publication of testimony offered before the Court of Cassation in the Dreyfus revision inquiry, devotes twenty-four columns to some twenty depositions of minor officials, most of which are favorable to Dreyfus. It gives also a fac simile of the bordereau.

My appreciation of THE TIMES is so deep that I seem to be its champion even in my dreams, and not to miss even a trifling occasion to assert my loyalty to it. I dreamed the other night that I was about to take a tour to Europe, (I wish it were true!) and burdened with bags, umbrellas, overcoat, , I went to the ticket office of some ocean line.

Marcus Daly did fairly well for a poor silver mine owner at the Aqueduct track yesterday, and three of his horses won enough to keep the wolf from the door of the Daly cabin for a couple of days longer. Mr. Daly had starters in two other races, but they failed to win, though one of them Uam Var, managed to get third money in a race for maiden three-year-olds.

The inquest into the death of six men by the fall of a traveling derrick at the north end of the Willis Avenue Bridge over the Harlem River on April 11 was held yesterday in the office of the Coroner of the Bronx, at One Hundred and Sixty-sixth Street and Third Avenue, by Coroner Lynch. No one was found responsible for the accident.

"Dr. H. Hogelsberg's" speculative concern, the Investors' Guarantee and Trust Company, which had a small office at 1,209 Lord's Court Building, appears to have succumbed to adverse market conditions. The letting agent of the building said yesterday that, although the name of the company had been taken from the door of the room, the rent was paid to May 1.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., April 20. -- The Alhambra, with a seating capacity of 3,000 persons, was comfortably filled this evening by an audience assembled to hear Col. William Jennings Bryan. As each person passed in he was given a dodger reading:

BUFFALO, April 20. -- A granite boulder weighing thirty-five tons, quarried near Lewiston, and erected on the grounds of Fort Porter in honor of the officers and privates of the Thirteenth Regiment, United States Infantry, was unveiled last evening without any public ceremony.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 20. -- The transports Newport and Warren sailed to-day for Manila, via Honolulu. The Newport carries Light Batteries F of the Fourth and Fifth Artillery, 125 marines to reinforce Admiral Dewey's fleet, and some Red Cross nurses. The Warren carries eight batteries of the Sixth Artillery, 200 recruits and 50 men for the Hospital Corps.

ALBANY, April 20. -- The Democrats in the Senate succeeded to-day in "holding up" a bill purporting to have for its object "the promotion of commerce on the seaboard waters of this State," but which, they claim, constitutes a "grab" of valuable water-front rights on Staten and Long Islands.

With the appointment of new officials in Jersey City to-day by Mayor Hoos, all the boards on May 1 will pass under Democratic control, for although the Democrats elected Mayor Hoos two years ago, and reelected him on April 11, the only departments they yet govern are those controlled by the Finance Board and the Street and Water Board.
HARRISBURG, April 20. -- The session of the General Assembly of 1899 adjourned finally at noon to-day, after having been in session a little over three and a half months.

ALBANY, April 20. -- In the Senate to-day Mr. Donnelly moved to discharge the Cities Committee from further consideration of his bill to establish a municipal gas plant in New York City. The motion was lost after considerable debate, in the course of which the city's financial status was discussed, and Republican members expressed objection to Tammany having the disbursement of the large sum of money involved in the proposition.

One day, recalling Col. ASA BIRD GARDINER'S sympathy with citizens who were "called names they did not understand," we referred to him as a paranoiac. We have since been informed by a distinguished alienist that the description was inaccurate and referred to an entirely different set of symptoms from those manifested by the learned District Attorney.

WASHINGTON, April 20. -- Capt. Shoemaker of the Revenue Cutter Service has issued instructions to Lieut. John C. Cantwell, who is to command the revenue cutter Nunivak on her two or more years' cruise on the Yukon River, in Alaska. The object of the assignment is to assist the local authorities in enforcing the customs and navigation laws.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., April 20. -- At Woodstock, Bibb County, this morning, "Lem" Collins, a negro, shot and killed John Herring, a leading merchant, after having been badly wounded in a street duel with Mr. Herring and his brother, "Pink" Herring.

WASHINGTON, April 20. -- The monthly statement of the collections of internal revenue shows that during the month of March the total receipts were $22,738,447, an increase over March, 1898, of $9,491,340. The chief increases were as follows: Spirits, $1,577,600; tobacco, $1,552,627; fermented liquors and taxes on same, $2,189,779; oleomargarine, $51,815; miscellaneous, $4,078,868; special taxes, $40,649.

WASHINGTON, April 20. -- The Washington Gas Company has been absorbed by the street railway and lighting syndicate, headed by Mr. Frederick C. Stevens, which recently bought up all save one of the street railways of the city, and also the electric light companies. A deposit of $250,000 has been made with the Fourth Street National Bank of Philadelphia to secure a consummation of the sale.

SANTIAGO, April 20. -- The special committee appointed by the Board of Trade to inquire into the municipal tax situation made its report at a public meeting this afternoon at the San Carlos Club. According to the committee, Gen. Brooke's order abolishes all licenses and all taxes except 8 per cent. on the incomes from land.

George T. Davidson, a lawyer of 123 Liberty Street, and until recently Chairman of the House Committee of the Democratic Club, was arraigned in the Centre Street Police Court yesterday charged with larceny. The complainants, Haven Stout, bankers of 1 Nassau Street, allege that on Jan. 29 last, the defendant bought from them three bonds of the Southern Railway Company, giving them in payment a check on the Fifth Avenue Trust Company for $3,183.75.

The war between the Judges of the Court of General Sessions and the District Attorney, which was reopened on Wednesday, was carried on yesterday with unabated vigor. Judge Newburger, one of the principals in the combat, took his seat on the bench in Part IV, with smiling countenance, but Assistant District Attorney Osborne seemed worried.

CHICAGO, April 20. -- Negotiations for the purchase of the Chicago, Indianapolis and Louisville Railway, known as the "Monon" Line, have ended, and the property will in a few days change ownership. The road has been bought by a New York syndicate, of which the Vanderbilts are prominent members. Samuel Thomas of New York, the President of the road and the controlling stockholder, has sold his holdings to this syndicate, which will immediately assume control.

Every time it appeared within grasp it was killed by its enemies. Two years ago it appeared within reach, but Greater New York and the debt limit again killed it.

The cruiser Raleigh is closed to all visitors to-day and in place of the flotilla of ferryboats that surrounded her since Monday there will be coal-laden barges this morning to replenish the bunkers of the vessel, preparatory to her trip to Philadelphia, Wilmington, and the Norfolk Navy Yard, where she will go out of commission about June 1.

PHILADELPHIA, April 20. -- The case of ex-Senator Matthew S. Quay, accused of conspiracy in using State funds on deposit in the broken People's Bank of this city, was given to the jury at 3 o'clock this afternoon. At 10 o'clock to-night the jurors had not agreed upon a verdict, and they were locked up for the night.

I have been a curious reader of novels and reviews for some time past, and my wonder increases as to the mammoth output of fiction from the publishing houses within recent years. One of your New York publishers advertises one new novel every day. The question arises with me, as it has with another recently.

Major Gen. Charles F. Roe of the National Guard would not comment yesterday upon the results of the hearing before Gov. Roosevelt on Thursday on the report of the court of inquiry appointed to investigate the Seventy-first Regiment's conduct in the Santiago campaign. He took the position that he knew nothing of the report, as it had not been officially announced.

WASHINGTON, April 21. -- The report that another German war vessel has been ordered to Samoa was received with interest by officials here, though no particular importance was attached by them to the matter, the opinion being expressed that the German Government was simply making an addition to its naval representation in Samoa so as to offset that of Great Britain, which she had a right to do, because of her large commercial interests there.

We congratulate Gov. ROOSEVELT upon the unruffled composure with which he has borne the ignominious defeat of the State Constabulary bill. He favored the measure. In a public statement he pointed out its virtues. His influence, so far as he could properly use it, was employed to commend the bill to the favorable action of the Legislature.

The Federal Court at Wheeling, West Va., has again had recourse to the "blanket" injunction, a device which enables a single Judge to send a citizen accused of acts constituting crimes or misdemeanors to prison without any trial whatever. Judge Jackson committed five men to jail yesterday for thirty days and fined them $50 each in pursuance of this new-found method of applying Russian principles in the United States of America.

Equestrians and those who ride in carriages may use the Speedway. The matter was settled yesterday by the decision of Justice Gildersleeve in the Doll ease, but cyclists are still barred from riding upon the driveway.

Columbia, Harvard, Tale, and Princeton chess players met the best players of Oxford and Cambridge yesterday in a match by cable, and at the conclusion of the first part of the contest last night it looked as if the result would be a draw. There are six players on each side, who are paired for that number of games, the time limit being twenty moves an hour.

The sixty-sixth anniversary of Founders' Day of New York University was celebrated yesterday at the university grounds. The programme was in charge of the class of '99, of which John S. Burton is President. During the morning there were track and field games, and at 3 o'clock exercises were held in the gymnasium, which was decorated in violet, the college color.

The Committee on Law of the Board of Aldermen gave a hearing yesterday on Alderman Glick's ordinance requiring managers of theatres and other places of amusement to display signs reading "Standing Room Only" in the entrances of such houses for each section of the theatre in which there are no seats left unsold.

Price's estate would be against the heirs, and that after more than forty years of litigation the case was finally settled, except for the entering of the decree.

Court Detective Commiskey met him at Lexington Avenue and Sixty-fifth Street, and the old man asked for money. Commiskey took him to court.

ALBANY, April 21. -- Gov. Roosevelt expects to send a special message to the Legislature to-morrow, defining his position on the rapid transit matter. He is convinced that there is misunderstanding on the part of the Senators and members as to just what his attitude toward the pending measure is, and in order to make it clear he will communicate it to them directly.

Doubleday McClure Company have discovered a poet. Not a new one, for some of his verses date thirty years back, but one whose vagrant lines, scattered through newspapers and magazines, are at last by the consensus of critics' opinions simultaneously and spontaneously pronounced to be very good.

PANA, Ill., April 21. -- The mutilated body of Miss Jane Brunot, a well-to-do woman of advanced years, was found early to-day in a well on the Brunot farm, near here. All hour later the dead woman's sister-in-law, Mrs. Anna Brunot; the latter's nineteen-year-old son Henry, and Frederick Sibley were arrested, charged with the murder.

ALBANY, April 21. -- Senator Krum this morning presented to the Senate the resolution adopted by the Committee on Taxation and Retrenchment providing for the appointment of a joint committee for the investigation of the subject of taxation.

TRENTON, April 21. -- The National Cycling Association, organized several months ago to conduct bicycle races in opposition to the League of American Wheelmen, was incorporated here to-day under the laws of New Jersey. The company is capitalized at $2,000. The purpose of the association is to direct and govern cycling races.

The will of Baroness DE HIRSCH, according to the report from Vienna, devotes the whole estate to the maintenance or increase of the charities founded and maintained by the Baroness and her husband during their respective lifetimes. The estate is valued at $100,000,000.

NEWPORT, April 21. -- The yacht Carmita, the property of William K. Vanderbilt, Jr., went into commission this morning, while a heavy rain and hail storm was raging in the inner harbor. The owner stood on the poop deck, while Capt. "Tom" Shea hoisted the ensign to the peak. To-morrow the Carmita will make a short trial cruise. Mr. Vanderbilt will be his own skipper.

MANILA, April 21. -- A force of about 200 rebels attacked yesterday afternoon the outposts of the Washington Regiment, near Taguig, south of Pasig and Pateros. Two companies immediately engaged the enemy and advanced into the open in skirmish order. The rebels were checked and routed after two hours' fighting, leaving twelve men killed on the field and several wounded.

The most important matter developed was President McKinley's instructions to the court of inquiry, which were delivered to the members of the court on Feb. 20.

Dunn, Sheriff. The Sheriff had levied on a stock of ready-made clothing belonging to the plaintiff, and at the sale it brought only $4,948.35.

HAVANA, April 22. -- Governor General Brooke and Gen. Maximo Gomez, Gen. Castillo, and Gen. Alejandro Rodriguez held a two hours' conference at the Hotel Trocha to-day with reference to the Cuban army rolls and the amount to be paid to each soldier.

LONDON, April 22. -- As a result of the incident at the Epsom Spring meeting, which resulted in the disqualification of Tod Sloan, the American jockey, who was riding Ecu d'Or, the Stewards were careful to make it clear that they did not consider Sloan blameable. The course is extremely difficult to a stranger, and Ecu d'Or proved practically unmanageable.

MINEOLA, L.I., April 22. -- The signing of the bill changing the boundary line between the Borough of Queens and Nassau County takes the villages of Elmont, Foster's Meadow, Irma Park, Cedarhurst, Inwood, Lawrence, and Lawrence Beach wholly or in part from the city, and restores them to Nassau County. Representative Samuel T. Baird of Louisiana died at Washington yesterday afternoon. He was stricken with acute rheumatism just prior to the adjournment of the last session of Congress. He had a robust constitution and made a strong fight against the illness. In the last week or two the original trouble became complicated with endocarditis, a dangerous inflammation of the membraneous lining of the heart, and blood poisoning set in.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, April 12. -- The political crisis is over. In so far as there was any undercurrent of thought looking to the island's annexation to the United States as a solution, that also is a thing of the past. Never in the history of constitutional institutions, it is said, has victory been more complete and satisfying than that which Jamaica has achieved against Great Britain's attempt to annul its political Constitution.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 22. -- The tenth annual open handicap games of the Princeton Track Association were held at Osborne Field to-day. Representatives were present from all the leading universities and many of the preparatory schools. No records were broken, but Tewkesbury of the University of Pennsylvania, the intercollegiate champion sprinter, equaled the world's record in the 220-yard dash of 0:21 1-5, which was made by Wefers of the University of Georgetown in 1896.

VICTORIA, B.C., April 22. -- The steamer Athenian, which reached port with mail advices to the 5th, has news of an attack by Chinese on a party of Germans who were proceeding to I-Chau-Fu on March 29. NEWPORT, April 22. -- William K. Vanderbilt, Jr., and a party of friends made a short cruise on the Carmita to-day.

Garwood, who died in this city last January, leaving a large estate, parts of which he bequeathed to various persons, and part for the purpose of establishing a home for aged dependent women.

SASSARI, Island of Sardinia, April 22. -- The King and Queen of Italy arrived here yesterday evening on board the royal yacht Savoia, which passed between the British and Italian fleets. LONDON, April 23. -- All this week our money market has been in a sloppy state. The lenders on credit have competed against each other as to who should lend the cheapest, and an odd thing about it is that there has been no more money to lend. Measured by the bank returns the market is just 62,000 better off this week than it was a week ago.

"A woman in black," as all agree, and carrying "a very pretty little girl," was seen to rush distractedly from the west Broadway sidewalk out upon the car tracks.

Most of them express the opinion that Germany will treat the incident with "dignified silence."

Bombay sent moderate orders, though Calcutta and the other Indian market were dull and inactive, partly owing to the fears arising from the plague.

A fire which occurred early yesterday morning in a Brooklyn tenement gave a plucky policeman a chance to prove himself a hero for the third time in his life. A dying man passed his last hours in the scenes of excitement which attend a fire in the night. He was rescued from the flames to die from natural causes an hour later.

WASHINGTON, April 24. -- The German Government has entered a formal protest against the language used by Capt. Coghlan of the Raleigh at the Union League Club banquet in New York last Friday night. The protest was lodged with Secretary Hay through the German Ambassador, Herr von Holleben.

PHILADELPHIA, April 24. -- The climax in the counterfeiting conspiracy which was brought to light here last week was reached to-day, when ex-United States District Attorney Ellery P. Ingham of this city and Deputy Internal Revenue Collector Samuel B. Downey of Lancaster were arrested by Secret Service officers on the charge of aiding the chief counterfeiters in their efforts to flood the country with bogus Treasury notes and internal revenue tobacco stamps.

BENNINGTON, Vt., April 24. -- E.D. Bennett, Superintendent of the Bennington and Rutland Railroad, was appointed receiver of the Bennington and Worcester Railroad to-day. This line is only nine miles long, and extends from Bennington to Glastonbury.

HAVANA, April 24. -- There have been twenty deaths from typhoid fever among the members of the Eighth United States Cavalry, stationed at the City of Puerto Principe, and 103 cases, all told, are reported. The persistence of the disease cannot be explained.
ALBANY, April 24. -- The bill presented by the Fallows committee, which investigated the Surrogates' office in New York, was defeated by the Senate in Committee of the Whole to-night.

COLUMBUS, Neb., April 24. -- The death of Lieut. Lester E. Sisson of the First Nebraska, at Manila, and the finding of his sweetheart's photograph near his heart, where the fatal bullet entered, is the final chapter in a romance whose introduction was written in this village several years ago.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, April 24. -- In the course of an address last night before the Ohio Society of the Sons of the Revolution, the Rev. Dr. Lyman Abbott referred to the Mazet inquiry. He quoted Mr. Croker as acknowledging that he was a politician for what there was in it for him.

The New Yorks were beaten again yesterday, the Baltimores winning the final game of the present series at the Polo Grounds by a score of 6 to 0. The shut-out was due to McGinnity, one of the Baltimores' young pitchers. He had the locals guessing throughout, using a slow drop curve and a "raised ball."

CHICAGO, April 24. -- An attack may be made upon the new revenue law by Chicago business men, who are alarmed over the fact that their financial condition is to become public property through the office of the Board of County Assessors.

The Rev. William A. Stark, pastor of the German Methodist Episcopal Church of Hoboken; Harold Haroldsen, who keeps a saloon at 60 Garden Street; his wife; Meta Tietjen, the barmaid, and Catherine Brennan, a servant, were summoned before Recorder Stanton yesterday on complaint off Alvin Parey of Rahway, N.J., to tell what they knew of Parey's marriage to Miss Tietjen.

ALBANY, April 24. -- Henry Miller presented "Hamlet" at the Empire Theatre to-night before a large audience. Despite the fact that Mr. Miller received a telegram prior to the rise of the curtain announcing the death of his father, his work in the role of "the melancholy Dane" resulted in his receiving many encores. This was Mr. Miller's first appearance in tragedy.

BERLIN, April 24. -- It is announced in a semi-official note to-day that the United States Secretary of State, Col. John Hay, has expressed to the German Ambassador at Washington, Dr. von Holleben, his strong disapproval of the "conduct of Capt. Joseph B. Coghlan" of the United States cruiser Raleigh.

CHICAGO, April 24. -- Another gigantic trust, to include all the large farm machinery factories of the United States, is in process of formation. Articles of incorporation under the laws of New Jersey are expected to be filed within a few days. The capital is to be $50,000,000, of which $15,000,000 has already been subscribed.

Gov. Roosevelt has informed the Merchants' Association's committee in charge of the dinner to Senator Frye to-morrow evening, in the Waldorf-Astoria, that he will preside. Senator Frye will arrive in the city with his family to-day and stay at the Waldorf-Astoria, where quarters have been provided for him.

The Gerlach Hotel, 49 to 55 West Twenty-seventh Street, will close its doors on Thursday. The property was sold at auction yesterday, as the result of a foreclosure suit, in which the Trustees of the Peabody Trust Fund were the plaintiffs. J. Pierpont Morgan, representing the Trust Fund, bid in the property on a single bid of $400, 000, which was $13,000 less than the amount due on judgment.

The first Supreme Court decision in regard to the validity of the fire insurance brokerage contracts with the insuring public, which have been the occasion of numerous suits in the lower courts, has just been rendered in the case of Jacob Romberg and Edwin Romberg contract insurance brokers, against William H. Konther.

Prominent Directors of the Society for the Prevention of Crime, of which the Rev. Dr. Charles H. Parkhurst is President, emphatically declared yesterday that there was no split, either present or prospective, in the ranks of their organization, because of difference of opinion on the Mazet investigating committe or for any other reason.

WASHINGTON, April 24. -- Attorney General Griggs, in speaking to-day of the negro lynching near Newnan, Ga., yesterday, said that the case had no Federal aspect, and therefore the Government would take no action whatever in regard to it.

George Gordon Battle of the firm of Weeks Battle, counsel for Roland B. Molineux, appeared before Justice Bookstaver, in Part II, of the Supreme Court, yesterday, and applied for a writ of habeas corpus for the prisoner, the indictment against whom for the murder of Mrs. Kate J. Adams was set aside by Justice Williams last week.

SOUTHOLD, L.I., April 24. -- The Rev. Bertram L. Boivin, pastor of the Universalist Church of this place, sent in his resignation this evening. He resigns, much to the regret of the congregation, to leave the ministry and become the private secretary of a wealthy widow whose home is at Erie, Penn.

The boarding masters and shipping masters who have been carrying on a warfare with the ship owners in their efforts to evade the provisions of the new shipping law designed to protect sailors against crimping, and who have been forced into the incongruous position of demanding higher wages for their former victims -- these gentlemen were happy yesterday.

ALBANY, April 24. -- The Rapid Transit Commissioners have not yet indicated to Senator Stranahan whether they will consent to their bill being changed in accordance with Gov. Roosevelt's suggestions, but from the fact that they notified him tonight that they would send a representative here to-morrow it is assumed that they are at least considering the acceptance of some amendments.
WASHINGTON, April 24. -- The North Atlantic Squadron sailed to-day from St. Pierre for San Juan de Puerto Rico.

When Major Henry Adams of the Engineer Corps proceeded yesterday to open bids for the work of dredging the East Channel at the entrance to this harbor, he was much surprised to discover that there was but one bid. He sent to the clerks to learn if some mistake had not been made, but only one bid had arrived in response to the advertising that has been continued for a month.

WASHINGTON, April 24. -- Information received at the War Department indicates that Gen. Otis is about to execute another important movement, the initial features of which are shown by to-day's press advices from Manila. The objective point is the insurgent town of Calumpit, lying about eight miles northwest of Malolos.

TRENTON, April 25. -- It was discovered in the Court of Chancery to-day that through mistaking a legal separation for a divorce much complication had resulted. One of the results is that Mrs. Albert Smith, who for nineteen years had supposed herself the wife of James S. Graham of Washington, D.C., ascertains that under the law she is not.

ALBANY, April 25. -- In vetoing a bill introduced by Assemblyman McEwan of Albany, Gov. Roosevelt to-day administered what is regarded as a severe rebuke to William Barnes, Jr., Chairman of the Republican State Executive Committee, and the leader of the local Republican organization.

ALBANY, April 25. -- The Senate to-day by an overwhelming vote amended the Rapid Transit bill in accordance with Gov. Roosevelt's wishes. Only seven Senators rallied to the bill as the commission wanted it, while thirty-seven voted to accept the Governor's amendments.

Sage, who will retire from the Wardenship of the State Prison at Sing Sing on May 1, will receive a post of importance in the Department of Correction in this city if the plans of Commissioner Lantry are carried out. It can be stated positively that overtures have been made to Mr. Sage, but as yet he has given no definite reply, and Mr. Lantry declines to discuss the matter at present.

ALBANY, April 25. -- Senator Sullivan's bill reducing the price of gas in the boroughs of Manhattan and the Bronx to 90 cents per 1,000 cubic feet passed the Senate to-day without a word of discussion and with but four negative votes. The vote on the final passage was 32 to 4, those in the negative being Senators Ambler, Armstrong, Ellsworth, and McCarren.

MANILA, April 25. -- Gen. MacArthur's division fought its way to the Filipino trenches before Calumpit to-day, advancing four miles, mostly through woods and jungle, and crossing the Bagbag River.

The trial of Theodore B. Willis and William E. Philips was continued yesterday in the Supreme Court, Brooklyn. The first witness for the prosecution was Daniel Doody, the contractor who, it is alleged, paid the City Works ring, through Philips, percentages on the contracts awarded to him.

The Tammany members of the Municipal Council made another attempt yesterday to pass several pending bond issues, but the effort failed, because of the opposition of the members from Brooklyn and Queens. The improvements which are contingent upon these issues will thus be set back for an indefinite period.

Noel Kentish, an artist of 27 Morningside Avenue, was arrested and taken to the West Thirtieth Street Station from Fifth Avenue and Twenty-third Street yesterday afternoon on a charge of using improper language in the presence of women. Miss Camille Birnbaum of 15 East Eleventh Street was the complainant.

Richard Croker will sail for England at 10 o'clock this morning on the American Line steamship New York. He will be accompanied on the trip by his sister, Mrs. Samuel E. Warren, and Miss Warren, his niece. Speaker Thomas B. Reed will sail on the same ship, and the Tammany leader looks forward to his companionship on the voyage with much pleasure.

NEWPORT, April 25. -- The will of Robert S. Hone, which was offered for probate to-day, is a brief one for so large an estate. The residence on Beach Street and Greenough Place, with its contents, is bequeathed to Annie Russell Hone in consideration of her having advanced $10,000 to the testator and for other considerations.

ALBANY, April 25. -- Gov. Roosevelt does not expect any further attempts at police legislation this session. The two Rochester Senators are standing firm in their opposition to the so-called State Constabulary bill, and the futility of undertaking any new project in that line so near adjournment seems to be recognized by all the Republican leaders.

That it will be passed there is small doubt. The see-saw process that has been predicted will then be on, since it is deemed unlikely that the Senate will accept the Assembly substitute for the Ford bill.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 25. -- Addison Johnson, Warden designate of Sing Sing Prison, said to-day, when questioned that it was too early to consider the question of appointments. Roosevelt on Wednesday last having been addressed to THE NEW YORK TIMES and to the Civil Service Reform Association, Secretary George McAneny of the association has prepared an analysis of the distinctive features of the act and a statement of its practical effect.

Hostilities between the District Attorney's office and the Judges of the Court of General Sessions have temporarily ceased. A fresh casus belli made its appearance in Judge Newburger's court yesterday, but under such circumstances that the Judge only smiled. He opened court with a number of the despised excise cases on his calendar.

Fleer Co., manufacturers of chewing gum, at 2,343 and 2,245 Callowhill Street to-day, two men were killed, three persons seriously injured, and over a score of others were more or less injured by flying dbris.
