Clinging astride a truck pole, Charles C. Waters, thirty-two years old, of 225 Third Street, Jersey City, had a wild ride through Centre Street behind a team of runaway horses yesterday afternoon. Waters, the driver, and John Schaeffer, his helper, were on the truck, owned by an express company, when the horse got beyond Waters's control at Duane and Centre Streets.

Casual readers of newspapers may have passed over the recent announcement of a lawsuit by Mr. RUDYARD KIPLING against certain American "pirates" of publishers without much notice. Therein the casual readers have been wrong. Mr. KIPLING is to-day one of the heroes of the "Anglo-Saxon" world.

PITTSBURG, April 26. -- The Carnegie Steel Company, Limited, has commenced the erection in West Homestead of an extensive plant for the manufacture of heavy car axles to be in operation within six months. It will be the largest forge of its class in existence and will have a capacity of from eighty to one hundred thousand tons of product annually.
Consolidation of a number of Southern car builders under the name of the Southern Car and Foundry Company.

MANILA, April 26. -- Aguinaldo's army to-day is defending Calumpit energetically, which is said to indicate that the rebels are finally making that place their last ditch, or stand, which the Americans expected them to do at Malolos. For the first time the Filipinos are employing artillery. They brought two guns into action in the trenches to-day before Calumpit, firing modern shrapnel, which burst over the heads of Gen. Wheaton's men without effect.

Mrs. Antonio de Navarro, who is best known to Americans as "Mary Anderson, the actress," is in New York City. She arrived on the steamship Majestic yesterday, accompanied by her husband. They had traveled from London under the names of "Mr. and Mrs. A.I. Hope," which they had assumed for the voyage.

LONDON, April 26. -- At a meeting to-day of the Cuba Submarine Telegraph Company, the Chairman announced that the affairs of the organization were in a satisfactory condition. The United States Government, he added, was examining the company's concessions from Spain and the British Foreign Office was supporting the company's claims.

LONDON, April 26. -- At the second day's racing of the Newmarket first Spring meeting to-day Sir R. Waldie Griffith's bay filly Styria, ridden by "Tod" Sloan, won the Wilbraham Plate. This race is of 200 sovereigns, by subscription of 5 sovereigns each, and 5 sovereigns more for starters, for two-year-olds.

CHICAGO, April 26. -- Ching Ling Foo, the Chinese conjurer, and his troupe were discharged to-day from the custody of the United States authorities by United States District Judge Kohlsaat, who thereby determined an important point in the attitude of the United States Government toward Chinese actors and public performers. Because he is an actor and not a laborer, it is decided that the alien labor law does not apply to the conjurer.

Brig. Gen. Fred D. Grant, in the best of health and spirits and tanned by the heat of a tropical sun, arrived last evening from San Juan, Puerto Rico, on the army transport McPherson, on his way to join the fighting forces in the Philippines, eager and anxious for active service.

One afternoon toward the end of December, 1892, a small group of persons assembled in the City Hall to see the rapid-transit franchise sold. The Commissioners appointed under the act of 1891 had prepared plans, obtained consents, and were about to sell at public auction the franchise to build the road and to operate it for 999 years.
PHILADELPHIA, April 20. -- The Raleigh, which is here to participate in the ceremonies attendant on the unveiling of the Grant Monument, has been warmly welcomed to the city.

Depuy Surrogate George L. Glasser of Queens County and ex-Supervisor Joseph Bermel of the town of Newtown, by whom Glasser was employed as counsel for the town, were arraigned yesterday before Justice Hirschberg in the Supreme Court, in Long Island City, on indictments found against them by the Queens County Grand Jury on the previous evening.

ALBANY, April 26. -- By the adoption of resolution suggested in a preliminary report made to the Assembly to-day by the Mazet investigating committee, the scope of the inquiry is extended so as to include county officers and county departments, and the committee is empowered to continue its sessions during the legislative vacation.

CHICAGO, April 26. -- Officers of the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railroad have decided to put on a line of transpacific steamers to ply between San Francisco and the Orient. The company is now planning to open its new line into the metropolis of the Pacific Coast on July 1, and it is in connection with this road that the new boat line is to be inaugurated.

BIRMINGHAM, England, April 26. -- The enormous rise in the price of copper is playing havoc with the leading industries in the Midlands. At Kynoch's hundreds of men have been discharged since the rise in the price of the metal began, and now, instead of 4,000 men, only 2,000 are at work there.

The annual conference of the New Jersey African Methodist Episcopal Church began in Zion Methodist Church, Jersey City, last night. It will continue six days. Bishop Alexander Walters presided. In his opening address he made an extended reference to the lynching of Sam Hose and Liga Strickland, the colored minister, in Georgia.

LONDON, April 26. -- Edward Rose's play "In Days of Old," produced by George Alexander at St. James's Theatre to-night, delighted a distinguished audience by its picturesqueness, though whether the plot is sufficiently well knit and the motives of sufficient human interest to insure a long run remains to be seen.

WASHINGTON. To profess one's self disappointed with Washington in this first week of April, 1899, would be like complaining of the gauntness of a rosebush in December. What would you have? It is not the season, either politically or atmospherically. Congress is gone and Spring has not come. In the city of Jeafy avenues there is not a leaf to be seen, and, except the irrepressible crocus, not a flower.
PARIS, April 26. -- The advocates and opponents of Dreyfus revision held rival meetings in Paris this evening, and fights occurred afterward in the streets. Several persons were injured.

ALBANY, April 26. -- Lieut. Col. Smith of the Seventy-first Regiment is not to be court-martialed for his conduct in the battle of San Juan, but the question of whether or not he shall remain in the National Guard is to be submitted to a special military court to be convened for that purpose.

We are sorry and disappointed that the Mazet Committee let Mr. CROKER get away to England without finding out a great deal more about the sources of his income and the actual relation of his private business, including the business of his sons, to the public business of the city.

WASHINGTON, April 26. -- The board convened by a special order to examine into and report upon the responsibility for the loss of 300,000 pounds of refrigerated beef sent to Puerto Rico last Summer has submitted its report and findings. PITTSBURG, April 26. -- Quay leaders here are reported to have said to-day that they had just completed a poll of the United States Senate, and that Mr. Quay had sixty-seven Senators pledged to seat him.

DETROIT, Mich., April 26. -- In a decision handed down late to-day the State Supreme Court declared invalid the main principle of the Pingree-Atkinson equal taxation bill, which was passed by the present session of the Legislature.

ST. LOUIS, April 26. -- The German newspaper publishers of Missouri held a meeting here to-day for the purpose of defining their position regarding what they call "the new policy of imperialism and militarism." Dr. Emile Pretorius, editor of the Wrestliche Post, presided. After a lengthy discussion the following resolutions were unanimously adopted.

DOVER, Del., April 26. -- Attorney General White to-day presented to the Kent County Grand Jury information in regard to the attempted bribery of legislators and the tampering with bills before the late Legislature. Subsequently the Grand Jury returned a true bill against Representative Mark L. Davis, and two true bills against E.D.C. Hegeman, Assistant Clerk of the Senate.

At a meeting of the Central Board of Education held yesterday afternoon a communication from Corporation Counsel Whalen was read regarding the resolution recently passed by the board asking him to stop all proceedings in the acquisition of sites in the Boroughs of Manhattan and the Bronx, in order that the lands now available in these boroughs may be devoted to the purpose of erecting new schools.

ALBANY, April 26. -- A blow was dealt at the growing practice of exempting property from taxation by special acts through the adoption by the Senate to-day of the concurrent resolution, already approved by the Assembly, for an amendment to the Constitution prohibiting such exemptions.

On Tuesday evening Mr. CORNELIUS N. BLISS'S fellow-partisans of the Republican Club paid to him the characteristic New York tribute of a dinner in recognition of his services in the National Government, from an important place in which he recently retired. Senator DEPEW was the spokesman for the club, and he announced at the outset that they honored Mr. BLISS as "the business man in politics, not the man in politics for business."

PROVIDENCE, April 26. -- At the session of the General Assembly this morning the Senate Committee on Judiciary presented its report on the petition for the repeal of the charter of the American Investors' Company, a corporation chartered under the laws of Rhode Island, but with a main office in New York City and branch offices in Boston, Springfield, Rochester and other cities.

Hugh Bonner the greatest fire fighter of modern times, has resigned his post of Chief of the Fire Department of the Greater New York to take effect on May 1, and co-incident with his retirement there will be established in this city a school of fire extinguishment of which Mr. Bonner will be the head.

The game between the Brooklyn and Baltimore baseball nines at Washington Park yesterday was long drawn out, and if it had not been for several brilliant bits of fielding, there would have been little for the 3,800 spectators to enthuse over. The Brooklyns won the game, but it was not an easy victory.
CANON CITY, Col., April 26. -- The discovery has been made that some very successful counterfeiters have been operating in the State Penitentiary here.

A perfect Spring day at the Aqueduct race track yesterday put winners and losers alike in such good humor that they even excused the long delays at the post, usually so thoroughly exasperating. The crowd in attendance, though the card promised nothing of particular merit in the way of sport, was a thousand or so above the average, and the betting was exceptionally heavy.

OTTAWA, Ontario, April 26. -- Reports are being received at Ottawa from the Klondike and other parts of the Yukon suggesting that it would be advisable to leave the military contingent undisturbed. It was suggested at one time that about one-third of the force would be left in the Yukon and the remainder recalled.

It is announced from Washington that Congressman GROSVENOR of Ohio is ambitious to "rattle around" in the place of Speaker REED in order that he may reverse the policy of that gentleman and pick out a committee that will recommend the House to repeal the civil service law. This is probably true, and it affords a fair measure of the mental and political capacity of Mr. GROSVENOR.

Mrs. Clark is also the buyer of the four lots at the northwest corner of Broadway and Ninetieth Street, the sale of which was recently reported.

Senator Ford's bill providing that precepts and warrants in summary proceedings issued by or out of the Municipal Court of New York City shall be served and executed by the district marshals was defeated in the assembly yesterday.

ALBANY, April 26. -- Only the signatures of the Governor and of the Mayor of New York City are now needed to make the amended Rapid Transit bill a law. It glided through both houses to-day with practically no opposition, and to-night the leaders of the movement against perpetual franchises are congratulating themselves on their victory.

James Pyle Sons closed their factories at 436 Greenwich Street all day yesterday on account of the funeral of their oldest employe, P.L. Cunningham. Headed by members of the firm, the workers in the factories and other employes went in a body to South Norwalk, Conn., to attend the services, and left notices posted on all entrances to the factories telling of Mr. Cunningham's death.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., April 26. -- A special to The Post Dispatch from Malden, a small village in Southeastern Missouri, says Mrs. James Tettaton, widow of Wash Tettaton, a prominent man of that section, and her four children were murdered last night. The bodies were partially burned in their home, which was set on fire by the murderer.

It was a great work, and as a literary performance it was an immense "tour de force."
NEWPORT, R.I., April 27. -- It was with the deepest feeling of regret that news of the death of Robert Goelet was received here to-night, first by a dispatch to Elbridge T. Gerry.
ALBANY, April 27. -- The Senate to-day confirmed the nomination of William Church Osborn to be State Commissioner in Lunacy, after considerable debate, by a vote of 40 to 7.

NEWPORT, April 27. -- Mrs. Walter L. Kane to-day sold a lot containing about 87,000 square feet of land, together with buildings thereon, situated on the northerly side of First and Second Beach Avenues, Middletown, to Mr. Julien T. Davies of New York. This land adjoins Mr. Davies's estate, Pine Croft, on the east.

LACONIA, N.H., April 27. -- The Lake Village Savings Bank of Lakeport has temporarily suspended payment. The bank suspended payment for a time when the Belknap Savings Bank failed about two years ago, but after a while began paying small amounts to its depositors. It is understood that withdrawals have been steady from that time until a suspension of payment again became necessary.

Men of any race can work in a climate where they can fight. Our soldiers from Kansas, the Dakotas, Nebraska, Minnesota, Iowa, and Montana have been in and about Manila some of them the better part of a year. For more than three months they have been constantly engaged in fighting the Filipinos.

MUSCATINE, Iowa, April 27. -- A heavy cloudburst, accompanied by severe thunder and lightning, visited the city to-day, damaging terraces and lower streets and temporarily suspending street railway traffic.

PHILADELPHIA, April 27. -- Ex-United States District Attorney Ellery P. Ingham and Harvey K. Newitt, who was Ingham's assistant, were arraigned before United States Commissioner Edmunds to-day on the charge of attempting to bribe Secret Service Operative William J. McManus in connection with the Jacobs-Kendig-Taylor-Bredell revenue-stamp-counterfeiting conspiracy. The hearing took place in the United States Circuit Court room.

It has a management that represents, all told, fully $10,000,000,000 of capital, and in that management are some of the leading financiers of the world.

Although yesterday was the regular meeting day of the Rapid Transit Commission no meeting was held. The members did not feel that there was business of sufficient importance to call them together. At the meeting on next Thursday it is probable that Alexander E. Orr, the President of the board, will retire from that office.

The case of Capt. COGHLAN was dealt with by the Navy Department in a very proper way. When a naval officer, at a club dinner which is necessarily somewhat in the nature of a public function, desires to relieve his mind about the conduct of the representatives of a nation with which we are on friendly terms, he ought not to assume that his remarks will be treated as strictly private and confidential.

It was Britishers' night at Carnegie Hall last evening, the occasion being the fifteenth annual dinner of Gordon Lodge, No. 173, of the Order of the Sons of St. George. Fully 200 members attended the banquet. John T. Canterbury, the toastmaster, introduced as the first speaker the Rev. Dr. S.P. Cadman, who responded to the toast, "The President and the Queen."

ALBANY, April 27. -- Gov. Roosevelt today discovered what he considered a piece of "crookedness" in the bill amending the primary election law, which has passed both houses and reached him yesterday, and he promptly had it sent back to have the obnoxious provisions taken out.

The Woman's Conference of the Society for Ethical Culture held its annual breakfast yesterday at the Hotel Savoy. Last year at this time the conference was raising money for war relief expenses, and it denied itself all luxuries, and, in consequence, the soldiers and their families were relieved to the extent of over $2,000 in money, in addition to other things.

Coghlan has unfortunately done, but it nevertheless taught a lesson to old sailors not to wade ashore out of their own element.

Dr. Michael B. Feeney, Chief Sanitary Inspector of the Health Department, yesterday submitted to President Murphy a report show the result of the investigation by engineers of the Manhattan Railway Company's structure on Greenwich Street, between the Battery and Fourteenth Street. In a letted accompanying the report, Dr. Feeney recommends that, pending repairs, "the use of this section of the road be discontinued if on further inspection it should be found necessary."

WASHINGTON, April 27. -- Commissioner Wilson of the Internal Revenue Bureau has sent a letter of instruction to Collectors of Internal Revenue regarding the disposition of cigars made and stamped by the alleged Lancaster (Penn.) counterfeiters. The Commissioner says that fives are the only denominations known to have been counterfeited.

The longer the Coghlan case was considered the less favorably has the Navy Department regarded it.

Yesterday, with its cool breezes but warm sun, was much more enjoyable than Wednesday, which was too warm for much movement or gayety. The avenue and the Park drives were crowded all the afternoon with handsome traps of all kinds, and it seemed as if all the gay world were out enjoying the first touch of returning Summer and the beauty of the Park, which is rapidly assuming its Spring garb.
BALTIMORE, April 27. -- At the meeting of the Johns Hopkins Scientific Associatioa to-day Prof. Henry A. Rowland gave a practical exhibition of the workings of his new multiplex telegraph printer.

ATLANTA, April 27. -- The proceedings of the ninth triennial International Sunday School convention to-day were enlivened by a heated discussion over the placing of negroes on one of the committees. The matter was amicably adjusted after considerable talk, but rumors which spread over the city regarding the trouble resulted in the Police Department ending a man to the opera house to investigate.

WASHINGTON, April 27. -- The Secretary of State and the Attorney General have been giving close attention to claims that the United States Government should recognize the Spanish cable concessions in the Philippines, and should continue to pay the subsidies paid by the Spanish Government while the Philippines were under Spanish sovereignty.

News reached this city yesterday of the death in Naples of Robert Goelet, real estate owner, financier, and society leader. Mr. Goelet's legal representative here, Mr. George De Witt, received information that death was caused by heart failure. This intelligence was a startling surprise to Mr. Goelet's New York friends, who, when they saw him in this city not long ago, formed the opinion that he was in excellent health.

MANILA, April 27. -- Gen. MacArthur's division crossed the Rio Grande to-day and advanced on Apalit, completely routing the flower of the rebel army. Most of the rebels fled to Apalit Station, where two trains were waiting them. They left hurriedly, presumably or San Fernando. ALBANY, April 27. -- In the midst of excitement unparalleled during the present session, the Republican leaders at 8 o'clock to-night abruptly adjourned the Assembly to prevent it running away from them and passing the Ford Franchise Tax hill.

WASHINGTON, April 27. -- Representative Sherman of New York, who was here this morning for a few hours and who talked briefly with friends as he went about some department business, candidly declared himself a candidate for Speaker, but would not enter into details to justify the confidence be expresses in his success in the contest.

District Attorney Steele yesterday afternoon closed the People's side of the case of ex-City Works Commissioner Theodore B. Willis and ex-Police Commissioner William E. Philips of Brooklyn, on trial in the Supreme Court, Brooklyn. Col. Albert E. Lamb will open the case of the defense this morning.

PARIS, April 27. -- A great sensation has followed the publication by the Figaro of the supplemental deposition made before the United Chambers of the Court of Cassation by M. Paleologue, one of the permanent officials of the Foreign Office, whose evidence establishes a new forgery. The Soir, an anti-Drefusite organ, violently attacks the Minister for Foreign Affairs, M. Delcasse, under whose orders M. Paleologue's second deposition was made.

ALBANY, April 27. -- Both houses of the Legislature to-day passed over Mayor Van Wyck's veto the bill providing for the appointment of a Commissioner of Records by the District Attorney of Kings County. In the course of the debate in the Senate Mr. Brackett made an attack upon Lieut. Gov. Woodruff in reference to that official's advocacy of the measure.

WASHINGTON, April 27. -- Information has been received at the War Department that the present customs laws of Puerto Rico are to be tested in the courts. It is intended to ship a cargo of goods from New York to Puerto Rico and refuse the payment of the tariffs established by the Government.

AUCKLAND, N.Z., April 27. -- Dispatches from Apia, Samoa, dated April 18, report that the British third-class cruiser Porpoise is still engaged in punitive cruises, frequently sending parties ashore to attack the Mataafans. The friendly natives under the command of Lieut. R.A. Gaunt of the Porpoise were attacked on April 12 from the French Mission Station at Falita.

Admiral Dewey's victory in Manila Bay will be commemorated on Monday next, May 1, the anniversary of the great naval battle. Mayor Van Wyck has been requested to order the display of the Municipal, State, and National flags on all city buildings, and there will be patriotic exercises in the public schools.

WASHINGTON, April 27. -- Commissioner Wilson of the Internal Revenue Bureau has decided that baseball games by college and amateur or local clubs for which an admission fee is charged are not subject to the special tax under the act of June 13, 1898.

HAVANA, April 22. -- The most startling feature of West Indian Spanish maladministration was the Custom House. The courts afforded fine dividends. Internal taxes were well thought of by official thieves. The army pay chest was a notably rich opportunity for a couple of years. But the richest vein in all Cuba, which automatically yielded a million and a half a month, was the Custom House at Havana.

LONDON, April 27. -- At the third day's racing of the Newmarket First Spring Meeting to-day Mr. J.M. Hanbury's four-year-old brown filly Lowland Beauty, by Allowa-Comely, won the Thursday Welter Handicap Plate. "Tod" Sloan rode Mr. C.F. Dwyer's Miss Nellie filly, but was unplaced.

WASHINGTON, April 27. -- Gen. Miles's visit to the White House yesterday and his talk with the President have caused a good deal of conjecture here, and reports have been heard of the purpose of the visit, some of which are contradictory.

WASHINGTON, April 27. -- Major Francis S. Dodge, Paymaster, has been ordered to proceed from New York to Havana with the necessary funds for the payment of the troops in the Division of Cuba. The Commanding General of the Department of the East will furnish a suitable escort for the funds.

The Brooklyns won their third straight game from the Baltimores at Washington Park yesterday by superior all-around play. The 3,500 spectators saw a much better game than was played on Wednesday. The Baltimores played a good fielding game, but were outclassed. There was not much hitting, but what little there was, particularly that of the home team, was timely.

Small fields of horses in all the races at the Aqueduct track yesterday made a short shrift of the racing and enabled the crowd to get home to dinner at an earlier hour than on any day since the meeting opened. The best race of the day was the opening dash of about seven furlongs, in which there were but three runners.

There is uncommon stir in the book trade just now. The usual falling off in the call for literature came, as in former years, immediately after the Christmas holidays, But it did not last, and now the business being done by the retail booksellers is over 30 per cent., in most cases, to what it was at this period a year ago.

WASHINGTON, April 28. -- "Now that they have sent out the white flag." said Senator Hawley at the War Department this afternoon, "we ought to be very cautious in our dealing with the Filipinos." That sentiment was the common one in both the War and Navy Departments, and it served to check great rejoicing over the prospect of a settlement with the natives through Aguinaldo.

Daniel Frohman yesterday completed an arrangement with Charles Frohman by which the Lyceum manager leases to his brother Charles the Lyceum Theatre. By this means certain of the theatrical interests of both brothers are united. Daniel Frohman will be enabled to extend his productions beyond his present theatre to the Lyric, Garden, and Garrick theatres in conjunction with Charles Frohman.

Barrows.

KIRKSVILLE, Mo., April 28. -- As a result of the tornado that swept through the eastern portion of this city last evening, demolishing half of the residences and other buildings, nearly fifty bodies and seventy injured persons have been recovered from the ruins. More than a dozen of the injured will die.

ALBANY, April 28. -- Superintendent of Elections Rodenbough is legislated out of office and a vast amount of new patronage provided for the local Republican and Democratic machines by the bill "to establish a separate Department of Elections in the City of New York," which passed the Assembly in the closing hours to-day.

WASHINGTON, April 28. -- Gen. Greely, announces that the United States transport Hooker will be placed under the orders of Major Joseph E. Maxfield on Saturday. She will sail on Monday carrying with her Major Maxfield, Lieut. Clarke, and twenty-five men of the regular Signal Corps to replace Signal Corps volunteers in the Philippines.

President McKinley, accompanied by Mrs. McKinley and a party of friends, including Secretary of the Navy Long and Mrs. Long and Secretary of the Treasury Gage, arrived in the city yesterday afternoon from Philadelphia, where the President officiated at the ceremonies attending the unveiling of the Grant Monument. The party went to the Hotel Manhattan.

LONDON, April 28. -- Ernest Vizetelly, who has hitherto shown that he is well-informed on the Dreyfus affair, has an article in The Westminster Gazette to-day, in the course of which he states that the German Government has addressed an expostulatory note to the French Government regarding the case.
WASHINGTON, April 28. -- The second annual congress of the Women's Whist League closed to-night.

All insist that the United States cannot treat with the rebel government.

WASHINGTON, April 28. -- The politicians are showing diligence in winding up the fight for the Speakership early in the year. An effort to bring about a conference of Illinois men, with the view of obtaining concert of action, has been discouraged, and the suggestion has been made here that the sifting process shall go on until the contest is narrowed down to two candidates, one from the East and one from the West.

Luna's brigade came upon the field from Macabeles on the double quick, the two regiments preserving a perfect formation.

The eight-hour parade and demonstration of organized labor this evening promises to be the largest of many years. There will be four divisions in the parade. The first division will include the building trades unions, the second the tobacco workers, the third the brewers and food producers, and the fourth the clothing workers and miscellaneous trades.

ATLANTIC CITY, April 28. -- The Atlantic City Horse Show Association was organized last night at the Hotel Windsor with a capital of $15,000. The first show will be given on July 13, 14, and 15, at the Inlet Park baseball grounds. The cost of the prizes will aggregate $6,000.

The volume which now comes fresh from the pen of Capt. Webster will therefore greatly aid in establishing geographical locality for New Guinea, but that alone only a part of its mission.

In a March number of THE TIMES'S SATURDAY REVIEW a contributor solicits ideas respecting the supposed limit of an ordinary man's vocabulary. He puts it at 500 words. It is much lower in a great many instances, which is a regrettable fact. The man of real culture finds that his vocabulary increases with the depth and fervor of his investigations and study.

Holdridge Ward have sold 373 and 375 Broadway, west side, 50 feet south of White Street, a plot 50 by 150, running through to Franklin Place, and now occupied by five-story buildings. The purchaser's name is withheld.

ST. PAUL, Minn., April 28. -- The general offices of the Chicago, Burlington and orthern will be moved May l'rom St. Paul to Chicago, the headquarters of the Burlington system. General Freight and Passenger Agent George P. Lyman will become Assistant General Freight and Passenger Agent of Chicago, Burlington and Quiney, with headquarters in St. Paul.

The three-thousand-odd spectators who saw the game at Washington Park yesterday between Brooklyn and Baltimore got their money's worth. They saw nearly three hours of runs, hits, and errors, and the uncertainty of the result did not allow the interest to lag. The game might have been continued half an hour longer, but the shades of night ended the fun.

Annie Logan of 124 East One Hundred and Eighth Street works as a servant in the family of Dr. Samuel Gregory, at 240 West One Hundred and Twenty-fourth Street. Annie has two brothers and a mother. When she went to work for Dr. Gregory she asked that they be not permitted to see her, as they continually annoyed her, demanding her money.

The dismissal of the indictment against Messrs. HOLT and BUTLER does not unfortunately go to the merits of the charge. The great question whether, in the jurisprudence of the English-speaking peoples, it is libelous to describe a public officer officially concerned with education as a "fine old educational mastodon" is still judicially undetermined.
ALBANY, April 28. -- The tax rate for 1899 is 2.49 mills. In 1898 it was 2.08 mills.

MANILA, April 28. -- Col. Manuel Argueleses and Lieut. Jose Bernal, chief of Gen. Luna's staff, entered Gen. MacArthur's line this morning bearing a flag of truce. Their errand was to propose a cessation of hostilities, pending an agreement upon terms or peace.
NAPLES, April 28. -- The body of Robert Goelet, late of New York City, who died here yesterday on board his steam yacht Nahma, will be left on the vessel and be taken to the United States.

Mrs. Harry Van Auken, widow of Supreme Court Justice Andrews's stepson, who has been in Bellevue Hospital for several days suffering from morphine poisoning, was placed under arrest late Thursday night charged with grand larceny, and removed to the prison ward. William Myllus of 12 Union Square, who secured the warrant, claims Mrs. Van Auken bought a five-hundred-dollar piano from him a year ago, and disappeared after she had paid $175 of the amount.

The defense opened yesterday in the case of ex-Commissioners Theodore B. Willis and William E. Philips, on trial in Brooklyn for conspiracy to defraud the city. Motions to dismiss were made by Gen. Tracy and denied. Col. Lamb made the opening address. He began by reviewing Willis's long public service. He laid great stress on the necessity of proving an overt act, and said that none had been shown.

Officers of the Bank of Commerce said yesterday that they could not confirm a rumor that Secretary Lyman J. Gage would succeed W.W. Sherman as President of the bank, and that they had no knowledge of any such plan of succession. They added that so far there had been nothing beyond friendly chat about filling the vacancy.

HAVANA, April 28. -- La Lucha publishes a dispatch from Holguin, Province of Santiago de Cuba, reporting that bandits yesterday sacked the Villages of Saro, Hutia, Peregrina, Canelon, and Sama, all in the northern part of the province, and that another party of fifteen attacked San Andres, about twenty miles northwest of Holguin.

PHILADELPHIA, April 28. --President McKinley and his party left the Hotel Bellevue shortly after 10 o'clock this morning for a visit to the cruiser Raleigh, which lies at anchor in the Delaware River off the centre of the city. They boarded a tug at 10:45 o'clock, and in about two minutes drew alongside the cruiser. The President was greeted by Lieut. Commander Phelps, who introduced him to Capt. Coghlan.

Cragin, has all the money it needs to start in business with a capital of $2,500,000 and $2,500,000 surplus, but the financier and business man who is to be at the head of it has yet to be chosen.

ST. LOUIS, April 28. -- According to the best information, the storm which caused so much less of life and destruction of property in Northern Missouri originated in Nebraska. Its course was southwest through Western Iowa to the Missouri State line, thence through Harrison, Grundy, Sullivan, Linn, Macon, Shelby, and Marion Counties: north and west through Lewis, Knox, Adair, Sullivan, and Putnam Counties.

HAVANA, April 28. -- The attitude of Gen. Maximo Gomez toward the "Intervening Power," as he calls the United States, causes a lively controversy among politicians here, and even among his friends. La Discusion and El Reconcentrado treat him as an ally of the United States, and refer to him as a "traitor to the cause of Cuban independence."

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, April 20. -- Among the passengers who left San Juan on the transport McPherson on the 18th were Gen. Robert P. Kennedy and Henry G. Curtis of the Insular Commission. After a stay of six weeks on the island they are returning to Washington to meet their colleague, Charles W. Watkins, who preceded them, and to submit their recommendations for the future government of the island.

ALBANY, April 28. -- As a sensational climax to a singularly uneventful session, the Assembly to-day, by a vote of 104 to 38, passed the Ford bill making certain corporate franchises liable to taxation as real estate, inaugurating thereby what is regarded as the most radical departure in tax legislation the State has ever known.

LONDON, April 28. -- At the fourth day's racing of the Newmarket first Spring meeting to-day, Mr. T. Craven's four-year-old chestnut colt Waterhead won the Friday Welter Handicap. Lord William Beresford's four-year-old chestnut colt Doric II., ridden by "Tod" Sloan, finished second in a field of seventeen. The betting was 3 to 1 against Doric II.

The report was signed at 2:30 P.M. by every member of the board, and soon afterward the members of the court left the Lemon Building, where all the meetings in this city have been held.

WARDNER, Idaho, April 29. -- Wardner to-day has been the scene of the worst riots since the labor war of 1892. One man is dead and another thought to be mortally wounded, and property valued at $250,000 has been destroyed by giant powder and fire. The damage was done by union miners and sympathizers from Canon Creek, about twenty miles from Wardner.

DETROIT, April 30. -- Secretary Alger was interviewed to-night by an Associated Press reporter relative to his prospective candidacy before the next Legislature for United States Senator from Michigan in succession to Senator McMillan. He was asked if Senator McMillan had intimated to him that he would not be a candidate for re-election to a third term in the Senate.
In yesterday's issue Mr. Theodore Northrop takes exception to my statement in a former letter that the "Filipinos were given their liberty nearly three months ago," and asks when, where, and by whom.
The Trustees of the West Presbyterian Church, of which the Rev. Dr. Anthony H. Evans is pastor, have resigned in a body, and as a result the war within the church has broken out afresh.

Apropos of the Christmas story told in Friday's TIMES by Mr. John Codman about the late Admiral Bayley, whose knowledge of other things than nautical was aptly illustrated, I am reminded of another good sea Captain, who in the early seventies commanded the good steamship Arizona of the Pacific Mail Steamship Company, then inaugurating a bi-monthly line between San Francisco and China.

ROCHESTER, April 30. -- Two persons were killed and over fifty, of whom a number are likely to die, were injured in a railroad wreck at Rosenbaur's Corners this afternoon. An excursion train, crowded with passengers, on the Rochester and Lake Ontario Railroad, better known as the Bay Railroad, left the track as it was going round a curve at full speed, and two cars were completely wrecked.

Senator Coggeshall, Senator Malby, and two or three other up-the-State Republicans called on Senator Platt at the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday. It was said that Senator Platt did not discuss the work of the Mazet committee with any one during the day beyond a few passing remarks. Chairman Mazet was out of the city most of the day.

I see in your edition of this morning that "T.G." is out again with a defense of non-resistance as a Christian duty and more objections to Lyman Abbott's remarks on the occasional necessity of war. While I have no sympathy with Lyman Abbott, considering most of his opinions both silly and pernicious.

COLERIDGE, Neb., April 30. -- A prairie fire burning in the hay flats along the northern tier of counties of Nebraska, ten miles from here, yesterday afternoon passed into the track of a tornado and was swept with the speed of the wind diagonally across this county for twenty-five miles, destroying everything in its path.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 30. -- The United States transport Sherman arrived here from Manila, and was followed into port shortly afterward by the Grant. Both ships were ordered into quarantine. On the way over one of the crew of the Sherman died of smallpox. How long the ship and passengers will be obliged to remain in quarantine is a problem, but it is possible that the officers may be released to-day.

WASHINGDON, April 30. -- The fifteenth annual report of the Civil Service Commission, under date of November 1, 1898, has been presented to President McKinley. It is an unusually interesting one, especially as it shows a larger number of appointments through examinations than ever before in the history of the commission.

The Rev. Dr. Rainsford preached a labor sermon last evening, in St. George's Church, under the auspices of the Church Association for the Advancement of the Interests of Labor. The church was well filled, and there were present representatives from the Central Federated Union and other labor organizations in the city.

Three meetings in the interest of the doctrine of Theosophy were held in this city yesterday, and the one of perhaps the most importance took place in the evening at the hall of the Aryan Theosophical Society, 144 Madison Avenue, the public being invited. The purpose of this meeting was to listen to accounts by returning delegates of the Congress of the Universal Brotherhood and Theosophical Society, which was held at San Diego, Cal., recently.

Deputy Chief Edward F. Croker has been selected by Fire Commissioner Scannell to succeed Hugh Bonner as Chief of the New York Fire Department. Commissioner Scannell made the announcement last evening, saying that the appointment was only temporary, and would so continue until the Civil Service Commissioners act under the White bill.

WASHINGTON, April 30. -- Rear Admiral Edwin Stewart, Chief of the Bureau of Supplies and Accounts of the Navy Department, the Paymaster General of the Navy, will be retired on May 5, when he will have reached the legal retiring age. To the Administration this severance of official relations will be greatly regretted.

LONDON, May 1. -- The Berlin correspondent of The Times says: "Emperor William has once more shown how entirely his most generous impulses are made to sub-serve the aims of State policy, and how far his ideas of foreign policy are exalted above the petty rancors of an influential section of the German press.

MANILA, April 30 -- 8:10 P.M. -- While it is the general expectation among Americans that the Filipino emissaries will return with revised proposals from Gen. Antonio Luna. Gen. Otis is not letting this prospect interfere with his preparations for pushing the war. Yesterday he ordered Gen. Lawton to return to Angat, a few miles northwest of Norzagaray, and not to advance aggressively while the negotiations are pending.
PITTSBURG, April 30. -- Evidences of good times in and around Pittsburg are shown by the following notices of wage increases:

WASHINGTON, April 30. -- Acting Secretary of War Meiklejohn made public to-day a report upon the commercial and industrial conditions in Cuba, showing that the future of the island under a stable government promises a wonderful development of wealth. The beneficial effects of an economical administration of the island's affairs, such as is now being given under the direction of the War Department, are already apparent.

City officials, lawyers, dealers in stocks and bonds, and business men generally have begun to appreciate fully the importance of the Ford Franchise Tax bill. At first glance it was apparently aimed only at the taxation of that intangible thing which Senator Ford calls an "easement in the public streets," and wishes to have classified, for purposes of taxation, as real estate, and which others generally call a railroad or other franchise.

" Charities," the official organ of the Charity Organization Society of this city, gives in its latest issue a review of the charitable activities of the past Winter. It finds as the most conspicuous feature of the season "the emergency relief measures resulting from the exceptional severity of the Winter, and especially from the February blizzard."
NEWPORT, May 1. -- E.L. Wharton's schooner yacht Thelma is being placed in commission.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, April 26. -- The political crisis described in the dispatch of March 28 reached a complete and sudden termination by the surrender of the Government. This, however, did not affect the proposed new tariff. The fight between the Government and the Representatives was solely over the Constitutional principle involved in the compulsory passage of Government measures, and not the tariff measure in itself.

The first anniversary of the victory of the American fleet over the Spaniards at Manila was celebrated yesterday in a fitting manner. The celebration was entirely informal. No official programme had been arranged, and there was no parade. The people, however, celebrated the victory in their own way.

Not content with the honor of being Dewey Day, yesterday possessed itself of another distinction -- that of being the hottest day of its date on the records of the local Weather Bureau. The mercury reached the highest mark at 4 o'clock in the afternoon, when it touched 80 degrees.

-- Several difficult and delicate questions are raised by an episode just reported from a Chicago hospital. A surgeon, assisted by his son, also a surgeon, was stricken with heart disease while performing an operation. The attack came at the most critical moment of the operation, and any delay in completing it meant probable death for the patient, and very great peril as a matter of certainty.
The following letter appeared in The London Times of April 20, 1899:

MANILA, May 2 -- 8:25 A.M. -- Yesterday, the anniversary of the battle of Manila Bay, was observed by the United States fleet, the usual drills being omitted. Admiral Dewey had many visitors, and the American and British merchantmen dressed ship.

GALESBURG, Ill., May 1. -- Prof. Frederick Starr of the University of Chicago lectured here Saturday night under the auspices of Knox College on his recent trip to Mexico. After the lecture the Professor was the guest of the Pundit Club, composed of college professors and men in the senior class.

Those of our publicists who are not quite clear what would be the right thing to do in the Philippines, but who are clear that whatever is is wrong, have been much cheered up by the account of the performances of a mob of savage lynchers in Georgia. They would be cheered up by any revelation of the imperfections of our civilization, and of course there are too many of them.

President and Mrs. McKinley returned last night to Washington. The last day of their stay was marked by the usual flow of visitors to the Hotel Manhattan. Mrs. McKinley spent a quiet, almost uneventful day, in the hotel, but the President paid the Brooklyn Navy Yard a visit and inspected New York's harbor from the deck of a Government tug.

LONDON, May 1. -- Joseph H. Choate, the United States Ambassador, and Baron Russell of Killowen, Lord Chief Justice of England, were the principal guests this evening at the banquet of the Hardwicke Society.

Roland B. Molineux must remain in the Tombs until again brought before the Grand Jury on the Charge of having sent the poison which caused the death of Mrs. Kate J. Adams. Justice Bookstaver, in the Supreme Court, yesterday handed down a decision dismissing the writs of habeas corpus and certiorari obtained for Molineux by his counsel, Weeks Battle.

BOSTON, May 1. -- It is rumored that the Cunard Steamship Company has secured control of the Eastern Railroad Company's East Boston pier, which is considered to be one of the finest terminals at this port. The Cunard officials do not deny or affirm the report.

The golf season at Morristown, N.J., will practically begin this week with a women's eighteen-hole handicap competition at the Morris County Golf Club to-morrow and a men's eighteen-hole handicap on Saturday. The committee has arranged twelve club contests for this month, each Wednesday being devoted to a women's tournament.

Yesterday was the beginning of a new term in the Court of General Sessions, and the Judges were shifted to different parts of the court. Recorder Goff took the bench in Part IV., where numerous dead men were called for trial during the last term. The usual array of excise cases appeared on his calendar, and the Recorder took occasion during the day to criticise the District Attorney.

In many ways yesterday's market had extraordinary features. After a weak opening strength was displayed throughout the whole list and buying by commission houses was conspicuous. Almost uniformly expressions of sentiment disclosed confidence. But during the noon hour a raid began which grew in force throughout the day till at the close of business quotations were under greater pressure than has been known in any recent market history.
NEW ORLEANS, May 1. -- Dewey Day was celebrated here in the schools to-day. Children wrote compositions on the Admiral and his feat of a year ago, and read them in the school.

ST. PAUL, Minn., May 1. -- The general observance of Dewey Day in the public schools of this city was accompanied by the celebration of Arbor and Bird Day, this being also the date designated by the Governor for that purpose. Flags on public buildings was the only observance outside of the schools.

WASHINGTON, May 1. -- The Brooklyns won a long-drawn-out game to-day by heavy and consecutive hitting, aided by errors and stupid playing of the home team. Kelley's batting and a one-hand catch by Keeler were the features. Score:

HAVANA, May 1. -- According to dispatches from Puerto Principe Province, the village of San Andres was recently raided by a band of forty outlaws led by Antonio Barcelo, formerly a citizen of Holguin, Santiago Province. The place was completely sacked, the bandits carrying off twenty horses, a large quantity of clothing and groceries, and $1.200 in money.

WASHINGTON, May 1. -- Paymaster General Stewart, United States Navy, was this afternoon informed by Assistant Secretary Allen of the intention of the Navy Department to retire him on May 5 for age. The communication also informed Admiral Stewart that he would go on the retired list under two sections of the personnel law, which assures him the rank and pay of a Rear Admiral.

CHICAGO, May 1. -- Flags were unfurled throughout the city to-day and portraits of Admiral Dewey were displayed on every hand, although there was no cessation of traffic on account of the holiday. In the public schools the anniversary of the battle of Manila Bay was celebrated.

WASHINGTON, May 1. -- President McKinley will find the report of the army beef court of inquiry ready in the White House when he returns to this city. Predictions as to what it will contain have been so free and have agreed so closely since the very hour the court adjourned that the President is not expected to find anything in it that it new.

WASHINGTON, May 1. -- In accordance with the request of the President to choose from each of the volunteer regiments now in the Philippines one man distinguished for gallantry for appointment as Second Lieutenant in the regular army, Gen. Otis has forwarded the following names:

WASHINGTON, May 1. -- The monthly statement of the public debt issued to-day shows that at the close of business April 29, 1899, the debt, less cash in the Treasury, amounted to $1,172,587,264, an increase during the month of $23,081,701. This is accounted for by the payment of $20,000,000 to Spain in settlement of treaty obligations.

In an irregular stock market yesterday with Stock Exchange dealings of over 830,000 shares, there were sharp and important declines in many specialties, and notably in Consolidated Gas and local traction stocks. If, as was claimed, the course of the market was due to a strictly professional raid, "the talent" could not have selected a better opportunity for a coup.

ST. ALBANS, Vt., May 1 -- The receivers of the Central Vermont Railroad ended their jurisdiction over the properties and employes of that corporation at 12 o'clock last night and the officers of the new company, the Central Vermont Railway, took formal possession at 12:01 this morning. Employes of the old company are retained in service until further notice.

Bishop Potter is still deliberating upon the question of the ordination of Dr. Briggs as a priest of the Protestant Episcopal Church. And while the Bishop deliberates, the discussion of the question spreads and increases in intensity.
WASHINGTON, May 1. -- The following cablegram has been received from Admiral Dewey:

NEWPORT, May 1. -- Two handsome monuments have arrived here, which were designed by architect George C. Mason of Newport and Philadelphia, for Mrs. August Belmont and Lieut. William Tiffany of Roosevelt's Rough Riders, both of whom are buried in the famous Perry Circle at the Island Cemetery.

ALBANY, May 1. -- Frank Martin, better known as "Young James," and Frank McHenry, both of Albany, were to go rounds as a preliminary at the Whitehall Athletic Club, this city, to-night. In the third round Martin received a terrible right over the heart. He dropped to his knees and was counted out.

MONTREAL, May 1. -- As a result of an expedition of the Dominion police against the obstreperous Indians at St. Regis to-day, one Indian was killed, two seriously wounded, and four arrested. The dead man is Jake Ice, a very bad Indian, who has been accused of killing his wife. The wounded are Jake Sunday and Pete Somebody. Jake Fire, Peter Fire, Peter Thompson, and Angus Baboneau were arrested.

BIRMINGHAM, May 1. -- Samuel Powell, umpire in a game of baseball at Lowndesborough, this afternoon was instantly killed by Frank McCoy, one of the players. The "Reds" and "Blues," two local teams, were the contestants, and Powell leaned to the "Reds." In the seventh inning McCoy who was the finest batsman for the "Blues," with two men on bases, hit a ball to the fence in left field.

WASHINGTON, May 1. -- Acting Secretary Meiklejohn has received the following report from Capt. Abercrombie, who is commanding the expedition investigating the Copper River route to the Yukon country: "My expedition disembarked to-day, April 23. Hospital organized for the care of destitute miners, who are now coming out of the interior by the route you contemplated opening as a military road.

SEATTLE, Washington, May 1. -- Sixty prospectors arrived here to-day from Copper River, Alaska, on the steamer Alaska. They brought with them a repetition of the stories of privation and death, and many bore evidences on their bodies of the ravages of scurvy and frost. A man named Young hobbled off the vessel on the stumps of two legs.

LONDON, May 1. -- The Marquis of Salisbury, Prime Minister and Minister of Foreign Affairs, and Mr. A.J. Balfour, First Lord of the Treasury and Government leader, announced to-day in the House of Lords and in the House of Commons, respectively, the general drift of the Anglo-Russian agreement regarding the spheres of influence of the Governments of Great Britain and Russia in China, as they have already been made known.

The Martha Washington Chapter, Daughters of the American Revolution, yesterday afternoon unveiled a tablet marking the first Presidential residence of George Washington, at 1 Cherry Street, under the shadow of one of the big stone arches of the Brooklyn Bridge. The site is at the junction of Cherry and Pearl Streets, on Franklin Square.

The New Yorks and Phlldelphias played. a ten-inning draw at the Polo Grounds yesterday afternoon, each team having scored eight runs when the game was called on account of darkness. The local team staved off a defeat in the ninth inning, scoring three runs, tying the score, through good batting, aided by a bad throw by Third Baseman Louder.

NEWPORT, May 1. -- To-day, Quartermaster Goldstein of Admiral Dewey's flagship Olympia came home from Manila. He is looking for his parents, who eleven years ago lived here when the tar was a lad. He ran away and enlisted in the navy as an apprentice, and after his training ship cruise he was sent to the Asiatic Station, where he has been ever since until he started for home on the Raleigh.

There was a rumor in Wall Street to-day that a strong syndicate of influential capitalists has obtained a charter under the laws of the State of New Jersey and proposes to combine all the gold brick interests of the country.

CHICAGO, May 1. -- Chicago is to establish an Episcopal Church in Puerto Rico. It will be organized soon at San Juan, with a membership of thirty-six. Bishop McLaren of the Chicago diocese to-day forwarded to San Juan documents authorizing the action and appointing the Rev. George B. Pratt to assume charge of the new congregation as rector.

WASHINGTON, May 1. -- Assistant Secretary of the Treasury Vanderlip this morning handed to Secretary Hay the drafts for $20,000,000, to be turned over to the Spanish Government, through Ambassador Cambon, according to the terms of the peace treaty.

At the Metropolitan Museum of Art yesterday a private view was given of what the card of invitation termed the "envois" of the students of architecture, sculpture, and painting of the American Academy in Rome. Yesterday was also private view day at the Museum itself, when the new acquisitions placed in position in the course of the last fortnight, during which the building has been closed, were seen for the first time.

HAVANA, May 1. -- Gov. Gen. Brooke and Gen. Gomez -- both of whom are annoyed at the slow progress made in arranging for the distribution of the $3,000,000 to the Cuban troops -- held another conference to-day at the Salon Trocha, Gen. Brooke's headquarters. The latter emphasized the necessity of disposing of the question at once, and Gen. Gomez quite agreed with the Governor General.

WASHINGTON, May 1. -- Advices received here from Bluefields, Nicaragua, treat of the causes of the trouble Americans are experiencing at the hands of the Nicaraguan Government. It is being impressed upon the officials here that persons high in the Nicaraguan Government are pursuing a policy calculated very deliberately to crush the American business interests, now of considerable magnitude in that country.

Lawrence Turnure, the well-known banker, died at 6:10 o'clock last evening at his residence, 417 Fifth Avenue, of paralysis, after an illness of eighteen months. Mr. Turnure never recovered from the first stroke he suffered, and had been confined to his house for a year and a half.

Bronson Howard's famous war drama called "Shenandoah." was put forward at the Broadway Theatre last evening to begin Mr. Jacob Litt's term of management. The spacious and handsome auditorium had been put in its Summer dress, and profusely decorated with bunting in honor of Dewey Day. The play was produced with all the showy scenery and effects employed when Mr. Litt revived it at the Academy just a year ago.

Six owners divided the honors in the races at the Aqueduct race course yesterday. Maher rode three of the winners, Spencer two, and Sherrer one. Of the three winners, Alex, Maid of Erin, and Box were favorites in the betting. Theory was a strong second choice, Boney Boy a joint second choice with Zanone, and Chopin a lukewarm third or fourth choice.

Corporation Counsel Whalen, in an opinion which he sent to the Department of Taxes and Assessments yesterday, disposed of the Ford Franchise Tax law as a revenue producer for this year, and showed plainly that nothing could be done under it in this city until the assessment for 1900 is levied.
It was "Cousin Day" for the Sorosis Society yesterday.

There was a report yesterday that Assemblyman Hoffman, one of the two Democratic members of the Legislative Investigating Committee, intends to issue a subpoena for Senator Platt and have him brought before the committee for examination. This is said to be one of the retaliatory measures that Tammany Hall has been planning.

F. De R. Wissmann has sold for Gutwillig Brothers to Warren Skillin, representing a client, the eight-story business building 3 and 5 West Eighteenth Street, on a plot 50 by 92. The price is reported at about $285,000.

The announcement of the completion of plans for a submarine cable between Germany and the United States is good news for all concerned. The new line has a promising commercial field, for the intercourse of all sorts between the two countries, which, for a long time now, has been steadily increasing, is sure to be stimulated by this new agency.

WASHINGTON, May 1. -- The One Hundred and Sixty-first Indiana Regiment, mustered out of service yesterday at Savannah, reached here late this afternoon homeward bound. The schedule contemplated arrival early in the day, and an elaborate programme for the entertainment of the men had been provided under the direction of the Indiana Republican Club, but they did not all arrive till late in the day.

BERLIN, May 1. -- The newspapers of Germany, commenting upon the latest news from the Philippine Islands, express the hope that the United States will now end the hostilities in the Far East. The Frankfurter Zeitung says:

Edward F. Croker took command of the Fire Department as Acting Chief yesterday morning, succeeding Hugh Bonner, who retired on half pay after making one of the most remarkable records ever made by a fire fighter. Mr. Bonnet went to headquarters yesterday morning and had a brief talk with his temporary successor.

Although New York University during the last year has received about $200,000 in endowments, fears are expressed among the members of the Council that the income next year will not be large enough to cover expenses. Unless additional endowments are received it is feared that either the students will have to be taxed more or else the cost of conducting the institution be cut down in some way.
PHILADELPHIA, May 1. -- Dewey Day was celebrated in this city to-day, in accordance with the proclamation of Gov. Stone, made upon the recommendation of the Legislature.

AKRON, Ohio, May 1. -- It is stated that a reorganization of the American Cereal Company is about to take place. It is proposed to increase the capital stock from $3,500,000 to $22,000,000. It is understood that those who are interested in the present company will control the new organization.
The Professional Woman's League held a business meeting yesterday to consider its election on Monday, May 8, at Lyric Hall, in Sixth Avenue, near Forty-second Street.
LONDON, May 1. -- Wycliffe's English Bible, known as the Bramhall Manuscript, from the Ashburnham manuscripts, was sold at auction for 1,750 ($8,750) to-day.

BOSTON, May 1. -- The Essex Club celebrated to-night Admiral Dewey's victory of a year ago with a banquet at Young's Hotel, at which were entertained Secretary of the Navy John D. Long and two heroes of the Manila Bay fight, Capt. Wildes of the Boston and Lieut. Commander Rees, formerly executive officer of the Olympia, besides Lieut. Commander James R. Selfridge, formerly of the Puritan, and Lieut. Commander F.A. Wilner of the Monadnock.

A reduction in the price of gas from $1.10 to 65 cents per thousand feet was the way in which the Consolidated and the New York Mutual Gas Companies celebrated Dewey Day. Official announcement was made last night that the Standard Gas Company would meet this cut in price made by its rivals, and it is probable that the New Amsterdam Company will follow.

WESTFIELD, Mass., May 1. -- James L. Hanchett, who left here Thursday under fear that he was about to be arrested for the embezzlement of $7,000 from the Steimer Moore Manufacturing Company, has returned to this city and offered to submit to punishment.

Most of the corporation lawyers in this city have reached practically the same conclusion regarding the Ford Franchise Tax bill, and that is that its provisions cannot be enforced without litigation. The chief point that many of the railroad corporation lawyers make is that their clients hold contracts with either the State or the Municipality which cannot be subjected to an extra tax, or any other obligation "not nominated in the bond."

CHICAGO, May 1. -- It is said on good authority that a deal by which the Charles T. Yerkes traction interests pass into the hands of a New York syndicate headed by William C. Whitney has been closed. Prices at which the transfers of the West Chicago and North Chicago properties were made are placed at 130 in the case of the former and 270 in the case of the latter.

There was a lively time in the new seven-story stone-front building at 507 and 509 West Broadway at 9 o'clock last night when fire started on the fifth floor. Twenty persons, all but three of whom were women and girls, were working for Wiener Spier, manufacturers of Swiss embroidery, on the top floor, and there was panic among them.
DARMSTADT, May 1. -- The death of Prof. Frederick Karl Christian Ludwig Buechner, the author of "Force and Matter," is announced.

Superintendent Elliott of the money order department of the Post Office was asked yesterday what effect the new rules of local banks, enforcing charges on the collection of out-of-town checks, had had upon the money order department.

LONDON, May 3. -- The Times announces this morning that it is not probable that the Shamrock, Sir Thomas Lipton's challenger for the America's Cup, will be launched before the first week of next month. At that time her mast will be put into place, and she will be towed to Cowes to complete her outfit, sailing thence to New York.

The sailings to-day occupy much of the attention of society, which for the next fortnight will be in a state of transition. The bookings on the European ships, as far as New Yorkers are concerned, will be much decreased, and nearly all the Summer resorts, with the exception of Bar Harbor, will have begun a preliminary season.

MANILA, May 2. -- The first authentic information regarding Lieut. J. C. Gillmore and his party of fourteen men from the United States gunboat Yorktown, who were captured by the Filipinos on April 12, was received to-day at the hands of Major Arguelles of the staff of Gen. Antonio Luna. It is in the form of a list of the missing men, and is signed by Lieut. Gillmore.

LONDON, May 2. -- Robert Louis Stevenson's widow has written a letter to The Westminster Gazette from Funchal, Madeira, on the bombardment of Samoan villages by British and American warships. Mrs. Stevenson says in the course of her letter:

PHILADELPHIA, May 2. -- As an indirect outcome of the arrest of William M. Jacobs and his alleged co-conspirators in the revenue stamp counterfeiting case, the most important National meeting in the history of the cigar leaf tobacco trade will convene in this city on May 22. Representatives will be present from all the principal cigar leaf centres, delegates coming from as far West as San Francisco.

DETROIT, Mich., May 2. -- The Michigan Society, Sons of the American Revolution, entertained the visiting members of the order to-night at a dinner. Among the guests were Secretary Alger, Senator Chauncey M. Depew, Major Gen. Joseph Wheeler, Major Gen. Wesley Merritt, Gen. Horatio C. King, and Inspector General Joseph C. Breckinridge.

It was reported yesterday that the Manhattan Railway Company had forwarded an appeal to the State Railroad Commissioners at Albany praying for the protection of that board against the alleged unjust attacks of the Board of Health. At the offices of the company neither a denial nor a confirmation of this report could be obtained.

All of the gas companies in Manhattan -- the Consolidated, Mutual, New Amsterdam, and Standard -- are now selling gas at 65 cents a thousand feet. The two last-named companies notified their customers yesterday that their interests would be protected, and that they could be assured that the companies would meet any cut in prices that their rivals made.

BRISTOL, R.I., May 2. -- The crew of the Defender, consisting of thirty-three men, nearly all of whom are Scandinavians, in charge of Capt. Darius Rhodes and Mate Leonard Miller, arrived here from New York to-day. They had some trouble in getting quarters, as the hotel where arrangements had been made for their accommodation was closed.

WASHINGTON, May 2. -- Acting on cable instructions from the Governor of the Bank of Spain, at Madrid, the French Ambassador, M. Cambon, has completed arrangements for transferring to Spain the $20,000,000 received from the United States.

The Rapid Transit Commission's session was presided over for the last time by Alexander E. Orr yesterday. Mr. Orr will retire from the board to-morrow, when his term as President of the Chamber of Commerce expires. Although Mr. Orr's successor as President of the Chamber of Commerce will become a member ex officio of the Rapid Transit Board, he will not by this fact occupy the position of President relinquished by Mr. Orr.

WASHINGTON, May 2. -- Assistant Secretary Taylor of the Treasury Department will send out invitations to-day to twenty leading architects in New York, Boston, Philadelphia, and Chicago to submit competitive plans for the new Custom House Building to be erected on the Bowling Green site in New York City.
NEWPORT, May 2. -- A large number of horses, with baggage, carriages, and servants for the cottagers, arrived to-day.

DETROIT, May 2. -- Senator-elect Depew said, in the course of an interview here today, that he did not believe that Gov. Roosevelt would seek a Presidential nomination next year. When asked as to what the Senate was likely to do with Senator Quay, he replied that it was hard to say.

BALTIMORE, May 2. -- Thomas G. Hayes will be Baltimore's next Mayor. The Democrats swept the city to-day, defeating William T. Malster, the present Mayor, by 8,748 majority. The election passed off quietly, there being no disturbances of a serious nature and comparatively few arrests.

The hesring of the ction brought by Carl Jussen agaJmst Fire Commdssioner John J Scannell to compel him to reinstate hi,m as Secretary of the Fire Department was continued yesterday before Justice Aidam and jury in the Supreme Court. Col. Jussen, who is a veteran of the civil v./r, alleges that qle was dismissed to make room for a Tamcnany man.

Henry Baldwin Hyde, President of the Equitable Life Assurance Society, and one of the best-known life insurance authorities in the United States, died yesterday afternoon of heart disease, at his residence, 9 East Fortieth Street. Mr. Hyde had been confined to his house for a year, but lately his physicians had considered him on the road to recovery.

Confidence, courage, the disposition to make a stand -- these seem only to be needed to dispose of bear security market campaigning in times like these; and the course of yesterday's market made this fact clear. Sharp tests waged at the opening of the market; the bear contingent was aggressive and had fables in volume and variety with which it was the purpose to appall the Street;

WELLINGTON, N.Z., May 2. -- Advices from Samoa indicate that the instructions received from the powers to cease hostilities make the situation in the islands very serious, as the rebels hold the main food supplies, and are again near the Municipality of Apia.

The convention off the National Association of Credit Men will be held at Buffalo June 6 and 8. Important questions relating to the National Bankruptcy law will be discussed, and suggestions received and codified preparatory to the assembling of the next Congress. The Committee on Mercantile Agency Service will perfect plans for more effectually punishing dishonest debtors, both under State laws and under the provisions of the Bankruptcy act.

One apparently modest measure passed by the late Legislature as to transportation of passengers within the limits of the present City of New York may have very considerable results. We refer to the bill authorizing the building of a tunnel under the East River, connecting the Long Island Railroad with the Borough of Manhattan.

ALBANY, May 2. -- Gov. Roosevelt has appointed Thursday, the llth inst., at noon, for the hearing on the Ford Franchise Tax bill. The Governor said this morning, that he had been deluged with letters from all parts of the State, and from representatives of railroad and gas companies in particular, petitioning him to give a hearing upon the measure.

TRENTON, May 2. -- The Pittsburg Milling Company, capital $1,200,000, was incorporated here to-day. The company is empowered to deal in grain of all kinds. The incorporators are Charles Donnelly, Robert D. Elwood, William J. Kerr of Pittsburg, Russell K. Forsyth of Allegheny, and George H.B. Masters of Camden.

LONDON, May 2. -- A remarkable degree of public interest was manifested in the farewell benefit to Lydia Thompson at the Lyceum Theatre this afternoon. All the leading actors and actresses in the city participated in the performance, many celebrities of the stage taking part, as at the benefit of Nellie Farron last year.

The semi-official statement that "the Government does not coincide with the serious view of the arrangement between Russia and England concerning China" was to be expected. WASHINGTON, May 2. -- Several members of the House Republican Caucus Committee, which has been engaged at Atlantic City in the preparation of a currency reform measure have reached here.

COLUMBIA, S.C., May 2. -- An incendiary, supposed to be a discharged servant, set fire to the house of Gen. Hampton at an early hour this morning. The General, who is eighty-one years old, was the first to discover it and aroused his daughter and the servants. He strapped on his cork leg, and, gathering up the swords of himself, his father, and his grandfather, escaped from the house.

ST. LOUIS, May 2. -- In the Circuit Court of Appeals to-day, with Judges Bland, Biggs, and Bond on the bench, a unanimous decision was made in an appealed case to the effect that a trust cannot cloak its objects under the form of a corporation and evade the penalties provided for violations of the Missouri anti-trust law of 1891. Under this decision debts owing to trusts operating as corporations in Missouri are not collectible.

ALBANY, N.Y., May 2. -- No appeal has yet been received from the Manhattan Railway Company by the Railroad Commission for protection in any form against the inspection made or proceedings taken by the Board of Health in New York City.

LONDON, May 2. -- An enormous crowd of people gathered in the vicinity of the Canon Street Hotel here to-day in the hope of hearing Mr. Cecil Rhodes's address before the meeting of the Chartered British South Africa Company. The people began gathering as early as 8 o'clock in the morning outside the hall, and thousands were refused admission to the meeting.
ROME, May 2. -- The Cabinet will meet to-morrow morning, and it is rumored that Gen. Pelloux will tender the resignation of the Ministry to King Humbert.

A heavy rain squall, accompanied by thunder and lightning, struck the city shortly after 6 o'clock last evening. The electric fluid claimed one victim. The storm was heralded by severe gusts that whipped up clouds of dust and swayed the branches of the leaving trees in the parks. The gathering of the storm over the Jersey hills made a magnificent spectacle.

BOSTON, May 2. -- Edward Atkinson, Vice President of the Anti-Imperialist League of this city, after reading the Washington dispatch saying that the Postmaster General of the United States had directed that certain pamphlets prepared by Mr. Atkinson be taken from the mails to Manila, said he had received no direct communication from Washington about the matter.

DETROIT, May 2. -- The congress of the Sons of the American Revolution took action to-day toward conferring medals upon the members who took part in the Spanish-American war. The President General was authorized to appoint a committee of three to procure metal from captured Spanish cannon or ships, and to cause to be struck therefrom medals for each soldier of the order.

Members of the School Board of Manhattan and the Bronx held a meeting yesterday at the Board of Education building to discuss and formulate a salary schedule for this borough for presentation to the School Board at its meeting to-day. Principals from various primary and grammar schools appeared before the Commissioners to offer suggestions for and discuss the new schedbule which is to follow the Ahearn bill.

Five men were buried in a cave-in, where an excavation is being made for a new building at the southwest corner of Broadway and Warren Street, shortly after 11 o'clock yesterday morning. Two were killed and the others were injured, one of them seriously.

The legislative investigating committee probably will enlarge the scope of its inquiry when it again meets in this city, May 16. Its powers were extended to include the county administration of New York, because it was found that many lines of inquiry lead also into county affairs.

WARDNER, Idaho, May 2. -- The first detachment of troops sent here in anticipation of a possible renewal of rioting by the striking miners arrived this afternoon from Spokane. Other soldiers ordered to Wardner are 120 men of the Twenty-fourth Infantry, (colored,) from Fort Douglas, Utah, under command of Major Thomas; Troop F. Fourth Cavalry, stationed at Boise, Idaho; one company from Fort Walla-Walla, and colored regulars from Helena, Montana.

MANILA, May 2. -- Major Manuel Arguelles and Lieut. Jose Bernal of the staff of Gen. Antonio Luna returned here to-day to renew and press the request of Gen. Luna for a cessation of hostilities. The two officers were received in conference by Major Gen. E.S. Otis. The proposals which they had to submit differed but slightly from those which they brought from the Filipino commander in the first place.

Brooklyn Rapid Transit was a most conspicuous feature of the day. In the general weakness during the morning the stock got down to 125, but closed at 132, showing a net recovery of nearly 7 points. The buying of the stock was at all times good, Flower interests absorbing it steadily and at times working aggressively in advancing its price.

The mere fact that the young officer says not a word about his own achievements is not particularly notable. That might have been simply good manners and observance of conventional rules followed by everybody except people who are boors as well as braggarts.

A road from Panama to Cape Horn is the closest parallel the map of the globe suggests to the scheme. There used to be a man who wrote pamphlets in favor of this.

BERLIN, May 2. -- Dr. Martin Eduard von Simson, the distinguished German jurist and politician, who was President of the Frankfort National Assembly in 1848, died in Berlin this evening in his eighty-ninth year.

Trolley Car No. 855 of the Nassau Railroad was speeding toward the bridge from Coney Island last evening, with the usual 6 o'clock crowd of passengers. They were nearly all from the east side -- workingmen with their wives and children who had been spending an hour or two at the island. Men and women were standing up between the seats.

ALBANY, May 2. -- Gov. Roosevelt to-day held a conference with representatives of various labor interests and others on the provisions of the Costello Anti-Sweatshop bill and anti-tenement house laws and of the State civil service law so far as they relate to appointments in the State labor departments.

The controversy which has arisen over the prospective ordination of the Rev. Dr. Charles Augustus Briggs, now a Professor in the Union Theological Seminary, as a priest in the Episcopal Church bids fair to creat a split among the members of that Church in this diocese. The clergy of the High Church party have opened an active campaign against Dr. Briggs's ordination.

The death of the President of the Equitable removes a strong and conspicuous figure from business and financial circles in this city. To the mass of the people in this community he was the least known of all the big men in it. He attended no public meetings, dinners, or ceremonials. Nobody ever saw his picture in the papers -- or, if so, it was without his privity or consent.

NYACK, May 2. -- Martin Kelly and his son, Garret, of Monsey, were arrested last night charged with hanging Richard Bayles, a negro, to make him confess to a theft. The occurrence was on April 18, and Bayles confessed that he committed the theft. He was sent to jail to await the action of the jury on a charge of grand larceny. Bayles says he confessed the theft in order to save his life.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., May 3. -- The granite monument erected by the State of Kentucky in Chickamauga Park was dedicated this afternoon with imposing ceremonies. At noon Gov. Bradley, his staff, and other prominent Kentuckians left the city for the park. Major 'Thomas H. Hays of the Kentucky Commission, in an address, formally tendered the monument to Gov. Bradley.
