The Council of the City Club, at a meeting held Tuesday evening, drafted a bill, to be introduced in the next Legislature, which is to prohibit and punish the soliciting from judicial officers or candidates for judicial offices, and the payment by such candidates, of assessments or subscriptions for political or other purposes.

The Philadelphias concluded their series at the Polo Grounds yesterday and no one seemed to be sorry that they will not return for some time. They administered another defeat to the local team. The Philadelphias were a hard lot to beat. They have a habit of developing a batting streak when it is least expected, and when this happens the best pitcher cannot stop them.

At the annual meeting of the Chamber of Commerce to-day, officers for 1899-1900 will be elected. There will, it is understood, be no opposition to the ticket, headed by Morris K. Jesup, who will succeed Alexander E. Orr as President of the Chamber. Mr. Orr has completed his fifth consecutive term of office.

The Board of Directors of the Equitable Life Assurance Society met yesterday in accordance with the previously issued call for the second regular quarterly meeting of the year. An adjournment was immediately taken until next Wednesday as a mark of respect to the memory of Henry B. Hyde, the President of the society, whose death occurred on Tuesday.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., May 3. -- The news of the shooting of Alexander Masterton in New York this afternoon created interest in Bronxville, where he was easily the leading resident. His home was on Midland Avenue. The residence is a handsome one. Mr. Masterton lived there with his wife and two daughters, Mrs. C.B. Tibbals and Mrs. W.N. Ferris. All three women are prostrated by the news.

In the current number of Munsey's Magazine Col. H.G. PROUT, the editor of The Railroad Gazette, has a very striking article on "The Railroads and the People," in which, with his usual clearness of statement and breadth of careful generalization, he explains some of the most essential facts as to the railroads and their wonderful relations to the daily life of the American people.

PARIS, May 3. -- The transfer of the exhibition site on the Quai d'Orsay, upon which the American Building will be erected, was made to the United States Commissioner to the Exposition of 1900, Mr. Ferdinand W. Peck, this afternoon. The ceremony, which was a simple one, took place in the presence of M. Picard and others.

Gen. MacArthur has moved his headquarters to San Vincento, across the Rio Grande. Gen. Wheaton's brigade has advanced beyond Apalit.

Deputy Surrogate George L. Glaser of Queens County and ex-Supervisor Joseph Bermel of Newtown were arraigned in the Queens County Court before Judge Moore in Long Island City yesterday to plead to Indictments. The Deputy Surrogate is accused of having collected an alleged fraudulent bill for $1,500 from the town of Newtown, while Bermel was indicted for auditing the bill and for misappropriating $200.

Gen. Maximo Gomez is a constant visitor and a welcome guest of this lady, and dines with her from three to five times a week.
NEWPORT, R.I., May 3. -- Miss Gammell has returned from a visit to her farm in East Greenwich.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 3. -- The local Post Office officials to-day seized some of the pamphlets sent out by Edward Atkinson, Vice -- President of the Anti-Imperialist League of Boston.

WASHINGTON, May 3. -- Acting Secretary of War Meiklejohn, in response to an inquiry, made the announcement to-day that the capitation tax imposed by the laws and regulations issued by the Treasury Department Aug. 18, 1898, and which tax is imposed at all ports of entry upon immigrants to the United States, equally applies to all immigrants applying for entry at the ports of Cubs, Puerto Rico, and the Philippines.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, May 8. -- H.B. Van Cleave, formerly President of the Van Cleave Glass Company, and a number of other Cleveland and Pittsburg capitalists, have organized a company under the name of the Pennsylvania Window Glass Company, to oppose the Window Glass Trust. The company will construct a plant at Kane, Penn., which will be the largest window glass factory in the country outside the trust.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 3. -- Four good colts, game and true, with two more whose chances to start will be governed entirely by the weather conditions, will face the starter's flag to-morrow afternoon in the twenty-fifth renewal of the Kentucky Derby. The city is crowded with visitors, and good judges predict that the largest crowd ever seen at Churchill Downs will witness the struggle, provided the day is fair.

The Morris County Golf Club, at Morristown, N.J. resumed its customary appearance of activity yesterday, when a number of the women golf experts competed in their first contest of the year. The match was twice over the nine-hole course, as the long course will not be opened until next Saturday, and the trophy is a cup known as the Short Course Cup.

PHILADELPHIA, May 3. -- The Portuguese bark Industria, Capt. Goncalves, which sailed from Philadelphia Jan. 15 for Lisbon with 136,030 gallons of refined oil, is missing, and is believed to have foundered at sea with all hands lost, twelve in number. The Industria, it is believed, was overtaken by the February hurricane which sent to the bottom with all hands, six powerful British steamships which were en route from this country to Europe.

MADRID, May 3. -- The Cabinet Council today decided to devote 5,000,000 pesetas to improving the fortifications in the Canary Islands. The Minister of Finance, Marquis Villa Verde, read the budget proposals.

WASHINGTON, May 3. -- The Brooklyns won a close game to-day by Kelly's double and Dahlen's single in the first, and Keeler's base on balls and steal, followed by Dahlen's single in the seventh inning. The local team has a weak lot of batters, and could not take advantage of opportunities to score.

Charles E. Schuyler Co. have sold for Maxwell E. Mannes to a client the plot at the southeast corner of Broadway and Seventy-eighth Street, 51.7 by 45.2 by 51.1 by 37.9, bought by the present seller for $37,500 at the second sale of the Eno estate properties.

Women golfers in this locality who are anxious to meet others in competition and win handsome prizes now have a favorable opportunity at Lakewood, for the three-day open tournament offered for women by the Lakewood Golf Club begins to-day. The first round will be eighteen holes, the best eight players to continue at match play for the chief trophy.

ALBANY, May 3. -- Gov. Roosevelt this afternoon signed two military bills of Assemblyman Henry. The first fixes the highest rank of officers on the Governor's staff at that of Colonel. The other provides for the appointment of cooks for National Guard companies while in the field.

Alexander Masterton, seventy-two years old, a wealthy banker, whose home was in Bronxville, and who was a Director in the Farmers' Loan and Trust Company, at 22 William Street, was shot and killed shortly after 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon in a room on the third floor of the Burlington apartment house, at 10 West Thirtieth Street, by J. Neale Plumb, a retired merchant, fifty-five years old, of 70 West Thirty-eighth Street.

William Bailey who was arrested on Tuesday afternoon charged with swindling Daniel Messmore, formerly a ship owner of this city, out of $50,000, was arraigned before Magistrate Pool in the Centre Street Police Court yesterday afternoon. There were two specific charges against Bailey. One was for issuing a worthless check of $100 and the other for issuing a check for $200, also worthless.

The suit of Dr. Elias L.M. Bristol against Col. Robert G. Ingersoll came up yesterday in the Sixth Municipal District Court. Dr. Bristol is suing the lawyer and lecturer for $165, which he claims was the value of a bust of Charles Dickens. Justice Martin reserved his decision, directing the counsel to submit briefs.

MANILA, May 3. -- The Filipino envoys, Major Manuel Arguelles and Lieut. Jose Bernal, have abandoned the pretense under which they came to Gen. Otis that they represented Gen. Antonio Luna, and to-day they announced that they came as representatives of Aguinaldo himself.

Mrs. T. Benton Leiter, the wife of a nephew of L.Z. Leiter, the Chicago millionaire, is at the Imperial Hotel, having arrived from Chicago, where she made her debut as an actress about two weeks ago. Mrs. Leiter has come to New York with the intention of appearing on the local stage, but is not ready yet to announce her definite plans.

ALBANY, May 3. -- Gov. Roosevelt to-day signed Senator Marshall's bill permitting the Long Island Railroad Company to depress its tracks on Atlantic Avenue, Brooklyn, in order to connect with the proposed tunnel to be constructed under the East River. The Governor said that just as soon as the Tunnel bill was returned to him by Mayor Van Wyck he would sign it.

Presbyterian benevolences are on the high tide of prosperity. On April 1 the Board of Foreign Missions needed $252,000 in order to close its year free from debt; on April 27 it needed only $21,000, and it closed its books on Monday $10,000 ahead. In this showing New York churches bore a full share, but the contributions came from all parts of the country.

WASHINGTON, May 3. -- From an Administration source it is learned that the report of the beef inquiry is a reply in a series of answers to the questions put by the President to the members of the board. These questions it is known were not made public until about the last week of the inquiry.

Gen. WESLEY MERRITT has put upon record two opinions of Gen. RUSSELL A. ALGER. One is thirty-five years old, the other but two days. The earlier was that Gen. ALGER, then Colonel of a volunteer regiment, ought to be dishonorably dismissed from the army for persistent neglect of duty.

ALBANY, N.Y., May 3. -- The State Board of Railroad Commissioners, at its regular weekly meeting held this afternoon, received the reports of the Inspectors who inspected the Manhattan Railway Company's structure with reference to electrolysis and as to its physical condition. The board adopted the recommendations incorporated in the reports, which show only two really bad defects on the entire road.

WASHINGTON, May 3. -- The Bureau of Foreign Commerce, Department of State, has issued a bulletin on the mining law of British Columbia. Consul Smith of Victoria, in forwarding to the department a copy of this law, says that the law is of special interest at this time, in view of the discoveries of gold in the vicinity of Atlin Lake, as it prohibits the holding of claims by aliens.

The New Amsterdam Gas Company took a hand in the war of prices yesterday, and cut its figure down to 50 cents a thousand cubic feet, meeting the cut of the Consolidated and going 15 cents better. This action was taken at a meeting of the Directors, held at noon in the offices of the Louisville and Nashville Railroad, at 120 Broadway.

CHICAGO, May 3. -- According to Dr. H.W. Wiley, chief chemist of the United States Department of Agriculture, who was called to the stand to-day to testify before the Senatorial Pure Food Investigating Committee, now in session here, fully 90 per cent. of the articles of food and drink manufactured and used in this country are frauds.
CHICAGO, May 4. -- All the women members of the Oakland Good Health Club have decided to dispense with corsets and all restraining bands in the matter of dress and adopt the Grecian costume.

WARDNER, Idaho, May 4. -- Four hundred United States troops are on guard to-night in the Coeur d'Alene mining district, and martial law is in full force in Shoshone County, Idaho. Brig. Gen. H.C. Merriam, who arrived to-day from Boise, has ordered, if possible, the arrest of all those implicated in blowing up the Bunker Hill and Sullivan Mines.

The entire interest of Andrew Carnegie in the Carnegie Steel Company has been purchased by his copartners in the business, with H.C. Frick at their head. The exact figures which represent the purchase price could not be learned. It is said, however, the price is over $150,000,000, and entirely satisfactory to Mr. Carnegie.

WASHINGTON, May 4. -- The Government has decided to establish a military post at Pyramid Harbor, in Alaska. This harbor is on Chilkat Inlet, near Chilkat Village. A company of troops will be sent to the post.

WASHINGTON, May 4. -- First Assistant Postmaster General Perry S. Heath returned to-day from a month's trip of inspection in the Island of Puerto Rico. Mr. Heath says that the official report made just as he sailed showed that the postal service on the island was easily self-sustaining, and that each Post Office was getting mail at least once a day.
WASHINGTON, May 4. -- As briefly announced in THE NEW YORK TIMES this morning, Brig. Gen. Eagan has suffered the disgrace which the readers of THE TIMES were led to expect that he might suffer.

CINCINNATI, May 4. -- The Farmers' Loan and Trust Company has entered suit in the United States court against the Baltimore and Ohio Southwestern Railway Company for the general purpose of fixing the status of the claims of the plaintiff.

CHICAGO, May 4. -- One of the most important objects sought by the Senatorial Pure Food Investigating Committee at its second session here to-day, was the formulation of legislation, not solely for the protection of the public against adulterated foods manufactured in this country, but also against those which are imported.
MANILA, May 4. -- Major Gen. MacArthur has carried San Tomas, after encountering a strong resistance.
MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., May 4. -- Mrs. Charlotte Bargnet, sixty-seven years old, of 44 South Fifth Avenue, Mount Vernon, N.Y., died last evening from dropsy.

There had been no formal agreement among the Kansas men on a candidate, he said, but he believed that the greater number of them were for Sherman.

Peckit, Catasaqua, Penn.; Vice President -- Walter Kennedy, Pittsburg; General Manager -- W.L. Sims, New York; Secretary -- Glen Wright, New York; Executive Committee -- Archer Brown.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., May 4. -- The Gate City and Birmingham Rolling Mills have closed down to take stock preparatory to absorption by the Republic Iron and Steel Company'. The Thomas Furnace Company, which is also in the combination, will continue its activity, and an additional furnace will be built.

CHATTANOOGA, May 4. -- The handsome monument erected by the State of Georgia to commemorate the deeds of gallant Georgians who fought at Chickamauga was dedicated to-day. Gov. ALBANY, May 4. -- Gov. Roosevelt to-day gave a hearing on the application for a pardon for Henry Hendricks of Allegany County, who is serving a life sentence in Auburn Prison for the killing of his wife, whom, he shot to death because of his mad infatuation for another woman. WASHINGTON, May 4. -- The charge pending here against the Rev. Dr. Wesley R. Davis of New York, who was accused of issuing worthless checks, was dismissed today. NEWARK, N.J., May 4. -- Charles Norton, once a light-weight champion pugilist, died last night at his home in this city. He had been troubled for the last four years with a complication of diseases. HORACE E. DRESSER, Vice President of the Board of Education of the City of New York, has been connected with the school system of Brooklyn for many years and with the Central Board since its organization. Mr. Dresser was born in this city, June 22, 1841.

Morris Park was never more lovely than it was yesterday when Filigrane, ridden by A. Clawson, and carrying the colors of A.H. D.H. Morris, won the eighth renewal of the Metropolitan Handicap. In the last three years the race has been at a mile, and each time it has been won by a three-year-old.

-- Few of the papers forming what is known as "the religious press" are much worried by "expansion" and "the dawn of an era of militarism," but among the few is The Christian Register, and its editor recently wrote to Secretary LONG, criticising the Administration, not on theological or moral grounds, but on those of practical politics, and prophesying disaster at the next Presidential election.

LONDON, May 6. -- There are signs of awakening enthusiasm on this side of the Atlantic regarding the forthcoming America's Cup races. The owners of quite a large number of steam yachts on the Clyde have intimated their intention to attend, and there is certain to be the largest muster of British yachts ever witnessed at any contest.

Alexander Masterton, the banker of Bronxville, who was shot and killed on Wednesday by James Neale Plumb, was buried in Woodlawn Cemetery yesterday. The funeral services were held at the residence of the deceased in Bronxville, and many friends of the dead man were present. Among them was J. Ives Plumb, a son of the murderer, and who has been closely associated with the man his father killed.

SEVILLE, April 12. -- All Spaniards venerate the name of Isabel la Catolica, nor is the impressionable De Amicis the only foreigner who has trembled and wept before the enshrined memorials, jewel box, mirror, missal, and crown of her royal womanhood. She is a precious figure in poor Spain's sunset revery -- a saint beneath a conquering standard, a silken lady in a soldier's tent.
As a constant reader of your conservative paper, I would, with your permission, state my views in answer to some of your correspondents on several important subjects.

It is announced on the authority of his partners, or his late partners, that Mr. ANDREW CARNEGIE, in retiring from the business of an ironmaster, does so only in order to take up the business of a philanthropist. It was of course out of the question that Mr. CARNEGIE should "retire," except with the assistance of an undertaker.

Miss Alice Rutherford, whose portrait appears on the first page of THE NEW YORK TIMES'S MAGAZINE SUPPLEMENT, is the oldest daughter of Mrs. George Croaker. She made her debut this Winter at a large musicale given in her honor by her mother, Mrs. Crocker, at the Astoria in January. Miss Rutherford was also at the Assembly and other fashionable dances.

COLBY, Kan., May 6. -- The Winter just closing in the Northwest has been one long to be remembered by the ranchmen. Stock raisers in Colorado, Wyoming, and Idaho have many sad stories to tell of the thousands of cattle and sheep that perished on account of the severe cold and by starvation due to heavy snows on the ranges.

Police Captain Price of the West Thirtieth Street Station yesterday received half a dozen letters from friends, congratulating him that he was going to London to investigate the story of Richard T. Nicholson, a prisoner in Wormwood Scrubbs Jail, who says he killed "Dolly" Reynolds. Capt. Price said there was no intention on the part of the police authorities to send him to England.

The Ford Tax bill may be a step in the right direction, though apparently crude in many respects. No doubt it will lead to endless litigation, which is a great favor to the legal profession, and it is not unlikely to some other methods of taxation which will tend to drive from New York much that should be encouraged to remain.

BERLIN, May 6. -- The belief has taken complete possession of the public mind in Germany that German interests in Samoa have been brutally and ruthlessly disregarded both by England and the United States. It seems that this view is steadily gaining strength with nearly all classes. The press reflects the sentiment with increasing violence.

HAVANA, May 6. -- Forty thousand will be used as the divisor in fixing the shares of the soldiers in the $3,000,000 allotted by the United States Government to be divided among the Cuban troops, and the payment will begin at the end of next week, a general order declaring the payment and setting forth the rules to be observed being issued by Governor General Brooke on Monday next.

WASHINGTON, May 6. -- Gen. Corbin, who keeps pretty well informed about what the President is to do in matters affecting the army, says that it is probable that the report to the President of The Beef Court of Inquiry will be given to the press on Monday before the President leaves for Hot Springs.

CHICAGO, May 6. -- The city is busying itself at present with a series of reforms. First there was elected a reform Common Council, although it has not so far done a great deal toward reforming anything. Then came a reorganization and strengthening of the body having in charge the issue of a Greater Chicago, the measure designed to reform the town organizations of the city.

THE TIMES is doing more at the present time to encourage that spirit of broad discussion which lies at the basis of general culture than any other of our great newspapers. It opens its columns not only to those who wish to present their ideas on passing topics, but to the more scholarly class who prefer to discuss general principles, and it impartially gives all a hearing who are worth hearing.

The twenty-fifth annual Spring games of the College of the City of New York were held yesterday afternoon at Berkeley Oval. Two of the college records were broken. In the 220-yard dash Dean Stratton, '99, lowered the record of 0:23 2-5, made by W.M. Craft at Berkeley Oval on May 11, 1889, his time being 0:22 2-5.

HONOLULU, March 31. -- This, the oldest of our foreign islands, deserves more than passing mention, as it contains the possibilities that go so far toward making happy and comfortable homes for people of moderate means who have agricultural tendencies and can stand working under the heat of a tropical sun.

COLUMBIA University gymnasts have much to feel proud of over the recent exhibition given by the gymnastic teams of Yale, Princeton, and Columbia at the new Columbia gymnasium. Though the exhibition was in no sense a contest, the youthful Columbia team did not suffer in their showing with that of the veteran teams of Yale and Princeton.

The New Yorks won another game from the Washingtons at the Polo Grounds yesterday, but the score was close, 3 to 2. The victory was well earned, the locals outplaying the Washingtons. Meekin pitched a steadier game than Dineen, who is a promising youngster.

WASHINGTON, May 6. -- Edward Atkinson may not be successful in his attempt to lead the Government to abandon the Philippines and turn over the islands and their people to the care of the gifted and crafty Aguinaldo, but he may turn out to be a reformer of some very extensive printing habits acquired by Congress, and notably by the Senate.

WHEN a certain eminent and respected lawyer, Servius Sulpicius by name, died suddenly at Mutina, it was the general opinion that his public services entitled him to the posthumous honor of a statue on the Rostra. To this end his friend Cicero, after delivering an oration in praise of Sulpicius in the Senate, moved that a bronze statue be ordered.

Within the limits of the Greater New York violets have been found in such great numbers this past week that the ground was fairly carpeted with them, and the children were able to gather big bunches of them in a few moments.

THERE was always a profusion of old-fashioned blossoms in the garden that sloped from this little white house to the water's edge. My early recollection of it is of a spot where the sun shone more brightly than elsewhere. The mingled scents of the flowers and the salt sea are as fresh and sweet as the story that was enacted here years ago.

The celebration over the return of the cruiser Raleigh calls to mind that the name hitherto has not been a lucky one in the navy. The only other naval vessel that has borne that name was a Revolutionary ship, which, after getting one Captain into serious trouble, ended in the British navy.

ATLANTA, May 6. -- Capt. James Alling Colvin of 453 West One Hundred and Fiftieth Street, New York, died to-day at 11 o'clock at Fort McPherson from pneumonia, after an illness of three months. Capt. Colvin volunteered in the Spanish-American war in April, 1898, and was stationed at Camps Alger, Meade, and Greenville.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, May 6. -- The Tariff bill has pased in committee with an additional clause providing that the duration of the treaty shall be ten years, instead of the proposed reservation of the legislative right of amendment whenever expedient for obtaining American reciprocity equivalent to that conceded to Cuba and Puerto Rico.

Mayor Van Wyck yesterday reorganized the Municipal Civil Service Commission, in conformity with the recently enacted White law. The former commission was legislated out of office by this statute, which required the appointment of a board not more than two-thirds of whose members should belong to the same political party.

A great crowd of spectators, comprising a large proportion of the social element of Lakewood, spent more or less of the day yesterday on the links of the Lakewood Golf Club, watching the concluding matches of the women's open tournament. The prizes were very well divided, and the close of the games saw several fair golfers proud in their enhanced reputation and in the possession of silver trophies as testimonials of their golfing skill.

The question of a cycle path on the bridge was discussed at a meeting of the Executive Committee of the New York State Division, League of American Wheelmen, at its headquarters in this city on May 3. The death recently of a cyclist on the bridge has spurred the officers on, and resolutions were adopted urging the construction of a road for wheelmen.

The watch doctor pondered over the case, looked wise, sprinkled lavender water upon it, and then remarked solemnly, "A case of mainspring failure!" "But what is to be done about it?" said the anxious owner.
NEWPORT, May 6. -- Mrs. Walter L. Kane has rented hot place on Bellevue Avenue, Mayfield, to A. Lanfear Norrie of New York for the coming season.

Permit me to say that I made no such assertion. Had I done so there would have been no necessity for my allusion to the "lodger franchise." If Mr. Fitzgerald will read over my letter carefully, he must come to this conclusion.

It is fortunate for the cause of public enlightenment that just now questions of "privilege" and municipal ownership are coming to the front. Thanks to THE TIMES for granting so much of its space to the discussion of these important themes.

Patrick Graney, a stevedore, forty-five years old, living at 100 Tenth Avenue, an attendant at St. Bernard's Roman Catholic Church, went to the rectory of the church yesterday to pledge himself to stop drinking. Before he had signed the pledge Graney dropped dead in the hallway of the house.

THE close of the long and prosperous season of the Castle Square Opera Company suggests some thoughts which ought not to be dismissed without utterance. In the first place the success of this institution, for that is what it has become, demonstrates that it is not necessary that opera should be performed by the world's greatest artists at an immense cost.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 6. -- The third annual athletic meet of the Interscholastic League, held under the auspices of the Princeton University Athletic Association, to-day, was a marked success. Many schools sent men to compete, Berkeley winning the greatest number of points.

BUFFALO, May 6. -- The Lake Carriers' Association to-night abandoned its efforts to settle the dispute between contractor William J. Conners and the grain shovelers. The members of the State Board of Mediation and Arbitration will remain here for some time to investigate the grain shoveling business, and ascertain what truth there is to the charges made by the men concerning the abuses of the contract system.

I presume I have to deal with a lady, but cannot quite decide whether to consider her the daughter of churchly parents or a simple devotee of homeopathy; the latter supposition seems to gain color from her proposed treatment of the Briggs controversy.

The annual Spring athletic games of Columbia University students were held yesterday afternoon at Columbia Oval. Despite the fact that a strong north wind was blowing, two of the college's records were broken.

The early Summer or suburban season may be said to have formally opened yesterday, with the first day of the Morris Park meeting. The Spring season, which was really no season at all, ended last week, and now begins the interregnum between the Spring season and that of the watering places, which will last until after the Fourth of July has passed.

It was reported yesterday that Bishop Potter might decide that no formal notice to the clergy of the ordination of Dr. Briggs is necessary, and that he would proceed with the services with the least possible publicity. When Dr. Briggs was ordained as a deacon no notice of the proposed ordination was given, the ceremony taking place quietly in Grace Church on a weekday morning.

The auxiliary cruiser Yosemite, with Capt. Richard P. Leary, United States Navy, Governor of Guam, and Commander of the Eastern Division of the Asiatic fleet, aboard, sailed from the Brooklyn Navy Yard yesterday afternoon for the Ladrone Islands, the scene of Capt. Leary's new duties.

PARIS, April 28. -- There is practically no further doubt that the decision in the Dreyfus case will be rendered by the Court of Cassation by June 1, but not before. As the evidence is published by the Figaro day by day the confusion increases on account of the French habit of allowing all sorts of irrelevant matters to be introduced into legal examinations.

Many thousands of persons evinced deep interest in the ceremonies attending the consecration of the new Church of the Holy Trinity, in Eighty-eighth Street, between First and Second Avenues, yesterday morning. Admission to the church was restricted by card, but the streets adjacent to the imposing group of buildings which comprise this Rhinelander Memorial, were for a while densely crowded.

A decision was handed down yesterday by Justice Bookstaver, in the Supreme Court, in a case which he characterizes as "peculiar and interesting," involving the question as to which of the members of a family who perished in a fire can be considered the survivors. The suit was brought by Mary Merritt to determine the claims of E. Osborne Smith and Peter Quinn to a dozen lots in the Borough of the Bronx.

The publication of the will of the late ANTONIO EUSEBIO TERRY raises anew a question that has been raised a great many times before. Because it contains the clause, unhappily too familiar, that if the widow marries again "she loses her interest."

THE story of the New York City Fire Department is one of thrilling adventures and gallant deeds, which follow each other in a regular train from the days when the department was first organized. It has been a long period and takes one as far back as 1731, when the good ship Beaver brought over from London two fire engines, with which the department began its career.

Nobody will accuse the Secretary of the Wireless Telegraph Company of exaggeration when he says that Sir THOMAS LIPTON and the authorities of Great Britain and the United States feel an intense interest in the company's plans for transmitting messages across the Atlantic Ocean without wires on the occasion of the yacht races for the America's Cup.

ROSLYN, L.I., May 6. -- Mrs. William C. Whitney died at her country home, at Westbury, at 12:30 o'clock this afternoon. Death was caused by paralysis, due to a dislocation of the cervical vertebrae, the result of an accident near Aiken, S.C., on Feb. 21, 1898. Mrs. Whitney had been unconscious since yesterday morning.

With the ensuing week, which promises to be unusually productive, the New York theatrical season of 1898-9 may be said to close. To be sure, most of the theatres will be open for a few weeks more. "Zaza" and "The Great Ruby" and "Colinette" will survive the season. Operetta and spectacular extravaganza know no season. For that matter, the beginning and ending of a theatrical season nowadays are never clearly defined.

WASHINGTON, May 6. -- Before the end of the next fiscal year the Government will bring to a close the publication of a great work, the "War of the Rebellion -- Record of the Union and Confederate Armies." Many persons who have seen the long lines of books with this title gradually filling up shelf after shelf of libraries have doubtless wondered whether it was ever to come to an end.

WASHINGTON, May 6. -- Naval officers have better opportunities, perhaps, than any other class of Government officers to accumulate rare and interesting objects, either for the illustration of some study or for the adornment of their homes. Some of them do collect, but the habit of systematic collection is not common in the naval service.

HAVANA, May 6. -- Utterances attributed to Gen. Lacret and other of the Assemblist leaders, published here to-day, are regarded as tending to inflame the minds of the Cubans against the United States, and to incite them to outlawry.

NEWPORT, May 6. -- Henry Bull died at sis home here this morning, in his eighty-fourth year. He was sixth in direct descent from Henry Bull, one of the original settlers of Newport, in 1639, and at one time Governor of the Colony of Rhode Island.

John P. Holland, inventor of the submarine torpedo boat, arrived here yesterday on the Cunard Line steamship Etruria. Mr. Holland has been abroad for his health. He denied yesterday that he had gone to England to sell to the British Government his invention.

Pando sent from his army at Sicasica 120 men, commanded by Arturo Ekuino, to Ayopaya, there to confer with Mr. Orellama as to the best means for simultaneously attacking Cochabama.

WASHINGTON, May 6. -- Solicitor General Richards has rendered an opinion in the case of an importer who declined to answer certain interrogatories propounded by the Appraiser of Merchandise at New York, under the authority conferred by Sections 16 and 17 of the Customs Administation act, as to the price at which the goods were sold.

Miss Bessie Challenger of Matthews and Bulger's "By the Sad Sea Waves" Company, who has been performing the part of Sis Hopkins since Miss Rose Melville left the company, on April 22, and Thomas W. Ryley, one of the managers of the company, were arrested yesterday and arraigned before Commissioner Shields on .the charge of violating the copyright law.

WASHINGTON, May 6. -- No further advices have reached the State Department from Samoa, and it is believed that none will now be had until the Eastern mail arrives, in about five days' time. The commission is due at Apia next Wednesday, and the department information is that there is no danger of further outbreaks meanwhile.

BERLIN, April 26. -- No measure presented in the Riechstag has ever encountered such a chorus of criticism as the Meat Inspection bill, which, after a two days' debate, has been referred to a committee of twenty-one members. Yet very few members were present at any time during the debate, and certainly at no instant was a quorum in attendance.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, May 6. -- The announcement is made here to-day that the officers of the Republic Steel Company will be as follows: President -- August Belmont, New York; First Vice President and Chairman of the Executive Board -- Myron C. Wyck, Youngstown; Treasurer -- John F. Taylor, Youngstown.

ST. PETERSBURG, April 21. -- The university troubles in St. Petersburg have taken on much the same character as the old-time "town and gown" rivalry in English university towns. The leniency of the Minister of Public Education toward the students at the time of the recent riots has had the opposite from the desired result.

IRENE VANBRUGH seems to have made an indisputable personal hit in the character of Sophie Fullgarney in Mr. Pinero's new comedy, "The Gay Lord Quex." Miss Vanbrugh was here some years ago with her sister Violet and her sister's husband. Arthur Bourchier.

Robert Taber, the husband of Miss Julia Marlowe, now playing an engagement in this city at the Knickerbocker Theatre, arrived yesterday on the American Liner Paris. Efforts were made to secure a statement from Mr. Taber as to the truth of the report that either he or his wife was about to sue for a separation. Mr. Taber said that the matter was a personal affair and he declined to discuss it.

It will celebrate to-day its one-hundredth birthday as a finished church, and an elaborate programme of special exercises and speakers has been arranged for services to-day and at other times during the week.

During the week the market waited for crop developments and export indications, and but for weakness in corn, wheat would have held its own.

COOPERSTOWN, N.Y., May 7. -- Horatio L. Olcott of Brooklyn committed suicide by laudanum at the Central Hotel in this place last night. He arrived here Saturday at noon and in the afternoon went for a drive. He purchased an ounce of laudanum at a drug store and returned to his room about 5 o'clock.

To-day's meetings were held in the Auditorium, Central Music Hall, and the First Methodist Church, and in spite of the in-element weather the aggregate of attendance was probably 10,000.

Coney Island and the beaches on Staten Island drew the majority of excursionists, but the trolley cars to Mount Vernon and Yonkers were also largely patronized.

DENVER, May 7. -- Gov. Thomas has announced that within a few days, if President McKinley and the Secretary of War continue to ignore his communications on the subject of the withdrawal of the Colorado regiment from the Philippines, he will take steps with a view to securing the immediate recall of the troops.

The New England Puritans have been more blamed for their treatment of the Quakers than for anything else they did. It is that which is chiefly responsible for the charge of bigotry and religious intolerance that is brought against them.

TOLEDO, May 7. -- The German-Americans of the city held a monster mass meeting this afternoon to protest against the proposed British-American alliance. Speeches were made by the leading Germans of the city. Before the meeting was over a division arose, and there was a heated discussion in which a great many of those present indulged, and the object of the meeting was lost sight of, many leaving the hall.

DULUTH, Minn., May 7. -- The damage done the rolling stock of the street railway company by mobs in different parts of the city to-night was greater than that of all of last week. More than 100 car windows were broken and three persons were injured.

Goulder of Cleveland, attorney for the Lake Carriers' Association, and Mr. Douglass, representing the Western Elevating Association, called on Bishop Quigley of the Catholic Diocese of Buffalo to-day and asked him to endeavor to induce the grain shovelers to accept the proposition made by Contractor Connors.

Dr. Peters took for his subject "The Jew as a Patriot." He said: "One of the gravest charges ever brought against the Jew is that he is not and cannot be a patriot.

There is some activity to be found in spots, and it may be said that the market has secured a fair business during the past week if the situation is averaged up.

ALBANY, May 7. -- By command of the Governor, Adjt. Gen. Andrews has issued an order directing Major Clinton H. Smith of the Seventy-first Regiment, who was Lieutenant Colonel in the volunteer organization, to appear before a board of examination organized to inquire into his moral character, capacity, and general fitness for service in the National Guard as a commissioned officer.

The women of the Morris County Golf Club at Morristown, N.J., will play over the long course for the first time on Wednesday. The contest will be the first of a series for a trophy known as the "Long Course"' Cup, which will be played for on alternate Wednesdays during the season.

In celebration of the centennial of the consecration of the edifice in which they still worship, the congregation of St. Mark's Protestant Episcopal Church began yesterday morning commemorative exercises which were continued at the evening service and which will be concluded to-morrow. It was on May 9, 1799, that the present church of St. Mark's was consecrated by the Right Rev. Samuel Provoost, the then Bishop of the diocese.

SPOKANE, Washington, May 7. -- Mine owners of Shoshone County, Idaho, that propose to operate during the reign of martial law may do so only on condition that they do not employ members of the Coeur d'Alene Miners' Union. This is the rule as laid down by Gen. Merriam and Attorney Gen. Hayes of Idaho. At a meeting of the mine owners in this city this morning Mr. Hayes presented this mandate.

Ezra F. Merrill, one of the best-known figures at Coney Island, where he was proprietor of the chutes and toboggan slides, died yesterday from the effects of an accident he met with on Wednesday last, on one of the slides. He was connecting a car, and was pushing it up the slide. He slipped, and the car ran back upon him, striking him in the abdomen with great force.

WASHINGTON, May 7. -- By direction of the President, who approves the findings, Acting Secretary of War Meiklejohn to-day made public the report and findings of the military court appointed to investigate the charges made by Major General Miles, commanding the army, that the beef supplied to the army during the war with Spain, was unfit for the use of the troops. The court has been dissolved.

The Rev. Dr. Newell Dwight Hillis continued last night in Plymouth Church, Brooklyn, his series of sermons on "Great Books and Great Authors." His subject was "John Ruskin's 'Seven Lamps of Architecture' as Interpreters of the Seven Laws of Life: A Study of the Principles of Character Building."

I think our naval officers make the proper distinction between "squadron" and "fleet." The distinction is also made in England, both by officers and by civilians, whereas our civilian officers, our people, and the press usually seem to make little discrimination between the two words.

MANILA, May 7. -- To clear the Filipinos out of Bacolor, about five miles southwest of San Fernando, will be the next task of the Americans. The rebel General Mascardo has a force of 6,000 men there, well armed and possessed of plenty of ammunition. His troops have never met American soldiers, and they think, according to reports carried to San Fernando, that they can "whip the whole lot."
NEWPORT, R.I., May 7. -- Sidney Webster is here having his recently purchased estate Pencraig made ready for occupancy.

The Rev. Dr. Charles A. Briggs, whose proposed ordination as a priest in the Protestant Episcopal Church is now the subject of so much discussion and controversy, occupied the pulpit of Holy Trinity Church of Harlem, at One Hundred and Twenty-second Street and Lenox Avenue, yesterday morning.

The auxiliary cruiser Buffalo, still decked in her gray war paint, steamed into New York Harbor in the faint light of early morning yesterday, bringing 597 souls from Manila, and an appropriate number of monkeys, dogs, and other mascots. Commander Joseph N. Hemphill had charge of her, with Lieut. Samuel W.B. Diehl as executive officer and Lieut. George W. Logan as navigator.

WASHINGTON, May 7. -- Senors J. Julio Henna and Manuel Zeno Gandia, Commissioners from Puerto Rico to the United States, have presented a second memorial to the President, reiterating the prayers of their first petition. They ask the following concessions.
The work of the little detachment of regulars in Idaho during the past week contains a lesson that the antiquated critics of a "standing army" would do well to ponder.

Ellen Young, sixty-two years old, with no home, died Saturday, in the House of the Good Shepherd. She was committed there by Magistrate Pool, in the Centre Street Court, on Friday, on a charge of intoxication. Yesterday afternoon Coroner's Physician O'Hanlon made an autopsy upon the body, and, instead of intoxication, he found that the woman had been suffering from acute pneumonia, which caused a delirium which the police mistook for intoxication.

Concluding a series of articles on the financial and industrial situation in the United States, Mr. George Paish of The London Statist sends to his paper an interesting discussion upon the likelihood of continuance of prosperity in this country. After reviewing and commenting upon the causes of the depression existing from 1893 to 1896, Mr. Paish writes:

-- People who are troubled by the quotations from soldier letters out of which the copperhead press is making so much should bear in mind certain facts, Most important of these is the fact that the tales of prisoners summarily executed and of villages looted are far from numerous, and have been made to appear so only by persistent repetition.

The Grand Jury resumed its investigations yesterday into the case of Roland B. Molineux, accused of the murder of Mrs. Kate J. Adams. The day closed with the investigation still unfinished, although it is expected that a decision will be reached this morning. During the morning it was said things looked favorable for the prisoner, but late in the afternoon it was reported that the investigation would culminate in the finding of an indictment.

Dr. Charles F. Roberts, Superintendent of the Sanitary Bureau, will apply to Magistrate Pool this morning for a warrant for the arrest of Mrs. Maria Miller of 312 East Twelfth Street, the Faith Cure doctor who attended twelve-year-old Lizzie Kranz, who is now reported to be dying of gangrene at the Eastern District Hospital, Brooklyn.

There was a hearing in the office of President Coogan of the Borough of Manhattan yesterday on a proposed ordinance regulating the height of buildings, which was drawn up under the direction of a committee of the Board of Trade and Transportation. The members of all the local Boards of Improvements in the borough were invited to attend, but not more than a dozen were present.

MOUNT VERNON, May 8. -- Coroner Banning and a jury to-day held an inquest in the case of Mrs. Charlotte M. Barguet, who died on Wednesday of dropsy, and who, it is claimed, was treated by Christian Scientists. Pascal T. Barguet, a son of the woman, testified that he had asked that his mother have a regular physician, but she refused to have one.

The Mayor to-morrow gives a hearing on the Long Island Tunnel bill. The public interest, the comfort and prosperity of the people of Brooklyn and its outlying towns demand the construction of this tunnel. The project calls for no expenditure of public funds. The tunnel will be built, equipped, and operated by private capital.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., May 8. -- The United States Flour Manufacturing Company to-day announced its intention to immediately double the capacity of three mills it recently acquired in this city, and possibly to build one more in addition. The mills in question formerly belonged to the Minneapolis Flour Manufacturing Company, and have a capacity of 5,000 barrels daily.

HAVANA, May 8. -- Major Gen. Wilson, Military Governor of the new Department of Matanzas-Santa Clara, has visited within the last ten days every railway point in Santa Clara Province, and has seen every Alcalde, Judge, priest, school teacher, banker, and important planter in the localities he has visited.

MANILA, May 8. -- The army's gunboats Laguna de Bay and Cavadonga, under command of Capt. Grant, which started up the San Fernando River for Guagua yesterday, presumably to establish there a base of supplies for the troops engaged in the northern campaign, returned to-day, Major Gen. MacArthur having failed to connect with the expedition.
WASHINGTON, May 8. -- Gen. Miles again to-day refused to comment upon the report of the army beef court of inquiry. When questioned in regard to his probable action in the matter, he replied:

I have just read your report of the sermon which the Rev. Dr. Briggs preached yesterday on the Holy Spirit. It was evidently prepared with a view to the present controversy respecting his ordination in the Episcopal Church, and intended to make it appear that he is a perfectly safe teacher.
BOSTON, May 8. -- The Executive Committee of the Anti-Imperialist League to-day adopted the following letter, to be sent to Edward Atkinson:

ORLEANS, May 8. -- The annual celebration of the deliverance of Orleans by Joan of Arc was held here to-day with the customary ceremonies. A salute of twenty-one guns was fired at sunrise, and all the bells in the city were rung. At 10 o'clock the municipal and other bodies went to the cathedral, which was decked with flowers and flags, as is the custom on grand occasions.

WASHINGTON, May 8. -- The Navy Department has selected a successor to Admiral Dewey to command the Asiatic station. Orders were issued to-day detaching Rear Admiral Watson from command of the Mare Island Navy Yard and ordering him to report to Admiral Dewey at Manila to relieve that officer when he feels that he can be spared there.

CHARLESTON, S. C., May 8. -- The annual reunion of the United Confederate Veterans will begin here Wednesday morning. Accommodations have been prepared for 35,000 people, and it is believed that fully that many will attend the exercises. Gen. John B. Gordon, Commander in Chief, arrived to-night, and Gens. Wade Hampton, Stephen D. Lee, and C. A. Evans, commanders of divisions, are also here.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 8. -- Attorney General Monnett this afternoon filed in the Supreme Court his answer to the motion of the Standard Oil Company requesting that he designate the persons alluded to in his statement that he had been approached with offers of bribes to dismiss the suits against the company, and named Charles B. Squires, formerly of Cleveland and now of New York, as the person through whom the alleged proposition was made.

Henry Hart, the Vice President of the Third Avenue Railroad Company, has sold all of the stock of the Fifth Avenue Coach Company, of which he is the President, to another corporation. The sale was made through the banking house of Strong, Sturgis Co.

The Presbytery of New York, in session at the First Presbyterian Church, yesterday, decided by a vote of 54 to 11 against the proposed consolidation of the Thirteenth Street and Fourth Avenue churches. As a result of this action, the Rev. Dr. Walter D. Buchanan, pastor of the Thirteenth Street Church, who has been an ardent advocate of the consolidation, is expected to resign, and the dismemberment of the congregation is threatened.

" He knows no more than a good-sized yellow dog," is a proverb denoting great stupidity on the part of a man, but the yellow dog of which Mr. Bergen tells in a late number of THE TIMES certainly forms an exception, and his intelligence has been far exceeded by other canines. In the old Christy minstrel show, for instance, the end man asks: "Bones, what's come o' that big dawg yo' used to had?"

OTTAWA, Ontario, May 8. -- The case of Thomas Meagher, who was seized on the Detroit River near Port Huron, tied to a bedpost, and afterward put in jail, where he lay for six days, came up in the Commons to-night.

Tammany Hall does not intend to recede from the position it assumed in regard to the Ford Franchise Tax bill, and at the hearing on the measure, which will take place before the Governor on Thursday, a committee of members of the organization, with as many of the Democratic Assemblymen and Senators as can get away, will appear and urge Mr. Roosevelt to sign the bill.

NEWARK, May 8. -- The Democratic Association of New Jersey filed articles of incorporation to-day. The incorporators are J.W. Shuckers, G.C. Callingwood, Tyler Gormly, Benjamin F. Robey, Miles W. Evans, Joseph H. Wehrle, Edward Wilde, and J.W. Arrowsmith. The object of the association is the maintenance and promotion of the principles enunciated in the Chicago platform.

Through your columns to-day there comes a wall of anguish that probably strikes a responsive chord in the hearts of all -- who own carriages. But there are men innumerable in our city possessing all the qualities of good citizens with whom the possession of a carriage is a matter of no importance.

ALBANY, May 8. -- At the Executive Mansion to-night at 8:50 o'clock Gov. Roosevelt pressed a button that set in motion the entire machinery which is being used in the electrical exhibition at Madison Square Garden, in New York City. The wires of the Postal Telegraph Company of this city were used to transmit the Governor's signal under the direction of Manager Edson Kimmey.

ALBANY, May 8. -- The statistics relative to the thirty-day bills, which are the measures left in the Governor's hands by the Legislature when that body adjourned, shows that 289 bills of this character were transmitted to the Governor for his signature and that there now remain in his hands 184 bills.

The steamship Esquimaux, owned and fitted out by Mr. Walker, the late proprietor of the yacht Ailsa, has sailed from Dundee for the whaling grounds. Mr. Walker will join the vessel when she touches at St. John's, N.F. The Esquimaux has been specially fitted, and the owner is undertaking the trip for pleasure.

MASSILLON, Ohio, May 8. -- A fire originating at 8 o'clock to-night through spontaneous combustion, burned Russel Co.'s immense paintshop and threshing machine warehouse. The building contained several hundred finished machines and a large quantity of paints. The loss is estimated at $500,000, partially covered by insurance.

WASHINGTON, May 8. -- Secretary Long has received the following letter from Rear Admiral Tirpitz, Minister of Marine in the German Cabinet, expressive of the good feeling prevailing in the highest naval quarters of Germany toward the United States naval authorities:

The Washingtons were beaten for the third consecutive time by the New Yorks at the Polo Grounds yesterday afternoon, the locals earning a victory through good fielding, base running, and timely hitting. The game was uncomfortably close for seven innings, but after that the New Yorks drew away and won easily by a score of 6 to 2.

Suppose the son of Lady Henry Somerset should succeed to the dukedom of Beaufort, will he be a "serious English Duke" because he is a Harvard man or because he is, "like his mother, of evangelical tendencies," (whatever that may mean,) or because, as is the fact, he takes himself very seriously?

HAVANA, May 8. -- President McKinley, through Adjt. Gen. Corbin, has instructed Governor General Brooke to make the North American Trust Company here the depository of all the funds of the Government in the island. The money now in the strong rooms of the Custom House will be moved to the bank.
The Spring rifle practice of the First, Second, and Fifth Brigades of the National Guard began at Creedmoor, L.I., yesterday. The weather was conducive to good shooting.

LONDON, May 8. -- United States Ambassador Joseph H. Choate was the central figure at the annual meeting to-day of the British and Foreign Sailors' Society at the Mansion House. The Lord Mayor presided, and the assemblage was a brilliant one. The Duke of Fife, in introducing Mr. Choate, said: "I ask you to give a warm and vigorous welcome to one of America's most brilliant sons.

NEWARK, May 8. -- There was an unusual scene in the Church of the Immaculate Conception at Montclair yesterday. As the congregation was about to leave, the Rev. Father Joseph F. Mendl told the people to wait, as he wished to make an example of some one. This was a boy named James Bray.

Maude Adams acted Shakespeare's Juliet for the first time in her life at the Empire Theatre last night, after a year's study of the role. The immediate result was a prodigious triumph. At the hands (literally speaking) of an audience of extraordinary quality, but somewhat overemphatic in the expression of its enthusiasm, the young actress received a mighty tribute.

A will contest containing many unusual features was that commenced yesterday before Surrogate Fitzgerald. The will is that of Dr. Thomas Seaton Robertson, who died Sept. 6, 1898. At the time the will was executed he had a suit pending against his wife for limited divorce on the ground of abandonment, and nothing was bequeathed to her.

NEWPORT, May 8. -- During the visit of the North Atlantic Squadron here the latter part of the month a series of torpedo boat attacks at night will be carried on with the Dupont, the Morris, and the Stiletto, which are now at the torpedo station, and which will shortly be reinforced by the Porter and the Winslow.

WASHINGTON, May 8. -- The War Department has received from Gen. Otis a dispatch giving the situation in the Philippines, some parts of which have been omitted in making it public. The dispatch, as given out, is as follows:

A formal and public protest against the ordination of the Rev. Dr. Charles A. Briggs as a clergyman of the Protestant Episcopal Church was made yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Benjamin F. De Costa, who, in speaking of the matter, said that he was not acting for himself alone, but for a number of others who oppose the ordination.

The New York members of the Society of the Sons of the American Revolution are to have an opportunity of expressing their disapproval of the action of the Michigan Society in inviting Secretary of War Alger to a dinner in Detroit last week, and converting the occasion into a demonstration in favor of Mr. Alger.

As a fairly constant reader of your paper and an admirer of the ability which has given New York an example of an able, clean, and dignified one-cent daily newspaper, allow me to ask you to specify the statements in Mr. ATKINSON'S famous pamphlets which you regard as being seditious or treasonable. I trust that you will answer frankly and directly without recourse to generalities or poking fun at Mr. ATKINSON.

The bungalow in which Kipling lived at Lahore was like ninety-nine out of a hundred Punjab bungalows, a one-storied building of about eight rooms, all communicating with each other, with a veranda on each of the four sides. The points in which it differed from other bungalows are given in the story of "Naboth," in "Life's Handicap" -- a story founded on fact for the encroachments of Naboth on the Kipling shrubbery were certainly grievous.

The Taxameter Syndicate, which is endeavoring to bring its cab-fare indicators into use in London, sends us a copy of a report drawn up by the British Consul General in Berlin on their introduction and working in Germany. This report has been independently obtained and no payment beyond the ordinary Consular fees has been made in connection with it.

LONDON, May 8. -- The Spring season of grand opera under the management of Maurice Grau was brilliantly inaugurated at Covent Garden Opera House to-night. When the curtain rose the entire chorus, grouped around a statue of the Queen, sang the national anthem.

Dr. Hans Hogelsberg, formerly President of the Investors' Guarantee and Trust Company, which had offices in the Lord's Court Building, at William Street and Exchange Place, in this city, is now under arrest in Los Angeles, Cal., with the prospect of returning to New York within a few days to answer to charges of swindling.

BERLIN, May 8. -- It is announced authoritatively that the committee of the Reichstag to which was referred the Meat Inspection bill, which was substantially agreed upon between the Imperial Cabinet and the United States Ambassador here, Andrew D. White, has reported against the measure and in favor of a bill so hostile to American interests that the Government probably will refuse to sanction it.

PLAINFIELD, May 8. -- What appears to have been an attempt to poison the family of T.D. Moran of Regent Street, North Plainfield, was made on Saturday. The family buys milk of B.R. Waldron of Coddington Avenue. The milk was left on the stoop, as usual, Saturday morning. Mr. Moran's sister drank some of it before it had been served to the other members of the family, and became very sick.

MUNCIE, Ind., May 8. -- The statement is nosy positively made that the mam mot:h window glass combine will be completed during the next few days and details of the scheme hitherto kept from the public have been brought to light. Glass men now regard it as settled that the American Window Glass Association, which goes out of existence iVIay 30, will be supplanted by the American Glass Company.

NEWPORT, R.I., May 8. -- The funeral of Henry Bull, father of Dr. William T. Bull and Congressman Melville Bull, occurred from the family homestead this afternoon, and was largely attended by the leading citizens of the city and State. The Episcopal burial service was conducted by the Rev. Mr. Gilliatt, pastor of St. George's Church. The interment was made privately at the Island Cemetery.

TOLEDO, Ohio, May 8. -- P.F. Whalen, one of the largest paint manufacturers in the country, said to-day that the purpose of the meeting to be held at the Auditorium in Chicago was to raise the price of paint all over the country. He also said that a combination might result from the meeting.

The incorporation at Trenton, N.J., yesterday of the Kern Incandescent Light Company is a new feature in the gas-rate war now going on in this city, and one which its promoters assert will make gas at the prevailing rates quite as profitable to the warring companies as it was at $1.10. The capital stock of the company, as stated in THE NEW YORK TIMES of yesterday, is $12,000,000.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 8. -- C.S. Bradford of this city, who has just returned from the Philippines, gives an account of the death of Prince Ludwig von Loewenstein, who was killed in the battle of Caloocan on Sunday, March 26.

NANTUCKET, Mass., May 8. -- Major L.C. Overman, formerly an officer in the United States Army, was instantly killed by falling from a staging on which he was at work at his Summer home here to-day. Mrs. Overman is at the Hotel St. George, Brooklyn, N.Y.

Nothing could be less like a politician, nothing could be more like a brave and honest man, than the remarks of Gov. ROOSEVELT upon the behavior of the Seventy-first Regiment at Santiago. A politician in his place would have gone into computations about the National Guard "vote," and the undesirableness of repelling it.

GUTHRIE, Oklahoma Territory, May 8. -- The cyclone which passed over Canadian County destroyed at least twenty farmhouses and caused great damage to growing crops. At Chickasaw seventeen buildings were wrecked and fourteen persons injured. J. H. Murray, a railroad man, who was caught under falling timbers, died of his injuries.

LOS ANGELES, Cal., May 8. -- Dr. Hogelsburg, who was arrested here yesterday and held at the request of the New York police to answer charges of grand larceny in connection with the conduct of the Investors' Guarantee and Trust Company, admits that he is the man wanted and that he fled from New York when he found he was short.

Sir: Referring to the particulars you gave in your issue of yesterday of the Lake Lefroy bicycle mail stamp, it may also be interesting to stamp collectors to know its history. I was one of the pioneers of the Red Hill Goldfield, (Lake Lefroy,) which was discovered in December, 1896, and is situated about forty-five miles from Coolgardie, Western Australia.

There was uncommon weakness all along the line in the stock market yesterday, and the most active operators in the Stock Exchange were the bearish brokers who are ordinarily credited with being followers of James R. Keene. As "the Street" interpreted the situation yesterday's slump in prices was the result of a concerted attack by Mr. Keene and his followers on the "bull" stronghold of ex-Gov. Roswell P. Flower and his extensive following.

CHICAGO, May 8. -- Further evidence that the United States at present is being used by other countries as a "dumping ground" for adulterated products of food and drink was given to-day before the Senatorial Pure Food Investigation Committee by Graeme Stuart of the W.M. Hoyt Company of this city.

A fire that blazed fiercely for two hours last evening destroyed the mattress and furniture factory of Levy Abrahams at 358 and 360 Broome Street, and from the time of the discovery of the fire until it was finally under control nearly 2,000 Italians living in the adjoining tenements on Broome and Elizabeth Streets were rendered homeless.

Great activity and sharp declines characterized yesterday's stock market. At times almost panicky conditions seemed about to rule. Many specialties were under extraordinary pressure, and nine out of ten stocks dealt in fell more or less.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, May 8. -- The Leader will say to-morrow:

BUFFALO, May 8. -- The strike situation to-night is practically unchanged. All efforts made to bring about a settlement have been balked by the absolute refusal of the strikers to consider any proposition that did not include the abrogation of the Conners contracts and the refusal of the Lake Carriers' Association to cancel the contract.

It developed yesterday that some of the crimps who have been fighting the ship owners resorted to overt methods on Sunday afternoon, when a body of boarding and shipping masters and their runners forcibly boarded the American ship Benjamin F. Packard, at anchor off Stapleton, S.I., and set upon another boarding master who had refused to join them in their fight and was supplying the crew to Capt. Zach.

A blanket of orchids covered the casket containing the body of Mrs. William C. Whitney during the funeral services in the Cathedral of the Incarnation, at Garden City, yesterday forenoon. Mrs. Whitney was very fond of orchids. There were wreaths, crosses, and pillows of orchids, and in the front part of the chancel stood a large cross of orchids intertwined with tender vines.

The Rev. Dr. R. Heber Newton has recently taken a lively interest in psychical research and phenomena, and, according to his own statement, he has made a number of experiments which he says have proved to him that a power exists of which little is as yet known. In his researches Dr. Newton has made visits to spiritualistic mediums and has attended numerous seances. Both, he says, are largely humbugs.

LONDON, May 9. -- The Duchess of York, accompanied by the Duke of Connaught and Mr. George J. Goschen, First Lord of the Admiralty, and others, launched the new royal yacht Victoria and Albert at Pembroke this afternoon. After the usual prayers, the Duchess severed a cord and the yacht glided into the water amidst vociferous cheering.
APIA, Samoa, May 4, (via Auckland, N. Z., May 9.) -- Everything is quiet on the island. Operations have been suspended pending the arrival of the Joint Commissioners from San Francisco.

The contract for dredging the East Channel in the lower bay for the improvement of navigation, which has been awarded by the United States Government to Andrew Onderdonk, will be signed to-day or to-morrow. The preliminary work has already been begun in the way of plans and estimates, and Mr. Onderdonk said last night that he expected the actual work of dredging would be under way by the latter part of the year.

WILMINGTON, Del., May 9. -- Six masked burglars early this morning overpowered Emil Meyer, the watchman, and Frederick Festing, the engineer, at the Bavarian Brewery, at Fifth and Dupont Streets, and then blew open the safe in the office, securing over $1,400, $500 of which was in cash.

DETROIT, Mich., May 9. -- Negotiations for municipal ownership of Detroit's street railways have come to a halt. The situation to-night gives little apparent hope for reaching an agreement as to price and terms of purchase between the city's Street Railway Commissioners and the owners of the street railways.

"We 'Uns of Tennessee" is the not too attractive title of an American drama of a very familiar brand, produced with much elaboration of detail at the American Theatre last evening to begin a "supplementary dramatic season" which is likely to be short. "We 'Uns of Tennessee" will not do.
In connection with the Memorial Day parade, the following orders were issued yesterday at the headquarters of the National Guard:

NEWPORT, R.I., May 9. -- It is reported here to-day that Mr. and Mrs. Potter Palmer have taken a lease of Mr. W.W. Astor's cottage, Beaulieu, on the cliffs for the coming season. The lease of the villa was consummated by the Palmers direct with Mr. Astor in Europe, and it is said that the wedding of Miss Grant to Prince Cantacuzene of Russia will occur at Beaulieu late this season.

THE NEW YORK TIMES, referring in its news columns yesterday morning to a decision of the Internal Revenue Department sent to Collector C.H. Treat in this city bearing upon the stamp tax on assignments on stock certificates, stated that "the usual form" of assignment on certificates was, according to the decision, not subject to the tax of 25 cents.

BUFFALO, May 9. -- While the strike situation remains unchanged there is still a hope for a speedy settlement of the trouble. To-night it was learned that the Lake Carriers' Association and Contractor Conners are willing to make concessions of a radical kind to the scoopers.

The exercises commemorative of the one hundredth anniversary of the consecration of St. Mark's Protestant Episcopal Church, which began on Sunday, were concluded yesterday with a historical service held in the church at high noon, at which the Rev. Dr. Morgan Dix, rector of Trinity Parish, delivered an address.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 9. -- The Standard Oil Company won a point in the Supreme Court to-day when a decision was handed down dismissing the contempt proceedings against Malcolm Jennings, a newspaper man.
The Stevens Real Estate Company has sold for Andrew J. Kerwin, Jr., to John O. Baker the plot 75 by 100 at the southeast corner of Broadway and One Hundred and Second Street.

BALTIMORE, May 9. -- The third triennial assembly of the General Council of the Society of Colonial Wars commenced its sessions to-day at the Hotel Rennert. Delegates are present representing seventeen States where the society now exists. Routine meetings were held in the morning and afternoon, and in the evening a dinner was given at the Maryland Club to the delegates by George Norbury Mackenzie.

WASHINGTON, May 9. -- The United States and Great Britain will stand together in the advocacy of the adoption of a scheme for the settlement of international disputes by arbitration, which will be presented to the Peace Conference at its meeting at The Hague on the 16th of the present month.

PHILADELPHIA, May 9. -- Three two-base hits and a single in the first inning won to-day's game for the Baltimores. Fifield was batted freely thoughout the game, but sharp fielding by the Philadelphias kept the Baltimores score down to 4 runs. Both teams played a clean fielding game.
LONDON, May 9. -- Sir Henry Irving, owing to the fatiguing character of the performance, has found it expedient to discontinue matinees of Sardou's "Robespierre," at the Lyceum Theatre.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., May 9. -- President McKinley has had a day of rest and comfort at the Hotel Homestead here. Official business did not intrude to disturb him, nor did importunate callers crowd to seek his favor. The guests seemed to know that his object was freedom from exertion, and this they accorded him.
The text of the report of the committee appointed by the Presbytery to confer with and counsel the congregation of the West Presbyterian Church was made public yesterday. It is as follows:

PRINCETON, May 9. -- The eighty-seventh annual commencement of the Princeton Theological Seminary ended to-day. Sixty-eight new ministers are now licensed to preach. President Ethelbert Warfield of Lafayette College delivered the address on behalf of the Directors. Dr. Joseph Smith of Baltimore conferred the diplomas. Seven graduates received the degree of Bachelor of Divinity. Dr. William Henry Green addressed the class for the Faculty.

CHICAGO, May 9. -- Forty-five paint manufacturers, representing leading paint grinding concerns in the United States, met yesterday at the Auditorium Annex and organized the Paint Manufacturers' Association of the United States.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 9. -- The Bulletin, the Harvard graduate weekly, has called for a discussion on the part of the rowing men of the question of shortening the length of the annual boat race from four to three miles. In its issue of this week, which appeared to-day, the communications are headed by one from President Charles W. Eliot, in favor of the three-mile course.
While heartily agreeing with a part of the Chicago resolutions, especially their praise of the gallantry of our troops, I do not think it right to make untrue statements.

ALBANY, May 9. -- There was no one present in opposition to the Ford Credit Insurance bill at the time designated for the hearing before the Governor to-day, so the hearing was put over until Thursday. Private Secretary Youngs says that the Governor has received but one letter against the measure. Frank White and other lawyers, however, proposed to speak against it.

SANTIAGO DE CHILE, May 9. -- The financial market here is very much depressed, and bonds are declining on account of a scarcity of paper notes. The public hopes for a new emission of currency to save the situation, but the Government seems to be opposed to such a measure. The Chilean Congress will meet on June 1.

The Board of Aldermen yesterday adopted the general license ordinance which has been pending for over a year. This ordinance, in another form, was passed some months ago, but was vetoed by the Mayor because several charges had been, according to his opinion, unnecessarily increased. It was accordingly amended, and was repassed by the Council, from which body the Aldermen received it yesterday.
CHICAGO, May 9. -- The Tribune will say to-morrow:

RICHMOND, Va., May 9. -- The Democrats of Virginia are on the eve of one of the most important political agitations which have disturbed that party since Mahone was overthrown, in 1883. The subject which is now distracting them is the proposition to nominate United States Senators by direct vote of the people.

Dinners in honor of the return of Admiral Dewey promise to become as numerous as were Jeffersonian dinners last month. Besides the dinner projected by "a large number of prominent business men," of which Alfred Chasseaud of 1,133 Broadway is Secretary, there is every likelihood that the Board of Trade and Transportation will give a banquet to the hero of Manila.

WASHINGTON, May 9. -- Capt. O.M. Carter, Corps of Engineers, United States Army, sentenced about a year ago to be dismissed from the army, fined, and imprisoned for criminal misuse of $1,600,000 of Government money set aside for river improvements, may soon be relieved of all anxiety about his fate.

OKLAHOMA, Miss., May 9. -- A desperate encounter between four well-known men took place on the street to-day at noon, and all four are now dead. Dr. J.H. Murfee and his son, Howard Murfee, were on one side, and C.D. and W.F. Clark on the other. Pistols and knives were used. C.D. Clark and Dr. Murfee and his son were killed outright, and W.F. Clark died early this evening of his wounds.

Stock market nervousness ruled again yesterday. The bear contingent continued aggressive. And the whole list suffered. Some losses were large. A variety of stocks closely held fell sharply, while in the old, standard, distributed issues there was less unsteadiness.

WASHINGTON, May 9. -- The foreign crop statistics which supplement the recent Winter grain report of the Department of Agriculture show that the Winter grain conditions almost everywhere in Europe are favorable.

An interesting and apparently successful test was made at the Sandy Hook Proving Ground yesterday with the Gathoman safety fuse in a shell loaded with wet guncotton and fired from a gun by means of smokeless powder. The object of the test was to show that wet guncotton could be safely used in a shell fired by powder.

WASHINGTON, May 9. -- S.B. Donnelly, President of the International Typographical Union, was before the Industrial Commission to-day. Referring to the strike of the stereotypers in Chicago last year, Mr. Donnelly said it was a failure because it did not have the sanction of the general order.

PHILADELPHIA, May 9. -- The higher officials of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company met yesterday in President Frank Thomson's office and discussed plans for the doing away with grade crossings in Washington.

The regular monthly meeting of the Seawanhaka-Corinthian Yacht Club was held at the clubhouse, 19 East Twenty-second Street. last night. F.S. Hastings was elected Treasurer, to succeed R.C. Wetmore, resigned. The question of racing rules was taken up and the club decided to adopt the rules of the Long Island Yacht Racing Association, with the exception of the rules of measurement. So far as possible the rules governing the classification will also be adopted.

CHARLESTON, S.C., May 9. -- In gala dress of bunting and festoons of electric lights Charleston is to-night welcoming the visitors and delegates to the ninth annual reunion of the United Confederate Veterans. All day the railroads have been emptying hundreds of men who wore the gray and their friends. Sleeping facilities for 40,000 persons have been provided and the prospect is that every cot will be needed.

The letters of your correspondents "S.P." and "West One Hundred and Twenty-ninth Street" complaining of the evils and dangers of ball playing on the streets ought to receive attention from the public as well as the police. This evil is not confined to the localities where your correspondents reside, but is general all over the city.

CHICAGO, May 9. -- The Senatorial Pure Food Investigating Committee to-day heard some startling testimony in regard to the adulteration of food products which may prolong its session considerably. Prof. A. S. Mitchell, chief chemist of the Wisconsin Dairy and Food Commission, made the sworn statement that nearly every butcher in Illinois used preserving liquids on scraps of meat which they laid aside for the manufacture of hamburger steak and other alleged delicacies.

ALBANY, May 9. -- The State Civil Service Commission has adopted a rule that will result in a radical change in State administrative departments. The new rule demands a certification of all pay rolls to the commission five days before each monthly pay day, and the Controller can only pay when such certification is indorsed by the commission.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., May 9. -- The Life Assurance Company of America, a receiver for which was asked in a suit filed in the Circuit Court yesterday afternoon, has left Indianapolis and Indiana. This fact was discovered by many policy holders and a Deputy Sheriff, who sought the rooms of the company on the eleventh floor of the Stevenson Block to-day.

The Grand Jury yesterday afternoon refused to indict Roland Burnham Molineux on the charge of having poisoned Mrs. Kate J. Adams. This is the second time that the case against the accused has broken down. The Grand Jury's decision caused considerable astonishment, not to say chagrin, to the officials of the District Attorney's office.

WASHINGTON, May 9. -- Senator Stewart of Nevada said to-day that he did not believe that the policy of the United States in the Philippines or the course of the Administration in dealing with that question would make an issue in the next general election.

Sixty-six orders, signed by Justice Gildersleeve, in the Supreme Court, appointing Commissioners of Street Openings, were filed yesterday in the County Clerk's Office.
