BALTIMORE. lIay 10. -The tha.'rd triennial meeting of the General Society of Colonial Wars held its opening session at the City Hall th4s morning.

MINNEAPOLIS, May 10. -- Managers Henry Little of the Pillsbury-Washburn Company and Manager J.S. Bell of the Washburn Crosby Company, emphatically deny a story telegraphed this morning from New York to the effect that the United States Flour Manufacturing Company has secured control of their mills. They assert that the report is too absurd to be believed by any one who is at all conversant with the situation.

RICHMOND, Va., May 10. -- A conference of Virginia Democrats cited "for the purpose of adopting such measures as may be deemed best to promoter the election of Senators of the United States by the direct vote of the people, and until that result is accomplished, the selection of party Senatorial candidates by some popular method," was held to-day. There were about 600 delegates present. Resolutions were adopted as follows:

The Civil Service Reform Association held its annual meeting last night in the Academy of Medicine. The President, ex-Secretary Carl Schurz, presided, and Secretary George McAneny read the annual report of the Executive Committee.

The stockholders of the Standard Gaslight Company attended the annual meeting yesterday in larger numbers than ever before known, and President Russell Sage obtained abundant evidence of their confidence in his management. Some of the stockholders personally assured Mr. sage that they approved of his course in the fight between the gas companies.

BUFFALO, May 10. -- The trouble between Contractor Conners and the grain shovelers is nearer a settlement to-night than at any time since the shipping season opened. The prospects now are that before the end of the week the whole matter will be adjusted.

CINCINNATI, May 10. -- In an interview H.R. Probasco, ex-United States District Attorney here, a relative of ex-Senator Sherman, and recently counsel for Gen. Miles, said to-day: "When the beef count convened, having previously served Gen. Miles as counsel in other matters, I was asked to go to Washington and confer with him regarding the proceedings before the court of inquiry.

The triennial meeting of the Society of the Cincinnati was held in Sherry's, at Forty-fourth Street and Fifth Avenue, yesterday, and in the evening celebrated its one hundred and sixteenth anniversary with a banquet at Sherry's. There was a meeting of the Executive Committee on Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, May 10. -- When the Olympia, Admiral Dewey's flagship, enters the Atlantic Ocean from the Mediterranean on her return from Manila, she will be met by the entire North Atlantic squadron under Admiral Sampson, and escorted to New York.

CHICAGO, May 10. -- Another meeting of the manufacturers of farm implements was held at the Great Northern to-day for the purpose of forming a combination to advance prices. The meeting was called by Col. Charles E. Whitman of St. Louis. At least thirty manufacturers of agricultural implements and machinery are represented or have agreed to abide by the decision of meetings here to-day and to-morrow.

PHILADELPHIA, May 10. -- The Philadelphias defeated the New Yorks to-day in an eleven-inning game that was well played. Carrick and Platt pitched for their respective teams, and both were almost invincible during the first half. In the eleventh inning, with two men out, Doyle made a three-bagger and was followed by Gleason with a two-bagger.

The Southern Democrats care more for BRYAN than for free silver. They can give up the Chicago platfom, but BRYAN must be their candidate next year. This is the report brought from the South by men who have good opportunities to learn the sentiment of the people there.
Memorial services for the Baroness Clara de Hirsch-Gereuth were held in Temple Emanu-El last night. The temple was crowded.

MANILA, May 10. -- The army "tin-clad" gunboats Laguna de Bay and Cavedonga, under command of Capt. Grant, steamed up the Rio Grande to Calumpit to-day, clearing the entire country of rebels from the bay upward.

WASHINGTON, May 10. -- R.G. Brooks of Scranton, Penn., and Walter J. Mullin of Wooster, Ohio, were before the Industrial Commission to-day. Both are mine owners in their respective localities. Both complained of the discrimination of the railroads which own coal mines and both spoke favorably of the labor organizations.

DULUTH, Minn., May 10. -- At 11 o'clock last night riotous strikers attempted to blow up a West Duluth street car with dynamite. There were ten passengers in the car, and they all received slight bruises. The car was thrown violently on its side and its trucks were blown to pieces. No arrests have yet been made.

But in the name of right reason, what does that "well-known Episcopal minister" whom "Orthodox" quotes mean by "the squalid depths of Unitarianism"?

The coming election of officers of the Seventy-first Regiment has aroused a great deal of interest and excitement among the rank and file. It was learned yesterday that the military authorities had decided to allow an election of Junior Major, and that this election would be held on Tuesday evening in the armory.

Mayor Van Wyck gave a hearing yesterday on Senator Marshall's bill amending the charter so as to permit the building of a tunnel, beginning at Flatbush and Atlantic Avenues, in Brooklyn, passing under the East River, and ending at Cortlandt Street, in the Borough of Manhattan.

Appraiser Wilbur F. Wakeman issued a comparative statement yesterday in regard to the duties collected at the Port of New York on the baggage of passengers during the six months ending Jan. 31, 1897, 1898, and 1899. The figures exhibit a marked decrease in receipts during the second year of the operation of the Dingley law.

Wall Street sentiment was far from optimistic when yesterday's stock market opened. It was enthusiastic before the close. It was almost as if a miracle had been worked. Pessimists without a single hope at 10 A.M. were overflowing with cheerfulness by noon, and at the end of the day were loaded again with long lines of stocks -- discarded only the day before because panics were in prospect.
Clarence True has sold the new five-story American basement dwelling at the southeast corner of Riverside Drive and Eighty-first Street.

PHILADELPHIA, May 10. -- There will be opened in the assembly hall of the Union League in this city to-morrow one of the greatest collections of rare paintings ever brought together in this country, both as to value and artistic merit. The paintings are all owned by Philadelphia art patrons, and are the cream of the many local private galleries.
OGDENSBURG, N.Y., May 10. -- The entire Democratic ticket was elected here to-day by a majority of 500. George Hall, for Mayor, received 605 majority over Capt. D.H. Lyon, Republican.

The women of the Morris County Golf Club had the privilege yesterday for the first time this season of playing over the long championship course. The regular greens of the entire eighteen-hole course were formally opened for use last Saturday, and the women yesterday used the links for the first match in a series of competitions for a trophy known as the "Long Course Cup."

CHICAGO, May 10. -- William A. Hendrie, the Chicagoan who was found by the police in New York City yesterday wandering around apparently insane, is a jeweler, with a store and residence at 3,716 State Street, and is seventy-two years old. Monday morning he started for New York over the Pennsylvania Road, and was to have been met at the station in New York by his daughter, Ollie Hendrie.

HAVANA, May 10. -- La Patria, one of the best-edited papers in Havana, comes out to-day with an editorial strongly indorsing the American administration. Its utterances are regarded as representing the best thought of the thinking element of the community. The editorial says, in part:

ALEXANDER as his successor in the Presidency of the Equitable Life Assurance Society causes not the slightest ripple of disturbance in the affairs of the company.

It must surprise a great many readers of your valued journal to note your editorial condemnation of the franchise tax, on the strength of one example quoted, and a very poor one -- namely, the Manhattan Railway Company. It is decidedly a very poor, in fact, the poorest possible, example to bring forward as a logical reason against taxing franchises.

I am glad to see that readers of THE TIMES who dissent from its Philippine views are beginning to speak out in meeting. Free speech is an American prerogative, and when it is curtailed it will be a sorry day. No other New York morning paper has a constituency equaling that of THE TIMES.

The Brooklyns yesterday defeated the Washingtons at the Brooklyn grounds in a game noted for heavy batting. Each team made fifteen hits, but the home team's batting was more opportune, which accounts for their victory by a score of 9 to 7. Still had several of the Washington players used a little more judgment in running the bases the game would have been much closer than it was and might even have resulted differently.
The Briggs case remains in statu quo. Bishop Botter maintains his silence, and no inkling as to his intention can be obtained.

WASHINGTON, May 10. -- The United States naval transport Badger, with the Samoan Commission aboard, is supposed to have arrived at Apia, Samoa, to-day, and there is much interest among officials in the important change of conditions which will be brought about when the commission assumes charge of affairs.
The suit of Smith E. Lane, an attorney, to recover from Mrs. Hetty Green $5,000 for legal services, adjourned from Tuesday, was continued yesterday before Judge Fitzgerald in the Supreme Court.

Two points of importance are fixed in regard to the share of the United States in the Peace Conference at The Hague. One is that we shall have the cordial sympathy and co-operation of Great Britain, and the other is that the common aims of the two great English-speaking nations will be such as to persuade the world that the understanding between them is a guarantee of general peace and in nowise a menace thereto.

Mahan, United States Navy, retired, and Mr. Seth Low, President of Columbia University, New York, delegates of the United States to the disarmament congress, which meets in The Hague on May 18, reached this city to-day, with their assistants. All of the party are in excellent health, and report that they greatly enjoyed their trip from the United States.

The Savings Banks Association of the State of New York held its annual meeting in the rooms of the Chamber of Commerce yesterday. There were present about 100 officials of savings banks throughout the State. President John Harsen Rhoades occupied the chair, and ex-Secretary of the Treasury Charles S. Fairchild, Prof. W.G. Sumner of Yale, and F.D. Kilburn, State Superintendent of Banks, sat with him on the platform.

READING, Penn., May 10. -- The order issued yesterday by President Duffy of the United Mine Workers, notifying all miners and laborers employed in the Lehigh and Wilkesbarre Coal Company's mines that after Friday, May 19, members of the Mine Workers' Union shall not work with men who do not belong to the union, is expected to cause serious trouble in the anthracite coal regions of Pennsylvania.
In your Illustrated Magazine of yesterday there appears an article on "Unsightly New York Statues."

In answer to your correspondent, "S.S.," in to-day's TIMES, concerning ball playing in the streets, I would advise him to complain to the Police Captain of the precinct. If that is of no avail, then he should complain to the Chief of Police, or go before the Commissioners.

James W. Alexander was elected President of the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States by the Board of Directors yesterday, to succeed Henry B. Hyde, who died last week. At the same meeting Director Chauncey M. Depew presented a memorial minute expressive of the grief of the members of the board over the loss of President Hyde.

WASHINGTON, May 10. -- The Inter-State Commerce Commission held a conference to-day with a number of railroad men on the question of rates. Many complaints have reached the commission to the effect that some of the roads are failing to observe their published rates, and the conference was for the purpose of securing compliance with the law in this respect. Annual meeting of stockholders of the American Tobacco Company. Retiring Board of Directors re-elected.

Mrs. Maria Miller, the magic medical curist, who tried to cure little Dora Kranz of 106 North Eighth Street, Brooklyn, of gangrene, was arrested yesterday on a warrant issued by Magistrate Brenner of the Adams Street Police Court.
WASHINGTON, May 10. -- Ex-Congressman Israel F. Fischer of Brooklyn has been appointed a member of the Board of General Appraisers at New York, vice Mr. Shurtleff, removed.

ALBANY, May 11. -- Privy Councilor von Knobel-Doeberitz and Councilor of State Baron Marschall von Bieberstein of Berlin, representing the Prussian Government to examine New York life insurance companies upon their application to do business in Prussia, made an official visit to Gov. Roosevelt and Superintendent of Insurance Louis E. Payn, to-day.

Elijah C. Harvey a mulatto, thirty years old, who is a graduate of an educational institution at Andover, Mass., and who afterward studied for the ministry, was arraigned before Magistrate Wentworth in the Yorkville Police Court yesterday morning on the charge of burglary. Harvey is said to have confined his burglaries chiefly in the homes of millionaires, among them being that of Charles T. Yerkes, at 864 Fifth Avenue.
It is now reported in many quarters that the ordination of Dr. Briggs will take place on Sunday next, as originally planned. In what church, or at what hour, however, no one will venture to say.

The managers and ex-managers of the Sons of the Revolution of the State of New York gave a dinner last night at Delmonico's in honor of the General Society of the Cincinnati, which has been holding its triennial session in this city. Decorations comprising the evolution of the American flag adorned the banquet hall.

BELVIDIERE, N.J., May 11. -- Edward Williams, employed at the Warren House, became despondent yesterday, and, after bidding good-bye to his wife and children, went to the Delaware River, which runs near his home, with the intention of drowning himself. He waded into the river until he was waist deep and thn hesitated.

WASHINGTON, May 11. -- Assistant Secretary Spaulding has decided that copyrighted books printed in Europe from plates made from type set in the United States are not subject to the prohibition of importation in Section 3 of the Copyright act of March 3, 1891. He has also decided that American goods which have been improved in condition or advanced in value abroad by American labor and materials are dutiable on reimportation.

WASHINGTON, May 11. -- The following communication, addressed to the editor of The Brooklyn Eagle, has been received by the Washington correspondent of the Eagle. It is from Rear Admiral John H. Upshur, now on the retired list. He is a close per sonal friend of Admiral Dewey. They are members of the same club in this city and have many tastes in common.
ALBANY, May 11. -- The Ford Franchise Taxation bill was the subject of a long hearing before the Governor to-day, when several prominent lawyers spoke in opposition to the measure.

There was a rumor about the Tenderloin last night that diamonds worth thousands of dollars had been stolen from a guest at the Waldorf-Astoria, and as the report gained circulation the value of the missing gems increased. The robbery was denied by Manager Boldt's representative, who said no theft had been reported in the hotel in six months.

It ought to be made especially plain to the public that in this controversy in regard to the admission of Dr. Briggs to the priesthood there is no question of High Church or low Church, ritualist or anti-ritualist, but one of loyalty to the Bible and the Church, or we may say, to the Bible and Christianity.

HOWARD CITY, Mich., May 11. -- Joseph Harvey last night killed his wife, his uncle, Robert Pierson, and his grandmother. He also fatally wounded his three-months-old baby and his father-in-law, John Logenslayer, and finally shot himself, inflicting a serious wound.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 11. -- The Kentucky distilleries and warehouse syndicate, it is understood on good authority, has purchased the large stock of whisky held by J. M. Atherton Co., who sold their plants to the trust some months ago. The stock was the largest held by any firm in Kentucky, being estimated at 65,000 to 75,000 barrels, or in the neighborhood of 3,000,000 gallons.

CAMDEN, N.J., May 11. -- Articles of incorporation were filed to-day in the County Clerk's office by the Automatic Safety Railway Switch Company. The objects of the company are to manufacture patented railway switches. The capital stock is $100,000, and the amount paid in is $1,000. The incorporators are J.C. McGrath, A.B.C. Dailey, W.C. Nichols, H.B. Peirce, F.J. McMahon, P.W. Boyes, and Joseph L. Dailey.

CLEVELAND, May 11. -- At a luncheon attended by members of the International Health Protection League this afternoon, the subject of corsets and bicycles came in for a discussion, in which Miss Marguerite Lindley, the advocate of dress reform, took part.

Much interest was aroused in shipping circles yesterday by the announcement that the North German Lloyd Steamship Company had decided to dock its passenger steamers in this city instead of Hoboken, where it has extensive piers. Hoboken, whose business interests are largely affected by the North German Lloyd and Hamburg-American Lines, which make it their terminal, was greatly agitated over the news.

LONDON, May 11. -- "Tod" Sloan finished first on Mr. H.J. King's four-year-old chestnut colt Florio Rubattino, in the Flying Handicap, at the third day's racing of the Newmarket second Spring meeting today. Twelve horses ran the Rous Course (five furlongs.) The betting was 2 to 1 against Florio Rubattino.

With the same bunch of millinery violets pinned to her corsage that have been her adornment for two days, Mrs. Hetty Green took the stand in the Supreme Court, before Justice Fitzgerald yesterday, to deny the statement made by Lawyer Smith E. Lane, who is suing her for a five-thousand-dollar fee, that he was held up by her in a room in the Chemical National Bank Building and forced to sign a paper.

WASHINGTON, May 11. -- Gen. Greely to-day made the first authoritative statement as to the progress making in the development of wireless telegraphy under the auspices of the United States Signal Corps. The conclusion is reached by Gen. Greely that the wireless system is not likely to supplant the ordinary method of telegraphic communication.

The Ward Line steamer Havana, which made a record trip of two days and twenty hours to this port from Havana, and which had been detained at Quarantine since her arrival Tuesday, reached her dock at 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon. The Havana had as passengers a number of army officers and 1,563 discharged soldiers from the various regiments stationed in Cuba.

CHICAGO, May 11. -- Capt. Frank F. Eastman of the Fourteenth United States Infantry arrived in Chicago to-day. He left Manila April 3, on sick leave, being one of the passengers on the transport Sherman, which arrived in San Francisco April 30. He is on his way to rejoin his family in Massachusetts.

WASHINGTON, May ll. -- The Industrial Commission to-day heard the first witness called in connection with its inquiry into the operations of trusts. The witness was James W. Lee of Pittsburg, attorney for several pipe line and oil companies, and formerly a State Senator of Pennsylvania. Mr. Lee's testimony was directed especially against the Standard Oil Company.
There are signs that the President is taking a serious view of the need of currency legislation at the coming session of Congress. He may well do so.

-- Sir JOHN LUBBOCK has raised an interesting and possibly important objection to the nationalization or municipalization of just those utilities that seem most likely soon to pass out of private or corporate into public control. The utilities to which he refers -- and being an eminent scientist, he speaks of them with authority -- are such as depend upon active and original scientific research for development and improvement.

CLEVELAND, May 11. -- The Iron Trade Review of to-day prints a letter written to its editor by Andrew Carnegie just before he sailed for Europe. The paper refers to it as "Mr. Carnegie's last trade utterance as an American steel master," and adds that "the developments of the past week give special significance and interest to it."

At the second day's session (yesterday) of the seventy-eighth annual conference of the AfroAmerican Methodist Episcopal Church, which is being held at the Zion Church at West Tenth and Bleecker Streets, the annual address was delivered by the Right Rev. J.W. Hood, D.D., LL.D., presiding Bishop of the New York annual conference.

CHICAGO, May 11. -- After several months negotiations the Pennsylvania Railroad Company has, it is reliably reported, obtained complete control of the Cleveland, Akron and Columbus Road, the main line of which extends from Columbus to Cleveland, Ohio. The Cleveland, Akron and Columbus was a part of the old Brice system, and is popularly considered one of the valuable short lines of the Middle West.

Mayor Van Wyck yesterday returned to the Governor Senator Stranahan's Rapid Transit bill, with these words written across its face: "Not accepted by the City of New York." This sentence kills the bill, which has never been considered by the city officials as a particularly good piece of legislation. It permitted private construction and ownership of the underground system and allowed the road to be built in sections.

CHICAGO, May 11. -- An association of heirs, with George W. Mills, manager of the United States Flour Milling Company as President, has been formed in Chicago to recover an alleged estate consisting of sixty acres of property in the heart of New York and Brooklyn, valued at $200,000,000. The claimants say this estate belonged to Alexander Montgomery, a noted Tory, who fled from New York when Gen. Howe evacuated with the British forces.

BUFFALO, May 11. -- The meeting of the Advisory Committee of Ten, of which Bishop Quigley is the Chairman, which was to have taken place to-night at the Bishop's residence, was postponed until 10:30 to-morrow owing to the illness of two members of the committee -- ex-Congressman Mahany and President PJ. McMahon of the Grain Shovelers' Union.

The thirty-third annual meeting of the National Board of Fire Underwriters was held yesterday in the assembly room of the New York Board. President E.C. Irvin of the Fire Association of Philadelphia presided and delivered the annual address. In addition to the approval of the reports of the various standing committees, the board took definite action in the direction of extending its jurisdiction over all other fire insurance organizations in the United States.

The strike of the members of the "Mother Goose" company, which has been performing at the Fourteenth Street Theatre, is likely to stop the play permanently unless some new capital is infused into the enterprise. The statement of Junius Howe, the manager of the company, to the effect that the fault lay with John Felts, the reputed financial backer of the enterprise, was denied yesterday by Myers Pohley, the attorneys for Mr. Felts.

ALBANY, May 11. -- Gov. Roosevelt this afternoon signed the Atlantic Avenue Tunnel bill. The bill gives to the Municipal Assembly the power to grant a tunnel franchise for a term of fifty years, with the option of renewal for another twenty-five years, after a revaluation.

Oliver Hansen, one of the contestants in the seventy-two-hour go-as-you-please race in the Grand Central Palace, collapsed yesterday, and was removed to the Flower Hospital. The physicians say that his condition is critical.

CITY OF MEXICO, May 9. -- An American at home reading of "Our Sister Republic, Mexico," feels fatally ties drawing close, but in this wonderful old city, the throbbing heart of a wonderful country, the relationship is forgotten, and curiosity, flavored with admiration, takes its place. He forgets that Mexico is our sister, older in years though far younger in her present form of successful Government.

In the old Trinity Church yard, near the Rector Street fence and a stone's throw from Broadway, a time-stained block of marble marks the grave of a fellow-townsman, who was, next to Washington, the greatest man this great country ever saw. I mean, of course, Alexander Hamilton.

PATERSON, N.J., May 13. -- Battered and bruised and with a look of extreme disgust, Detective Taylor of the local force appeared before Recorder Senior to-day with Ignatz Graemer, an alleged forger, in his custody.

PHILADELPHIA, May 13. -- The Philadelphias sustained their reputation as a team of heavy batters to-day and shut out the New Yorks for the second time in two days. Colcolough was batted all over the field, Douglass being the only man failing to get a hit. Delehanty made four doubles and Lajoie and Flick each had a triple to his credit.

BOLKER, during his four years at college, never made a friend. To him neighbor in a lecture meant either nuisance, if fidgety and inclined to talk, or object of indifference, if quiet and taciturn; snob, if well dressed; nonentity if, like himself, shabby.

Mrs. Stuyvesant Fish's young son, Sydney, who was operated upon last Thursday for appendicitis by Dr. Charles McBurney at the home of his parents, Madison Avenue and Seventy-eighth Street, is improving, and his recovery bids fair to be rapid. The unexpected illness of the lad has somewhat unsettled his parents' traveling plans, but if he continues to improve, they will, in all likelihood, leave for their trip to Alaska the latter part of this month.
NEWPORT, May 13. -- Mrs. Thomas O. Richardson has rented the Richard Baker cottage on Ledge Road and the Cliffs known as Westcliff, to Cornelius Vanderbilt, Jr., for the coming season.

The Washington team has vacated these parts for a time, and there is not one baseball enthusiast in Greater New York who will mourn their absence. At Washington Park, in Brooklyn, yesterday they made an effort to play ball and failed. The Brooklyns defeated them twice in less than four hours.

PRINCETON, May 13. -- Princeton beat Harvard this afternoon in the first game for the collegiate championship by a score of 10 to 2. It began to rain as play was called. The ball was wet and the pitchers were at a great disadvantage. It was anybody's game till the sixth inning, when Morse, Harvard's pitcher, became unsteady, with the bases filled.

THE annual tournament for the lawn tennis championship of the Southern States will open Tuesday afternoon on the courts of the Bachelors' Tennis Club, on M Street, near Connecticut Avenue, Washington. This will mark the opening of the championship tennis season, as it is the first big tournament on the official schedule for the year.

I would not again encroach upon your valuable space were it not that when I am told, in such a discourteous manner as "Dorfmenel" adopts, that I know nothing about the matter which was the subject of my recent note to you, I am naturally anxious to prove that I do know whereof I speak.

The old-fashioned, monarchical method of spying has been strangely supplemented during the last five years. When Carnot was murdered in 1894 the whole of France was seized with panic, and a bill against the Anarchists was pushed through the Chamber in the late Autumn. The Deputies, anxious for their favorite watering places, accepted the wildest provisions, and the concierges of Paris were promoted, almost without opposition, into informal agents of the police.

The International Navigation Company announces that it has under construction four first-class passenger steamers, two for the Red Star Line service between New York and Antwerp, and two for the Philadelphia-Liverpool service of the American Line. All the boats are being built on the Clyde by the Clydebank Engineering and Shipbuilding Company.

WELLINGTON, N. Z., April 17. -- Under an act which has just been brought into operation in New Zealand, no man or woman in this country who has attained the age of sixty-five years and been a resident of it for five-and-twenty can possibly become a beggar or be subject to arrest under the vagrancy laws.
WASHINGTON, May 13. -- The Whisky Trust was under investigation by the Industrial Commission to-day. Charles C. Clarke, a distiller of Peoria, Ill., was the witness.
NEWARK, N.J., May 13. -- Articles of incorporation of the Hyde Behman Amusement Company were filed with the County Clerk here to-day. The capital stock is $500,000.

AUBURN, May 13. -- The Rev. W.H. Hubbard, Chairman of the Committee on Systematic Beneficence of the Presbyterian Church, will report to the General Assembly at its meeting in Minneapolis next week that the total income the past year of the eight Presbyterian boards was $2,513,184, an increase of $300,000 over the last year.

When the large clock in the Stock Exchange indicated the hour of 10 yesterday morning, a roar of human voices arose from the densely crowded floor such as had not been heard there in many years. Never before were there so many brokers assembled in the trading room, and never before was there manifested such an ungovernable eagerness to sell stocks.

Memorial services for Baroness de Hirsch were held yesterday afternoon in the auditorium of the Educational Alliance, at East Broadway and Jefferson Street, which were attended by the members of the Hebrew Free School Association, and Baron de Hirsch English Day Schools. The services were in connection with the regular weekly divine services for children, held at the Alliance.
LONDON, May 13. -- The United States Ambassador, Joseph H. Choate, is giving daily sittings to J.S. Sargent for a portrait.

Your editorial of this morning entitled "Not Just the Thing" strikes a keynote to which every sensible American citizen should heartily respond. Admiral Dewey is a servant of the United States Government. He has received his education and training at the expense of the people of the United States.
WASHINGTON, May 13. -- The Secretary of the Navy has received an opinion from the Controller of the Treasury in regard to the Naval Personnel act which is of general interest to officers of the navy.

ANNAPOLIS, May 13. -- The Columbia University eight finished half a length in front of the naval cadets in a fierce struggle on the Severn to-day after having pulled over the two-mile course in 12 minutes and 48 seconds.

Men of prominence and influence in the theatrical profession who look back over an experience of thirty and even forty years say that the season now closing is the best financially that they ever knew. There are but few discords to mar the harmony of this opinion. Two or three of the New York theatres have lost money, but in each of these instances there have been special reasons for the ill fortune.

The State target ranges at Creedmoor were occupied yesterday by the cavalrymen of Squadron A. Major Bridgeman was in command. The squadron got an early start and made such rapid progress that there was time left for a trial at sharpshooting. In the two hours that the long ranges were open five men qualified, three from Troop 1 and two from Troop 2. Major Kirby was in charge of the ranges.

It now appears that Secretary ALGER has made another of those curious mistakes to which he is liable when he thinks that he is stating a fact. Early this week he announced that Senator MCMILLAN of Michigan had frequently told him that he had no desire to remain in the Senate if the Secretary wanted his seat.

BERLIN, May 13. -- Negotiations for a commercial treaty between the United States and Germany have now been taken up in earnest at this end of the line. United States Ambassador Andrew D. White expects that, despite the number of formidable obstacles that must be overcome, such treaty as will be satisfactory to both Nations will crown the efforts of the representatives of the two Governments.

LONDON, May 13. -- The coming week be a memorable one in history, for the first meeting of all the nations of the world will be held to put to one another the question with which the Welsh Bards open their yearly festival of song, "Is it peace?" Whatever result may be occasioned is momentous.

LONDON, May 13. -- At the second day's racing of the Gatwick Spring meeting, today, Mr. H.V. Long's three-year-old colt Lord Edward II. won the Prince's Handicap. "Tod" Sloan rode Lord William Beresford's bay filly Jiffy II. and captured second place. Seven horses ran, one mile and a half. The betting was 4 to 1 against Jiffy II.
HELENA, Mon., May 13. -- Ex-State Senator Fred Whiteside has filed at Kalispell, Mon., a damage suit for defamation of character against The Helena Independent, a leading Clark organ.

THE choir of the Church of St. Mary the Virgin has been brought into prominence by the service last Sunday to commemorate the twenty-fifth anniversary of Thomas M. Prentice's connection with the parish as conductor of the choirs, following a similar anniversary of his brother, George B. Prentice, Mus. Doc., which took place in 1896.

There was a conflict in the Centre Street Police Court yesterday morning between Agent King of the Gerry Society and the Chief Clerk of the court, who was backed up by Magistrate Cornell. It was brought about by the case of William Hackett, living at 983 Columbus Avenue, who was sent to the island in default of $500 bail for beating his wife.

WASHINGTON, May 13. -- Ex-Representative Hartman of Montana, who has been home and has come back to Washington, brings news and opinions. The latter are about Mr. Bryan and Mr. Belmont, and sustain Mr. Bryan's declination to dine with a Democrat who will not accept 16 to 1. He thinks that Mr. Belmont and Mr. Hanna are both supporters of the same interests and advocates of the same financial policy.

The long popular operetta "Erminie," was reproduced at the Casino last night with a cast made up of several well-known favorites of the comic opera stage. The result was an entertainment which had many delightful features, and which was received with every evidence of favor by a large audience.

BERLIN, May 1. -- Disquieting rumors continue to circulate respecting the Emperor's recent sojourn at Wartburg Castle. He left Berlin intending to have some good shooting in the preserves of his new estates, and had also planned attending a representation de gala organized by the Grand Duke of Saxe-Weimar in his honor at the Eisenach Theatre.

Wall Street closes its business week depressed. The chief of its leaders is gone. Gov. Flower is dead. His taking off was sudden. Market results were grave. Many bad factors had been apprehended, fore-fended; but the loss of the leadership of this the foremost of Captains came as a sensational surprise; and throughout all the financial world disturbing effects were shown.

CHICAGO, May 13. -- Everything save the formalities of signing has been completed concerning the traction deal, and the great West and North Side street railways of this city have passed from the control of Charles T. Yerkes to that of the syndicate of which Mr. Whitney, Mr. Widener, and Mr. Elkins are the heads.

POTTSTOWN, Penn., May 13. -- Mrs. G. Warren Bradford of this town was on the wrecked train and had a narrow escape from instant death. She was riding in the car just ahead of the Pullman, and when the crash occurred she was hurled from her seat. The passenger who sat next to her was killed

The Rev. Dr. John Watson (Ian MacLaren) arrived in this city last evening from his lecture tour of the western part of the American Continent, returning by way of the Canadian Pacific Railroad to New England, and thence to New York. He will return to his home, in Liverpool, on the White Star Line steamship Teutonic, sailing on Wednesday.

CHARLESTON, May 13. -- The failure, accidental or designed, to assign Gen. Joseph Wheeler to any place in the great procession of Confederate veterans here this week is exciting much comment. Gen. Wheeler came here at the invitation of the veterans and was the guest of United States Judge Brawley, an ex-Confederate.

The fight to prevent the North River Heat, Light and Power Company from obtaining a foothold in North Hudson County resulted yesterday in President Banta and eight workmen of the company being arrested.

Capt. Codman's dog story, which is commented upon in your editorial columns today, recalls another which was vouched for to me a few years ago by people whose veracity is unimpeachable. A man in Sydney, Cape Breton, had a big dog which, for certain reasons, he wished to find a new home for; so he gave him to the Captain of a steamer that was going across to Liverpool.

CHICAGO, May 13. -- Ex-Gov. Flower was well-known among Chicago's heavier financiers. His first venture here of great importance was that made at the time the old Chicago Gas Company was reorganized. He was a member of the syndicate that accomplished the reorganization, and his holdings in that stock were large.

After several conferences between Senator Platt and the leaders of the Republican State machine, which consumed the greater part of yesterday, it was announced last night, on what be considered eminent authority, that Gov. Roosevelt had decided to accede to the demands of the organization and to call an extra session of the Legislature at once.

ST. PETERSBURG, April 28. -- In view of the approaching Pan-German Congress at Hamburg, at which the Austrian Pan-Germans will give full expression to their hopes and aspirations, it is of interest to take into consideration the probable role of Russia in the threatened dismemberment of Austria-Hungary.

SAN JUAN, May 13. -- The new school laws and regulations just issued by Gen. John B. Eaton, Superintendent of Public Schools in Puerto Rico, have caused great surprise to the natives by the large increases made by them in the salaries of the teachers throughout the department. The salaries which heretofore have been payable in Puerto Rican currency, are now payable in gold.

LONDON, May 13. -- Archbishop Ireland of St. Paul made a most favorable impression by his oration at the Joan of Arc ceremony at Orleans on Monday, and has been asked to deliver a panagyric on St. Clotilde to-morrow at St. Clotilde's, Faubourg St. Germain. The Paris Debats highly complimented Archbishop Ireland on his eloquence and marvelous acquaintance with the French tongue, adding:

The results of the investigations made by Admiral Lord Charles Beresford in his recent journey have just been published. Last February the distinguished British nobleman and member of Parliament passed through the United States on his way from China to England. He had been studying the questions of commerce and trade of Great Britain and the whole Anglo-Saxon race with China, at the request of the Associated Chambers of Commerce of Great Britain.

WILMINGTON, N.C., May 13. -- At an adjourned meeting of the stockholders of the Wilmington and Weldon Railroad Company held here to-day, an arrangement was perfected between that company and the Southern Railway Company, by which the Southern gets that part of the Atlantic and Yadkin Road (late the Cape Fear and Yadkin Valley) between Santford and Mount Aria.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., May 13. -- Not often has the Presbyterian General Assembly crossed the Mississippi River. Only once, indeed, has it been held in the Northwest. That was in 1886, when it came to Minneapolis, and so well was it entertained that when asked to return again this year the offer was accepted with enthusiasm.

If Admiral DEWEY were to return in command of a victorious fleet, or in what might properly be called an official capacity, he would encounter some awkward international questions. It is quite true that he might be expected to dispose of each as it arose with the tact and sagacity which he has shown in not less a degree than fighting qualities.

POUGHKEPSIE, N.Y., May 13. -- The Vassar Athletic Association celebrated its fifth field day Saturday, May 13. The weather was perfect; the audience, which is strictly feminine, as the profane masculine observer is debarred from witnessing the "sports," was very enthusiastic, and cheered the winners lustily.

The entertainment provided this evening at Koster Bial's Music Hall will include Lottie Gilson, Monroe and Mack, Lizzie Raymond, Ed Latell, Truly Shattuck, Simms and Graham, Tom Brown, Maude Courtney, Wiseman Quartet, Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Drew, Josie De Witt, the Hulines, Beaumont Sisters, Phasey Troupe, Ethel Levey, Johnson and Dean, and Clarenze's Quintet.

The will of R.R. Burney, who for many years was Secretary of the Young Men's Christian Association, was filed for probate in the Surrogate's office yesterday. Mr. McBurney died at Clifton Springs, N.Y., on Dec. 27 last. The value of the estate is unknown.

The question of a Spring social season forces itself upon the attention of any one familiar with New York social conditions as one watches the afternoon parade of handsome equipages up and down Fifth Avenue, sails on the river or bay, drives or walks through the parks in and around the city, and especially when one visits any one of the score or more of country clubs that dot the suburbs in all directions.

Gov. FLOWER did not seem, even to those who knew him best, to have the qualities of a successful politician or of a leader in Wall Street. Yet it was in politics and in finance and chiefly in the last three or four years of his life that he won his highest distinction and the respect and confidence of the public.

The New York State Division of the League of American Wheelmen, and in fact, all cycle organizations, are now working together for a cycle path across the Bridge. Members of the Municipal Assembly have been approached, a resolution passed by Long Island clubs has been submitted to the representatives from Brooklyn Borough, recommending that the Municipal Assembly pass an ordinance having for its object the establishment of a Bridge cycle path.

LONDON, May 13. -- The Queen has commanded Mr. Grau to give a performance of "Lohengrin" on May 24, the cast to include the De Reszke brothers, Mme. Nordica, and Mme. Schumann-Heink. Mme. Patti makes since her marriage, her first appearance at the Queen' Hall, on Thursday. She is arranging for an American tour next Winter.

One of the largest entry lists in the history of the Intercollegiate A.A.A.A. has been received for the annual track and field championship meeting, which will be held at Manhattan Field next Friday and Saturday. As was the case last year, the trial heats in all the events will be run on Friday, so that Saturday will be taken up mostly for finals.

BALTIMORE, May 13. -- Formal answers of the trustees of several of the mortgages which the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Company has petitioned the United States Circuit Court for permission to exchange for new securities, which the company will ask permission on Monday to issue, were filed to-day in the Clerk's office of the court.

BRISSTOL, R.I., May 13. -- The doors of the big shed at the Herreshoff works, where the Columbia is being built, were swung wide open for a few minutes to-day to allow a cartload of plating to be carried in, and one or two of the outsiders in the yard had a good view of the new cup defender.

LONDON, May 13. -- Joseph Chamberlain came forward this week as a successful beggar in the cause of philanthropy. He recently asked for u250,000 ($1,250,000) for the Birmingham University, and Andrew Carnegie's gift practically completes the sum required. The conditions of Mr. Carnegie's donation meet the warm approval of the press.

With the exception of the sale of the Real Estate Exchange, the last week has had few distinguishing features. In no class of property has there been any considerable amount of anything that looks like investment buying, and while the volume of business would make a fair showing, it has been made up largely of the dealings of the professional element.

The proposed formal protest at the church service on the part of the Rev. Dr. Clendenin and others to the ordination of the Rev. Dr. Briggs has fallen enough, and Dr. Briggs will this making in the Pro-Cathedral, Stanton Street, be advanced to the priesthood without any such dramatic interruption as has for some time been expected.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., May 13. -- President McKinley, Mrs. McKinley, and a few friends visited Natural Bridge, Va., to-day. They left the Homestead Hotel after an early breakfast, and at 8:15 started on their trip over the Chesapeake and Ohio in the special train which carried the Presidential party to Hot Springs.

LONDON, May 13. -- There was tremendous excitement at Leyton to-day over the cricket match between the Australians and the Essex County Club. The crowd was suggestive of Derby Day. At the beginning of play to-day the Australians collapsed, only making 73.

PARIS, May 5. -- After the Fashoda incident most people imagined that France had decided to abandon her policy of pin-pricks. But no sooner does the Chamber meet than it would seem that she intends to go back to her old methods, more particularly with respect to England.
CHICAGO, May 13. -- Two million dollars of stock in the company which will secure the street railway holdings of Charles T. Yerkes has been subscribed for in Chicago.

SYDNEY, N.S.W., April 1. -- It has frequently formed a source of surprise to those visiting the Australian colonies during seasons of drought to find considerable numbers of cattle, sheep, and other live stock in apparently healthy condition in districts where not even the ,tiniest blade of grass is visible.

THE revival of "Erminie" ought to give the operetta libretto writers something to think about, but whether it will or not is another matter. The level of the recent operetta libretto is so low that it is only by the pressure of the necessity of publishing the news that any newspaper critic can be induced to give one of these works a moment's serious consideration.

READING, Penn., May 13. -- The wreck which occurred last night on the Philadelphia and Reading Railway at Exeter, six miles south of here, was one of the worst that ever occurred in this State. Twenty-eight dead and fifty injured, some so badly that they may not recover, is the awful result of the accident.

SHANGHAI, May 14. -- The Tsung-li-Yamen, Chinese Foreign Office, has replied to the Russian Minister at Peking, M. de Giers, that the Government is unable to accede to the Russian demand made last Wednesday for a new railway concession connecting Peking with Russia's present system in Manchuria.

HARRISBURG, May 14. -- Gov. Stone has made public his action on the General Appropriation bill passed by the recent Legislature, which provides for the ordinary expenses of the various branches of the State Government, the interest on the public debt, and for the support of the public schools for the fiscal year beginning June 1, 1899.

At the annual banquet of the Royal Academy of Arts Lord Salisbury announced the Anglo-Russian agreement regarding China, as already telegraphed, and then proceeded in lighter vein as follows: I was struck, Mr. President, in listening to the eloquent addresses of my two colleagues, that both of them assumed a slightly apologetic attitude.

Mr. ANDREW CARNEGIE is so ardent in his anti-imperialism that he continually foresees the immediate triumph of his cause even while to others it still seems discouragingly far off. He was one of those who opposed the ratification of the treaty of peace and, returning from a visit to Washington last Winter, he triumphantly announced that the treaty was beaten.

The Rev. Dr. Charles A. Briggs and the Rev. Charles H. Snedeker were yesterday morning, without formal protest on the part of those opposed to Dr. Briggs, advanced to the priesthood in the Episcopal Church, in the Pro-Cathedral, in Stanton Street. Bishop Potter conducted the ordination services.

The woolen goods division of the textile markets has been quieter this week than for many weeks previous, particularly in men's wear, dress goods, and blankets. Each has had its turn of extreme activity and larger business than for several seasons past, but all have now relapsed into a quiet state. Blankets were sold up to the capacity of the mills, a thing unknown for many years.

London is complaining that it is impossible to get any facts upon which to base an estimate upon the stability and worth of the shares of the new Amalgamated Copper Company. Discussing the copper combine, The London Statist says:

TACOMA, Washington, May 14. -- Letters from owners of claims at Cape Nome, Alaska, say: "Two hundred dollars can be made per day without sluice boxes, and we could double it with them. Three men using a rocker and one shoveling took out $163 in one day. Six men with two rockers took out $620 out of Anval and Snow Creeks in five hours.

The comic paper boarding house joke about Mr. Hallroom and the landlady, long regarded by a cynical and suspicious public as visionary and baseless, received a startling confirmation yesterday. It was, of course confirmed in Brooklyn, one of the few places that supply a color of probability to comic paper jokes.

The Princess Salm Salm yesterday, at Odd Fellows' Hall, 69 East Eighth Street, presented to the twenty-eight civil war veterans of the Eighth Regiment a flag under which they fought during the rebellion. The husband of the Princess was at that time Colonel of the regiment, and the flag had been in her possession for over thirty-four years.

The report was current yesterday that the place which the death of ex-Gov. Flower made vacant, not only as a leader in Wall Street, but also as a special partner in the firm of Flower Co., (of which Anson R. Flower, brother of the ex-Governor, is the head,) would be filled by Anthony N. Brady of Albany.

WASHINGTON, May 14. -- Admiral Dewey's home coming by way of the Mediterranean is likely to give occasion for distinguished honors from the navies of Europe, most of them being represented by extensive squadrons in those waters, and some of them having their chief naval stations at Mediterranean ports.

" Prof. Drummond and the Dawn of an Era of Friendship Between Science and Religion" was the subject of the Rev. Dr. Hillis's sermon in his series on "Great Books and Great Authors," delivered last night in Plymouth Church, Brooklyn. He said in part:

In a letter printed in THE TIMES on May 6, "G." takes exception to the statement of the Rev. Dr. Peters that the Jews are the most anciently cultured people in the world, and quotes authorities to that effect. While conceding some of the points to be well taken, it seems to me, nevertheless, that "G." takes entirely too narrow a view of the subject in controversy.

READING, Penn., May 14. -- The total number of dead, as a result of Friday night's rear-end collision on the Philadelphia and Reading Railway at Exeter, six miles below here, reached twenty-nine today. William D. Jenkins of Norristown, dying to-day at the hospital at that place. Of the large number of injured persons still in the hospitals here three are in a serious condition and small hope is entertained for their recovery.

LONDON, May 14. -- We have scrambled through the mid-monthly Stock Exchange account with but little dependence on the Bank of England, and money now is likely to be easy to the end of the present month. It was a huge account of business in small bargains, the bulk of business being concentrated on mine shares, hence, perhaps, the ease with which payments have been made.

The Herreshoff-built steam yacht Althea, formerly Judy, has been bought by Clifford V. Brokaw, and will be in charge of Capt. Frank Johnson this season. She is fitting out at Richard Peck's Fifty-fifth Street Basin, Bay Ridge. Her name will be changed to Uvira, the name of Mr. Brokaw's old yacht.

Do let us keep to facts. Your correspondent, John J. Bealin, in your issue of to-day says among other things: "Let us go back to Plymouth Rock and we will take into consideration the Puritan Fathers and see how much they assimilated. Is it not a fact that the old Puritan stock has died out?"

ALBANY, May 14. -- It is reported that Gov. Roosevelt and the leaders of the Republican Party will meet Tuesday and fix the date for holding the extra session of the Legislature to consider the Ford Franchise Tax bill and rapid transit measures.

CHICAGO, May 14. -- Donald McLean, a well-known railway promoter, fell or jumped from the fourth-story balustrade of the Palmer House at noon to-day, and died to-night from his injuries. He had been living at the Palmer House since May 6. His daughter, Mrs. D.N. Phillips, has occupied the room adjoining, and Saturday night Mrs. Annie W. Conkey, a professional nurse and a friend of Mrs. Phillips, remained with her.
CHICAGO, May 14. -- The League baseball games scheduled to be played here today were postponed on account on the rain.

BUFFALO, May 14. -- The grain shovelers will return to work to-morrow morning under the agreement reached at 1 o'clock this morning at the conference between the Lake Carriers' Association, elevator men, and grain shovelers. The terms of the agreement were reduced to writing and properly signed to-night at the residence of Bishop Quigley.

The Jordan L. Mott Iron Works, whose main plant is situated at One Hundred and Thirty-third Street and Third Avenue, have been bought by a new trust, known as the American Plumbing Supply and Lead Company, composed of forty-five important plumbing supply concerns in the United States.

SAULT STE. MARIE, Mich., May 14. -- The schooner Nelson, deeply laden with a cargo of coal, foundered in Lake Superior, off Grand Marais, last evening, and all hands went down with her. So far as known here no one escaped from this, the first disaster of the season, except the Captain.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., May 14. -- Secretary Alger forwarded to the President to-day some dispatches from Gen. Otis. They advised him that another peace commission from Aguinaldo was on its way to Manila to discuss terms of peace. No instructions were sent from here to Gen. Otis, the policy being, as heretofore, to leave matters entirely with Gen. Otis.

The Rev. Dr. Madison C. Peters of the Bloomingdale Reformed Church last evening gave the second lecture in the series "Justice to the Jew," taking for his text Psalm xv., 5: "He that putteth not his hand to usury."

ORANGE, N.J., May 14. -- The Rev. Dr. Charles Hall Everest, for nine years pastor of the First Congregational Church of East Orange, presented his resignation to the congregation to-day. A meeting was held immediately after the services and the resignation accepted. For a year or more there has been dissatisfaction and unrest in the church.

Yesterday was essentially a day for the country, and every one who could, went out of town. At an early hour New York was deserted. The country itself is just now in its full glory, and the fields and gardens are radiant with the blossoms of Spring. The golf enthusiasts had it all their own way, and it was again with difficulty that all who went out to Ardsley could play on the links.

BUFFALO, May 14. -- The Board of Directors of the Pan-American Exposition Company yesterday unanimously agreed that the exhibition shall be held on what is known locally as the "Rumsey Farm," located on the Niagara frontier, in the northern suburbs of the city, and including a portion of Delaware Park.

MANILA, May 14. -- Prof. Schurman, President of the United States Philippine Commission, gave a farewell luncheon to-day to Admiral Dewey,, at which Prof. Dean C. Worcester and Col. Charles Denby of the commission, with Gen. MacArthur, Mrs. Lawton, and others, were present. The health of the Admiral was drunk with the utmost cordiality.

A report to the effect that ex-President Grover Cleveland had dropped dead at Middle Bass Island, near Sandusky, Ohio, was received in this city about 7:30 o'clock last night. As is usual in such cases, the rumor spread with great rapidity, and an hour after the report was received, it was the subject of discussion about the lobbies of the up-town hotels, and in the political clubs.

The history of the Stock Exchange on Saturday contains both encouragement and -- for prudent men -- warning.

WASHINGTON, May 14. -- The State Department has been informally advised that claims aggregating a considerable amount have been made by British, French, and German residents in Cuba during the recent insurrection, and that these ultimately will be pressed against the United States Government.

I thank you for your answer to my letter in regard to the charges that Mr. Atkinson's pamphlets were seditious or treasonable. MANILA, May 14. -- The civilian members of the United States Philippine Commission are favorable to the meeting with a Filipino commission, which was suggested yesterday on behalf of Aguinaldo by Lieut. Reyes, of the staff of Gen. Gregorio del Pilar, who came to Gen. Lawton under a flag of truce bearing the proposal.

The large bronze bust of Thomas Paine by Wilson McDonald, which is to be placed on the Paine Monument at New Rochelle, was unveiled last night on the platform at the Academy of Music. The unveiling was followed by a lecture on Thomas Paine by Col. Robert G. Ingersoll in the presence of a large gathering of the admirers of the two philosophers -- the dead and the living.
GENEVA, Switzerland, May 14. -- Sixteen South American Archbishops and Bishops have arrived here on their way to Rome to attend the forthcoming Consistory.

WARDNER, Idaho, May 15. -- The crisis in the labor troubles here is expected to commence on Thursday of this week. Should the period pass over quietly no more outbreaks of lawlessness, it is thought, need be looked for during the continuance of military rule. On the other hand, should there be any clash this week between the soldiers and the element in the union, it is impossible to tell what bloodshed may occur.
PITTSBURG, May 15. -- The Chicagos won to-day's game from the Pittsburgs through a three-bagger by Green and an error. Score:

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., May 15. -- George D. Scott, manager for John D. Rockefeller, under Superintendent Hemmingway, committed suicide this morning about 6:30 o'clock, while laboring under temporary aberration of the mind.

The Peace Conference, which has been called by an imperial rescript of the Czar Nicholas of Russia, will meet at The Hague, the capital of Holland, Thursday. This Conference exalts, for the moment, the quiet little town into a prominence beyond that of any other city of the world. For several weeks it will be the Mecca of all those who are looking for universal peace.

CHICAGO, May 15. -- The Rev. W.W. Reynolds, pastor of the Brightwood Methodist Church of Indianapolis, recently wrote to Capt. Luke Colleran, Chief of the Chicago Detective Department, inquiring if the use of the bicycle among women had affected their morality in any perceptible manner. Although not offering statistics, Capt. Colleran's reply deals with the subject in a positive manner.

WASHINGTON, May 15. -- "The Dewey fund has been started," said Assistant Secretary Vanderlip to-night. "Very simple machinery has been employed to open it, and the rest must depend to a large extent upon the newspapers that have suggested the raising of the money with which to present a home to him.

Probably the brief travesty of the Empire Theatre "Romeo and Juliet," introduced in the barn scene of "The Man in the Moon" at the New York Theatre last night, is "good humored." It certainly is not apt, witty, or ingenious. Sam Bernard, in white silk robes and with flowing brown hair, looks quite human and feminine until he speaks in his familiar dialect.

The Methodist preachers of New York held their regular weekly meeting yesterday at 150 Fifth Avenue. The feature of the meeting was an address by the Rev. Dr. Theodore L. Cuyler of Brooklyn, who is a Presbyterian, on "Old-Time Methodism." Dr. Cuyler pointed out that in the progression of churches in recent years it was, to be deplored that the effective methods of teaching employed in the old days were too often abandoned.

MINNEAPOLIS, May 15. -- Many Commissioners to the Presbyterian General Assembly and others interested have arrived here to attend the foreign missionary meeting, which opens to-morrow. Important questions which may come before the Assembly are already under consideration, including the case of the Rev. Dr. Arthur C. McGiffert, whose sentiments, expressed in his book, "The Christian Church in the Apostolic Age," fell under the ban of last year's Assembly.

NORFOLK, Va., May 15. -- For a year there has been talk of the formation of a trust to control the peanut trade in Virginia, and for some time options have been held upon nearly, if not all, the cleaning houses in the State. Those options have been extended once or twice, and the last renewal expired to-day.

Israel F. Fischer of Brooklyn, appointed United States General Appraiser to succeed Ferdinand N. Shurtleff, removed by President McKinley, was installed in office yesterday. He was sworn in by United States Commissioner Benedict at the Public Stores. Mr. Fischer will assume his duties this morning.

The Inter-State Commerce Commission began yesterday morning in Room 43, Federal Building, a session of two days to investigate the differences existing between export and domestic rates on grain and its products from the West to this city, and also the objections of the railways and ocean lines to having established and public tariffs.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 15. -- For fifty years it has been an unwritten law of Princeton that no chorus parade must pass through the streets. Every show proprietor, in making his Gates, has always left Princeton from the list, for it had been a matter of common knowledge in the profession that the students would enforce the unwritten law.

In yesterday's stock market they who were most active and influential were men of consequence much beyond the average of those who figure in the daily routine of Wall Street. Instead of further declines there was steadiness throughout the whole market. Here and there quotations fell off under special pressure, but the market as a whole was strong throughout the day.

LONDON, May 15. -- Queen Victoria arrived in London to-day from Windsor, accompanied by the Duke and Duchess of York and her suite, and drove to Kensington Palace, the party occupying a number of open four-horse landaus, with postilions in blue and white, red-coated outriders, and escorted by a detachment of the Horse Guards.
LONDON, May 15. -- The Filipino Junta here has received the following message from Aguinaldo, cabled from Hongkong under date of May 12:

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 15. -- Circulation was given to-night to the statement, bearing some marks of authenticity, that the successor of Timothy Dwight of Yale University had at last been found, and that at the May meeting of the corporation next week, or another closely following, Prof. Arthur Twining Hadley would be elected to that position.

SYRACUSE, May 15. -- Officers of the Syracuse tube company in this city to-day stated that the National Tube Company, a consolidation of the principal mills in the United States making wrought iron and steel pipes and tubes, would probably be formed this week. It will have an annual tonnage of 1,000,000 tons of tubular goods, and will be capitalized at $65,000,000.

BALTIMORE, May 15. -- Judges Goff and Morris, sitting in the United States Circuit Court, signed an order and decree to-day authorizing the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Company to issue full-paid and non-assessable stocks and bonds for the purpose of retiring the old issues, as provided for in the plan of agreement decided upon by the reorganization managers.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., May 15. -- It is the intention of President McKinley to be in the Western States at the time of the return of the volunteers from the Philippines. It is expected that the necessity for the retention of volunteers in the Island of Luzon will not exist much longer, and when the volunteers reach their native States for muster out, Mr. McKinley hopes to be there to greet and honor them.

HAVANA, May 15. -- Gen. Maximo Gomez informed Gov. Gen. Brooke to-day that he must withdraw from the plan for distributing the $3,000,000 appropriated to the payment of the Cuban troops to the extent that he will not name other Commissioners to replace those originally named by him who have refused to serve. Gov. Gen. Brooke is to go ahead with a new plan, Gomez remaining in an attitude of friendly inactivity.

WASHINGTON, May 15. -- It is expected at the War Department that Gen. Otis will take steps at once to replace the Spanish garrison at Zamboanga with United States troops. The indications are that a comparatively small force will suffice, provided that it is supported by one or two gunboats.

Joseph Mullen, an ex-convict who had been on trial before Judge Cowing, in Part II. of the Court of General Sessions, charged with killing his wife, was convicted yesterday of murder in the first degree. Mullen was defended by Lawyer William F. Howe.

Michael Kivelin, thirty-eight years old, of 972 East One Hundred and Sixty-first Street, head shipping clerk for a Grand Street department store, was shot twice in the shoulder last evening by John Healey, twenty-eight years old, of 410 East Tenth Street. Healey was a packer in the same store, but was recently discharged. Kivelin was taken to Gouverneur Hospital, not dangerously hurt, and Healey was locked up in the Eldridge Street Station.

What was announced as a joint debate on "The Honesty, Feasibility, Wisdom, Justice, and Equity of the Financial Plank of the Chicago Platform," took place last evening in the Assembly Hall of the United Charities Building. Wilbur Eastlake was the supporter of the affirmative side of the proposition, and J.J. Russell opposed it. A dozen or more of the audience endeavored to take part in the discussion.
The Brooklyn and Philadelphia baseball teams furnished an interesting exhibition for nearly 5,000 persons at Washington Park yesterday. The home team won by score of 8 to 5.

Justice Russell, in the Supreme Court, yesterday heard testimony in the action for a separation brought by Clara Wendell against her husband, Frank L. Wendell, a cloth importer of Worth Street. The matrimonial troubles of the Wendells have frequently been aired in public print.

HONGKONG, May 15. -- The native opposition to the occupation by British forces of the new territory Kow Loon, opposite Hongkong, has suddenly been renewed. About 900 men of the Hongkong Regiment, with machine guns, are leaving here to-day and to-night, while the volunteers have been warned to be in readiness for any emergency.
READING, Penn., May 15. -- Coroner Rothermel to-night announced his intention of beginning the inquiry into the cause of the wreck on the Philadelphia and Reading Railway at Exeter next Monday.

BUFFALO, May 15. -- Boss Scooper Nevels was set upon to-night while returning from work by a crowd of boys. He drew a revolver and fired two shots in the air. Before he reached home a crowd of women numbering over 100 joined in the attack upon him, beat him badly, and took away his revolver. Nevels was rescued by the police.

Had St. Thomas's Protestant Episcopal Church been twice its present size it would have been filled yesterday by persons eager to attend the funeral of ex-Gov. Roswell P. Flower. Many old friends and business associates of the dead financier who reached the church a quarter of an hour before the time fixed for the services were unable to get through the vestibule, so great was the crowd.

PARIS, May 15. -- M. Francisque Sarcoy, the famous dramatic critic, died to-day in his seventy-first year.

The legislative investigating committee will resume its sessions at 10 A.M. to-day in the room of the Criminal Branch of the Supreme Court, Criminal Courts Building. The committee intends to sit four days every week during the Summer, but the special session of the Legislature may interrupt it for a few days. All the members of the committee are now in the city except Mr. Fallows, who will arrive early this morning.

The Committee of Arrangements has received assurances to that effect cabled by Senator A.J. Beveridge of Indiana, who is now at Hongkong, and is acting as its representative.

Wiener of the Chicago Clinical School. The return to youth, it is asserted, is produced by hypodermic injections of the lymphatic fluid of animals, particularly young goats.

CLEVELAND, May 16. -- The Fasig-Tipton blue ribbon horse sale opened this afternoon and continued to-night at the Tattersall mart in Glenville. The bidding was fairly lively, and fifty-four horses were disposed of in the afternoon. It was considered surprising that Norace and Advertiser went at such low figures. Following were the sales for $500 and over.

Mr. and Mrs. Bradley-Martin gave a dinner of eighty-six covers in the Astor Gallery, at the Waldorf-Astoria, last evening. The invitations, which were issued last week, were informally worded and stated that the affair was an au revoir to Mr. and Mrs. Bradley Martin's friends in New York. This statement disposes of the story so frequently printed of late that the entertainment was to mark Mr. and Mrs. Bradley Martin's final farewell to New York.

Despite the threatening weather in the early afternoon, yesterday's attendance at the Open-Air Horse Show, at Manhattan Field, One Hundred and Fifty-third Street and Eighth Avenue, was much larger than on Monday. The features of yesterday's show were the fox hunt, in which a pack of eight couples of hounds were sent off in full cry on a drag, and a four-in-hand driving competition from the Waldorf-Astoria to the grounds.

The man found dead on Sunday last in Field's Woods, in Willowbrook, Staten Island, died from strangulation. Death did not result from the pistol shot wound in the side, and the shot which caused the wound in the side was not fired by the dead man. Coroner's Physicians Whitman and Mord and Dr. John L. Feeney, Chief Sanitary Inspector of Richmond, unite in saying that the death was due to asphyxiation.

C. Oliver Iselin said yesterday that the yacht Columbia, the new defender of the America's Cup, will be launched June 8. The affair, according to this authority, will be interwoven with some of the early Summer social events of Providence and Bristol.

He is awaiting further information from New York City as to whether or not the amendments to the bill which he favors will have the support of the organization. If not, then he will sign the Ford bill to-morrow.

LONDON, May 17. -- Sir Thomas Lipton has limited to fifteen the number of guests to be present at the launching of the America's Cup challenger Shamrock. The date of the launch will not be made public. The Prince of Wales and the Duke of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha will have a private view of the Shamrock about June 7.

WASHINGTON, May 17. -- Rear Admiral Schley left this afternoon at 3:30 o'clock over the Pennsylvania Railroad for Omaha, to pay a long-deferred visit to ex-Senator Manderson. He was accompanied by Mrs. Schley, and will not return before June 5.

An honorable acquittal was accorded Harry C. Woodruff by Magistrate Cornell yesterday, in the Centre Street Police Court, where he was examined on the complaint of Herman Kohl of Philipsburg, N.J., who charged him with being connected with the Financial Agency Company, at 145 Nassau Street.
THE HAGUE, May 17. -- All the delegates to the International Peace Conference have arrived. To-day was spent in a general exchange of visits.

The jury summoned by Coroner Guy to investigate the killing by a trolley car of Edward Halker, two years of age, of 365 Steinway Avenue, Steinway, yesterday censured the New York and Queens County Electric Railway for running its cars at such high speed and without fenders. A copy of the finding was ordered sent to Mayor Van Wyck and another to District Attorney Davidson of Queens County.

PITTSBURG, May 17. -- Ex-Congressman E.E. Robbins, counsel for the Baltimore and Ohio at Greensburg, has closed negotiations for the purchase of 3,000 acres of coal lands in Westmoreland County, near Irwin. Engineers of the railroad are surveying for a proposed branch to run from Guffey Station, twenty-five miles from Pittsburg and the Baltimore and Ohio main line, to the virgin coal property.

COLUMBIA, S.C., May 17. -- The people of South Carolina are deprived of the gratification of giving a home to Gen. Wade Hampton. The movement to raise a fund for that purpose was spontaneous in all sections of the State, and began immediately on the burning by an incendiary of Southern Cross.

WASHINGTON, May 17. -- The Record and Pension Office of the War Department, which had about as much as it could attend to before the war with Spain came on, and was supplying the Pension Office with the data necessary to enable applicants for pensions to prove their claims, is now undertaking to procure and card index the histories of all volunteers who served in the last war.

BUFFALO, May 17. -- Bishop Quigley took a determined stand in his efforts to bring the strike of the grain shovelers and sympathetic organizations to an end to-night, and as a result the outlook for a cessation of the trouble is somewhat brighter. The striking freight handlers in East Buffalo have appointed a committee with power to act, which will confer with the lake line managers to-morrow.

HAVANA, May 17. -- An order will be issued to-morrow appointing Lieut. Col. W.A. Rafferty of the Second Cavalry, Lieut. Col. Randall of the Eighth Infantry, and Lieut. Col. Bisbee of the First Infantry, to supervise the distribution of the $3,000,000 to the Cuban troops. All appointments under former orders will be revoked.

BOSTON, May 17. -- The promoters of the plan for consolidating the electric street railways and electric lighting plants of Massachusetts and Rhode Island, announced to-day that the last of the thirty-three companies which it is proposed to take into the combination had been secured. The capitalization of the combined companies, it is understood, will be not less than $24,000,000, of which one-half will be 4 per cent. cumulative preferred stock, and one-half common stock.

CHICAGO, May 17. -- Negotiations are in progress for a consolidation of the elevated railroads of Chicago. The indications are that the South Side, the Lake Street, the Metropolitan, the Northwestern Elevated, and the Union Loop Company will be one company within a few weeks. It is understood that C.T. Yerkes has assented to the terms offered.

WASHINGTON, May 17. -- Humphrey Taylor, a negro suspected of the Rosenstein murder at Slidell, Md., to-day shot and killed Police Sergeant Fritz Passau, wounded Policeman Gow, and kept a posse of half a dozen officers at bay from the loft of a house for nearly two hours. Dozens of shots were exchanged between the officers and the fugitive, who only surrendered when preparations were made to burn the house.
NEWPORT, May 17. -- Robert Sedgwick arrived from New York this evening.

The Brooklyns won their third straight game from the Philadelphias at Washington Park yesterday afternoon. The victory enabled them to pass Chicago in the League race, and the team left last night on its first Western trip ensconced in second place. There was a big crowd on hand to give the team a send-off, some 5,100 persons being present.

ALBANY, May 17. -- The board designated to examine into the moral character, capacity, and general fitness for service in the National Guard as a commissioned officer of Major Clinton H. Smith of the Seventy-first Regiment, who was charged with cowardice at Santiago, convened at noon to-day in the State Armory. It will sit behind closed doors. Major Smith, the accused, prior to his appearance before the board, had a private interview with the Governor.

It was a day for the commoners at Morris Park yesterday, and it was also a day for the "plungers," as four of the six races were won by pronounced favorites -- Algol. His Royal Highness, St. Callatine, and Challenger; a fifth, by Prince of Melbourne, an equal favorite for his race with Withers, and the other by Bettie Gray, who was third choice of the speculators in her race.

WASHINGTON, May 17. -- As the result of a conference held at the Foreign Office in London between Lord Salisbury, Sir Julian Pauncefote, and Ambassador Choate, the latter acting under direct instructions from Secretary Hay, it can now be predicted that the High Joint Commission to adjust issues between the United States and Canada will be reassembled during the coming Summer or early Fall.

The annual commencement of the General Theological Seminary in Chelsea Square, West Twentieth Street, near Ninth Avenue, took place yesterday morning in the chapel. After the exercises the cornerstone of the building to be known as Hoffman Hall was laid.

TRENTON, May 17. -- The Electric Automobile and Manufacturing Company, with an authorized capital of $500,000, was incorporated to-day. The company is empowered to manufacture and operate vehicles propelled by electricity or other power. The incorporators are Charles P. Scott of New York, Frederick W. Gaston and Edgar J. Runyon of Elizabeth, N. J.

Russell Sage was defeated for Trustee of the West Presbyterian Church last night, and with him the entire old Board of Trustees except Henry M. Flagler and S.C.T. Dodd. All of these Trustees resigned after the recent action of the congregation in voting to retain the Rev. Anthony H. Evans as pastor. The members of the board contended that this vote was in effect a condemnation of their course and financial policy.

ALBANY, May 17. -- Gov. Roosevelt has called an extraordinary session of the Legislature to meet next Monday night at 8 o'clock. At that time he will transmit a message to the body, calling its attention to such legislation as he desires passed. The Legislature, thus assembled, can act only upon questions submitted to it by the Governor.

ELIZABETH, N.J., May 18. -- No one here had heard before this evening that the Government might locate the naval magazine desired in New York Harbor at Tremley. Nothing had been heard of the matter until word came from New York to-night that this was proposed. The selection of the site, however, if it is under consideration, will be fought by every business interest along the Staten Island Sound shore.

The transfer was not attended by any ceremony.

PARIS, May 19. -- A serious strike in the Paris Post Office occurred yesterday, which was not ended until 4 o'clock this morning, when the first brigade of striking postmen resumed work.

The North German Lloyd mail steamship Barbarossa, which left her pier at Hoboken at 11 o'clock yesterday, bound for Bremen, returned at 4 o'clock with a fierce fire raging in her forehold.
