NEWPORT, May 18. -- A private dispatch received from New York states that Admiral Sampson, with his fleet, will sail at 3 P.M. May 28 for Newport and arrive early the following morning. The fleet will land its infantry battalion on inauguration day, May 30. After the exercises the fleet will begin its work in connection with the Naval War College.
MONTCLAIR, N.J., May 18. -- One of the most prominent citizens of Montclair is threatened with hydrophobia. He lives on Mountain Avenue and is engaged in business in New York.

The first session of the decennial meeting of the Actuarial Society of America was held yesterday in the Directors' room of the Metropolitan Life Building.

WASHINGTON, May 18. -- Assistant Secretary of the Treasury Vanderlip and Treasurer E.H. Roberts learned to-day that the impulse to contribute to the Dewey Home Fund only needed to be directed, for, as a result of the announcement that a committee had been formed to receive and account for contributions, the morning mail brought a large number of subscriptions, varying from $100 to 10 cents.

The hall was filled with men and women, the members and friends of the United Hebrew Charities. Isaac Wallach, one of the Directors of the building, presided.

PHILADELPHIA, May 18. -- It is reported here that the worsted yarn trust, to be known as the United States Worsted Yarn Company, with a capital of $50,000,000, is practically an assured fact, and that all that remains to be done is the matter of formal organization. Nineteen worsted yarn spinners, including the largest spinners in the country, are said to have agreed to enter the trust.

Clark Wallace, in the House of Commons to-day, called the Prime Minister's attention to a Washington dispatch in which, referring to the High Commission, it was stated: "The negotiations have taken a new turn by the suggestion that the Alaskan boundary question be submitted to arbitration, independent of the other issues involved, thus leaving the commission free to resume its work on the many other pending questions."

The recently organized New York Realty, Bond, Exchange and Trust Company closed its first transaction yesterday. In the salesroom at noon, 101 and 103 East Twenty-ninth Street, sold under partition proceedings, were struck down to Henry Morgenthau, President of the company, for $36,700.

ALBANY, May 18. -- Among those who appeared before the Governor to-day in opposition to the Doughty Barren Island bill was Dr. Lewis, President of the State Board of Health. Dr. Lewis admitted that there were disagreeable odors at times omitted from the island, but, he said, they were not at all detrimental to good health.

Grace, owners of the Columbia Theatre of Boston, by which he will take the management of that house next season and conduct it as music hall.

Frederick A. Hammond has obtained a renewal of his lease of the Plaza Hotel from the New York Life Insurance Company. WASHINGTON, May 18. -- The German Ambassador, Dr. von Holleben, called at the State Department to-day and had a talk with Secretary Hay, in the course of which, it is understood, reference was made to the opening of the sessions of the Peace Conference at The Hague.

Nothing now can simplify the Speakership contest but the renunciation by Speaker Reed of his determination to retire from Congress.

WASHINGTON, May 18. -- Secretary of the Navy Long is deeply interested in the result of an experiment which is to be made under the direction of Capt. John M. Hawley for the enlistment of 300 or 350 men in the West. It is believed that Western enlistments will quicken that section's interest in the navy.

A portion of the valuable collection of manuscripts, known as the "Appendix," formed by the late Earl of Ashburnham, was brought to the hammer in London two weeks ago. The choicest volume in the catalogue was an important text of the later version (1400-40) of Wycliffe's English Bible, known as the "Bramhall Manuscript."

CINCINNATI, May 19. -- The Federation of Labor organization of Cincinnati held a demonstration to-night in honor of Mayor Samuel H. Jones of Toledo. After the street parade more than 4,000 persons listened to Mayor Jones at Music Hall for over two hours. There were frequent outbursts of applause.

Fellows, lately a professor in a Brooklyn educational institution. He omitted nine-tenths of the maximum penalty, sending Fellows to the House of Correction for one year only.

VICTORIA, B.C., May 20. -- The schooner Werfa, which left Dunedin, New Zealand, last September, on an interisland trading expedition, with a party of nineteen, was wrecked and all but one of those who started out on her were lost. The news of the accident reached Sydney just before the sailing of the Miowera, which arrived here to-day.

ALBANY, May 20. -- -Mayor Van Wyek to-day returned to the Governor, with his veto, the Separate Department of Elections bill for New York City, which emanated from the Cities Committee. The Governor, it is understood, will ask the Legislature at its extra session next week to pass a new Election Department bill, believing that he can pass it over Mayor Van Wyck's second expected veto.

Ferdinand W. Peck, United States Commissioner General to the Paris Exposition of 1900, returned yesterday morning by the steamer St. Louis. He was accompanied by Mrs. Peck and J.H. McGibbons, Director of Exploitation, of his staff.

WASHINGTON, May 20. -- So far the Navy Department knows nothing except in the most general way of the itinerary of Admiral Dewey's cruise from Manila to New York. He has reported simply that he will come by the Suez route and has not indicated officially how long he will take in making the trip.

VIENNA, May 2. -- Perhaps the loveliest month in the year in Vienna is May, as the air then is so brilliantly clear, the sun so bright, the foliage in all its Spring beauty, and the heat still bearable. Year by year the departure for the country is postponed more and more by the aristocratic and leading families of Vienna, so that the season is extended further and further into the late Spring every year.

TOLEDO, Ohio, May 20. -- To-day the Directors of the Wheeling and Lake Erie Railroad Company closed negotiations for the purchase of the Cleveland, Canton and Southern, and voted to issue bonds to cover the purchase. They also voted to refund the outstanding bonded indebtedness of 5 per cents. at 4 per cent.

EASTON, Penn., May 20. -- Lafayette College is preparing to dedicate the restored Pardee Hall. WASHINGTON, May 20. -- The President and Mrs. McKinley, with the friends who accompanied them, reached Washington at 5:30 P.M. to-day over the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad. The stay of twelve days at Hot Springs was one almost entirely of rest, the only break being a day's run to Natural Bridge, Va., a week ago. The outing has been of great benefit to the President, and he resumes his official duties thoroughly refreshed and invigorated.

At the first shot the hand on the flagship played a lively air, and her white-clad sailors crowded the decks and gave a tremendous cheer.

Malster, the present Executive at the City Hall, has put politicians on their mettle, and already things are waxing warm for the Fall election, when a Governor of the State will be chosen, as will members of the State Senate and House of Delegates.

WASHINGTON, May 20. -- Consul General Frank H. Mason, at Berlin, makes an interesting report on the development by industrial economists in Germany of an invention "which promises to solve more effectively than has been done hitherto the problem of consuming bituminous coal, slack, sawdust, and other inferior forms of fuel without smoke and under conditions of extreme economy."

ANNAPOLIS, May 20. -- The race between the Pennsylvania and Naval Academy crews did not come off until after sundown. A high wind made the water on the Severn too rough for the sport, and the races were twice deferred on that account.

WASHINGTON, May 20. -- The War Department has turned over to Gen. Shafter the complete direction of all military affairs in Alaska. Toler, and it is to become the permanent property of the member who wins it three times.

Tripler, THE TIMES of this morning states among other things: "Mr. Tripler paid his respects to Prof. Morton of Stevens Institute, who, Mr. Tripler said, has referred to his attempts to utilize liquid air as another Keely motor scheme."

The Huguenot Yacht Club of New Rochelle held its special race yesterday in a smacking breeze from west-northwest. The clouds had looked menacing, but under the freshening wind they were split and rifted, and the sun turned their fluffy edges into silvery fleece. The sea was what the boys on the knockabouts called smooth, but the dories did not turn out.

In spite of the fact that the Mazet Investigating Committee practically put "it up" to Chief Devery to make the next move in the matter of poolrooms in this city, and the promise of Commissioner Abell that he would see that the law was enforced, there was little evidence yesterday that anything had been done in the line of forcing the gamblers to put up their shutters.

Mr. GOLDWIN SMITH writes to The London Times to deprecate the proposition embodied in the new bill for the government of London. The cities of the United States are, as might have been expected, the helots whom the author introduces as frightful examples of the perils of "an elective, that is to say a political, instead of an administrative organization."

Mortimer N. Lang, twenty-four years old, of 401 Manhattan Avenue, and Montgomery Milbank of the same age, a son of Dr. Robert Milbank, of 154 West Forty-eighth Street, with two other young men, dined in May's restaurant, at 50 West Twenty-eighth Street, last night, and then tried to walk out without paying for their dinners, so it is claimed.

The musical season in New York City will end to-morrow, when Mr. Emil Sauer will offer the final concert in the shape of a piano recital at Carnegie Hall. Meanwhile the centre of such musical activity as is most interesting to the readers of this paper has shifted to London. The season of grand opera under the direotton of Maurice Grau opened at Covent Garden on Monday, May 8, with a performance of "Lohengrin."

WHEN Daniel Webster was Secretary of State for one month under President William Henry Harrison, and later under President John Tyler, he occupied a house which was then new. It was the house that Senator Chauncey M. Depew has selected for his Washington home at the beginning of his term of office.

The Committee on Securities of the Stock Exchange has ruled that in the settlement of contracts of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad new first mortgage 4 per cent. and new prior lien 3 1/2 per cent. bonds, "when and as issued," interest ceases on the day of delivery if made before May 24.

ORANGE, N.J., May 20. -- A reception was given at the Essex County Country Club this afternoon in honor of Rear Admiral William T. Sampson. It lasted from 3 until 6 and was attended by several hundred persons. The Rear Admiral's pennant was run up on the club's flagstaff.

-- That the newspaper has come to play a decidedly important part in American life is a fact which everybody in the country will readily acknowledge, but this unanimity has hardly prepared us to learn that there is an "American Sunday," distinguished from other Sundays, or at least from the English Sunday, by the appearance on that day of morning newspapers of large size.

TOLEDO, Ohio, May 20. -- Members of a syndicate of English capitalists stopped off here to-day, en route from the West to New York. They are here for the purpose of buying up all the Portland cement factories of consequence in the country, and organizing a powerful combination to control the output. They are Leedham White, Anthony White, C.P.E. Cheefins, and R. Carling Styles of London.

LONDON, May 20. -- The House of Commons rose yesterday for the Whitsuntide holidays, fatigued by dull debates and bored by the prospect of duller ones to come. The London Government bill has passed the committee stage, the Government having rearranged the administrative areas of the greatest city in the world in one sitting, which, as Liberal papers remark, is probably the record performance in constitution-mongering.

At the meeting of the Bostonian Society in the Old State House, Mr. C.W. Ernst delivered an interesting talk on the subject, "Words Coined in Boston." Mr. Ernst said that Gov. Andros introduced, among other unsalutary things, the term, "Your Excellency," as applied to the Governor. The speaker claimed the word "boss" was first used by a man named Gardner, who came in a ship from the North Sea in charge of some mechanics.
LONG BRANCH, N.J., May 20. -- Summer guests are beginning to arrive at Long Branch in force. William Dobbin of Ashbourne, Penn, is here for the season.

The prize competitions in athletics and military drill of the Church Temperance Legion brought a host of admirers of the young soldier to the Seventy-first Regiment Armory yesterday. The legion is a Protestant Episcopal organization, and its members, who come from parishes all over the United State, make a solemn promise not to drink intoxicants while they retain their membership.

The Tenderloin, to all outward appearances, was closed tight at 12 o'clock last night. This strict observance of the law was attributed by some persons to the orders issued by Chief Devery on Friday to the Captains of the different precincts.

The Long Island Regatta Association will hold its annual regatta on July 8 over the North Beach course, which will be improved and staked off at every quarter-mile point. Secretary Pelton has announced that silver cups instead of medals will be awarded for each event.
BRIDGEPORT, May 20. -- Mrs. Caroline Cox, seventy years old, who was once worth $70,000, was to-day taken to the almshouse by a Sheriff, who had served a writ of execution on her property.

MANILA, May 20. -- Gen. Gregorio del Pilar, commander of the insurgent forces in front of Gen. Lawton's division; Lieut. Col. Alberto Barretto, Judge Advocate; Major Zealcita of Aguinaldo's staff, and Senor Graciognzaga, a former member of the Filipino Cabinet, constitute the commission appointed to co-operate with Senors Florentine Torres, Pablo Campo, and Teodore Yanco of Manila, for the purpose of negotiating terms of peace with the American Commissioners.

MINNEAPOLIS, May 20. -- The Rev. Dr. A.C. McGiffert of the Union Theological Seminary by letter to the Presbyterian General Assembly to-day refused to comply with its request of last year that he should modify his attitude on doctrinal matters expressed in his "Christian Church in the Apostolic Age" or else withdraw from the Church.

WASHINGTON, May 20. -- "We may not come to it right away," said ex-Gov. Oates of Alabama to-day, "but we must come to it before long, or else Alabama will fall behind the other States in the estimation of the United States. Alabama has got to stop suppressing the voter, ballot-box stuffing must be prevented, and our laws governing the judiciary must be modernized, or we will suffer.

HAVANA, May 21. -- A number of persons interested in the "debtor and creditor decree" attended the departure of the five Commissioners this afternoon for Washington, where they hope to secure a modification of the measure. Dr. Junco, head of the commission, said the question was one of great importance, because affecting millions already invested and preventing millions from being invested.

CHICAGO, May 21. -- Every day that the tie-up of the grain fleet continues on account of the strike of longshoremen at Buffalo the commerce of Chicago is hurt, according to the estimates of shipping men, to the extent of almost $1,000,000. The aggregate loss thus far to the local trade by the paralysis of through lake traffic is placed at $15,000,000.

The gale of wind which blew down the Speedway yesterday made a heavy driving coat a desirable piece of clothing. The other surroundings were pleasant enough, for there was a blue sky and plenty of sunshine. The Harlem River to the east of the long driveway was alive with oarsmen, and dandelions dotted the lawns along the entire path.

LONDON, May 21. -- The news of the disaster to the Paris spread rapidly in London, and great excitement and alarm was felt until the arrival of information that all on board were safe. The company's offices were besieged with inquirers, anxiously asking for news regarding friends or relatives on board the steamer.

MINNEAPOLIS, May 21. -- After a Sunday devoted to churchgoing and preaching and three popular meetings in the interests of home missions and Sabbath observance, the Presbyterian General Assembly will begin to-morrow a week of hard work.

WASHINGTON, May 21. -- A remarkable state of affairs and a case unprecedented in postal history is shown at Skaguay, Alaska, the gateway to the Yukon, in reports just received at the Post Office Department. The office was established and opened at Skaguay Jan. 1, 1898, and W. B. Sampson was appointed Postmaster.

The woolen goods division of the textile markets is a place of quickly varying modes. This was emphasized during the week by the change which has taken place. There is not so much more business being accomplished, but the clothiers are beginning to "take notice." Their men are pretty generally on the road, and have begun to send in orders, not enough, however, to determine in any way what the season is likely to be.

CHICAGO, May 21. -- Inhabitants of Chicago now live to be twice as old as did persons thirty years ago. In other words, the average age at death was twice as high in 1898 as in 1868. This remarkable announcement is officially made by the Department of Health. The conclusion is demonstrated by an elaborate statement of statistics, illustrated by diagrams.

CINCINNATI, May 21. -- A provisional organization of the National Association of Jewish Charities was made here to-day by representatives from a dozen States and from most of the large cities. The meeting began last Friday, and its sessions have been held so as not to conflict with those of the National Conference of Charities and Corrections, which began a week's session on Wednesday.

Mr. Archer in his "American Jottings" comments very sympathetically on the recent decline in the rate of increase of our native American stock, particularly the New England stock, and suggests as a reason the disinclination of those in moderate circumstances (which includes the great majority) to face the responsibility of large families.

BELLEFONTAINE, Ohio, May 21. -- Mrs. Rachel Austin and her son William were murdered in their home at Middleburg, this county, last night, and their bodies nearly cremated, the house being set on fire. Ernest Austin, a younger son, lies at the point of death in a neighbor's house from a bullet wound in the breast.
The Rev. Dr. Charles H. Eaton preached before a large congregation in the Church of the Divine Paternity yesterday morning. His subject was "What Can the Peace Conference Do?"

Perhaps it may interest your readers to learn something of the Twentieth Kansas Volunteers and of Gen. Fred Funston, late their commander. When the Spanish war broke out and a call was made on Kansas for troops, the Twentieth Kansas was the first regiment organized. It was principally made up of farmers' sons, nearly all Populists.

Some of the press dispatches from Cuba and some corroborative writing by individual correspondents at Havana are giving the impression that the task of pacification, having for one of its objects the giving of an ultimate stable government to the people of Cuba, is being injudiciously conducted by our representatives there.

The French Ministry of War very wisely warns Commandant MARCHAND not to lend himself to be a party to popular demonstrations on his return to France. MARCHAND has traveled several thousand miles through a pestilential country. In the race for Fashoda he distanced the brave MACDONALD, who was trying to reach that place from Uganda.

BRUSSELS, May 21. -- Last evening Archbishop Ireland, accompanied by Bellamy Storer, United States Minister-designate to Spain, and Mrs. Storer, dined at the royal palace at Laeken with King Leopold, Queen Marie Henriette, and the other members of the royal family. His Majesty was most courteous, showing great interest in the Archbishop.

Harry Kuhlke, said to a Republican politician, and Elizabeth Dorman, who refused their addressees, were arraigned in the Jefferson Market Court yesterday on a charge of intoxication. Magistrate Simms fined them $5 each. Kuhlke declared his arrest was an outrage.

FALMOUTH, England, May 21. -- The American Line steamer Paris, Capt. Watkins, from Southampton and Cherbourg, for New York, went aground just off Lowland's Point, an outlying ridge of the Manacles, early this morning at a point half a mile from where the wrecked Atlantic Transport Liner Mohegan lies. The passengers, numbering 386, were landed safely.
Edward Selleck, formerly a Paymaster in the Custom House, in this city, committed suicide at his home, 332 West Eighty-fifth Street, yesterday afternoon, by shooting himself in the right temple.

A case of smallpox was discovered yesterday in the almshouse on Blackwell's Island, and as a result of the investigation by the officials of the Board of Health, the place was put under quarantine. In the institution there are about 2,000 persons, while on the island, in the various institutions, there are in all something like 10,000.

CHICAGO, May 21. -- The treatment here received in a football game this afternoon was too rough to suit William G. Passemore. He was with a number of other young men at Polk Street and Ashland Avenue, where the game was in progress, and while he was assisting in a rush he was slightly bruised.

The affair was first reported as a case of drowning. Investigation showed the man to have received wounds on the head which without doubt caused death.

The Daughters of the American Revolution, New York City Chapter, held their annual, services yesterday afternoon at Trinity Church, the Rev. Dr. J. Nevett Steele delivering the annual sermon. The regular day for the annual church service was the first Sunday after Easter, but owing to the illness of Dr. Steele the service was postponed.

Of all the open-air religious gatherings that occurred in Broadway last night not one drew a larger crowd than that conducted by the United States Church Army of 288 Lexington Avenue, on the corner of Broadway and Thirty-fifth Street, when the unusual spectacle was witnessed of a minister of the Protestant Episcopal Church preaching in the street in his vestments and of the reading of the evening service.

FRANKFORT, Ky., May 21. -- J.B. Burton, who was released from the penitentiary here in March, after serving almost three years for obtaining money under false pretences, proves to be J. Burton Beverly, an Englishman of good family, who has recently inherited about $1,400,000 from his uncle.

SEATTLE, Washington, May 21. -- The long-expected catastrophe at Dawson has occurred, and three-fourths of the town lies in ashes, while hundreds of miners and shop keepers, gamblers and saloon men, are living in tents, sleeping on the snow in blankets, or moving up the creeks into the settlements at the mines.

HAVANA, May 21. -- Senor Domingo Mendez Capote, Secretary of Government, has been devoting considerable time to a study of the electoral laws of various nations with a view of formulating plans for inauguration here.

WASHINGTON, May 21. -- There was a rumor here to-night that there had been a hostile meeting at Bluefields between the Nicarauguan gunboat San Jacinto and the United States cruiser Detroit, which is looking after the interests of Americans in that vicinity.

ST. LOUIS, May 21. -- St. Louis and New York played two games at League Park to-day before a crowd of 17,000 persons. Both games were dull and listless. The Giants won the first game by bunching five hits in the eighth inning. Doheny was very wild in the second game, and gave eight bases on balls.

The Rev. Dr. Benjamin F. De Costa of the Church of St. John the Evangelist prepared a sermon in answer to Bishop Potter's recent letter in reference to the ordination of Dr. Briggs, and started to preach it yesterday morning, but after he had talked for about five minutes he was so overcome by emotional feeling that he passed over the bulk of his manuscript and dismissed his audience with a ten-minute sermon.

ITHACA, May 21. -- After the victory of the Cornell baseball team over the Princeton team at Ithaca yesterday, the students began to celebrate the occasion in what they believed to be harmless ways. Bonfires were built, and a number of the prominent business men of the city lent the boys a hand. A large fire was started on the principal thoroughfare, and the police interfered.

Roosevelt seemed to be getting his ideas about franchise tax legislation from an ex-Governor of the State, who, Mr. Palmer regretted to see, was opposed to the Ford bill.

The feature of the sport at the Morris Park track to-day will be the race for the Amateur Cup, over the Withers mile, in which only gentlemen riders qualified under the rules of the National Steeplechase and Hunt Association may compete. The race closed with twenty-two horses eligible to start, and of this number eight are named to face the starter to-day.

A meeting of the Colonial Aid Society was held yesterday afternoon in the Waldorf-Astoria, to hear from Gen. and Mrs. Guy V. Henry an informal account of educational and relief work in the Island of Puerto Rico. This society was organized two weeks ago by a number of New York women among whom interest has been aroused for the Puerto Ricans because of their destitution.

HELENA, Montana, May 22. -- Mail advices from the eastern part of the State are to the effect that the advent of Spring has caused the Cheyenne Indians to become a little frisky, as has been the case for several years past, especially when the quotas of troops at the adjacent military posts have been reduced.

WASHINGTON, May 22. -- The report from Manila that a form of government has been proposed to the Filipinos, including a Governor General, Cabinet, and Advisory Council, is confirmed at the State Department, where it is said this is the general line of action on which the authorities here and at Manila are proceeding.

WASHINGTON, May 22. -- In anticipation of the prompt return of the volunteer troops in the Philippines, the Secretary of War to-day telegraphed instructions to Gen. Shafter, commanding the Department of California, at San Francisco, to establish a model camp at the Presidio for the accommodation of about 4,000 volunteers from Manila pending their muster out.

CINCINNATI, May 22. -- To-morrow the Great Latonia Derby will be decided over the famous old Kentucky course at Latonia Springs. The indications are for a beautiful day and a fast track. Seven high-class three-year-olds are entered in the big event, and a good contest is expected, as the field is an evenly balanced one and promises to be a very open race.

A fire in Greenpoint early yesterday morning rendered about fifty families homeless and destroyed most of two blocks, at a loss estimated by some at $192,000, though others figure that the damage will approximate over $300,000. The district is partly occupied by factories and partly by tenements.

NEWPORT, May 22. -- A report reaches here to the effect that Mr. and Mrs. F.W. Vanderbilt, who own the villa called Rough Point, on the Cliffs, intend to pass their Summer season elsewhere than at their cottage hereafter, and that the coming season will find Mr. Vanderbilt's brother, W.K. Vanderbilt, occupying the house.

CINCINNATI, May 22. -- Gen. O.O. Howard, recently retired from the United States Army, and Col. H.H. Adams of New York, after a short stay in this city, have gone to New York. They came to Cincinnati from a trip through the mountainous regions of Kentucky and Tennessee.

MILWAUKEE, May 22. -- Edward C. Wall, National Democratic Committeeman of Wisconsin, made public to-day the call for a conference of members of the National Democratic Committee at St. Louis on May 25. While the announcement of the call was published some time ago, the full text is issued to-day for the first time.

Of all the ills to which human flesh is heir, perhaps the most wearing and miserable is that inability to sleep, which doctors call insomnia. Sleep is more necessary than food. A man would perish from want of sleep sooner than from lack of food.

ELIZABETH, N.J., May 22. -- The Union County Grand Jury concluded its labors to-day and handed up to Judge Vail twenty-seven indictments for various offenses. A presentment was made against a number of building and loan associations incorporated and doing business under the laws of other States which, in the opinion of the Grand Jury, were conducted on a swindling basis. CINCINNATI, May 22. -- Breitenstein kept the hits well scattered to-day and won his first game of the season. The Giants should have won in the ninth, when they made a single and two doubles, but Gleason's coaching prevented more than the tieing run to score. Score:

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., May 22. -- E. Hamford Sturges of this city and his cousin, Miss Catherine Leonard of Mount Vernon, were injured in a runaway accident last night. They were driving behind a spirited horse in a runabout along Pelham Bay Avenue in Pelham Manor when the horse became excited.

MONTREAL, May 22. -- The following telegram has been received by Commander Murray of Hancock Post, G.A.R., from Lieut. Col. That is a very singular accident by which the liner Paris has been cast away on the British coast. It is the more singular because the spot where the disaster occurred is so near the place where a British steamer has been lost within a few months under circumstances much more tragical.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- The monthly statement of the collections of internal revenue shows that the total receipts for April, 1899, were $22,274,217, a gain as compared with April, 1898, of $6,991,473. The collections from the several sources of revenue are given as follows: Spirits, $7,490,831; decrease, $181,107; tobacco, $4,729,849: increase, $522,640; fermented liquors, $5,503,796; increase, $2,255,060; oleomargarine, $140,067; increase, $20,995; special taxes under War Revenues act, $22,076; miscellaneous, $4,387,595; increase, $4,351,807.
MANILA, May 22. -- In spite of the presence of the Filipino Commissioners in Manila, the military operations continue with unabated rigor.

Our public school system fosters a form of "absenteeism" which I regret. We are in the suburbs with some of the needs and opportunities of a country town. Every morning teachers from without come here and conduct our schools. In the afternoon I see them hurrying away to the cars, and feel as though the lifeblood of our village were being so far drained off.

ALBANY, May 22. -- The Legislature met this evening in extraordinary session, pursuant to the call of Gov. Roosevelt, to consider the amendments suggested by him to the bill of Senator Ford providing for the taxation of franchises. A message embodying the Governor's views on the subject was read and briefly discussed in each house.
Louis Lese has bought, through Cyrille Carreau, an irregular plot equivalent to about four and a half lots at the northeast corner of First Avenue and One Hundred and Seventh Street.

The Ninth Regiment, N.G., N.Y., of New York City, occupied the State Rifle Range at Creedmoor yesterday. Twenty-two per cent. of the men present qualified as marksmen. A light 9 o'clock wind prevailed. The score was as follows:

John Jacob Astor's steam yacht Nourmahal, which returned from her European trip, arriving at Newport on Saturday and in these waters on Sunday, was tied up at Tebo's yard, South Brooklyn, yesterday. She is to go out of commission.

The Trust Company of America, whose promotion has been due mainly to Edward F. Cragin, one of the concessionaires of the Grace-Cragin-Eyre Nicaragua Canal project; James M. Donald, Vice President of the Hanover National Bank; Alvah Trowbridge, Vice President of the National Bank of North America, and others, will be incorporated at Albany to-day.

A very poor performance of a very dull and uninteresting play was given at Wallack's Theatre last evening. Henri Meilhac's "Ma Cousine," as it was acted here a few years ago by Mme. Rejane, was accounted by good judges a pleasing if not a proper entertainment. It was morally reprehensible, as much contemporary' French comedy is, but it was not coarse, and the subtle histrionism of Rejane was shown in it to perfection.

Dr. J. JULIO HENNA, a Commissioner from Puerto Rico to the capital of the Government of which Puerto Rico is a province of some sort, asks the President some questions which seem to be very pertinent, which are put in admirable temper, and which every citizen of the United States must admit are entitled to a candid and kind answer.

CHICAGO, May 22. -- Englewood had a real bullfight Sunday, and the matadors, two boys, Willie Reinig and George Jessup, narrowly escaped with their lives. For some time the boys have been reading Spanish literature telling of bullfights and they concluded they wanted to be matadors and receive the plaudits of their friends.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., May 22. -- Senator Chauncey Mitchell Depew has just purchased from Mrs. Winifred K. Finch a farm of thirty acres located on Maple Avenue, both sides of the street, on the outskirts of the village. Peekskill people are wondering what Dr. Depew wants with the thirty acres of land in the village of his nativity.
PHILADELPHIA, May 22. -- Delegates to form a Leaf Tobacco Board of Trade met here to-day. The constitution and by-laws presented by the Committee on Organization were adopted.

August Linke, thirty years of age, a cooper, caused great excitement in the crowded corridor of the Mills Hotel No. 1, at 160 Bleecker Street, at 9 o'clock yesterday morning by firing two shots at Samuel Tuttle, sixty-six years of age, a retired broker. Linke, after a brief struggle, was disarmed and taken by a policeman to the Mercer Street Police Station.

Yesterday's stock market was dull and uninteresting. The sluggishness and heaviness that characterized the closing days of last week were again in evidence and prices sagged during the earlier trading hours, suffering from a general lack of active support by the larger financial interests and from rather persistent, though unaggressive, selling by bearish room traders.

It was reported last night that Perry S. Heath, First Assistant Postmaster General, and his brother, Fletcher Heath, had negotiated for and practically acquired a controlling interest in the stock of the Seventh National Bank of this city. In addition to this report, it was further rumored that they were on the point of assuming control of the bank, as a result of their reported purchases of the stock.
WASHINGTON, May 22. -- In the United States Supreme Court an opinion was rendered to-day in the case of the City of Richmond, Va., vs. the Southern Bell Telephone and Telegraph Company.

FALMOUTH, Cornwall, May 22. -- The North German Lloyd steamer Bremen, which left Southampton on Saturday, arrived here this morning under instructions to embark for New York the saloon passengers of the Paris, which is ashore near Coverack. But the passengers were not ready to proceed on their voyage, many of them still suffering from shock, so the Bremen continued on her passage westward.
The Minneapolis Fire and Marine Insurance Company has been admitted to Arkansas.

The old fight between the Gerry society and the State Board of Charities was continued yesterday afternoon, when the first session of the investigation was held, in the office of Albert Stickney, the Visitor appointed by the Supreme Court to investigate the conduct, acts, and proceedings of the society.

COVERACK, May 22. -- The situation of the American Line steamer Paris, Capt. Watkins, which went aground early yesterday morning just off Lowlands Point, two miles east of this place, while on a voyage from Southampton, via Cherbourg, for New York, remained unchanged to-day. The weather was fine and clear, with a smooth sea, and a light off-shore breeze blowing, all the conditions being favorable for salving operations.

HAVANA, May 22. -- The Cuban arms question is apparently nearing a complete and rapid settlement. The payment and dispersal of half the armed bands that have been, voluntarily or involuntarily, quartered on the country will begin, according to the present programme, next Saturday in this city.

The North German Lloyd steamer Barbarossa, which put back to her dock on Thursday with a serious fire in her cargo, and on her way up North River rammed and seriously damaged the French line steamer La Bretagne, resumed her outward voyage from Hoboken at 4:20 o'clock yesterday afternoon bound for Bremen.

CAMDEN, N.J., May 22. -- The Brown-Aberle Company filed articles of incorporation to-day in the County Clerk's office, with a capital stock of $500,000, and $1,000 paid in. The objects of the corporation are to manufacture and sell hosiery and knit goods.
We take it that the reports sent out from time to time from Washington as to the plans of the Republican caucus committee on the currency are intended to sound public opinion.

MINNEAPOLIS, May 22. -- The Presbyterian General Assembly this afternoon voted down two plans to reduce the membership. The Committee on Reduced Representation, appointed a year ago, scarcely received courteous treatment, so pronounced was the feeling against getting further away from the people.

The Clara de Hirsch Home for Working Girls in Sixty-third Street, between Second and Third Avenues, was opened to the inspection of the members of the press yesterday afternoon. The building is completed and furnished, and has already twenty-five girls, although there is room for between seventy-five and a hundred.

THE HAGUE, May 22. -- The Disarmament Committee of the Peace Conference will meet at 4 o'clock to-morrow afternoon, the Committee on the Laws of Warfare will meet during the afternoon, and the Committee on Arbitration will meet on Wednesday. The first session of each committee will be devoted to the election of officers.

MONTREAL, May 22. -- The Canal Advisory Commission appointed by Gov. Roosevelt of New York completed its tour of the system between Lake Erie and Montreal this evening, and will leave for Pittsburg in the morning.

The fifty-fifth annual meeting of the American Medico-Psychological Association, which was founded in 1844 as the Association of Medical Superintendents of American Institutions for the Insane, began yesterday morning at the Waldorf-Astoria. Dr. Henry M. Hurd, President of the association, opened the meeting, Dr. C.B. Burr, acting as Secretary.

PITTSBURG, May 23. -- John Sherman was in Pittsburg to-day on his way to Mansfield, Ohio, where he will spend the Summer. He said that he had fully recovered his health. He was very bitter in his denunciation of the Philippine war.

THE HAGUE, May 23. -- The chiefs of the delegations to the Peace Conference held a private meeting this morning at the "House in the Woods," and afterward informed their colleagues of the arrangements made for a choice of Presidents of the various committees, as agreed upon last evening.
BOSTON, May 23. -- The Executive Committee of the Anti-Imperialist League today voted to elect the following additional Vice Presidents:

LANSING, Mich., MAY 23. -- The House today refused to concur in the Railroad Taxation bill passed by the Senate nearly two weeks ago, increasing railroad taxation under the present law about $32,000 annually. This afternoon the House passed a bill, by a vote of 72 to 22, which increases the taxes on railroads operated in this State about $500,000 over last year's assessment.

The former Governor of Georgia whose address in Boston we published yesterday morning does not throw much light on the future and does not make out a very good case for his people in the present. This we regret, for he is a man of ability, much respected in his own State, and one to whom the people of the North would gladly listen if, happily, he had anything really enlightening to say.

WASHINGTON, May 23. -- An example of the manner in which anti-American prejudice is formed in some portions of Europe has been brought to the attention of the State Department in the issue of Le Petit Marseillais of Marseilles, France, of May 7.

Meyer Greenberg filed plans with the Building Department yesterday for a building of almost "spite-house" dimensions, to be erected at 193 and 195 Elm Street. The structure, which, according to the plan. will be four stories in height, will have an attractive frontage of 40 feet 2 inches. Its depth, however, at one end is 8 feet 7 inches and at the other 9 feet 3 inches.

LONDON, May 23. -- At the second day's racing of the Hurst Park Club Whitsuntide Meeting to-day, Mr. J. Cottrill's four-year- old chestnut colt Lackford, by Juggler-Cailleach, won the Stewards' Handicap. "Tod" Sloan rode Angelina, the property of Mr. D. Seymour, but was not placed. Eleven horses ran one mile.

William H. Kimball, who resigned as Bank Examiner last week and was elected Vice President of the Seventh National Bank, confirmed yesterday the report that new interests controlled an important share of its capital. "But," he added, "neither the policy nor the management of the bank will be changed.

LONDON, May 23. -- Particulars have just been received in London regarding the incident of the hoisting of the British flag over Port Royalist, Island of Palawan, of the Philippine group, by Capt. Pfort of the British steamer Labuan. He reports that he visited the island on Feb. 1 and found the people in a state of consternation.

READING, Penn., May 23. -- Before the Coroner's jury which is investigating the railroad wreck at Exeter, in which twenty-nine persons were killed and about sixty were injured. Train Dispatcher J.H. Rourke testified to-day that, in his judgment. Engineer Harry Orrell was responsible for the accident. Orrell was on the train which crashed into the express train.

CHICAGO, May 23. -- By a transaction that was closed to-day the St. Louis and Northern becomes the property of the syndicate that bought the Chicago and Alton, and which later was represented in the combination that purchased the Monon. Just what was paid for the St. Louis line cannot be learned, but it is maid that about $13,000,000 was involved.

GREENWICH, Conn., May 23. -- Shadrach Jackson Close, seventy-nine years old, Postmaster and general storekeeper of the little village of Stanwich, seven miles to the north of this place, was found early this morning lying on the porch of his store, unconscious, with his skull fractured, his jaw broken, and suffering from other injuries which will almost certainly prove fatal.

Every day shows that the city is gradually thinning out and that the suburbs are beginning what promises to be a gay season. Carriages on the avenue are fewer in number, and it is only now and then that familiar faces are seen. At the great hotels and restaurants the West and the South have congregated, and each evening resembles a reception there, but with guests not familiar to New York eyes.

LONDON, May 23. -- The gathering of the royal family at Windsor Castle to-morrow to celebrate the eightieth birthday of Queen Victoria will be the largest, with the exception of the Jubilee gathering, that has assembled there in many years. Not only will four generations in succession be present, but there will be a great gathering of children and grandchildren of her Majesty.

ALBANY, May 23. -- The Senate Committee on Taxation and Retrenchment met tonight, and, after a brief session, gave out the proposed Franchise Tax bill. The bill is framed closely on the suggestions maple by the Governor. It includes the Ford bill in full. It will be printed and on the files in the morning, and will be introduced in both houses.

The Twenty-second Regiment, Col. Franklin Bartlett, went to the State target ranges at Creedmoor, yesterday. Brig. Gen. McCoskry Butt of the First Brigade was present, though he did not shoot. Of the 405 officers and men who faced the targets, 87 per cent. qualified as marksmen.

NEWPORT, May 23. -- The case brought against I. Townsend Burden by his former chef, Lucien Bayle, Whose wife claimed the reward offered by Mr. Burden for the recovery of Mrs. Burden's jewels, which were recovered by the London police, to whom Mr. Burden paid the reward after full investigation, has been settled out of court, and the case, which has been pending for so long a time, will not come to trial.

WASHINGTON, May 23. -- Admiral Dewey's last concern before leaving Manila was for the safety of the crew of the Yorktown's launch held captive by the Filipinos. He has initiated steps that are expected to result very soon in the release of these captive, but it is deemed unwise to make them public in advance of their execution.

Suit for absolute divorce has been begun by Robert L. Cutting against his wife, who is well known on the stage as Minnie Seligman, and to whom he was secretly married seven years ago. Mrs. Cutting, who is now playing an engagement at a vaudeville theatre in this city, says she will bring a counter suit.

Nine horses from the racing stable of Rogers Rose sold at auction at Morris Park yesterday for $29,000. The three-year-old Lothario, who proved such a big disappointment in the Withers Stakes, was knocked down to G.E. Smith, better known as Pittsburg Phil, for $10,000, which was the top price of the sale.
City Marshals Marks and Lee, attached to the Seventh Civil District Court, in the Yorkville Police Court building, had an experience yesterday morning they will not forget for a long time to come.

At the regular weekly meeting of the Pilot Commissioners, held yesterday afternoon in their office in the new Chesebrough Building, in State Street, Michael McDonald, the pilot who took the North German Lloyd steamship Barbarossa out to sea, and who was on the bridge when, returning, she struck the French steamer La Bretagne, submitted his report.

We own to some surprise in reading what purport to be the reasons set forth at Washington by Representative ALBERT J. HOPKINS of Aurora. Ill., for his expectation that he will be elected Speaker of the Fifty-sixth Congress.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 23. -- Paul Ford, twenty years old, a son of the late Judge Charles Ford, made things lively at the residence of Mrs. Ann Bradford in Metuchen early to-day. It is alleged that he gained an entrance to the house by opening a dining room window. Mrs. Bradford occupies what is known as the Westervelt Mansion.
CAMBRIDGE, May 23. -- The John Harvard Statue at Harvard University was again defaced by paint last night. The students will hold a mass meeting to consider measures for finding out who did the work.

ALBANY, May 23. -- Neither house of the Legislature transacted any business to-day owing to the fact that the Senate Committee tee on Taxation and Retrenchment, to which Gov. Roosevelt's message on the taxation of franchises had been referred, was not ready to make a report. Both houses held short sessions and adjourned until to-morrow.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., May 23. -- This was a quiet day with the Presbyterian General Assembly. It transacted considerable routine business without any friction, and adjourned early in the afternoon to view the Minneapolis suburban lakes and Minnehaha Falls.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 23. -- It was the same old story to-day; the Louisvilles could not hit, while the Brooklyns batted Dowling almost at will. Score:

WASHINGTON, May 23. -- Secretary Hay has received from President Schurman of the Philippine Commission a long message giving the results of the meetings thus far held with the Filipino Commission, sent by Aguinaldo to treat with the Americans. The message was laid before the President tonight. He was very much gratified at its contents, which were said to encourage the belief that something definite may be accomplished.

WASHINGTON, May 23. -- Washington's Peace Jubilee was inaugurated at sunrise to-day by a National salute of thirteen guns from the Dolphin, anchored off the navy yard, and by the chimes of bells and sound of steam whistles all over the city. The day had been declared a half holiday in the departments, and the employes of nearly all the bureaus were released at noon, the hour being marked by a salute of forty-five guns.

We confess we had overlooked this in our comments upon the loss of the Paris.

Again yesterday Sugar Trust was the all-important stock. It disappointed everybody by showing weakness at the opening, whereas a sharp bulge was expected. But after getting down from 161 to below 150 it developed new strength and ran up sharply to 163 1/4. Aggressive Lawson buying and scattered covering by timid shorts was responsible for the bulge.

MANILA, May 23. -- The conference between the civilian members of the United States Philippine Commission and the representatives of the Filipinos continues. The military and civil elements of the American Commission differ regarding the wisdom of continuing the conferences, the former adhering to their original demand for the unconditional surrender of the insurgents.

The recent purchase by William C. Whitney and Thomas H. Ryan of the control of the State Trust Company, a corporation organized and operated under the wing of the American Surety Company, has caused the report to circulate in some quarters that the parent company had passed into the control of Whitney and Vanderbilt interests.

There was a good deal of solemn nonsense in the Board of Aldermen yesterday over the Queen's birthday. It seems that a resolution introduced by one of the members in a spirit of clumsy pleasantry quite unworthy of an Irishman providing for displaying the flags on the city buildings on the anniversary of the Queen's birth was laid on the table at a former meeting, but had been reported to have been adopted.

TOLEDO, May 23. -- Mayor Jones's plan for conducting the Toledo gas plant was successful in the City Council last night. The City Clerk is authorized to advertise for bids for running the plant, the profits to be turned in to the city Treasury. It is understood that a syndicate has made a favorable offer to conduct the plant for forty years.

George W. Quintard's twin-screw yacht Saranac is in dry dock at Tebo's, having new propellers put on her. The propellers are a device of recent invention.
PARIS, May 23. -- A duel has been fought on the Ile de la Grande Gatte between Catulle Mendes, the French author and dramatic critic, and M. Vanar.

CHICAGO, May 23. -- The Hotel Men's Mutual Benefit Association to-day elected the following officers for the ensuing year: President -- D. Clifford Shears, Cincinnati; Vice President -- Albion Brownell, New Bedford, Mass.; Secretary-Treasurer - J.K. Blatchford, Chicago. Board of Directors -- Frank Upham F.W. Rice, E.S. Pinney, H.J. Bohn, M.A. Loring, L.E. Howard, C.C. Hilton, and W.H. Worth.

There was a sudden closing of some of the poolrooms and gambling resorts yesterday. Notwithstanding the statement made by Chief Devery that the poolrooms and other gambling places were watched just as closely before the Mazet investigating committee began its work as they have been since, many places which were running last week were closed, and to the few that remained open, with one exception, no stranger could gain entrance.

WASHINGTON, May 23. -- The commission composed of Special Agents George W. Whitehead, George W. Maher, and Burton Parker, appointed to investigate charges of maladministration at the Appraisers' Stores in New York, has submitted its first report.

At the meeting of the Municipal Council yesterday President Guggenheimer presented a resolution asking the Board of Public Improvements to draw up and submit to the Municipal Assembly an ordinance providing for the exclusion of heavy vehicles from Fifth Avenue from 2 to 7 P.M. below Thirty-ninth Street, and from Fifty-ninth Street to One Hundred and Tenth Street at all times.

PROVIDENCE, May 23. -- The many details of the construction of the new cup defender Columbia yet to be completed make it appear that in order to launch her on the date named, June 8, operations will have to be carried on at night for a week or so before she is launched. The workmen are rushing things at present in all departments of the works at Bristol.

Immediately upon the return of William R. Stewart, President of the State Board of Charities, who sails for Europe to-day, proceedings will be instituted against him for contempt of court in refusing to answer questions put to him on Monday at the first session of the investigation into the charges brought against the Gerry society.

Mayor Van Wyck yesterday sent to the Board of Aldermen his veto of a resolution adopted by that board on March 21 last, providing for the appointment of a committee to attend a meeting of the League of American Municipalities in September next. In his message the Mayor said:

Marion Clark, the twenty-months-old daughter of Arthur Clark, who was stolen by her nurse, Carrie Jones, on Sunday, is still in the hands of her abductors so far as the police of this city know, and there is absolutely no clue to her whereabouts or to the identity of the persons concerned in the plot to kidnap the child.

DETROIT, May 23. -- The Detroit Street Railway Commission, appointed to purchase and operate for the city all the street railways within the city, made its first report to-night to the Common Council.

Frederick Southack Co., in conjunction with E.A. Cruikshank Co., have sold for Eugene Lentilhon to John S. Hawley the six-story iron-front building 557 and 559 Broadway, running through to 128 and 130 Mercer Street, 50 by 200. This property was sold in partition proceedings early in March, and was purchased at that time by the Union Trust Company, representing the present seller, who was an interested party in the partition suit.

Justice O'Gorman, in the Tenth Municipal District Court, yesterday, handed down a decision in favor of Anna M. Davidson against the Hammerstein Amusement Company, requiring the corporation to vacate the premises at 207, 209, and 211 West Forty-second Street, which, it is claimed, they have squatted upon.

Mr. and Mrs. H. McK. Twombly gave a reception and musicale last evening at Florham their country residence in Madison, N.J. The 300 guests were all from Morristown and Madison, the New York society contingent being represented only by the host and hostess. This was the first large entertainment ever given at Florham, owing to the Twomblys having been in mourning for the last two years.

Mayor VAN WYCK made a sensible use of the veto power when he sent back the resolution of the Board of Aldermen providing for the appointment of a committee to represent this city at the meeting of the League of American Municipalities next September. There is an obvious impropriety in giving official recognition to an organization that may at any time affirm the most preposterous doctrines.

The Governor's Franchise Tax bill is an attempt to bring within reach of the assessor a large amount of personal property not now fully or regularly taxed, and some of it perhaps not taxed at all. The franchises of corporations are personal property. The Governor's bill declares that they shall be taxed as real estate.

CHICAGO, May 24. -- Under its new management the Chicago and Alton promises to become one of the most important railroad systems in the West. The acquisition of the St. Louis, Peoria and Northern by the Alton already has been announced, and the indications are that the Kansas City, Pittsburg and Gulf Road will become; when it gets out of the hands of the receivers, a part of the Alton Railroad system.

TRENTON, N.J., May 24. -- Hobart A. Tuttle, private secretary to Gov. Voorhees and a brother-in-law of Vice President Hobart; ex-Assemblyman Hayward A. Harvey of East Orange, Lawrence S. Mott of Newark, and George A. Denham of Boston are charged with fraud and conspiracy in a suit instituted in the United States Circuit Court to-day.

Senator Clark of Montana arrived yesterday on the steamship Majestic. He said that he expected to remain in this city a few days. Asked if he had taken part in the formation of an international copper trust, he said: "No, I have had nothing to do with an international copper trust, and I do not know anything about any such scheme.
OMAHA, May 24. -- Rear Admiral and Mrs. Schley left for Denver this afternoon and received an enthusiastic ovation at the depot and at all the towns en route through Nebraska.

PORT TAMPA, Fla., May 24. -- The eightieth birthday of Queen Victoria was celebrated at Port Tampa to-day. Salutes were fired from the British and American war vessels lying in the harbor. The shipping in the harbor was gay with flags and pennants, and throughout the town there was a liberal display of flags, bunting, and floral decorations.

MANILA, May 24. -- Two companies of the Third Infantry and two companies of the Twenty-second Infantry, forming Gen. Lawton's rear guard, returning from San Miguel to Balinag, yesterday, escorting a signal party which was picking up wire laid with Gen. Lawton's expedition, found that the insurgents had reoccupied the country, and hard fighting followed from daylight until the Americans camped at night.
MINNEAPOLIS, May 24. -- The Presbyterian General Assembly this morning devoted its attention chiefly to the subject of missions.

WASHINGTON, May 24. -- The Secretary of War to-day made public a report from Major Gem MacArthur, being one of the reports inclosed by Gen. Otis in his own report of the operations in the Philippines, which was in part submitted to the Cabinet yesterday. Gen. MacArthur's report covers a period of time from the evening of Feb. 4, when the insurgent outbreak began, to Feb. 28.
GRIFFIN, Ga., May 24. -- The flogging of three colored operatives of the Kincaid Mills on Monday night by White Caps has led to sensational developments.

LONDON, May 24. -- Torrents of rain to-day ushered in Queen Victoria's eightieth birthday. At Windsor, where a general holiday is being observed, the town was decorated with flags and the church bells were rung at 7 o'clock in the morning.

ST. LOUIS, May 24. -- Ways and means of conducting the next Presidential campaign will be considered by the Democratic conference at the Planters' Hotel to-morrow. It is not likely that much other matter will come before the meeting, and no definite action of any sort will be taken unless a majority of the members of the committee is present.

WASHINGTON, May 24. -- The Navy Department is making ready to receive the recovered Spanish cruiser Reina Mercedes at the Norfolk Navy Yard. There has been some telegraphic correspondence between the Navy Department and Admiral Farquhar, commandant at the Norfolk Navy Yard, respecting the vessel.

WASHINGTON, May 24. -- The rapid increase of Japanese immigration to Hawaii has attracted the serious attention of the authorities here of late, and inquiries have been set on foot to learn the extent of the invasion and how it can be checked. The reports received by the immigration authorities are in line with press dispatches stating that the influx is steadily increasing.

PHILADELPHIA, May 24. -- Prof. Daniel G. Brinton, N.D., Professor of American Archaeology and Linguistics at the University of Pennsylvania, has presented to the university his entire collection of books and manuscripts relating to the aboriginal languages of North and South America. Dr. Brinton has long been one of the foremost authorities on these subjects, and his library of works regarding them is perhaps the most complete in existence.

BUFFALO, May 24. -- Mr. and Mrs. James C. Saunders, who are accused of manslaughter under the United States law because they allowed no medical attendance upon their child Ralph, who subsequently died, were formally put under arrest this morning. Their names are on the same warrant with those of Mr. and Mrs. Kinter, the Christian Scientists who attended the child.

COVERACK, Cornwall, May 24. -- The scene in the vicinity of the steamship Paris was most interesting and animated when, an hour before high water, the American Line steamer and her attendant tugs put on a full head of steam and exerted their utmost power to refloat her. These efforts continued fruitlessly for two hours, and it was finally decided to defer the attempt to float her until a later tide, probably on Friday.

OLIVER, Ga., May 24. -- Frank Evans was killed and J.B. Proctor probably fatally wounded by Sam Perry, a notorious negro, last night near Cameron. Perry's wife was abusing Mr. Proctor's children and cursing "white folks" in general, when Evans, who heard the woman, remonstrated with her.

The State Board of Charities has refused the application of Mrs. Rose Hawthorne Lathrop for articles of incorporation for the cancer hospital for women, which she has been conducting in this city for several years. Dr. Stephen Smith of this city, to whom the matter was referred for consideration, reported against the granting of the incorporation papers.

Your correspondent "American" went far out of his way yesterday to attack the New York Volunteers in his endeavor to give to the regulars their meed of praise for the excellent work they did at Santiago. Let me note one fact which seems to have escaped his attention and the attention of Gov. Roosevelt when he reviewed the findings of the Seventy-first Regiment.
Richard V. Harnett Co. have sold for James C. McAndrews of London, to David Forbes, the six-story building northeast corner of Water Street and Cuyler's Alley, 28.1 by 85.3.

ALBANY, May 24. -- Twenty-seven votes having been pledged to the Governor's new franchise tax bill at a caucus of Republican Senators held this evening, the passage of the measure is now assured. The present indications are that the bill will go through both houses, and that the extraordinary session will be terminated to-morrow.

LOUISVILLE, May 24. -- The Louisville's losing streak was broken to-day. After tying the score in the ninth and with Powers on third, Manager Hanlon of Brooklyn sent word to Yeager to give Clark his base on balls. Grim stepped out of the box to receive the first ball pitched and Umpire Emslie called a balk Powers scoring.

There is still no clue to the whereabouts of Marion Clark, the twenty months' old baby that was abducted by her nurse, Carrie Jones, in Central Park on Sunday morning. The few minor clues now in the possession of the police are admitted by them to be of little value. No arrests have been made, but one woman is under surveillance.

Col. E.W. Cole of Nashville, Tenn., one of the most prominent coal and iron men in the South, was stricken with heart disease in the corridor of the Fifth Avenue Hotel last night. After lingering about half an hour he died in the office of the cashier of the hotel, despite the efforts of two physicians who were immediately called in.

Your editorial attacks and criticisms against all those who disagree with your wild expansion policy are, to say the least, most incongruous and discordant with the general tone of THE TIMES, and certainly do not meet the approval of a great many readers of your very attractive and well-conducted journal.

The members of the American Medico-Psychological Association turned their attention toward the criminal side of the insanity problem at yesterday's session of the annual meeting, at the Waldorf-Astoria. The first paper was that of Dr. E.C. Runge of St. Louis, on "Our Work and Its Limitations." Dr. Runge condemned the system of congregate dining rooms in insane asylums. Ward dining rooms, he said, tended to promote the domestic feeling among patients.

ALBANY, May 24. -- In accordance with a message from the Governor, referred to them this morning, the Finance Committees of the Senate and the Assembly have agreed upon a bill appropriating $75,000 for the State's part in the celebration of Admiral Dewey's return to the United States.

In addressing the graduating class of Packard's Business College on the occasion of the forty-first anniversary and commencement, in Carnegie Hall, last night, the Rev. Dr. Newell Dwight Hillis, pastor of Plymouth Church, Brooklyn, spoke of "The Message of John Ruskin to the Twentieth Century."

BERLIN, May 24. -- The Tuberculosis Congress was opened in the Reichstag Building this morning, with 2,000 members, of which 200 were delegates from German and foreign Governments, present. The Empress of Germany, as patroness of the congress, was seated in the Royal Gallery. Her Majesty wore a bright Spring costume of yellow silk and carried a large bouquet of red roses.

ALBANY, May 24. -- In the Assembly to-day Mr. Harburger withdrew his resolution on the death of ex-Gov. Flower and Senator Brown's concurrent memorial resolution on the subject was unanimously adopted. The Speaker appointed as the Assembly members of the memorial committee called for by the resolution, Messrs. Bryan and Roberts of Jefferson Miles of St. Lawrence, and Harburger and Roche of New York.

ALBANY, May 24. -- Senator Raines's bill amending the election laws in conformity with the recommendations suggested by State Superintendent of Elections McCullagh was signed this morning by the Governor.

Mrs. Delia Seaman, who lives with her two little children in three rooms in the rear of the tenement house 302 West One Hundred and Thirty-fourth Street, tells a thrilling story of having been bound, gagged, and assaulted by burglars, who also threatened her life and set fire to the apartment.

The published statement of the Treasury Department of the findings of the commission to investigate Appraiser Wakeman is a worthy side piece to the report of the "Beef Commission." The literary bureau of the Administration ought to be congratulated. They can find in the English language such fine phrases, such soothing words for condemning admission of wrongdoing, that it reads all like a lullaby, especially to the uninitiated.

The Seventy-first Regiment, under command of Capt. J.H. Wells, occupied the State target ranges at Creedmoor yesterday. After marching to the Long Island Ferry, at the foot of Thirty-fourth Street, the regiment took a troop train at Long Island City. With the help of a clear day and very little wind, about 88 per cent. of the men qualified.

Apathy affects the market. Small disposition to trade shows in any quarter. Most of the transactions recorded by the Stock Exchange ticker represent merely the speculations of members of the Stock Exchange themselves. The room trading element is fairly active by fits and starts, but no lasting results ever follow such activity.
NEW HAVEN, May 24. -- The New England championship lawn tennis tournament was continued here to-day in the presence of an enthusiastic crowd.

The Mayor, in his testimony the other day before the Mazet committee, distinctly declined to condemn, or even to criticise, the working of any part of the municipal machinery of which he is the executive head upon the ground that it was still too early to judge of the efficiency of that machinery.

Page 6 of THE TIMES is my favorite page, and I enjoy reading the editorial articles, although I sometimes differ from your opinions.
Jockey Powers, who has ridden some very poor races for J.J. Hyland, has been released from his engagement.

ALBANY, May 25. -- The State Land Board at its meeting to-day received a letter from Charles E. Wellborn of New York City asking if the State would sell the unoccupied part of Fire Island to private individuals for purposes of a modern hotel, which would be erected there. The Secretary was directed to notify the writer that the board would consider a petition for the sale of the land.

THE HAGUE, May 25. -- Both sections of the Committee on the Laws of Warfare of the Peace Conference met separately today and began the examination of the subject submitted to them, the Red Cross section discussing Paragraph 5 and Paragraph 6 of the circular of Count Muravieff, Russian Minister of Foreign Affairs, and the Brussels conference section discussing Paragraph 7.

DALLAS, Texas, May 25. -- News reached here to-night of a triple lynching near Aley, a small village in Henderson County, that occurred late last night. Aley is situated between Cedar Creek and Trinity River, seventy-five miles southeast of Dallas, and fully fifteen miles from any railroad, telegraph, or telephone connection.

First he attempted to head off the Ford bill by asking the Legislature to remit the subject of tax law revision to a special committee.

COVERACK, Cornwall, May 25. -- Further efforts were made at 3 o'clock this morning and again late this afternoon to refloat the American Line steamship Paris, but failed. Five powerful tugs tried to pull the vesssel off the rocks, but she was not moved. More coal is being jettisoned from her bunkers and another effort to float her will be made at daybreak.

WASHINGTON, May 25. -- Representative Sherman's confident expectations touching the Speakership are considered to be justified in the estimation of Lemuel E. Quigg who was questioned about that matter after a visit at the White House this morning.

CLEVELAND, May 25. -- Hugh J. Buckley, President of the Board of Elections, was removed from office by Mayor Farley to-day. Mr. Buckley is charged with misconduct in office. The Mayor refuses to make specific charges.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 25. -- It became known to-day that Herbert Seeley of New York is an inmate of the Keeley Gold Cure Institute here. He has been passing off as G.B. Haggar, but is in reality Herbert Seeley of the "Seeley dinner" notoriety. He came here about four weeks ago, just after he had returned to this country from Cuba.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 25. -- The Yale Corporation to-day elected Prof. Arthur Twining Hadley to succeed Timothy Dwight, resigned, as President of Yale University.
WASHINGTON, May 25. -- The following cablegram has been received at the Navy Department, dated Apia, May 16, via Auckland:

Eliot, C.B., of the British Embassy at Washington, representing Great Britain, arrived here on May 13. Its first sitting took place May 16.

ALBANY, May 25. -- When the Senate convened at 11:20 o'clock this morning Senator Higgins presented a favorable report from the Finance Committee upon the bill appropriating $10,000 for the expenses of the State Tax Commission in the enforcement of the Franchise Tax bill. This was progressed to the order of final passage without objection.
Two lives were lost at a fire which gutted the three-story brownstone dwelling at 112 West Forty-ninth Street early yesterday morning. It was occupied by Margaret Hilton as a furnished room house.

Edward R. Andrews, acting as trustee, recorded a mortgage yesterday for 144,500, made in favor of the Scottish Provident Institution of Edinburgh, Scotland. The mortgage covers the property owned by the Andrews estate of Boston at the northwest corner of Chambers Street and Broadway, and secures notes for the sum stated, maturing in ten years.

Commodore Postley's schooner Colonia is to go into commission to-day at City Island.

Stocks are scarce. The way yesterday's market acted made the fact clear. For a fortnight all the bear traders of Wall Street have been ramming and jamming away at values, and to some extent were able to push quotations down -- through sales of stocks they did not own.

OCEANSIDE, L.I., May 25. -- Last Spring a hen belonging to a well-known resident of this community hatched from a pure game egg a chicken with three legs. The little thing was a neighborhood curiosity, and grew into a fine young cock. Two of its legs are normally placed, while the third is at the rear, a little to one side.

The money given by the Westchester Racing Association during its three weeks' meeting, which came to an end yesterday, was well distributed among the eighty horsemen who secured some portion of the money hung up. Sydney Paget leads the winning owners, for Jean Beraud's victory in the Belmont Stakes yesterday placed him in front, with winnings of $18,535.
NEWPORT, May 25. -- Gen. and Mrs. J. Fred Pierson will arrive for the season on Monday, as will Commodore Gerry and family.
Buyers of roadsters were liberal in their bidding yesterday at the American Horse Exchange. They had good stock before them in the sales ring, all of them the property of J. Dickman Brown.

It was reported that the Security Insurance Company of New Haven will shortly increase its capital stock from $200,000to $300,000, and that the additional issue of stock will be offered to stockholders at its par value.

The Twelfth Regiment of the New York National Guard, in command of Col. R.W. Leonard, spent yesterday at Creedmoor, L.I., in target practice on the State ranges. Of 240 men who were present, 219 qualified as marksmen. Brig. Gen. McCoskry Butt, who was once Colonel of the Twelfth, was present in uniform, and took part in the shooting.
