WASHINGTON, May 25. -- Acting Secretary Cortelyou to-day called upon Assistant Secretary of the Treasury Vanderlip, Chairman of the Dewey Home Fund, and placed in his hands a check from the President, constituting Mr. McKinley's contribution to the fund. In doing so Mr. Cortelyou conoveyed to Mr. Vanderlip the expression of the President's interest in the undertaking and his pleasure in contributing to this testimonial to Admiral Dewey.

WASHINGTON, May 25. -- The suggestion that ex-Senator German shall be the Democratic candidate for President in 1900, published here as having taken shape in New York, creates less surprise than might have been expected in a city where the Democrats have been almost entirely swallowed up by the "regular" faction that makes fidelity to Bryan and free silver its cardinal doctrines.

ST. JOHN, N.B., May 25. -- A fire which broke out in a house owned by John Porter, adjoining Nose's warehouse, caused the death of Miss Cunard and Mrs. Arnold Mowery here to-day. The insufficiency of the water supply permitted the flames to spread, and 150 buildings were burned.

HAVANA, May 25. -- Major Gen. Fitzhugh Lee, Military Governor of the Havana-Pinar del Rio Department, wired Gov. Gen. Brooke at El Vedado to-day that 200 Cubans of the command of Gen. Mayia Rodriguez, near Marianao, dispersed yesterday, after resolving not to take the $75 per man. Some of them sold their arms and others took them to their homes.

There are one or two private members of the Municipal Assembly who have contrived to get out of its proceedings the reputation of well-meaning citizens. But really the only member who has extracted from it anything that flattery could call a "boom" is Mr. GUGGENHEIMER. His objections to profane swearing, which we make no doubt are perfectly sincere, have incurred some ridicule, due, doubtless, exclusively to his name.

LONDON, May 26. -- All the dispatches to the morning papers from The Hague show that the Peace Conference is suffering from lack of preparation. The Muravieff circular contains heads and chapters, but no details. Its author emphasized disarmament but slighted arbitration. M. de Staal, in opening the conference, absolutely reversed this order.

ALBANY, May 25. -- The extraordinary session of the Legislature adjourned late this afternoon after having passed a substitute for the Ford Franchise Tax bill. The measure went through the Senate by a vote of 30 to 18, all the Republicans and three Democrats voting for it, and through the Assembly with 87 affirmative and 62 negative votes.

Edward R. Borland, a young man who was held for the Grand Jury in $1,500 bail by Magistrate Brann in Morrisania Police Court on Tuesday, on a charge of larceny preferred by Mrs. Ella M. Greason of 329 Willis Avenue, is now also accused of forgery. It is charged that he forged what was alleged to be a copy of a divorce in Mrs. Greason's favor, granted by Justice Pryor.

ST. LOUIS, May 25. -- When the conference of members of the Democratic National Committee adjourned this afternoon at 5:30 o'clock it had taken no action regarding the policy of the party in the coming Presidential campaign. Planks for the platform were not even discussed. The meeting from first to last was one of discussion regarding methods of work next year and the ways and means by which this work could be accomplished.
Albert E. Hicks and Samuel F. Burns have sold to Donald Mitchell the old buildings 50 and 52 West Forty-fifth Street, 40 by 110.5.

Frank Ives, the world's champion billiardist, and his partner W.H. Thatcher, were badly beaten last night in the first half of their match of three-cushion carrom billiards with Jacob Schaefer and John A. Harrison, both of Chicago. The match was played at the Ives Billiard Parlor, Forty-second Street and Broadway, and the first half consisted of 60 points, out of the total of 125.

The controversy over imperialism in Plymouth Church, Brooklyn, had a mountain-and-mouse ending last night. When the business meeting adjourned last Friday night there was every prospect of a warm discussion over the majority report, which advocated that there be no discussion, and the minority report, which severely arraigned the Administration and directed that a debate on the subject be held.

Mr. Secretary GAGE has never ventured to tell the public why Mr. SHURTLEFF was removed from the office of Appraiser. His nerve will now have to undergo a still more severe trial if he does not remove Mr. WAKEMAN. There was no reason known for removing the one; Mr. GAGE'S own investigating commission has given numerous and strong reasons for removing the other.

ALBANY, May 25. -- Sealed proposals were received at the office of the State Controller to-day for the purchase of $500,000 registered bonds of the State, to be issued for the payment of expenses of the National Guard and Naval Militia during the recent war with Spain. The bonds are dated May 1, 1899, and are of the denomination of $5,000, with interest at 3 1/2 per cent. per annum.

CAMDEN, N.J., May 25. -- The New York Ship Building Company, which was recently formed, will, it is believed, locate its proposed great plant on the Delaware River, in this city. To-night the Camden City Council passed a resolution guaranteeing that the land which the company proposes to buy here shall be assessed at its present valuation for twenty years.

YORK, Penn., May 25. -- The thirty-ninth convention of the General Synod of the Lutheran Church in the United States, which was called to order in St. Paul's Church to-day by President Hamma, began its business to-day by electing the following officers: President -- The Rev. S.F. Breckenridge, Springfield, Ohio; Treasurer -- Lewis Manss, Cincinnati; Secretary -- The Rev. Dr. W.E. Fisher, Shamokin, Penn.

LONDON, May 25. -- The fifty-fourth annual festival of the Royal General Theatrical Fund was held this evening at the Hotel Metropole and proved one of the most brilliant events in the history of the institution. The Earl of Dartmouth presided, and among the guests were United States Ambassador Joseph H. Choate, Baron Rathmore, Edward Terry, George Alexander, Beerbohm Tree, J. Comyns Carr, and Fred Terry.

The members of the American Medico-Psychological Association met in the Waldorf-Astoria yesterday morning to continue their annual meeting. A paper omitted from Wednesday's programame, "Judicial Errors in Lunacy," by Dr. George Villeneuve of Longue Pointe, Quebec, was first presented. Dr. Villeneuve treated of the various classes of cases where insane men have been punished as criminals.
WASHINGTON, May 25. -- The Chicago has sailed from Ismalia for Aden, en route to the East Cost of Africa, and by way of the Cape of Good Hope to Brazil.

The English Government and the House of Commons have just given another evidence of the firmness with which the principle of fair and equal taxation, as opposed to any favoritism whatever, is now engrafted on the British system.
VIENNA, May 25. -- Emperor Francis Joseph received Mark Twain (Mr. Samuel L. Clemens) in special audience this afternoon.

MADRID, May 25. -- It is announced that Senor Don Emilio Castelar, the distinguished Republican orator and statesman, who had been suffering from an attack of pulmonary catarrh, contracted last Winter, is dead Senor Castelar passed away at Murcia, capital of the ancient kingdom and modern province of that name.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., May 25. -- A Democratic anti-trust banquet was held this evening at the Coliseum, under the auspices of the Jeffeson Club of this city. Harry B. Hawes, President of the club, acted as toastmaster, and at the principal table with him were seated W.J. Bryan, ex-Gov. John P. Altgeld, O.H.P. Belmont, H.C. Wetmore, Representatives Champ Clark and David A. De Armond, and other prominent Democrats.

The automobile which left Cleveland at 7 o'clock Monday morning to establish an automobile record between Cleveland and New York, arrived in front of the Astor House at 5:45 o'clock yesterday afternoon. The trial was under the auspices of The Cleveland Plain Dealer.

LONDON, May 26. -- The new annual melodrama at the historic Adelphi Theatre is the joint work of Seymour Hicks and Mr. Latham, and will be produced in September. It shows England and France on the verge of a war. A treasonable plot is hatched at Southampton, of complicity in which the hero is falsely accused, and has a hairbreadth escape of being drummed out of the service.

MANILA, May 20. -- The events of the last week have emphasized the need of a much larger army here, without which, according to the best authorities in Manila, it will be impossible for Gen. Otis to establish American supremacy in the Philippine Islands. The inadequacy of the American forces is said to be responsible for the large total loss in the number of small encounters, without material results as a compensation.
WASHINGTON, May 26. -- Admiral Dewey telegraphs the Navy Department that he will stop at various places on his way to the United States and will reach New York about Oct. 1.
NEWPORT, May 26. -- Lieut. Col. W.E. Randolph, United States Army, is the guest of Col. John Hare Powel.

GRIFFIN, Ga., May 26. -- Seven men, accused of being members of the "Laborer's Union Band" of so-called whitecaps, were arrested to-day. They are C.V. Barnett, Tom Reynolds, Jet Moore, William Thomas Lebrad, Paul Ellis, Carl Fry, and Clifford Thomas. They have been lodged in jail.

LONDON, May 27. -- The morning papers prominently discuss the future of the Anglo-American Commission, with an apparent desire to pacify both Canada and the United States, though strongly disinclined to give the colony any lack of moral support.

HAVANA, May 26. -- The distribution of the $3,000,000 which the United States Government has offered as a gratuity to the Cuban troops on disbanding and surrendering their arms will begin at 10 o'clock to-morrow morning at the foot of the Prado.

HAVANA, May 26. -- Gov. Gen. Brooke has a decree ready to be issued, making editors and publishers responsible for libels. The Spanish law made the writer of an article alone responsible; and in consequence every Havana editor has a hired substitute, paid to sign articles of a defamatory character. This substitute is usually a "long-time" convict, who, for money enough to make imprisonment easy, will sign anything.

IN intimate friend of Morris K. Jesup, the recently elected President of the Chamber of Commerce, being asked to describe he distinguishing characteristics of that eminent financier and philanthropist, replied without hesitation "Ability to make money and the disposition to dispose of it in unostentatious benevolence."

LEBANON, N.H., May 27. -- The American Woolen Company has bought the mills of the Mascoma Flannel Company and the Riverside Woolen Company of Lebanon. It is expected that both plants will be operated in full. The Mascoma mills have not been running for more than six months.

ANNAPOLIS, May 27. -- The crew of Yale University's eight-oared shell outrowed the naval cadets to-day over a two-mile straightaway course, and crossed the line 11 1/2 seconds ahead of the middies. It was the original intention to go over the outside course, from Greenbury Point to the county bridge, but after twice postponing the race because of choppy seas, it was decided to contest over the inside course on the Severn.

THERE is much talk in England jus now of various people who propose to cycle from the Cape of Good Hope, South Africa, to Cairo, Egypt. The matter has been discussed with several authorities in the interior of Africa, who give as their opinion that those persons who talk lightly of such a feat can hardly know what an utterly impossible one it is.

NEWPORT, May 27. -- On Monday next the North Atlantic Squadron is expected from New York to take part in the exercises on the following day, when Elisha Dyer will for the third time be inaugurated as Governor of this State. The city is already beginning to show signs of gala displays, and within the next twenty-four hours many stores and houses will be gaily decorated.

ST. LOUIS, May 27. -- St, Louis won a sensational contest from Brooklyn in the ninth inning to-day. Singles by Tebeau and Burkett and a sacrifice by Stenzel won the game. Both Young and Kennedy pitched in fine form. Stenzel made a home run in the fifth, with Burkett on second. Eight thousand persons saw the game.

Percival Stewart in property on Seventeenth Avenue, Sixteenth Avenue, Twenty-ninth Street, and Crooks Avenue. Zurlinden, the Military Governor of Paris, has arranged for delegations of all arms of the army and navy to receive the Major at the club.

It was an inspiring sight to see all those humble working people singing the music of the masters with an enthusiasm which it would be well nigh impossible ever to get from the more pretentious persons of the upper circles of society.

"Ghosts" was given here some year ago with Courtenay Thorpe as the paretic, Oswald; Ida Jeffreys Goodfriend as Fru Alving, Eleanor Lane (and afterward Olive Oliver) as Regina, and Arthur Lawrence as Pastor Manders.

He shows that owing to the tenacious insistence on State and local rights, the prison system in America is anything but uniform.

Beach, who, as a Conservative, has represented North Hants and the Andover Division of Hants successively for forty-two years, becomes Father of the House of Commons. Sir John Mowbray entered Parliament in 1853 for the City of Durham, while Mr. Beach was not elected for Hampshire till 1857, a difference of four years.

The sense of values there amuses and refreshes the wanderer from more practical shores.

FALMOUTH, May 27. -- Another supreme effort to float the Paris was made this evening, but resulted in failure. Six tugs were made fast to the steamer by steel hausers and anchors were put out astern, the chains from which were attached to the steam winches on the stranded steamer. The propellers of the Paris were then driven at full steam astern, but the efforts were unavailing.

Company K of the Seventy-first Regiment is likely to have very few members in line in the Memorial Day parade Tuesday. The reason for this is a feeling of antagonism which has developed against Second Lieut. John M. Thompson, the present commander of the company.

The University of Pennsylvania again carried off the championship at the annual track and field meeting of the Intercollegiate Association of amateur athletes of America, held at Manhattan Field yesterday afternoon. It was a foregone conclusion that the Philadelphia collegians would win, but they were hardly expected to score as many as 57 points, more than twice as many as Harvard, which finished second.

MINDEN, Neb., May 27. -- A disastrous tornado visited this section last night. The list of known wounded now numbers eight and six are believed to have been dangerously injured. They are J.V. Tennant, wife, and son, struck by flying debris; Joseph Bayer and wife, Charles Billich's two children, and John Ross, fatally hurt by being carried a mile in the storm by force of wind.

Dairymen near here are said to have profited by the developments before the army board which investigated the beef scandals, and to have purchased large quantities of chemicals, with which they treat the milk in such a manner that it will keep for weeks in the hottest sun.

WATERLOO, Iowa, May 28. -- The through train from Chicago to Minneapolis over the Rock Island and Burlington, Cedar Rapids and Northern Railways was wrecked at 1:15 o'clock this morning at the crossing of Sink Creek, about four miles southeast of this place. The train consisted of six coaches, including mail and baggage car, smoking car, two passenger coaches, and sleeper.

Sampson commanding, sailed from Tompkinsville shortly after 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon, bound for Newport, R.I., which port will be used as the base of the Summer evolutions and exercises of the squadron. Known only as a peddler, Charles J. Benson of 329 Eighth Avenue is supposed to have died rich. He was found early yesterday morning by Patrolman Shields of the West Thirtieth Street Station sitting apparently lifeless on the stood of a house on West Twenty-fifth Street, near Tenth Avenue.

WASHINGTON, May 28. -- The State Department is in receipt of a report from Consul Allen at Seoul, detailing the trade conditions in Korea, and showing some curious facts in connection with the country. Imports and exports for 1898 have fallen off almost a third as compared with 1897, owing to the scanty rice crop, which forced the natives to retain for food much grain that otherwise would have gone abroad in trade.

In the afternoon a general mass meeting for men only was held in the Auditorium. An address was given by S. N. Sayford of Boston to an immense audience.

The thirteenth convention of the United States Grand Lodge Independent Order Sons of Benjamin, one of the largest Jewish organizations in the United States, opened yesterday at the Murray Hill Lyceum, in West Thirty-fourth Street, near Third Avenue. The last convention was held in Baltimore three years ago, and in the interim dissensions in the order have been frequent and lively.

The weekly statement of the New York City Associated Banks, issued Saturday, shows an increase in the reserve of $9,302,200. The banks now hold $43,933,725 more than the legal requirements. The changes in the averages show a decrease in the loans of $17,578,800, an increase in specie of $3,692,900, an increase in legal tenders of $2,454,100, a decrease in deposits of $12,620,800, and a decrease of circulation of $35,600.

Stock Exchange brokers get an extra rest to-day. While all the country celebrates Memorial Day to-morrow, Wall Street suspends business for to-day as well. This interval of inactivity will do Wall Street no harm. Business men there have had much chance to overwork during recent months, and an extra day of recreation will be helpful.

If Chief Constructor Hichborn is consulted and his advise taken, she will not be considered anything more than a trophy.

BOSTON, May 28. -- The State Convention of the Social Democracy was held in this city to-day, twenty-five branches being represented by fifty-six delegate. LONDON, May 28. -- Paris has at last betrayed symptoms of tiredness. The French are marvelous people, the most painfully thrifty in the world, but even they cannot find the means for all the follies to which they are invited to subscribe. Early this week some of their industrial paper structures began to crumple, and suddenly the Bourse found itself overloaded in many directions.

HAVANA, May 28. -- There were 111 applicants to-day for shares in the $3,000,000 which the United States has offered as a gratuity to the Cuban troops. Thirty received $75 each The others were not on the rolls, although they had guns, which they were ready to turn in, and certificates of service.

ANNAPOLIS, May 28. -- Appropriate exercises were held at the United States Naval Academy Chapel here to-day at the unveiling of the memorial tablet to the late Cadet William H. Boardman of Massachusetts, who was accidentally shot at San Juan, Puerto Rico, in the Spanish war.

The Metropoliltan Opera House was yesterday afternoon crowded to its doors on the occasion of a lecture on Christian Science by Carol Norton, "member of the International Board of Lectureship of the Mother Church of Christian Science, Boston, Mass." The lecture was under the auspices of the fourteen Christian Science churches of the metropolitan district, and each of the churches was well represented.

In a recent communication to the French Academy of Sciences M. Albert Verley describes the method by which he has succeeded in preparing, by artificial means, the odoriferous principle to which the characteristic scent of the jasmine blossom is due. The latter is so peculiar and incomparable that it has of late years held the proud position of being the only floral perfume which art and science have not succeeded in imitating.

The skies are not yet clear in the Philippines and they are darkening in Cuba. The burden of the Administration's responsibilities and of its anxieties, also, is not lighter than it was three months ago; perhaps it is heavier. The negotiations with AGUINALDO'S Commissioners have proved fruitless, and it is tolerably evident that the sending of them was a trick of that perfectly irresponsible reprobate to gain time to re-form his army or to escape.

The statement issued this morning by Mr. T.C. PLATT is as puzzling as was his hasty indorsement of Mr. McKINLEY last week, unless explained in the same manner. The Boss has had a terrible setback, and he takes this way of persuading the public that he has not been driven from business and of inviting his old customers not to abandon him.

SALT LAKE, Utah, May 28. -- Rear Admiral Schley arrived here to-day from Denver. At Provo, Utah, he was met by a reception committee headed by Gov. Wells and other prominent citizens. A large and enthusiastic crowd greeted the party at the railway station. This afternoon the Admiral and party attended the services at the Tabernacle.
NEW YORK, April 18. -- A charming romance has just developed in this city of surprises, the hero being Prince Francis of Auersperg, a descendant of the famous Austrian Premier.

PATERSON, N.J., May 28. -- A carriage containing two men, two women, and a child was struck at 6 o'clock this evening by a train on the Greenwood Lake Division of the Erie Railroad at Singac, eight miles from here. Miss Juliette Rafferty, thirty years old, of 572 Main Street, this city, was killed.

BUFFALO, May 28. -- One week ago to-day a man giving the name of Robert Hale, residence 1,220 South Broadway, St. Louis, lodged at the house of Mrs. King, 81 Swan Street, this city. He had with him two children, a three-year-old boy and a girl apparently seventeen months old. Monday morning Hale disappeared taking with him the boy, but leaving the girl behind.

WASHINGTON, May 28. -- The War Department has made public a report from Gen. Irving Hale, who commanded the Second Brigade, Second Division, of the Eighth Army Corps at Manila, upon the stirring events between the nights o Feb. 4 and 9 there. This division was quartered in the vicinity of the water works and a portion of it, the Nebraska regiment, fired the first shots that began the active fighting with the insurgents.

LONDON, May 28. -- Business on the Stock Exchange last week was flat, and the movement in prices unimportant. The fear of dearer money caused weakness in consols, which closed at 109 3/4, the lowest figure this year.

LONDON, May 29. -- The Washington correspondent of The Daily Chronicle, referring to the Alaska boundary dispute, says: "President McKinley has all along been most anxious to bring about a settlement. He personally urged the American Commissioners to make every reasonable concession, and to go to the extreme limit of generosity if necessary, so desirous was he to remove all cause of friction.

PARIS, May 29. -- While the Dreyfus case was proceeding in one part of the Palace of Justice, the Assize Court, on the other side of the building, was occupied with the trial of MM. Deroulede and Marcel Habert, members of the Chamber of Deputies, who are charged with inciting soldiers to insubordination on the day of the-election of President Loubet.

WASHINGTON, May 29. -- All the volunteers now in the Philippines, if they are mustered out at San Francisco, are to be invited to mobilize at Minneapolis and St. Paul. There they are to receive a rousing welcome, made the more notable by the presence of President McKinley.

Several more alleged clues that were thought to lead up to the solution of the mystery surrounding the abduction of Marion Clarke, the infant daughter of Arthur W. Clarke, have come to naught, and by their own admission the police are just where they were when they received the first word that the child had been carried off by her nurse.

-- According to a published interview, Mr. BERNARD N. BAKER, President of the Atlantic Transport Company, calls the wreck of the Paris an "impenetrable mystery," and declares his inability to understand how the vessel came to approach the English coast, since she had started from the coast of France and had a perfectly clear and straight course out into the open sea.
President MCKINLEY, amid troubles that are serious and inevitable, has finally consented to go out of his way and to invite other troubles gratuitous, continuous, and discreditable.

James McCartney, Commissioner of the Department of Street Cleaning, yesterday sent to Mayor Van Wyck a report on the operations of his department for the year 1898. The report is a long one, and embraces, in detail, the work for the year, which, he intimates, has been retarded by the new conditions incident to consolidation, and which can only be overcome by a process of comparatively slow growth.

" After the storm the calm" fits particularly the condition of affairs at the Brooklyn Jockey Club race course yesterday. The frenzied shouts of thousands, such as filled the air when Banastar rushed home alone winner of the Brooklyn Handicap on Saturday, were missing. So, too, was the frantic rush and the terrible overcrowding at the betting ring.

The crowd of passersby in Broadway, just above Tenth Street, shortly after 11 o'clock yesterday morning, saw a man poised on a scaffold which dangled forty feet above the flagging in front of Grace Protestant Episcopal Church, on the east side of the thoroughfare. Suddenly he slipped and fell to the flat, hard stone beneath.

The statement was made yesterday in quarters practically official that C. Oliver Iselin has an interest in the new cup defender Columbia amounting to $20,000. There had been an impression that Mr. Iselin's financial interest in the boat was much smaller, and that his connection with her was principally that of manager.

BUFFALO, May 29. -- The preliminary trial of Mr. and Mrs. Kinter and Mr. and Mrs. Saunders, Christian Scientists, charged with being responsible for the death of Young Rolfe Saunders, was resumed this forenoon. As little or no evidence against the women had been brought out, they were discharged.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., May 29. -- Mrs. Peter A. Meeker of Roseland was killed this morning at the crossing of the Erie Railroad at Roseland Avenue, Caldwell. She was fifty-four years of age, and the wife of a well-known resident of Roseland. She had driven into Caldwell with her daughter, Miss Grace V. Meeker, who is a student at the State Normal School, at Trenton.

Noting the apparent failure of the scheme to distribute $3,000,000 to the "Cuban Army" and the signs of dissatisfaction with our rule that are evinced by many of the Cubans, I wonder if one of the causes for the friction may not be senseless rules made by our representatives in authority for the conduct of these people.

A revolt within the Democratic Party of this city against the further dominance of RICHARD CROKER, if well planned and wisely organized, ought to succeed at the present time. But the charge against him ought to be that he is a bad leader for the party and an enemy to decent government, not that he has "turned down" a district leader.

OTTAWA, Ontario, May 29. -- Speaking in the House to-night on the Alaska boundary question, Sir Wilfrid Laurier said that a series of articles had been appearing in the American press which showed there was an evident attempt on the part of some parties to create the impression that Canada had taken an unreasonable stand.

HAVANA, May 29. -- To-day's events in connection with the payment of the Cuban troops entitled to apply here for a share in the American gratuity seemed to indicate that the opposition to the receipt of the bounty by privates was disappearing. In American military circles it is considered that a fine start has been made and that the opposition is defeated.

WASHINGTON, May 29. -- A gentleman who is familiar with the exchanges between the United States and Great Britain respecting the Canadian boundary controversy makes the following statement as to the attitude of the American Commissioners in order, as he says, that the people or the United States and Great Britain may have an opportunity to judge for themselves of the comparative rectitude of the actions of the United States and Canada, respectively:

The Federation of Churches and Christian Workers in this city, of which Spencer Trask is President, has just completed and published the results of its third sociological canvass. The work was confined to the Twenty-first Assembly District, as its two previous canvasses were limited to the Fifteenth and the tenement section of the Nineteenth Assembly District.

MANILA, May 29. -- An order has been issued re-establishing the Philippine courts, which have been closed since the American occupation. It revives all the Spanish system, without conflicting with the sovereignty of the United States.

BLACKFOOT, Idaho, May 29. -- Ex-Senator Dubois, Chairman of the Executive Committee of the National Silver Republican Party, was interviewed as to the present attitude of the sliver Republicans. Mr. Dubois said:

WASHINGTON, May 29. -- The President and Secretary Hay are gratified at the precedence given by The Hague Conference to the subject of arbitration, which is regarded as mainly American in conception. The detailed scheme of arbitration which is to be proposed by the United States delegates was carefully wrought out at the State Department before the Commissioners sailed from New York.

LONDON, May 29. -- In the cricket match to-day between the Australians and Oxford University the former eleven were all out in the first innings for 303 runs. At the close of play Oxford had scored 36 runs for one wicket down.

Alonzo J. Whiteman of Dansville, N.Y., and ex-State Senator of Minnesota, who was arrested on Saturday on a charge of securing $93.75 from the New Amsterdam Hotel by means of a worthless check, has escaped from the clutches of the police, who place the blame on Magistrate Pool, who is sitting in Jefferson Market Police Court.

The Winnifred, the first American built tramp steamship, which last Winter was put on trial by the New York and Puerto Rico Steamship Company, has proved a failure, according to reports, and as been thrown back on the hands of her builders, the Bath Iron Works of Bath, Me. The Morgan Steamship Company has chartered the discarded vessel, however, for a month, to run between this city and New Orleans.

There is a curious coincidence in the fact that the Texas anti-trust law goes into operation almost exactly at the same time that the anti-trust law of Arkansas is declared by the courts to be fatally defective.

Is there not great danger ahead for investors in the present craze for municipal bonds? The so-called securities of little Western and Southern communities that would be dear on a 10 per cent. basis go at 4 per cent. or less. All the Southern States except Texas are in default on their State bonds -- some, like Tennessee, on bonds given for ante-war debts. Some like Georgia repudiated their bonds given for railroad purposes.

The meeting of the Methodist preachers at 150 Fifth Avenue yesterday was marked by a display of feeling antagonistic to higher criticism. The address of the day, by William Phillips Hall, a Wall Street broker and an evangelist, was an attack on higher critics. He took for his subject "The Old Paths."

There was a surprising and unexpected scene at the regular meeting of the Church Club of the Diocese of Long Island, which was held last night in the Brooklyn Bank Building, in Clinton Street. These meetings are generally highly pacific and enjoyable affairs. The trouble was precipitated by the Rev. Dr. Pelham Williams of Greenbush, Mass., one of the invited speakers.

PARIS, May 29. -- The Dreyfus affair appears to have lost the power of producing any unusual excitement. The scene in the Court of Cassation had all the aspects of a solemn religious ceremony, and the elaborate precautions to prevent the expected riotous demonstrations proved quite unnecessary. Nothing indicated that anything unusual was happening in the assembly.

HAVANA, May 29. -- Memorial Day will be observed by the United States military and naval forces here. Appropriate ceremonies have been arranged, and the wreck of the United States battleship Maine, the graves in Colon Cemetery, and those at Camp Columbia will be decorated with flowers.

BOSTON, May 29. -- Mr. Richard H. Dana, when asked this afternoon what he thought of the new exemptions, said: "I think this is a backward step in the cause of civil service reform." He said: "Out of 4,000 offices exempted, a very small number, possibly 100 or 200, it might be wise to exempt.

Vice President William H. Kimball of the Seventh National Bank said yesterday that Mayor Josiah Quincy of Boston, who is identified with Assistant Postmaster General Perry S. Heath, his brother, Fletcher S. Heath; Gen. W.P. Orr, Frank H. Roy, and others who have acquired stock of the bank, visited him last week and returned home on Saturday.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, May 23. -- A year or two ago an American named Best Harding Archer came to Jamaica. He was a capitalist in a small way, and went in for banana cultivation, purchasing a property in the Parish of Portland, known as Eden Vale.

WASHINGTON, May 29. -- The Navy Department, which will soon take up the payment of prize and bounty money arising from the war with Spain, has taken steps to protect the sailors involved in the distribution and secure for them the fullest amount of their claims with the least expense to the recipients.

Two somewhat unusual and delicate surgical operations have been performed within a week at St. Mark's Hospital -- the removal of bullets from vital parts of the body after being located by X-ray photographs. One patient died yesterday morning from peritonitis while the other bids fair to recover. Dr. Carl Beck was the operating surgeon in both cases.

CHICAGO, May 29. -- Twenty-five dairy cows were slaughtered at the Stock Yards this morning to confirm the tuberculin tests made by the State Veterinarian, which showed that this number of cattle, out of a herd of sixty-one cows, were infected with tuberculosis. Milk was sold in Chicago from these cows.
PARIS, May 29. -- The Court of Cassation met to-day to hear the debates in the application for a revision of the Dreyfus case.

SING SING, May 29. -- Adrian Braun, the wife murderer, was executed in the electric chair here to-day. The current was turned on at 9:17 A.M., and 1,800 volts were sent through his body. The current was kept on for one minute. At 9:18 Braun was pronounced dead, but Warden Johnson decided on a second shock.

CHICAGO, May 29. -- Capt. Charles D. Clay of the Seventeenth Infantry, a grandson of Henry Clay, has returned from Manila on sick leave. He was wounded near Malolos March 25, fifteen days after landing from the transport Grant. The bullet entered his neck, and has not been extracted. He went last night to his home, in Lexington, Ky., but expects to go on to New York immediately for treatment.

WHITE PLAINS, May 29. -- The case against the Mount Vernon Christian Scientist accused of being responsible for the death of Mrs. Charlotte Barguet was not presented to the Westchester County Grand Jury yesterday, but the whole matter was laid over until Wednesday. The accused are Mrs. Clarence Fowler and Ethel and Lister Barguet, children of the dead woman.

BATH, Me., May 29. -- The United States torpedo boat Dahlgren was floated off the ways on which the craft has been built at the Bath Iron works, at 4:20 o'clock this afternoon. As soon as she was fairly afloat Mrs. John Vinton Dahlgren, who is the wife of the late Admiral Dahlgren's youngest son, broke a bottle of champagne over the decorated bow and pronounced the christening words.
Plans for the celebration of Memorial Day were given in detail in THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday. The general and salient features of the local observance of the anniversary are as folows.
If the President pursues a successful policy in Cuba and the Philippines it will not be a subject of campaign strife next year. That would be fortunate for him and for the country.

The announcement in yesterday's papers that the typographical union which includes the German printers has determined to engage a professor of English, so as to enable its members to do work in that language, is of high significance. It shows that the demand for German reading is not even stationary, but is relatively, if not positively, decreasing.

It became known yesterday that the proposition to increase the capital and surplus of the North American Trust Company, to the Presidency of which Alvah Trowbridge, Vice President of the National Bank of North America, has been elected, to $2,000,000 and $1,000,000, respectively, was sanctioned last week.

NEWPORT, May 29. -- Upon the arrival of the North Atlantic Squadron this afternoon from New York, after having adjusted compasses off Block Island, Admiral Sampson and his officers were fairly deluged with cards for social functions. The fleet will take part ill the inauguration of Gov. Dyer to-morrow, and the infantry battalion of the fleet will be in line, with Capt. Sigsbee in command.

BOSTON, May 29. -- After six days of careful consideration, Gov. Wolcott to-day vetoed the so-called Spanish Veterans Preference bill. The bill exempted veterans of the late war with Spain from civil service examinations and gave them a preference on the public services appointment lists next after the veterans of the civil war.

THE HAGUE, May 29. -- The drafting committee, or sub-committee, of the Arbitration Committee of the Peace Conference met today and discussed the Russian scheme, adopting with slight modifications the first six articles. Count Nigra, chief of the Italian delegation, submitted a proposal of mediation and arbitration consisting of six articles in the form of an amendment to the Russian project.

YORK, Penn., May 29. -- This was church extension day in the General Synod of the Lutheran Church of the United States. The Rev. H.H. Weber, Secretary of the board, made the report, an abstract of which follows:

PROVIDENCE, May 29. -- The assembling of the crew of the Columbia at Bristol is a reminder of the near approach of the launching The latest arrival in Bristol is Capt. Charles Barr, who was selected months ago by the Iselin-Morgan cup defense syndicate to sail the Columbia in her races during the season of 1899.

WASHINGTON, May 29. -- President McKinley to-day issued the amendments to the civil service rules which he has had under consideration for about a year. It releases from the operations of the civil service rules about 4,000 offices. Through changes in Rule III. the following named positions, which have been classified under the Civil Service act, are excepted from the requirements of examination or registration, unless otherwise stated:

The Yale University team defeated the University of Pennsylvania in the college relay race in the Knickerbocker Athletic Club games at Bayonne, N.J., yesterday. The race was at one mile. Yale's time was 3:24 2-5, beating Pennsylvania 50 yards. Pennsylvania would have been beaten worse if Francis had not started about fifteen feet before his mate reached the line on the third quarter.

AUSTIN, Texas May 30. -- Dr. Souchon, City Health Officer of New Orleans, to-day telegraphed to State Health Officer W. F. Blunt that yellow fever had reappeared in that city, one death from the disease occurring yesterday. Immediately upon receipt of the telegram from Dr. Souchon, Dr. Blunt wired to General Superintendent W. G. Van Vleck of the Southern Pacific as follows:

LONDON, May 30. -- The London International Chess Congress opened at St. Stephen's Hall, Westminster, in this city, today. There was a large attendance of representatives of the principal chess clubs of Great Britain. Sir William Hart Dyke opened the proceedings with a brief address, in the course of which he extended a hearty welcome to the foreign players.
WASHINGTON, May 30. -- The weekly crop bulletin of the Weather Bureau, issued today, is as follows:

Gov. Roosevelt addressed as many people as could gather within the sound of his voice at Grant's Tomb, in Riverside Park, yesterday. His oration was the principal feature of the Memorial Day exercises, which were conducted by U.S. Grant Post, No. 327, G.A.R., of Brooklyn. Thousands visited the tomb, and a large proportion of the people tarried in its vicinity throughout the afternoon.

Not a year has elapsed since the United States obtained the right of authority over the peoples of Cuba and Puerto Rico. It is pertinent to consider and discuss the question whether our officials in the countries named are pursuing the best methods to win for us the appreciation and good will of these peoples.

LONDON, May 30. -- Sensational scoring was made in the cricket match begun yesterday between the Surrey and Somerset elevens at Kensington Oval. Surrey had the first innings, and batted all yesterday and part of to-day, making a total of 811 runs, one of the highest records in first class cricket.

NEWPORT, R.I, May 30. -- Elisha Dyer, for the third time, was inaugurated Governor of Rhode Island to-day. The day was observed as Newport's annual holiday, and in addition to the naval exercises there was a big celebration in honor of the presence of Rear Admiral Sampson and the ships of the North Atlantic Squadron.

COVERACK, Cornwall, May 30. -- The position of the American Line steamer Paris remains unchanged. The weather is excellent. Numerous sightseers have visited the shore in the vicinity of the stranded steamer.

NEWPORT, May 30. -- The boat race between the seamen gunners and Old Colony Club racing crews for the silk flag offered by the Misses Hunter was won by the Old Colony Club over the Belmont-Garrettson course this morning, in the presence of thousands of people. The judges were W.K. Vanderbilt, Jr., Col. D.E. Young, and Mayor Boyle. Commander McLean was referee and G.R. Plumer starter.

HILTON, N.J., May 30. -- The eleventh annual Irvington-Millburn twenty-five-mile road race was held to-day over the famous Springfield Avenue course between Irvington and Millburn. A.W. Ross of Harrison, N.J. -- a five-minute man -- won the race by five lengths. John King of Newark, N.J. -- a four-and-a-half-minute man -- was second, and H.R. Skiff of Hartford, Conn. -- a four-minute man -- was third.

BOSTON, May 30. -- Gen. Joseph Wheeler, the cavalry leader, who led "the boys in gray" at the famous charge at Shiloh, and, nearly thirty-seven years later, beneath the Stars and Stripes, cheered on the volunteers at Santiago, was the orator and guest of honor at the Memorial Day services of E.W. Kinsley Post, No. 113, G.A.R., at Boston Theatre.
Your editorial, "Keep It Out of the Campaign," in this morning's issue, is noteworthy.

Mrs. Louisa Green of 204 Bowers Street, Jersey City, informed Chief of Police Murphy yesterday that she had been swindled out of $169.60 by the American Investment Company, whose officers were arrested in Hoboken last Wednesday night. Mrs. Green said that she had paid the company's agent $119.60, for which he agreed to buy a lot on Gifford Place and build a house for her.

PARIS, May 30. -- The Assize Court, engaged in the hearing of the case against MM. Paul Deroulede and Marcel-Habert, charged with inciting soldiers to insubordination, resumed its sitting at noon to-day. The entry of the defendants elicited shouts of "Vive Deroulede!"

WASHINGTON, May 30. -- After the adverse criticism which American naval designers were subjected to some years ago because of a supposed lack of stability on the part of some of the United States gunboats, they have been gratified to ascertain from personal inspection that the standards in foreign navies are far below the American in this matter.

WASHINGTON, May 30. -- To-day the National capital devoted itself to the observance of Decoration Day. The ceremony at Arlington was notable by the presence of the President and members of his Cabinet, and of many leading officers of the army and navy, as well as officials prominent in public life. The orator of the day was Assistant Secretary of the Interior Webster Davis, who, in the course of his address, said:

TIFFIN, Ohio, May 30. -- The Synod of the Reformed Church to-day adopted a resolution requesting the United States Government to set aside in its new building in New York City, for the reception of immigrants, a room where religious services may be held. A copy of the resolution was ordered to be forwarded to T.V. Powderly, Superintendent of Immigration.

Warm weather and golf enthusiasm, the latter showing itself early in the morning and continuing until sunset, were the chief holiday features yesterday on the Morris County Club links, at Morristown, N.J. The players began to arrive before 9 o'clock, and the links had more playing, from the first to the eighteenth hole, than they have experienced before this year.

Miss Julia Dent Grant, Brig. Gen. Frederick Dent Grant's daughter, reached the city yesterday with her aunt, Mrs. Potter Palmer, on the North German Lloyd steamship Kaiser Wilhelm der Grosse. Miss Grant is soon to become a Russian Princess, her engagement to Prince Michael Cantacuzene of Russia having been announced some time ago.

YORK, Penn., May 30. -- The regular order of business on the opening of the Lutheran General Synod this morning was consideration of the report of the Board of Publication The Rev. S.A. Holahan, Corresponding Secretary of the board, read the report.

PARIS, May 30. -- Before the Court of Cassation to-day M. Ballot-Beaupre concluded his report on the Dreyfus case by asking for a revision of the verdict of condemnation and a retrial of Capt. Dreyfus by a court-martial. He declared solemnly that he had become convinced that the bordereau was written by Major Count Ferdinand Walsin Esterhazy.

Another day -- the tenth since the abduction of little Marion Clarke -- has passed, and yet the police are no nearer a solution of the mystery than they were at first. There have been clues innumerable, from cranks, from persons well disposed and anxious to give their aid, and from another class that sees in the notoriety given the case a chance to advertise themselves, but all have led to nothing.

ELMIRA N.Y., May 30. -- A finer day for an athletic meeting could not be looked for than that which favored the Cornell and Princeton teams at Maple Avenue Park today. The attendance was about 4,000, and the half-mile track was in splendid condition. The only element of disappointment was the absence of Ralph Hutchinson, 1902, a local athlete, who is a famous all-round athlete at Princeton.

HAVANA, May 30. -- Decoration Day was observed here in a notable manner. At 9 o'clock this morning Mrs. Estes G. Rathbone and a committee of women who had been selected for the purpose were taken in Rear Admiral Cromwell's launch, escorted by a detachment of marines, to the wreck of the battleship Maine, where they strung the skeleton of the craft with ropes of laurel and wreaths of flowers.

LOUISVILLE, May 30. -- Although the day was gloomy and dismal, and threatened rain, the graves of the Union soldiers in the cemeteries of Louisville and New Albany, Ind., were decked with flowers in the presence of large concourses. There was a musical service at Cave Hill Cemetery, followed by the oration of the day by Henry Watterson.
I notice in this morning's issue of your paper that some suspicions of a Mr. Fitch of Uncasville, Conn., are given publicity.
Factional fights in the stock market are not unlikely to be spirited this week -- not so much over the general list as in specialties.

ITHACA, N.Y., May 30. -- The Cornell-University of Pennsylvania boat race, which was postponed from the scheduled time of 3:30 o'clock this afternoon, was rowed at 7:30 o'clock this evening. Cornell won by half a length.

Mrs. Kate King, forty-eight years old, of 229 West Nineteenth Street was found dead in one of the bedrooms of her flat yesterday afternoon, having been asphyxiated by illuminating gas. Beside her body lay her nine-year-old son, Raymond, unable to move, but still conscious. He was at once removed from the flat, and, with the aid of doctors soon recovered.

In your report from Washington in today's TIMES, bearing the heading "What Canadians Wanted," it is stated that the Canadian Government insists upon the ceding of Pryamid Harbor, in Southeastern Alaska, to Canada.

A citizen saw two young men with a jimmy prying open the door of Cashman Peyser's tailor's shop on the ground floor of 107 Chrystie Street, early yesterday morning. He notified Policeman Madigan. The burglars saw the policeman approaching and ran. They went through Chrystie Street to Broome, and through that thoroughfare toward the Bowery.

PARIS, May 30. -- A large throng gathered this afternoon in the Cemetery of Picpus to assist in the annual decoration by the Americans of the tomb of Lafayette. The interest of the occasion was enhanced by the knowledge that ex-President Benjamin Harrison would speak.
LONDON, May 31. -- The correspondent of The Standard at The Hague says:

The New Yorks and Cincinnatis broke even at the Polo Grounds yesterday, 14,000 persons seeing the home team win the afternoon game by scoring two runs in their final inning. The spectators were entertained by a row on the field, due to a decision by Umpire Gaffney. This decision gave the locals the chance to win, and the visiting players were not slow to display their anger.

MANILA, May 30. -- Memorial Day was celebrated at Battery Knoll, where Scott's guns were planted against the Filipino trenches in the first day's fighting at Manila. Nearly three hundred soldiers lie buried there on a bleak mound surrounded by rice fields, rough boards marking the graves, which are ranged in five unbroken rows.
LONDON, May 31. -- The Daily Telegraph's correspondent at The Hague says:

The new building of St. Vincent's Hospital, at 153 West Eleventh Street, to which the destitute sick of the city will be admitted free of charge, was formally opened yesterday by Archbishop Corrigan in the presence of about fifteen hundred people. The building had been tastefully decorated for the occasion by flowers and potted plants.

PARIS, May 30. -- Three events have taken place to-day, each of which, without the other, would have sufficed to electrify France. All coming together, interest was diffused, and no convulsion thus far is apprehended.

TOULON, May 30. -- Major Marchand arrived here at 12:30 o'clock this afternoon on board the French cruiser D'Assas. The hero of Fashoda was greeted with immense enthusiasm, the ship having him on board being escorted into the harbor by a large number of steamers.
THE HAGUE, May 30. -- The Vaderland prints to-day what purports to be the text of the Russian proposals regarding mediation and arbitration.

WASHINGTON, May 30. -- Cardinal Gibbons, Papal Delegate, Mgr. Martinelli, and other prominent Catholic churchmen took part to-day in the second day's celebration of the centennial of Georgetown Convent. It is estimated that at least one thousand women, representing every State in the Union and many of the Latin-American countries, took part in the ceremonies.

The most notable passenger who arrived yesterday on the North German Lloyd steamship Kaiser Wilhelm der Grosse was the Duke d'Arcos, who comes to assume the post of Spanish Minister at Washington, which has been vacant since the hurried departure of Senor Polo y Bernabe, April 20, 1898, on the eve of the outbreak of war between the two countries.

PHILADELPHIA May 30. -- The team match between the Manhattan and Franklin Chess Clubs was played to-day at the rooms of the latter in this city. De Visser was the Captain of the New York team, while D. Stuart acted in the same capacity for Philadelphia. Fourteen games were contested, the final score being: New York, 7 1/2; Philadelphia, 6 1/2.

Yesterday was an innovation upon the usual celebration of Memorial Day, whether since it has been known as Memorial Day by universal observance, North and South alike, or in the earlier period when it was known as Decoration Day, and when each State responded, in its own way, to the general desire of the American people.

The ordinary American citizen must have been stricken with wonder upon reading the newspaper reports of the goings on of the Cuban patriots, both civil and military. Not that the Cuban civil patriot has ever commanded the complete confidence of the American people. They have supposed him to be, like the Irish patriot of a former generation, simply a person who had an unusually strong aversion to gaining his bread by honest industry.

On the North German Lloyd steamship Kaiser Wilhelm der Grosse, from Bremen, which tied up at her Hoboken pier about 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon, some interesting tourists reached this city. Among them were fifty-two passengers who were taken from the American Line steamship Paris, which went aground near the Manacles, off the southern coast of England, on Sunday, May 21.

One feature of the Dreyfus affair, now drawing to its climax, strikes Americans as singular -- the relative insignificance of the President in the stormy drama. This was emphatically expressed by M. CASIMIR-PERIER in his testimony before the Court of Cassation. "When I occupied the Presidency," he said, "I was extremely unfamiliar with what was going on in the affairs of France."

We pointed out yesterday that the President's order extending the spoils principle to a large number of the places in the civil service was a distinct violation of his personal pledges and those of his party. We propose to-day to examine briefly some of the effects of this act upon the civil service and upon the politics of the country.

While there were several opportunities for the harness racers to furnish amusement yesterday at points near the city, the only local event was the matinee card at the Parkway track, Brooklyn. It was expected that the first of the contests for the loving cup offered by Fire Commissioner Scannell would be the feature, but this had to be canceled for want of material.

THE TIMES being the high road by which all who have cause for complaint send their grievances to be righted, I will take advantage of this and begin by asking if there is a law compelling the conductors of all public conveyances to enforce order and good behavior, and to respect -- as far as possible -- the convenience and comfort of their passengers.

WASHINGTON, May 30. -- President McKinley, in the estimation of civil service reform advocates, has abandoned, in a measure the high position he occupied in 1890, when he declared his support not only of the civil service law as it stood, but his desire that it should be made more largely inclusive than it then was.

LONDON, May 30. -- The plague may complicate the home-coming of Admiral Dewey. Various Governments have already declared severe quarantine regulations against all Egyptian Red Sea ports and Hongkong, where the fresh cases and the number of deaths have nearly doubled in the last week, the new cases numbering 143 and the deaths 134.

HAVANA, May 30. -- Early this morning Lieut. Col. George M. Randall of the Eighth United States Infantry, accompanied by Paymaster Moses, his clerks, a Surgeon, and a military escort, with nearly $200,000, left by special train for Santiago de las Vegas; but, owing to various delays, the payment did not begin until this afternoon.

CHICAGO, May 30. -- Those interested in the Speakership race in the West are discussing a rumor to the effect that Congressman Henderson is merely a "stalking horse" used in the interest of Mr. Sherman.

The thirty-third annual regatta of the Harlem Regatta Association of Amateur Oarsmen took place yesterday, and was the largest in number of entries and the most interesting ever held under the auspices of the organization. At daybreak the river presented a scene of unusual activity. Nearly all the contestants were in evidence, some taking short spins on the river and some limbering up in the boathouses.

CHICAGO, May 30. -- Under directions from the War Department, Brig. Gen. T.M. Anderson, commanding the Department of the Lake, has ordered Company E, Seventh United States Infantry, to Alaska. The company is stationed at Fort Sheridan. Capt. C.S. Farnsworth is in command. The soldiers are to do garrison duty in place of a company of the Fourteenth Infantry which has been withdrawn and sent to Manila.

LONDON, June 1. -- The special dispatches from The Hague to the London morning papers agree that the American scheme meets with much favor, as being eminently practical. Sir Julian Pauncefote, the head of the British delegation, has modified the British proposal, and now suggests that the administrative council should not be international, but should be appointed by the Government of the country where the permanent court assembles.

At the annual meeting yesterday of the New York Produce Exchange President Brainard made an address, and reports were made by Treasurer E.C. Rice and the Finance Committee, of which E.T. Barrows is Chairman.

Three victories in the saddle for Odom, two for McCue, and one for O'Connor made the record of the day's racing at the Gravesend track yesterday afternoon. Odom had an easy time winning with Admiration, a comparatively easy one winning with Montanic, and rode a really brilliant race when he won with Pirate M. in the last race of the afternoon.

As a resident of Manhattan, who bitterly opposed the consolidation with Brooklyn, I feel that I have a right to complain of the present situation. Those who supported the scheme or refused to vote must be assured to have desired higher taxation, and they should not object now that they have got it.

When the delivery was completed, the sellers mailed to the purchaser a statement of the quantity and purchase price, with a notice that the terms of payment were a note payable at sixty days from date.

They are inclined to regard Marchand as such a man; and he has many qualities befitting the character. M. Forain, the caricaturist, has taken him the gold medal voted by the Black and White Artists. Mrs. T. Benton Letter of Chicago has definitely decided to become an actress, and to-day she will sign a contract to make her first professional appearance in vaudeville next Monday at Proctor's Twenty-third Street. Theatre, in a one-act piece entitled "A Stolen Kiss." After her appearance at Mr. Proctor's down-town theatre she will be seen at the Pleasure Palace in Fifty-eight Street.

The Brooklyns scored an easy victory over the Louisvilles at Washington Park yesterday afternoon. After the first inning the game was devoid of interest, the Brooklyns getting five runs by good batting. After that Dowling had the Brooklyns guessing. Hughes pitched a fine game, and but for two consecutive hits in the opening inning the Louisvilles would have been shut out.

The wedding of Miss Goodridge and Mr. John Iselin described in another column, was the social event of yesterday. Many of the guests already out of town drove over in drags to Riverdale from various parts of the country.
Eugene Schutz business manager for Chauncey Olcott for a number of years, was married on Monday to Miss May George of Hartford, Conn. Miss George has not been identified with the profession.

The Cromwell Line steamship Knickerbocker from New Orleans, carrying a cargo of freight and forty-five passengers, came into port early yesterday morning with fire raging in two of her holds. The flames were discovered early Monday morning, and for forty-eight hours the vessel had made a running fight of it.

The annual parade and review of the Police Department will take place to-day. It will be the largest parade ever held by the police, and it is estimated that nearly 5,000 members of the force, including officers and men, will be in line. There will be five regiments, divided into ten battalions of ten companies each, besides a large force of mounted men, bicycle riders, and patrol wagons.

George J. Gould and his Lakewood Club polo team made their first appearance yesterday in a regular contest in the Polo Association's circuit of events. George Gould did play in his first match game about two weeks ago at Meadow Brook, on the Westchester Country Club team, but it was the first appearance of the Lakewood team as an aspirant for polo honors.

In contests waged yesterday on the Stock ]xchange bear speculators had the better of it. Quotations under pressure receded materially. In the list of et changes for the day declines were very generally the rule. From start to finish the market was subject tO attack -- not in a few quarters, but throughout the whole list.

PARIS, May 31. -- MM. Deroulede and Marcel-Habert, who have been on trial before the Assize Court here on the charge of inciting soldiers to insubordination in connection with the election of President Loubet, were acquitted to-day.

LONDON, May 31 -- The second round of the international chess tournament was commenced at noon to-day, when the seventh round of the original schedule was adopted and the pairing was as follows: Teichmann vs. Pillsbury, Steinitz vs. Janowski, Lasker vs. Schiechter, Blackburne vs. Cohn, Mason vs. Bird, Tschigorin vs. Tinsley, Maroczy vs. Lee, and Showalter a bye.

Jacob Morrill Patterson died suddenly yesterday morning at his home, in Fordham. Mr. Patterson was in his sixty-first year. He had not complained of feeling ill for months, and his sudden illness and almost immediate death was a great surprise to his friends add family, who supposed that he was in the best of health.

WASHINGTON, May 31. -- The State Department to-day made public an official abstract of the report of the Nicaraguan Canal Commission as presented by Admiral Walker, the head of the commission. The report itself covers 136 typewritten pages and is accompanied by eleven appendices. It is understood to be the intention of the President to submit the full report to Congress at the beginning of the next session.

COLUMBUS, May 31. -- The Republican Congressmen of Ohio will meet here tomorrow night at the suggestion of Gen. Grosvenor, to discuss the Speakership question. Mr. Van Voorhis of Zanesville will preside.

It is not surprising that the Christian Scientists should have been able to call together an audience of three thousand persons to hear Mr. NORTON'S exposition and defense of their mummery. It is not even disquieting. In every community there is a certain percentage of persons reputed to be intelligent who are really feeble-minded.

COLUMBUS, May 31. -- With Senators Foraker and Hanna, the Ohio Congressmen, and other leaders all here to-night, the indications are that there may be two opposing slates on the State ticket arranged before the Republican State Convention assembles to-morrow, but nothing definite can be learned as to the combinations to-night.

Edward English of Newburg, N.Y., was attacked last night by a gang of toughs at the Harlem River and One Hundred and Twenty-ninth Street, robbed of his valuables, and then thrown into the water. His cries were heard by some East One Hundred and Twenty-sixth Street Station detectives, who happened to be on the bridge, and they ran to his assistance, at the same time rapping for help.

Mrs. Rosina Vollhart has sold to John J. Roberts the seven-story apartment house known as the St. Bevan, at the northeast corner of Madison Avenue and One Hundred and Sixteenth Street, on a plot 50 by 100.11. The buyer gives in part payment sixteen lots on Tremont and Mapes Avenues, comprising a plot 225 by 190.

I read with considerable interest the article that appeared in your esteemed paper of May 30 under the heading of "How to Reduce Gas Bills," and while I agree with your correspondent as to the benefits to be derived from the use of an automatic gas regulator, I would venture to forward a few corrections for publication.
BALTIMORE, May 31. -- The following resolutions were adopted to-day at the annual meeting of the Civil Service Reform As sociation of Maryland:

SAN FRANCISCO, May 31. -- Mrs. Jane L. Stanford, widow of Leland Stanford, executed deeds to-day conveying to Stanford University the bulk of all her wealth, consisting principally of stocks and real estate, for the improvement and perpetual maintenance of that institution. Deeds were placed in the keeping of Judge Lleb, President of the Board of Trustees, and they will be recorded to-morrow with the Clerk of Santa Clara County.

At the twenty-ninth annual meeting of the New York Cotton Exchange, held yesterday, President Thomas M. Robinson reported, for the Board of Managers, on the affairs of the year. He noticed with commendation the action of Congress in appropriating money to improve New York Harbor.

WASHINGTON, May 31. -- The President to-day declared to a Congressman who called that there was not at present any contemplation of largely increasing Gen. Otis's forces in the Philippines. He said that nothing had been received from Gen. Otis which indicated the necessity for more troops beyond the regulars who are to be sent to relieve the retiring volunteers.

In this morning's TIMES Mr. G.W. Hopping attempts to instruct your readers in regard to the demand notes of 1861. In support of his assertion that an unlimited legaltender quality (including receivability for customs and all other dues to the United States) kept these notes always at par with gold, he appears to rely mainly upon the reckless statements of one Judge Warwick Martin. It would have been wiser to ascertain the facts.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 31. -- The Ohio Valley League of Bimetallic Clubs, with delegates from Ohio, Indiana, Illinois, and Kentucky, is holding its annual convention in this city. The attendance to-day was small. Judge J.P. Tarvin, President of the Bimetallic League, occupied the chair.

Another defeat was administered to the New Forks by the Cincinnatis at the Polo Grounds yesterday afternoon, but it was anything but an easy victory. The locals made a big bid for victory in their last inning, and for a while the Cincinnati team was nervous, but the game ended when Davis struck out, while there were two bases occupied.

PARIS, May 31. -- The surroundings of the Palace of Justice were almost deserted today when the Court of Cassation resumed hearing the arguments in the application for a revision of the Dreyfus trial. Many of the public seats in the count were empty.

There were few now developments in the Marion Clarke abduction case yesterday, which remains as great a mystery as ever. The most notable action taken so far is a proposition made to the Board of Aldermen by Alderman Muh that the Mayor be authorized to offer a reward of $10,000 for information which will lead to the recovery of the child and the arrest and conviction of her kidnappers.

One result of the meddling of Congress with what it does not understand is seen in the failure to receive bids within the statutory limit for the armor plate of the new battleships and other vessels of war authorized by Congress. This failure will no doubt be set down by the more ignorant and weak-minded members of Congress to a "combination" among the makers of armor plate.

NEWBURG, May 31. -- A resolution was adopted on the evening of Memorial Day by about twenty of the organizers of the Lincoln Association of Newburg, indorsing and upholding the action of the Seventh Regiment during the war between the United States and Spain. The resolution was suggested by the reports which came to the meeting of the treatment of the regiment during the day along its line of march in New York.

It is probable that those interested in the will of the late Dr. Thomas Seton Robertson will not have it contested, but will settle all differences out of court. A.H. Hummel, one of the beneficiaries under the will, said yesterday that the matter was virtually settled.

A peculiar accident occurred about 9:30 o'clock yesterday morning on the Third Avenue elevated road between Ninety-sixth and Ninety-seventh Street. A car was suspended over the edge of the structure for half an hour, as a result of somebody's blunder. Its rear trucks had fallen to the sidewalk with ill-effect to the flagging.

In THE TIMES of May 28 your correspondent "Simplicicus" asks the reason of the charge of heart of The New York Sun which last Summer attributed the victory of Santiago to Schley, but which no refers to that commander in terms of profound contempt, and enthusiastically gives the entire credit of the victory to Sampson.

The fourth day of the proceedings of the thirteenth annual convention of the United States Grand Lodge of the Independent Order of the Sons of Benjamin, which is being held in the Murray Hill Lyceum, was marked yesterday by amendments being made to the constitution and by-laws, as recommended by the annual report of the Grand Master.

LONDON, May 31. -- Flying Fox, the favorite, won the great Derby, for 6,000 sovereigns, at Epsom to-day, after an exciting contest with Holocauste, ridden by Tod Sloan, the latter horse breaking his leg at the fetlock joint in the straight. Sloan was unhurt and was escorted to the weighing room by a squad of policemen, who could scarcely make their way through the dense crowd.

Referring to the two addresses lately made by clergymen of the Episcopal Church before the Church Club of Brooklyn on the subject of Sunday schools, the difference of the status of those within this Church should be explained.

While the best race of the day at the Gravesend track of the Brooklyn Jockey Club yesterday was the steeplechase which wound up the day's sport, there had been a lot of pleasure preceding it. One of these pleasures was the appearance of the annual Walden-Morris-Littlefield "bluff," which has come to be looked for with each recurring season.

James A. Tyng, who has won two golf club championships within the past week, those of Morris County and Baltusrol, continued his good work yesterday in the opening round of the Baltusrol Club's three-day tournament on the links near Short Hills, N.J. In the qualifying round he again made the amateur record score for the course of eighty-two strokes, held by himself, and won the special cup given for the lowest record of tile day.
The contention of the Controller that the decoration of the Hall of Records be delegated to the supervision of the Art Commission, highly commendable in spirit, is still not well considered.

None are so blind as those who will not see. Even to this day there are persons at large and having access to pens, ink, and paper who will have it that the Maine was blown up by an explosion of her own magazine.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 1. -- The following officers have been elected by the American Baptist Home Mission Society: President -- Stephen Greene, Massachusetts; Vice Presidents -- E.M. Thresher, Ohio, and W.G. Brimson, Illinois; Treasurer -- F.R. Hathaway, New York; Auditors -- Edgar L. Marston and L.A. Requa, New York; Corresponding Secretary -- L.J. Morgan, New York; Recording Secretary -- The Rev. Dr. A.F. Hobart, New York.
