It is reported that twenty-five men are to be added to the bicycle police in Manhattan and Brooklyn. The force is too small, and even a larger increase than this is needed -- three times as many could be used to advantage.
ASBURY PARK, N.J., June 1. -- There seems to be a possibility of a split in the flock of the Rev. Howard T. Widdemer, which forms the First Congregational Church.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 1. -- The outcome of the Republican State Convention, which began here to-day, is as much in doubt tonight as it was before the opening session was held. A combination appears to have been formed against Senator Hanna, and against Judge George K. Nash as his candidate for Governor; but whether or not the members of the combination can agree upon any of the other candidates is uncertain.

On your editorial page yesterday, speaking of the changes in the marriage laws of Cuba and Puerto Rico, you say: "A system that practically abolished marriage of any sort for a large portion of the population can hardly stand comparison with one which, whatever its faults, does encourage and make cheap and easy the regularization of all unions. * * *

High-class saddle and harness horses under the hammer brought out a large crowd of bidders to the sale yesterday at the American Horse Exchange, and prices for the stock offered ranged from $200 upward to $3,850. The animals were the consignment brought from Iowa by W.C. Bryant, but only part of the lot were sold.

BOYERTOWN, Penn. June 1. -- Representative Chad B. Spatz of this county, for whom warrants of arrest have been issued, charging him with having offered Representatives Hill and Miller of Northampton County a bribe to sign a paper pledging their votes to George A. Jenks, the Democratic caucus nominee for United States Senator, to-day appeared before a Justice of Peace and waived a hearing.

An Irish layman wishes to say a few words in your valuable paper on the following subjects: "The Rev. Charles Briggs" and "Dreyfus." The one a Christian and the other a Hebrew. The one persecuted by his own Church for years; the other wronged and persecuted almost to death by his own Government which he would willingly die to defend.

LAKE MOHONK, N.Y., June 1. -- Increased interest and larger numbers characterized the second day's proceedings of the Mohonk Arbitration Conference. The Rev. Edward E. Hale reviewed the history of arbitration during the past thirty years, and the Rev. Dr. William Hayes Ward set forth the differences between the proposals for a court limited as to time by Russia and those for a permanent tribunal provided in the British and American propositions.

More testimony in the contest over the will of the late Anna Sutherland was heard by Surrogate Varnum yesterday. The case has been dragging in the courts for months. The contestant is Katherine C.K. Hagan, the wife of Dr. H.H. Hagan, of 41 West Fiftieth Street, and a daughter of the testatrix by her first husband.

LOUISVILLE, June 1. -- At to-day's session of the Ohio Valley League of Bimetallic Clubs, President James P. Tarvin was re-elected. A committee, including John P. Altgeld of Illinois George Fred Williams of Massachusetts, W.J. Overmeyer of Indiana, M.J. Semonin of Kentucky, Allen Y. Clark of Indiana, and James P. Tarvin of Kentucky was appointed to co-operate with the National Democratic Committee in perfecting the organization of the party throughout the country.

Why in the name of all that is beautiful and sincere in Christianity, do not the people discontinue this perpetual "nagging" in the newspapers anent the Church, ritualism, vestments, ? Those to whom church, ritualism, and vestments mean something real and vital cannot but be pained to see words with meanings so sacred to them used in such a profane and aggressive manner.

WASHINGTON, June 1. -- The Insular Commission appointed by the War Department to investigate the affairs of Puerto Rico and to report upon all matters relating to currency, laws, taxation, judiciary, public improvements, education, and civil affairs generally has made a unanimous report to the Secretary of War.

PARIS, June 1. -- The civil and military authorities and a big crowd of people went to the railroad station at Lyons at 1 o'clock this morning in order to welcome Major Marchand, the African explorer, on his way to Farts from Toulon, and a great concourse began assembling around the Paris depot of the Lyons-Paris Railroad at an early hour to-day.

WASHINGTON, June 1. -- Rowdy ball playing, which came near resulting in blows between Mercer and Bowerman, disgusted many of the spectators at to-day's ball game between Washington adn Pittsburg and finally required the services of a policeman to keep the peace. The trouble was occasioned by Mercer apparently taking the ball from Bowerman and thereby preventing the former being cut off at the plate.

PARIS, June 2 -- 1 A.M. -- Lieut. Col. du Paty de Clam, seriously implicated by the recent proceedings before the Court of Cassation as the probable instigator of some of the forgeries that have figured in the Dreyfus affair, was placed under arrest at half past 7 last evening (Thursday) and taken to the Cherche Midi Military Prison.

YORK, Penn., June 1. -- The adoption of the report of the Committee on Ministerial Acts, at a session of the General Lutheran Synod, which lasted until near midnight last night, was the cause of much rejoicing among the delegates at this morning's session.

WASHINGTON, May 29. -- United States Consul John C. Covert, writing from his post at Lyons, France has transmitted to the State Department a report on a special quality of wheat for the making of alimentary pastes in France and other European countries which is worthy of attention. "In several European countries," says the report, "the different forms of edible pastes known as macaroni, spaghetti, vermicelli, nouilles, , are produced in very large quantities.

NEWPORT, June 1. -- At 11 o'clock this morning the schooner Ada Ames, Capt. K. C. Emery of Rockland, Me., put into this harbor with her fore rigging carried away, her bulwarks stove in, her rails smashed, and a boom lying across the forward part of the vessel. On board were Capt. Charles C. Mattox and five seamen of the Mattie Holmes, with scarcely clothing enough to cover them.

A modern Noah's ark floated through the Narrows yesterday and anchored off the foot of Forty-second Street, Brooklyn. It was the British steamer Angola, Capt. Carruthers, which arrived from Calcutta with animals, birds, and reptiles in infinite variety. There never was such a howling, screeching, cackling, braying cargo brought into this harbor.

THE HAGUE, June 1. -- The First Commission, by a vote of 18 to 3, has adopted a resolution prohibiting the use of the dumdum, or flattened bullet. Italy, Austria, and Great Britain formed the minority. It was also resolved to prohibit the use of explosives from balloons and explosive bullets.

Permit me a few words of comment on the article, "No Rubric Against Reservation," by "Churchman," in your issue of today. The rubric in question reads as follows, "and if any of the consecrated bread and wine remain after the communion, it shall not be carried out of the church; but the minister and other communicants shall, immediately after the blessing, reverently eat and drink the same."

Capt. Price declared yesterday that he will give Frank Moss all the proof he wants in corroboration of the statements made by him on Wednesday against the Mazet committee's counsel the next time he goes on the stand. "Mark you," he said, "when I do appear I'll give Moss as lively a time as he ever had."

The Academy of Design property at the northwest corner of Twenty-third Street and Fourth Avenue has been purchased by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company. The deed which was placed on record yesterday gives the consideration as $440,000. The transaction was a cash one, and the purchasers will take immediate possession.

The Police Department turned out 5,000 strong for its annual parade yesterday afternoon, and after a march of nearly ten miles through sweltering streets and beneath a broiling sun, it was reviewed by the Mayor and the Police Commissioners, backed by nearly all the heads of the various municipal departments.

The will of Sam T. Jack, actor and theatrical manager, was filed for probate yesterday in the office of the Surrogate. His estate is valued at $75,000. The testator leaves one-third of his property to his wife, Emma, and one-third to his brother, James C. Jack, and divides the remaining one-third between his father, William S. Jack, his mother, his sister, and several nephews and nieces.

The feature of the June meeting of the Chamber of Commerce yesterday, at which Morris K. Jesup presided, was an address on America's interests in the Far East by John Barrett, ex-United States Minister to Siam.
Schrag Richtberg, in conjunction with George W. Mercer, have sold for Gertrude Leslie to William C. Strange the four-story brownstone-front dwelling 42 West Twentieth Street, 25 by 92.

ST. JOHN'S, N.F., June 1. -- The Danish steamer Orion, Capt. Callesen, from New York May 27 for Copenhagen, carrying a general cargo of flour, pork, poultry, and grain, with a crew of forty-five men, besides twenty shipwrecked seamen going as passengers by her, went ashore this morning at daybreak at Fresh Water Point, seven miles west of Cape Raye, and became a total wreck.

Three persons were injured at a fire yesterday morning in the dyeing and cleaning establishment of Ernest Sheer at 433 Third Avenue, a three-story brick building. The fire started from an explosion of naphtha and $4,000 damage was done.

Frederick Haken, ten years old, of 265 Clinton Avenue, West Hoboken, was instantly killed yesterday by the accidental discharge of a rifle. He and Frank Corbett, nine years old, and George De Miller, seven years old, were playing soldiers in the carpenter shop of William Kolbing, who is De Miller's grandfather, and were using a rifle which they had found standing in a corner.

WASHINGTON, June 1. -- The new Spanish Minister, Duke d'Arcos, called at the State Department at 2:45 this afternoon to pay his respects to Secretary Hay and to make arrangements for his presentation to President McKinley. The Minister went alone, the French Ambassador having arranged for the visit.

KIEL, June 1. -- The German warship, built to replace the iron-clad Kaiser Wilhelm, was launched to-day in the presence of Emperor William, who named her Kaiser Wilhelm der Crosse. The Grand Duchess of Baden performed the christening.

The salvation of the trade of the United States from the stifling effect of high tariffs has been the fact that within the Union trade was absolutely free. Apparently the Administration is determined that our new possession in the Antilles, Puerto Rico, shall suffer all the evils of protection with none of the relief to be got from trade with the United States.
SYRACUSE, June 1. -- Prof. Frank J. House, who from 1892 until last Spring was Principal of the High School in Fayetteville, committed suicide last night by hanging himself in an old lime mill.

Mr. Karl Blind writes from Hampstead under Thursday's date: "In the appreciative biographical notice concerning Dr. Eduard Simson, the fact of his Jewish origin has not been mentioned. The days of his political activity were, fortunately, days when no man of intellectual value would have disgraced himself by taking part in an 'anti-Semitic' movement.

Adolph Friedman, the bankrupt fire wrecker, who had fire sales stores at 8 East Fourteenth Street and on Eighth Avenue, near Twenty-fourth Street, has been ordered by Referee in Bankruptcy George C. Holt to pay to the trustee elected by his creditors $31,587.

CHICAGO, June 1. -- The Board of Assessors put the total of the assessed valuation of real and personal property in Cook County at about one billion dollars. This is due to the new system of assessment carried on by the Board of Review. President Upham of the board says that the personal property will foot up $500,000,000 and the real state as much more.

Yesterday being the 1st of June was one of weddings. There were quite a number in town, and a few in the suburbs, accounts of which will be given in another column. The "exodus," as it is called, from town continues, and the extreme heat drove many people away from the city. Fifth Avenue at last shows a Summer abandonment.
PARIS, June 1. -- Marchand is here. There is great enthusiasm, but no noisy demonstrations. A few flags have been unfurled in his honor. Every one he sees is favorably impressed by him.

WASHINGTON, June 2. -- The Cabinet, at its meeting to-day, decided that there was no present necessity for the enlistment of volunteers. The situation was gone over at the Cabinet meeting very fully before this conclusion was reached. The President stands ready at any time it may appear necessary to authorize the enlistment of volunteers, should more men be deemed necessary, although hoping that such a contingency may not arise.

PARIS, June 3. -- The Echo De Paris announces this morning that the Court of Cassation has virtually finished its labors in connection with Dreyfus revision. It says that at yesterday's sitting, after three hours' deliberation, only six Councillors had given their opinions; whereupon the President of the court, desiring to shorten proceedings which threatened to be interminable, proposed a vote by "yes" or "no" on important questions.

CHICAGO, June 2. -- Congressman A.J. Hopkins this afternoon withdrew from the National Speakership contest in favor of Col. D.B. Henderson of Iowa. Nine of the fourteen Republican Congressmen in the Illinois delegation were present at a meeting held in the Grand Pacific Hotel this afternoon.

LONDON, June 2. -- At the fourth day of the Epsom Summer meeting to-day Mr. H. Hardy's four-year-old bay filly Queen of Song, ridden by Tod Sloan, won the Walton Plate. Six horses ran; five furlongs. The betting was 3 to 1 against Queen of Song.

Mrs. Paul L. Bayles, a young woman, attempted suicide yesterday morning by leaping from the Staten Island ferryboat Southfield, which had left the Whitehall Street Pier at 9:50 o'clock yesterday morning, opposite Bedloe's Island. " True Versus Faise Education" is the title of an essay by Mr. Henry Herzberg appearing in the February issue of The Coming Age. Mr. Herzberg makes a strong appeal to a degenerate people for pure morals and a higher life. He tells in a scholarly and lucid style of the decay of man's spiritual and physical condition, ascribing a false educational system as the cause.

WASHINGTON, June 2. -- The news of the cession by Spain of the Ladrones, Carolines, and Palaos in the Pacific Ocean to Germany does not seem to create surprise among State Department officers. A prominent officer, who would not be quoted, said that there had been some prospect that such a cession would be made, and he had not heard that any objection would be offered by the Government of the United States.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 2. -- The strong room of the Oceanic Steamship Company's steamer Alameda, which arrived to-day from Australia and Honolulu, was robbed on the voyage, $25,000 in gold being, missing. While the Alameda was at Sydney thirty boxes, containing 150,000 English sovereigns, were put in the treasure room of the vessel, consigned to San Francisco. In each box were 5,000 sovereigns, and each was duly sealed and labeled.

OMAHA, May 30. -- By the ficklenes of the Missouri River a square mile of Nebraska adjacent to Omaha has this Spring been dumped over on the Iowa side. By a similar change in the current years ago it gave a slice of Iowa to Nebraska, and this tract has been decided by the courts to belong to Iowa still, although it is now a part of Omaha, and is covered with houses.

Police Capt. Braun of the Madison Street Station and 100 policemen had their hands full in trying to keep the immense gathering in order.

The Hartford is to be used exclusively as a training ship for recruits, and will be the first vessel in the navy to be devoted to such a purpose.

EASTON, Penn., June 3. -- Parker H. Titus was to-day arrested by a Constable on a charge of conspiracy to bribe. He gave bail in the sum of $800 for his appearance before the Dauphin County Court on June 12. Titus is the man who is said to have attempted to bribe Representative Hill to vote for Quay for United States Senator.

Many are the explanations and good the stories told regarding the origin of the famous Indian kettles or potholes that abound along the shores of Lake George, N.Y. However, there can be no doubt that nature is directly responsible for their creation. Scientists say that they were formed by the constant twirling around of small stones that were held captive in the eddies of the water that once covered these shores during the glacial period.

LONDON, June 3. -- United States Ambassador Joseph H. Choate, at the conference which he had with the Marquis of Salisbury at the Foreign Office yesterday, submitted dispatches from the officials at Washington, who have considered the points raised by the Canadians in the Alaska boundary dispute.

WASHINGTON, June 1. -- Consul Mahin of Reichenberg, in a report to the State Department under date of April 21, 1899, quotes an account in a local newspaper of a process for making artificial cotton from the wood of the fir tree.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, June 3. -- Advices from the Island of Montserrat, one of the British West Indies, report that forty-five earthquakes occurred in a period of five hours on May 17, and that these were followed by frequent isolated shocks.

Time brings us each year a most important astronomical event in which all are interested, and that is the arrival of the sun at the most northerly point in its career, or the Summer solstice, as it is called. It reaches that point just before the 21st day of the month arrives from an astronomical point of view.

THE HAGUE, June 3. -- The Drafting Committee of the Peace Conference to-day held an important meeting, at which M. de Staal, head of the Russian delegation; Sir Julian Pauncefote, chief of the British delegation, and Count Higra, chief of the Italian delegation, were present.

Miss Susan De Forest Day yesterday gave the second and last of two receptions on board her yacht Scythian, anchored off Whitestone Landing. The white vessel glistened in the sunlight, and, fanned by soft breezes, was an inviting spot to the many guests present, who had left behind them the heat of the city.

BERLIN, May 20. -- Potsdam was en fete on Saturday to welcome the imperial pair on their return from Wiesbaden. After the round of festivities in the Hessian oasis their Majesties are glad to get back for a short time to the Potsdam New Palace, the only castle out of the fifty he owns in which the Emperor feels really at home.

LONDON, June 3. -- Senator Wolcott of Colorado is staying at Claridge's Hotel, on his way to Carlsbad. In conversation with a reporter the Senator grew enthusiastic on the subject of the growing prosperity in the United States and the rapid increase in the exportation of American manufactures, and predicted the triumphant re-election of President McKinley by an increased majority.

LONDON, June 3. -- Those who have been working in favor of Mrs. Florence Maybrick will not be surprised at her release at any moment, now that United States Ambassador Joseph H. Choate has had two interviews on the subject with the Marquis of Salisbury, at which his strong representation of the American view of the matter met with a most promising reception.

BRISTOL, R.I., June 3. -- The delay occasioned in adjusting the stern piece on the Columbia has caused the other work to lag somewhat. At best it is a slow job, fitting the stern piece and putting it in place. Its elliptical shape and slightly curving outline consumed a deal of time in getting the exact fit.

THE STATEMENT OF PANIZZARDI. -- It was reported on Friday from Rome that Lieut. Col. Panizzardi, who was Military Attache of the Italian Embassy in Paris at the time Dreyfus was convicted, had made a statements to the correspondent of The London Daily Mall in which he said that he always know that Esterhazy wrote the bordereau.
"No small thing has made me as happy for a long time," said the woman, "as those transfers from the elevated to the surface cars and vice versa."

Shifting light winds interspersed with calms marked the twenty-fifth annual regatta yesterday of the Knickerbocker Yacht Club, off College Point. This was particularly disappointing because of the interest aroused by the entry of a large number of the best boats that have raced this season and the prospect of seeing them together.

AUSTIN, Texas, June 3. -- One of the most horrible murders known in the criminal annals of Texas was committed about 8 o'clock last night near Manor, this county, the victims being G.W. Engburg and his wife, a well-to-do young couple who resided on a farm there. The crime was discovered at an early hour this morning, when the two bodies were found lying in the bedroom of their home.

WASHINGTON, June 3. -- Many post-convention opinions are heard here, particularly from Ohio men, to account for the change that appeared to overcome the Columbus convention between Thursday night and Friday morning. Every prophet inspired by Foraker seems to have received a disparaging blow, and Hanna's admirers do not know whether to crow or to weep.
A careful study of the new Franchise Tax act of this State leaves no apparent escape from the conclusion that its unconstitutional provisions render the entire act absolutely void.

HAVERSTRAW, N.Y., June 3. -- When George Beauregard Barrow, alias J.J. McNally, alias James Wilson, alias Mark Beauregard, was informed in his cell to-day of the arrest of Bella Anderson, he maintained the same silence he has kept ever since his arrest, simply saying, "I have nothing to say." Not even a change of expression could be noticed.

The Council of the General Federation of Women's Clubs met in Philadelphia last week and discussed the reorganization of that body. The Worcester Woman's Club has taken the initiative, asking that the delegates to the Federation be representatives only of State Federations, and not of individual clubs, so large a number making the organization unwieldy.

There has been every indication of Summer in the real estate market of the last week. Some of the more optimistic point to the interruption caused by Tuesday's holiday and express the hope that active dealing has not been suspended until the Fall. There are doubtless many who would gladly share this hope if there had been anything in the reports of the last few days to justify it.

PARIS, June 3. -- Col. Du Paty de Clam is confined in the cell where he tortured Dreyfus. He showed himself a torturing inquisitor, bereft of conscience. What an awful awakening there must now be of the hidden monitor! Nemesis has been less halting than usual in overtaking him. I am told that he was preparing to escape to Belgium when he was arrested.

Henry Meyer had his picture taken for the Rogues' Gallery at Police Headquarters yesterday. He was arrested at 48 Avenue A by Detectives O'Neill and Aikman of the Leonard Street Station on the charge of grand larceny. The complainant is Franklin J. Minek, a merchant of 204 Duane Street, for whom Meyer had been bookkeeper for nearly three years.

The D'Artagnan referred to on Page 5 of the last issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES ILLUSTRATED MAGAZINE, to whom the house in the Rue de Richelieu was transferred in 1689, cannot possibly be the D'Artagnan of Dumas, for the simple reason that the latter, according to Saint-Simon, (Tome VII., Page 110, Edition Hackette,) was killed before Maestricht in 1673!

WASHINGTON, June 3. -- The War Department has received a lengthy report front Gen. Wood at Santiago, in which he says that he has just returned from a long trip through the interior and along the north coast of Santiago Province. This, with the preceding trip, completed about ten days ago, has included every town of importance in the province, as well as most of the smaller ones.

NEWPORT, June 3. -- This evening Gordon McKay gave a dinner at his cottage at Ochre Point in honor of Admiral Sampson. The table was ornamented with American Beauty roses and small American flags. The guests included Admiral Sampson, Capt. Chadwick, Flag Lieut. Staunton, Dr. T.A. Kenefick, Mrs. George A. Converse, the Misses Converse, Miss Bennet, the Misses Yardley, and Charles H. Roberts.

LONDON, June 3. -- The sensational collapse at the Derby on Wednesday of the French horse Holocauste, whose death represented a loss of $30,000 to his owner, was an intense disappointment to the large French contingent which came over to see what was confidently predicted to be a victory for their representative.

Speaker REED made an exhibition of that Mephistophelean humor of which he possesses so large a share in making his list of appointments to the Board of Visitors at West Point. For he named as a member of the board Mr. MARSH of Illinois. One would suppose that it would be particularly unpleasant for that statesman to visit the Military Academy just now, except under the protection of a strict incognito.

When the treaty of Paris was concluded between the United States and Spain, the latter ceded to the former the Philippine Islands and the Island of Guam, the largest of the group known as the Ladrones, or the Marianne Islands. With that treaty the interest of the United States in the Spanish possessions in the Pacific or elsewhere was determined and disposed of.

PARIS, June 3. -- The Court of Cassation revises the Dreyfus case and orders a new trial before a court-martial at Rennes. Every one expected this decision; still it caused a hush of astonishment. It was received in court with jubilant cries of "Vive la Justice!" The Jewish world rejoiced at the Saturday afternoon services in the synagogues.

SING SING, June 3. -- Squadron A to-day rode the twenty-one miles from Van Cortlandt Park to camp here in six hours, making three stops. Much of the distance was ridden between lanes of people who gathered at the sides of the roads and greeted and applauded Gov. Roosevelt and the cavalrymen.

LONDON, June 3. -- Play in the International Chess Tournament was resumed at St. Stephen's Hall, Westminster, in the City, to-day, when the fourth round was begun according to No. 1 of the Berger schedule. The players therefore met as follows: Janowski vs. Schlechter, Pillsbury vs. Cohn, Maroczy vs. Bird, Teichmann vs. Tinsley, Steinitz vs. Tschigorin, Lasker vs. Blackburne, Showalter vs. Lee, and Mason a bye.

NOTWITHSTANDING the number of amateurs who dabble in photography, despite the magazines devoted to what the Germans call "light printing," the public is very far from realizing that there is as great a difference among photographers with regard to the quality of their productions as among painters.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 3. -- The Pacific Coast export lumber manufacturers have consummated arrangements which will make the price of shipbuilding material much higher from now on than it has been for a long time past. The combination is composed of all of the Pacific lumber mill companies in British Columbia, Washington, and Oregon, controlling the entire output of pine on the coast.

LONDON, June 3. -- It is not precisely a dignified or an impressive fact, but it is a fact nevertheless, that British domestic politics at this moment centre round the Mahdi's disinterred corpse. Any hope that Morley would abandon his intention of moving to refuse assent to the Queen's message proposing a grant of 30,000 to Kitchener disappeared when Rosebery selected this intention for denunciation in his last speech.

The chief difficulty under which the Democratic Party at the Presidential election of next year must labor will be to frame a platform on which its discordant elements may be united. A majority being opposed to trusts and high tariff, it is expected that the real and imaginary evils which are attributed to them will be exhibited to public opprobrium.

The new Darroch propellers which were put on George W. Quintard's screw yacht Saranac have had a trial, with gratifying results. These screws have been described in this column. The trial took place Memorial Day, and Capt. Belmont reports that they gave the craft an additional speed of one and one-eighth miles an hour.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., June 3. -- Admiral Dewey soon after his return from Manila will visit Morristown as the guest of Lieut. Commander Henry W. Miller, retired, President of the Morris County Savings Bank. Lieut. Commander Miller has received a letter from Admiral Dewey, dated on board the flagship Olympia April 25, announcing his intention of visiting Morristown.

The tyranny of caste in certain parts of India seems to be still unbroken, though there are not wanting signs that there will soon be a general revolt on the part of the educated classes against its exactions. Quite recently a certain Indian gentleman, who had received his early education in London, came from the interior to Bombay and was entertained by an old English friend there.

NEILA VAN BRUNT can lay claim to the proud distinction of being the youngest golf player, probably, in America. At any rate, there is no doubt that she is the youngest devotee of the links in this part of the country.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., June 3. -- The Rev. Dr. W.H.P. Faunce of New York has been elected President of Brown University. The name of Dr. Faunce was reported by a special nominating committee, and his election was unanimous, twenty-one of the forty-five members of the corporation being present.

Fierce contests are just now waging in Wall Street. Not in a long while has there been such fighting. The market isn't broad, but back of such transactions as make up fair daily aggregates much vehemence shows.

PARIS, June 3. -- The Court of Cassation to-day rendered a decision in favor of a revision of the Dreyfus case and ordering a new court-martial, to sit at Rennes, sixty miles from Nantes, for the trial of the prisoner.

A Spinoza museum has been opened in the house where the famous Hebrew philosopher lived and polished lenses for his bread at Rhynsburg, near Leyden. The house has been restored in the seventeenth century style.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 3. -- Yale defeated the Princeton baseball nine by the score of 8 to 0 in the first championship game of the series. Fully 5,000 spectators witnessed the game, many being Yale and Princeton graduates and friends from neighboring cities. The delegation of Princeton rooters, however, was surprisingly small.

Your "German-American" correspondent in THE TIMES of this morning appears to be ignorant of the fact that the original poem entitled "The Luck of Eden-Hall" is the work of neither Uhland nor Longfellow, but is a composition of J.H. Wiffen of London, a member of the Society of Friends, whose first work was published in 1812.

Edouard Remenyi, the Hungarian violinist, was known all over the world. His strongly marked individuality and his vigorous expression of unique opinions led many to suppose that the tenor of his daily thought ran toward eccentricity. There may have been grounds for the belief, but there is reason to think that Remenyi's musical faith was founded on a firm basis.

WASHINGTON, June 3. -- About all the Republicans here have come to the conclusion, owing to some events that have occurred within a week, that Gen. David B. Henderson of Iowa will easily win the Speakership fight. That the West would have the Speaker in the Fifty-sixth Congress was apparent from the first, if only the West should decide it to be desirable and politic.

FREEHOLD, N.J., June 3. -- The contract has been awarded for the foundation of the monument to mark the site, near this place, of the Old Scots' Meeting House, the First Presbyterian Church in America. The monument is to be ready for unveiling in the third week in October, when the New Jersey Synod will meet at Asbury Park.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 3. -- Several years ago Commodore Gerry purchased the estate where his villa, Seaverge, stands. It has been so much improved that few would recognize the place as the same which the Commodore purchased.
CHICAGO, June 3. -- Congressman Henderson of Iowa came in to-day and had a long conference at the Grand Pacific Hotel with Congressman Hopkins on the Speakership question.

Bella Anderson, or Carrie Jones, the young woman who kidnapped Baby Marion Clarke two weeks ago to-day, is behind the bars in the Union County Jail, in Elizabeth, N.J., and the case, which has stirred the community as no other has since the kidnapping of Charlie Ross twenty-five years ago, has been cleared up, if the confession of the Anderson girl is to be believed.

A MAN who in the afternoon of life deliberately retires from active business, with a sound body, un-impaired vigor of mind, and a fortune of considerably more than $1,50,000,000, with the avowed intention of devoting himself to philanthropic pursuits, possesses, it must be conceded, extraordinary qualities.

Patrolman O'Brien of the Madison Street Station has been trying to solve the push- cart question, and in order to bring the matter before the public arrested one of about two hundred peddlers in Division Street and arraigned him before Magistrate Flammer in the Essex Market Court yesterday. O'Brien started in by making a long statement that it was impossible to enforce the existing ordinances.

WASHINGTON, June 3. -- The Navy Department has made public a report from Admiral Dewey recommending the advancement of Ensign Cleland Davis ten numbers above his present rank for strikingly gallant services rendered in connection with Gen. MacArthur's division in the engagement ashore near Malolos and Caloocan.

ST. PETERSBURG, May 21. -- The proposition just made by the Russian Government to abolish the Siberian convict system is but another, and certainly not the least important, step toward the complete transformation of Siberia from its present condition to one of the most prosperous districts of the empire.

An examination of the latest statement of the condition of the Treasury shows that it is highly probable that the expenditures for pensions during the fiscal year will be slightly less than the appropriation made for that purpose by Congress. On May 31 they had reached $129,018,043.

WASHINGTON, June 3. -- The French Ambassador, M. Cambon, called on Secretary Hay to-day and formally surrendered the representation of Spanish interests, which he has conducted for some time. This step followed the presentation of the Duke of Arcos as Spanish Minister, and the assumption by him of the duties thus far performed by the Ambassador.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., June 3. -- The Washtenaw Evening Times printed a statement to-night as follows: "There are three members of the Board of Regents who stand ready to promote President Angell's resignation, and there are others on the board who will accept it if it is tendered."

WASHINGTON, June 3. -- The decision in the Dreyfus case excited much interest in official and diplomatic quarters, particularly at the French Embassy, and the disposition was to accept the conclusions of the court as final and for the best interest of all concerned.

Announcement was made yesterday that the publishing houses of Harper Brothers and the S.S. McClure Company had formed an alliance entailing changes in the personnel of both concerns. The effect of this coalition, it was said by members of both firms, would be the realizing of specific publication plans.

Sydney William Garrett, late Gunner's Mate, United States Navy, who served the big guns in the after turret of the battleship Indiana in the fight with Cervera's fleet, will be buried from the old John Street Methodist Episcopal Church, in this city, under the auspices of the Farragut Association of Naval Veterans, Port of New York, this afternoon at 2 o'clock.
A man running rapidly and followed by hundreds of persons who were yelling "Stop thief!" created excitement in Broadway, between Twenty-sixth and Thirtieth Streets, last evening.

The proceedings of the Mazet committee the other day seem to have been enlivened by a remarkable exhibition on the part of Dr. O'SULLIVAN and subsequently dulled by his absence. It will be agreed that the license of a lawyer in insulting witnesses and third parties must be very gross indeed in order to attract any attention whatever.

James A. Tyng, L. H. Graham, and Charles F. Watson were the victors yesterday in the chief events of the closing contests of the Baltusrol Club's open golf tournament at Short Hills, N. J. Tyng, who won the cup for the lowest score on the first day, and who within a week has won the amateur championships of both the Baltusrol and Morris County Clubs.

WASHINGTON, June 3. -- There is no change to-day in the attitude of the Department of State and the Administration concerning the cession by Spain to Germany of the Carolines, Marianna, and Pelew Islands. No regret is expressed anywhere, except in the Navy Department, because the United States, in securing other Spanish possessions in the Pacific, did not ask for these as well as the Philippines and the Sulus.

WASHINGTON, May 27. -- The ingenuity displayed by some people in reaching bizarre and unique interpretations of apparently simple statements is marvelous at times. An instance occurred recently that astounded even the hardened clerks in one of the departments that has many peculiar persons as correspondents. A request came to this department for one of its publications.

WASHINGTON, June 4. -- Acting Secretary of War Meikeljohn has received from Havana a general statement of articles of merchandise imported into that port during the month of February, 1899, showing the countries from which the importations were made. Other reports of a similar nature are expected to be filed with the Secretary of War covering other ports in the Island of Cuba.

The Police Board's new rules regulating the doings of Coney Island's numerous and diverse places of amusement seem to he peculiarly elastic in their nature and susceptible of a different interpretation each Sunday. This was patent to the hundred thousand or more people who journeyed to the island yesterday.

I am not a man of religious extremes. I have read with wonder the trial before what the Archbishop of Canterbury says is not a court in respect to incense, for I cannot understand why any one should either insist on incense being used during a religious service or why he should object to its use.

WASHINGTON, June 4. -- The coal production and consumption of the world during the past fifteen years are presented in some tables just prepared by the Treasury Bureau of Statistics. These show that while the United Kingdom is still the largest coal producer of the world, the United States is a close second, and if the present rate of gain is continued, will soon become the leading coal producing country of the world.

The women lawyers of New York City and vicinity met on Saturday afternoon for the first time. They met at the invitation of Miss Mary G. Potter of the New York Bar, Miss Mary Philbrook of the New Jersey Bar, and Dr. Mary D. Hussey of the class of 1898 of the "New York University Law School at the residence of Dr. Hussey an Arlington Avenue, East Orange.

BOSTON, June 4. -- The men who identified "Mrs. S.A. Brown," the suicide of the Metropolitan Hotel, in New York, to-day reached Boston to-night with the body. One of them is a man who called at Police Headquarters here yesterday, and told the officer in charge that he knew the woman. The name which he gave in New York was, he said, an assumed one.

Passengers on trains coming from the South and West, voyagers upon lake boats, and residents in all sections of the city whose homes are upon elevations have noticed from time to time in the past few months that a vast iron and steel dome has gradually risen among the many church spires of Milwaukee.

TOPEKA, June 3. -- A suggestion as to the adaptability of Kansas for wool production is afforded by well-attested records of some of its flocks, which are easily accessible, says Secretary F.D. Coburn of the Kansas Department of Agriculture in the board's recent quarterly report devoted to "The Modern Sheep."

According to officers of the Fifth Brigade they have the same grounds of complaint against Division Headquarters for interference with brigade matters as has Gen. McCoskry Butt of the First Brigade. It is understood that Gen. George Moore Smith, who commands the Fifth Brigade, may also go to Albany in order to straighten matters out.

PARIS, June 4. -- Emile Zola, who has returned to Paris, has written asking the Public Prosecutor to send to his residence a notification of the sentence which the Versailles Court passed upon him in the libel action growing out of the charges which he brought against the officers who conducted the Esterhazy court martial.

POUGHKEEPSIE, June 4. -- The Columbia 'Varsity and freshman crews rested in their quarters to-day. There was no rowing, and the boathouse was deserted. In the morning the oarsmen attended service at Christ Episcopal Church having been specially invited by the rector, the Rev. S.A. Weikert.

In the Field Before Calumpit, via Manila, April 25. -- This is the story of the Twentieth Kansas and how that regiment charged an intrenchment filled with Filipinos, got across the Quingua River, and drove the insurgents back to the next stronghold. It is not the first nor the second time the Kansas boys have got what they went for, and they went in like veterans.

LONDON, June 4. -- A dull week with a lot doing is a fair description of the current markets. The Stock Exchange settlement passed with ease, and money is plentiful at moderate rates, except on Kafirs and Kangaroos, and there 10 to 20 per cent. does not seem to count for much. The average rates elsewhere are from 4 to 5 per cent.

UTICA, June 4. -- Congressman James S. Sherman left to-night for New York, to be gone all the week. He expects to be in the city all the time except Tuesday, when he will be in Washington. Referring to the Speakership contest, Mr. Sherman said to a reporter: "I am still a candidate, and shall continue to be unless n majority of the New York delegation at its meeting Tuesday declares for some one else."

Evidence accumulates that calamity in its most appalling form has descended upon the calamity howlers and is pursuing its ravages unchecked among them. We called attention the other day to Mr. O.H.P. BELMONT'S remark about the burdens that now overwhelm the country, and enumerated some of them -- great business activity, large bank clearings, high wages and plenty of work, increasing railroad earnings, and prosperity, insolent and ruthless, stalking through the land.

It is authoritatively announced, according to Yachting, that W.G. Jameson acted in behalf of the Prince of Wales in buying the Britannia before the recently intended sale. The famous cutter will therefore again be seen under the royal colors, which she carried with such remarkable success for five successive seasons.
The Poet Laureate's "madrigal" for the Queen's Birthday is distracting to the students of literary texts.

NEWPORT, June 4. -- There are various rumors as to who is to occupy Mr. and Mrs. W.K. Vanderbilt's villa, Rough Point. It is believed that either Mr. and Mrs. W.K. Vanderbilt, Jr., or Mr. and Mrs. George Vanderbilt will make use of it.

The funeral of ex-Quarantine Commissioner Jacob M Patterson, who died on Wednesday, took place from his late residence on High Bridge Road, near Morris Avenue, at noon yesterday. The modest house was too small to hold the large number that attended. People gathered on the lawn around the house, and many followed the remains to Greenwood Cemetery, where the burial took place.

PEEKSKILL, June 4. -- Peekskill's trolley line to the "short ferry" to the State camp was completed this afternoon. It will probably increase the attendance at the camp largely, making access easier and cheaper. One car began to run as soon as the last rails were down, and a sort of general jubilee was held.

Three startling events in the industrial world have followed each other in rapid succession. These taken separately are sufficiently sensational to awaken the British manufacturer and workman by showing that our trade is quickly vanishing.

MANILA, May 2. -- Americans engaged in legitimate business have addressed a joint letter to the Chamber of Commerce of San Francisco, begging that body to use its influence with the Executive at Washington looking to a reduction of the prohibitive customs duties. The Spanish customs rates are still exacted.

MANILA, June 4. -- Gen. Hall's column, in the movement upon the Morong Peninsula, completed a circuit of twenty miles over rough and mountainous country, having two engagements with the insurgents, one of them severe, and keeping up an almost constant fire against scattered bands of rebels for nearly twenty-four hours from 4 o'clock Saturday morning, when the column left the pumping station.

Fast ball was played by the New Yorks at Weehawken yesterday; they vanquished the Louisvilles with the greatest of ease. Nothing that came anywhere near any of them "got away." Gleason's fielding was notably swift and accurate.
