NEWPORT, June 4. -- The Defender lay at anchor near Fort Adams throughout the day, and all work was suspended save that which was absolutely necessary. W. Butler Duncan, who is in charge of the yacht, and Royal Phelps Carroll were on board for some time. To-morrow the first of the tuning-up trials will begin.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 4. -- The little schooner-rigged boat Coke, about thirty feet long and five tens measurement, sailed for Manila to-day. Capt. Freitche, the sole occupant of the vessel, proposes to make a tour of the world in the frail cockleshell. He claims to have crossed the Atlantic in a vessel of even smaller dimensions.

MANILA, June 4. -- The position of the American troops to-night indicates that they will to-morrow sweep the peninsula of Morong, the land projecting to the south into Laguna de Bay, where the insurgents are supposed to have a large force, near the town of Morong, as well as the battery on the western shore of the peninsula which recently smashed the propeller of the gun-boat Napidan.

PEEKSKILL, June 4. -- Squadron A rode into camp at 12:20 to-day after a journey from Sing Sing, of which the most notable incident was the reception at the town of Peekskill, in which practically the entire population participated.
The motor cycle was on its trial at the Crystal Palace yesterday, and it came out of the test with flying colors. The ordinary leg-propelled bicycle records were left hopelessly behind.

There was a lively breeze blowing in from the Harlem River over the Speedway yesterday that was welcomed by the large crowd of drivers, who would otherwise have sweltered under the sun. The horses, too, seemed grateful for the cool wave that swept over the river, for the fast ones among them without exception were in excellent fettle, and were ready to take up a brush at the word of command.

The Fire Department demonstrated its ability to fight fire from the roof and upper stories of tall buildings by a standpipe test in the St. Paul Building, Ann Street and Broadway, yesterday morning. The test which was conducted under the supervision of Acting Fire Chief Croker, began at 9 A.M., and consisted of two experiments.

HAVANA, June 4. -- According to a dispatch from Guines, Col. George M. Randall, who, with the pay car and his escort, arrived there yesterday to continue the payment of the Cuban troops, slipped on a piece of banana peel to-day and broke a tendon of his left leg. Though in great pain, he declines to give up the work he has in hand, and was in attendance all day at the disbursement office.

I wish that I might do more than idly indorse the Coney Island Park plan of Mr. Coler. It is a scheme the unfeasibility of which seems its only obstacle, but let this obstacle be removed, and who shall say that a Coney Island Park, with green shade trees and rambles and dells and lawns, together with that sublimest of ozone breezes, is a delight not worth the paying and working for?
The editor of The North American Review has accorded space to W.J. BRYAN to present in the June issue of that periodical his interpretation of the political principles of THOMAS JEFFERSON.

PARIS, June 4. -- The Cabinet Council this morning decided that the French second-class cruiser Sfax, now at Fort de France, Martinique, should proceed immediately and bring Dreyfus from the Isle of Devils to France. The cruiser is expected to arrive at Brest about June 26, when Dreyfus will be handed to the military authorities, and lodged in the military prison at Rennes.

Mrs. Johanna Schilling, thirty-five years old, and her two daughters -- Gertrude, ten years old, and Edna, eight years old -- were found dead yesterday afternoon in their home, in the tenement at 305 East Eighty-fourth Street. All had been asphyxiated by gas. From letters left by Mrs. Schilling there is no doubt that the woman murdered her children and committed suicide.

The members of the Fairfield County Golf Club, at Greenwich, Conn., began Saturday the first of three competitions for the President's Cup, given by George W. Hubble. It is a handicap match play contest against the bogie score. The second match will be played next Saturday, and the final one on July 1. The third competition for the Queen's Jubilee Cup will be on June 24.

CITY OF MEXICO, June 4. -- The news of the conversion of Mexico's 6 per cent. gold debt in Europe on the new basis of 5 per cent. excited much attention here. When all the details of the arrangement are made known by the finance department of this Government it will be seen that the arrangement is even more favorable to the Government than at first appears.

The general tone of the dry goods market as a whole still continues to show improvement. The manufacturing clothier is beginning to do business in earnest, and has during the week placed a number of good duplicate orders for Fall weights. As conditions now are, any business done by the clothier must almost immediately be reflected to the primary market, and the next few weeks will develop without doubt an excellent amount of trading.

George Dunn, twenty-six years old, of 19 Fourth Avenue, Brooklyn, was arrested yesterday morning for intoxication and taken to the lower Fulton Street Station. When he was arraigned at the desk Sergt. Donnelly noticed that his head was cut, and asked him what was the matter. He said that he had got into a row with a waiter in George Dedge's restaurant at 161 Washington Street, and that the latter had struck him.

For two years we have exported no gold to London. During those two years we might have imported gold. Europe owed us a great deal of money. Our heavy exports of merchandise and foodstuffs had given us a large credit balance over there. As the money was earning something there and the interest rate remained low here we allowed it to stay there instead of importing it in the form of gold.

PARIS, June 4. -- It was a premeditated riot that took place to-day on the weighing ground of the Auteuil race course. The object of the rioters was to insult President Loubet, and perhaps in the heat of faction and fight to get rid of him.

PARIS, June 4. -- President Loubet, accompanied by the Premier, M. Dupuy, and the Chief of the Military Household, Gen. M.C. Bailloud, drove to the Auteuil races this afternoon, closely followed by Mme. Loubet in a second landau. As they drove along the Avenue des Champs Elysees, the crowd bowed respectfully, but on arriving at Auteuil, they were met by a violent demonstration, evidently organized, and directed against the President.

The shipment of $1,000,000 gold to Europe by the National City Bank on Saturday has put Wall Street on the alert and has started a general discussion as to the exchange and money market position. None of the foreign houses seems to be able to figure out just why the National City Bank exported its gold.

The declarations made in the Ohio Republican State Convention as to the President's civil service order suggest to The Tribune some reflections as to the motive for the order and as to how it will work. They are sensible and pertinent. The Tribune says:

In The North American Review for June, Mr. LYMAN J. GAGE, Secretary of the Treasury, has a very remarkable article, which we urge every business man who cares to look beyond the events of the week to read and study.

While investigating the history of tea, an English writer came across a rare manuscript in the British Museum giving a quaint summary of the virtues of the herb called tea or chee. It was dated Oct. 20, 1686, and purported to be a translation from the Chinese, as follows:

When did Texas first become a part of the territory of the United States? Probably almost every reader of The Pioneer Press will answer: "At the time when the Independent Republic of Texas was annexed to the United States, just prior to the Mexican war." But this reply would be wholly inaccurate.

CHICAGO, June 4. -- Rear Admiral Schley left for New York this afternoon, accompanied by Mrs. Schley. The last public function in the programme prepared for the Admiral's entertainment in Chicago was a luncheon at the Union League at noon to-day. In the course of the speech he made the Admiral spoke in complimentary terms of the Administration's conduct of the war.

The woman who committed suicide at the Metropolitan Hotel by taking poison on Thursday last has been identified as Miss Lizzie S. Holt of Boston. She was, it is alleged, a member of a well-to-do family, and was herself the owner of some valuable oil stocks and much handsome jewelry. She had been despondent and melancholy for two years, it is said, though for what reason her family did not know.
HAVANA, June 4. -- Gen. Collazo publishes in The Herald of Havana a letter expounding the Cuban idea of the situation. He says, in part:

The Republicans of the House appear to be resolved to offer the Speakership on a golden salver to DAVID B. HENDERSON of Iowa. He has been getting pledges of votes while the other candidates thought they were thinking about getting them, and now he announces that more than a majority of the Republican members have pledged him their support.

Polo of the most exciting sort was seen yesterday on the grounds of the Country Club of Westchester, when the first and second teams of the Philadelphia Country Club engaged in the final contest for the Country Club Cups. The second team won by the narrow margin of one goal, the score standing nine goals for the second team and eight for the first Philadelphia team.

We called attention on Sunday to the extremely uncomfortable position in which Mr. MARSH of Illinois had placed himself, supposing him to be a man of decent sensibility, by accepting an appointment as one of the official visitors to the Military Academy. It is worth pointing out, in addition, that the grievance of the regular army against him and his associates is equally the grievance of the country at large.

In the Department of Political Economy at Yale, of which Prof. HADLEY, the newly elected President of the university, has been the head, the new Socialism has obtained no foothold. They teach hard common sense in that department if we may judge from the recent utterances of one of its professors upon a question that is much discussed nowadays in this country.

LONDON, June 5. -- Augustin Daly has quite recovered from his recent sickness and has gone to Paris for a few days with Mrs. Daly and Miss Ada Rehan. He will return on June 20 for the hearing of the case against George Edwardes, resulting from a dispute regarding sharing the profits of Daly's London theatre, of which Edwardes is the owner and Daly the lessee.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, May 30. -- Recent advices from the French Island of Guadeloupe indicate the continuance of the so-called race war there, which led last month to the partial destruction of the industrial capital, Pointe-a-Pitre by fire.

At 2 o'clock this afternoon the annual assembly of the Masonic Grand Lodge of the State of New York will open in the Grand Lodge Room of the Masonic Temple at Twenty-third Street and Sixth Avenue. This assembly will bring together 745 delegates from as many lodges throughout the State, and with the addition of officers and permanent delegates, the number of Masons attending the assembly will be brought up to about 900.

THE HAGUE, June 5. -- The Arbitration Committee of the Peace Conference held a meeting to-day under the Chairmanship of M. Leon Bourgeois. Andrew D. White, head of the United States delegation, Sir Julian Pauncefote, head of the British delegation, and M. de Staal, head of the Russian delegation, with all the members of the committee, were present.

The returning trains and boats yesterday brought back to town but a proportion of the travelers who left on Saturday. In fact, there are not many representatives of society in the city just at present. Newport is beginning to fill up slowly, and the smaller resorts are all commencing to show signs of social activity.
LONDON, June 5. -- Senator Chauncey M. Depew, with his son, Chauncey M. Depew, Jr., will leave for Paris to-morrow.

The June Grand Jury convened yesterday, after having been sworn in by Judge Newburger, in Part I. of the Court of General Sessions, and immediately the jury was called upon to consider the cases of the kidnappers who on May 21 stole Baby Marion Clarke in Central Park. The result of their deliberations was the finding of an indictment early yesterday afternoon against the three principals in the plot.

I have been at some pains to collect information as to the number of casualties that have taken place latterly within two or three miles of the Manacles. One fisherman who is still in middle life recalls 36. His list, however, is incomplete, for more than 50 have happened during the past thirty years. Of these considerably more than half may he classed as total wrecks.

LONDON, June 5. -- The fifth round of the international chess tournament was begun in this city at noon to-day, when the order of play was arranged according to Round 7 of the Berger system, which read as follows: Mason vs. Lasker, Tinsley vs. Steinitz, Bird vs. Teichmann, Cohn vs. Maroczy, Schlechter vs. Pillsbury, Showalter vs. Janowski, and Lee vs. Blackburne; Tschigorin a bye.

The report of the State Society of Labor on wages, rent, and savings of workingmen makes some interesting revelations which will be surprising to many readers. Home-owners, it appears, not only make higher wages than renters, but save more money each year, the percentage of savings being in some instances astonishing.

FORT DE FRANCE, Martinique, June 5. -- The Admiral commanding the French squadron in these waters received yesterday an order to send the cruiser Sfax to take Dreyfus from Devil's Island, off the coast of French Guiana, and convey him to France. The Sfax, which is commanded by Capt. Coffinienes de Nordeck, left for Devil's Island at 10 o'clock last evening.

ELIZABETH, N.J., June 5. -- Mr. Marsh went to the county jail to-night and informed Bella Anderson that she had been indicted. She seemed a little startled at first, but quickly recovered her composure. She told Mr. Marsh she knew that Wilson had stolen three rugs from the Automobile Company.

NYACK, N.Y., June 5. -- Charles E. Le Barbier, Assistant District Attorney of New York, and Detectives Reidy, Armstrong, and Morris arrived in Nyack this evening with bench warrants for the prisoners James and Jennie Wilson, or Barrow, who were committed to the Rockland County Jail this afternoon after waiving examination at Garnerville.

An English journalist who has recently been acting on war service in the Philippines sends to a relative in this country a not unamusing account of the methods adopted by some representatives of the "yellow press" of America and their employers to make their accounts of the present operations interesting, tactics which seem to be successfully copied, indeed rather improved upon, by the Filipinos themselves.

NEWPORT, June 5. -- The automobile carriage has made its appearance in Newport. The first arrival was for Buchanan Winthrop and automobile bicycles for W. Butler Duncan and Col. Reginald Norman arrived late in the day.
PHILADELPHIA, June 5. -- Frank Thomson, President of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company, died at 7:30 o'clock this evening at his home, at Merion, a few miles out of the city.

LONDON, June 5. -- At the anniversary meeting of the Royal Geographical Society this afternoon, United States Ambassador Joseph H. Choate presented the medal awarded to Sir John Murray, who is a naturalist and chronicler of the Challenger expedition, by the American Geographical Society.

ALBANY, June 5. -- Violators of the pure food laws of the State are under investigation by the State Board of Health, which has inaugurated a crusade against adulterated food products. Its agents are now at work throughout the State collecting samples for the purpose of bringing the guilty persons to justice.

Representative James S. Sherman announced at the Manhattan Hotel last night that he was still a candidate for Speaker of the House of Representatives; that he expected to continue to be unless the delegation from this State declared against him, and that he was confident he would have the support of a majority at the meeting of the delegation to-day.
WASHINGTON, June 5. -- Gen. Otis reports the following deaths since his last weekly report:
The Pacific Surety Company of San -rancisco has applied for a license to do business in the State of Indiana.
PARIS, May 16. -- The first night of M. Marcel Schwob's translation of "Hamlet," with Mme. Sarah Bernhardt in the title role, is definitely fixed to take place on Thursday next.

The examination of John F. Baudouine, a voluntary petitioner in bankruptcy, was continued yesterday morning in the office of Theodor Aub, Referee in Bankruptcy, at 149 Broadway. Mr. Baudouine was senior member of the dissolved firm of John F. Baudouine Co., his partners being up to that time Frederick W. Scheibeler and Andrew B. Werl.

An attempt to garrote Mrs. Jullette Osborn of 238 Herkimer Street, Brooklyn, was made yesterday afternoon on Third Avenue by a man who wanted to steal the woman's pocketbook, with $13 in it. Mrs. Osborn's assailant, who was arrested, then pretended to be insane. He says he is George Brown and that he lives in Boston.

Prof. DEAN C. WORCESTER is one of the American Civil Commissioners sent to the Philippines by the President. He has just cabled to The Chicago Times-Herald a long statement regarding the stories that our army is treating the Filipinos with cruelty. In all the instances as to which he has personal knowledge these stories are false, and he believes that the others also are.

WASHINGTON, June 5. -- No definite information was obtainable to-day as to the subject of discussion during the conference at the White House late last night between the President, Acting Secretary of War Meiklejohn, and Adjutant General Corbin. The latter refuses to refer to the matter in any manner.

PARIS, June 5. -- The Chamber of Deputies met at 2 o'clock this afternoon. The public galleries were crowded with fashionable people, including many ladies in pretty toilets, who used their fans vigorously on account of the heat. The galleries of the Senators and diplomats were also full.
Controller Coler continues to receive letters congratulating him on his plan for the redemption of Coney Island by the establishment of a public park on the site of that notorious resort.

BERLIN, May 10. -- The removal and enlargement of the Emperor's Berlin stables, which are opposite the old palace, at the corner of Breite Strasse and the Schlossplatz, will cost from 7,000,000 to 8,000,000 marks. According to the plan of the architect, Herr Geheimrath Ihne, the front facing the Spree will be 200 yards in length.

The following account of how the Princess was informed that she had succeeded to the throne is taken from the "Diary of a Lady of Quality": "On June 20, 1837, William IV. died. The scene closed at 2 A.M., and in a very short time the Archbishop of Canterbury and Lord Conyngham -- the Lord Chamberlain -- set out to announce the event to their young sovereign.
WASHINGTON, June 5. -- By direction of the President, the American Colonial Bank of Puerto Rico is designated as the depository of the War Department for the Island of Puerto Rico.

WEST HAVERSTRAW, N.Y., June 5. -- The hearing of the Barrows, husband and wife, began in the picnic and pleasure grounds of Garnerville this afternoon. On the platform were the Justice and the two accused persons, the one a slight, nervous-looking woman, the other a tall, slim man, with a weak face.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 5. -- The Yale freshman baseball management has received word from the Princeton manager that it will be impossible for the latter nine to come to New Haven to play a third game to decide the baseball supremacy of the two freshman nines. Each nine has won a game.
The following, which I translate from Heinrich Duntzer's commentary to Uhland's poems, may Interest some of your readers, especially "German-American" and Mr. Arthur Gulterman:

"In considering who should be Speaker," said Congressman G.W. Smith of Illinois, "we ought to look at the matter from a policy or politic standpoint. In looking over the list of Speakers elected from the formation of the Government, you will see that Pennsylvania has had three -- Fred A. Muhlenberg, two terms; Galusha A. Grow, one term; Samuel J. Randall, two terms.

An authoritative denial has been made of the report that Archbishop Keane, so widely known and so well beloved in Washington, is to return to the United States to resume his former position as the head of the Catholic University here. It will be remembered that Bishop Keane's transfer, two or three years ago, was the cause of a great deal of controversy and dissatisfaction.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, May 30. -- The abstract question of the political possibility and the industrial and commercial desirability of the annexation of the British West Indies to the United States is nothing new. As a matter of casual discussion, at least, it has been on the cards since 1867, when Gen. Grant developed the scheme for acquiring the Danish Islands.

CHICAGO, June 5. -- The jury in the case of Baron and Baroness de Bara, charged with using the mails to conduct a fraudulent business, brought in a verdict late this afternoon finding both defendants guilty. The maximum penalty is twelve years and six months' imprisonment and a fine of $12,000. A motion for a new trial was made, and, pending the decision, sentence was deferred.

The last two weeks of the engagement of Mrs. Leslie Carter in "Zaza" was begun last evening at the Garrick Theatre, when the management, in order to celebrate the one hundred and fiftieth performance, presented to every one attending a handsome souvenir. The souvenir was in the form of a book, giving some facts concerning the actress's stage career, the story of "Zaza," and sixteen illustrations of the scenes in the play.

The congregation of Mount Olivet Baptist Church (colored) met last night in the church in West Fifty-third Street and unanimously extended a call to the Rev. Dr. C.T. Walker of Augusta. Ga., to occupy their pulpit. The church has been without a pastor since the resignation of the Rev. Dr. Wisher, whose quarrel with his people over political matters was given much publicity.

In former days a medicine was valued according to its nauseousness. Even now there are those who distrust a pleasant medicine. Yet our sense of taste is a guard and guide implanted in us to enable us to avoid that which would do us harm. What the taste approves benefits the body, what it rejects would oftentimes, if taken, impair the health, sometimes destroy the life.
An insect census has just been taken on purely scientific lines with a view to determine as far as it is possible which insects are a boon and a blessing to mankind and which are the reverse.

The Cook County Recorder's office has been open some three months for the registration of land titles under the Torrens law. A considerable number of titles have been registered during that time, and now transfers are beginning to be made under the act. It is here that the great advantage of the system becomes apparent.

The three keepers attached to the penitentiary on Blackwell's Island who rescued some men who had been capsized in the East River on Sunday evening, after setting out from Long Island City, opposite the penitentiary, for a pleasure sail in the sloop Schnudel, may be rewarded for their bravery.

Frank R. Sherwin, promoter, of 40 Exchange Place, yesterday filed a petition in bankruptcy, with known liabilities of $164, 414 and no assets. There are many other claims against him, the amounts of which are unknown, for services, money loaned, merchandise. Many of the claims are barred by the statute of limitations, but are put in as a matter of form.
WASHINGTON, June 5. -- Senator Allison of the Senate Finance Committee, in an interview to-day said:

Mr. J.A. Longdon, President of the Institute of Mining Engineers, told the general meeting of that body yesterday that during the last twenty-five years the output of coal had increased from 120,000,000 to 200,000,000 tons, and the ratio of increase (after deducting years in which great strikes occurred in the coal trade) was 2 1/2 per cent. per annum.

WASHINGTON, June 5. -- One of the reasons for the visit of Secretary of War Alger to the West is said to be his desire to prepare the way in Michigan for his election to the United States Senate, as the successor of Senator McMillan. His assumption that McMillan was not anxious to be re-elected was disposed of by Senator McMillan's declaration that he expected to be elected to serve another term.

OTTAWA, Ont., June 5. -- In the House of Commons to-day Sir Wilfrid Laurier presented the protocol of the Anglo-American Conference on the Alaskan boundary question. There was nothing in what the Premier read to the House which was not covered by the cabled reports on the subject.

WASHINGTON, June 5. -- The President does not conceal his vexation at the report of the National Civil Service Reform League on the recent changes in the civil service regulations. Indeed, to several visitors to the White House he has complained that the comments upon the changes made much of the alleged weakening effect and very little of the added strength assured to the system by the changes.

BOSTON, June 5. -- The announcement that Prof. George Harris of the Andover Theological Seminary had been chosen President of Amherst College was a little premature. It is a fact that the Trustees of Amherst at a recent meeting took up the matter of choosing a President. Prof. Harris was one of the candidates considered, but the meeting adjourned without a selection.
The Chicago Times-Herald may fairly be regarded by Mr. McKINLEY as among his most devoted friends, but it is very severe in its criticism of the recent civil service order:

The Cleveland baseball team never had a chance to win from the Brooklyns at Washington Park yesterday afternoon. They showed in front for one inning, but once the Brooklyns were fairly started it was all over. The fielding of the visitors was of a kind that will not bring many victories to the club.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., June 5. -- Gov. Roosevelt after inspecting the early morning work of members of Squadron A left at 10:25 for West Point. He was accompanied by Gen. Roe and staff, Lieut. Col. Lee of the British Army, and Lieut. Col. Kitson of Canada. The members of the Governor's staff left for New York.

Frank Moss of counsel to the Mazet investigating committee said yesterday a Tammany combination had been recently formed to make war upon him and the committee and to hamper its work in every way possible. Mr. Moss said he had received knowledge of the movement against the investigation from a member of Tammany Hall well up in its counsels.

LONDON, June 5. -- Nat Goodwin, Miss Maxine Elliott, and their company appeared at the Duke of York's Theatre this evening, under the management of Charles Frohman, in "The Cowboy and the Lady," by Clyde Fitch. They were accorded a most cordial welcome by an audience completely filling the theatre.

CHRISTIANIA, June 5. -- According to a dispatch from Mandal, the most southern town of Norway, two boys, on May 14 last, found on the north coast of Iceland a small cork case containing a slip of paper dated July 11, 1897, signed "Andree, Strindberg, and Fraenckel," and bearing the words: "All well. Thrown out bout longitude 81, latitude unknown."
LONDON, June 5. -- The House voted Gen. Lord Kitchener a grant of 39,351 to-day, after a lively debate concerning the destruction of the Mahdi's tomb.

A pleasing innovation at the Gravesend track yesterday was the running of the hurdle race at the beginning instead of at the close of the day's sport. It was a handicap at a mile and three-quarters, and had a field of a half dozen starters, with Ben Eder favorite in the speculation and Forget a strong second choice.

Mrs. Mary Miller, the faith healer whose black salve and incantations made necessary the amputation of the left foot of twelve-year-old Dora Kranz, was yesterday found guilty of practicing medicine without being a duly registered physician, and was sentenced to five months' imprisonment in the Kings County Penitentiary by Justices Fitzgerald, Keady, and Fleming, in the Court of Special Sessions, Brooklyn.
GREAT NECK, L.I., June 6. -- Peter Strock, forty years of age, employed by Robert Pegue, a farmer of this place, was overcome by the heat this afternoon while at work and died.

The Brooklyns won their ninth straight game yesterday, defeating the Cincinnatis at Washington Park in a well-played game. The Cincinnatis made a strong bid for victory in the ninth. Selbach hit for two bases with the bases full, bringing in three runs. Kennedy then replaced McJames in the pitcher's box and saved the game.

Don de Oro kept up his winning gait by landing the Brookdale Handicap at the Gravesend races yesterday, taking up an impost of 125 pounds over a course of a mile and a furlong, and running it in record time for the track -- 1:53 -- thus beating the performances of Tenny in the Fort Hamilton Handicap, May 30, 1899, and of Sir Walter in September of last year, by a full second.

FORT DE FRANCE, Martinique, June 6.--When the dispatch boat Goeland, bearing the Superintendent of the prison and the Commander of Marine Artillery, who were designated by the French Government to notify Dreyfus of the revision of his trial, arrived yesterday from Cayenne at the Ile du Diable, Dreyfus was waiting on the shore.

Robert Bush, a steam engineer, living at 79 Steigman Avenue, Jersey City, was instantly killed about 9 o'clock last night by catching hold of an electric light wire in the basement of the building at 33 Trinity Place.

Mrs. Kate Treat Goodsell has commenced an action for an absolute divorce from her husband, Edward Lees Goodsell, in the Supreme Court. Justice Beach yesterday made an order sending the case to a referee, who will hear it and determine the issues. The referee has not yet been appointed.

TARRYTOWN, June 6. -- This was grievance day in Tarrytown and North Tarrytown, and many citizens entered pretests against the assessments fixed against them. In North Tarrytown about thirty property owners asked reductions. Counsel for John D. and William Rockefeller announced a protest, and said their clients had instructed them to continue the fight which has been going on for two years.

ROME, May 23. -- Leo XIII, takes a great interest in all the festivities in connection with the Queen's birthday, and has ordered his private secretary, Mgr. Angeli, to keep him posted in regard to the fetes. "The sovereigns of our generation are getting very few," he said the other day, "and I always hear of honors to those who have lived long with sympathetic pleasure."

Will you kindly inform several of your daily readers by what authority there is a different customs law applying to Puerto Rico from that applying to Alaska? Just what is the status of Puerto Rico under the treaty of peace?

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., June 6. -- The sun blazed down to-day upon the camp of the troopers of Squadron A. But they stucl to their work The horses were foamcorered during the drills and seemed fagged out at the end. The men stood up to their work in splendid style and did not falter, although it wa so hot on the field that it almost burned one's hand to touch the ground.

There is no telling, at least not by us, how old is the saying that republics are ungrateful. "But now the time gives it proof." KITCHENER'S victory is a good deal more recent than DEWEY'S. It did not begin to be of so much national importance as DEWEY'S. And already it has been rewarded with a fullness that, to tell the simple truth, puts us to shame.

The votes of the fifteen Republican Congressmen from this State were yesterday pledged to David B. Henderson of Iowa for Speaker of the House of Representatives, but not until two members had withdrawn from the delegation caucus, and those remaining had cast a complimentary vote for James S. Sherman of Utica.

A Summer market with the Summer weather; traders too busy to bestir themselves, small disposition showing to be active either upon one side of the market or the other. Recently aggressive bears were yesterday doing little raiding, while they who are recognized as leaders on the bull side seem content to watch rather than work.

LONDON, June 6. -- The Secretary of State for the Colonies, Mr. Joseph Chamberlain, replying in the House of Commons today to Sir Edward Temperley Gourley, Advanced Liberal member for Sunderland, said that before the Anglo-American-Canadian Commission adjourned proposals and counter-proposals for the arbitration of the Alaskan boundary were made, but the Commissioners, he added, were unable to agree respecting the tribunal and terms of reference.

The New Yorks found the Cleveland team an easy mark at the Polo Grounds yesterday, and as this aggregation will remain for three more games, there is no reason why the local team should not improve its position in the pennant race.

The knowledge that the home office of the International Navigation Company has in its possession the report of Capt. Watkins of the steamship Paris has revived speculation among shipping men as to why the vessel ran on the rocks off the Cornish coast. The report will be submitted to the Federal authorities, who are making an investigation into the disaster.

MANILA, June 6. -- The American forces have occupied the peninsula, and Gen. Hall's column is encamped at Morong. Major Truman, marching across from Binangonan, found it impracticable to form a cordon, and the insurgents, with the exception of a hundred or two, escaped through the mountains after Gen. Pio del Pilar, dragging their batteries by buffaloes at night.

The Mazet investigating committee sat yesterday without audience, and there was no counsel present to represent any of the witnesses. At the opening of the session Mr. Mazet announced that the committee would hereafter refuse to allow the presence of counsel owing to the conduct last week of Mr. Henderson and Dr. O'Sullivan.

The will of Edith Sybil Whitney, wife of William C. Whitney, who died at her country home at Westbury, L.I., on May 6, was filed for probate in the Surrogate's office yesterday. According to the petition filed with the will, the value of the estate is unknown. The heirs at law named in the petition are Arthur B. Randolph and Adelaide D. Randolph, the son and daughter of the testatrix.

It is an unusual thing for a man with an annual income in the neighborhood of $50,000 to dress like a tramp from choice and sleep in the cheapest hotels or at times in calabooses for lack of better accommodations. Yet such an individual, it is said, is J. Eads How, son of the late Col. James F. How, Vice President of the Wabash.
The Independent this week will contain the following article by Rear Admiral Sampson on "The United States Navy."

Lachman Goldsmith have sold, through A. Rothmiller, to Peter Muller, the builder, a plot of fourteen lots, being the block front on the east side of Seventh Avenue, between One Hundred and Thirty-eighth and One Hundred and Thirty-ninth Streets, and extending 178 feet in depth on either street. The price is reported at $180,000.

LONDON, June 6. -- Previous to play in the sixth round of the international chess masters' tournament, now in progress at St. Stephan's Hall, Westminster, it was announced that Teichmann had withdrawn from the contest, and that all the games he was yet to play would be scored against him, according to the rules of the tournament.

OMAHA, June 6. -- The following letter has been received by the editor of The Bee from United States Consul General Osborn at Apia, Samoa. The letter referred to as being printed in Truth of London was given out as having been written by Mr. Osborn. It was a most severe arraignment of Chief Justice Chambers of Samoa and of the British Consul and naval commanders.

If Mr. HENDERSON of Iowa is to be the next Speaker of the House of Representatives, as he has good reason for thinking that he will be, the people of New York will not complain or feel like complaining.

The annual meeting of the Actors' Fund of America was held yesterday at the Madison Square Theatre. The following officers were elected: President -- Louis Aldrich; First Vice President -- John Drew; Second Vice President -- Antonio Pastor; Treasurer -- Andrew A. McCormick; Secretary -- Edwin Knowles; Trustees for two years -- A.M. Palmer, William E. Sinn, Augustus Pitou, Charles H. Hoyt, Roland Reed, Augustin Daly, Milton Nobles, and Harry Harwood.

WASHINGTON, June 6. -- There is considerable dissatisfaction in official and diplomatic circles over the continued postponement of the British-Venezuelan arbitration proceedings, as the delay causes personal inconvenience to Chief Justice Fuller and Justice Brewer, who are arbitrators, and to ex-President Harrison and ex-Secretary Tracy, who are counsel, as well as to the British and Venezuelan officials now gathered at Paris.

DETROIT, June 6. -- Gov. Pingree, Elliott G. Stevenson, and Carl E. Schmidt, the three Commissioners appointed by the Common Council of Detroit to purchase and operate the city's street railways, to-night made formal application to the Council for one of three ordinances necessary to carry out the transaction according to the commission's programme.

WASHINGTON, June 6. -- According to a private letter received here from Munich, a German-American journalist, Louis Holler, editor of The Camden County Journal, published at Camden, N.J., on the occasion of a lecture delivered by him in the hall of the Radical German Union, at the Bavarian capital, on the German-Americans, their life and work, most bitterly criticised the present American Administration and the President.

Sutherland of Rochester opened the one hundred and eighteenth annual communication of the Grand Lodge, at Masonic Hall, in this city yesterday.

The Rockland County officials seem to be weakening in their determination to hold the prisoners here for trial, if they ever had any real desire to do so.

The News regards the appearance at New Orleans of a single case of the disease as an inadequate excuse for interrupting the commerce of the State and for filling its cities with panic fear.

Mataafa expressed willingness to abide by the Commissioners' decision, and blamed the Europeans for the recent trouble.

Fulton Street, between the Borough Hall and Flatbush Avenue, is never so crowded as between 8 and 10 o'clock P.M. and the malicious poodle could not have chosen a better time.

Controller Coler yesterday submitted to the Municipal Assembly a statement showing the deficiencies for 1898, which, under the charter, are to be apportioned among the several boroughs; the budget for 1899, the amount of county charges included in that budget, and the estimated receipts of the general fund for the reduction of taxation.

PARIS, June 6. -- In the Senate to-day the President, M. Fallieres, at the opening of the session declared that in the presence of the scandals at Auteuil on Sunday nothing could shake the confidence felt in the republic, and he assured President Loubet that the warmest sympathy of the Senate would never fail him.

Yesterday was the hottest June day in the history of the New York Weather Bureau, where records extend back twenty-seven years. The highest temperature officially recorded during the day was 97 degrees at 3 P.M., which is within 3 degrees of the highest temperature ever recorded in the local Weather Bureau. Unofficial thermometers in the sizzling, stifling streets recorded temperatures far above this mark, and the comedy of "collar wilting" weather became a tragedy.

Cacheux of the Gendarmerie and four gendarmes. The prisoner is apparently in good health, but seems to be fatigued. The verdict of the Court of Cassation has caused a very favorable impression here and in French Guiana.
PARIS, June 7. -- Mr. Augustin Daly died suddenly this afternoon.
PARIS, June 7. -- Matin says that the Government has taken steps to demand the extradition of Esterhazy.

CHICAGO, June 7. -- B.B. Caldwell, Chairman of the Western Passenger Association, tendered his resignation at a meeting of that body to-day to accept the position of General Traffic Manager of the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railway.

Mr. Reed has been opposed to currency legislation, his answer to an inquiry about such legislation having been not long ago: "If we say there is need of currency legislation, we shall admit that there is something the matter with the currency."

A committee of ten, representing the officers, firemen, and retired members of the New York Fire Department, presented to Miss Helen Miller Gould yesterday, at her home in Irvington, N.Y., a handsome album illustrating the scenes of the Windsor Hotel fire and her own good deeds in providing for the comforts of the firemen while they were fighting it. Every page of the album is beautifully engraved.

Prices for standard securities have been under the hammer for weeks; every art that adroit manipulators know has been resorted to through a vigorous raiding campaign.

Greystone, the country seat of the late Samuel J. Tilden, was sold at auction yesterday at the front door of the Manor Hall, in Yonkers, William M. Ryan conducting the sale. Samuel Untermyer of the law firm of Guggenheimer, Untermyer Marshall bought the entire property for $171,500.

NEWARK, N.J., June 7. -- A decision in favor of the Lister heirs was rendered by Vice Chancellor Stevens to-day in the suit which was brought by them to prevent the transfer of stock of the Lister Agricultural Chemical Works, held in trust by William R. Weeks, to the American Agricultural Chemical Company. commonly known as the Fertilizer Trust.

DETROIT, June 7. -- The Michigan Congressional delegation, which is solidly Republican, will cast its twelve votes for Representative Henderson of Iowa for Speaker of the next House. It was so decided at a caucus of the delegation held on Lake St. Clair to-day on board Congressman Corliss's yacht.

SARATOGA, June 7. -- A case involving very important questions affecting life insurance was argued before the Court of Appeals to-day. It was the cause of Emil Greeff of New York, respondent, against the Equitable Life Assurance Society, appellant. William B. Hornblower and Charles B. Alexander appeared as counsel for the Equitable, and Dickinson W. Richards appeared for Mr. Greeff.

WASHINGTON, June 7. -- Late in the day the officials learned the details of the latest negotiations in London, referred to in cable dispatches, and Secretary Hay and the British Charge d'Affaires, Mr. Tower, conferred on the subject. The details of the proposition were not made public.

The weather of yesterday in New York was record-breaking in more ways than one. In the first place, while the highest registered temperature during the day was lower than that of the day before, the mercury stood hour after hour higher than ever before recorded here on June 7, and took a big drop in the evening.

COLUMBIA, S.C., June 7. -- Judge James Aldrich has never lost an opportunity while on the bench of denouncing "mob law." At Conway to-day he sentenced two young negroes to life imprisonment, at hard labor, for offenses against two white girls. The negroes were captured in the woods, confessed, and were turned over to the Sheriff. The trial was conducted quietly.

LONDON, June 7. -- The Exchange Telegraph Company publishes an interview with the Parliamentary Secretary of the Colonial Office, the Earl of Selborne, in which he is quoted as declaring that the conference at Bloemfontein between President Kruger of the Transvaal Republic and the British High Commissioner and Governor of Capt Colony, Sir Alfred Milner, proved eminently unsatisfactory, and that there is no probability of its resumption.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., June 7. -- The Indiana Supreme Court holds that a public corporation which entered into a combination with other corporations to destroy competition and thereby increase the price at which an article was sold to the inhabitants of the State becomes liable to a forfeiture of its corporate franchise.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., June 7. -- The negro Will Hill, who, with his brother, Alexander Hill, shot and killed Mrs. Rufus Hubbard, wife of a well-to-do farmer, Monday afternoon, desperately wounded Hubbard himself, and sent a bullet through the hand of the babe Mrs. Hubbard was holding in her arms when she was killed, was lynched at the Hubbard home just at daybreak this morning. The Hubbard residence is a farmhouse near Centreville, Bibb County.

This was the amount of a promissory note given by him to her on Oct. 23, 1896. The plaintiff claims that O'Brien was her general guardian in a proceeding to recover her mother's property, and was also administrator of the estate.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, June 7. -- Articles on expansion, bearing Senator Foraker's name, which were sent to The Century Magazine and North American Review, have been declared forgeries by the Senator. The articles were postmarked Hanover, Penn., and were signed John B. Foraker, per George K. Metzger.

NEWPORT, June 7. -- The Defender, having undergone the neccesary repairs after her mishap on Tuesday off the Brenton's Reef Lightship, came down from Bristol this afternoon, and passed out of the harbor under a working topsail, jib staysail, and mainsail. The yacht ran out beyond Point Judith, and Mr. Duncan stated after the Defender anchored in the harbor that the trial was generally a good one.

Henry Laurens Clinton, the lawyer, died at his home, 58 Park Avenue, yesterday morning. He had been confined to his room for more than a year with a complication of Bright's disease and rheumatism. His condition assumed a dangerous phase last Monday, and he finally succumbed to an apoplectic stroke. Mrs. Clinton was with her husband when he died. He had no children. The body will be taken to Buffalo for interment.

The morning session, at which Grand Master Sutherland presided, was taken up almost entirely by the formal election.

Fire started on the ground floor of Frederick Loeser Co.'s department store on Fulton Street, Brooklyn, at 10 o'clock yesterday morning. The store was fairly well filled with shoppers, but they got out at the first alarm. There was a good deal of excitement, but no panic. The cause of the fire is said to have been the crossing of electric wires.
ALBANY, June 7. -- The State Railroad Commission has handed down decisions in twenty-two petitions made by the Long Island Railroad Company.

Columbia University held its one hundred and forty-fifth annual commencement yesterday, at which degrees were conferred on 470 students. Long before the hour set for the beginning of the procession, which was the first important event in the day's programme, the grounds were filled with spectators, who put off going into the furnace-like air of the gymnasium until the last moment.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., June 7. -- All arrangements were completed to-day for the funeral services over the body of Frank Thomson, late President of the Pennsylvania Railroad, wihch will be held to-morrow at 11 o'clock, at "Corkerhlll." A special train will leave New York at 7:55 to bring over the many friends of Mr. Thomson from that city, and at 10:30 a special will leave Broad Street Station.

The fickleness of the American season has had proof in the present heated spell. The average bachelor of society is enjoying it hugely. He sometimes has been shy of accepting house party invitations, actually remaining in town and passing the evening at the club or at one of the numerous Summer city amusements.

The Board of Estimate at its meeting yesterday authorized the Park Department to expend $4,000 for the erection of two permanent booths, one in Central Park, the other in Tompkins Park, for the distribution of sterilized milk. Heretofore this sterilized milk has been distributed from temporary booths, erected by Nathan Straus, who also furnished the milk.
BERLIN, June 8. -- A private telegram received here from Madrid says it is reported Germany intends to purchase the island of Fernando Po.

NEWBURG, June 8. -- The first day's play of the Powellton Golf Club's second annual tournament began this morning. The heat was intense, and would have been suffocating had it not been for a stiff breeze. The course, owing to the long-delayed rain, was hard as iron, and it was almost an impossibility to get under the ball with a brassie.

Word was received in Jersey City yesterday that Gov. Voorhees had appointed the commission authorized by the last Legislature to consider the consolidation of the twelve cities, towns, and townships of Hudson County, to be known as Jersey City.

The Rev. Alfred De Barritt, who four months ago founded a Congregational church in the City of Havana, has returned to this country for a brief stay, during which he will address meetings and appeal for help in aid of his religious and educational work in Cuba.

The big Sound steamboats Richard Peck and C.H. Northam, both of the New Haven Line, were in collision between Norwalk and New Creek early yesterday morning. The Northam was so seriously injured that she was run ashore, and her passengers were transferred to the Peck and brought back to this city.

LONDON, June 8. -- The advices received here to-day from South Africa, emanating from British sources, show more completely the utter failure of the recent conference at Bloemfontein between President Kruger and the British High Commissioner, Sir Alfred Milner. The London afternoon newspapers all refer to the dangerous situation.

CINCINNATI, June 8. -- The peculiar swindle perpetrated in Louisville Monday, when the German Insurance Bank paid $5,000 to two men who presented a check for that amount, purporting to come from the cashier of the Citizens' National Bank, has resulted in two arrests here and a partial confession. Fred Freidenheimer, a young man well connected in Louisville, was first arrested, and his step-father being advised came here immediately.

CHICAGO, June 8. -- Slavonic laborers are, it is claimed, being imported by the wholesale into South Chicago, tagged like express packages. The majority are promptly engaged by the Illinois Steel Company, and United States Immigration Inspectors have been watching this influx and say they are convinced that there have been many violations of the contract labor law.

GREENS FARMS, Conn., June 8. -- The steamboat C.H. Northam is resting easily to-night, and no attempt will be made to float her until midnight. It is thought, however, that the attempt will be unsuccessful, as she has been driven so far on the beach that it will need to be an exceptionally high tide before she can be floated.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 8. -- The Yale track athletic managers have decided to permit as many of the Yale track athletes as are candidates for the honor of becoming members of the Yale-Harvard intercollegiate track team which will compete with the Oxford-Cambridge athletes in July in England to enter the games to be held on Saturday at Travers Island.

It was another hard day for the backers of favorites at the Gravesend race course yesterday. All were beaten until the last race was reached, when Bannock came to the rescue of punter and plunger alike. He was a slight favorite over Dan Rice, who ran second, this being the only race in which the two favorites ran according to the estimates of the bookmakers.

ALBANY, June 8. -- Gov. Roosevelt, accompanied by his Military Secretary, Col. Treadwell, arrived here from New York at 11:15 A.M. to-day, and proceeded direct to the Executive Mansion, where he met Secretary Youngs and went through the stack of letters awaiting him. The Governor will leave here at 8:15 o'clock to-morrow morning for Rochester, where he will speak at the unveiling of the Frederick Douglass Monument.

Morris S. Wise, Referee in Bankruptcy, has filed in the United States District Court. Southern District of New York, a report on his objections to the discharge of Matthew McNamara, a butcher, who Dec. 9, 1898, was on his voluntary petition adjudicated a bankrupt.

BRISTOL, R. I., June 8. -- The question as to whether or not the cup defender Columbia should be painted above the water line was settled to-day. The Columbia is now a white yacht like most of the cup defenders before her. The work of painting the yacht was begun this morning, and at 6 o'clock the task was completed.

Expressions of sorrow for the death of Augustin Daly in Paris last Wednesday were received in large numbers and from many quarters at the office of Daly's Theatre yesterday. Scores of verbal messages were left at the box office, and more than fifty telegrams of inquiry and condolence from different parts of the country were received during the day.

Arrangements have been made by all the transportation lines reaching Coney Island to handle the crowds which will visit the Greater New York Athletic Club this evening to witness the prize fight between "Bob" Fitzsimmons and "Jim" Jeffries for championship honors. Referee George Siler of Chicago will call the men into the centre of the ring about 9.30 o'clock.

CATSKILL, N.Y., June 8. -- The number of delegates to the General Synod of the Reformed Church in America was increased by arrivals last night and to-day to 250. The General Synod at its session to-night listened to a sermon by the retiring President, the Rev. Dr. Edward B. Coe of New York.

PITTSBURG, June 8. -- A great combination has been planned of all the whisky and spirit interests east of the Mississippi, according to a manufacturer of rye whisky here. He said options had been taken on all the rye whisky distilleries, and some of these have been closed. The others expire July 1. It will require about $50,000,000 to form the combination.

The most important action taken by the Masonic Grand Lodge yesterday was the adoption of an amendment to the Constitution looking to the change of the date for its subsequent annual communications from the first Tuesday in June to the first Tuesday in May This action is the direct outcome of the discomfort experienced by the members of the Grand Lodge from the excessive heat.

ALBANY, June 8. -- Gov. Roosevelt this afternoon approved the new civil service rules as prepared by the State Civil Service Commission to secure a proper enforcement of the new White Civil Service bill passed by the last Legislature. The Governor had some doubts as to the provisions regulating promotions, and made a couple of amendments to this part of the law.

Roland B. Molineux, now a prisoner in the Tombs charged with assault upon Harry Cornish in sending the latter a package containing cyanide of mercury, which caused the death of Mrs. Kate J. Adams, will in all probability be released to-day in $5,000 bail, and then immediately be rearrested.

WHITE PLAINS, June 8. -- Surrogate Silkman of Westchester County has received a letter from Mrs. C. Davenport Bolsbridge of 29 Middagh Street, Brooklyn, asking his assistance in an effort to obtain some of the property once owned by Andrew Corsa, the last of the Westchester guides, where St. John's College now stands, at Fordham.

PARIS, June 8. -- The body of Augustin Daly, who died suddenly yesterday afternoon at the Hotel Continental in this city, was embalmed to-day, and will be sent to Havre to-morrow morning and shipped to New York from there by way of Southampton. There will be no religious ceremony here.

At a meeting of the Lewisham Board of Works considerable amusement was caused at the announcement of the titles given by a local land owner to some newly-made streets on his estate. Among the names were Francemary, Amyruth, and Elsiemaud.

George B. Barrow and Addie Barrow, his wife, who were held by the Rockland County authorities for the kidnapping of Baby Marion Clarke, were brought to this city yesterday morning and, with Bella Anderson, the nursemaid, arraigned before Justice Edgar L. Fursman, in the Criminal Branch of the Supreme Court.

WASHINGTON, June 8. -- When the State Department closed for the day, it was with the expectation on the part of the officials that the modus vivendi which had been under negotiation in London would be completed and signed to-morrow. The signing probably will take place in London, as between Ambassador Choate and Lord Salisbury, unless the programme is changed over night.

The tearing down of the old reservoir at Forty-second Street and Fifth Avenue necessitates the removal of a large part of the trees and shrubbery which surround and practically cover the stone faces of the structure, and the contractor, Eugene Lentilhon, is anxious to dispose of the part which belongs to him.

Strength showed throughout nearly every part of yesterday's security market. Stocks that lagged were affected by special influences having to do altogether with their own situation. A conspicuously weak feature was American Steel and Wire. Official statements -- and they can be relied upon -- have disclosed that in addition to earning 7 per cent. upon its preferred stock the company is making the equivalent of 18 or 20 per cent. upon its common stock.
BUFFALO, June 8. -- The National Convention of Credit Men to-day elected John Field of Philadelphia and Frederick Standart of Denver President and Vice President, respectively.

CHICAGO, June 8. -- Export provision rates from Chicago were cut 2 1/2 cents to-day. The Michigan Central made the reduction via New York and Boston to meet a similar cut by the Chicago and Grand Trunk via Montreal. The new rate will be 22 1/2 cents via New York and Boston and 20 cents via Montreal.

The Nordlinger-Charlton fireworks plant at Graniteville, S.I., was practically wiped out of existence yesterday afternoon. Thirty-six buildings were destroyed within a space of five minutes after the first explosion. A few buildings erected some time ago on another location about a quarter of a mile away is all that remains of the big plant. A score of persons were injured more or less severely, but all will recover.

The New Yorks did not have to put forth their best efforts to defeat the Clevelands, for the third consecutive time, at the Polo Grounds yesterday. The Cleveland team is at present in no condition to be in the League, and will win very few games. Incidentally it will cost the other eleven club owners some money, as it is no longer a drawing card.

WASHINGTON, June 8. -- The Cuban Commission, which has come to the United States to seek a modification of the decree issued at the direction of the President extending for two years the time within which debts contracted in Cuba prior to Dec. 31 last may be paid, arrived in Washington from New York to-night.

ROME, June 8. -- It is officially announced that the Pope, at a secret Consistory on June 19, will create twelve Cardinals. A public Consistory will be held on June 22, when a number of Italian and foreign Bishops will be preconized.

PHILADELPHIA, June 8. -- Rain stopped to-day's game at the end of the sixth inning. In the fifth the Philadelphias had a lead of one run, and in the sixth St. Louis, with two singles, a double, and a triple secured one run to the good. It was raining briskly at this time, and Capt. Cooley wanted Umpire Burns to call the game.

PARIS, June 8. -- Slight riots occurred this evening between the Revisionists and the Anti-Revisionists after a meeting addressed by M. Francis de Pressenso of the Temps, in the Clichy District of Paris. There were several fights between rioters and police, who charged the populace.

WHITE PLAINS, June 8. -- The will of Seth Lyon of the town of Bedford, who died in 1873, leaving a will dated April 19, 1870, with Hannah Lyon, Mary Lyon, and Emma C. Lyon as subscribing witnesses, all of whom are now dead and have been for several years, has been filed for probate with Surrogate Silkman of Westchester County.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., June 8. -- This morning before daybreak and about two hours before the Southern Railway north-bound passenger express is due in this city, three white men, evidently bent on train-wrecking, assaulted Henry Herring, night watchman in charge of a switch engine doing duty on the spur track leading to the Sloss coal mines.

ALBANY, June 8. -- Gov. Roosevelt has appointed Hugh McRoberts of Tompkinsville Quarantine Commissioner, to fill the vacancy caused by the death of Judge Patterson. The Metropolitan Opera House was nearly filled last evening with students and the friends of the graduating class of the New York University. It was the sixty-seventh commencement of the university, and the class, numbering 391, was the largest yet of the roll of graduates. The stage was filled with invited guests and the Faculties and alumni of the different schools.
HIGHMORE, S.D., June 9. -- The return to this town of a man and woman divorced five years ago, but who are again husband and wife, adds the last chapter to a romantic story of love and war.

LONDON, May 25. -- Dr. Conan Doyle has pleased a crowd of unsuccessful writers by complaining in a letter to the daily press that a certain well-known critic is as multiform as Andrew Lang himself. The critic in question is the editor of The Bookman and the correspondent of The New York Bookman. He is also editor of a Nonconformist weekly, and he writes criticisms under different signatures in a variety of other papers.

PARIS, June 9. -- At a Cabinet meeting held this morning, the Premier, M. Dupuy, and the Minister of War, M. Krantz, announced that Gen. Zurlinden, the Military Governor of Paris, and the Prefect of Police, M. Blanc, had adopted rigorous measures to preserve order at Longchamps on Sunday, upon the occasion of President Loubet's visit to that place to witness the race for the Grand Prix de Paris.

This doubt is wholly without foundation; and it may be positively asserted that the dialect, as given in the book, is a faithful reproduction of the speech one constantly hears throughout the rural districts of Central New York.

After consulting for three hours, the six members of the committee present dispersed without having taken any action beyond agreeing to delegate the continuance of the committee's duties during the Summer to sub-committees.

Charles H. Treat, Collector of United States Internal Revenue for the Second District is about to distribute blanks on which banks and bankers are required to make sworn statements on which the special war revenue tax will be levied. It is not likely that the collection of this tax will be made without appeal to the United States Attorney General, or perhaps litigation in the form of a test case.

WASHINGTON, June 9. -- Assistant Secretary of the Treasury Vanderlip, Chairman of the Dewey Home Fund Committee, was called upon several times to-day to deny the report that the committee of which he is Chairman had intended to abandon the attempt to raise the fund and had only been prevented by the President.

The Clevelands were defeated for the fourth consecutive time by the New Yorks at the Polo Grounds yesterday afternoon, but, unlike the three previous contests, the victory was anythings but a walkover.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 9. -- The schooner George A Howes was capsized in a severe thunder squall this afternoon two miles off Barnegat Life Saving Station. The vessel turned bottom upward instantly, and what became of her crew is not known. It is feared that all on board were drowned, although some of the crew may have been picked up by a passing tugboat bound for New York.

LONDON, June 9. -- While the House of Commons was in Committee of Supply on the Foreign Office vote to-day, Rear Admiral Lord Charles Beresford, Conservative, member for York City, delivered a scathing criticism of the Government's policy of "drifting in China." He said the Government had deceived the people and allowed the open-door policy to be finally killed by permitting Russia to interfere in a purely commercial enterprise like the Shanghai-Kwan Railroad.

James Boothby Burke-Roche, member of Parliament for West Kerry, Ireland, called on Mayor Van Wyck yesterday, in company with James E. Fitzgerald, a well-known Tammany Hall orator, who comes from the same part of Ireland as Mr. Burke-Roche.

Most persons who pick up the new Kipling book called "From Sea to Sea" will be surprised to find in it another and longer sketch bearing the same title.

Murphy of the Health Board, when asked about the report that he had submitted the investigations of his engineers into the condition of the elevated structure of the Manhattan Railway Company to the present Grand Jury, said emphatically that he had not. He explained that he had submitted the matter to the May Grand Jury, but owing to a rush of business before that body no action had been taken.

It was said that the British and American sides had agreed upon the principles, as it was supposed, that should govern in the arrangement of the modus.

NEWPORT, June 9. -- Mr. and Mrs. Perry Belmont, who were at the Muenchinger-King cottage to-day, and returned to New York this evening, met a New York architect at their cottage, By the Sea, and plans for extensive alterations to the interior were decided upon. They will be completed by the time Mr. and Mrs. Belmont return from Europe in August.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., June 9. -- A monument erected in memory of Frederick Douglass, who for many years resided here, was unveiled in this city this afternoon. Its site is near the New York Central Station, and it consists of a bronze figure standing upon a granite pedestal.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 9. -- Notwithstanding the rain, crowds of Princeton alumni and friends of the students are coming into the old college town on every train to witness the game with Yale to-morrow. A parade with brass bands and fancy costumes will open the afternoon to encourage the Tigers.

Gov. Benton McMillin of Tennessee, who has been in the city for a week negotiating a loan for the State, started back to Nashville last night after having accomplished his mission to his entire satisfaction.

A special feature of the services was the reading of "the great act of consecration and reparation to the sacred heart of Jesus." The form of this act was printed by Archbishop Corrigan and sent to all pastors in the city, to be read at either the morning or the evening service.

Graduating exercises of the Academic Department of the Polytechnic Institute, Brooklyn, were held last evening in the chapel of that department. ALBANY, June 9. -- Justice Truax has handed down his decision in the matter of the application of Henry H. Lyman, State Commissioner of Excise, for an order revoking and canceling the liquor tax certificate of Bernhardt Lazarowitz. The premises at 122 Stanton Street, New York City, where Lazarowitz had a saloon, are within 200 feet of the Epicopal Pro-Cathedral.

Adams. MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., June 9. -- Charles Bratsch was murdered in front of his cottage at Fleetwood, a suburb of this city, to-night. Two persons, including the prisoner's wife, are under arrest, and the police are looking for a second man, whom they suspect of knowing something of the affair.

Her role will be Marie Antoinette, of course. Henry Hamilton is writing, for Beerbohm Tree, a new play on the subject of "Monte Cristo." So that the Dumas boom in the theatres is not to die just yet.

A paragraph in your current issue of THE SATURDAY REVIEW on Victor Hugo's Voltaire oration makes me desirous of saying some things about "Cheerful Yesterdays,'' whose author, Col. Thomas Wentworth Higginson, is named as being present at the time the oration was delivered. I have had a copy of my friend's book for a long time, but heretofore have been unable to publicly express my delight in its perusal.

ALBANY, June 9. -- The most important changes from the previous rules in the new civil service rules adopted by the State Civil Service Commission and approved by the Governor are the abolition of the separate examination for fitness provided by the civil service law of 1897, and the requirement that in the future appointments in the competitive class shall be made from the head of the eligible list in order of standing.

Mr. Straus drove his horse in the trial, for which no special preparation was made.

We have held from the start that the differences between the Dominion of Canada and the United States as to the Alaska boundary would be settled without serious trouble, either by agreement or by arbitration. It now seems that the difficulty about which so much ado has been made for the past few weeks has been disposed of by a temporary arrangement that will probably lead to a permanent adjustment.

CATSKILL, N.Y., June 9. -- At this morning's session of the General Synod of the Reformed Church the Rev. Dr. Ferdinand S. Schenck of New York City was elected Professor of Pastoral Theology and Sacred Rhetoric at the Theological Seminary at New Brunswick.

SYDNEY, New South Wales, May 1. -- The immensity and variety of the mineral wealth of New South Wales has just received another illustration in the discovery, by officials connected with the Department of Mines here, of vast deposits of bauxite, which is a hydrated oxide of aluminium, and, practically, the only ore used in the arts for the manufacture of aluminium at the present time, having taken the place formerly occupied by cryolite.

CAMBRIDGE, June 10. -- The Varsity crew and substitutes will leave Cambridge for New London next Tuesday. The greater part of the work of coaching the crew as an eight has yet to be done, as the order in which the men are rowing and which is, in all probability, the final make-up, is less than two weeks old.

IF there is one thing that the New York public likes better than another it is a parade. New Yorkers, as a rule, will get up earlier and stand longer in bad weather to see a parade go by than any other people on earth.

The deal by which Henry Corn disposed of his new building on the northwest corner, even though it was largely a trade, is none the less significant through the fact that Henry O. Hevemeyer is the buyer.

CHICAGO, June 10. -- Men whose paid province it is to see that the State of Illinois receives her dues in taxes from her citizens are joyful because it is being, demonstrated that the new revenue law is a marvelous aid to them. Tax dodgers, under the workings of this measure, have to cope with factors that never before have been opposed to them, and their ways are hard.

WASHINGTON, June 10. -- Preliminary reports of the Spring wheat acreage indicate a reduction of about 470,000 acres, or 2.5 per cent. Of the twenty States reporting 10,000 acres or upwarl in Spring wheat, six report an increase aggregating about 245,000 acres, and fourteen a decrease amounting to about 715,000 acres.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 10. -- "Tom" Sharkey has issued a statement in which he says he is "still the champion heavyweight of the world," and that Jeffries will have to dispose of him before laying claim to that title.

LONDON, June 10. -- The crisis with the Transvaal, so long anticipated in your dispatches, is now upon us. From the mass of telegrams and comment, it may be well, since Americans are so largely interested in the Rand, both by employment and by investment, to disentangle the essential facts of the situation.

VIENNA, May 30. -- Mark Twain has left Vienna after a twenty months' stay, and no other town has ever seen him depart with more regret. He had become well known to every one. Wherever there was a festivity or something interesting to be seen or heard the famous humorist was to be found.
Frank Worthing has been engaged to play the part of David Brandon, and Mme. Cottrelly that of Mrs. Belcovitch, in the production of the "Children of the Ghetto."

NEWPORT, June 10. -- A year ago if a cottager were asked if Newport would be gay during June, 1899, the reply would have been "Decidedly not." But, strange as it may seem, Newport is quite gay, as a glance back at the week's festivities will show, but of course due in a large measure to the presence of Admiral Sampson and his warships.
