INDIANAPOLIS, June 10. -- The Sentinel to-morrow will say: "The trust mania has reached the brewers, and it is said on the best of authority that a scheme is on foot to form a trust with $1,000,000,000 capital and buy up all the breweries in the country.

PARIS, June 2. -- We have had a most sensational week -- one which will certainly count in the annals of French history for all time. The President of the Chamber of Requetes who is the reporter on the Dreyfus case, has pronounced before his colleagues, the Judges of the Court of Cassation, an earnest appeal in favor of the wretched prisoner on Devil's Island.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., June 10. -- Gov. Roosevelt arrived in camp at 5 o'clock this afternoon and was greeted with a salute of nineteen guns. The Governor made a tour of the camp this evening, and will inspect its workings in the morning. He will leave later in the day for Oyster Bay. Adjt. Gen. Andrews arrived this morning, and a salute of nine guns was fired in his honor.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., June 10. -- The Siegel-Cooper home for the women employes of the big store, at Sixth Avenue and Eighteenth Street, New York, opened at this place to-day. Last year three of "Phil" Daly's cottages on Second Avenue were occupied by these employes, but this season the Wheeler cottage, at North Bath and Second Avenues, has been selected by the firm.

There seems to have been some progress made in the movement on the part of the New York State Division of the League of American Wheelmen to secure a bicycle path on the Brooklyn Bridge. The meeting of the division, held last Wednesday, brought a response from Bridge Commissioner J.L. Shea, in which he indorsed the movement and asked that a committee be appointed to confer with C.C. Martin, Chief Engineer and Superintendent.

A suit to recover over $700,000, brought by the Industrial and General Trust, Limited, an English corporation, against J. Kennedy Tod and James G. Leiper, constituting the Reorganization Committee of the Birmingham and Sheffield and Tennessee River Railroad Company, came up for trial in the Supreme Court before Justice Smyth and a jury yesterday.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 10. -- The life-saving crew remained all night near the wreck of the two-masted schooner George A. Howes which capsized during a storm yesterday. The Little Egg Harbor Life Saving Station reports that so far as can be learned no member from the ill-fated craft has been saved.

When crossing the Brooklyn Bridge recently, it occurred to me that the uneven strain this magnificent structure is for several hours daily subjected to might be the cause of weakening it and wearing it out prematurely, and if owing to its construction this uneven strain cannot be remedied on the present structure, it might be easily avoided on bridges to be built in future leading into the City of New York.

A favorite amusement for old and young is the siva, the word meaning to dance. It is not, properly speaking, dancing, but is more like an acting charade, for, although accompanied with music, singing, and slapping of hands, the siva has no steps or regular figures, its motions consisting, of slow pacings, bodily and facial contortions, and what may be called descriptive acting.

WASHINGTON, June 10. -- The capital has been quivering with heat for a week, and for several days existence has been a struggle for breath. The oppressive weather has lasted long enough to quite arrest the tendency of visitors to this city, which usually enjoys a strong influx of hotel patrons in the early Summer.

BRISTOL, R.I., June 10. -- The sloop Columbia, the America's Cup defender of 1899, was launched from the south shed of the Herreshoff works at 8:15 o'clock this evening. There were from 5,000 to 6,000 spectators on shore and in yachts anchored off the yard, and the new yacht was cheered to the echo as she glided slowly into the water and was saluted with guns and steam whistles.

A fragment of a human body, with head, arms, and shoulders missing, and the legs gone below the knees, floated into the basin of the Crescent Athletic Club boathouse, at the foot of Eighty-fifth Street, Bay Ridge, yesterday morning and brought to the police of Brooklyn a mystery to solve.

STOCKBRIDGE, Mass., June 10. -- The recent hot wave has had its influence upon Stockbridge as much as upon any of the Summer resorts, and people have been flocking into the village for the past two weeks, delighted to get away from the heat of the city to the cool, shaded streets and the charming country homes of Stockbridge.

Four racing days of the Brooklyn Jockey Club's meeting remain before the animals move to the handsome racing park of the Coney Island Jockey Club. Except for the Greater New York Steeplechase, to be run on Monday, the fixtures for the week are unimportant until the last day of the meeting, Thursday.
Bear speculators this week have attempted their utmost at demoralization. They have failed. Final quotations for the week show advances instead of declines.

CHICAGO, June 10. -- It is understood that when the National Democratic Committee meets here, on July 20, it will be asked to adopt a resolution which will practically debar from participation in the convention Democrats who are certified by State Conventions that fail to reaffirm the Chicago platform.

One tidy little refrigerator about six feet wide and twice that depth is the butterman's stall in this market under the sea. Little tubs of butter are arranged on shelves to the amount of 5,000 pounds, and in company with these are 20,000 eggs. Twenty-five hundred quarts of milk and cream are stored in a separate room, all having been sterilized.

It is interesting to observe that Puerto Rico is giving us much less trouble than any other of our new possessions. Of course it is the smallest, but it is giving less trouble "per capita." And the reason for its tranquillity is also interesting, as given by those who are in the best position to judge.

AN EXPENSIVE ENCROACHMENT. -- Henry Dudley contacted in writing with William Sperb to sell the latter, for $15,500, a lot 75 feet front by 100 feet deep on Fifty-ninth Street, near Tenth Avenue. Sperb paid $500 on account; an additional amount was to be paid on delivery of the deed, and a mortgage for a part of the purchase price was to be given back by Sperb at the same time.

NEWBURG, N.Y., June 10. -- The second annual tournament of the Powelton Golf Club came to an end to-day, when A. De Witt Cochrane, St. Andrew's, beat Maturin Ballou, Apawanus, by 9 up and 7 to play at 36 holes for the Powellton Cup, and E.C. Ennerer beat H.A. Waldron, Powelton, by 9 up and 7 to play in the Consolation.

WASHINGTON, June 10. -- The report of Capt. A.G. Sawtell, Chief Quartermaster of the Second Division of the Army in the Philippines, showing the operations under his charge since hostilities began with the Filipinos, gives a good account of the transportation service of the army. He say there was sufficient transportation until the troops began to move against the Filipinos, when it was found necessary to impress all available vehicles.

BERLIN, May 30. -- The "Congress for Combating Tuberculosis as a National Disease," which closed on Saturday, cannot be said to have given any very encouraging results. Statistics showing the prevalence of consumption in all parts of the world were repeated with monotonous insistence, but no effective means of eradicating the dread malady was brought to light.

They fought for the championship of the world, an intangible distinction of which one of them was the possessor, but which, as the result of this encounter, passed to the other.

TOPEKA, Kan., June 10. -- Pages have been written of the power of attachments to old associations, but possibly no more forcible illustration of this kind has ever been discussed than one that has just come to light in Labette County, Kansas.

"Many Irish names appear strange," writes the distinguished Irish scholar. Dr. Philip MacDermott, "and uncouth to the average English reader, though if their etymology and pronunciation were perfectly understood, they would be found truly beauful and euphonious." The names of the ancient Milesian families were prefixed with "Mac" and "O," the latter apparently predominating with Princes and distinguished men.

PHILADELPHIA, June 10. -- President Alexander J. Cassatt of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company, who was yesterday elected by the Board of Directors to succeed the late Frank Thomson, met the Vice Presidents and high officials of the road in conference to-day and placed himself in immediate touch with the various departments which will henceforth come directly under his notice.

COVEROCK, Cornwall, June 10. -- The American Line steamer Paris, which ran on the rocks off the Manacles May 21, is now known to be doomed. A southeast wind is blowing, bringing in heavy seas, which are driving the steamer astern landward. Her boilers have shifted, her false bottoms are gone, and the divers are unable to work.

It is certainly very encouraging that Secretary GAGE feels impelled to explain that the recent civil service order of the President is not so bad as it has appeared to those interested in the subject who have criticised it. This shows sensitiveness to the opinion of disinterested citizens, with no axes to grind and no partisan spite to gratify.

ROME, June 10. -- The clerical Il Cittadino of Genoa says the Pope has decided to establish a permanent Apostolic Delegation in Canada. Investigation, however, shows this statement to be premature. Arrangements are in progress, and if carried out it is understood that Mgr. Zalowski, the Apostolic Delegate to India, who is now in Rome, will be appointed Apostolic Delegate to Canada.

It is an interesting coincidence that Rear Admiral John C. Watson, who is assigned to the command of the Asiatic Station of the United States Navy in Admiral Dewey's absence, is, like Dewey, "one of Farragut's boys." It was as Lieutenant that Watson won a picturesque place in history as "the man who lashed Farragut to the mast."

Lord CHARLES BERESFORD is about the only person now in sight who continues to hold or profess any faith in the possibility of saving China or of maintaining "the open door." It was not to be expected that he should let the last chance pass for that the dispatches describe as a "scathing criticism" of the course of the British Government in the Far East.

ASBURY PARK, June 10. -- Red-hot breezes direct from the torrid zone, coupled with depressing humidity, are responsible for the unusual rush of city visitors to the Monmouth coast resorts this week, and Asbury Park and Ocean Grove, as usual, were the objective points with fully two-thirds of the sweltering tourists.

PANA, Ill., June 10. -- To-day at Hillsborough, twenty-six miles went of Pana, a riot was narrowly averted. Non-union coal miners have been working in the mines there, owned principally by George V. Penwell, President of the Penwell Coal Company's mine of Pana, who has never left his quarters in this city unless accompanied by body guards since the riot of April 10 last, when seven persons met their death.

The arrangements for the funeral of Augustin Daly were partly completed yesterday after a conference between Archbishop Corrigan and ex-Judge Daly. Upon the arrival of the body next Saturday on the American Line steamship New York, it will be conveyed to Mr. Daly's late home, 14 West Fiftieth Street, and remain there until Monday morning, when it will be taken to St. Patrick's Cathedral, where the services will begin at 9:30.

LONDON, June 10. -- The indications point to an early termination of the theatrical season. Annie Russell, whose illness prevented an anticipated renewal of last year's successful appearance in London, returns to America by the White Star Line steamer Majestic on Wednesday. Her physician is confident that all she needs is complete rest.

Because of the blazing and baking heat of the first week of June the one roof garden that was ready for business was the most prosperous place of public amusement in all the town. Two of the others have been made ready now, and perhaps the roof-garden weather will hold.

The too free use of perfumes about the person has been avoided for many years and held inadmissible in good society, the merest hint of a faint odor being all that was possibly allowed. Recently this edict of good taste has not been so strictly regarded, and such perfumes as violet and sandalwood, both of them expensive ones when pure, together with heliotrope, are somewhat in favor again.

There was an exciting finish to the game between the New Yorks and Bostons at the Polo Grounds yesterday afternoon, but it was not the locals that furnished the finish. They allowed the Bostons to score three runs in the ninth inning, just enough to win.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 10. -- Princeton won the second game of the Yale-Princeton series this afternoon by a score of 6 to 2. The game was one of the most brilliantly played contests that has ever taken place on the home field.

HAVANA, June 10. -- The soldiers at Camp Columbia are still living in tents, the barracks for their accommodation not having been finished. The daily heavy rains are causing great annoyance. All the tents are of new brown hospital canvas, which was thought to be the best obtainable for the climate, but has proved utterly unfit.

LONDON, June 10. -- Sarah Bernhardt was greatly shocked at the news of the death of Augustin Daly. She said: "In common with every member of the profession in all lands, we render tribute to the great manager, who did so much for the profession for all time. Sir Henry Irving, Ellen Terry, and George Edwardes have all expressed to me their grief.

The annual match shooting for the Carnochan Trophy by the Seventh Regiment took place at Creedmoor yesterday. There were only nine company teams present. The men from Company E abandoned their plans to take part when they learned of the death of the Captain of their company, George B. Rhoads, who was killed by a cable car.

There are indications that local rowing clubs will send more entries to the People's Regatta, in Philadelphia, on July 4, than they have in many years. Several Harlem River crews are already in training, but they have not fully decided positively as yet whether they will enter. Ten days' more training will decide the question.

In considering the Dreyfus case, around which for two or three years the politics of France have revolved, one of the most singular reflections is that of the complete unimportance of the personality of Capt. DREYFUS himself. For all this time France has been ringing with his name and parties have divided over his case.

THE Dart is a little river of Devonshire, England, which used to be filled with salmon, in fact it was considered one of the best salmon rivers in the south of England. The water is now in perfect order; but there are no fish. It seems that a couple of years ago the man who owned some land below a place called Totnes Weir began to net the pool there.

Since France has sought to annihilate distance by tariffs, and to control for her profit The Indo-Chinese market, it would have been fair in return to open her ports to the products of Indo-China. But this was not done, and partly for the reason that these products furnished an indispensable portion of the revenue from the import duties.

BERLIN, June 10. -- The cession of the Pacific islands to Germany focused attention during the week. A curious feature was that while on receipt of the news the press as well as everybody at first expressed satisfaction, this changed radically as the week advanced and the terms of the bargain became known.

LENOX, Mass., June 10. -- The Lenox country places are nearly all occupied, the cottagers coming up from New York at least two weeks earlier than usual on account of the hot weather. This week during the extreme heat in New York the mercury in Lenox climbed up into the eighties, which is very rare, as it reaches that point not more than once or twice during the entire Summer.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., June 10. -- Chief of Police Foley is convinced that Charles Bratsch, whose body was found on his doorstep on the outskirts of the city last night, committed suicide, and was not murdered. For a while the Chief of Police and Coroner Banning disagreed, and then the Coroner came around to the Chief's way of thinking, and ordered the prisoners released from custody.

ROME, May 25. -- Floridia's new opera, "La Colonia Libera," the plot of which has been taken and adapted by Illica, the now famous librettist, from one of Bret Harte's Californian tales, was given here a week ago, and, despite the evident unsuitability of certain parts of the book, was well received and scored a success.

TOWARD the close of the Administration of President Rutherford B. Hayes, and while Senor Don Felipe Mendez de Vigo was Envoy Extraordinary and Minister Plenipotentiary for Spain to the United States, the First Secretary of the Legation was Senor Don Jose Brunetti.

WILMINGTON, Del., June 10. -- The torpedo boat Stringham, which the Harlan Hollingsworth Company is building for the Government, was launched this afternoon at 1:28 o'clock. Alias Edwina Stringham Creighton, granddaughter of the late Admiral Stringham, and daughter of the late Rear Admiral Creighton, gave the vessel its name.

LONDON, June 10. -- The Third International Congress of Publishers, which opened Wednesday at Stationers' Hall, this city, has awakened general interest. The American delegates were Messrs. Putnam, Appleton. Chichester, D.C. Heath, R. McClure, and Herbert Stone of Chicago. Prof. Mavor of Toronto represented Canada, and Lord Strathcona and Mount Royal, the Canadian High Commissioner, participated in the social part of the programme.

POUGHKEEPSIE, June 10. -- The Columbia 'Varsity crew rowed in their new Waters shell for the first time this forenoon. The shell proved very satisfactory, although alterations will have to be made in three or four of the slides to make them conform to the men who use them. The freshmen followed the 'Varsity and went over the same course.

Mortimer Menpes, the artist who is just now engaged in making 190 sketches of Mrs. Brown-Potter in different characters and costumes, says that the chief ingredient of good dressing is a sense of humor and Mrs. Potter agrees with him. "No really witty person, for instance," says Mrs. Potter, illustrating, "if she were stout of figure and scant of breath, could possibly turn out in Lady Habberton's radicals."

It is expected that the work of remodeling the ground floor of the Grand Central Station will begin soon after the Fourth of July. The general plan of the changes that are to be made has already been described. One of the main features will be the great rotunda, in which are to be the ticket offices.

Yet a great deal was learned about this neighbor in the sky -- among other things, that he is attended by two tiny satellites, or moons, never seen before.

THE HAGUE, May 23. -- The Hague is swarming with strangers, all peaceward bent. The Hagenaar is also very willing to be out of doors, for the fine weather at last has come, although the wind is still a vigorous guest, delaying his departure, I fancy, in order to aid the minority when the conference gets at its hottest.

An unusually large number of members and guests of the Morris County Golf Club went out to the clubhouse near Morristown, N.J., yesterday. The feature was the first competition for the silver cup recently presented by the President, G.G. Frelinghuysen.

MADRID, May 27. -- Spain seems actually skied over with the wings of guardian angels. The traditional tutelar of the nation, Santiago, counts for less, especially in the south and centre of the peninsula, than might be expected, and was long since officially superseded by the Virgin; but cities, hamlets, families, individuals, all have their protecting saints.

LONDON, June 11. -- American rails improved last week on the Stock Exchange, finishing firm at the best prices of the week. Among the increases were Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul, which rose 1 1/4 points; Reading firsts, 1 1/4; Pennsylvania, 3/4; Erie firsts, 3/4; Central Pacific, 5/8; Missouri Kansas and Texas, 5/8; New York Central and Hudson River, 1/2; Northern Pacific common, 1/2; Union Pacific, 1/2; Wabash preferred, 1/2.

True to its promise of last night, the company made no attempt to move cars today. There was no activity about the barns or terminals, and the big crowds of strikers and idlers that assembled saw nothing to excite them.

Member Owen, and Secretary Bishop of the State Board of Arbitration arrived in the city this evening, coming at the request of President Everett of the Big Consolidated Company. Their arrival was a surprise to the strikers.

" I am the Queen! The Queen of Prussia!" exclaimed a tall, distinguished-looking woman last night as she strode majestically into the West Twentieth Street Police Station and commanded Sergt. Churchill to rout out the royal foot guards and chastise her enemies.

CASPER, Wyo., June 11. -- The "Hole in the Wall," for years a refuge for outlaws, promises to be cleansed of its desperate inhabitants. The daring robber band which looted the Union Pacific express at Rock Creek recently and escaped to the fastness of their dens in the "Hole in the Wall," in spite of the fact that they were closely pursued over plain and mountain, are to be systematically hunted to their death.

ALBANY, June 11. -- The Bureau of Labor Statistics has issued a quarterly bulletin relative to the present industrial conditions in this State. The bulletins are issued under Chapter 569 of the Laws of 1899, the clause for the issuance of the same having been suggested by Col. Roosevelt. The bulletin just issued is the first under the law and contains statistics for the quarter ended March 31.

Coney Island was in full working order yesterday, although the cool weather kept the attendance down to about 60,000. Everybody was doing business except the bathing house people. The bathers were few and shivery, and the public gave its attention to other methods of amusement.

WASHINGTON, June 11. -- Over 5,000,000,000 gallons of petroleum, according to the Treasury Bureau of Statistics, are now produced annually in the world. Of this amount 2,500,000,000 are produced in the United States, 2,250,000,000 in Russia, and the remainder is distributed among a dozen countries, Austria producing 87,000,000; Sumatra, 72,000,000; Java, 30,000,000; Canada, 29,000,000; Roumania, 24,000,000; India, 15,000,000; Japan, 8,000,000; Germany, 7,000,000; Peru, 3,000,000, and Italy about 1,000,000 gallons.

LONDON, June 12. -- A correspondent of The Daily News at The Hague says: "I learn that Dr. Zorn, the German delegate, spoke on Friday against arbitration. When I asked him for a copy of his speech I got a point blank refusal, Dr. Zorn saying: 'All I can tell you is that Friday's sitting was extremely interesting and that I presented Germany's objections to the scheme for a permanent arbitration tribunal.'

LEBANON, Penn., June 11. -- Returns of last evening's Republican primaries in Lebanon County have been received from all districts and show a complete victory for the anti-Quayites. H.T. Euston and H.C. Grittinger, the anti-Quay candidates for delegates to the State Convention, were elected, and the anti-Quay candidates for the county offices were successful. The anti-Quayites will have a majority of five in the County Committee.

The next President of Brown University will be the Rev. Dr. William H.P. Faunce, the present pastor of the Fifth Avenue Baptist Church, who was elected to the office some time ago, and yesterday announced to his congregation that he had decided to accept the offer Dr. Faunce's decision was the natural result of a tendency toward educational work which has led him to give some part of his time to it.

SIOUX CITY, June 11. -- A tornado this afternoon struck two miles southeast of the little town of Salix, sixteen miles from here. John Malloy, farmer, and his wife and sixteen-year-old son were killed; Miss Bessie Malloy, the eighteen-year-old daughter, had her skull fractured and is not expected to live; Thomas and Patrick Malloy were badly hurt.

The Red Cross Society for the Maintenance of Trained Nurses has issued its report for the period between May 18, 1898, and March 1, 1899. This society was organized in May of 1898, in the early part of the war with Spain, for the purpose of "giving our soldiers and sailors every advantage in sickness that modern skill and science afford."

PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad, West Indies, June 3. -- Complaint has been made to the Consul for Germany at this port by Mr. Schierholz, a German, against the Government of Venezuela for illegal imprisonment and forcible deportation from Venezuela under most extraordinary circumstances.

WEST BERLIN, Vt., June 11. -- The indiscretion displayed by Patrick Broughal in visiting Mrs. Robert Redpath in the absence of her husband, after being warned to keep away, led to his being treated to a coat of tar and liberally sprinkled with feathers last night. For some time past Broughal's attentions to Mrs. Redpath had been offensive to several people in the community.

PEEKSKILL, June 11. -- The Third Battery reached camp a little after noon to-day. The night was spent at Nelson Park, in Sing Sing, and camp was broken a little before 10 o'clock. The trip from Sing Sing to the camp was made at a walk, but despite this the artillerymen, their horses and guns were coated thick with dust when they reached the camp.

WASHINGTON, June 11. -- The War Department to-day received a report from Major Gen. Otis of the military movement yesterday to the south of Manila for the purpose of clearing out the rebels in that section. It shows that the movement was a great success and that the enemy's loss was considerably greater than stated in the press dispatches. Gen. Otis's cablegram is as follows:

POUGHKEEPSIE, June 11. -- The baccalaureate sermon at Vassar College was preached this morning by President James Taylor, the senior class numbering 118. American politics came in for a share of President Taylor's attention. The college chapel was filled with college girls and their friends and relatives. The Columbia College 'Varsity and freshmen eights occupied seats in the little gallery.

WICHITA, Kan., June 11. -- Mrs. Ray Higgins, a bride of two hours, is dead and her husband and young brother badly injured as a result of a charivari party given them at their home near Watonga, Oklahoma, Friday night. The charivari party, composed of about twenty friends of the young married people, refused to go when requested to do so, but continued to make deafening noises by beating on pans and firing shotguns.

The farmers on Long Island say that unless rain falls within a week there will be an utter failure of the season's crops. Even corn, which usually flourishes in dry, hot weather, is wilting and drying up. The hay crop, which should now be pushing toward maturity, is drying up, and in some sections nothing remains now but to cut it as it stands.

THE SUCCESSION TO THE COBURG THRONE. -- On the death of the heir apparent to the throne of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha, a younger brother of the reigning Duke became heir presumptive. He is Queen Victoria's third son and is known as the Duke of Connaught, who at one time was a promising candidate for the rank of Commander in Chief of Her Majesty's forces.

LONDON. June 11. -- This has been an untoward week and business all round has been unsatisfactory. The only thing that has cheered us is our foreign trade returns for May, which show a satisfactory increase in exports; yet the figures for the leading branches are rarely up to those of 1897. Your reduced purchases of textiles are the principal cause of this.

NEWARK, N.J., June 11. -- The cornerstone of the new Cathedral of the Sacred Heart was laid here this afternoon. It is estimated that 25,000 persons attended the ceremonies. Early in the morning visitors began to arrive from all parts of the State in small parties, and by noon the various church societies began to arrive on special trains and trolley cars.

PHILADELPHIA, June 11. -- At the forty-seventh annual meeting of Progressive Friends at Kennett Square yesterday William Lloyd Garrison bitterly attacked the American policy in the Philippines. His address was on "Imperialism and Betrayal of Democracy."

The work of giving promising Cuban lads a chance to gain the education which many of them eagerly desire is being carried on at present under the auspices of the Cuban Educational Association, of which Major Gen. Joseph Wheeler is President and Gilbert K. Harroun, the Treasurer of Union College, is Secretary and Treasurer.

A decidedly easy tone characterized the money markets of the past week. There was at all times a liberal supply and borrowers had no difficulty in obtaining loans even where they asked concessions as to collateral. The gold shipments, which, in view of their size, were looked upon as probable money-market factors, had no effect whatever upon rates.

PARIS, June 11. -- President Loubet has had his revanche for last Sunday's outrage at Auteuil. When he drove to Longchamp to-day to attend the Grand Prix he was the hero of a great popular demonstration, expressing itself in one form or another along the whole route from the Elysee Palace to the race course.

BARBOURVILLE, Ky., June 11. -- Since the change of venue was granted at the little village of Manchester, Clay County, yesterday, for the Baker murder trials to be held here, this city has been in a state of excitement. A repetition of yesterday's tragedy at Manchester, when "Tom" Baker, the principal defendant, was shot dead while a prisoner of the court, is believed to be impossible here.
NEWPORT, June 11. -- Mr. and Mrs. John R. Drexel returned to New York to-day in the Sultana.

CHICAGO, June 11. -- The Record to-morrow will say: "Extensive precautions against a shortage in Chicago's supply of natural gas are about to be taken. Contracts have just been closed by the Chicago and Indiana Natural Gas Company, through whose mains gas is piped from the Indiana fields, for the erection of an immense new pumping station at Howell Corner, Grant County, Ind., and the construction of a new ten-inch main into Chicago.

There is a gradual stiffening in the prices of raw wool both here and abroad, and this will have the effect not only of sustaining prices on woolen fabrics, but undoubtedly will push them up a little further in the near future. Next season probably will see higher prices than this. This advance in wool is largely on account of the scarcity that is becoming evident in various parts of the world.

Some time ago the Government representatives at the navy yard at Portsmouth caused the graves of the dead Spanish prisoners on Seavey Island to be properly marked, so that they can at any time be identified. Thomas C. Leckey of that city sent newspaper accounts of this to the Spanish officers who were there, and received in reply a letter, from which the following is taken:

WASHINGTON, June 11. -- The Government has been requested, by President Cabrera of Gautemala, to suppress a filibustering expedition now being fitted out in Cuba for the purpose of overthrowing his Government.

SEA CLIFF, L. I., June 11. -- Bishop McConnell of Brooklyn to-day laid the cornerston of St. Boniface's Roman Catholic Church in this village. Several hundred persons attended the ceremonies. The Bishop was assisted by the Rev. James Barrett, his secretary, and ten other priests. Father Tierney preached the sermon. The new church will have cost $9,000 when completed.

It is not improbable that there will be disclosure this week of plans in which large financial interests are uniting for security market activity. Those plans are far advanced. They have passed the preliminary stage. Their active progress shows in many ways. And it is not unnatural to expect now open declaration of purposes in view.

MANCHESTER, Ky., June 11. -- Last evening Thomas Baker, leader of the Baker faction of the Baker-Howard feud, was shot and instantly killed in front of the Court House. The shot was fired from a rifle, and from the house of Sheriff Beverley White, directly across the street. White and Bal Howard are recognized as Howard leaders, but White was on the street at the moment Baker was killed, and Howard was two squares away.

The churches of Brooklyn took a vigorous stand yesterday in favor of Controller Coler's Coney Island park scheme. In two of the leading churches of the city, Plymouth Church and the Church of the Pilgrims, mass meetings were held, while in many of the other churches resolutions were adopted and sermons preached in favor of the plan.

MILWAUKEE, June 11. -- Capt. Frederick Pabst and Eugene Wusthoff of the Pabst and Schlitz Brewing Companies, respectively, deny that Milwaukee breweries are connected in any way with the reported gigantic brewery combine, which, it is alleged, is to include nearly all the important breweries of the country, and be capitalized at $1,000,000,000.

Precisely at 12:03 this morning, and to the strains of "Mr. Johnson Turn Me Loose," played by the Ninth Regiment Band, eleven white and two colored men started "the great international six-day relay walk and go-as-you-please contest" at Madison Square Garden. The start was witnessed by four or five hundred spectators.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 11. -- Alexander De Witt, a familiar figure on the streets of Poughkeepsie, who passed away a few days ago at the advanced age of ninety-two years, instead of being comparatively poor, as all of his relatives and friends thought, was a wealthy man. Securities to the amount of $40,000 have been found in his effects.

The wonderful quarter of a mile in 29 seconds, made by Cobwebs, Nathan Straus's handsome chestnut gelding on the Speedway last Thursday, was the chief topic of conversation among the road drivers who congregated yesterday at the Speedway road houses, and there was talk of another trial against time by the speedy trotter.

BRISTOL, R.I., June 11. -- A revised list of the casualties resulting from the explosion of the flashlight apparatus at the launching of the Columbia late last night shows that several more were injured than at first reported.

Those who played the steeplechase which wound up the racing at the Gravesend track yesterday afternoon, particularly those who backed the favorites -- the Chamblet Stable, White Garters and Diversion -- had a lot of grumbling. The pair finished first and second, as named, after a very pretty chase in which White Garters led the field from one end of the route to the other.

Ineffective pitching enabled the Bostons to win another game from the New Yorks at the Polo Grounds yesterday afternoon, Carrick was the offender. The Bostons hit his curves from the start, and after they had piled up eleven runs Capt. Gleason called a halt. This was after two were out in the third inning, Colcolough replacing Carrick.

WASHINGTON, June 12. -- Mr. G. Waldo Smith of New York, President of the Wholesale Grocers' Association, was the only witness before the Industrial Commission to-day, in connection with the trust investigation. Mr. Smith refused to speak of combinations of capital as trusts. He asserted that there were no trusts and that the combinations were unjustly so called.

Yesterday's meeting of the Presbytery, which took place at the First Church, was characterized by the carrying of a warm dispute in the session of the Fifth Avenue Church over the Warszawiak case before the members of the Presbytery, and by a re-opening of the West Presbyterian Church case, with a result which may prove fatal to Dr. Evans's hold on the pastorate.

Henry C. Henderson, who was retained by Capt. Price to represent him as counsel before the legislative investigating committee, was arraigned yesterday before Magistrate Olmsted in the Centre Street Police Court on the charge of disorderly conduct during the hearing of the committee on June 2. The hearing was conducted by Magistrate Olmsted in his private room, which was filled by the witnesses, lawyers, and members of the Mazet committee.

PARIS, June 12. -- The Prefect of Police, M. Blanc, has ordered an inquiry into the charges of police brutality yesterday. If they are substantiated the men at fault will be punished severely. The Government to-day removed the ban from the Automobile Club.

CHICAGO, June 12. -- That Augustus Thomas has improved since he wrote "Alabama" and "In Mizzoura" seems to be the opinion of those who saw the first presentation of "Arizona," his new play, at the Grand Opera House to-night. In every respect it is stronger, in plot and treatment, than either of his best-remembered other plays.
CHICAGO, June 12. -- Senator W.B. Allison of Iowa is in Chicago. He says the Republican leaders of the West are becoming satisfied the Vice Presidential nomination will be from the West next time.

LONDON, June 12. -- The Rev. William Garden Blaikie, D.D.,LL.D., Professor of Theology, Free Church, Edinburgh, and former President of the Pan-Presbyterian Alliance, died at North Berwick, Scotland, early Sunday morning.

James A. Garland, Vice President of the First National Bank, has sold his residence, 259 Madison Avenue, adjoining the southeast corner of Thirty-ninth Street, to R.C. Nickerson of Chicago, for about $125,000. The buyer, it is understood, will occupy the house in the near future.

CHICAGO, June 12. -- As the Chicago, Rock Island and Pacific west-bound express train pulled into Geneseo, Ill., 160 miles south of Chicago, at 9:50 o'clock last night, three cars left the track and crashed into a stock train standing on a siding. Fifteen persons were injured, the three passenger cars demolished, and the stock train locomotive disabled.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., June 12. -- The First Battalion of the Twenty-third Regiment moved out of the State camp this morning at 9:30 under conditions as nearly resembling actual service as it is possible to make them. The men were in heavy marching order and moved out of camp as if leaving the base of supplies behind and liable to have trouble in forcing every step of their march through an enemy's country.

WASHINGTON, June 12. -- The Madrid dispatches regarding the advices of the Spanish Minister here to his Government brings out the substance of a short interview which the Duke of Arcos had with Secretary Hay last Thursday. On this occasion the Duke of Arcos urged on this Government the pressing desire of his Government for the utmost expedition in the efforts to obtain the release of the Spaniards still held by Aguinaldo.

James J. Jeffries, the new heavyweight champion of the world, appeared at the Coney Island Sporting Club last night and boxed three rounds with his sparring partner, James Daly. The rounds were of two minutes each. Jeffries clearly showed that he could play all around his adversary.

BOSTON, June 12. -- Mrs. Amelia Carter of New York, who says she was married last Wednesday, has reported to the police here that her husband has robbed and deserted her. According to the woman's story, Henry Carter, who represented himself to be a reporter for a New York newspaper, married her last Wednesday evening at Gustavus Adolphus Church, New York.
LONDON, June 12. -- The following is the text of the challenge sent to the Presidents of the Harvard and Yale University Athletic Clubs:
LONDON, June 12. -- Joseph H. Choate, United States Ambassador, spent the end of last week at Birmingham as the guest of Joseph Chamberlain, Secretary of State for the Colonies.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., June 12. -- J.K. Van Ness, known as the "Count," was to have been tried in the police court to-day for discharging firearms in the city. He did not appear for trial, as he feared that while he was away the Elizabeth and Westfield Trolley Company would extend its lines through his property.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 12. -- The class day exercises of Princeton University began this morning, when President Patton delivered the address of welcome in Alexander Hall before the graduating class, alumni, and guests. A large number of visitors has been attracted to the town.

ST. PAUL, June 12. -- A tornado swept over Hastings, Minn., and Hudson and New Richmond, Wis., to-night, being probably the centre of a storm that gave St. Paul and Minneapolis a hard rain and blow from 3 to 8 o'clock.

WASHINGTON, June 12. -- The War Department has under consideration an order sending the Twenty-fourth and Twenty-fifth Infantry to Manila to reinforce Gen. Otis. The order has not yet been issued, but arrangements for relieving these regiments are being considered, and it is quite probable that they will be completed in a few days.

The appointment of this commission is simply another game of procrastination, brought about by the allied opposition to the United States getting possession of a short route to the Far East. This opposition is powerful and active. It never rests, and when you come to analyze it, it is enough to make one despair.

CHICAGO, June 12. -- Drastic measures are imminent in the Presbyterian denomination for the punishment of libelous criticism of one minister by another. At a meeting of the Chicago Presbytery to-day Moderator John H. Boyd strongly condemned ecclesiastical libelers and demanded their punishment in accordance with the law of the Church.

MANILA, June 12. -- The funeral of Capt. Henry Nichols, the commander of the United States double-turreted monitor Monadnock, who died from sunstroke on Saturday, took place at Cavite yesterday, with appropriate naval ceremonies. The officers of the fleet were present and the flags on all the vessels were half-masted.

The following is a copy of the correspondence which has passed between Everett P. Wheeler, a member of the Executive Committee of the Civil Service Reform Association, and Secretary Gage of the Treasury regarding recent changes in the civil service rules.

Historic Plymouth Church, which has taken an active part in so many reform movements, has taken the lead in another, which has for its object the solution of one of the great problems of the day -- the church hat question. The church hat question is second only to the theatre hat problem in importance.

FREEHOLD, N.J., June 12. -- Dr. Frank D. Toms, whose home is at Keyport, N.J., was convicted to-day of atrocious assault and battery upon William H. Smith. The assault occurred on April 30. Stories had been circulated in regard to Dr. Toms and Mrs. Smith. Smith called at the physician's office and is said to have threatened the doctor.
CLEVELAND, June 12. -- The attempt of the big Consolidated Railroad Company to move its cars to-day was attended by scenes of wild disorder in various parts of the city.

Senator Marcus A. Hanna returned to the Waldorf-Astoria yesterday, after a visit to Vice President and Mrs. Hobart at their country home. Normanhurst, near Hollywood, N.J., walking a trifle lame, but looking otherwise very little like the tottering invalid the Western papers have pictured him.

According to a decision handed down yesterday by Justice Nash of the Supreme Court, the Manhattan Elevated Railway Company is liable to the City of New York for more than $2,000,000 of taxes, due for the years 1804 to 1898.

PARIS, June 12 -- The Dupuy Ministry resigned to-day after meeting defeat in the Chamber of Deputies on the question of its policy in taking unusual precautions yesterday for the preservation of public order and the protection of President Loubet. The Cabinet, on the tinai revision, was beaten by the decisive vote of 321 to 173.
A natural market -- naturally strong-ruled in Wall Street yesterday. Prices advanced easily, and not in a few parts of the market merely, but generally.
St. Paul and Kansas City 5 per cent. prior lien bonds amounting to $2,823,150 called by the Chicago Great Western for payment at 105.

The Populists and 16 to 1 men now in control of the Democratic organization are resolved that there shall be no bolting from the National Convention next year. It is their present intention, according to report, to seat none but free-silver delegates. The National Committee meets in Chicago on July 20.

There will be quite a number of weddings this week, and there will not be a general departure from town until after these functions have taken place. To-morrow the wedding of Miss Dickey and Gen. Varnum, at Grace Church, will be the occasion for a gathering of the people who are yet remaining in town.

SARDIS, Miss., June 12. -- Simon Brooks, colored, was lynched by a mob of 500 negroes near here between midnight and dawn to-day for an attack which he and another negro made Saturday night on a negress.

A new freight and passenger steamer service between New York and Providence, R.I., was begun yesterday by the New Haven Steamboat Company. The steamboat Shinnecock left the New Haven Company's pier, 25 East River, at 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon with nearly all of its passenger accommodations engaged.

The National City Bank will to-day ship $2,000,000 in gold coin to Europe on the steamship Lahn. The gold was yesterday taken from the Sub-Treasury on Clearing House balance tickets, so that the transaction will not affect the United States Treasury gold balance.

The suit of Miss Lesbia M. Bostwick against Count Malta Lierven Steingranat of Sweden for $50,000 damages for breach of promise of marriage, ended yesterday in the Supreme Court with a verdict for $45.86. Miss Bostwick is indignant, says the sum awarded to her is ridiculous, and is anxious to know how it was reached.

MONTREAL, June 12. -- The Board of Directors of the Canadian Pacific Railway met to-day and accepted the resignation of Sir William C. Van Horne as President, immediately re-electing him as Chairman of the Board of Directors. Vice President T.G. Shaughnessy was elected President of the road.

LONDON, June 12. -- The tenth round of the International Chess Masters' Tournament was begun in this city to-day, when the pairing was arranged according to the ninth round of the Berger system, which was as follows:
NEWPORT, June 12. -- Mrs. Henry Clews has arrived at her cottage, The Rocks, for the season.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 12. -- The Harvard 'Varsity crew will leave for New London to-morrow afternoon. Fourteen men will be taken, including the coxswains. The make-up of the crew is as follows: Stroke, Higginson; 7, Sheafe; 6, Bancroft; 5, Lawrence; 4, Tilton; 3, Wood; 2, Evans; bow, Harding. Substitutes, (four:) Stroke, Blake; 3, Kernan; 2, Perkins; bow, Endicott.
In regard to the recent gold shipments, I think that some of your contemporaries treat the matter with altogether too much indifference.

Several missing portions of the body that was washed ashore at Bay Ridge on Saturday were recovered in the East River yesterday, and while the body is not yet intact, the parts recovered should lead to identification if the man has any friends in this city. The first portion found yesterday consisted of the upper part of the chest and part of the head, as far up as the bridge of the nose.

YONKERS, N.J., June 12. -- Albert Dersofi, who has been missing from his home here for unknown reasons since June 5, and who, it was thought, might be the man whose body was found mutilated at Bay Ridge, had his name tattooed on his left arm but had no marks on the right arm. Derson was forty years of age and weighed about 190 pounds.
MINNEAPOLIS, June 12. -- There are repeated rumors that the tornado at New Richmond, Wis., has killed 250 people. The full extent of the disaster is unknown.

The six-day walking match at Madison Square Garden, which started at midnight Sunday, came to an inglorious end at midnight yesterday. Two or three men, who had been ambling in racing togs about the Garden amphitheatre, just to finish out their twelve hours, stopped in disgust as the clock struck 12, and the scanty crowd of onlookers gathered about them, while thoughts of Mr. Samuels, the manager, filled the minds of all.

PARIS, June 12. -- Shortly before 6 o'clock this afternoon the boulevards presented a typical Parisian scene. The sidewalks were crowded with lounging boulevardiers, and every seat at the little tables in front of the cafes was occupied by a Parisian, sipping absinthe or some similar aperitif before dining, and animatedly discussing the races at Auteuil and everything but the debate in the Chamber of Deputies.

THE HAGUE, June 12. -- At an adjourned meeting of delegates to the Peace Conference, under the Presidency of M. de Staal this morning, it was resolved to furnish the newspapers with statements of the proceedings of the committees as well as of the plenary sittings.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., June 12. -- A message was received at the Wisconsin Central offices here late to-night from Stevens Point from Mr. Horn, Division Superintendent of the Wisconsin Central at that place, as follows:
If Mr. COLER could have the entire guidance and management of his plan to convert Coney Island into a public park, there would be very little disinterested opposition to it.

PARIS, June 12. -- The Chamber of Deputies was crowded to-day, and there was considerable suppressed excitement when M. Vaillant, Socialist, representing one of the divisions of the Seine, interpellated the Government on yesterday's "police outrages" at the Pavillon d'Armenonville, and demanded to know the instructions the Government gave the police in regard to the Socialists, who, he said, defended the republic against the Reactionaries.
NEWPORT, June 12. -- Capt. John McGowan has been detached from the training station and ordered to command the Monadnock at Manila.

The Thirteen Club had a memorable dinner last night on the roof of the Jersey Central Railroad Building, Liberty and West Streets. The floral decorations were orange and green. The candlesticks were skulls, with a good article of grave mold clinging to them, and further beautified by the drippings which ran down on them and made a very fair representation of clinging wisps of white hair.

ALBANY, June 13. -- The Court of Appeals has decided against George W. Green, H.W. Cannon, and John J. Tucker, who sought to contest their removal from office as Aqueduct Commissioners by Mayor Van Wyck. The court affirms the lower court's decision refusing them relief.

The brief but swift career of Dom Eugenie Faria Gonzales de Teixeira, Marquis of Aguila Branca, as a "good thing" in this city has come to an end. He has engaged in real estate, matrimonial, legal, and artistic enterprises and in two years has lost $150,000 in cash, which he brought here from Brazil, and other property valued at $50,000 or $75,000.

WASHINGTON, June 13. -- Moreton Frewen, the silverite from England, who is said to be on the way to examine his silver properties in the Far West, talked here to-day about the relations between Great Britain and the United States, bimetallism, the partition of China, and Indian finance in very much the same strain as in 1896, when he was a warm admirer of and believer in William J. Bryan.

MANILA, June 13. -- Gen. Lawton unexpectedly fought the liveliest engagement of the war south of Las Pinas to-day. On this occasion American field guns were engaged in the first artillery duel against a Filipino battery concealed in the jungle. Companies F and I of the Twenty-first Infantry at one time were nearly surrounded by a large body of insurgents, but the Americans cut their way out with heavy loss.

The Mazet investigating committee resumed its sessions yesterday and continued its inquiry into the work of the Department of Taxes and Assessments. Commissioner William F. Grell and several of the Deputy Commissioners were examined and light was thrown on the manner in which assessments have been increased since the new charter went into effect.

BALTIMORE, June 13. -- Baltimore and Brooklyn played a double-header to-day and broke even. Six singles, a two-base hit, two bases on balls, and three errors in the seventh inning of the opening game gave the Baltimores eight runs and a victory.

JACKSON, Miss., June 13. -- At a mass convention held in Yazoo City to-day the Hon. John Sharpe Williams made formal announcement of his candidacy for the long term of the United States Senate, commencing March 4, 1901. Williams is at present a member of Congress from the Fifth District, and his entrance complicates the Senatorial race between Gov. McLaurin and "Private" John Allen considerably.
The steamboats Cepheus and Pegasus of the Iron Steamboat Company that make trips to Coney Island grounded off Norton's Point yesterday.

VIENNA, June 13. -- The stock market here to-day was unfavorably influenced by the weakness of the Berlin and Frankfort Boersen.

WASHINGTON, June 13. -- Prof. Ernst Maas of New York, formerly chemical expert of the Glucose Sugar Refining Company of Chicago, testified before the Industrial Commission to-day that when he refused to sign a protest to Congress against the passage of the Mason Pure Food bill the company stopped his salary, though he had a five-year contract.

Secretary GAGE in the unpleasing and thankless task he has assumed of defending the President's "step backward" in the reform of the civil service has sought to explain it by the plea that the Civil Service Commission could not or would not furnish lists of persons from whom the exempted places could be filled after competitive examination.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 13. -- This evening Gordon McKay entertained about forty guests at dinner, after which a dance was enjoyed. The dance was given in honor of Miss Joujou Converse, daughter of Capt. and Mrs. George A. Converse. The table decorations were American Beauty roses, and the recently renovated ballroom was used for dancing for the first time since the changes were made.

OMAHA, Neb., June 13. -- A tornado struck the town of Herman this evening and practically wiped the place out of existence. Herman is a place of about 300 inhabitants, in the extreme northern part of Washington County. It is on the line of the Chicago, St. Paul, Minneapolis and Omaha Railway.

Wallace MacFarlane was the defendant in a suit brought before Justice Andrews, in the Supreme Court yesterday, by a former client, Mrs. Marie E. Suttie, who seeks to recover $10,000. Mrs. Suttie asserts that in 1888 Mr. MacFarlane was her counsel, and as such she ordered him to bid in certain lands advertised for sale in the Real Estate Exchange.

WASHINGTON, June 13. -- The Dewey Home Fund Committee has not yet received information from the "friend of Admiral Dewey," who is said to be responsible for a statement published here and elsewhere, that Admiral Dewey has sent word that he will not receive the gift proposed to be offered to him of a home in Washington.

GUANAJAY, Pinar del Rio, Cuba, June 13. -- Lieut. Col. William H. Bisbee arrived here this morning and began paying the Cuban troops, many of whom were waiting. They received their shares of the American gratuity with enthusiasm, seeming to be very grateful for an opportunity to return to their homes with funds enough to meet their immediate necessities.
WASHINGTON, D.C., June 13. -- The following cablegram has been received at the Navy Department from the Commander of the Newark:
PITTSBURG, June 13. -- The annual meeting of stockholders of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company, adjourned from June 6, was held in this city to-day.

PARIS, June 13. -- Baron de Christiani, who assaulted President Loubet with a cane at the Auteuil races on June 4, was sentenced to-day in the Correctional Police Court at the Palace of Justice to four years' imprisonment and to pay the costs of the trial.

BERLIN, June 13. -- The Cologne Gazette to-day, referring to the stories of German hostility to arbitration at The Hague, declared that Germany at present stands by Article VIII, of the Russian programme, providing for the formation of a tribunal of arbitration as the occasion requires, adding:

THE HAGUE, June 13. -- The Sub-Committee of the Red Cross Section met to-day, Prof. Asser of the Dutch delegation presiding, to hear the report of Prof. Louis Renault of the French delegation on the extension of Geneva Convention principles to naval warfare.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, June 8. -- An exodus has set in from Puerto Rico. The reduction of the military forces and their return to the United States have brought about a decided change in many Puerto Rican towns. What the agricultural classes lost by the recent depression in their products was partially regained by the merchants, who sold liberally to the army and the soldiers.

Abram S. Hewitt, ex-Mayor of New York and for ten years a member of Congress from this city, is now a legal resident of New Jersey. Toward the latter part of 1898 Mr. Hewitt took the necessary steps to change his citizenship from New York to Ringwood, N.J., where he has maintained a homestead for about fifty years.

CHICAGO, June 13. -- With the approach of the end of the time allowed for the filing of personalty schedules, the Assessors are learning some novel reasons from property owners for not scheduling. The representative of a large corporation said to-day that if his concern were scheduled, its creditors would attach its property within a day after the publication of the schedules.

The threatened turning down of Frank Bulkley as the Republican leader of the Twenty-ninth District was accomplished last night at a meeting of the district delegation to the County Committee held at the Plaza Republican Club.

MANILA, June 13. -- Information, believed to be reliable, has reached here of the assassination of Gen. Luna and his aide-de-camp, Lieut. Pasco Ramon, June 8, by Aguinaldo's guard at the headquarters of Aguinaldo. FISHKILL LANDING, June 13. -- The police of this place are looking for Marion Chapman, three years old, of Brooklyn, who, the girl's mother says, has been hidden away. Mrs. Chapman appeared before Judge Rogers a few days ago and asked the aid of the authorities. She said she thinks her sister-in-law, Ida Chapman, has brought the child here.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 13. -- The annual meeting and banquet of the Princeton University Alumni Association were the features of to-day's commencement programme.

Although there were two stakes on the card for decision at the Gravesend track yesterday, the sport was of the most commonplace character, with no event to set the blood a-tingling. In money value the Gazelle Stakes for three-year-old fillies was the most valuable. It was a run of a mile and an eighth, and had but five starters, the prize going to ex-Corporation Counsel Clark's filly.

WASHINGTON, June 13. -- Acting Secretary Meiklejohn issued an order to-day directing that the number of enlisted men in each company of infantry regiments serving in or ordered to the Philippines be increased from 112 to 128. Fifteen full regiments and two battalions each of two other regiments will be subject to this order.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., June 13. -- The First Battalion of the Twenty-third Regiment, which is out on scout duty and practicing soldier life, broke camp at Crofts to-day and moved out to Oscawanna Lake, where they are camping.

" Bob" Fitzsimmons, the pugilist, was voted a nuisance by the busy men of Wall Street yesterday. Shortly after 1 o'clock Fitzsimmons, who was accompanied by Martin Julian, shambled into Broad Street from Wall Street with a couple of hundred idlers and messenger boys trailing after him.

BUFFALO, June 13. -- A serious encounter took place to-night as a result of the employment of non-union men in the freight houses in place of strikers. To these non-union men the epithet "scab" was hurled frequently throughout the day by ore handlers.
It is reported that the South German Reinsurance Company contemplates entering the United States.

The Directors of the Manhattan Railway Company held their quarterly meeting yesterday and declared the regular quarterly dividend of 1 per cent. on the stock, including the recent issue of $18,000,000 for electrical equipment, financial adjustments, and betterments. Treasurer Daniel W. McWilliams denied a report that at the meeting the decision by Justice Nash against Manhattan for more than $2,000,000 of taxes due from 1894 to 1898 was discussed.

WICHITA, Kan., June 13. -- Miss Julia Roberts was married to Allan Denton at Iola yesterday. The bride confessed at the altar that she did not love the man whom she was to marry, but she was marrying him to prevent the foreclosure of a mortgage and the loss of the old homestead. Denton was the possessor of this mortgage, and he said he would cancel it if Miss Roberts would become his bride.

NEWTON, N.J., June 13. -- James and Jason Campbell of this place were shot last night by Constable John Hotalen while resisting arrest. James Campbell died this morning from his wounds, and it is thought Jason Campbell cannot recover.

BRISTOL, R.I., June 13. -- The big Oregon pine mainmast of the cup defender Columbia was successfully stepped this afternoon. Preparations that were going on from early morning to accomplish the task resulted in the stick being set in place at 5:20 o'clock. The mast was lifted from its resting place on the south wharf by means of the derrick on the steam lighter Archer of Fall River owned by Capt. Job Terry.

Masten of Masten Nichols, who appears for Mr. Baudouine's many creditors, subjected the petitioner to a searching examination.
LONDON, June 13. -- Mme. Sarah Bernhardt has arranged to play "Hamlet" on June 29 in the famous theatre at Stratford-on-Avon, the town where Shakespeare was born.

Risse, Chief Topographical Engineer and Engineer of Construction, accompanying a drawing, showing the location of the proposed improvement with the changes it would involve.

WASHINGTON, June 14. -- The preparation of vermuth in Italy and France has been made the subject of special investigation by the United States Consuls in those countries, and the results are published by the Bureau of Foreign Commerce of the Department of State. The chief centres of the manufacture of vermuth are Turin, Italy, and Marseilles, France.

WASHINGTON, June 14. -- Henry O. Havemeyer, President of the American Sugar Refining Company, was examined by the Industrial Commission to-day in connection with its investigation of trusts. His testimony related almost wholly to the sugar industry, and he opened with a vigorous attack upon the customs tariff. This attack was made in a written statement, which the witness read in a ringing voice.

WILMINGTON, Del., June 14. -- J. Rogers Maxwell, who for years has been a prominent figure in yacht-racing circles, has finally adopted steam as a motive power for his pleasure craft, and his new steam yacht Kismet was launched this afternoon from the yards of Pusey Jones, this city. CINCINNATI, Ohio, June 14. -- It costs nothing to make and sell gas. The Cincinnati Gas Company can sell it at 75 cents a thousand feet or 5 cents a thousand feet, and the price it charges will all be profit. The by-products, chief of which is coke, more than pay the cost of producing the gas.

CHICAGO, June 14. -- The Pullman Palace Car Company has received a big order from Chevalier Boutelle, who represents large railway interests in the Argentine Republic and Buenos Ayres and has been in Chicago for some days looking over plants and manufactories. His syndicate, which represents $150,000,000 of English capital, has heretofore done all its buying in England.

Although there were a stake race and two handicaps on the card for the Gravesend races yesterday, the sport was, on the whole, much of the consolation order. There were surprises for the bookmakers when Gaze won the opening dash at six furlongs, with 10 to 1 against her and when Gulden landed the race for maiden two-year-olds at 15 to 1.

THE HAGUE, June 14. -- It is now expected that the Peace Conference will not adjourn before the middle of July. It is thought that the labors of the delegates will be finished before that time, but there is the additional question of the acceptance by the powers of the decisions adopted by the conference.

WASHINGTON, June 14. -- Thomas F. Lyons of North Carolina was to-day appointed a First Lieutenant in the United States Marine Corps. He was formerly an enlisted man in that corps, was promoted to the grade of Sergeant, and was the only non-commissioned officer found qualified for a commission. The appointment of a non-commissioned officer to the grade of First Lieutenant is almost without precedent in the history of the Marine Corps.

CHICAGO, June 14. -- Passenger traffic affairs in Eastern territory are reported to be in bad shape. The Baltimore and Ohio to-day announced a cut of $3.60 in the round trip Summer tourist rate between Chicago and Pittsburg, and it is the impression that the lower charge will be used to demoralize the regular one-way business.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 14. -- This afternoon Mrs. A. Livingston Mason gave a reception at her cottage, on Halidon Hill, in honor of Admiral Sampson and the officers of the North Atlantic Squadron, and the affair was very largely attended by the cottagers, the army and navy contingent of the city, besides a very large attendance of fleet officers.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, June 6. -- Montserrat, one of the lesser Leeward Islands, which is blessed with telegraphic isolation and communicates with the outside world by mail only twice a month, has just sent forth a somewhat remarkable earthquake story. For some time, a period apparently coincident with the recent seismic disturbances on the mainland, extending from Argentina through Brazil and the Guianas northward as far as Salvador, Montserrat had felt repeated shocks.

ROME, May 8. -- Much comment and discussion has been aroused here by the recent declarations of the Minister Palumbo regarding the seriously defective state of the Italian Navy at present, despite the enormous expenditures lavished upon its maintenance during the last few years.

PARIS, June 5. -- The "demonstration" or "manifestation," as the French call it, or, as it would be designated in New York, the riot, which occurred yesterday at the famous race course at Auteuil, on the occasion of the Steeple Chase meeting, the most socially important event of the gay season in Paris, was witnessed with amazement by hundreds of Americans who were among the fifty thousand spectators present.

POUGHKEEPSIE, June 14. -- The Vassar College Commencement exercises proper were held to-day. The literary exercises were participated in by the following senators: Grace Hannah Robbins of St. Paul, Adele Heyworth Merwin of New Haven, Mary Louise Brinckerhoff of Mount Vernon, Mary Louise Hosmer of Oswego, N.Y.; Jean Hamilton of Oswego, N.Y., and Leila Clement Spaulding of New York City.

FRANKLIN, Ky., June 14. -- The discrimination which the Louisville and Nashville Railroad has been making as sales agent of coal mines in favor of manufacturing enterprises has aroused the wrath of the State officials here. In consequence L.B. Finn, County Attorney, and John E. Byers, Commonwealth's Attorney, filed suits against the Louisville and Nashville Railroad Company, amounting in the aggregate to $24,000.

PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad, West Indies, May 20. -- President McKinley having revoked, by proclamation, the act of Congress under which the United States tonnage duty was suspended on vessels arriving at American ports from the British colonies of Trinidad and Tobago, the Legislative Council here will shortly be asked to arrange the tariff on shipping in order to make this a free port and thus gain relief from the measures of the United States.

HERMAN, Neb., June 14. -- The fatalities caused by the tornado last evening were not so numerous as first reported, but the village was about completely wiped out, only two or three houses, the Methodist Church, and the school building being left.

The Bostons won the final game of their series with the New Yorks at the Polo Grounds yesterday afternoon, but it was a close call. There might have been a different tale to tell had the locals played baseball as it should be played. A little more judgment should have been used in making plays when runs were imminent.
PHILADELPHIA, June 14. -- The anniversary of the adoption of the American flag was observed here, the birthplace of the National emblem, with appropriate ceremonies.

A warrant for the arrest of Lawyer Henry C. Henderson, charged with disorderly conduct before the Mazet investigating committee, was issued in the Centre Street Police Court yesterday by Magistrate Olmsted, who also declared the lawyer's $500 bail forfeited.

A company to be known as the Union Trust Company of New Jersey was organized in Newark yesterday. MANILA, June 14. -- Before dark last night the Fourteenth Infantry swam the Zapote River, charged, and carried the trenches, a heavy fusillade of artillery preparing the way and covering the crossing. The insurgents broke for the woods before the Fourteenth reached them.

LONDON, June 14. -- One of the principal literary features of the first number of Lady Randolph Churchill's new magazine, The Anglo-Saxon Review, to be issued within the next ten days, will be a paper by Whitelaw Reid, on the advances in international law and the changes in National policy resulting from the Treaty of Paris, which he helped to negotiate.

The most ambitious Summer church effort ever undertaken in this city will be inaugurated, if all goes well, on June 18. It consists of a vast outdoor service enterprise, backed by the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian, Amity Baptist, Calvary Baptist, Central Presbyterian Churches, and the Church of the Disciples and Church of the Strangers.

NEWBURG, N.Y., June 14. -- George Appo, the criminal and "green goods" man, was this afternoon released from the Matteawan State Hospital, having been declared sane by Justice Barnard in the Special Supreme Court, sitting at Poughkeepsie. Appo has been an inmate of the Matteawan State Hospital for some months.

A meeting of prominent Tammany men was to have been held at the Waldorf-Astoria last night to talk over with James Boothby Burke-Roche, M.P., the proposed purchase of the Lakes of Killarney for conversion into an Irish National Park.
TROY, June 14. -- Commencement exercises of the Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute were held this evening. Capt. Henry C. Taylor of the battleship Indiana made an address.
PARIS June 14. -- President Loubet received M. Poincare this morning for the purpose of intrusting him with the task of forming a new Cabinet.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., June 14. -- The First Battalion of the Twenty-third marched into camp at 11 o'clock this morning, tired, dirty, and perspiring, but in good spirits after a march of nine miles from Lake Oscawanna. The battalion was aroused at 4 o'clock this morning, and after a few scouting movements by detached parties the camp was struck and the march back to camp was begun.

The Hanson Place Baptist Church of Brooklyn decided at a meeting held on Tuesday night to erect a new church building. The resolution adopted name $200,000 as the sum to be raised, $125,000 in cash, and subscriptions being necessary before the work can be started. The date of dedication is fixed for October, 1904, when the church will be twenty-five years old.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., June I4. -- The Deacons of the First Congregational Church of this place have requested the Rev. Howard T. Widdemer, the founder and pastor of the church, to resign. This action follows an informal investigation lasting two weeks into rumors which had been circulated relative to the minister.

The trial of George Beauregard Barrow, the leader of the kidnappers of Marion Clarke, was begun yesterday before Justice Fursman in the Criminal Branch of the Supreme Court. Arthur W. Clarke and Mrs. Clarke, the parents of the child, and Bella Anderson, alias Carrie Jones, the nurse girl, testified.

The Ward Line freight steamer Macedonia, which was rammed by the Old Dominion Liner Hamilton, at 6 o'clock on Tuesday evening in the fog off the New Jersey Coast, went down three hours later in six fathoms of water about seven miles south of the Scotland Lightship and about two miles off Seabright.

HARRISBURG, Penn., June 14. -- Four hundred and thirty-five representatives of the Democracy of Pennsylvania met here today for the purpose of nominating candidates for Supreme Court Judge, Superior Court Judge, and State Treasurer. At midnight the convention adjourned until tomorrow morning without having accomplished the first and most important piece of work cut out for it; namely, the selection of a candidate for Supreme Court Judge.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 14. -- To-day marked the closing exercises of Princeton University's one hundred and fifty-second annual commencement. The long programme began with a procession of Trustees, Faculty members, alumni, and the graduating class. The line of march was from Nassau Hall across the campus to Alexander Hall.

The Wetmore divorce case, which has been before the courts of this State in various phases for many years, was the subject of a decision by Justice Scott, in favor of Mr. Wetmore, in Supreme Court, Special Term, yesterday. Annette B. Wetmore secured a decree of absolute divorce from William B. Wetmore in April, 1892, and the custody of their three children was awarded to her.

CHICAGO, June 14. -- In the arrest of Bartholmae Kost, a young cabinetmaker of Vienna, Austria, the Chicago police believe they have cleared up the mystery surrounding the death of Marie Veodicka of Vienna, a crime which created a sensation in Austria, and for the perpetrator of which the police of two continents have been searching for some time.

LONDON, June 14. -- At noon to-day the twelfth round of the International Chess Masters' Tournament was begun at St. Stephen's Hall, Westminster. The pairing was arranged according to Round 4 of the Berger system. The players were paired as follows: Tschigorin vs. Blackburne, Tinsley vs. Lasker, Cohn vs. Steinitz, Showalter vs. Maroczy, Janowski vs. Pillsbury, Lee vs. Mason; Bird and Schlechter had byes.

ALBANY, June 14. -- The State Civil Service Commission has decided that in the certification from the eligible lists of prison guards, residents of the First and Second Judicial Districts shall be certified for appointment in Sing Sing Prison; residents of the Third, Fourth, and Fifth for appointment in Clinton Prison, and residents of the Sixth, Seventh, and Eighth Districts for appointment in Auburn.

PHILADELPHIA, June 15. -- The one hundred and forty-third annual commencement of the University of Pennsylvania took place to-day in the Academy of Music. Nearly every State was represented among the graduates. The picturesque feature of the exercises was the procession of students, Trustees, and instructors, headed by Provest Harrison, which marched from the college grounds to the Academy.

WASHINGTON, June 15. -- The members of the commission appointed by the President to examine into the question of the most feasible route for a canal across the Isthmus of Panama met this morning in the Corcoran Building. The only absentee was ex-Senator Pasco of Florida. Admiral Walker was elected President, after which the commission called upon the President in a body to pay their respects.

WASHINGTON, June 15. -- The Agricultural Department to-day issued a circular giving the substance of reports received by it up to June 10 on the condition of foreign crops. It says that a British commercial estimate tentatively puts the world's wheat crop of 1899 at 2,504,000,000 bushels, against 2,748,000,000 bushels in 1898, a reduction of 244,000,000 bushels, or nearly 8.9 per cent.

Forty-one hundredths of an inch of rain fell during the course of an hour, which is about one-third as much as had fallen during the three preceding months.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., June 15. -- The Sheriff of Randolph County, with a posse, went to the house of W'alter Phillips, colored, near Yiredowee, last night, for the purpose of arresting his son, Hazel, aged twenty, for a crimp committed in the neighborhood. HARRISBURG, Penn., June 15. -- The contest before the Democratic State Convention for Supreme Court Judge ended this evening with the nomination of Judge S.L. Mestrezat of Fayette County on the twenty-eighth ballot. Charles J. Reilly of Williamsport, permanent Chairman of the convention, was nominated by acclamation for Judge of the Superior Court, and William T. Creasy of Columbia was the unanimous choice for State Treasurer.
