LONDON, June 15. -- The second test cricket match between the visiting Australian team and an ele;en representing all England opened at Lord's grounds to-day with magnificent w-either. There were about 25,000 people present. Tickets for the match have been much sought after, the price of seats ranging from $10 downward.

NEWBURG, June 15. -- For the last twenty years the question of consolidation of the twin villages of Fishkill Landing and Matteawan has been under discussion. It has been admitted generally that the consolidation ought to take place, but whenever a meeting has been held on the subject there has usually been an agreement all around except when it came to the question of the name.

BALTIMORE, June 15. -- Options have been secured on 150 large clothing manufacturing establishments throughout the country by Samuel Rosenthal, Jr., of this city, who for the lust four months has been actively engaged in forming a gigantic clothing combination, to be incorporated under the laws of New Jersey, and to be known as the American Clothing Manufacturing Company.

OXFORD, Ohio, June 15. -- Dr. W.O. Thompson, President of Miami University, was yesterday elected President of Ohio State University at Columbus. The Trustees of Miami University increased the salary of Dr. Thompson to the amount of the salary at Ohio State University, and it is now thought that he will remain here.

NEWPORT, June 15. -- Many improvements have been made at the golf club under the management of Lispenard Stewart, Chairman of the House Committee. The clubhouse has been put in excellent order, all the floors having been polished and new rugs having been placed in the ladies' tearoom.

CHICAGO, June 15. -- Chicago banks must pay taxes on the book value of their capital stock, without deduction for unearned interest, collection charges, Government bonds, and real estate. That decision was reached by the Board of Assessors after a long session, convened to consider claims filed by State and National banks for exemptions on the grounds stated.

CLEVELAND, June 15. -- While the sixth day of the street railway men's strike started peaceably enough, there was serious rioting before nightfall, and several non-union men were taken to hospitals in consequence. The trouble began shortly after noon, near the Lake View car barns on Euclid Avenue.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., June 15. -- National Republican Committeeman Henry C. Payne of Wisconsin, who returned from New York to-day, where he attended a conference of the Senate Finance Committee, makes a statement that, in his opinion, a bill will be formulated at the coming session of Congress that will place the United States upon a gold standard basis.

The Sixty-ninth Regiment, in command of Col., Puffy, occupied tile State target ranges at Creedmoor, L. I., yesterday. Out of the 240 men who were present, 148 succeeded in qualifying as marksmen, i number of commissioned officers of the old One Hundred and Sixty-ninth Reg4ment took part in the shooting.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, June 15. -- For thirty-six hours the town of Brackett has been under water as the result of a serious cloudburst early yesterday morning. Houses had been washed away with all of the stock of goods they contained.

Two outbreaks, both eruptions from smoldering district fights, contributed a volcanic character to the meeting of the Republican County Committee, at the Murray Hill Lyceum last night. But both were suppressed without serious disturbance.

PARIS, June 15. -- The first formal meeting of the Venezuelan Arbitration Commission opened this morning. The arbitrators, counsel, and others began assembling at the Foreign Office shortly before 11 o'clock. They were received by the Minister of Foreign Affairs, M. Delcasse, in the apartment in which the tribunal will sit.

CHICAGO, June 15. -- The general liquidation of corporations operating in America but controlled by British capital is the result predicted from the operation of the income tax law of Great Britain by Joseph Theurer, President of the Peter Schoenhofen Brewing Company, Limited and Otto C. Butz, attorney for the corporation.
WASHINGTON. June 15. -- The Standish has sailed from Norfolk for Annapolis.

The first meeting of the New York and Brooklyn baseball teams at Washington Park yesterday afternoon resulted in a victory for the Brooklyns. Only part of the game was played, owing to a rainstorm, but it was enough to give the Brooklyns a victory by a score of 6 to 2.

PHILADE.LDHIA, June 15. -- .kt a meeting of the Board of Directors of the Northern Central Railway Company, held to-day, A. J. Cassatt resiqned as a Director and was elected President of the com4)any. The resignation left two vacancies, tile other being caused 1)3' the death of John N'. llutchinsoll.

THE HAGUE, June 15. -- The Red Cross Sub-Committee of the Peace Conference met to-day, Prof. Asser of the Dutch delegation, presiding. Prof. Louis Renault of the French delegation explained that certain modification had been made in the report, meeting the wishes expressed by his colleagues at the last session.

A violent storm late in the afternoon yesterday that gave the parched links of the Oakland Golf Club at Bayside, L.I., a much needed soaking contributed incidentally to the amusement of a piazza full of golfers who, having finished their contests, watched with glee the finishing plays of a few belated competitors in the annual open tournament as they toiled through the rain and soggy greens.

PARIS, June 15. -- The persons arrested in connection with the riots at Auteuil June 4, when President Loubet was assaulted on the race course, were arraigned in the Tenth Correctional Court to-day. Many representatives of high society were present, including a number of ladies in rich toilettes.

OXFORD, Ohio, June 15. -- The culmination of the diamond anniversary jubilee of Miami University occurred to-day, when a class of sixteen men was graduated and Whitelaw Reid of the class of '56 delivered the commencement address upon "Our New Duties." Speaking of the responsibilities which fell upon the United States at the close of the peace treaty with Spain, Mr. Reid said, among other things:

What is it we are trying to do in the Philippines? That is the question that is forcing itself upon public attention. If it is merely to do what the Spaniards did, to hold possession of Manila and such other ports and places from which revenue may be derived, without troubling ourselves about the "hinterland," then it seems that we are doing too much and wasting valuable lives.

HIGHLAND FALLS, N.Y., June 15. -- The body of a than apparently fifty years old was found in Cranston's Grove last night. Three soldiers who had been searching for deserters found the body in a clearing. The head rested on a rock and the gTound in the vicinity bore evidences of a struggle. There were several pools of blood near the body.

HAVANA, June 15. -- Lieut. Col. William H. Bisbee of the First Infantry arrived here this morning from Guanajay, Province of Pinar del Rio, where he had been paying the Cuban troops, to obtain more funds and to confer with Gov. Gen. Brooke regarding additional pay days there. With Gen. Brooke's approval, the payment of troops will be continued four days more at Guanajay.

In your issue of June 14, under the heading, "Nathan Hale Memorial," occur many inaccuracies, and it is due to the Daughters of the American Revolution -- if that is the society that is furnishing funds to place the "Nathan Hale Schoolhouse" in proper repair and is caring for its preservation -- to be set right regarding the history of said building.

WASHINGTON, June 15. -- The President and Mrs. McKinley will leave Washington late to-morrow afternoon for Holyoke, Mass., where they go to attend the commencement exercises of Mount Holyoke College, at South Hadley. Their niece, Miss Grace McKinley, will be graduated from that institution this year. The trip will occupy from ten days to two weeks.

Friends of Major Thomas F. Lynch, formerly of the Sixty-ninth Regiment, said yesterday he would shortly be elected Colonel of the Irish Volunteers. The volunteers at present are in command of Col. Scanlan, who took the position after Col. James Moran was deposed. Col. Scanlan, however, only accepted the command of the organization temporarily, and prominent members of the Irish Volunteers assert that he desires to see Major Lynch succeed to the position.
PARIS, June 15. -- M. Poincare informed President Loubet this morning that he would accept the task of forming a Cabinet. He will take the War portfolio, in addition to the Presidency of the Council.

The New York Realty, Bond, Exchange and Trust Company has bought from Harriet L. Schuyler 520 and 522 Broadway, five-story buildings on a plot 50 by 100, on the east side of the street, about 60 feet south of Spring Street. The deal was negotiated through Brokers John F. Doyle Son.

ST. LOUIS, June 15. -- The Inter-State Commerce Commission met here to-day to hear testimony relating to shipping rates, both domestic and foreign. Mr. Knapp, Chairman of the commission, presided, and the other members were Messrs. Prouty and Calhoun. Nearly every railroad company in the South and West interested in the question before the commission were represented by prominent officials, as were also several commercial bodies, including the Chicago and Kansas City Boards of Trade.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., June 15. -- The Ohio Society of California will to-day end to President McKinley an invitation engraved on a plate of gold, asking him to become the guest of that organization in this city. The society is already raising a. fund for his entertainment, it 'being generally believed that the Chief Executive will visit the Pacific Coast later in the year.

LONDON, June 15. -- The United States Ambassador, Joseph H. Choate; First Secretary Henry White, Second Secretary J.R. Carter, and Lieut. Colwell, .the United States Naval Attache, have joined the society throngs at Ascot, where "Tod" Sloan to-day won the New Biennial Stakes (second year of the thirty-sixth) on Lord William Beresford's three-year-old chestnut colt Cainan.

The first sale of the Hudson River Tunnel Railroad Company was held yesterday at the sheds at the west end of the tunnel, at Fifteenth Street, Jersey City. It was conducted by Special Waster in Chancery Randolph Parmly. There was only one bid, of $300,000, by Frederick B. Jennings of Stetson, Jennings Russell, attorneys for the American bondholders, and for that sum the property was knocked down to him.

WASHINGTON, June 15. -- Congressional indorsement, with the specific statement that the applicant indorsed is to be charged to the quota of the Senators and Representatives making the indorsement, will be necessary to enable an applicant for a place in the census service to become worthy the attention of the director or likely to be considered as eligible for employment.

The Washington Post yesterday printed a letter as from Lieut. Commander Hodgson, declaring the conversation which The Sun has printed as occurring between Hodgson and Rear Admiral Schley at the time of the Brooklyn's loop at Santiago to be a falsification. This was the letter:

WASHINGTON, June 15. -- The Industrial Commission held only an afternoon session, and heard but one witness to-day, J.N. Jarvie of the firm of Arbuckle Brother, and Manager of the firm's sugar refining business. Mr. Jarvie's testimony was brief. He was easy and courteous in his attitude toward his inquisitors, refusing to answer only one question, viz.: How much it cost his company to refine sugar.

Having seen the fight and having read the report of DEVERY'S testimony, a traveler without further information would say that the Chief of Police was either an idiot or a low knave. He is neither. He is not such a fool as not to know that the law was grossly and triumphantly violated at the fight he witnessed.

Senator HANNA said on the eve of his departure for the baths of Aix that the Democrats would probably "turn down" BRYAN next year. Possibly the Senator has inside information. The big politicians do now and then exchange confidential advices across the party line. But the wayfarer with no helps to knowledge but his eyes and ears can see that BRYAN is losing ground.

BRISTOL, R.I., June 15. -- Progress on the rigging of the Columbia was so far advanced to-night when the riggers completed their day's work on the yacht that the eyes were all spliced in the ends of the steel shrouds, and the metal thimbles for the turn-buckle shackles fitted. The splicing was accomplished in one day.

We are not surprised at the treatment of the Coney Island project by the Board of Public Improvements. As it lay in the mind of Controller COLER it was much too large a plan to receive immediate approval. And still our own criticism of the plan of the Controller would be that it is too small rather than too large.

With the running of the Brooklyn Derby, for three-year-olds, at a mile and a half, and the Tremont Stakes, for two-year-olds, at three-quarters of a mile -- the furthest horses of that age are allowed to run at this season of the year -- the Spring meeting of the Brooklyn Jockey Club was brought to a close yesterday.

LONDON, June 16. -- The Odessa correspondent of The Daily News says: "Emperor Nicholas, it is reported here, is much disappointed at the prospect of the outcome of the Peace Conference. In the opinion of his advisers, no further hope need be indulged that sufficient success will be attained to warrant the reassembling of the conference.

We conceive that THE TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW is doing a public service of its kind in reporting literally the remarks which Dean VAN AMRINGE, in his capacity of Acting President of Columbia, had to make, at the commencement of that institution last week, to the eminent persons whom it delighted to honor by complimentary degrees.

LANSING, Mich., June 16. -- Gov. Pingree marked the closing day of the Legislature by sending in veto messages which were incidentally made a medium for criticising the Legislature for alleged failure to carry out the people's wishes. The Governor vetoed the amended Beet Sugar Bounty bill, and also a bill appropriating $40,000 for a State building and exhibit at the Pan-American Exposition, at Buffalo.
SING SING, N.Y., June 16. -- George B. Barrow, the kidnapper, entered the prison at 3:15 o'clock this afternoon and was put in Cell 1.059. He has not been assigned to any work as yet.

Mr. Yeats has written not a little of readable verse, and a new volume from his pen is sure to meet with a kindly welcome from many readers. In the little book called "The Wind Among the Reeds" the author has sought to embody his feeling for Irish song. He has endeavored to voice the emotions of the humbler Irish people, and to view the poetic side of their life.

FORT SCOTT, Kan., June 16. -- Deputy United States Marshals Mooney of this city and Trigg of Wichita, with a number of assistants, left here yesterday on a special train for Yale and Fleming, Kan., to serve sweeping injunctions on the union miners at those towns. The injunctions were issued from the Federal court here upon orders from Judge Hook, who heard the application in Chambers, at Leavenworth.

Possibly "Holley" may derive some comfort from the knowledge that he is not quite alone in his opinion of "David Harum," as expressed in the last SATURDAY REVIEW. Before reading it I received a letter from a relative whose judgment of literature I consider particularly good, (because it agrees with mine,) in which it was said, "A friend persuaded me to read 'David Harum,' and now 'I am laying for him.'"

It was only to be expected that the extraordinarily high prices realized for pictures by American artists at the Thomas B. Clarke sale would result in the throwing upon the market of other collections of such works. For many years the experience of those who sold paintings by native artists was uniformly an unhappy one.

In THE TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW for May 13 appeared a notice of Mrs. Oliphant's "Autobiography," and now that the American edition of the book is ready, so interesting has it been found that it calls for a second notice.

Underground rapid transit between the Boroughs of Manhattan and Brooklyn is promised within the next two years. The beginning of work on this important project without further delay is promised by a company composed of eminent financiers, railroad men, and public-spirited citizens.

All who have read it will agree with Miss Rives, who says in her letter to THE TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW that "One of the strongest and most remarkable poems produced of late in America is Prof. Markham's 'The Man with the Hoe.'" The first effect produced by reading the poem is, as she says, "a sudden new sympathy for the man with the hoe."

HAVANA, June 16. -- The greatest confusion exists in the lists of Cuban soldiers at Canajuani. Many of the men cannot collect their $75, as they appear on the rolls as having been promoted to the ranks of officers, of which fact they had no knowledge previously.

LANCASTER, Penn., June 16. -- The stock of W.M. Jacobs, which was confiscated by the Government upon the exposure of the celebrated Jacobs-Kendig-Bredell-Taylor counterfeiting scheme, was sold to-day. The sale attracted a large number of tobacco men, all the big firms in New York, Philadelphia, Baltimore, Richmond, and other Eastern tobacco centres being represented.

I was pleased to read in your issue W.C. Browning's praise of J.A. Altsheler's "A Herald of the West," because he expressed my opinion, too, and I remember when the book appeared R.H. Stoddard, the veteran literary critic, said in The Mail and Express that the author was doing better work in American historical fiction than any other man since Cooper.

Ex-Congressman Perry Belmont, President of the Democratic Club, who sails for Europe to-day on the Campania, expressed himself yesterday as heartily in favor of the nomination of Arthur P. German for the Presidency. It is known that there have been conferences in this city of National Democratic leaders in Mr. Gorman's interests recently.

LONDON, June 16. -- The Star to-day says: "After the racing yesterday at Ascot Sloan appeared on the lawn, and a waiter accidentally upset a glass of liquor over Sloan's clothing. The latter instantly rose from his chair and struck the waiter in the face with a champagne bottle, inflicting severe wounds.
Will the Police Commissioners put Chief DEVERY on trial for the offenses committed and acknowledged by him before the Mazet committee?

Who that has experienced the keen sense of physical delight that waits upon the early morning ramble through the woods but would sacrifice many other pleasures for its perennial cling to the mind? When that is obtained, we honor its possessor by the title of "lover of nature." He can paint the colors, but cannot descant upon their meaning and gorgeousness.

The new building of the Seaside Hospital at New Dorp, Staten Island, was dedicated yesterday afternoon to the work for which it was erected by St. John's Guild. At the invitation of the Trustees of the guild, about 300 persons, most of them women, took a trip to New Dorp on the steamer Hazel Kirke to inspect the new building.

NEWPORT, June 16. -- The yacht Navahoe, belonging to Royal Phelps Carroll, arrived here last evening for the Summer. The sloop yacht Queen Mab is hauled out for repairs. The thirty-footer Carolina, owned by Pembroke Jones, has arrived from Bristol. The Wa Wa and the Vaquero are also here, and the Hera is expected shortly.

Bernard Karsch, a jeweler at 641 Eighth Avenue, builded less wisely than he knew when he complained to the Building Department that the new building of the Franklin Savings Bank, in which he is a Director, projected too far over the sidewalk, to the detriment of his own property, which adjoins the bank's structure on the south.

The Forty-seventh Regiment of Brooklyn spent yesterday at the Creedmoor target ranges. Col. J.G. Eddy was in command, and Capt. J.D. Henry, the Small Arms Practice Inspector of the regiment, directed the shooting. About 200 men were present, most of whom qualified as marksmen. The shooting on the pistol ranges was particularly good, every commissioned officer becoming a marksman.

The Rev. Dr. James Chambers, who for the past seventeen years has been pastor of Calvary Presbyterian Church, will announce his resignation at to-morrow morning's service. It is likely he will be appointed Secretary of the Missionary Department of the Board of Publication of the Presbyterian Church.

BOSTON, June 16. -- An event of interest to all yachtsmen on this side of the Atlantic may develop from the proposition of the Eastern Yacht Club to offer a perpetual challenge cup for competition by the New York. Seawanhaka-Corinthian, Larchmont, and Eastern Yacht Clubs. The announcement of the plan has just been made to the members of the Eastern Yacht Club by the Regatta Committee.

This paraphrase on the familiar rigmarole of "The House that Jack Built" was printed first in an early number of "The Pathfinder," but without the name of the writer. It was said to be "a masterpiece of word-mongering," whose author was unidentified, (but,) whoever he was, must have been a genius at literary construction."

AUSTIN Texas, June 16. -- Adjt. Gen. Thomas Scurry returned to-day from Columbus, Texas, where he had been for several days aiding the force of rangers in preventing a renewal of hostilities between the two factions of that place. He reached there Sunday morning, and found the situation critical.

WASHINGTON, June 16. -- The Industrial Commission to-day heard a statement from P.E. Dowe of New York, President of the Commercial Travelers' National League. Dr. Dowe said the opinion of the commercial men at large was that trusts were a menace to the community. He estimated the number of traveling salesmen in the United States at 350,000, saying that the census figures of 60,000 were grossly incorrect.

LONDON, June 16. -- The dinner given by the Whitefriars Club to Mark Twain (Samuel L. Clemens) this evening at the Hotel Cecil was a remarkable tribute to the author, and at the same time to the friendly relations existing between Great Britain and the United States.

At a hearing before Justice Fursman, in the Criminal Branch of the Supreme Court yesterday, Bartow S. Weeks of counsel for Roland B. Molineux accused Assistant District Attorney Osborne of having declared the members of the May Grand Jury violated their oaths of office. Mr. Weeks's statement was based on an affidavit drawn up by Mr. Osborne.

Anthony Comstock and three of his men, reinforced by three policemen, raided an alleged gambling room at 1,188 Third Avenue last night and arrested Francis J. Trainor, who keeps the saloon at that number, and Charles Lambfred of 318 East Sixty-first Street, who is charged with being the dealer for the game.

HARRISBURG, Penn., June 16. -- The Grand Jury of Dauphin County to-day ignored the bill of indictment against ex-Senator John J. Coyle and Michael J. Costello of Philadelphia, charging them with corruptly soliciting Representative John Engler of Lycoming County to vote to reconsider the McCarrell Jury bill in the House of Representatives last February.

Walter J. Travis and R.C. Watson, Jr., the Oakland and Westbrook representatives, will meet to-day in the final struggle for the chief trophy in the Oakland Golf Club tournament at Bayside, L.I. Expectations, therefore, have not been upset in the present tournament, for although some of the other players might be termed fairly able golfers, none of them can equal the ability of these two.
LONDON, June 16. -- Mr. Andrew Lang is translating the Homeric hymns for Mr. George Allen.
Incorporation, at Trenton of American Mining Company with a capital of $1,000,000.
C.R. Gregor's Sons have sold for the estate of Francis Lahey to August Oppenheimer the plot, 102 by 100.8, on the north side of Eighty-sixth Street, 133 feet west of Park Avenue.

THE HAGUE, June 16. -- The Drafting Committee for the arbitration tribunal scheme, which should have met to-day, adjourned its sitting to Monday next. The ostensible reason for the adjournment was the absence of Baron Estournelles de Constant of the French delegation, who drew up the minutes.
Two perils confront the Mazet committee, from both of which it may be triumphantly delivered by the fortitude of its Chairman and its counsel.

MANILA, June 16. -- A Spanish officer who has been a prisoner in the hands of the rebels, and who was released by Aguinaldo, has come through the American lines to Manila. He claims to have been a witness of the assassination of Gen. Luna.

LONDON, June 16. -- Still another Dumas play will be in the London bills next Autumn. This is Sydney Grundy's long-talked-of adaptation of "La Tulip Noire," which has been kept back at the Haymarket Theatre by the long runs, first of "The Little Minister" and then of "The Manoeuvres of Jane."

Your correspondent, Hattie Erminie Rives, in your issue of May 27, has, much to my gratification, some words of praise for the poem, "The Man With the Hoe," and I quite agree with her that these unfortunates, of which the poet's subject is a type, do not feel their miseries as keenly as the artists and authors who portray their degradation.

In THE TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW of May 27 there is a letter signed F.J. and headed "Hamerton's Intellectual Life." This is a book, in my opinion, of great value, but in his eulogy of it your correspondent does not, I think, give an accurate representation of it, in the allusions he makes to some authors quoted there.

My dear SATURDAY REVIEW, what is the secret of "David Harum's" popularity? Why, the business man has discovered it. Who among the people one meets is most enthusiastic about "David Harum"? It is the man who never reads anything but his newspaper and the magazines he buys on his business trips, and who doesn't care a straw for literature.
I have never trespassed on your time or space before, but I feel that I should like to say a word in commendation of a little book that I have just finished reading.

The reported decision of some of the New York publishers to follow the example of an English publishing house and describe their books, hereafter, in catalogues and newspaper advertisements, by length, width, and weight, instead of using the old forms, Svo, 12mo, and the like, is probably "in the line of progress.'' Alas -- as the poet said --

I hesitate to criticise, and tardily, too, so eminent a writer as Mr. Edmund Gosse, a reputed authority on eighteenth century literature; but I may be pardoned for calling attention to a few careless errors that occur in his entertaining "essayette" on "Unhappy Welsted," that appeared in Literature of date of April 28.

I herewith send you a copy of a letter written by an old gentleman nearly eighty years of age which I believe will interest numerous readers of your SATURDAY REVIEW as a most excellent sample of a style of composition, now almost extinct, whose chief characteristics, a quaint, extreme verbosity and sonorous, well-rounded sentences, have made it unavailable to the busy world of the fin de siecle, even if its retention were desirable.

It is a little singular to find the old question of the island first discovered by Columbus coming to the front once more, and to notice in the discussion of it such slight reference to the original authorities and a complete silence concerning such writers as Mr. Rulolf Cronau, Don Juan Ignacio de Armas, and Lieut. J.B. Murdock of the United States Navy.

A spacious, light, and roomy villa on a high bluff overlooking the Hudson River at Yonkers is the residence of John Kendrick Bangs, author, editor, and humorist. A short ride from the New York Central station in a carriage or trolley car lands one at Mr. Bangs's place, which is one of a row of detached villas standing in large lots of ground.

MISHAWAKA, Ind., June 16. -- James H. Long has been arrested here charged with robbing a New York bank of a large sum five months ago. The murder of his accomplice is also alleged. Officers have trailed Long since the crimes were committed, finally locating him in a secluded spot four miles east of here.

"The Market Place," the posthumous work of Harold Frederic, published by the Frederick A. Stokes Company, is now selling in its thirteenth thousand, and a third edition is in preparation. The advance orders that are coming in promise a fifth impression at an early date. In other words, the novel, after a few weeks of desultory sales, seems to have "caught on."

Mike Morrissey, the new "Irish Champion," who is scheduled to meet Peter Maher at the Lenox Athletic Club on Tuesday night to decide the Irish heavyweight championship, is the latest aspirant for the pugilistic laurels now worn by Jim Jeffries of California. Surprising things are told of Morrissey's cleverness by men who have seen him box in Ireland.
Reading Celia Thaxter's "Life and Letters," one realizes what possibilities of delight lie in the knowledge of nature at first hand.

MANILA, June 16. -- A large force of rebels attacked Gen. MacArthur's lines at San Fernando at 4:30 o'clock this morning and met with an unexpectedly warm reception. The natives were repulsed with a less of seventy-five killed, thirty prisoners, and many wounded.

Permit me to enter a gentle protest against the tone of W.L. Alden's London letters. I do it with bated breath, as he generally speaks in such an ex cathedra style as to make one feel that criticism of him approximates blasphemy. But I, for one, have not found "Lavengro" (which I have just read) either "utterly dull" or "exasperating."

A certain well-known small, bookshop in New York is responsible for the statement that many customers will only buy new books on the condition that they are sent home with their pages cut. Such people know little of the minor pleasures of reading, the sum total of which goes to make up the hook lover's crowning happiness.

Mr. Daly's first library was sold Oct. 14, 1878, and following days, by George A. Leavitt Co. of this city as "the valuable and interesting collection formed by a prominent American playwright, consisting of an unusually choice and desirable assemblage of books relating to the drama, including many extra illustrated and unique copies." There were 1,117 lots in the auction catalogue, and the sale is said to have realized over $10,000.

Speculation concerning a successor to the Rev. Dr. William H.P. Faunce in the pastorate of the Fifth Avenue Baptist Church has already begun. At this early date there are three factors in the situation. These are John D. Rockefeller, the Rev. Dr. H.M. Wharton of Baltimore, and the Rev. Dr. A.C. Dixon of Brooklyn.

George Beauregard Barrow, who planned the abduction of Baby Marlon Clarke, passed last night in the State prison at Sing Sing. He was found guilty of the crime of kidnapping yesterday and sentenced by Justice Fursman in the Criminal Branch of the Supreme Court to fourteen years and ten months' imprisonment at hard labor, two months less than the maximum penalty.

CHICAGO, June 16. -- Subscribers for the stock of the National Trust Company, which A.E. Stillwell, the Kansas City Railroad promoter, proposes to establish here, are being actively solicited. It is sought to have underwritten $1,250,000 of stock, of which it is said $950,000 has already been subscribed.

It is not likely that many of your readers agree with what Mr. William L. Alden wrote concerning George Eliot in his literary letter from London published in THE SATURDAY REVIEW of May 6.

BALTIMORE, June 16. -- A number of important changes will be made in the transportation department of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad on July 1. The position of General Superintendent of the Trans-Ohio lines, now held by J.M. Graham, will be abolished, and the jurisdiction of General Superintendent Thomas Fitzgerald will be extended over the main line from Philadelphia to Chicago, including its branches.

LONDON, June 5. -- A most melancholy document is the letter which the Secretary of the Authors' Club has addressed to all persons who propose to have any dealings with publishers. The letter is a criticism of the form of contract with authors, which the Publishers' Association has drawn up, and it shows that the author who signs such a contract will deliver himself completely into the hands of the publisher.

With the memory and influence of Mr. Le Gallienne's book, "Young Lives" fresh upon me, I was greatly impressed by the mysterious nature of your criticism, published May 20. This alone stirs me to the superfluous vindication of a book palpably its own defender.

The indications that the obstructionist members of the Municipal Assembly were beginning to come around to Controller Coler's way of thinking on the question of bond issues was somewhat discounted by the developments of yesterday at the City Hall.

Mr. WHITELAW REID'S talk at the Miami University Commencement makes what Mr. GREELEY used to call mighty interesting reading. Nobody who had knowledge of Mr. REID'S labors as a Peace Commissioner at Paris or of his previous utterances on the subject could have been in doubt as to his views on the subject of expansion. He is a firm believer in the honorable fulfillment of our National obligations.

WASHINGTON, June 16. -- A reciprocity treaty between the United States and Great Britain in relation to trade between this country and the British colony of Barbados was signed at the Department of State to-day by the representatives of the two Governments. It is the first treaty framed under the Dingley law, and the first of the series of treaties which the British colonies to the south of this country are seeking to effect.
PARIS, June 16. -- Senator Pierre Marie Waldeck-Rousseau has accepted the responsibility of constructing a Ministry, M. Poincare having found the task impossible for him to perform.

The contents of some biographies seem to be a mere compilation of statistics, but Edward Everett Hale has here provided us with a channel which assimilates all that is knowable about the youth, growth, personality, and genius of James Russell Lowell.

Will you allow me space for this, which I am persuaded will interest a large number of your readers: A-calling the attention of writers, editors, and magazine and newspaper owners to the injustice of omitting the names of authors, almost invariably, when using matter from some other publication in their columns?

The publication of "Wessex Poems" has crowned Thomas Hardy prince of the pessimists -- a title he has justly earned. It is in the first spontaneous expression that we reveal ourselves to the world: that which follows is either an affirmation and perfection of what has gone before, or a growing away from nature.

The writer of the notice of Miss Harraden's new story, in your issue of May 6, seems to be unaware that there is a third English version of the Pealter, with which millions of English-speaking men and women all over the world are much more familiar than they are with either of the two which he has named.

When our egregious District Attorney was engaged in a controversy with his esteemed congener of Rockland County as to which of them should prosecute the stealers of a baby a good many of us were inclined to hope that the rustic jurist would carry his point. ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 16. -- One of the interesting papers read to-day at the joint meeting of the Southern Hardware Jobbers' Association and the representatives of the manufacturers was: "Are the trusts necessary under existing circumstances, and are they detrimental to the jobbers' interests?"

PARIS, June 18.--Gen. Mercier, who was Minister for War when Capt. Dreyfus was condemned, spoke publicly for the first time since the Court of Cassation rendered its decision at a meeting of the French Patriotic League yesterday, where he was greeted with loud applause.

Fanny McPherson, the eighteen-year-old schoolgirl who -- passing under the name of M.E. Richards -- was arrested on Saturday at the Hotel Lincoln on the charge of stealing clothing worth $400, the property of Mrs. W.C. Wooley, from the Gerard Hotel, 123 Wrest Forty-fourth Street, was arraigned in the West Side Police Court yesterday morning, before Magistrate Wentworth.

HAMILTON, N.Y., June 18. -- The baccalaureate sermon to the members of the graduating class of Colgate University was delivered in the Baptist Church this morning by the President, the Rev. Dr. George E. Merrill. At the evening service, the Rev. Dr. Henry A. Cordo, '59, of Lambert, N.J., delivered the annual sermon before the Theological Seminary.

The concert and dance hall keepers at Coney Island yesterday carried out their threat of defying the Sunday liquor laws as interpreted by the Police Board, and as a result twenty or more were arrested by Capt. Kenny's men. All were at different times during the day notified to go to the station, where they gave $1,000 bail to appear at the Coney Island court this morning.
LONDON, June 19. -- The correspondent of The Times at The Hague, who thinks the outlook for the Peace Conference promising, says:

HOLYOKE, Mass., June 18. -- To-day was hardly one of rest for President McKinley. In the morning he attended church, and in the afternoon visited Mount Holyoke College to hear the Baccalaureate sermon. In the evening, however, he and Mrs. McKinley remained indoors, and no callers were admitted.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 18. -- Christ Church Parish began to-day the celebration of the one hundred and fiftieth anniversary of the building of Horse Neck Chapel, the first Episcopal church in this town, which was built on the brow of Put's Hill in 1749.

-- In the course of his address at Miami University Mr. WHITELAW REID said that "it would be an ill-day for the colleges if crude and hot-tempered incursions into current public affairs, like a few unhappily witnessed of late, should lead even their friends to fear that they have been so long accustomed to dogmatize to boys that they have lost the faculty of reasoning with men."
BRUNSBUTTEL, Prussia, June 18. -- Emperor William distributed the prizes at the Elbe regatta to-day, and afterward dined on board the Fuerst Bismarck with the owners of the competing yachts.

CHICAGO, June 18. -- Gen. T.B. Hyde of Bath, Me., is dangerously ill at the Auditorium Annex. He is suffering from Bright's disease, and has had three such severe convulsions that Dr. J.D. Hammond, who was called to attend him, despaired of his life.

The Session of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church held a brief meeting yesterday after services. William H. Brookfield, who, as a member of the congregation, endeavored during his recent visit abroad to induce the Rev. Dr. Alexander Connell to accept the call to the church through urgent personal appeal, appeared informally before the Session and made a verbal report of his efforts.

BALTIMORE, June 18. -- The Federation of American Zionists began its second annual conference here this morning. Prominent Jews from nearly every section of the United States were present. The federation remained in session all day and well into the night, with short intermissions for meals.

I am much gratified to see that THE NEW YORK TIMES may presently share with myself in the abuse which has been poured upon me since the Postmaster General violated the United States mail and took therefrom eight pamphlets of mine which have been falsely held to be seditious and treasonable.

I entertain the highest respect for veterans of every grade, but your "Veteran" correspondent, writing from the Elysian shades of Staten Island on the 14th, appears to be more captious than candid. The word "prevalence," as used in my communication of the 12th inst., was, under the circumstances, pardonable and sanctioned by common usage.

There is a steady improvement to be noted in the business in men's wear woolens, and orders are being received much more freely than for some time. This improvement has been noted as in evidence for two or three weeks, but it is very decided now. The principal feature of interest in the trade is the advance that was named last week Thursday by the Washington Mills on their clay worsteds.

With deep regret I observe in your columns the alarming news that "Riots in India are becoming serious." It is very unfortunate that there must be an outbreak on top of all the troubles in that land of my birth. Whatever may be the cause of these disturbances one thing is clear, and that is this, the outbreak is not against the British Government.
The Rev. Dr. Newell Dwight Hillis preached his last sermon of this Summer yesterday morning in Plymouth Church. He will not occupy the pulpit again until Fall.

MADISON, Wis., June 18. -- The crew of the University of Wisconsin will leave tomorrow for Poughkeepsie, where they will enter upon final preparations for the contest with Pennsylvania, Cornell and Columbia Coach McConville is in charge. The crew is believed to be the best that ever donned the scarlet.

Two contrasting items of interest are to be found in the news of the day. One is the failure to adjust the Cleveland surface railway strike, because, as reported, the employing company refuses to deal with a committee composed in part of the general officers of the employes' union, and also because it will not dismiss the new men employed since the strike was declared.

OTTAWA, Ontario, June 18. -- Sir William Van Horne's retirement from the Presidency of the Canadian Pacific Railway and appointment as Chairman of the board is more discussed in Government circles than any event that has taken place recently. It is well understood Sir William simply exchanges a wide field of activity for a wider one.

We note with intense regret that Mr. MCKINLEY has recently issued an order releasing four thousand offices from the civil service and its rules, and placing them at the disposal of the politicians. This is said to be done with a view to the next Presidential election. Yet Mr. McKINLEY must have seen during the last few years the importance to the State of Independent, self-respecting public servants.

CLEVELAND, June 18. -- There were no new developments in the strike of the street railway men to-day, principally for the reason that the company made no attempt to operate cars, except on the Euclid Avenue line. The police still afforded ample protection, and the cars were run on schedule time from 7 o'clock in the morning until 6 o'clock this evening.

Hill, who was at the head of the defeated Democratic State ticket the year that Judge Haight was elected, with the rest of the Republican State ticket, had this to say to-night as to the statement by L.M. Lockwood alleging corruption in Judge Haight's election, before the Industrial Commission on Saturday:

The stage, scenery, tables and chairs, and all other paraphernalia of Koster Bial's roof garden were destroyed by fire yesterday morning. The fire started at 8:30 o'clock, and for three hours the firemen worked to extinguish it. When the last ember was put out, Manager Aarons set at work a large force of men.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 18. -- The Rev. Samuel M. Crothers of the First Parish Church, Cambridge, delivered the baccalaureate sermon before the senior class of Harvard University this afternoon in Appleton Chapel, using Isaiah Ill., 2, as his text.

ELIZABETH, N.J., June 18. -The Right lqev. George F. Seymour, Bishop of Springfield, Ill., presided this morning in Christ Church at the ordination to the priesthood of Curate W. ,x,r. r:ty of All Angels' Church, New York, and the Rev. E. B. iNTash, curate of Christ Church, Elizabeth.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., June 18. -- The Seventh Regiment is supposed to be resting, preparing for the week of toil to begin to-morrow. As a matter of fact, it has been doing its resting by day and becoming aggressively awake and lively by night. Last night the men of several companies decided sleeping to be a pernicious and demoralizing habit, unworthy of soldiers, and declared a boycott against it.

Julius Mackewroth, twenty-eight years old, a waiter of 403 West Forty-eighth Street, was shot and killed early this morning in the Empire, a Raines law hotel at Forty-eighth Street and Eighth Avenue.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 18. -- In the presence of 1,000 people or more, Capt. William Andrews, known as the "lone navigator,'' left this city this afternoon in a little craft named The Doree, which is barely twelve feet in length, to attempt to cross the Atlantic Ocean. He took an eastern course, and headed direct for the Azore Islands, where he expects to stay for a few days to reprovision his larder.

It costs 35 cents to go from the City Hall to Yonkers -- by electric car to the Grand Central Station and thence by train over the New York Central Road. To go from the City Hall to Yonkers via the Third Avenue elevated line to One Hundred and Twenty-ninth Street, and then over the "Huckleberry" system on trolley cars costs just 8 cents.

Funeral services over the body of Augustin Daly will take place at St. Patrick's Cathedral this morning at 9:30 o'clock. There will be no change in the arrangements made by the cathedral authorities, ex-Judge Daly, and Richard Dorney. The names of W.R. Grace and T.H. Kelly have been added to the list of pall bearers. They have signified their willingness to act.

A panic, resulting from the blowing out of a fuse, occurred among the passengers of a car on the Rogers Avenue line of the Nassau Electric Railroad, Brooklyn, late last night. Three women were injured, one of them fatally, it is thought.

PHILADELPHIA, June 19. -- Two six-foot policemen and two equally stalwart civilians engaged in a life and death struggle with a huge East Indian bear on Market Street at noon to-day. The policemen were Reserves Oliver C. Blackburn and Wesley M. Powell, and the two civilians, William and E.C. Vahle of 319 Market Street, owners of the bear.

The guests of the Brighton Beach Hotel were startled yesterday evening by a fire which broke out in the engine room of the building and put all Brighton Beach for a short while in a turmoil. It was all under control in half an hour, and the damage did not amount to more than $1,000 or $1,200, but there was considerable excitement while the fire lasted.

WASHINGTON, June 19. -- A telegram was received at the War Department to-day from California Senators George C. Perkins and Stephen M. White, saying: "Southern California supports Administration in its efforts to suppress the Philippine insurrection, and tenders the President for immediate service well-organized and thoroughly disciplined regiment of infantry.

BALTIMORE, Md., June 19. -- The first business at to-day's session of the annual conference of the Federation of American Zionists was the election of two members from America, to serve on the Executive Committee of the International Congress, which will assemble on Aug. 15, at Basel, Switzerland.

CIRCLE CITY, Alaska, May 29. (via San Francisco, June 19.) -- A story of possible cannibalism and death on the Yukon trail has just reached here. Three men who left Dahl River on Dec. 5 for Jimtown were not heard of again, and they were supposed to have been lost. Nothing was heard of them here till the steamer Rideout, which arrived to-day, brought a terrible tale of suffering and horror.

THE HAGUE, June 19. -- Dr. Zorn, the member of the German delegation to the International Peace Conference, who was dispatched Friday by Count von Munster, the chief German delegate, after a conference with his colleagues, to inform Emperor William personally of the condition of affairs in regard to the board of arbitration question, returned to Scheveningen to-day from Berlin.

The trial of Mrs. Addle Barrow, one of the kidnappers of Marion Clarke, will begin in the Criminal Branch of the Supreme Court next Monday morning at 10:30. This was decided yesterday by Justice Werner, and was stated as mutually satisfactory by District Attorney Gardiner and William F. Howe, for the defense. The proceedings were brief.

YALE QUARTERS, Gale's Ferry, Conn., June 19. -- To-day witnessed a decided innovation in the training life on the Thames. The secrecy which has characterized the work seems to have been abandoned, and a more helpful and sportsmanlike spirit developed between the rival settlements at Red Top and Broadview.

More or less has been written by correspondents of THE TIMES about the street noises. I wish to add another protest against them. Just how they are to be lessened or suppressed I do not know, but it is within the power of the Police Department to do this. We live in a respectable neighborhood, where it is reasonable to expect as much quiet as the streets of a large city can afford.

It was reported yesterday that the Niagara office building, 137 Broadway, at the northwest corner of Cedar Street, had been sold to a recently formed trust company of this city, the name of which was not mentioned in the rumor. The Niagara Building is six stories in height and of stone, with an iron front.

LONDON, June 19. -- The final round of the first part of the international chess tournament was begun at St. Stephen's Hall, in this city, this noon, when the fifth round of the Berger system served for the pairing of the players, which was arranged as follows: Maroczy vs. Janowski, Steinitz vs. Schlechter, Lasker vs. Bird, Blackburne vs. Tinsley, Mason vs. Tschigorin. Pillsbury vs. Lee, Showalter and Cohn byes.

NEWPORT, June 19. -- The yachts departing to-day were the Aphrodite, Langonda, and Seneca. Arrivals, yawl Montecetto and schooner Palmer. The thirty-footer Carolina has gone west to join the other boats of her class in racing.

John Y. Huber, the owner and President of the Keebler-Weyl Baking Company, and also of the United States Biscuit Company, both Philadelphia concerns, operating under separate charters, announced yesterday that he would soon have a plant in operation in this city. Mr. Huber is one of the few big manufacturers in his line in the country operating independently of the National Biscuit Company.

Louis Zimmermann, a mason fifty years old, who formerly lived at 1,602 Clinton Avenue, Borough of the Bronx, died under peculiar circumstances on Oct. 29 last, at 18 West One Hundred and Third Street, and it is owing to the efforts of his wife to have the mystery surrounding his death solved that the Coroner and the District Attorney have at last decided to make an investigation.

BALTIMORE, June 19. -- At a mass meeting to-night, held under the direction of the Zionist Conference, Rabbi Gustav Gottheil of the Temple Emanu-El, New York, spoke of the Dreyfus trial and condemnation. He delivered a bitter arraignment against the injustice done Dreyfus, saying, in part:

LONDON, June 19. -- The St. James's Gazette, this afternoon claims to have received from an absolutely reliable source at Pretoria, capital of the Transvaal, the plan of campaign which will be followed by Gen. Joubert, Commander in Chief of the Boers, in the event of war between the Transvaal and Great Britain.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill. June 19. -- The Supreme Court to-day decided that the law allowing certain students to be admitted to the bar after two years of study is unconstitutional Two of the Justices -- Phillips and Boggs -- dissent. The sum of the decision is that the Legislature has not the right to control admissions to the bar.

WASHINGTON, June 19. -- James Barrett, Vice President of the Georgia State Agricultural Society, was the only witness before the Industrial Commission to-day. He spoke upon the agricultural conditions in the South, saying they were worse to-day than they had ever been in the history of the country.

PORTSMOUTH, N.H., June 19. -- Harry Hough, who lately absconded from Dover, N.H., after having robbed the Cocheco National Bank of Dover, of which he was the assistant cashier, and the Cocheco Savings Bank, of which he was the Treasurer, was brought here to-day, having been arrested in Boston.

CAMP WINTHROP, June 19. -- The first battalion of the Seventh Regiment is here among the hills of Putnam County, and the officers are proud in the conviction that their men can take care of themselves anywhere and in any kind of campaign, and understand the rough work of real soldiering as well as they do the dress parade and fancy branches.

BRISTOL, R.I., June 19. -- Up to a late hour to-night there was still much doubt as to the date on which the cup defender Columbia would take her first trial spin. Everything was arranged for a trial on Wednesday, but matters have been disarranged by the failure of the blocks to stand the hydraulic pressure to which they were subjected.

MANILA, June 19. -- A battalion of the Fourth Infantry, which left Imus, where Gen. Wheaton is in command, this morning, to reconnoitre toward Peres das Marinas, where it was believed most of the rebels who escaped from Paranaque and Bacoor had fled, was attacked by apparently friendly natives in the rear, which brought on a sharp engagement, lasting several hours.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, June 19. -- Up to 4 o'clock this afternoon this promised to be the most uneventful day in the big street railroad strike. At that hour another serious riot broke out in an entirely new quarter and one non-union man was sent to the hospital in consequence.

More than 700 candidates from the city schools have passed the examination for admission to the Normal College. President Hunter said that there were 1,020 who tried for admission. There are more admissions from private and parochial schools than ever before. The highest averages were obtained by the following:

EDINBURGH, June 19. -- In the Parliamentary by-election held to-day in the Southern Division of Edinburgh to fill the vacancy caused by the death on June 2 last of Robert Cox, who had represented the constituency in the Liberal-Unionist interest since 1895, the Radical candidate, Arthur Dewar, defeated the Liberal-Unionist candidate, Major Gen. Andrew G. Wauchope, carrying the division by a majority of 831 votes.

CAMDEN, N.J., June 19. -- In Chancery Chambers to-day, attorneys for Walter R. Kern filed a bill with Vice Chancellor Reed asking the court to restrain the Federal Steel Company from paying any dividend on the common stock at present, and especially to restrain the company from paying the quarterly dividend of 1 1/4 per cent. on the common stock that the Directors declared on June 16, payable July 20.

HOLYOKE, Mass., June 19. -- The citizens of this city have become accustomed to the presence of the President and his party, and there are no longer crowds of curious persons blocking the street before the residence of ex-Congressman Whiting. President McKinley arose early and at 9 o'clock this morning the entire party started by the special train for Northampton to attend the commencement at Smith College.

CHICAGO, June 19. -- There was a good deal of variation in the wheat market to-day. At the opening the confidence of traders who had been buying on the belief that the Russian crop had been ruined by drought was staggered by cables reporting good rains in some parts of the drought-stricken districts and by a break of 1 3/8d, at Liverpool.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 19. -- As the result of a conference between Senator Quay and a few political friends, neither Judge Porter of Allegheny nor Judge Archbold of Lackawanna will be named for appointment to the Supreme Court of Pennsylvania. Another man not as yet determined upon will be chosen for the place.

PITTSBURG, June 19. -- Enoch Eavanoski's young wife, Emma, and his infant daughter Emma, were burned to death to-day as the result of the explosion of an oil can, with which the woman attempted to start a fire at their home, 22 South Thirtieth Street, South Side. The husband was so badly burned in trying to save his family that he will be continued to the hospital for some time.

In his eagerness to make out a case against the May Grand Jury, the District Attorney has revealed many of the secrets of the Grand Jury room and thrown a flood of light upon the extraordinary procedures in the Molineux case.

BALTIMORE, June 19. -- Alexander Brown went to Philadelphia to-day to attend a conference of the representatives of street railway companies from New York, Philadelphia, Pittsburg, and Chicago. He admitted that negotiations were in progress looking to a consolidation of the various properties, but said he could not give details until after the conference.

The Board of State Commissioners reached this city yesterday on their tour of the counties in search of information on which to base their equalization tables, and spent two hours in consultation with President Feltner and other officials of the Department of Taxes and Assessments.

More rapidly each day are the watering places and Summer resorts filling up. It is hardly a fortnight before the beginning of the season. Already at many of them, especially at Newport, an avant courrier has already made an appearance, and small dinners and luncheons in consequence have been given.

Judge Addison Brown of the United States District Court for this district has recently handed down a decision which is of importance to the brewing interests of the country, especially those who do an export business.

NEWPORT, June 19. -- A number of young men among the cottagers have begun training for the various swimming matches which will take place at Bailey's Beach during the Summer, and among those who have begun to train are Thomas Whipple and Clement Cleveland, Jr.

" More than $1,000,000 has been needlessly expended in the construction of levees on Bayou La Fourche, La., since 1890," is the statement made by two members of the Mississippi River Commission, which body convened in annual session at the United States Army Building, on Whitehall Street, yesterday.

The police of the Eldridge Street Station have for the past few days been investigating a queer tale of alleged kidnapping, brought to their attention through a letter found by Samuel Juskowitz of 10 Bayard Street on the night of June 12. The letter was inclosed in an envelope, through which was thrust a small key, presumably to weight the letter.

One of the most peculiar accidents that have ever happened on the Brooklyn Bridge occurred yesterday morning, causing a delay to traffic on the bridge car line and necessitating the transfer of all passengers to the trolley cars.
BERLIN, June 19. -- In the Reichstag to-day Herr Leibermann von Sonnenberg attacked Great Britain's proceedings in Samoa. The Minister of Foreign Affairs, Baron von Buelow, replied, saying:

HAMPTON, N.H., June 19. -- Norman Williams, a prominent lawyer of Chicago, died here this evening. Mrs. Merritt, wife of Gen. Wesley Merritt, is a daughter, and she, with the General, was at the bedside.

PHILADELPHIA, June 19. -- A gang of masked robbers, probably ten in number, early this morning raided the receiving office of the Fairmount Park Transportation Company, at Belmont, in Fairmount Park, and after holding up the receiver and five other employes of the railway, blew open the safe, securing over $3,000, the company's receipts for two days.

PHILADELPHIA, June 19. -- The Westchester Country Club polo team of New York to-day defeated the Rockaway Country Club team, also from New York, on the grounds of the Philadelphia Country Club, by a score of 12 3/4 to 7 3/4 goals. The Westchester team was conceded five goals: thus it will be seen that both teams made the same score.

LONDON, June 20. -- A brilliant audience at the Duke of York's Theatre last evening received with great favor the production of "An American Citizen," under the management of Charles Frohman. Nat Goodwin and the Misses Maxine and Gertrude Elliott had unanimous and enthusiastic recalls.

As the body of Augustin Daly was borne into St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday morning the St. Augustine bell, which was Mr. Daly's contribution to the cathedral chimes, was tolled. This same bell was tolled twice again during the obsequies -- once at the elevation of the Host and finally while the body was being carried out of the cathedral.

Samuel C. Butterfield of 262 Vest One Hundred and Twenty-second Street, a clerk in the Twelfth Ward Bank, whose clothing was found in a room of Balmer's bathhouse at Coney Island on Sunday, is still missing. The police at first concluded that the man had been accidentally drowned while bathing in the surf.

The extreme silliness of the granite cutters' strike is the most obvious fact about it. It is the most obvious fact about the sympathetic strike in general. The sympathetic strike is a corollary to the great untruth which was the legacy of POWDERLY to an ungrateful world, the great untruth, namely, that "an injury to one is the concern of all."

CHICAGO, Ill., June 19. -- Mrs. Potter Palmer left Chicago for Newport this afternoon to remain during the Summer and probably until after the wedding of her niece, Miss Julia Grant, to Prince Cantacuzene of Russia. Miss Grant and her mother will leave for Newport on Wednesday. Potter Palmer will remain in Chicago probably for several weeks.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 19. -- The twelfth annual meeting of the National Ophthalmological, Otological, and Laryngological Society opened here at the Hotel Dennis to-day Seventy-five eye and ear specialists were present. Dr. Elmer J. Bissel of Rochester opened the session with an address, and the Secretary, Dr. H.D. Schenek of New York, presented communications from Dr. C. Knox Shaw and Dr. William Wright, both of London, honorary members.

The security market is neglected; nine out of ten changes yesterday were fractional. Bear traders continue noisy, but they accomplish little. They who are counted upon for leadership on the bull side seem disposed chiefly to take vacations. Nowhere, though, in important circles is there any show of doubt touching business conditions, present prosperity, prospective improvement.
WASHINGTON, June 19. -- Senor Segrario, recently appointed Spanish Consul General at Havana, is about to leave Washington to establish himself at Havana.

A picturesque figure about the Waldorf-Astoria is United States Senator William M. Stewart of Nevada. Attired in a suit of buff linen, and wearing a wide-brimmed sombrero, the Western statesman, with his long, snow-white hair and flowing beard, attracts much attention.

BATH, Me., June 20. -- The United States practice vessel Chesapeake was launched from the Bath Iron Works yard this morning. She was christened with American champagne by Miss Elise Bradford, daughter of Rear Admiral Bradford, Chief of the Bureau of Equipment, at Washington. The launching was successful in every particular.
The weather in New York and vicinity yesterday was freakish and uncertain in its nature, and completely upset all calculations and prognostications.

THE HAGUE, June 20. -- The Geneva Convention Committee of the International Peace Conference held a plenary session to-day to consider the report of its sub-committee. Capt. Mahan of the American delegation again drew attention to the omission of an article defining the exact status of wounded and shipwrecked men falling into the sea during a battle and picked up by neutrals or by hospital ships.

HAVANA, June 20. -- The Administration Economica, which is charged with the disbursement of the finances of the Provisional Government of Havana and the province, publishes a statement showing that from January to May, inclusive, the receipts were $763,194 and the expenses $178,228, the balance being cash on hand.

CHICAGO, June 20. -- Youngsters engaged in a religious war of miniature dimensions this morning. Fifty boys, half of them of the Christian and half of them of the Jewish faith, made Stewart Avenue look like a mediaevel battle ground until the police from the Mazwell Street Station appeared and quieted the disturbance.

While Stock Exchange business continues to drag there develop varied suggestions of better market times ahead. Evidence shows of progress in important pending financial transactions of consequence. And practically every underlying condition is favorable to exceptional activity and improvement as soon as a new start be given headway.

There was a continuation yesterday morning of the hearing in the bankruptcy proceedings of John F. Baudouine before Referee Theodor Aub. At the beginning of the meeting it was arranged that three appraisers -- John T. Boyd, Conrad S. Keyes, and Albert G. Harttorm -- appointed by Mr. Aub should visit Mr. Baudouine's apartment at 1 West Sixty-eighth Street for the purpose of appraising the personal property he has there.
PARIS, June 20. -- It is definitely announced that President Loubet has asked M. Bourgeois, who is head of the French delegation at The Hague Peace Conference, to form a Cabinet.

Quiet but exceedingly ambitious projects are being conducted by Wall Street financiers having interests in the various local transit properties. What is sought falls little short of the actual consolidation of the properties either into one ownership, or, (failing to accomplish that much,) such an arrangement as will permit of concentration in management.

The Commissioners from Puerto Rico to the United States feel, according to Dr. F. Juilo Henna of 8 West Fortieth Street, one of their number, that they and theirs in Puerto Rico have been treated scandalously by the United States Government, and so they have prepared a protest which they hope the American people will read.

Bella Anderson, or Carrie Jones, the nurse girl who stole the Clarke baby, and who pleaded guilty to kidnapping and was sentenced to four years' imprisonment, was yesterday taken from the Tombs for the women's prison in Auburn. She left in charge of a Deputy Sheriff and another officer, the party boarding a Fourth Avenue car without attracting attention.

Nothing had been heard from Maher, the jockey suspected of having been purposely left out of the running of the Suburban Handicap in the interest of the gamblers, when the Stewards of the Coney Island Jockey Club and such of those of The Jockey Club itself as were at the track left for their homes after yesterday's racing.

CLEVELAND, June 20. -- Mob rule held sway on the South Side to-night for more than an hour. A mob of 5,000 persons attacked the Holmden Avenue car barns of the Cleveland Electric Railway Company and rushed through the yard containing sixty cars, destroying everything they could see until driven out by the police.

AUSTIN, Texas, June 20. -- Gov. Sayers to-day received a letter from Gov. J. Hoge Tyler of Virginia, indorsing the proposed anti-trust conference of Governors and Attorney Generals. He writes: "It will give me pleasure to co-operate in any measure that will have a tendency to check the evils of trusts and combinations and to keep trusts and corporate power within bounds.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 20. -- The big singlestickers Navahoe and Defender this afternoon went outside for a short race. The Navahoe was leaving her anchorage in the inner harbor when the Defender was seen to hoist her big mainsail, a good breeze blowing from the southwest. As the Navahoe sailed past Fort Adams the Defender hoisted her anchor, and her sails quickly filled, and like an arrow she was off.

The most successful yearling sale of the year took place in the American Horse Exchange last night, when the yearlings from the Belle Meade Stud, property of Gen. W.H. Jackson, were placed under the hammer. The top price of the sale was $5,200, which was paid by "Tom" Welch, trainer for the firm of C. Fleischmann's Sons, for a chestnut colt by Iroquois-Taribera.

Since Frederick W. Vanderbilt and Dr. W. Seward Webb visited California last Winter frequent and persistent reports have come from San Francisco that the Vanderbilts were going to buy extensive terminal properties in that city for the purpose of completing a line of railroad entirely under their control from New York to San Francisco.

CHICAGO, June 20. -- A considerable cut in the time of passenger trains between Chicago and New York will be made by the Lake Shore and New York Central Road next Sunday. The schedule of one of the west-bound trains from New York to Chicago will be lowered so that the run will be covered in just 24 1/2 hours, and a corresponding east-bound flier will go through in the same time.

LONDON, June 20. -- At the Oxford Assizes to-day, Joseph Stockley was sentenced to ten years' imprisonment for stealing a quantity of plate belonging to the Duke and Duchess of Marlborough, which had been left in charge of a steward.

WASHINGTON, D.C., June 20. -- In its precipitate haste to discredit Lieut. Commander Hodgson, which it is generally admitted here has been done, the Bureau of Navigation yesterday omitted a line or two of his statement to Capt. Chadwick, and to-day a supplementary statement was issued to make good the omission.

WASHINGTON, June 20. -- It required some persistent rummaging to-day in two departments of the Government to obtain any information concerning the Island of Balabac, in the Philippines, where, according to the report of Capt. George T. Spicer of the ship Glooscap, printed in THE TIMES to-day, the natives massacred all the male Spaniards at Balabac and divided the women among the islanders as slaves.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 20. -- The commencement exercises of Rutgers College took place to-night. The following honorary degrees were conferred: LL. D., Gilbert Collins, Justice of the Supreme Court of New Jersey: H.H.D., the Rev. D.D. Grifis, Ithaca, N.Y.; D.D., the Rev. J.H. Raven of Metuchen and the Rev. J.H. Wyckoff of India.

ST. LOUIS, June 20. -- Dr. Thomas Osmond Summers, late Major Surgeon in charge of the fever hospital at Santiago, and a well-known yellow fever expert, shot himself through the head last night. Despondency, caused by fancied lack of appreciation by the Government of his services during the Spanish war, is assigned as the cause for the act.

BRISTOL, R.I., June 20. -- Every possible effort is being made to get the Columbia rigged in time for a trial trip to-morrow, and although the steel boom is yet to be slung, the arrival in Bristol to-day of an additional number of sheaves for the blocks leads to the belief that the new cup defender will leave the yard on the day scheduled, although it may be late in the afternoon.

ST. LOUIS, June 20. -- It is announced that, as Gov. Stephens has signed the Street Railway bill, the negotiations for a general consolidation of all the street railroads of St. Louis, which have been in progress for some time, have been practically completed. The deal involves nearly $100,000,000.

CAMP NOAH L. FARNHAM, Border of Lake Oscawana, June 20. -- This has been a day of ups and downs for the First Battalion of the Seventh Regiment, for its sturdy backs have been strained climbing the spurs of the Cat Hills and the great Oscawana Hill, which is a terror, and its knees have been tested descending into Canopus Valley and traversing the lines of Putnam Valley.

HOLYOKE, Mass., June 20. -- This was what might be appropriately called honor day at South Hadley. Mount Holyoke College was honored by the presence at its commencement exercises of President McKinley, and in turn it honored him by conferring upon him in the chapel of the college the degree of Doctor of Civil Laws.

DETROIT, Mich., June 20. -- Moses Fowler Chase, aged twenty-one, alleged to be mentally incompetent, and reputed to be worth $600,000, disappeared from the Hotel Cadillac last Sunday night. He had been a patient at a sanitarium in Flint, and was en route to his home in Lafayette, Ind., accompanied by his father, Frederick Chase, a lawyer.

ITHACA, N.Y., June 20. -- Gov. Roosevelt was greeted with cheers to-day when he attended the class day exercises of the class of 1899 in Cornell Armory. No less uproarious was the reception which awaited him at Dewitt Park later in the day, when he was greeted by the men, women, and school children of the city.
POUGHKEEPSIE, June 20. -- Passengers on the steamer Mary Powell this afternoon, on her up trip from New York, had a thrilling experience as the vessel emerged from Haverstraw Bay.

WASHINGTON, June 20. -- The Agricultural Department has received an interesting report, dated Manila, from Lieut. A.P. Hayne, California Heavy Artillery, on agriculture in the Philippines. Lieut. Hayne had been able to make no personal observations beyond the American lines, but he transmits the translation of an article prepared for him by Senor Manuel del Busto, chief of the Agricultural Experiment Station in Manila.

His advertisements in the daily newspapers state that persons who desire loans of from $20 to $200 on their salaries can secure them.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., June 20. -- The Rev. Howard T. Widdemer of the First Congregational Church won a victory at the meeting of his congregation this evening. He tendered his resignation before the report of the committee which had been investigating his alleged conduct toward a girl whom he employed as his secretary could be presented.

WASHINGTON, June 20. -- The Industrial Commission to-day continued its investigation of the agricultural conditions of the South. J. Polk Brown, President of the Agricultural Society of Georgia, was the first witness. He said that the condition of agriculture in the South was more depressed than it had ever been.

The Council did approve the issue of $1,849,000 of bonds for street and park openings, but it refused to take up any of the other proposed issues, and all efforts to get the Board of Aldermen to act failed as flatly as they have done heretofore.

ST. MICHAEL'S, Azore Islands, June 20. -- The steam yacht Conqueror, owned by Frederick W. Vanderbilt, arrived here yesterday.

Archbishop Corrigan presided over the forty-sixth annual commencement exercises of Manhattan College, which were held yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall, at Seventh Avenue and Fifty-seventh Street. Speeches were made by the following members of the graduating class: Walter T. Casey, James R. Bartley, Peter A. Hanley, William M. Dwyer, James A. Cahill, John E. Kiffin, and William P. O'Ryan.

Molineux waived examination, after his counsel, George Gordon Battle, had remarked that an examination was unnecessary, since Justice Fursman had ordered the case to be submitted to the next Grand Jury.
