SPRINGFIELD, Mass., June 21. -- President McKinley and his party started from Holyoke at 10:15 o'clock this morning on board the trolley car Rockrimmow, which took them to South Holyoke. There they went on board the little steamer Mascot, on which was a reception committee from here, headed by Mayor Gilmore, the trip down the river being begun at 10:40.

The action of the Council in approving two bond issues on Tuesday and refusing to take up others, and of the Board of Aldermen in failing to act at all through the absence of Tammany members, caused the charge to be made openly yesterday that Tammany is not sincere in its professed desire to put the bond issues through.

WASHINGTON, June 21. -- A rather premature announcement has been made of a plan by which the Bureaus of Construction, Engineering, and Equipment, in the Navy Department, are to be made subject to an Admiralty Board, constituted similarly to that board in the British Navy, and, of course, reducing, in a measure, the importance of the heads of those bureaus as at present constituted.
COLOMBO, Island of Ceylon, June 22 -- 6 A.M. -- The United States cruiser Olympia, with Admiral Dewey, has just arrived from Singapore.

The fifty-third annual regatta of the New York Yacht Club will be sailed to-day over courses which extend from Buoy 13, near the Narrows, through the lower bay and outside the Hook, course No. 1 being to and around Sandy Hook Lightship and course No. 2 to and around Scotland Lightship.

STATE CAMP OF INSTRUCTION, PEEKSKILL, June 21. -- This camp was surprised this morning by the First Battalion, which came tramping briskly in at 10:05 o'clock, having started from Lake Oscawana at 6:45, and made the nine miles over trying roads in three hours and twenty minutes, with three rests, two of ten and one of five minutes.

The State Board of Charities at Albany has before it for consideration the application of the Woodbine Nursery of Brooklyn for approval of its incorporation. The Directors for the first year, as named in the articles of incorporation, are Margaretha Davis, Mary Agnes Phillips, and Mary Dowling of 38 Woodbine Street; William H. Blakely of 935 Gates Avenue, and Honora Sailesbury of 12 Walworth Street.

WASHINGTON, June 21. -- It is estimated that the Treasury deficit for the fiscal year 1899, which closes ten days hence, will be less than $100,000,000. Already the receipts for the year aggregate over $498,800,000, with the expenditures barely $100,000,000 more, with ten days, judging from past years, of abnormally heavy receipts yet to be included.

BRISTOL, R.I., June 21. -- The indications are now that the Columbia will not have her trial spin until the latter part of the week. In fact, it is stated in some quarters that she may not go out until Saturday. The new sheaves to replace those that failed to stand the test have been received. The new steel boom is also ready, and it is expected that it will be slung to-morrow.

LONDON, June 21. -- When the House of Commons went into committee to-day on the Military Works Loan bill, the Parliamentary Secretary of the War Office, George Wyndham, moved a resolution authorizing the introduction of a bill providing a loan of 4,000,000, repayable in yearly installments, for defense works, barracks, and rifle ranges at home and abroad.

PHILADELPHIA, June 21. -- The police of this city are investigating the death of Joseph McCaig, aged fifty-four years, of Beverly, West Va., who died suddenly to-day in a boarding house at 1,429 Montgomery Avenue, after being under the treatment of W.F. Reynolds, a Christian Scientist.

DETROIT, June 23. -- Arguments before a Common Council committee to determine whether the Council shall submit to the people the question of municipal ownership of street railways were concluded at 5:30 this afternoon. A special meeting of the Council is called for to-morrow to decide whether a special election shall be ordered.

An amusing scene was witnessed at the immigrant station at the Barge Office when a loving husband, by mistake, came near claiming another man's wife for his own. It happened that there were detained at the Barge Office two women. They were about the same age, both were named Maria Lewandowska; both were good looking, and each was accompanied by a small child.

Yesterday was sailing day, but the ships did not take away many fashionable people. The Count and Countess di Conturbia were among those who sailed. Others were Mr. and Mrs. James Elverson of Philadelphia, and Mr. Thomas Hugh Kelly, Mr. Eugene Kelly has leased a very beautiful country place on the Thames, and his brother will pass a part of his Summer there.

CHICAGO, June 21. -- The Erie Road has cut the tourist rates from Chicago to Boston $5. The Michigan Central and other roads will meet the cut, and a rate war, spreading over the whole eastern territory, is imminent. The Erie's rates, which go into effect next Sunday, make the round trip tourist fare from Chicago to Boston $33, as against $38, the rate put in by the other lines.
NEWPORT, June 21. -- Rabbi H.P. Mendez of the Spanish and Portuguese Synagogue of New York, with his family, has arrived here for the Summer.

WASHINGTON, June 21. -- The condition of agriculture in New Jersey formed the subject of inquiry by the Industrial Commission to-day. Franklin Dye, Secretary of the State Board, was the witness. He said the general condition of the agricultural laborers of New Jersey was better now than forty or fifty years ago. Their hours of work were shorter and they were better paid.

PARIS, June 21. -- The Venezuelan Boundary Commission reassembled at 11 o'clock this morning. Sir Richard Webster, the British Attorney General, resumed his speech on behalf of the case of Great Britain. Dealing with the period from 1300 to 1637, he said that Great Britain was unable to rely on the data relating to Spanish or Venezuelan control, and was compelled to fall back upon the discovery and circumnavigation, so-called, of the unit of Guiana.

The investigation into the affairs of the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children was continued yesterday before Albert Stickney. Mr. Stickney was appointed for this purpose under a special law passed by the last Legislature, by Justice Beach of the Supreme Court, on the petition of Frederick D. Tappen, one of the Directors of the society.

WASHINGTON, June 21. -- Surgeon Wyman of the marine hospital service to-day received a cablegram from Dr. Park, quarantine officer at Santiago, reporting the existence at that port of fourteen cases of yellow fever and four deaths. Five days ago came the first report of the appearance of the fever.
WASHINGTON, June 21. -- The monthly statement of the collections of internal revenue shows that the total receipts during May, 1899, were $23,500,734, an increase over May, 1898, of $9,402,616.

CINCINNATI, June 21. -- Everything indicates that E.H. Pittman, an aged canvasser from England, who is serving a long sentence at the workhouse, on a charge of practicing a trick game, is innocent. He was convicted on the testimony of eighteen women, who identified him as the man who swindled them.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 21. -- Dr. Charles A. McQueston, who was on the staff of Gen. E.S. Otis, and who was Health Officer at Manila, has returned home, invalided by the climate.
LONDON, June 21. -- At the second day of the Gatwick Summer Meeting to-day Lord William Beresford's Blacksmith, ridden by "Tod" Sloan, won the Crabbet Plate.

CLEVELAND, June 21. -- The effort to settle the strike of the street railway men is likely to be successful, and it is now believe that a settlement may be reached to-morrow. Through the efforts of the special committee of the City Council the officers of the company and a committee of the strikers were brought together to-day to discuss the ultimatum presented by the company yesterday.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., June 21. -- Booker T. Washington, President of the Industrial and Normal School, to-day furnished for publication an elaborate paper discussing the race question.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, June 21. -- Late to-day the first of a threatened series of suits on behalf of ticket brokers against railroad companies was filed in the Common Pleas Court. The plaintiffs are John M. Scalely and Louis B. Bloom, and each ask for $20,000 damages from the Big Four.

Mr. SHARKEY by his agent, binds these men to "engage in a contest for the championship of the world" in pugilism or prizefighting.

MEDFORD, Mass., June 21. -- Tufts College to-day conferred the degree of Doctor of Laws on Austin B. Fletcher, a member of the New York bar. While a student at Tufts, Mr. Fletcher won the prize for oratory. He was admitted to the Massachusetts bar in 1880 and removed to New York City in 1882.

APIA, Samoan Islands, June 14, via Auckland, New Zealand, June 21. -- Mataafa has surrendered 1,850 rifles and the loyalists have given up 2,000. After June 20 a heavy penalty will be enforced upon natives found with rifles in their possession. Mataafa promises to turn in more weapons.

PARIS, June 21. -- William Hastings, describing himself as an American, giving his age as fifty-two, and asserting that he was formerly a Judge in New York City, was arrested here to-day on a charge of attempted blackmail and of threatening to kill M. Challot, a business agent.

WASHINGTON, June 21. -- Until the news came to Washington from Chicago that Col. Henderson had been Chairman of the Committee on Rules of the House, everybody here, and probably Mr. Henderson, supposed that the Chairman of that committee, in the last Congress was Thomas B. Reed, Speaker of the House.

BALTIMORE, June 21. -- Rear Admiral Schley was this morning the recipient of a handsome silver tea service at the hands of the Ladies' Auxiliary of the Schley Testimonial Committee. The presentation was made at Nacirema, the home of Gen. Felix Agnus, in the Green Spring Valley, by a subcommittee of fourteen ladies appointed by Mayor Malster.

Knapp, Andrew Miller, and Thomas Hitchcock, Jr., stewards of the Coney Island Jockey Club meeting, acting on their own initiative, and not at the request of Maher, the deposed jockey, began an investigation as to the cause of Banastar's being practically left at the post in the race for the Suburban on Saturday last.

WASHINGTON, June 21. -- Brig. Gen. Theodore Schwan, United States Volunteers, who has been ordered to duty with the troops in the Philippines, said farewell to his friends in this city to-day prior to his departure for San Francisco, where he will embark for Manila.

ALBANY, June 21. -- Eleven companies of New York City and Brooklyn, formed to buy, sell, manufacture, rectify, compound, and deal in wines, liquors, spirits, and other articles of merchandise, filed articles of incorporation with the Secretary of State to-day, with a capital aggregating $49,500.

Moses Fowler Chase, twenty-one years old, of Lafayette, Ind., heir to a fortune of $800,000, whom the police of Detroit, Mich., asked the police of this city to look for on Tuesday, is still at the Waldorf-Astoria, where he arrived on Monday night in company with his uncle and aunt, Mr. and Mrs. Charles C. Duhme of Cincinnati.

About 300 of the 1,080 members of the Dewey Reception Committee appointed by Mayor Van Wyck responded to the Mayor's call for a meeting of the committee in the Aldermanic Chamber at the City Hall at noon yesterday. Among the number were many of the city's most prominent men, with a large sprinkling of well-known politicians.

CINCINNATI, June 21. -- Moses Fowler Chase, the young man whose alleged abduction has been a current topic for several days, spent several years of his life in Cincincinnati with Mr. and Mrs. Charles C. Duhme. It is said that in case of the young man's death the estate would go to his father if he died without a will.

THE HAGUE, June 21. -- The best-informed circles here do not share the gloomy views of the European press regarding the Peace Conference. After a week's adjournment the Arbitration Committee met for a short time to-day, Dr. Zorn of the German delegation and Frederick Holls of the United States delegation attending.

CHICAGO, June 21. -- John W. Hahn, City Clerk of Evanston, has proved himself to be the most conscientious public servant that city has ever had. He has asked the Evanston Council to give him more work, as he was not doing enough to earn his salary. In consequence of his strange request, J.W. Rhodes, son of ex-Alderman Rhodes, has suffered official decapitation and likewise the loss of $65 per month as Water Clerk.

A four-ball golf match between amateurs and professionals was played yesterday on the Oakland Club links at Bayside, L.I. It was the first contest of the kind played here this season. Walker J. Travis, the Oakland champion and winner of three open tournaments this season, with David Hunter, the Oakland professional, and James A. Tyng, the Baltusrol and Morris County champion, with Willie Anderson, the Baltusrol professional, were the competitors.

NEW HAVEN, June 21. -- The Rev. W.M. Barrows, the minister who recently married Perry Belmont and Mrs. Henry D. Sloane at Greenwich, was this morning severely censured by his fellow members in the General Association of Congregational Ministers of Connecticut in session at the Church of the Redeemer.

MANILA, June 21. -- Copies of the insurgent organ, Independencia, show that the Filipinos' hopes of success are kept aflame by political movements in America. The Independencia prints reports of alleged speeches made at alleged meetings in the United States denouncing the war, and it asserts that these represent the dominant American sentiment.

The old board, in the days when the old Common Council was a "co-ordinate branch," as JOHN COCHRANE used to call it, could not have presented a more discouraging and even loathsome spectacle.
WASHINGTON, June 22. -- The board appointed by the War Department to study the distribution of typhoid fever in army camps expects to complete its report by the end of July.

CLEVELAND, June 22. -- The hope of a settlement to-day of the street railway strike was shattered when the strikers at a meeting rejected, by unanimous vote, the proposition submitted by tile company to the special committee of the City Council, and to which the strikers' committee agreed this afternoon.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 22. -- The third day's session of the fifty-fifth annual meeting of the American Institute of Homeopathy was the liveliest held so far, the cause being the debate over the selection of the second choice for place of meeting next year, in which the delegates from Cleveland scored a victory.

A bevy of women of all ages brightened Special Term, Part V., of the Supreme Court yesterday with their presence and occasional laughter. HENLEY, England, June 22. -- The members of the Argonaut Rowing Club of Toronto, who were passengers on the White Star liner Teutonic, arrived here to-day after traveling all night long.

When the German Kaiser, in his dispatch of sympathy concerning the Illness of RUDYARD KIPLING, spoke of "our common race," Englishmen and Americans alike received the declaration with a certain shock. We know perfectly what Englishmen and Americans mean when, after dinner, they talk about our common race.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass. June 22. -- Yale defeated Harvard this afternoon by a score of 2 to 0. The Yale team's victory was due not so much to the number of their hits as to their skill in making hits with men on bases.

DANVILLE, Ill., June 22. -- Rossville, a little town twenty miles north of Danville, was the scene of unusual excitement last night. About midnight a crowd of young men, disguised as White Caps, knocked at the door of the residence of James Briley. Briley opened the door and was seized and dragged out of the house.

WILLINGTON, Del., June 22. -- The steel steam yacht Willada was launched here yesterday. She was constructed by the Pusey Jones Company for Col. William Hester of Brooklyn. The lines of the yacht are exceedingly graceful. The length over all is 128 feet; beam molded, 16 feet 6 inches; depth, 9 feet 9 inches.

AUSTIN, Texas, June 22. -- The old Town of Carrizo, the county seat of Zapak County, about midway between Laredo and Rio Grande City, on the Texas border, was swept away by the Rio Grande flood yesterday. The town had a population of several hundred Mexicans of the poorer class. Their houses were jackal adobe structures, which quickly melted away when the high water struck them.

The Normal College of the City of New York celebrated its thirtieth annual commencement in the college chapel yesterday morning, when 400 young women were graduated. President Thomas Hunter presided, and addresses were made by Joseph J. Little, Chairman of the Board of Trustees, and George M. Van Hoesen, Chairman of the Executive Committee.

ROME, June 22. -- The Pope to-day held a public Consistory, at which the hats were presented to the recently created Cardinals, with the exception of the Papal Nuncio at Madrid and the Archbishop of Goritz.

CHICAGO, June 22. -- The fight between Eastern roads over passenger rates may be said to be fairly on. The Wabash and the Nickel Plate gave notice to-day that they will meet the five-dollar reduction made by the Erie in round trip tickets between Chicago and Boston. The Michigan Central has practically announced that it will cut its fares $5, although no official notice yet has been given.

ADAMS, Mass., June 22. -- President McKinley and Mrs. McKinley and their friends, who came here yesterday and who will be the guests of W.B. Plunkett for a week, had a quiet, restful time to-day after the recent series of visits, receptions, and other incidents of their tour in the central part of the State.

WASHINGTON, June 22. -- The Secretary of State has received a dispatch from Commissioner Bartlett Tripp, at Apia, Samoa, saying that peace had bee nrestored in the island; the commission had sustained the decision of Chief Justice Chambers in the contested case of the election of the King; that Malietoa Tanus has resigned; the kingship was to be abolished, and a provisional government established.

BOSTON, June 22. -- The Metropolitan National Bank was neatly robbed of $10,000 about noon to-day by a stranger who was tempted by the pile of bills which lay on the desk of the paying teller, Charles S. Balfendahl. There was no less than $70,000 in the pile, in denominations of $1,000, $100, and $50.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., June 22. -- Ignatz Cosmoro, a miner in the Gaylord mine of the Kingston Coal Company, was entombed in a breast in the mine last Monday, and remained in the bowels of the earth, 400 feet from the surface, until noon to-day, when he was taken out by rescuers, who had been working heroically day and night ever since the accident occurred.

Justice Beach, in the Supreme Court, granted yesterday to William G. Davies, William H. Choate, and Joel B. Erhardt, the Commissioners appointed to appraise the value of the land acquired by the city for the widening of Elm Street, $15,000 each additional compensation for the work done by them beyond that paid them under the scale allowed by the city of $10 a day.

WASHINGTON, June 22. -- L.W. Youmans of South Carolina was a witness to-day before the Industrial Commission. He said the agricultural interests of the South were greatly depressed, and he attributed the depression to the fact that silver was not recognized as a money metal. He said there had not been an increase of the volume of money to correspond with the increase of population.

MINNEAPOLIS, June 22. -- A dispatch from Walker, Minn., says: "The many rumors relative to the removal of trespassers off of the Indian reservation were confirmed today, when Capt. Mercer, the Indian Agent, received peremptory orders to remove all white persons off the Chippewa Indian Reservation within thirty days.

William B. Bushnell, a promoter, and patentee of an invention for manufacturing ice, was brought before Justice Beekman, in the Supreme Court, yesterday, on a writ of habeas corpus obtained on his own application, asking for his release from Bloomingdale Asylum, where he has been confined since last January.

The address delivered at the University of Michigan yesterday by Prof. NICHOLAS MURRAY BUTLER of Columbia was such a message as it is well for the great university of the East to send to the strong uiversity in the heart of the continent. Its subject was "The Education of Public Opinion," with especial reference to politics.

Mrs. Zimmermann, the widow of Louis Zimmermann, the mason who was killed on Oct. 29 last by a fall down stairs in the house of Alpheas J. Goddard, where he had gone to collect a bill due him for work on houses in which Mr. Goddard was interested, was found yesterday at 3,030 Third Avenue, in the home of Mrs. Wolf, where she is living.

ITHACA, N.Y., June 22. -- Three hundred and thirty-five diplomas were to-day conferred upon the graduating class of Cornell University. All the departments and colleges in the institution were represented. The seniors formed in line in front of Morrill Hall and Library and moved from there to the Cornell armory.

CHICAGO, June 22. -- In the opinion of Gov. Theodore Roosevelt, erstwhile Colonel of the Rough Riders, the ten nymphs who invaded tile lake front a week ago, ought to form in columns of two, scale the wall that skirts the domain of the Illinois Central Railroad, and take a bath in the lake without waiting for some considerate mortal to supply them with the regulation suits.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., June 22. -- The second day of the Democratic Convention was a blank so far as proceedings of record go. Under the surface, however, it was a busy day of electioneering and wire-pulling. Two short sessions were held, one in the morning and one in the evening. At the former committees were appointed and a recess was taken until evening to allow them to work.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 22. -- Frederick A. Hubbard, the lawyer through whom Perry Belmont and Mrs. Sloane arranged for their marriage by the Rev. Dr. Walter M. Barrows, pastor of the Second Congregational Church, objects to the impression which has gone abroad that he practiced deception on his own pastor in order to induce the clergyman to unite the couple in marriage.

ALBANY, June 22. -- Charles R. Skinner, State Superintendent of Schools, has attacked the authority of School Superintendent William H. Maxwell of New York City to issue licenses to school teachers. Mr. Skinner declares that he has the right under the general State law to require all teachers to submit to an examination prescribed by him before they can be licensed to teach.

There is some prospect for developments to-day in the matter of Controller Coler's fight against the Municipal Assembly on the hold-up of bond issues. The Controller did not appear at his office yesterday, but he is expected there this morning bright and early, and the intimations yesterday were that his reappearance after a day's rest would be the signal for the beginning of the legal proceedings that have been so long threatened.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 22. -- Henry T. Oxnard, President of the American Beet Sugar Association, has prepared a reply to H.O. Havemeyer's recent argument before the Industrial Commission at Washington. He flatly denies many of Mr. Havemeyer's statements, and accuses him of seeking to destroy the American beet sugar industry in order to foster the refineries that handle foreign raw material, besides attempting to divert public attention from the Sugar Trust by attacking the tariff.

The plans and specifications which are to serve as a guide for the architects who will compete for the privilege of designing the new Custom House on the Bowling Green site, have been forwarded to the various firms and individuals who may compete, by James Knox Taylor, the supervising architect, representing the Government in the matter.
The venerable ex-Senator HENRY W. BLAIR of New Hampshire has come to the surface as the defender of the protective tariff against the charge that it promotes monopolies and trusts.

An application for retirement on half pay was filed by Detective Sergt. Philip Reilly yesterday. For many years past Detective Reilly has been assigned to the Wall Street district, and his alertness and extensive knowledge of criminals and their ways have had a deterrent effect on crime in that locality.

Alzamira Battersby, Vice President of the Brighton Beach Racing Association and Superintendent of the Brighton race track, was held for the Court of Special Sessions by Magistrate Leale in the Coney Island Police Court yesterday. He is charged with assaulting Policeman Peter Campbell. John Y. McKane was one of the spectators in court.

A part of the income of that portion of the Baron de Hirsch Fund allotted to America is to be devoted to ameliorating the conditions which prevail in Brownsville, a thickly populated Hebrew quarter of Brooklyn. A movement with this end in view is now on foot, and a committee is preparing a report as to the plan and scope of the work.
POUGHKEEPSIE, June 22. -- The many here interested in the forthcoming race had an opportunity this evening to size up the Wisconsin University crew.

It was definitely learned yesterday that the purchasers of the Niagara Building, at Broadway and Cedar Street, which Potter Brother recently sold for $1,150,000, as announced in this column, were the members of a syndicate organized by William H. Chesebrough, and headed by Mr. Chesebrough and Stewart Browne.

WASHINGTON, June 22. -- The honorary degree of LL. D. was to-day conferred by Georgetown University on Rear Admirals Winfield Scott Schley and George W. Melville, Major Gen. Joseph Wheeler, the Hon. W. Bourke Cockran of New York, Dr. Samuel Bussey, District of Columbia; Dr. Daniel Brower, Illinois, and the Hon. Thomas Herron, United States of Colombia.

LONDON, June 22. -- The Exchange Telegraph Company says it has been definitely decided to launch the cup challenger Shamrock on Monday, and that she will arrive at Southampton Wednesday in order to be fitted out.

The feature of yesterday's play in the Lenox Tennis Club's open tournament was the exciting match in the semi-final round of the scratch singles between J.P. Paret and B.C. Wright of Boston. These two experts were officially ranked just even last season, and there was much rivalry between them in consequence.

HAMILTON, N.Y., June 22. -- The commencement exercises of Colgate University were held to-day. There were ten speakers. The Lewis commencement oration prize of $60 was awarded to Fred John Nevinger of Johnsonburg. The Board of Trustees conferred the degree of Doctor of Divinity upon the Rev. William T. Carson Hanna, '70, Bradford, Penn., and the Rev. William Wallace Dawley, Colgate Divinity School, 'S1, of Minneapolis, Minn.

CAPON SPRINGS, West Va., June 22. -- The Educational Conference devoted itself last night to an informal discussion of the question, "How the higher institutions of learning may help the public schools."
BOSTON, June 22. -- Admiral Sampson's squadron -- the flagship New York and battleships Massachusetts, Indiana, and Texas -- sailed for Newport at 9 o'clock this morning.
PARIS, June 22. -- Late this afternoon the announcement was made that Senator Waldeck-Rousseau had completed the formation of a new French Cabinet.

Detective Raehume of Capt. McClusky's staff made a clever arrest of a noted criminal just as the latter was leaving a train from Boston, Mass., in the Grand Central Station at 6 o'clock last evening. The prisoner, whose real name is Philip Lambele, but who gave his name as George Shea, although only twenty-one years old, is one of the cleverest sneak thieves in the country.

Maher's ride in the Suburban took second place in the gossip of the racegoers at the Sheepshead Bay track yesterday. Talk was more regarding the operations of Sydney Paget, the manager of the Hon. William C. Whitney's racing stable. Mr. Paget was reported to have secured a contract with the light-weight jockey George Odom for a term of three years at a salary of $10,000 per year.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 22. -- The thoroughbred department of the celebrated Palo Alto Farm will soon be a thing of the past. In October the famous stallions, Racine and Flambeaux, and every other well known thoroughbred on the farm, will be put on the block in New York. The trotting department at Palo Alto will be maintained, as it has always been more than self-sustaining.

Duhme, arrived in the city yesterday, and said he would remain here for a while "to see what happened." "Marchez au Pas" stares one in the face at frequent intervals, and causes ever the bus drivers to pull in their splendid, struggling horses.

LONDON, June 10. -- Mrs. Gertrude Atherton succeeded in irritating quite a number of people by her recent article in The Bookman concerning English authors. She characterized Meredith's style as atrocious. This reminds one of the man who at a dinner party remarked that "there was no God," and thereby instantly obtained the reputation of being a profound thinker.

Mr. William Waldorf Astor heretofore has written two clever novels, "Valentine" and "Sporza," and many excellent and original papers, showing that he is no amateur in literary work, but a conscientious artist. A glance at the table of contents of Matthew P. Breen's forthcoming book, entitled "Thirty Years of New York Politics, Up to Date," gives promise of a most readable book. While grouping together the most interesting sensational episodes of social and political metropolitan life, the author discusses and dissects bossism from its early development in William M. Tweed to the present time.

WASHINGTON, June 23. -- Richman Coles, a farmer of Salem County, N.J., was before the Industrial Commission to-day. He said the farmers of New Jersey had no especial complaint, though there was a general feeling that conditions might be improved. Prices for their products were generally lower, while wages for farm hands were higher than formerly.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 23. -- The class day exercises of Harvard University were held to-day in Sanders Theatre. There was a large attendance and the weather was all that could be desired. The exercises opened with the class oration by William H. Conroy, Jr., of Philadelphia. Conroy has been prominent as editor of The Crimson and as a debater during his course.

DETROIT, June 23. -- The doctors disagree in their testimony in the hearing upon the application for extradition from New York of Mr. and Mrs. Charles H. Duhme of Cincinnati, who are charged with the abduction from this city of their nephew. Moses Fowler Chase of Lafayette, Ind., heir to property worth upward of half a million dollars.

NEWPORT, June 23. -- The North Atlantic Squadron, consisting of the flagship New York, bearing the flag of Admiral Sampson, and the battleships Indiana, Massachusetts, and Texas, arrived this afternoon from Boston. While en route Thursday general quarters was sounded at night, and there was a sham battle with a supposed enemy.

It is only in recent years that the 'cello tone has been recognized by the average attendant at concerts.

THE HAGUE, June 23. -- M. de Staal, President of the Peace Conference, at a meeting of the committee this morning introduced the Russian proposals looking to the arrest of the increase of armaments, and read a declaration disclaiming all intention of proposing a reduction of armaments at present.

In the absence of Secretary of War Alger from Washington, D.C., Acting Secretary Meiklejohn has revoked a contract recently made for about $500,000 worth of rapid-fire guns, awarded by the War Department to the Driggs-Seabury Gun and Ammunition Company, whose offices are at 120 Liberty Street, this city.

The sun dial was certainly known and the clepsydra, or water clock; the lever and pulley as well as many other forms that indicate a high appreciation of knowledge, learning, and discovery.

HARVARD QUARTERS, GALE'S FERRY, Conn., June 23. -- The Harvard University eight rowed up stream about 11 o'clock this morning and practiced racing starts. Coach Storrow instructed the oarsmen on the body swing and tried to have them get a little longer reach. Considerable attention was also paid to keeping the blades buried at the finish of the stroke.

Mrs. Santiago Porcella, wife of a merchant of this city, whose home is in Cranford, N.J., died Thursday at her Summer residence, Crescent Beach, Conn., of quick consumption. The cause of her death is directly charged to the teachings of Christian Science. Mr. Porcella, at his home in Cranford last evening, where his wife's body was taken yesterday, made the statement that he regarded her death as nothing less than murder.

DETROIT, Mich., June 23. -- Gov. Pingree gave out a public statement to-day to the effect that he had combined with Secretary Alger in the interests of Alger's Senatorial candidacy. Gen. Alger will not withdraw under any circumstances, nor will he spend any money in the campaign.

Alphonse Daudet belongs to the small company of fiction writers vital to one's education. The final preparations for the preliminary trials of the Holland submarine torpedo boat have been completed. They will take place in Upper, or Little, Peconic Bay, which is near the eastern entrance to Long Island Sound, and will be begun this week.

LONDON, June 24. -- At the London Athletic Club's meeting at Stamford to-day, the half-mile run was won by Lutyens in 1 minute 57 2-5 seconds. The 120-yard hurdle race was won by Turner in 16 3-5 seconds. The mile-and-a-half run was won by H.C.P. Bennett in 6 minutes 51 seconds.

Bryan and other leaders of his party. While not committing himself as to whether this country should own and govern the Philippine Islands, he declared strongly against the anti-expansion plea.

There are billboards here almost as big as the Masonic Temple, billboards that obscure the parks and shut out the lake and its breezes.

VERA CRUZ, Mexico, June 24. -- Dr. Edward Liciaga, representing the Mexican Government, has arranged with Health Officer A.H. Doty of New York for the use of the yellow fever serum in Vera Cruz, where there are a great many cases of the disease. Dr. Doty has appointed a young physician of Charleston, S.C., who is thoroughly immune to yellow fever, to represent him and use the serum here.

LENOX, Mass., June 24. -- The first weekly handicap golf match of the season is scheduled to take place at the links to-day. It will be eighteen-hole medal play, and the winner will receive a cup. Among those who will compete are S. Parkman Shaw, Carlos de Heredia, H.P. Rogers, Sam Frohtingham, Harold Godwin, John Sloane, Jr., and Myles Standish.

SEATTLE, Washington, June 24. -- Purser Carroll of the steamer Humboldt, which arrived yesterday from Alaskan points, claims that he had in his custody $230,000 in dust, and estimates that there was about $300,000 more not turned over to him, in the different staterooms. To-day $150,000 worth of dust was deposited in the United States Assay Office, and a fifty-thousand-dollar lot was billed at an express office for shipment to Philadelphia.

GREENVILLE, S.C., June 10. -- Does anybody in New York remember Jimmie Mackey, who used to run with No. 5 Engine when its house was at Fulton and Dutch Streets, in the thirties? He was apprenticed to John P. Moore, gunmaker, at 202 Broadway, and lived with his employer at 9 Dutch Street, where Cornelius Vanderbilt had a room while he was struggling to establish himself in the steamship business.

About 3,000 persons witnessed the bicycle races under the auspices of the Kings County Wheelmen at Manhattan Beach yesterday afternoon. The competitors in the various events included nearly all the best amateur and professional racers in the country.

SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, Jun 24. -- John O. Bookwalter, a unique figure in American National life, art connoisseur, millionaire, Nebraska ranchman, Democratic politician, but some time ago disgusted with Ohio Democratic political methods, is home again for a brief stay, after a long trip through European and Asiatic Russia, most of his time being spent in Siberia.

LARGE oil portrait of Presiding Justice Charles H. Van Brunt hangs in the courtroom of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court of New York, in the First Department. It typifies the high regard in which its distinguished prototype is held by the members of the New York bar, for it was painted as a subscription testimonial, and was presented with complimentary formalities about two years ago.
CHICAGO, June 24. -- Ex-Gov. Altgeld declared yesterday that the railroads will be placed under fire by the Democratic Convention next year.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., June 24. -- Torn with dissension, the Kentucky Democrats are having a hard time holding their State Convention. After three days of waiting, under temporary organization, for the Credentials Committee to dispose of contests involving about a third of the whole delegate strength or convention, they were prevented last night from considering this report by a disturbance caused by the admittance to the floor of outside persons.

ST. PETERSBURG, June 12. -- In spite of the Peace Conference at The Hague, Russia continues to arm, the great military question of the day in St. Petersburg being the reorganization of the artillery. No decision of the War Department has, however, yet been made public in this important matter.

THE one hundred and eighteenth annual communication of the Grand Lodge of Free and Accepted Masons in the State of New York, which was recently held at the Masonic Hall, in this city, drew together some 900 delegates and officials, representing nearly 100,000 Master Masons.

THE Empire of Germany lodges its Ambassador to the United States in its own house. Great Britain and Mexico are the only other nations that have provided homes for their diplomatic representatives. Germany, or Prussia, rather, followed the example of Great Britain as long ago as 1861, when the King of Prussia sanctioned the purchase for the Minister of Prussia of a large but plain and comfortable house on Fifteenth Street, near Pennsylvania Avenue.

CHICAGO, June 24. -- The officers of the Woman's Christian Temperance Union, who believe that Sunday should be observed as a day of rest, have a problem on their hands in connection with their trip to the next convention at Seattle. The meeting opens on Tuesday, Oct. 17, and the problem consists in reaching that point without traveling on Sunday.

CAPON SPRINGS, West Va., June 24. -The Educational Conference, which has been in session here since June 20, completed its work yesterday, and it is now possible to give a survey of the ground and see exactly what has been accomplished and what planned for the accomplishment of future labors.

LAS VEGAS, N.M., June 24. -- Roosevelt's Rough Riders' day opened auspiciously, the clouds having dispersed over night. Business men and residents whose decorations were damaged by the heavy rainfall last evening were busily engaged early in the day in restoring brightness and color to the scene.

SOUTHAMPTON, June 24. -- This place is filling up rapidly, very few of the cottages remaining unoccupied. The residents are very quiet, however, and there are scarcely any social events to speak of. The season proper will probably commence with the first week in July, although the series of Friday night dinners and dances at the Meadow Club will be commenced next Friday, which will be a week or two earlier than in former years.

BURLINGTON, Iowa, June 24. -- The Iowa and Mississippi Valley Railroad Company, with $300,000 capital, has been organized here and will be operated in Lee, Des Moines, and Louisa Counties. It will connect at Oakville with a branch of the St. Paul, admitting this road to Burlington as a rival of the Chicago, Burlington and Quincy.

As one of the old citizens of New York, interested in its historical antiquities and representations, and their proper care and preservation, I, with many others, would like to see the memorials and statuary in the public parks of Greater New York restored and put in order.

LONDON, June 24. -- The spirits of the Liberals have once more gone up with a jump. South Edinburgh has turned a Conservative majority of 97 into a Liberal majority of 931, and East Edinburgh has raised a Liberal majority of 449 to 1,930. Moreover, there is every prospect of the Liberal candidate winning the important conservative seat of Oldham in Lancashire, made vacant by death.

SARATOGA, N.Y., June 24. -- Saratoga is now nearer New York City than it was yesterday noon, as was shown by the time made by the new Saratoga Limited Expless. The train covered the 183 miles between New York City and Saratoga in 225 minutes, which gives for it the record of being the fastest train in the world. Cheers from thousands greeted the train as it pulled into the Delaware and Hudson Station here.

Four new and handsome Wagner cars filled with passengers rolled out of the Grand Central Station at 1:50 o'clock P.M. yesterday on the first trip of the Saratoga Limited. This is the New York Central's new train which is to be run on the time of the Empire State Express between New York and Saratoga every day except Sunday.

Two men lost their lives yesterday during the regatta on Long Island Sound of the Seawanhaka-Corinthian Yacht Club. They were Mr. Rockwell, a guest, and one of the crew, whose name was Mitchell, on the thirty-foot cabin sloop Dot, owned by C.T. Pierce, a paint manufacturer of this city, who lives at Riverside, Conn., and is a member of the Riverside Yacht Club. Mr. Rockwell was a resident of Englewood, N.J.

BAR HARBOR, Me., June 24. -- It has been many years since Bar Harbor has presented so gay an aspect in June. For some reason the cottage people began to arrive unusually early this Summer, and the closing week of June will find a large colony of Summer people settled for the season. The hotels will all be open in another week.

The papers in the application of John McQuade for a writ of mandamus against the Municipal Assembly "and the members thereof," to compel them to act upon the resolution for the issuance of $250,000 of corporate stock of the city for the account of water supply, were completed yesterday, and Alexander Thain, Mr. McQuade's attorney, announced that the application probably would be made on Tuesday, before Justice Bischoff of the Supreme Court.

LONDON, June 24. -- C.N. Jackson, G.C. Vassall, A. Hunter, and the Rev. J.H. Gray met to-day at the Queen's Club to arrange the preliminaries of the interuniversity sports, to take place July 22. They selected the following team:

That a paper like THE TIMES, which can reason so correctly on free trade, the currency, free silver, , could at the same time bring itself to believe that injustice is ever tolerable, continues to be a matter of surprise to its readers.

The conference that has just closed its sessions at Capon Springs in West Virginia adopted three important measures. One was the employment of a general agent of the conference, under the direction of Dr. CURRY, executive officer of the Siater Fund and the Peabody Fund, to study in detail the methods of education in the South.

The Seventh Regiment returned home yesterday from a week of hard work in camps and on the march, and had the most exciting and dangerous experience of the week after it was ready to take the train. A violent storm struck the camp of instruction, and there was a dazzling electric display, in the course of which two men were stunned and several others were shocked.

Charlie" Murphy, who on Wednesday last rode a mile paced by a locomotive in 65 seconds at Maywood, L.I., will not make a second trial, as was announced a few days ago. He will not ride again until his final attempt next Friday, the second day of the midsummer carnival of the New York State Division, League of American Wheelmen, which will be held at Patchogue.

DETROIT, Mich., June 24. -- The testimony in the Chase-Duhme extradition hearing before Gov. Pingree was concluded to-day. Alfred Russell, counsel for F.S. Chase, father of Moses Fowler Chase, began the argument in behalf of the application for a requisition upon Gov. Roosevelt for the return from New York of the Duhmes, and of Charles Peterman, Moses's alleged abductors.

Wall Street's business week has not had much in it of extraordinary consequence. Such professional speculators as continue interested in current Stock Exchange affairs seem still disposed to keep on the bear side, and they see to it that bear fables are given circulation. They have tried to make much ado over the continuance of gold exports, and they indulge largely in prophecies of coming tightness in the money market here.

The Paymaster General of the Navy -- it will be remembered that Secretary LONG could find only one appointment in his whole department, that of his own private secretary, which he wished exempted from competitive examination -- has just been issuing an order regulating the conduct of his clerks.

BERLIN, June 24. -- The trade relations between the United States and Germany continue to attract considerable attention. The chief Agrarian organ, the Deutsche Tages-Zeitung, leaves no doubt that Count von Kanitz's recent motion for a modification of the tariff of 1879 was aimed at the United States and was intended to counteract the differential treatment of German sugar and the reciprocity concession to France.

Mr. S.E. MORSS of Indianapolis thinks that the Democratic Party should declare for free silver next year and then drop it. "The financial declaration of 1896 will be reiterated," he says, "but it will not and should not form the dominant issue. If it does, we cannot win."

The last week in June and the first week in July are the dates which year after year are supposed to be those fixed for the opening of the Summer social season. Newport is slowly gathering its set together; the hotels and boarding-houses of Narragansett Pier are open for visitors; Southampton cottages are rented; Bar Harbor is beginning to look inhabited, and the entire coast from Maine to Cape May is ready.

LONDON, June 24. -- Every now and then new versions of the tragic death of the Crown Prince of Austria are published, and they always attract interest. The West End now asserts that it has obtained the "true story" of the tragedy of Prince Rudolph's death, "gathered from an undeniable source." This version of the affair says:

An audience of 1,500 persons gathered yesterday afternoon in the Gospel Tent, at Broadway and Fifty-sixth Street, to hear an address by Rear Admiral Philip, commandant of the Brooklyn Navy Yard. Preceding Admiral Philip's address there was a song service, led by Miss May E. Storrs and J.A. Birkholz.

PARKERSBURG, West Va., June 25. -- About 7 o'clock this evening a tramp sprang out of a brush pile alongside of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad, near Adamston, eighty miles east of here, and attacked a twelve-year-old boy named Jay McClung, who was on his way to Clarksburg, with the apparent purpose of stealing his hat.

CHICAGO, June 25. -- "Dutch" Neal, the St. Louis pugilist who fell unconscious in the ring last Wednesday night in the sixth round of a glove contest with Harry Peppers, the California middleweight, died to-day without having regained consciousness. Neal's death is attributed to a blood clot on the brain, resulting from overexertion while in an unfit physical condition.

A small riot in which three men were badly wounded occurred yesterday morning at McKeon and Varian Streets, Stapleton, S.I. The riot was between a gang of Italians and rowdies who had been drinking. Nearly fifty persons participated in the fight. The police reserves were called out, and succeeded in arresting the ringleaders, two Italians, who are brothers. There were several shots fired.

The Washington correspondent of our ardent contemporary. The American Economist, (published weekly by the American Protective Tariff League,) writes to his paper that Mr. HAVEMEYER'S attack upon the protective system has "attracted some attention among friends of the policy of protection" in that city.

MANCHESTER, Mass., June 25. -- Senator James McMillan of Michigan, who is staying here, said last evening that the new phase in the Senatorial contest in his State was not a surprise. Said Senator McMillan:

BRISTOL, June 25. -- The new cup defender Columbia is, as it was expected she would be, a wonder. She had her first builder's trial in Narragansett Bay this morning, which included a brief but exciting brush with the old Defender, and which proved beyond the shadow of a doubt that the Columbia is far and away an improvement on the former champion.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 25. -- It has been the consistent policy of the colleges to abstain from doing any practice on Sunday, but Wisconsin made an exception to-day. The crew is not familiar with the course, and during the short time it has been here this year there has been but little chance for practice work on account of the rough water. So Coach McConville took his eight out twice to-day.

ELIZABETH, N.J., June 25. -- The trouble in the Westminster Presbyterian Church over the selection of the Rev. John Ecob as pastor has culminated in the resignation of the Rev. E.E. Cobb of the Second Presbyterian Church as Moderator of the sessions. He says there appeared to be too much discontent in the congregation, and he does not care to be a party to the discord.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., June 25. -- The one hundred and fourth commencement of Union College was begun to-night by the delivery of the baccalaureate sermon by President Raymond. The sermon was founded on the text. "Freely ye have received, freely give." Dr. Raymond spoke at length on charity, and then dwelling on National topics, said:

GALE'S FERRY, Conn., June 25. -- Realizing the necessity of varying the monotony of the course of the training as much as possible, the entire 'Varsity squad, with their coaches, and almost all of the freshmen crew were taken down to New London and had dinner at the Pequot House to-day.

In the present week the third Republic of France will pass to a crisis of its existence. Whether it will be manifested through a tragic overthrow of the Waldeck-Rousseau Ministry and a consequent struggle for supremacy between the Socialists and the army, or whether it will pass almost unnoticed in the confusion of events, does not particularly matter.

LAS VEGAS, N.M., June 25. -- Col. Roosevelt was the central figure in to-day's exercises connected with the Rough Riders' reunion. He is wearing to-night a gold medal given him by the people of New Mexico. The medal was presented at the conclusion of the regimental review, the presentation speech being made by Frank Springer.

LONDON, June 25. -- We have had an anxious week, only partially brightened at the close by the formation of the new French Ministry. At last the Paris Bourse has begun to take alarm, and all the early part of the week poured Tintos and African gold shares into the London market.

CHICAGO, June 25. -- Congressman H.S. Boutell is at his home suffering from concussion of the brain and minor injuries received in a collision with a scorching bicyclist a few nights ago on Grand Boulevard. The Congressman was knocked senseless, and it was two hours before he was restored to consciousness.

LYNBROOKE, L.I., June 25. -- Eli Rosenkranz of 642 Courtlandt Avenue, New York City, was found drowned near Hick's Beach this morning by a fisherman. The body was towed to a float at Long Beach and landed there. No one recognized the man at the time, but a little later his son, Bernard Rosenkranz, of the same address, appeared and identified the body.

The house and farm of Troop C Country Club of Brooklyn, on Manhasset Bay, were informally opened yesterday. The club occupies historic ground, and its home is likely to be the scene of many important social functions for years to come.

CHICAGO, June 25. -- Taylor and Demont presented Brooklyn with most of its runs to-day, the former hitting three batsmen and giving five bases on balls, the latter making two very bad errors. Jones did some clever work in centre, and Lange made a wonderful catch, stopping what looked like a clean home run. Attendance, 24,421. Score:

Thomas Power Walsh, commonly known as "Fatty" Walsh, a Democratic leader in the Second Assembly District, and one of the best known and most picturesque politicians in the city, died suddenly last night of heart disease, at his home, 48 Madison Street. He had been out Saturday night calling on some friends, and returned shortly after midnight.

NEW HAVEN, June 25. -- President Timothy Dwight, the retiring President of Yale University, to-day preached his last baccalaureate sermon before the graduating classes of the academic and scientific departments. The service was rendered all the more interesting as the occasion was also the fiftieth anniversary of President Dwight's own graduation.

MINEOLA, June 25. -- The Nassau County Board of Supervisors met last evening a delegation of architects, headed by R.W. Gibson. The architects came to argue and urge a reconsideration of the action taken in selecting Plan 22 for the new county Court House.

LOUISVILLE, June 25. -- Up to a late hour to-night there is no sign of an agreement between any two of the Democratic candidates for Governor, and it seems likely that the first ballot taken when the State Convention meets to-morrow morning will result just about as did the eleventh Saturday night. Candidates and their managers have been on the go all day, out of one conference into another, but so far to no purpose.

The Sunday attendance of oarsmen at the various Harlem River clubs was not diminished to any great extent by the showery weather yesterday. In fact, the rain held off until nearly 2 o'clock, and by that time the crews who are training for the New England, Philadelphia, and Long Island regattas had completed their work, and the barge parties had reached their destination.

Few Wall Street observers expect much activity this week, the extra holiday following it -- the Stock Exchange being closed from Saturday till Wednesday -- having the moral influence of inducing a disposition to go slow, to even up -- to wait. The bear contingent is unlikely to give up its nagging campaign, however.
KIEL, June 25. -- In the Kiel Regatta today Emperor William sailed his steel yawl Yacht Meteor, winning the first race.

There is a fair reorder business coming forward for dress goods, but the quantity ordered by each merchant is so small that if it were not for the large number that are placing these orders the agents would be discouraged. As it is, they argue that this very style of buying promises better for the future of the season than it would if the purchases were heavy at the present.

The organization of the surface railroad employes in Manhattan and Brooklyn was yesterday reported as making great progress, and two-thirds of the men, motormen, conductors, and station and power house employes have already been enrolled.

OCEAN GROVE, June 25. -- The first meetings of the regular Summer religious services were held to-day under the auspices of the Ocean Grove Camp Meeting Association of the Methodist Episcopal Church. The several meetings were attended by thousands of Methodists from all parts of the country.

CHICAGO. June 5. -- Secretary Easley of the Civic Federation of Chicago, under whose direction a conference will be held in Chicago Sept. 13-16, to consider trusts and combinations and legislation for their control, has received hundreds of letters from prominent men all over the country accepting invitations to be present at the meeting.
There are several points in the settlement arrived at in the Cleveland street railroad strike that are of much importance.

CHICAGO, June 25. -- A special to The Chronicle from Jefferson City, MO., says: "The State Board of Equalization has decided upon a plan of taxing the franchises of Missouri corporations. It will begin with the railroads.

When Gov. THOMAS of Colorado gets his fellow-Governors and the Attorney General of the United States together to talk over the evils of trusts and how they should be made to conduct their business we hope that he will invite representatives of the various farmers' organizations in the nature of trusts described by Mr. HOLMES of the Department of Agriculture before the Industrial Commission.

HAVERSTRAW, June 25. -- Archbishop Corrigan to-day officiated at the dedication ceremonies of the handsome new Slavonic Catholic Church which has just been completed at this place. The Archbishop was assisted in the impressive service by thirty priests. The dedication service was begun at 10 A.M. and lasted until noon.

A great deal of honest and intelligent and public-spirited work has from time to time been done by volunteers toward improving the condition of life in the tenement houses which lodge the great majority of the inhabitants of this city. One of the most noteworthy of these public services is that which has just been done by the Tenement House Committee of the Charity Organization Society.

ST. LOUIS, June 25. -- St. Louis played a double header with New York and Cleveland to-day and lost both games. The contests, however, were exciting all through, and neither game was won until the last man was out. Schreckengost, who was recently traded to the Cleveland Club by St. Louis, made three hits and won the game for his club. Attendance, 10,000. Score:

LONDON, June 27. -- The correspondent of The Daily News at The Hague says: "The German delegates to-day privately informed their colleagues that they had received instructions to accept the principle of a permanent tribunal of arbitration as outlined in the Anglo-American plans.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., June 26. -- Brig. Gen. Charles King, who returned from the Philippines a short time ago, in a letter to The Milwaukee Journal, published to-day, states that the capability of the Filipinos for self-government cannot be doubted, and if given a fair start, they could look out for themselves infinitely better than our people imagine.

The managers of fifteen concert and music halls at Coney Island and in the Borough of Manhattan were summoned before the Police Board yesterday to show cause why their licenses should not be revoked for violations of the laws. Ex-District Attorney Ridgway of Brooklyn represented the Coney Island people.

A pamphlet has been sent to us by the Finnish Committee in the United States called "Russian Perfidy in Finland -- the Story of the Coup d'Etat." Its chief value lies in the abundant citations from the text of various official documents in which the exact relation of the Grand Duchy of Finland to Russia is set forth, with the language of the pledges made by the successive Czars as Grand Dukes.

AUSTIN, Texas. June 26. -- Gov. J.D. Sayers received the following reply to-day to the invitation to attend the proposed anti-trust conference, to be held in St. Louis Sept. 20, from Gov. Henry Gage of California:

The Anchor Line steamship City of Rome, which caused a great deal of uneasiness in shipping circles on her outward bound passage to Glasgow by being reported as steaming eastward directly in the path of west-bound steamers, signalized her arrival from Glasgow early yesterday morning by running into the New Jersey Central Railroad steamboat Monmouth in the lower bay.

The New York Presbytery met in adjourned session yesterday afternoon at the First Presbyterian Church. The care taken by the members of the Presbytery to keep their proceedings from the press was the cause of precipitating a warm discussion, in which pointed references were made to one minister who, it was said, was guilty of the crime of having been "seen at different times talking with five or six members of the press."

BREST, France, June 26. -- The French first-class cruiser rage, which put to sea Sunday evening, the belief being that she was going to meet the Sfax, having Capt. Alfred Dreyfus on board, returned here at 7 o'clock this evening.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., June 26. -- A continuous performance of howling farce, lasting eight hours, a rare vocal entertainment, with soloists and a chorus of several hundred voices, declamation, and tin horn tests of lung power, made up the programme of the sixth day's session of the Democratic State Convention, and it narrowly escaped winding up in an exhibition of pugilism and marksmanship.

Superintendent Smith of the menagerie in Central Park has been for the past three weeks taking count of stock, and he has come to the conclusion that he is overstocked. He will have an auction sale on Friday.

Roger H. Lyon, a lawyer of 170 Broadway. is the attorney, he says, of capitalists who have arranged to incorporate in New Jersey the "American Isthmus Ship Canal Company," with a capital of $30,000, which may be increased to $250,000,000. ADAMS, Mass., June 26. -- The vacation which President and Mrs. McKinley have been enjoying here as the guests of the Hon. and Mrs. W.B. Plunkett is at an end, and to-night the Presidential train bore them toward the Nation's capital. The President returned to his executive labors in remarkably fine health, but Mrs. McKinley is quite poorly, and it was on her account that the present stay was curtailed by two days.

NASHUA, Iowa, June 26. -- Miss Minnie Murray was married this afternoon to H. Sternberger of Cripple Creek, Col., and immediately after the ceremony the couple left for their new home in the West. The bride was the "woman in white" who gained prominence in 1896 by her enthusiasm for Gov. Boies at the Chicago Convention.

GALES FERRY, Conn., June 26. -- Today's work has been characterized by considerable racing between the Harvard 'Varsity and freshman crews and also a determination on the part of the coaches to give the new Davis shell a thorough trial. Both crews went out together at 6:30 this evening.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 26. -- Newport is during the present season to be visited by several foreign noblemen, and if the President can change his present plans for the Summer, he and Mrs. McKinley will pass a week or so at the Summer home of a well-known cottager, in Bellevue Avenue, who enjoys the close friendship of the President.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 26. -- The class day exercises of the senior class of Yale University were held this afternoon in the amphitheatre erected on the campus for the occasion. About 1,200 people were in attendance.

POUGHKEEPSIE, June 26. -- Pennsylvania and Cornell shared honors equally on this the opening day of the intercollegiate regatta on the Hudson River. Pennsylvania's four-oared crew won the two-mile race against Cornell, and Cornell turned the tables in the eight-oared freshman race, winning cleverly from Columbia, with Pennsylvania a good third.

NEW HAVEN, June 26. -- The seventy-fifth anniversary of the Yale University Law School was celebrated this afternoon. The oration was made by Attorney General John W. Griggs, whose theme was "The Advances of Jurisprudence in the Nineteenth Century." The exercises were held in College Street Hall.

The Trust Company of America began business yesterday in the Singer Building under favorable auspices, and President Ashbel P. Fitch said last evening that the transactions of the day had been wholly satisfactory. The Clearing House agent for this trust company will be the Hanover National Bank, the company's registrar.

Railroad men and the financiers of Wall Street found an absorbing topic yesterday in the statement, published exclusively in THE NEW YORK TIMES, that the Boston and Albany Railroad was to be leased in perpetuity to the New York Central and Hudson River Railroad Company. The importance and far-reaching significance of the arrangement described was readily appreciated by persons familiar with railroad conditions in the Eastern States.

HAVANA, June 26. -- Owing to the murders, robberies, and depredations in the vicinity of Guanajay, the peasants are sending their families into the town. The Mayor, having decided it would be impossible to reach the culprits through the ordinary processes of law, issued all order for the arrest of all disreputable characters on suspicion.

WASHINGTON, June 26. -- Surgeon General Wyman, when shown the dispatch telling of the arrival at Honolulu of the Nippon Maru, on which the bubonic plague had made its appearance, said the Marine Hospital Bureau had received no information on the subject. This, he thought, was due to the fact that Dr. Carmichael of the Marine Hospital Service, who investigated the case, had gone into quarantine, and was therefore unable to communicate with Washington.

Michael Lyden, twenty-two years old, living with his parents at 69 Columbus Avenue, was shot and instantly killed in a saloon at 52 Amsterdam Avenue shortly before 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon by Dudley Smith, colored, twenty-five years old, of 237 West Sixty-first Street. Smith escaped at the time, but was later captured.

-- It is most curious that "Anglo-Saxon," when applied to the inhabitants of this country, seems to give fully as much annoyance to certain Americans whom it comes very near fitting as it dogs to certain others who have an undoubted right, at least on ethnic grounds, to find fault with it.

AUSTIN, Texas. June 26. -- Attorney General T.S. Smith stated to-day that he would keep his eye on the gigantic syndicate that is now seeking to get control of all the cattle in Texas. Under the provisions of the existing anti-trust law of this State the live stock industry is exempt, but there is no such exemption in the new anti-trust law, which goes into effect Jan.31, 1900.

PITTSBURG, Penn., June 26. -- It is said that all the tin plate works in the country will be closed at midnight on Friday as a result of the failure to settle the wage scale at the conference in Chicago. Fully 50,000 persons will be thrown out of work by the shut-down.

LONDON, June 26. -- Sir Thomas Lipton's America's Cup challenger Shamrock was successfully launched at 3 o'clock this afternoon, in the presence of an immense crowd, including many distinguished persons. She collided with a barge on reaching midstream from the slips, and for a time there was great alarm, but it was soon ascertained that she had received very little, if any, injury.

GALES FERRY, Conn., June 26. -- The work of this the opening day of the week in which Harvard and Yale boating supremacy is to be settled was light. The Yale University crew started in for its day's work at 9 A.M., and pulled a mile up the river and back practicing starts, followed by stretches of thirty strokes.

LONDON, June 26. -- At Wimbledon to-day in the lawn tennis singles championship, R.L. Doherty, holder of the championship, defeated A.W. Gore, three sets to two. Ill the ladies' final championship, Mrs. Hilliard beat Mrs. Steadman two to one. In the gentlemen's doubles, Hobart and Nisbet beat Simond and Caridian, three sets to two. In the third round Gore and Barrett beat Dixon and Ritchie, three to one.

Lemuel Ely Quigg, President of the Republican County Committee, yesterday announced that he intends to make an issue of a coalition between the Independents and Republicans in the coming Fall campaign. He is willing to accept a re-election only on the condition that he shall be empowered to arrange for the support by the Republican organization of independent candidates for Assemblymen and Aldermen in the hope of defeating Tammany Hall.

BOSTON. June 26. -- The Rev. Dr. Nathan F. Wood was formally chosen President of the Newton Theological Institute to-day. Dr. Wood will give up his pastorate at the Commonwealth Avenue Baptist Church, and go to Newton at once.

According to Major THOMAS W. SYMONS of the Canal Commission, "the commission will not recommend the spending of another cent of the people's money until some plan is adopted which will provide a guarantee that it will be properly used."

Commencement exercises of the class of '99 of the College of St. Francis Xavier were held last night at Carnegie Music Hall. Archbishop Corrigan presided, and awarded the diplomas and prizes. Two stake events, a handicap at a mile and three overnight events furnished the sport at Sheepshead Bay yesterday for about 5,000 visitors. There was nothing out of the ordinary in the day's racing, except, perhaps, the small size of the fields that showed up in the Spindrift and Spring Stakes, and the case with which both stakes were won, respectively by Ethelbert and Mischievous.

A petition in involuntary bankruptcy was filed here yesterday against the National Shear Company, commonly known as the Shear Trust, whose office until recently was at 290 Broadway, and headquarters at Newark, N.J., by Arthur E. Dennison, W. Stanley Campbell, and Louis A. Wyman, all of Boston, whose claims aggregate $27,000, all on notes of the company to the order of J.C. Pearson of Boston.

The Trustees in liquidation of the Standard Oil Trust accounced yesterday that over two-thirds of the trust certificates have been converted into the corporative stocks to which holders were entitled, and requested that such certificates as are now outstanding be presented for exchange without delay in order that the trust may be completely liquidated.

The Executive Committee appointed by Mayor Van Wyck last week to arrange the details of the reception to Admiral Dewey met in the City Hall yesterday for the purpose of organization. Mayor Van Wyck called the meeting to order, and Gen. Daniel Butterfield, on the motion of the Mayor, was unanimously elected Chairman.

Whatever else may be thought of the action of the clergyman who preached in Newport on Sunday against the social recognition of those persons of either sex whom he called "home wreckers," it will be admitted that his sermon showed no lack of courage. It is true that the church in which he preached, though a fashionable, is not the fashionable, church of Newport.
BIRMINGHAM, England, June 26 -- Joseph Chamberlain, Secretary of State for the Colonies, addressing the Unionists of this city this evening, carefully reviewed the Transvaal question.

PAINESVILLE, Ohio, June 26. -- Senator Burrows of Michigan is visiting here. In an interview to-day he declared that his colleague, Senator McMillan, would be a candidate to succeed himself, and would be reelected next year. Concerning Secretary Alger's alliance with Gov. Pingree, Senator Burrows said he thought the Secretary had destroyed what chance he might have had to go to the Senate by making such an alliance.
