TOLEDO, Ohio, June 26. -- Fire to-day entirely destroyed the Michigan Central freight house, partially destroyed the Cincinnati, Hamilton and Dayton freight house and burned one hundred loaded cars, the aggregate loss amounting to over $300,000, a very small part of which is covered by insurance.
Secretary Robert B. Kerr probably will have fully 100 names to announce this afternoon as the entries for the amateur golf championship, beginning July 3, at the Onwentsia Club, near Chicago.

BOSTON, June 26. -- There is now visible on the surface of the sun a spot which, it is said, is by far the most remarkable seen in twenty years. Its appearance has been a great surprise to observers, as, according to the astronomical almanac, this is the eleventh, or off, year for sun spots, and besides this it appeared with a suddenness which is unusual.

Both the Boston and Albany and the New York Central Railroads were built Up by consolidations, the piecing together of detached and fragmentary lines constructed in the early days when a road from Boston to Worcester or from Utica to Syracuse was a bold venture for capital and enterprise.

The legal struggle for the right to use the words "Colonial Dames" was continued in the Supreme Court before Justice Bookstaver yesterday. The trial appeared to be the most exclusive social function in the city, as, aside from the court officials and reporters, nobody but the Colonial Dames of the several factions and their special friends and kinspeople was allowed to enter the room.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 26. -- This evening the second mate of the Columbia was sent on shore to summon Dr. Knapp to attend Mrs. C. Oliver Iselin, who was on board the tender St. Michaels, ill with a cold. Later a trained nurse was sent on board to attend her, and in case she is no better to-morrow will leave the tender and start for her home.

The opening matches in the metropolitan championship lawn tennis tournament drew a large crowd of spectators yesterday to the courts of the West Side Tennis Club, Eighty-ninth Street and Central Park West. The club has secured an unusually fine entry list for its third annual tournament this year.

LONDON, June 26. -- The International Council of Women opened to-day in the Convocation Hall of the Church House, instead of the large hall of Westminster Town Hall, which was found to be too small to accommodate the delegates.

BRISTOL, R.I., June 26. -- The new cup defender Columbia, fully completed, was turned over to the owners, represented by C. Oliver Iselin, this afternoon, and to-night left for Newport in tow of the tender St. Michaels.

Before the races began at Sheepshead Bay yesterday afternoon, horsemen gathered in the American Horse Exchange paddocks, opposite the track, where the yearlings from the Ellerslie Stud, the property of R.J. Hancock, were sold at auction. The first animal led into the ring was a handsome chestnut colt by imp. Charaxus-Genevieve, and he brought the best price of the sale.

CHICAGO, June 26. -- Three thousand men and boys went on a strike at the packing houses this morning, and they were driven from the stock yards by a large force of policemen. There was no disorder, for the promptness of the police, under Capt. Lavin, prevented the strikers from assembling about the plants after they had refused to go to work.

PARIS, June 26. -- When the new Cabinet members presented themselves with a declaration of policy of the Chambers to-day exciting scenes and lively debates followed, but the Senate and the Chamber of Deputies finally approved the declaration -- the Senate by a vote of 187 to 25 and the Chamber of Deputies by a vote of 263 to 237.
WASHINGTON, June 26. -- Gen. Otis, in reply to a cable from the War Department asking for information regarding the situation and conditions in the Philippines, today cabled a long reply, as follows:

A farewell luncheon was tendered yesterday at Zanghere's restaurant to the Rev. Dr. W.H.P. Faunce, the newly elected President of Brown University, by the Baptist Ministers' Conference of New York and vicinity. Over a hundred ministers were present. The Rev. Joseph Sullivan of Paterson, President of the conference, presided.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., June 27. -- Eight miners have just reached here from Alaska with $250,000, the result of two years' digging within twenty miles of Dawson. One of them, named W.H. Armstrong, has a nugget worth $360. "The country is full of idle men," said Armstrong, "and every steamer brings a lot more to swell the list.

NEWPORT. R. I., June 27. -- The race between the Columbia and the Defender for the trophy offered by the Newport Yacht Racing Association, to be sailed off Newport, has been arranged by the Regatta Committee of the association, Capt. Woodbury Kane and Mr. Ralph N. Ellis, and the date has been set for July 20.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 27. -- After crossing the line the giants from Wisconsin paused a moment to take in their surroundings and then wormed their way out from among the maze of rowboats and small yachts that lined the course on its shore side. They immediately rowed across the river to their boathouse, which is situated about opposite the finish mark.

MADRID, June 27. -- The disturbances at Saragossa were excitedly discussed to-day in the Chamber of Deputies. Senor Romero y Robledo asked if it were true that eight had been killed and forty wounded. Senor Dato, Minister of the Interior, replied in the negative.
WASHINGTON, June 27. -- The weekly crop bulletin issued by the Weather Bureau to-day says:

MILWAUKEE, June 27. -- Gov. Roosevelt's daylight journey across Missouri, Iowa, and Illinois was a repetition of his journey West He arrived here at 11:30 to-night, and will leave on a special train at 3:15 P.P. to-morrow. Acrowd met him at Marceline and another at Bucklin. Telegrams poured into Paul Norton's car begging the Governor to speak at Fort Madison, Iowa, and Galesburg, Ill.

The Sheriff has an attachment against David B. Lee, at the Union Club, from the Countess Waldersee, who is Mr. Lee's sister. She claims that on Sept. 12, 1885, she loaned him $20,000 in Germany, and that he has never repaid the sum. The interest on the loan, she says, now amounts to $16,513.

One hundred and twelve golfers, representing forty-five clubs, comprised the amateur golf championship list given out yesterday by Secretary Robert B. Kerr of the United States Golf Association. Undoubtedly a full hundred will start next Monday morning on the Onwentsia Club links, near Chicago, for the amateur golf championship of the United States.

GOUVERNEUR, N.Y., June 27. -- The body of a well-dressed stranger was found to-day in the St. Lawrence River at a point near Massena. It was badly decomposed, and probably had been in the river two months or more. Two bad cuts were found near the heart.

Considerable doubt seems to exist concerning the value of the jewels brought here from Europe by Mrs. Phyllis E. Dodge and seized by the United States Customs officials last Saturday. The Customs officials in a general way say the gems are worth about $130,000, and add to this valuation wearing apparel, alleged to be contraband, which in the absence of proof to the contrary they place at several thousand dollars more.

NEWPORT, R. I., June 27. -- Some of the yachtsmen who saw the brushes between the new sloop yacht Columbia and the Defender, the champion of 1895, to-day are not so enthusiastic this evening over the speed of the new boat as they were after the short skirmish off Jamestown, on Sunday forenoon.
CHICAGO, June -- W. -- o4, dispatch to The Tribune from Detroit says:

The picture which Gen. OTIS paints of the situation in the Philippines is a sombre one. The rainy season has set in, practically putting an end to offensive military operations, and the native insurgents are not crushed. There are several thousand of them hanging on the edge of the belt which we hold around Manila.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., June 27. -- To-day was alumni day of commencement week of Union College. There was an unusually large number of graduates present. Gen. Daniel Butterfield, '49, of New York, was elected Alumni Trustee.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., June 27. -- William Goebel, who, with an iron grasp had ruled the Democratic State Convention since it assembled nearly a week ago, was nominated to-night for Governor on the twenty-sixth ballot after a contest unparalleled in this State for bitterness and determination, and, on the part of the winner, for skillful manipulation.

MANILA, June 28. -- Major Gen. Otis has ordered the opening up to trade of many important ports that have been closed since the outbreak of the war. These include San Fernando, on the west coast of Luzon, Aparri on the north coast, Curimao, and all ports in the islands of Samar and Leyte.
WASHINGTON, June 27. -- The President upon his return to Washington was promptly acquainted with the situation in the Philippines as exhibited in Gen. Otis's statement cabled yesterday.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 27. -- Pennsylvania's university eight won the intercollegiate boat race here this afternoon, after the finest contest in the history of boat racing. The crew from the University of Wisconsin was second, beaten by but half a length, after the gamest kind of a race, and beaten only because her coxswain steered the crew far out of the course in the last mile, and so lost a race that was practically won.

Ferdinand N. Shurtleff, who on May 15 last was removed from the position of General Appraiser by President McKinley, yesterday, through his attorneys, filed a petition in the United States District Court, and began suit against the Secretary of the Treasury to recover $307.69, the amount of salary he claims to be due him.

The reception of Gov. ROOSEVELT by the people of the Western States through which he has been traveling is attracting much attention, from Michigan to the Berkshires. If the Governor were the ordinary ambitious politician, the President might well regard his going to and fro in the land with suspicion and resentment, but also with perfect equanimity, for to the ordinary ambitious politician the pace would be fatal.

LONDON, June 27. -- The Shamrock's mast was stepped to-day, and the fitting of her spars and standing and running gear is proceeding rapidly. The length of her lower mast is given as 108 feet, her topmast is said to measure 70 feet, and it is reported that her boom is 110 feet long.
NEWPORT, June 27. -- Miss Whitney Lake has arrived from Boston for the Summer.

J. Pierpont Morgan and H. McK. Twombly attended a meeting of the Directors of the Lake shore and Michigan Southern Railroad in the Grand Central Station yesterday. President W.H. Newman was also present, and business pertaining to the internal affairs of the Lake Shore Road was transacted.

Public buying showed in yesterday's stock market. Such transactions have not been recently much in evidence. Bear speculators were still aggressively trying to force quotations downward, but new sentiments of confidence withstood the raids.

The contracts entered into some years ago between the winegrowers of California and the Winemakers' Corporation of that State, whereby the growers were to turn over their wines to the corporation, expire with this year's vintage, and whether the corporation will be dissolved or not is a question that is exciting deep interest in trade circles.

LONDON, June 27. -- The Duke of Norfolk, Premier Duke, Hereditary Marshal of England, presided to-day at a special meeting of the Catholic Union Society of Great Britain, convened to hear an address by Archbishop Ireland.

The daily budget of chatter from the different resorts is not very prolific of news. The "season," while it is supposed to have died some time ago in town, does not seem to have revived anywhere else. There are house parties and a few little entertainments, but there is nothing of moment, and Newport is still indulging in anticipations which may or may not be realized.

-- A resident of Reading, Penn., has received from his son, now in Manila with the Twelfth United States Infantry, a letter containing the following passage: "Some of our soldiers have been placed upon the records as traitors and 'dishonorably discharged.' A number of them have gone over to the Filipinos and have already fought against us.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 27. -- The Harvard baseball nine this afternoon defeated the Yale nine on the eve of the Yale commencement. The game was won in the first inning, when Harvard scored three runs. After the first inning Yale played better ball than Harvard, though the team work of the visitors was decidedly better, and Yale was weak at bat.

There was genuine surprise among the followers of form at Sheepshead yesterday, when in the fourth race, a handicap at a mile and a half. P.S.P. Randolph's Knight of the Garter galloped home an easy winner in front of Ben Holladay, the long-distance champion for the past two years. Latson, George Boyd, and several other good distance horses.

CHICAGO, June 27. -- The 1893 scale of wages decided on by the packers Monday was put into effect at the stock yards to-day, and fully 1,000 men who had struck returned to work in the various plants, some 700 or more of them going into the Armour establishments alone. On the other hand, secret meetings of the workers were numerous.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., June 27. -- Several months ago Silas Hawks, a farmer living near Little York, Hunterdon County, died, leaving his property to his son, Silas Hawks, Jr. The property was encumbered with a mortgage, which it was thought Hawks would be unable to raise. A few days ago Hawks was tearing out an old brick oven in the house, when he came across a rusty tin box.
CLEVELAND, June 27. -- The home team outbatted the New Yorks to-day, but its hits were badly scattered. The New Yorks, on the other hand, hit opportunely and ran bases well. Score:

GALE'S FERRY, Conn., June 27. -- Although the coaches who have the developing of the Yale crews realize that there are yet some slight imperfections in the work of their men, they evidently feel that it is better to let them go into the race in their present condition rather than attempt to drive new points into them at this critical time.

NEW LONDON, Conn., June 27. -- This old harbor town is ready for its chief annual event, the boat race between crews representing Harvard and Yale Universities. Anticipation is keyed up to the highest pitch. The people expect to-morrow, the day of the race, the largest crowd that has attended a similar contest here in many years.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., June 27. -- A race riot of serious character is raging at Brookside, a mining town fourteen miles west of this city. Three negroes are already dead and another is fatally wounded. Meanwhile both whites and negroes, who have been heavily armed for the last two days, are still in an attitude of defiance, and more bloodshed is expected.

Tatham Brothers' shot tower, at 82 Beekman Street, caught fire last night for the second time in its history. The fire caused a loss of only $3,000, and, unlike the first fire, in March, 1895, there were no casualties.

SEATTLE, Washington, June 27. -- The latest advice from the newly discovered goldfields at Cape Nome, Alaska, are contained in a letter from Major E.S. Ingraham of Seattle, who writes under date of Feb. 2, 1899. Major Ingraham is the leader of a party of fourteen men who were fitted out by Prince Luigi of Italy and local business men.

WILMINGTON, N.C., June 27. -- The Clyde Line freight steamship Pawnee, Capt. A.D. Ingram, which left Brunswick, Ga., on June 23, with a cargo of lumber and cotton for New York, was destroyed by fire on Sunday when off Currituck, on the North Carolina coast. The Captain and crew were forced to abandon the ship and take to one of the small boats.

The Executive Committee of the Manhattan Railway Company had its usual session yesterday, but authorized publication of information of importance in regard to the progress made toward equipping the system with electric motive power. The official statement given out by President George J. Gould was as follows:

Frightened by the whistle of an elevated railroad engine and a rapidly running electric car, the three big horses that draw Engine No. 33 ran away with the engine while the apparatus was being coupled to a fire hydrant opposite Cooper Union early yesterday morning. Driver Henry Bohme, thirty-two years old, of 62 First Street, in trying to stop the runaways, was seriously injured, and is now in St. Vincent's Hospital.

A.A. McCormick has sold for Elliot Zborowski of Paris, France, the Parkway Apartment House, at 45 West Seventy-second Street, adjoining the northeast corner of Columbus Avenue and the street, on a lot 50 by 102.2. The seller purchased this property in 1890 and gets a cash consideration for it now. The price and the buyer's name are withheld. It is understood, however, that the building brings well over $100,000.
BERLIN, June 27. -- The steamer Kaiser Friedrich, which was built for the North German Lloyd Company, not having fulfilled the conditions of the contract, has been rejected by the company.

I was much interested in reading the article appearing in THE TIMES of the 19th inst., written by Mr. Edward Atkinson of Boston, and with your kind permission desire to say a few words in relation thereto.

LONDON, June 27. -- An immense meeting, attended by more than 2,000 persons, was held in Queen's Hall this evening, the Countess of Aberdeen presiding, for the discussion of a resolution, proposed by Baroness von Suttner of Austria, calling upon the International Council of Women to do all in its power to advance the interests of international arbitration.

The announcement that Gov. PINGREE and Secretary ALGER have made up their differences is by no means "confirmed." On the contrary, Gov. PINGREE has taken some disagreeable pains to show that he is not a McKinley man, and that he is not an Alger man if ALGER is a McKinley man.

I frequently notice in THE TIMES, which I read daily, (and other journals,) attacks on the so-called anti-imperialists. I take pleasure in saying that I am not one of them. My impression is that the parties most generally attacked are not so much opposed to the war as to the manner of its conduct.

Commencement exercises in many of the public schools of the city were held yesterday and were largely attended, the graciousness of nature in sky and atmosphere adding to the general enjoyment. Notable instances of faithful and often brilliant work on the part of pupils, girls a well as boys, were recorded in several schools.

WASHINGTON, June 27. -- In an interview given out Sunday night, after his return to Washington from the West, Secretary of War Alger, after stating that his views did not "stand as those of the Administration," added:

CHICAGO, June 28. -- With the exception of the trouble at the Vilas Robbins plant, where about 500 men and boys refused to work to-day, the epidemic of strikes at the packing houses appears to be at an end. In every plant notices were posted to-day warning employes that any one quitting before the regular hour would be discharged.

Robert P. Porter sailed on the American Line steamer St. Paul yesterday for Europe. He arrived in this country some days ago from a tour of Europe, and returns to complete economic investigations m Russia. Asked about his Cuban and Puerto Rican tariff and fiscal work, Mr. Porter said the fiscal machinery of the two islands was working satisfactorily.

The New York State Commerce Commission, appointed to inquire into the decline of the export trade at this port, met in the room of the Board of Managers in the Produce Exchange yesterday to listen to testimony. Charles A. Schieren presided.

LONDON. June 28. -At to-day's session' of the International Council of Women, Mrs. Stanton Blatch read a paper on "Primary Education," advocating the introduction of manual training at every period of education, but deprecating the introduction of domestic occupations and the attempt to adapt trades to educational processes.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, June 28. -- The people of Cincinnati will erect two bronze memorial tablets at Fort Thomas, Ky., on July 1, the anniversary of San Juan Hill. One is for a lasting tribute to the Sixth Regiment of United States Infantry, and the other in memory of Col. Harry C. Egbert, formerly of that regiment.

The two negroes, Joseph Robertson of Fifteenth Street and Third Avenue, Coney Island, and John Seymour of 327 West Thirty-seventh Street, Manhattan, who were arrested Tuesday charged with being implicated in the theft of $4,700 from "Charles Brown," in Seventh Avenue, were discharged by Magistrate Cornell, in the Jefferson Market Court, yesterday.

LONDON, June 28. -- The Pall Mall Gazette says it has discovered in London two members of the Clan-Na-Gael, from the United States, who are en route to the Transvaal and trying to secure money and men in support of the Boers.
Annual commencement exercises were held in a number of public schools in the city yesterday.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 28. -- The annual commencement of Yale University was celebrated to-day. The weather was decidedly inauspicious, rain beginning to fall about 9:30 A.M., a quarter of an hour before the forming of the elaborate procession.

A special dispatch from London to The Chicago Tribune explains the wreck of the Paris on the Manacles, in the English Channel, as due to a simple error of Capt. Watkins. It is said in the dispatch that Capt. Watkins, on leaving Cherbourg, entered the departure in the log of the Paris "6:35 P.M." The next entry was "Passing Caskets 7:35."

Man's inhumanity to man is as often manifested upon the champaign of politics as on the firing line or in the fighting top. Here is Gov. ROOSEVELT prancing through the West, drawing great crowds and evoking the plaudits of the people without a thought of the woe of which his proceedings may be the occasion in the bosoms of others.

CHICAGO, June 28. -- Gov. Roosevelt arrived in Chicago from Milwaukee to-night over the Northwestern Road. The run of eighty-seven miles was made in ninety minutes, record breaking time. A carriage took the Governor to the Lake Shore Station, where he left for the East. Many shook hands with him at the station and he was given a hearty good-bye.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., June 28. -- The Republican race for Governor is about won, though the convention does not take place for three weeks. Attorney General Taylor has received 820 instructed votes for Governor and 848 are necessary to nominate. His nomination on the first ballot seems certain, as he has the support of the administration people.
BOSTON, June 28. -- Regarding the negotiations for the absorption of the Boston and Albany by the New York Central Railroad. The Transcript says:

Lieut. Melton K. Schwenk died at his residence, 59 West One Hundred and Twenty-seventh Street, last evening from appendicitis and a complication of diseases. He was taken ill Monday and was to have been removed to St. Luke's Hospital at 3 o'clock yesterday, but his condition became too serious.

The Secretary of the Tenement House Committee of the Charity Organization Society, in a polite and interesting communication which we elsewhere publish, at once thanks THE TIMES for, and takes exception to, a recent article upon the conditions of improved tenement houses.

The members of the Fourth Avenue Presbyterian Church by a vote of 175 to 5 last night extended a call to the Rev. Dr. Walter D. Buchanan to become their pastor. An effort was made to have the call made unanimous, but the five -- all of them were women -- remained obdurate and their votes were recorded in the negative. The salary is $5,000 a year.

There are a few old plainsmen who would have given much to have been in Central Park yesterday morning to take part in the only buffalo hunt that this city has, perhaps, ever known, at least as far back as the memory of the oldest inhabitant serves. It only needed some cowboy costumes to make the thing a very good imitation of a buffalo hunt on the Western plains.

During the extreme heat of the early part of this month those of our citizens who have had occasion to traverse many of the treeless city streets have doubtless longed for the passing relief at least which the grateful shade of trees would have afforded.

CINCINNATI, June 28. -- Fifteen thousand people assembled at Saengerfest Hall tonight expecting to listen to a concert marking the opening of the golden jubilee of the North American Saengerbund, and left sorely disappointed. No concert was given. The hall was not completed, so far as the stage and flooring were concerned, and no notice had been given of the unexpected delay.

Albert S. Moore, who lives in Brewster, Putnam County, has filed a petition in bankruptcy here, with liabilities of $86,415 and no available assets. He had 124 shares of the East River Silk Company of Astoria, but they are pledged as collateral for more than their value. His life is insured for $10,300 in his wife's favor.

RICHMOND, Va., June 28. -- At a meeting of prominent Jewish citizens and residents of French birth held here to-night steps were taken to celebrate the vindication of Dreyfus, should the court acquit him.
NEWPORT, June 28. -James Van Alen will soon return from his fishing trip in Canada and entertain a number of his friends at dinner at Gooseberry Island, and sail for England for the Summer.

AUSTIN, Texas, June 28. -- Attorney General Smith to-day rendered an opinion that when a foreign corporation, which has been granted a permit to do business in this State, becomes delinquent in its franchise tax payment, and fails to make such payment, together with the prescribed penalty of $5 per month, within six months from the time the delinquency occurs, its right to do business in Texas cannot be revived by getting a new permit.

CLEVELAND, June 28. -- The Great Lakes Towing Company was organized here today with a capital stock of $5,000,000, one-half of which is to be preferred and the other half common stock. The papers of incorporation will be filed in New Jersey within the next week by James H. Hoyt of this city.

LONDON, June 28. -- The twenty-second round of the International Chess Masters' Tournament was begun at St. Stephen's Hall, Westminster, at noon to-day, when the pairing, adopted from the second round of the Berger system, was as follows:

The assailants of Admiral SCHLEY have now burned all their powder and he remains next to DEWEY the most popular and generally admired officer of our navy. His professional standing has been quite unaffected by the assaults made on him inside and outside the department, and his reputation as an officer and a gentleman has been enhanced by his manly behavior under the fire of calumny and slander.

Another important purchase by Henry Corn was announced yesterday, Mr. Corn has bought from Mrs. Mayer Kahn the two-and-a-half story old buildings 838 and 840 Broadway, on a plot with a frontage of 50.6 on Broadway and 192 on Thirteenth Street, a rear line of 28.10, and a south line, irregular, of about 95.4.

I have read with interest a report in to-day's TIMES of a sermon preached yesterday in Newport, R.I., by the Rev. Mr. Hamilton. Surely, all right-minded persons must agree with him in his denunciation of those whom he calls "home wreckers," but is he not too severe in asking for the social ostracism of divorced people in general?

WASHINGTON, June 28. -- Although it is admitted at the War Department that forces to strengthen Gen. Otis are to be provided, and that when they are raised Otis will have fully 30,000 effectives all the time, the details for the raising and equipment of the men are not discussed by War Department officials.

NEW LONDON, Conn., June 28. -- In a thirty-eight-mile beat to windward, the new yacht Columbia beat the Defender eight minutes, besides giving the old champion a two-minute handicap. Yachtsmen from New York and hereabouts are jubilant, for the yacht's most sterling qualities must come out in a race to windward.

AUSTIN, Tex., June 28. -- Leopold Schwarzman, a cigarette manufacturer of the City of Mexico, passed through here to-day on his way to Montreal, Canada. He stated that negotiations for the combination of all of the principal cigarette factories in Mexico have been completed. The capital of the new syndicate is $1,750,000.

WASHINGTON, June 28. -- Gen. Harrison Gray Otis of Los Angeles, Cal., has been requested by the President to come to Washington to discuss with him the situation in the Philippines, where he served for many months with great credit to himself and his command, and he is expected to be here in a few days.

" Why did you devote your unusual talents to swindling people?" was asked of the Rev. John W. Brown, M.D., colored, after he had pleaded guilty to an attempt to commit grand larceny and had been remanded by Judge Hurd of the Kings County Court.

MILWAUKEE, June 28. -- "He won with our boys in blue, and will be our President, too." Thus ran one of the banner inscriptions displayed to-day in Milwaukee's flower parade, of which Gov. Theodore Roosevelt was the centre of attraction. But this apparently did not interest the Governor half as much as did another sentence displayed everywhere and on every lip:

PITTSBURG, June 28. -- Leever, the home team's pitcher, allowed the Brooklyns only five hits to-day. Three of these were made in the eighth inning, and enabled tile Brooklyns to score their only run. Hughes was easy for the home team, but miserable support helped materially in running up the score against him.

TRENTON, N.J., June 28. -- Senator Stokes is preparing a letter which a committee representing banks of the northern portion of New Jersey, including Trenton, will send on Saturday to the New York Clearing House. The letter will ask that the banks in the territory named be placed upon the discretionary list and be exempt from the collection fee imposed by the New York banks upon out-of-town checks.

The Board of Education held its bi-monthly meeting at the board rooms yesterday afternoon President Joseph J. Little presiding. Previous to the meeting of the board the Trustees of the Normal College held a short meeting and decided on a change in the course of study at the college. The course will hereafter be five and six years.

Permit me to thank you for your very valuable editorial in to-day's issue on "Our Tenement Houses" and for your words of approval of the suggestions of this committee. Your comments were based, I imagine, on the tentative suggestions offered by this committee to a conference of persons interested in the subject, held on May 12.

Might I be allowed to express a few thoughts that occurred to me one of these warm days in Central Park? With a book and a bicycle I strolled till I found a breezy seat in a large arbor, occupied only by half a dozen other readers. After a time there came an invasion of boys, and I supposed the arbor would become untenable.

BRUSSELS, June 28. -Another disturbance occurred in the Chamber of Deputies today when the order of the day of the Right was adopted, expressing confidence in the President of the House against the vote of the Socialists.

There is nothing better worth doing for a newspaper in this city just now than a full and faithful report of the proceedings of the Municipal Assembly. A "vitascope" of their doings might be even more instructive and exemplary. But then their proceedings are merely instructive, and therefore do not appeal to the people who glue their eyes to the peep-holes of the vitascope.

RENNES, June 28. -- The official list of the members of the Dreyfus court-martial, which is to assemble in the Army Service Building for the retrial of the prisoner is as follows: President -- Col. Jouraust; Major Brongniart, Major De Breon, Major Profilet, Major Merle, Capt. Parfait, Capt. Beauvais.

A meeting of the Directors of the New York Central Railroad will be held in the executive offices, Grand Central Station, tomorrow, for the purpose of considering the lease in perpetuity of the Boston and Albany Railroad by the New York Central. It is believed that the details of the arrangement described in THE NEW YORK TIMES of last Monday, will be definitely agreed upon at this meeting.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 28. -- Harvard University closed its 262d year to-day with the graduation of the class of 1899 and the conferring of degrees upon the members of the senior class and others, the course and honorary degrees reaching an aggregate of 986. The exercises were held in Sanders Theatre.

Public interest in the security market extends. Various manifestations of it were disclosed yesterday. All the standard stocks were strong, there being hardly an exception in the long list. The railroads of the West were conspicuously at the front, most of them reaching higher points than recently have been recorded; but leadership still was held by the Vanderbilt group, of which New York Central naturally was most prominent.

WASHINGTON, June 28. -- Secretary Alger seems to be about the only man in Washington who believes he will continue indefinitely to be Secretary of War. He insists positively, buoyantly, and cheerfully that he is going right along with that business and that his relations with Pingree will not in any respect or degree impair his standing with the President.

The Presidents of the trunk lines east of the Mississippi River, with the representatives of their principal western connections, met yesterday in the last regular session until September in the office of Joseph F. Goddard, Commissioner of the Trunk Lines Association, at 143 Liberty Street.

Your alert pension claim agent, the man who has learned that the supply of real applicants for pensions was likely to die out, and that the war with Spain was a blessing for pension claim agents, has taken the precaution to prepare many of the latest volunteers for introduction to the Pension Commissioner before they had ceased to be soldiers.

SCHENECTADY, June 28. -- At the commencement exercises of Union College to-day, the degree of LL.D. was conferred upon Hamilton W. Mabie of New York. The degree of L.H.D. was given to Prof. Ira N. Hollis of Harvard University.

Doubtless the golfers' week in Chicago may be prolific of lessons which, if heeded by the golfing powers that be, may lead to the betterment of the game in America. The difficulty which confronts the competitors in the annual contest for the championship now, on the eve of the event, however, indicates that those powers are not always as quick as they might be to heed lessons.

BALTIMORE, June 29.--Ex-Postmaster General James A. Gary, in an interview, declared that he is not a candidate for Governor, and that he will work for the re-election of Gov. Lowndes, who will probably be renominated by the Republicans. A Washington report states that McKinley wishes Gary to be the State leader and thus supplant Senator Wellington. This Gary denies.
WASHINGTON, June 29. -- Adjt. Gen. Corbin was not in his usually amiable frame of mind this morning when he reached his office.

President Clausen said yesterday that he had received an application from a man who desired to run an automobile in Central Park. It was said by the President that the request had been refused, as it was not thought proper to use the Park for such a vehicle, which might frighten horses and otherwise be a disfigurement or annoyance.
The fourteenth annual regatta of the New Rochelle Yacht Club to-morrow winds up this week's yachting, and next week the Sound circuit will begin. The schedule is as follows:

GLENS FALLS, N.Y., June 29. -- A certificate of incorporation of the Warren County Railroad has been filed with the Secretary of State. The company will build an electric freight and passenger road from Warrensburg to Lake George, a distance of seven miles. The principal stockholders are ex-State Treasurer A.B. Colvin and J.M. Coolidge of Glens Falls, J.A. Powers of Lansingburg, and Congressman L.W. Emerson of Warrensburg.

DETROIT, June 29. -- A complete lock-out is in effect this afternoon at Pingree Smith's big shoe factory, which employs upward of six hundred people. The only work in progress is that necessary to clean up the machines.

Gen. Leonard Wood, Governor of Santiago, was the guest of honor at an informal reception given yesterday afternoon in the Chamber of Commerce rooms by the Trustees of the Cuban Orphan Fund. The rooms of the Chamber were filled with well-known business men and others, including a number of women.

CHICAGO, June 29. -- The adjournment of Judge Waterman's court to-night at the close of the evidence in the case of Elizabeth Ann Ingersoll and John C. Collins, charged with kidnapping Gerald Lapiner, was marked by a pathetic scene. It was the action of the sister of Mrs. Ingersoll, praying the father of the boy to have mercy on the aged woman and his refusal to listen to her plea.

Mrs. Harvey J. Ramsey, who because her husband snored cut his throat with a razor, in the Garden Hotel, was yesterday found guilty of the crime by a Coroner's jury and declared to be temporarily insane. After the inquest was finished Mrs. Ramsey tried to commit suicide by stabbing herself with a hatpin. She was caught in time, however, by Policeman O'Rourke of the Coroner's office.

CHICAGO, June 29. -- Dean C. Worcester, member of the Philippine Commission, to-day cabled The Times-Herald denying reports that Filipino prisoners were shot by order of American officers. This was in response to a cable inquiry sent by H.H. Kohisaat, as follows:

NEWPORT, June 29. -- Mayor Boyle has reappointed W.W. Sherman as a member of the Park Commission, and when seed today Mr. Sherman stated that he had declined the appointment. This decision on the part of Mr. Sherman will be met with general regret by the people of this city who have seen so much of Mr. Sherman's good work on the commission for the past six years, and especially his work with the Boulevard.
QUEENSTOWN, June 29. -- The British second-class cruiser Melampus and the torpedo boat Gossamer have left this port to destroy the derelict bark Siddartha.

Edward F. Croker, Acting Chief of the Fire Department and nephew of the leader of Tammany Hall, was yesterday promoted by Fire Commissioner Scannell to be Chief of the department. The promotion was made without a civil service examination, although Commissioner Scannell on the day after the application of Chief Hugh Bonner for retirement was filed intimated that he would hold a competitive examination for the place.

LEXINGTON, Ky., June 29. -- Every indication points to a big bolt in the Democratic Party long before the November election, as leading Democrats to-day declared themselves against William Goebel, the Democratic nominee.

WASHINGTON, June 29. -- "The Brooklyn will not leave New York until after July 3. The men of that fine cruiser shall have their reunion, and, even if she were ready to go to Newport to-morrow, she should not budge until after July 3."

CHICAGO, June 29. -- Eleven hits off Doheny, together with four bases on balls, two wild pitches, two passed balls, five errors, and a batsman hit, gave Chicago their seventeen runs in the first three innings. After that the game was a farce. Attendance, 2,800. Score:

CLEVELAND, June 29. -- In the heavy northeast gale last night, the steamer Margaret Olwill, laden with stone from Kelley's Island to Cleveland, foundered in Lake Erie off Lorain. Nine persons were drowned. Four members of the crew have been picked up by passing steamers and brought into port.

The article in to-day's TIMES on the "California Wine Trade" is a very fair summary of the subject. In fact, it is more accurate than most of the accounts which have heretofore appeared in the daily papers.

An important purchase of property north of One Hundred and Seventy-seventh Street on the east side has been made through the City Real Estate Company, representing the Manhattan Railway Company, and Jefferson M. Levy, which is said to foreshadow the virtual extension of the elevated road to Yonkers as soon as the third-rail system is completed.
WASHINGTON, June 29. -- J.C. Monaghan, United States Consul at Chemnitz, in a report to the State Department dated April 24 says:
BRUSSELS, June 29. -- The city was the scene of further rioting to-night, growing out of contentions in the Chamber of Deputies concerning the Electoral bill.

CHICAGO, June 29. -- E.J. Brewer and Mrs. Eva Curtis former lovers, at one time engaged to be married, but now bitter enemies, stood in the private court of Justice Dooley this afternoon and told stories of their courtship, the many days spent together, the breaking off of the engagement, and the final separation.

The details of the acquisition of the Boston and Albany Railroad system by the New York Central will be discussed and possibly definitely acted upon at a meeting of the Directors of the Vanderbilt line today. Some of the stockholders of the Boston and Albany have been giving expression to their opinions within the past few days.

Seeing the following article in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Saturday, the 17th, causes me to request that you please publish in your interesting columns some facts about the first "White House" of the Confederacy, situated in the City of Montgomery, Ala.

Justice Bischoff, in the Supreme Court, yesterday handed down a decision respecting a widow's right in the body of her husband. The ease in which the decision is rendered is that of Mary P. Buchanan et al. vs. James D. Buchanan, an action for replevin and damages in the amount of $5,000, which was tried without a jury by consent.

The contention by Treasury Agents that on Saturday when she landed from the steamship St. Paul, Mrs. Phyllis E. Dodge of 104 West Eightieth Street attempted to smuggle jewels worth about $45,000, in that she did not declare them, is now under investigation by Col. Dudley S. Phelps, Chief of the Law Division of the Custom House.

The fight for supremacy in the Tammany Hall organization in the Ninth Assembly District yesterday assumed a new phase When John C. Sheehan, the present leader, declared that he and his friends had indubitable proof that his enemies had violated the Corrupt Practices act and that it was the intention to call the attention of the District Attorney and the Grand Jury to the matter.
LONDON, June 29. -- Senator-elect Chauncey M. Depew of New York is back in this city. When seen to-night he said:

THE TIMES has received a letter from a complaining reader and friend who dissents altogether from its views about AGUINALDO and our policy in the Philippines. His sympathies go out to the Filipinos in what he calls their struggle for liberty. He appears to think that we have no right to restore or maintain order in the islands.

The rooms in Front Street, Long Island City, which have been the headquarters of ex-Mayor Patrick Jerome Gleason for thirty-three years were finally closed last night in a blaze of glory. The owner has determined to pull down the old rooms and replace them with an office building, and the preliminary work of demolition will begin to-day.

The Board of Estimate yesterday paid its respects to the Council by adopting unanimously a resolution rebuking the latter for delaying public improvements and causing the discharge of laborers by holding up bond issues. This is the first time the Board of Estimate has taken any action in regard to the delinquency of the Municipal Assembly.

Miss Mabel F. Green, who was crushed yesterday morning by an elevator in the German-American Insurance Company's building, at Nassau and Liberty Streets, died last night in the Hudson Street Hospital from a compound fracture of the right leg, extensive lacerations of both legs, and shock.

AUSTIN, Texas, June 29. -- Many inquiries have been received here from the East regarding the recent ruling of Attorney General Smith, excluding from this State corporations incorporated in another State for the purpose of doing business in Texas. Attorney General Smith to-day furnished Gov. Sayers with the following reasons for his ruling:

NEW LONDON, Conn., June 29. -- When the news was carried to the Harvard quarters, immediately after the finish of the 'Varsity race, the band was at once taken in hand by some Harvard boys and coached in playing "Fair Harvard." The cooks, waiters, boatmen, and two or three outsiders joined in hoarse yells of joy.

HAVANA, June 29. -- An interesting point has come up in connection with the insurance companies. These organizations now have to lodge their capital in the Cuban Treasury, instead of the Spanish, as was formerly the case. They take the ground that under the new regime the only change is in the place of deposit, and that in all other respects the law is as before.

Knollwood opened its links and clubhouse to visiting golfers from local clubs yesterday, giving the first big tournament in two years on its excellent eighteen-hole course. Two years ago the Knollwood Country Club, which is situated between White Plains and Elmsford, was one of the most active in promoting the game of golf.

The attempt to do business in the State of Texas is already punishable by fine and imprisonment in certain cases. If Populistic rage continues to inhabit the minds of the lawmakers and public officers of that State it is probable that within a few years resort will be had to sterner measures.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 29. -- While a bather clung for his life to the piling of Young's ocean pier this afternoon a crowd of carpenters and spectators on the pier above his head madly tore up the flooring of the big dancing pavilion in an attempt at rescue. It was successful, a rope being lowered, which he tied about his waist.
CLEVELAND, June 29. -- The visitors were outplayed to-day, the home team hitting opportunely and playing a fast game in the field. Score:

WASHINGTON, June 29. -- "There will be a sharp contest," said ex-Representative Kerr of Pennsylvania to-day, "for the control of the Pennsylvania delegation to the next Democratic National Convention. The regular Democracy, the supporters of the Chicago platform, will select the majority of the delegates, in my opinion, but the gold Democrats of Philadelphia and the money centres will make a hard fight for supremacy in the delegation."

Irving M. Scott, President of the Union Iron Works, San Francisco, the builders of the Oregon, Olympia, Charleston, San Francisco, and other war vessels, is in the city, and was among those who paid their respects to Gen. Leonard Wood at the Chamber of Commerce yesterday afternoon.

CAMBRIDGE, June 29. -- Not many students were left in Cambridge after the general exodus following commencement, but those who remained received the news from New London with an enthusiasm that would have done credit to three times the number.

CINCINNATI, June 29. -- Although quite a number of disappointed people left the city to-day, after the one-day postponement of the concerts of the Golden Jubilee Saengerfest of the North American Saengerbund, there was a multitude at the heal before 7 o'clock to-night, and they were not this time barred out by policemen.
A severe electrical storm passed over Long Island during the early hours of yesterday morning.

PITTSBURG, June 29. -- The Pittsburgs again defeated the Brooklyns by outplaying them at every point. In the third inning eight hits and six runs were made off Dunn. Sparks had poor control, and was relieved in the fourth by Tannehill, who held the visitors down to three hits. Attendance, 2,000. Score:

Before the races began yesterday at Sheepshead Bay Auctioneer William Easton held the sale of the Silver Brook Stud yearlings, the property of L.O. Appleby. There was a large attendance and some lively o dding A expected, the star of the sale was the brother to Henry of Navarre and The Huguenot, a handsome chestnut colt, by Knight of Ellerslie-Moss Rose.

NEW LONDON, Conn., June 29. -- Harvard swept the board here to-day in the regatta with Yale, winning all three races -- four-cared shell with coxswain, eight-oared freshman, and eight-oared 'Varsity -- in succession. It was a record for college boating that has certainly not been equaled in years. In each case the victory was clean-cut and decisive, so that there can be no complaint from the defeated ones.

An enterprising London bookseller has invented a new crime. He took novels that would not sell and pasted on them covers bearing the names of novels for which the public yearns. Then he displayed the deceiving volumes on his stand and the hurried passerby, noting only the title and the price, chose, paid, and continued on his deluded way.
SOUTHAMPTON, June 29. -- The America's Cup challenger, Shamrock, which at low water late yesterday evening was aground, with a list to port of fifteen degrees, was towed safely off the mud to-day.

ALBANY, June 29. -- Gov. Roosevelt, who stopped off at this city this afternoon for a few moments on his way to New York City from the West, declared that he is not a candidate for the Republican nomination for President in 1900, and that he is in favor of a renomination of President McKinley. In an interview at the railway station he said:

WASHINGTON, June 29. -- The President recently granted a pardon to Little Bear, convicted in the Indian Territory of horse stealing and sentenced to five years and two months in the Ohio Penitentiary. The pardon, which was issued on the ground that the prisoner was in the last stages of consumption, was received too late, as he died on the day before it was to go into effect.

Dullness but withal sturdy strength shows in the security market. The bear contingent is industrious but accomplishes little beyond extending an already large short interest; liquidation appears in no part of the market. Here and there, however, are soft spots, apparently.

LONDON, June 29. -- The Secretary of State for the Colonies, Joseph Chamberlain, and the Chancellor of the Exchequer. Sir Michael Hicks-Beach, received this afternoon a deputation for the Eastern Telegraph Company The Marquis of Tweed-dale and others expressed objection to State competition with private enterprise, referring to the proposed Pacific cable, and Sir Michael Hicks-Beach promised to furnish a written reply.

Much of the fashionable world was at New London yesterday. The boat races and the coming of the Defender and the Columbia were the attractions. The fleet of yachts from Newport and from New York was very large. Mr. and Mrs. Royal Phelps Carroll had a jolly party on the Navahoe, and the Gerrys went over in the Electra.

LEEDS, England, June 29. -- The third test cricket match between the visiting Australians and an All-England eleven opened here to-day. The weather was bright, though the wicket was soft after a night's rain and favorable to the bowlers. There were about 12,000 spectators present when the Australians went to the wickets.

The writ of habeas corpus obtained by the Hon. James Boothby Burke-Roche to comper his wife to produce their daughter Cynthia was dismissed by Justice Beekman, in the Supreme Court yesterday, in accordance with an agreement reached by both sides, by which it is understood, Mr. Burke-Roche will be able to see his daughter.

There seems to be considerable doubt about the race on the Sound between Columbia and Defender under the auspices of the Riverside Yacht Club, negotiations for which were announced yesterday in THE NEW YORK TIMES as being made. The club offered a five-hundred-dollar cup for the race, provided the race should be Columbia's first race in the Sound, and the next following that which is to take place off Sandy Hook.

NORFOLK, Va., June 29. -- It is now announced that the Peanut Trust, which has been talked of for some time, will within a very short time begin its existence under the name of the American Edible Nut Company.

For some unaccountable reason owners continue to spoil the daily programmes of the Sheepshead Bay meeting by scratching out their candidates and leaving only small fields to contend for the stakes and purses. This is especially noticeable in the stake events, where fields that are originally large enough to make the races open ones are reduced to perhaps three or four starters.

The resignation of Pierre Lorillard, Jr., from the Presidency of the P. Lorillard Tobacco Company led to the publication of a report that he had also determined to resign as Treasurer of the Continental Tobacco Company. CHICAGO, June 29. -- The trial of August Becker, charged with having murdered and then dismembered and boiled the remains of his wife in order to leave him free to marry Ida Sutterlin, a seventeen-year-old girl, was suddenly interrupted to-day when it was found that the indictment named Mrs. Becker as Elizabeth, when it should have been Therese.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 29.--The uncertainty of life was demonstrated to a large congregation of members of St. James's African Methodist Episcopal Church to-night, when the Rev. Joseph S. Thompson of Macedonia Church, Camden, was stricken in the presence of the audience and the assembled clergymen of the Camden District of the New Jersey African Methodist Episcopal Conference at the service marking the close of the district conference in session here for two days.

BUFFALO, June 29. -- The National Social and Political Conference resumed its session this morning to discuss non-partisan efforts in political reform. The subject is divided into eight subdivisions -- expansion and militarism, permanent internal tribunal, proportional representation, recall or imperative mandate, single tax, non-partisanship, temperance, and organized labor.

Many would-be arbiters of the Philippine question have had their fling in the papers, and one Edward Atkinson tried the bolder scheme of flinging firecrackers at the feet of our Bucephalus, in the hope of scaring something, but now he lies kicking in the back yard because papa will not let him play in the street.

The Tammany Hall Executive Committee yesterday practically sanctioned the revolt against the leadership of John C. Sheehan in the Ninth Assembly District by recommending to the Police Board for appointment as election officers the names of the men selected by Councilman Frank Goodwin, who is directing the attack against Mr. Sheehan.

PITTSBURG, June 30. -- The last day of the scale year of the Amalgamated Association of Iron, Steel, and Tin Workers ended at midnight. While definite figures cannot be given to-night as to how many men will be idle to-morrow, it is known that more than 50,000 of them will he forced to quit work temporarily, at least.

JEFFERSON CITY, Mo., June 30. -- The Missouri Supreme Court, sitting en banc to-day, awarded a writ of ouster on the information of Attorney General Crow against seventy-three foreign fire insurance companies doing business in St. Joseph, Mo., for violating the State Anti-Trust act of 1895. Under this decision the companies cannot continue doing business in the State.

LONDON, June 30. -- The Digger News, the Boer organ in London, prints a dispatch from Johannesburg to-day announcing, on reliable authority, that the Volksraad will be asked Monday to confirm an arrangement made by the Executive Council, acceptable to the British High Commissioner, Sir Alfred Milner, and the British Government.

In a recent letter concerning the senseless celebration of the Fourth of July, which appeared in your paper, "All Old Subscriber" dwelt too lightly, to my thinking, on the most serious evil which he mentioned. I say the most serious, for we will all acknowledge that moral injury is more than physical, and that which tends to moral deterioration of more importance than causes of physical distress, however upsetting the latter may prove.

" David Harum" has now reached its one hundred and ninetieth thousand, and is selling as high as 1,500 copies per day. With the exception of the religious novel, "In His Steps," of which, its publishers claim, over 300,000 copies in this country and Great Britain have been sold, "David Harum" has probably sold better than any work of fiction since "Trilby" was the rage.

The Committee on By-Laws and Legislation of the Board of Education, to whom was referred the consideration of the question which has been discussed by State Superintendent Skinner and City Superintendent Maxwell, as to the necessity of an examination under the control of the State Superintendent of Public Instruction as a qualification for a license to teach in the City of New York, reported at a special meeting of the board yesterday.

At a meeting of the Society of the Army of the Potomac, in Troy, a couple of years ago, Gen Lucius H. Warren called the attention of the assembly to the anomalous fact that, although there are many of statues of army and navy heroes in Washington, there is none of Gen McClellan, the first commander of the Army of the Potomac, who twice saved the National capital.

ROME, June 30. - A Cabinet council was held this evening, after which Gen Pelloux, the Premier, conferred with King Humbert, who signed a decree closing Parliament on account of the disorders in the Chamber arising over the discussion of the royal decree empowering the Government to prohibit public meetings and to punish strikers.

A sale of Central Park animals was conducted yesterday in the sheepfold on the west side of the Park. The animals were chiefly sheep, but some deer and Cape buffaloes and a pair of jackasses were sold.
The Wine and Spirit Gazette of to-morrow's date will devote much attention to the Distilling Company of America. It will say editorially:

THE HAGUE, June 30. -- The First Committee of the Peace Conference discussed to-day the reports of the War and Marine sub-committees on the Russian proposals to stop the increase in armaments and military budgets.

BAY CITY, Mich., June 30. -- Spencer O. Fisher, ex-Congressman, leading Democratic politician, and formerly a wealthy lumberman, has filed a petition in bankruptcy in the Federal Court. The action is the result of a series of misfortunes caused chiefly by the failures of others with whom Mr. Fisher had business relations.

COLD SPRING HARBOR, L.I., June 30. -- The State Fisheries Hatchery here is now engaged in lobster hatching. Superintendent Walters is sending away daily large shipments of young lobsters from twenty-four to forty-eight hours old. Yesterday 300,000 were skipped to Princess Bay, S.I. The greatest difficulty of the work is to keep the lobsters from eating each other.
ALBANY, June 30. -- The annual convention of the National League of Commercial Travelers of the United States opened here this afternoon.

The final round of the metropolitan championship lawn tennis tournament drew a large crowd to the courts of the West Side Tennis Club yesterday. The players were J.A. Allen, champion of Yale, and J.P. Paret of the Lenox Tennis Club. Paret won, after one of the most exciting matches of the season. The full five sets were played, and the experts seesawed in the lead, first one and then the other holding the advantage.

PEKING. June 30. -- The French Consul at Meng-Tzu. Province of Yun-Yan, where anti-foreign disturbances recently occurred, reports that the situation is unchanged. Thirty-eight well-armed Europeans took refuge in the residence of the Taotai after the siege of the Consulate, which is now guarded by troops.

The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court yesterday handed down a decision which recalls the burglary of the Manhattan Savings Institution. That bank sued the New York National Exchange Bank to recover nine one-thousand-dollar bonds of the City of Yonkers. The latter institution took them as security for a loan of $7,000 made to one Pell in 1896, nearly eighteen years after the burglary, when they were stolen.

Papers in the suit which has been begun in the Supreme Court by William H. Rieger to enjoin the Metropolitan Street Railway Company from using the subways which it has built and which it intends to build to hold electrical conductors to supply electrcity for heating, lighting, and power purposes, were yesterday served on the defendant company and on the other defendants who have been joined in the suit.

WINNEMUCCA, Nevada, June 30. -- Last night a special train containing Companies L and M of the Twenty-fifth United States Infantry and Company E of the Twenty-fourth Infantry arrived in Winnemucca. A number of men left the train and raided a neighboring saloon. They wrecked the bar and stole what liquor there was in sight. Chris Deiss, the barkeeper, was shot down by one of the soldiers, after which they all fled to the train.
WASHINGTON, June 30. -- The United States Consul at Salvador informs the State Department that yellow fever has made its appearance there.

Held securely in a wooden box and guarded as zealously as if it had been a tarantula, a small black pinch bug was carried into Bellevue Hospital last night by a man who declared it was one of the much advertised "kissing bugs." The man said his name is H.J. Smith, and that he lives at 42 Reid Avenue, Brooklyn.

The Asbury Methodist Church, at New Springville, S.I., is without a choir as the result of a remark the Rev. John McMurray is alleged to have made at a sociable one evening last week. At the sociable referred to the pastor, it is said, applauded a solo by one of the members of the choir and then remarked: "Why can't we have such singing as that on Sundays?"

Comment is aroused among those who study New York church conditions by the announcement that the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Archangel would undertake to build a new church in One Hundred and Sixteenth Street, somewhere between Eighth and Lenox Avenues. This is the precise field which the Rev. Dr. James Chambers, who lately gave up the struggle in Calvary Presbyterian Church, declares to have been pre-empted by the Jews.

WASHINGTON, June 30. -- The situation in the Philippines was discussed at the Cabinet meeting to-day, and general satisfaction was expressed in the Administration's plans for the reinforcement of Gen. Otis, which contemplate the reopening of active operations on a large scale when the rainy season closes, Sept. 15. Secretary Alger reported that enlistments were coming up to expectations.

HAVANA, June 30. -- Gen. Ludlow, Military Governor of Havana, in the course of an official communication to Gov. Gen. Brooke, complains of statements printed in American newspapers regarding the existence of yellow fever here, which intimate that the authorities have reasons of their own for concealing the actual facts of the case.

CHICAGO, June 30. -- Dr. John Cuthbert Hall, President of Union Theological Seminary of New York City, has been appointed to the Haskell Lectureship in Comparative Religion in the University of Chicago. The position, which is one of the highest in the gift of the local institution, requires that all lectures shall be given in India.

Their idea was that a victory for Harvard meant that the Harvard undergraduates, alumni, and sympathizers would spend their winnings here "like drunken sailors."

TRENTON, N.J., June 30. -- Articles of incorporation of the American Writing Paper Company were filed to-day. The authorized capital is $25,000,000. The Don Juan overture by Mozart, Saint-Saens's Symphonic Poem, the Weber-Berlioz "Invitation to the Dance," and Wagner's Kaiser March.

Lewis of Waukesha, Wis., that he would get an injunction to restrain the committee from carrying out its plan for exploding five tons of dynamite on the summit of Big Bull Mountain on July 4.

The women had assisted the men defenders, and the latter becoming strikingly less the fair sex armed themselves.

GETTYSBURG, Penn., July 1. -- The equestrian statue of Major Gen. John F. Reynolds, who commanded the First Corps of the Army of the Potomac, was unveiled to-day with appropriate ceremonies on the spot where the distinguished soldier was killed by a sharpshooter's bullet on the first day of the battle of Gettysburg.

WASHINGTON, July 1. -- The reports from Samoa of the progress being made by the Joint High Commission toward a settlement of the disturbed conditions existing there are received with satisfaction here. As to Mr. Chambers's future nothing has been assured. If he is to retire as part of the scheme of compromise projected by the commission it is probable the Administration will provide another post for him.

LINCOLN, Neb., July 1. -- State Auditor Cornell has provoked a sensation by refusing to turn over to the new Insurance Commissioner the records of the Insurance office.

BERLIN, June 22. -- A strike began in Berlin on Saturday, which threatens to prove the severest tussle that has taken place between capital and labor in Germany for several years. In consequence of a resolution taken by the Masons' and Bricklayers' Unions on Friday night, 7,700 men ceased work on Saturday morning.

BREST, July 1. -- The Sfax, which has arrived here, had several plates and her bulwarks slightly damaged by the heavy bumping of the Caudan against her sides when Capt. Dreyfus was transferred, the sea being very rough. The only incident on the arrival of the prisoner at Brest was the cheering by two sloops manned by boys belonging to the training ship Borda, which passed the Sfax as she was proceeding to her moorings.

The people clustered along the shore of Hudson Park, and hired all available boats to go out to the big sloops, for it takes a close look to satisfy even the land lubbers.

The waters of Long Island Sound, off Premium Point, were studded with the sails of racing craft yesterday on the occasion of the fourteenth annual regatta of the New Rochelle Yacht Club, and, towering above the biggest of the entries and the sightseeing craft, sloops, schooners, and others of every description, were the lofty spars of Columbia and Defender, which shared attention with the races.

The opponents of the bill continue the policy of seeking to kill it by bringing forward as many rival projects for compensation as possible, these now numbering about 150.

LONDON, July 1. -- Senator Hanna completed the first ten days of his stay in England at Windsor, where he witnessed a military review this afternoon and caught his first glimpse of the Queen. He has enjoyed London immensely, and his health has been so greatly benefited that he has postponed his visit to Paris and Aix-les-Bains for another week.

CHICAGO, July 1. -- Leaders of the disaffected element in the stock yards expressed themselves to-day as confident that there will be a general strike throughout the yards on Monday. They admit, however, that nothing will be settled until after the close of the mass meeting which is to be held to-morrow.

ST. PETERSBURG, June 17. -- All St. Peterburg is "en fete" for the centenary of Pouschkine's birth. Never before in the memory of Russians has one of their countrymen been so honored. Pouschkine, the great national poet, is the only subject of conversation in St. Petersburg. New editions of his works make their appearance almost daily.

WASHINGTON, July 1. -- The Washington Navy Yard has a new feature of interest in the lately completed model experimenting basin for which Congress made provision three years ago. It is now in full running order and busied with the models of the smaller cruisers authorized by the last Congress.
BRIDGEPORT, Conn., July 1. -- The New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad Company to-day completed, negotiations for the purchase of the property of the Bridgeport Steamboat Company.

WASHINGTON, July 1. -- Herr von Mumm, who is to be German Charge d'Affaires during the absence of the German Ambassador, will sail on the Prinz Regent Luitpold, arriving in New York about July 14, according to an official dispatch just received here.

There have been disagreements in other Cabinets, and sometimes members of the President's official family have disagreed as to public policies to be adopted and followed by Administrations.

AUSTIN, Texas, July 1. -- There has been another twenty-four hours of continuous heavy rainfall throughout the flooded district of Central and Southern Texas, with the result that the rivers and streams have had their overflows greatly augmented, inflicting additional loss and damage aggregating hundreds of thousands of dollars to the agricultural interests.

LONDON, July 1. -- The paramount thought among the crowds which thronged the inclosures at the review of troops at Aldershot Monday, judging from the frequent references to the subject, was one of admiration for the wonderful powers of endurance displayed by Queen Victoria, enabling her to bear the fatigue such an afternoon necessarily inflicts on anybody of such an advanced age.

CAPE MAY, N.J., July 1. -- The first week of the active social Summer season has been a very interesting one, taken in every way. The visiting journalists who were here from Friday until this week left on Monday, and on that evening special trains arrived bearing members and guests who have been attending the thirty-first annual Convention of the American Society of Civil Engineers.

WASHINGTON, July 1. -- Contrary to the expectations of the Treasury officials, the Government expenditures during the fiscal year closed yesterday exceeded the receipts by only $88,875,989. One month ago the officials predicted that the deficit might not exceed $100,000,000, but at no time up to a few days ago was it expected the amount would be less than $95,000,000.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 1. -- The Nippon Maru was towed from the mail dock into the stream to-day, this action being decided upon by the Board of Health. The physicians considered the vessel highly dangerous, in view of the statement of Dr. Barbat, the bacteriologist, that germs from two Japanese sailors of the Nippon Maru were those of the bubonic plague.
BAYONNE, N.J., July 1. -- Failure on the part of many yachtsmen to participate, compelled the Regatta Committee to postpone the Knickerbocker Athletic Club yacht races this afternoon.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., July 1. -- Dr. Stark, a physician of Wilkesbarre, Penn., was robbed while seated on the porch of the Hotel Biscayne, on South Carolina Avenue, last night at a late hour. Dr. Stark made the acquaintance of two men, who claimed to be New Yorkers, and when they made inquiries for a stopping place he directed them to the hotel in question.

LONDON, July 1. -- The Dominion Bay banquet was held this evening, Lord Strathcona and Mount Royal, Canadian High Commissioner, presiding. The guests included all the Agents General for the Colonies, the Earl of Aberdeen, the Marquis of Lorne, Lieut. Gen. John Wimburn Laurie, and a number of Canadian residents of London.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., July 1. -- Mrs. O'Sullivan, the wife of Sylvester J. O'Sullivan, manager of the United States Fidelity and Guaranty Company of Maryland, was fatally burned here at noon to-day in the store of Crosby Hill, on Front Street. She died six hours after receiving her injuries in the Muhlenberg Hospital.

The membership of the League of American Wheelmen has increased nearly 1,500 during the past week. The total membership now numbers 58,717, against 57,223 last week. The New York Division took in 312 new members.

THE regatta of the New York Yacht Club, which took place last week, was one of decided interest, yet it lacked some of the intensely absorbing features of the regattas of past years. Perhaps this is the thought of one who has seen too many regattas to enter fully into the spirit of the present.

HELENA, Mont., July 1. -- Every day adds to the strength of the case against the two Dillon suspects whom Under-Sheriff Moore recently captured in the belief that they were the robber brothers, belonging to the famous gang of highwaymen. At the time of their arrest letters were found upon them showing their names to be either Nolan or Putty.

RENNES, France, July 1. -- The landing of Dreyfus at Quiberon was almost unnoticed. At 9 o'clock yesterday evening the guard-ship Caudan put to sea to meet the Sfax, which had been sighted. The unusual bustle attracted many people to the harbor, but, as they saw nothing, the crowd dispersed.

VIENNA, June 13. -- The trial by the Landesgericht Vienna of the famous criminal Julius Raidl, of whose arrest I wrote last Summer, commenced to-day. It took the examining Judge almost a year to investigate the four hundred or more burglaries and thefts which the "King of the Burglars," as he proudly calls himself, committed within a period of ten months.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., July 1. -- At 8 o'clock this evening Acting Governor Walter Warder decided to send troops to Carterville. Five hundred or more union and non-union men are at war there. Both sides are determined to fight it out. A Sheriff and posse can do nothing with the situaton until the factions are disarmed.

ROANOKE, Va., July 1. -- Vice President and General Manager Barr of the Norfolk and Western Railroad, has tendered his resignation, to take effect July 15. Mr. Barr will accept a position with a Western road. L.E. Johnson General Superintendent or the Norfolk and Western, will succeed Mr. Barr as Vice President and General Manager.

The stretch of holiday -- from Friday to Wednesday -- which is allowed so many, has given the town a deserted look. Already -- but for the fireworks and crackers -- the absolute calm of midsummer has settled upon New York. Fifth Avenue is almost given up to the lovers of the wheel and very few faces appear at the club windows.

WASHINGTON, July 1. -- A reciprocity treaty with Jamaica was concluded at the State Department to-day at a conference between Commissioner Kasson, in behalf of the United States, and Mr. Tower, the British Charge d'Affaires. The Jamaican treaty is now to be forwarded to Kingston for the approval of the colonial authorities, and when this is given the formal signing of the instrument will occur.

R. GLENN'S handsome and interesting volume on "Some Colonial Mansions" is the latest addition to the list of works on the Colonial history of our country. For some years the steadily increasing interest in matters Colonial and Revolutionary, which has been so largely the result of the work of the various historic and patriotic societies, has assured to books on these fascinating subjects a sure if not very large sale.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 1. -- The Pennsylvania Railroad Company has been found guilty of withholding over $2,000,000 of the earnings which belong to the minority stockholders of the Louisville Bridge and with defrauding the bridge out of $300,000 worth of property.

John C. Sheehan, it was announced yesterday, will come to the city from Long Branch to-morrow and take steps to begin legal proceedings against the Police Commissioners to prevent them from appointing the election officers selected by the Goodwin faction of the Tammany Hall organization in the Ninth Assembly District.
LONDON, July 1. -- "Ted" Sloan won the Hurst Park Foal Plate, of 1,500 sovereigns, to-day, on Democrat. Vain Duchess was second and Oria third.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., July 1. -- Fourth of July being so near at hand, nearly every person at this resort is getting in readiness to celebrate the glorious old day. The hotel and boarding house keepers say they have received more applications for rooms for this Fourth than any season since the closing of Monmouth Park.

BAR HARBOR, July 1. -- The famous Kebo Valley Clubhouse, which has been the centre of the social life of Bar Harbor for years past, is a heap of ashes. Nothing remains to-night but a two-foot parapet of stone upon which the beautiful but flimsy wooden structure was built.

PITTSBURG, July 1. -- There now seems to be no doubt that there will be an extensive strike at the big Homestead plant of the Carnegie Steel Company. Whether or not the contest will rival that inaugurated July 1, 1892, remains to be seen.

"Keep the wrists and ankles cool in Summer and warm in Winter," say the doctors, "and you will be as comfortable as may be desired at both seasons of the year." Fashion is taking care of the ankles as far as possible in this respect this Summer, and everything in hosiery is openwork. Charming openwork stockings come in pretty shades of dark blue, and they are exceedingly attractive when worn with low tan shoes.

ATHENS, Ala., July 1. -- A thirteen-year-old boy, named Thomas, living on a farm several miles in the, interior, last night stabbed and killed his older sister, who had quarreled with him for not helping support the family. The boy then turned on his aged mother, who had come to her daughter's assistance, and slashed her so terribly that she died in a short time.

PITTSBURG, July 1. -- The new scale year of the Amalgamated Association of Iron and Steel Worers began to-day, with a better record for the union than has been made for more than half a dozen years.

PHILADELPHIA, July 1. -- The Lakewood (N.J.) polo team was badly beaten to-day on the grounds of the Philadelphia Country Club, at Bala, a suburb of this city, by the Devon team. Lakewood was conceded eight goals' handicap, and lost by a score of 19 1/4 goals to 10. The teams were made up as follows: Devon -- C.R. Snowden, G.W. Kendricks, Charles Wheeler, George McFadden.

The army reveled and rejoiced, and with liberty, for Louis himself was flushed with pride at the triumph of his arms, and in the universal excitement some excess was overlooked.
I read Mr. Gerald Gair's letter, which you print this morning, with great interest. He hits several nails on the head.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., July 2. -- The troops ordered by Acting Gov. Warder to proceed to Carterville -- Company C of Carbondale, Capt. Eugene Barton commanding, and Company F of Mount Vernon, Capt. Neil Pavey commanding, all of the Fourth Infantry, and all under command of Col. Lewis E. Bennett, Fourth Infantry, Illinois National Guard, arrived at Carterville this afternoon.
