Bicycle races were held yesterday afternoon at the Vailsburg track, at Newark, N.J., under the auspices of the New Jersey Racing Association. Six events made up the card -- one an exhibition half mile by "Eddie" Bald. Bald rode the half mile in 0:55 with a flying start paced by Neville and Hadfield of Newark on a tandem.

HAVANA, July 2. -- La Lucha will publish to-morrow a statement regarding matters which its conductors say they have been investigating and carefully guarding for several weeks, owing to the reticence of those concerned, and the desire of the latter to avoid a premature disclosure leading to a possible failure of their plans. The paper will say:

OFF HONOLULU, ON BOARD TRANSPORT SHERMAN, May 29, 1899, (Latitude 23 degrees 4 minutes north, longitude 154 degrees 46 minutes west.) - Observations and impressions found in the Marine Transport Service, a new feature in our army, must be of interest, not only to those having personal alliances with our soldiers, but to those also whose kind influence and cooperation contribute so largely to their care -- the loyal and devout women of our country.

The genius of Southern womanhood doesn't run largely to speechifying and holding mass meetings. Most of us prefer to lecture in private and allow our gentlemen to speak for us on public questions. This may have led our sisters at the North to think but poorly of our intellectuality and to believe us incapable of thinking or judging beneath the surface.

The Treasury comes out at the end of the fiscal year about $24,000,000 better than the Secretary estimated that it would at the date of his annual report last December. The deficit, which he had calculated would reach $112,000,000, amounts to only about $88,000,000. Nearly one-half of the difference is made up from the returns of the tariff due to the increased imports for the last half of the fiscal year.

TOLEDO, Ohio, July 1. -- The promoters of the Ohio Centennial are at last getting down to business, and there is reason to believe much will be accomplished. There was a lengthy quibble over the form and legality of the first issue of bonds, but that has been settled, and Spitzer Co. purchased the bonds, giving an immediate fund, which was greatly needed.

" Gospel tents are no new things," remarked the old inhabitant who was waiting for the opening of the door newly cut in the board fence inclosing the vacant lot at the corner of Broadway and Fifty-sixth Street, above which fence a banner, bearing the legend : "Glad Tidings," was floating in the afternoon breeze.

AUSTIN, Texas, July 2. -- There is no improvement in the distressing situation in the extensive flooded districts of Central and Southern Texas. On the contrary, the inundation is growing worse. There have been continuous and heavy rainfalls during the past twenty-four hours, which have added to the already unprecedented volumes of water in the rivers and creeks of the richest agricultural region in the State. There seems to be no end to the rainfall.

As a "constant reader," I have followed the question which you mooted, that of a reasonable name for "electric-auto-mobile-horseless-carriages." I have read the suggestions with interest and with some surprise that they have not been more fruitful. Our fellow-citizens do not realize evidently the dire necessity which will soon confront them in the want of a name for these "E.-a.-h.-carriages," which will be expressive but not bulkier than the ordinary mouthful.

The Middle States championship lawn tennis tournament begins this afternoon on the courts of the Orange Lawn Tennis Club. This event ranks second in importance only to the Newport and Longwood meetings. Champion "Mack" Whitman won the new Middle States Challenge Cup last season, and he will defend his claim to the trophy.

WASHINGTON, July 2. -- In some of the orations that will be delivered on the Fourth of July, undoubtedly a good deal will be said voicing the disgust of the pension attorneys because the Pension Commissioner has got through the fiscal year, ended June 30, without spending all the money appropriated to be available in that year for pensions.

WASHINGTON, July 2. -- The Agricultural Department has pressed the moving picture machine into the service of science. The division of vegetable pathology now has a device of this sort in operation in one of its greenhouses, photographing the growth of a small oak tree. The machine works automatically, taking a picture each hour.

The Richmond Hill, L.I., golf team for the season will be composed of Charles W. O'Connor, Joseph A. McCord, Arthur Mann, W.H. Rachau, Arthur Hinds, Edgar W. Van Vleck, C.S. Van Rensselaer, and O.G. Smith. The team will play the Crescent Athletic Club golfers next Wednesday on the latter's links at Bay Ridge.

Mike O'Donald, an ex-convict, got into a fight last night over a game of cards on canalboat at the foot of East Sixty-seventh Street. John S. Murphy, twenty-six years old, of 203 East Sixty-fourth Street, says O'Donald tried to shoot him, that he got the revolver away from him, and with one blow gouged the ex-convict's left eye out.

Pingree to-night dispatched a letter to Secretary Alger in relation to the criticisms of the Secretary and the numerous comments recently published concerning the agreement made by the Governor to support Gen. Alger in his campaign for the United States Senatorship. The letter is as follows:

MANILA, July 2. -- Prof. J.G. Schurman of the United States Advisory Commission for the Philippines returned to Manila today from a three weeks' tour of the southern islands. He takes an entirely hopeful view of the general conditions there. The intelligent and substantial citizens desire an American protectorate. The masses are awaiting the settlement of the war in the Island of Luzon before declaring themselves. They are chiefly anxious to be undisturbed.

Does he sink his talons, his tentacles, his hooks, his beak, or his forked tail into the quivering flesh and then suck up the wretch's blood like a mosquito or a creeping cimex lectularius?
NEWPORT, July 2. -- Mrs. Stuyvesant Fish this evening gave a large dinner at Crossways, her first entertainment of the season.

How many commanders of army corps in the war of the rebellion are now living? This is a question that veteran officers of the great civil struggle have been asking each other with considerable interest and curiosity of late. None was able to answer it with anything like accuracy, however, until the other day, although all of them did much thinking and figuring.

LONDON, July 2. -- Mr. Robert Grant Webster, who had represented the Eastern Division of St. Pancras. London, in the Conservative interest in the House of Commons since 1886, has accepted the Chiltern Hundreds, thus resigning his seat.

LONDON. July 2. -- Our end of the half-year money scrimmage has been got through with comparative ease. Borrowings from the Bank of England have been about as usual -- ten millions -- but now money will be cheap for a month at least. The truth is that your exports of gold have saved the European markets from considerable danger, and if they continue we shall probably have moderate rates for money until Autumn.

LEXINGTON, Ky., July 2. -- Gov. Bradley arrived here to-day from Cincinnati, with the information that the call for 300 State troops last night was the result of forged messages to him, purporting to be from a gentleman in Lexington, in whom the Governor had confidence, and one from Frankfort, purporting to be from a State officer.

One of the most unfortunate excursions that ever left New York was that given by the Social Labor Union, an east side organization, on Saturday. It resulted in serious suffering to several thousand people, who were kept from their homes all Saturday night and much of yesterday, in the accidental death by shooting of Etta Reichbach of 153 Suffolk Street, as told in THE TIMES yesterday, and in distress and anxiety to hundreds of families.

PITTSBURG, Penn., July 2. -- As a result of a street car collision to-night on the road of the Monongahela Traction Company, two persons are dead, five seriously injured, and ten others more or less hurt.

CHICAGO, July 2. -- Promptly at 7:30 o'clock to-morrow morning Walter McKittrick of the St. Louis Country Club and Phelps B. Hoyt of the Glenview Golf and Polo Club will tee off in the first qualifying round of the fifth annual tournament of the United States Golf Association, which takes place on the Onwentsia Club's links at Lake Forest.

VALENCIA, Spain, July 2. -- Very serious disturbances are in progress here, arising over the general dissatisfaction because of the budget proposals. Under the orders of the Captain General of Valencia, Gen. Molto, the troops occupied the streets yesterday morning, and now hold all the strategic points.

The second annual Federal Festival of the Arbeiter Sangerbunde, or Workingpeople's Singing Societies, of the Northeastern States was begun last night with a Commers in the Grand Central Palace. Over 4,000 persons, it was estimated, were in attendance, the visiting societies from other cities coming out in force.

SUMMIT, N.J., July 2. -- The most destructive fire in the history of this place started at 3 o'clock this morning, and resulted in a loss of $150,000. It is suspected that it was of incendiary origin, as the block in which it occurred has been on fire five times in the last year. Twenty families were rendered homeless, and the business of the place is seriously interrupted.

PARIS, July 2. -- As the outcome of the Government's prudence, all France remains tranquil. Maitres Demange and Labori, with M. Math'eu Dreyfus and his wife, arrived this evening at Rennes. The town is quite tranquil.

Persons in Upper Lexington Avenue were startled yesterday morning when they saw a half-clad man rushing along toward the Harlem River and shouting at the top of his voice "Help! Help! Murder! Police!" Policeman Kearney pursued the fellow and chased him to the river's edge, where the chase ended abruptly by the man diving overboard.

It was "Sailors' Day" in the Scotch Presbyterian Church, Central Park West and Ninety-sixth Street, yesterday morning. The trials and triumphs of Uncle Sam's Jack Tars were stirringly set forth in addresses by Chaplain R.H. Steele and Lieut. Commander Albion V. Wadhams, United States Navy.

The meeting at the West Side Branch of the Young Men's Christian Association yesterday, the last for the Summer, was devoted to addresses by naval officers and a collection for the Naval Young Men's Christian Association's work at the Brooklyn Navy Yard. Rear Admiral Philip, Commander Albion W. Wadhams, United States Navy; Capt. Merrill Miller, and Chaplain R.E. Steele were on the platform.

Friends of the Readings are in no wise disconcerted by the recent sluggishness of their stocks. They say that, quite apart from any consideration of the pending coal deal, the company is doing all that they call wish. The May statement showed an improvement of about $100,000 over the previous year, of which two-thirds was in the operations of the coal and iron company.

This is my first letter to a newspaper, but I cannot refrain from backing up "Mrs. J.M.G." In her reply to Mr. Smyth's letter. I spent a year with my wife in France, traveling on a tandem, and returned a firm believer in divided skirts, or even bloomers, for women's wear on a wheel.

Jack of the United States ship Brooklyn came ashore yesterday and commemorated the anniversary of the famous battle of Santiago by dancing all day under the same flag he fought under just a year before. He called it "Schley Day," and made it Schley Day.
WASHINGTON, July 3. -- There is continued improvement in Mrs. McKinley's condition, and to-day she sat up for a portion of the time.

One man lost his life and several persons narrowly escaped death at an early morning fire yesterday in Mrs. Annie Brennan's furnished room house, 33 Market Street. The victim is Owen Stroker, a longshoreman.

NEWPORT, July 3. -- To-day was the first anniversary of the battle of Santiago -- the battle in which Cervera's splendid squadron was destroyed by the American warships outside Santiago. The day here was marked by a general celebration, in which the ships of the North Atlantic Squadron, under Admiral Sampson, the attaches of the naval stations, the cottagers and townspeople, and the yachts and shipping in the harbor all took part.

Paul Cattana, a music teacher, twenty years old, was run over and almost instantly killed by a cross-town car on Thirty-fourth Street, near Second Avenue, yesterday afternoon. Cattana, who had just alighted from a north-bound trolley car on Second Avenue, ran toward an approaching Thirty-fourth Street car going east, and which was coming down the hill at a good rate of speed.

Speculators on the bear side, planning for depression and contributing what they can to excite Wall Street nervousness, suffer disappointment to-day. They have counted upon widespread labor troubles crystallizing into strikes (with possibility of worse) on the National holiday. Some basis there seemed for the prospect, too, for it is even suspected that agitators have had from Wall Street bears more than words of sympathy.

Society celebrates the glorious Fourth with more than its usual enthusiasm this year. It has, with the exception of Dewey and his officers, all the heroes of the late war to be lions on the Nation's birthday. Two of the observances planned will therefore be of much interest. One is, of course, the celebration at Oyster Bay at which Gov. Roosevelt is expected to be present and speak.

POUGHKEEPSIE, July 3. -- The recent announcement by the New York Central Railroad of special excursion rates to New York on Sundays has inspired the Poughkeepsie Ministers' Association to frame a petition to the President of the company, begging him to desist from the practice of inducing people to go to New York on that day.
LONDON, July 4. -- The Daily News this morning publishes an article, with illustrative designs, comparing the yachts Columbia and Shamrock.

CHICAGO, July 3. -- Geologists assert that the natural gas supply of Indiana will be practically exhausted in four or five years. What this would mean to the prosperity of the gas belt may be seen from figures showing the importance of only one among the numerous industries in Indiana dependent on natural gas for power.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., July 3. -- There was a bad wreck on the Raritan River Railroad this evening. Forty persons rolled down a twenty-foot embankment in a car. No one was killed, and only one person was seriously injured. The railroad runs from Perth Amboy to this place.
James Oliver, "the silver-tongued orator of Paradise Park," left this city yesterday morning for Sunrise City, in the Klondike region, where he controls six claims and a water gate.

CHICAGO, July 3. -- Four persons are believed to be dead beneath the tottering walls of the Western Paper Stock Company's plant, on Indiana Avenue, which was burned to-day. The missing are Bartholomew Sparkiewietz, foreman, fifty years old; Julius Ostowsky, fifty years old; Mrs. Josie Doyle, twenty-one years old, and Steffina Bigdies.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 3. -- The Kentucky National Bank to-day filed in the United States Clerk's office, at Indianapolis, a suit against the Louisville, New Albany and Chicago Railway Company and its successor, the Chicago, Indianapolis and Louisville Railway Company and others, asking for a receiver.
The Munich Reinsurance Company of Germany has been admitted to Pennsylvania.

WASHINGTON, July 3. -- The Adjutant General's office to-day gave out a statement based on cable advices from Gen. Otis regarding the number of recruits required to fill the vacancies in the regular regiments new in the Philippines, the transports available for the return of volunteers and for the transportation of fresh troops to the Philippines and the estimated time it will take to complete the work of enlistment.

PHILADELPHIA, July 3. -- In honor of Rear Admiral Schley, who with Mrs. Schley is the guest of Col. A.K. McClure, editor of The Philadelphia Times, at his home at Wallingford, about twelve miles from this city, a reception was given to-night by the citizens of the vicinity. Fully 2,000 persons assembled on the spacious lawn and porches.

Vacancies created in the Plant Investment Company of New Haven, Conn., and the Plant system of railways by the death of Henry B. Plant were filed yesterday at meetings of Directors at the local offices of the companies. Robert G. Erwin of Savannah, Ga., was elected President of the Plant Investment Company, and M.F. Plant, only son of the late Henry B. Plant, Vice President.

AUSTIN, Texas, July 3. -- In some localities of the flooded districts of Texas the situation is improving. The rains during the past twenty-four hours have not been so generally continuous, but a terrific rainfall is reported to have occurred between Hearne and Hempstead. The Brazos River is falling in its upper course, but is still slowly rising and inundating additional territory near the Gulf.

NEWPORT, July 3. -- The thirty-footers here had an interesting race this afternoon over the Dyers Island course. The wind was southwest, and the start was at 3:15 o'clock. The summary and times: Dorothy, 5:38:35; Veda, 5:39:05; Wa Wa, 5:40:43; Asahi, 5:44:50.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, July 3. -- Kingston and Port Antonio are preparing for an informal but enthusiastic observance of the Fourth, as a compliment to Florida's generous exhibition of Anglo-American sentiment on the Queen's Birthday.

The unanimity of their return is explained by the opening of the schools, public and private, which occurs in September.

BROOKE to establish military government throughout the island must therefore be viewed with some suspicion. It is rather more likely to have proceeded from dislike for the Cubans than from sympathetic interest in the Americans.

The first of the series of trial races to select a challenger for the Seawanhaka International Challenge Cup for small yachts was held yesterday on the Sound off Centre Island, under the auspices of the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club. Three new boats of the twenty-foot class, built for the purpose, were the contestants.

According to the usually well-informed correspondent of The Evening Post at Washington, there is to be a very vigorous movement in Congress next Winter for the establishment of a "parcel post." We have, to be sure, a certain kind of parcel post now, by which "merchandise" can be sent over considerable distances by mail at less cost than by express.

From many points in New Jersey come stories of outrage in the official management of the schools. In Camden, Mr. Manness has been dropped without a hearing and without cause being assigned. This is alleged to be purely a matter of private revenge. The case of Miss Greenfield of Kearny is asserted to be political revenge on the lady's father.
A report gained credence among the politicians yesterday that Mayor VAN WYCK has decided to withhold his signature from the civil service rules to which the State Commission asks his approval.

Capt. Thomas of the West Forty-seventh Street Police Station appeared at Police Headquarters yesterday and preferred charges against Doorman Edgar Sharp, who was on duty Sunday morning at the station when the Tocci twins, charged with murder, made their escape. Inspector Thompson also made charges against the doorman for making a false report.

WASHINGTON, July 3. -- President McKinley and Gen. Harrison Gray Otis, who arrived here yesterday from the West, had an extended conference to-day on affairs relating particularly to the campaign in the Philippines. They are long-time personal friends and the opportunity of discussing questions of importance in which they are mutually and deeply interested was enjoyed by both.

WASHINGTON, July 3. -- Ambrose C. Dunn, Vice President of the Chesapeake Bay Construction Company, which has a railroad under construction from this city to Chesapeake Beach, filed a petition in the Supreme Court of the District to-day asking that a temporary receiver be appointed to take charge of the property pending a dissolution of partnership and an accounting.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., July 3. -- The "kissing bug" has descended upon Atlantic City and touched the lips of Mrs. Helen Veasy, a cottager at 213 Chalfront Avenue, and John McCaffrey, a fourteen-year-old Western Union messenger boy. Mrs. Veasy was sitting last night on the porch of the cottage when a large insect came sailing up to her in the semi-darkness and lighted for an instant on her lips.
BUFFALO, July 3. -- The National Social and Political Conference held a stormy session to-day, the matter under discussion being an address to the public, which was finally adopted.

LAKE FOREST, Ill., July 3. -- The fifth annual tournament of the United States Golf Association was begun to-day over the 18-hole course of the Onwentsia Golf Club, thirty miles north of Chicago. Nearly every golfer of prominence in the country was present when Secretary William Bage Kerr of the association called the first pair for the qualifying round at 7:30 o'clock this morning.

The Municipal Assembly yesterday received from the Department of Taxes and Assessments the assessment books for 1899. There are 224 volumes, including the assessments on real estate and personal property of individuals and resident and non-resident corporations. These books will, according to Section 909 of the charter, remain in the custody of the Municipal Assembly until the last week in August, during which time they will be open to inspection by the public.

Brown, sixteen years of age, was walking along Nassau Street, near John, when Lohse came along with a bundle.

Willett, President of the Bar Association of Alabama, will make the "long talk," and among the "short talkers" will be J. D. Richardson of Tennessee and Senator Thomas F. Grady, Patriotic exercises will he held in the Auditorium at Ocean Grove, and an address will be made by a prominent navy official.

There arrived in this city yesterday copies of The New Era of June 24 last, a Catholic journal of London, which contains an interview on "Americanism" that paper's editor had with Archbishop Ireland in Paris. The Archbishop is now in London, and it is expected he will sail for this country in a week or so.

The opening matches in the Middle States championship lawn tennis tournament attracted many spectators to the grounds of the Orange Lawn Tennis Club, at Orange, N.J., yesterday. The club has secured the largest entry list in its history, and the best in quality. Only the singles were started yesterday, but the big field of forty-four players was narrowed down rapidly.

Dowe, President of the National League of Commercial Travelers, is credited with stating at their annual convention at Albany yesterday that there had been 35,000 commercial travelers thrown out of employment by the organization of trusts and some 25,000 more had suffered a reduction of salary.

Otherwise the Socialists threaten extremes, even revolution.

BUFFALO, N Y., July 3. -- Another pugilistic champion has gone under, and again a younger man supplants an older one. Frank Erne of this city met George Lavigne of Saginaw, Mich., in the open arena of the Hawthorne Athletic Club, at Cheektowaga, a suburb of this city, to-night, and after fighting twenty fierce and clever rounds wrested the lightweight championship of the world from the Western man.

Real estate men generally regarded yesterday as a holiday. Many of the larger firms did not open their offices at all. There was only one sale in the auction room, and the reports of business at private contract were wholly without interest or importance.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., July 4. -- Louis Ginzburg, a Jewish rabbi and proprietor of a meat market at 153 Susquehanna Street, was stabbed and probably fatally injured this morning by one of two negroes who entered his shop and attempted to steal some meat.

Perhaps the clearest account of the troubles in the Transvaal that has appeared, in a more moderate compass than that of a volume, is that which Mr. SIDNEY BROOKS has contributed to the current number of The North American Review. But it is more than a description, or even than a diagnosis, for it proposes a remedy.

RED BANK, N.J., July 4. -- The Red Bank Yacht Club held a regatta to-day, a fifteen-mile course being sailed in a fresh southwest wind, which grew steadily from start to finish. The start was made from the clubhouse in front of J.C.G. Hupfel's Summer cottage, and the course was laid to Oceanic and return.
SARATOGA, July 4. -- Miss Dorothy L.F. Wheeler, who was injured in the Windsor Hotel fire in New York City, died here to-day. She was the daughter of Mrs. G.P. Wheeler.

The New York Aquarium was enriched yesterday by about 100 specimens of more or less rare tropical fish from Bermuda, which were brought here on the steamship Orinoco. The specimens were in charge of Prof. Charles L. Bristol of the Biological Department of the New York University, who went to Bermuda last May on purpose to secure anything odd in the fish line.

Local cricketers celebrated the Fourth by an extra indulgence in their favorite pastime, and all-day games were the rule on most of the grounds in the vicinity of the city.

HENLEY, England, July 4. -- The River Thames presented an animated scene this afternoon at the opening of the Henley races. There are fifty-three entries, as against fifty-four in 1898, of whom three crossed the seas.

Tammany Hall, or rather that part of it which attended the annual celebration of the Tammany Society in the Wigwam yesterday, broke away from its leaders and yelled itself hoarse for Bryan, free silver, and anti-imperialism, and ignored the boom for Augustus Van Wyck for the Presidency, which was slated as the principal feature of the occasion.

Policeman Aime Jelis of the West Thirtieth Street Station distinguished himself last night by saving two persons from a burning building. Twice he risked his life, and would have gone into the building a third time if not restrained by the firemen and his brother policemen.

NEWPORT, July 4. -- The Fourth of July was celebrated by almost all the cottagers, and never in the history of the place have there been so many social events in twenty-four hours as was the case to-day.

HELENA, Mon., July 4. -- The cornerstone of the new State Capitol was laid this afternoon. Never before has such a large crowd assembled in this city, special trains having brought thousands of visitors to Helena. The city, in both residence and business sections, was gayly decorated, and all business was suspended.

Mr. and Mrs. H. McK. Twombly entertained the residents of Florham Park Borough, N.J., yesterday. Florham Farms is the name of the Twombly country home, which is near Madison. The entertainment was in the fashion that is popular with England's wealthy land owners.

MANILA, July 4. -- There was a great celebration of the Fourth here to-day with fireworks, bands, speeches, and decorations everywhere, all nationalities participating. The foreign ships and Consulates, including the Spanish, raised their colors in conjunction with the Stars and Stripes. The flagship Baltimore fired a National salute at noon.

MELROSE, Mass., July 4. -- Capt. N.M. Dyer, who, with the Baltimore, led the second attack of Dewey's squadron upon Montojo's fleet at Manila, reached his home in Melrose this afternoon. He was met at the station by a large crowd, a brass band, and the fire company. Capt. Dyer was detached from the Baltimore three months ago on account of ill-health.

The bicycle race meet at the Manhattan Beach track yesterday afternoon attracted an attendance of 4,000 people, the principal event being a race between Harry Elkes of Glens Falls, the middle-distance champion of America, and Arthur Gardiner of Chicago. The distance was twenty-five miles and the purse $1,000. The contestants were paced by motor cycles.

PARIS, July 4. -- There was a grand reception this afternoon at the United States Embassy, which was beautifully decorated with flowers, tropical plants, and flags. Nearly the whole American colony attended.

F.W. Menzies and Miss Guthrie were the victors yesterday in the closing rounds of the members' tournament at the Seabright, N.J. Golf Club for the two cups given by William F. Havemeyer. Menzies met J.W. Ryle in the final round, and won by 6 up and 4 to play, the cards being:

BRUSSELS, July 4. -- The members of the Right in the Chamber have unanimously agreed to the Government proposal referring the Electoral bills to a committee of all parties. The Left has also assented, with a resolution limiting the time of the committee's deliberations. It is believed this will solve the trouble for the present.

WASHINGTON, July 4. -- It is said at the War Department that the return of the volunteer organizations from the Philippines will have no effect on the rank of the volunteer general officers now on duty there. The number of general officers depends, not on the particular organizations in the service but on the total number of men.

DUBUQUE, Iowa, July 4. -- Judge Shiras of the Federal Court has decided the famous O'Brien County (Iowa) land case by ruling that the title in the disputed land is vested in the innocent purchasers. A land grant was given to the Sioux City and Pacific Railway, conditioned on the construction of the road into Minnesota. Building was stopped at Lemars, Iowa.

Two victories were scored by the Washingtons over the New Yorks at the Polo Grounds yesterday. For a team that is next to last in the pennant race the Senatorial aggregation played a mighty fast game -- indeed, one good enough to defeat the best clubs in the league. The New Yorks played well, but were not quite swift enough for the Washingtons.

DETROIT, Mich., July 4. -- Injunction proceedings have been begun in both the United States and county courts on behalf of several railroads to prevent ticket scalping during the Christian Endeavor convention.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., July 4. -- A bunch of firecrackers to-day set fire to the Pittsburg Hotel, on Mississippi Avenue. The guests in the dining room were alarmed when Fireman Harry Barnes of the Atlantic Fire Company rushed in crying fire. Tables were instantly deserted, some of the guests hurrying upstairs after valuables, while others went to the front of the building.

The strictness with which the quarantine regulations are being observed here during the season in which yellow fever is rampant in Cuba was illustrated yesterday when Rear Admiral B.J. Cromwell, U.S.N., late Commandant of the Port of Havana, who arrived from that city on the steamship Havana, was removed from the vessel at Quarantine and taken to Hoffman Island for observation.

Another race in these waters has been arranged for Columbia and Defender. It will be sailed on the Sound on Saturday as a special race, under the auspices of the Larchmont Club, which has offered a prize. The start will be at 11:30 o'clock A.M., over a course still to be laid out, but which will be marked off with special reference to the great draught of the two yachts.

Independence Day was yesterday duly observed in this city. So far as recognition of the anniversary by powder-burning and detonation is concerned there was enough noise and smoke to satisfy the most ardent and demonstrative patriot.

ELIZABETH, N.J., July 4. -- The twenty-five mile bicycle road race between Elizabeth and Rahway was the principal feature of the day's sports. The course was between the Oakwood House, on the Rahway road, and Rahway. Three laps to Rahway and two to Elizabeth constituted the twenty-five miles.

W.L. Hicks, in the golf tournament of the Nassau Country Club at Glen Cove, L.I., yesterday won the chief trophy presented by H.W. Maxwell. The Consolation Cup was won by J.W. Johnson, who beat H.S. Beard at the nineteenth hole, after a tie game. Beard in the semi-final round defeated Miss Ruth Underhill, who was the only woman competitor in the match.

The first of the series of polo games in the two weeks' tournament on the grounds of the Rockaway Hunt Club of Cedarhurst, L.I., was played yesterday by the Lakewood Club and the second team of the Rockaway Hunt Club. The Lakewood team won. The line-up was as follows:

The people in and around Oyster Bay, Gov. Roosevelt's home, celebrated the Fourth by uniting in the organization of a boom for Roosevelt for President, in which the Governor did not assist, and with a happy demonstration, celebration, and proclamation of religious toleration, in which the Governor was a zealous and enthusiastic participant.

LONDON, July 4. -- More than 400 guests attended the banquet of the American Society in London at the Hotel Cecil this evening, and a brilliant galaxy of ladies viewed the function from the gallery of the banqueting room. As a display of patriotism and Anglo-Saxon goodfellowship, the affair was not excelled even by the famous banquet given last year.
SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., July 4. -- The steamship Coptic arrived late last night from Hongkong and Yokohama, via Honolulu.

The Fourth of July being the anniversary of the putting forth by our Revolutionary fathers of the Declaration of Independence, absolving themselves "from all allegiance to the British Crown," the political disciples of the school of Jefferson might make it a most fitting occasion to declare their independence in their own political party.

LAKE FOREST, Ill., July 4. -- To-day's play in the amateur golf tournament was remarkable for good work under adverse circumstances. The Onwentsia grounds were in poor condition from the soaking rains of yesterday and last night, the greens being soggy and dead, and the conditions were rendered still worse by showers.

Of the ninety-seven owners that secured some part of the money given away by the Coney Island Jockey Club during its thirteen days' meeting just ended, John E. Madden was the most fortunate, his share being $22,850. This was due principally to David Garrick's victory in the Great Trial Stakes, aided by the Prince of Melbourne's victory in the first part of the Double Event.

In the preliminary rounds of the Flushing Golf Club championship contest yesterday, Herbert R. Peck, who won the medal in the qualifying rounds, was defeated by Alex. McNell by 3 up and 2 to play. R.H. Elliot defeated W.C. Fergueson by 7 up and 6 to play. Craig Colgate defeated L.M. Richmond by 3 up and 2 to play.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., July 4. -- There was the largest attendance on the Assembly grounds at Chautauqua to-day ever known on the Fourth. The grounds were beautifully decorated with American colors, the amphitheatre being ablaze with flags. Bishop Vincent presided at the celebration, and Justice John Woodward of the New York Supreme Court was the orator of the day.

The twentieth annual regatta of the Larchmont Yacht Club, sailed yesterday, was a great success for Larchmont and a brilliant Fourth of July celebration. For even a Larchmont Fourth of July regatta, it was almost unprecedented. Some one said that the Regatta Committee and the weather committee had evidently vied to outdo one another and both had succeeded.

THOUSAND ISLANDS, Clayton, N.Y., July 4. -- The State Commissioners of Fisheries, Game, and Forest were at the islands a few days ago to examine the dozen or so little islands and points of the mainland that have been purchased and set aside as a reservation. They found the docks completed, and gave orders for the erection of pavilions, one on each reservation, to be one story high and 30 by 40 feet ground measurement.

PHILADELPHIA, July 4. -- The Philadelphias returned home to-day from their successful trip and signalized their home-coming by defeating the Brooklyns in two games. The first game was witnessed by the largest crowd ever assembled at a morning game on the local grounds. Dahlen was put out of the first game by Umpire Smith for too vigorously disputing one of his decisions.

Gov. HOGG of Texas, in Tammany Hall yesterday, was as gay and exciting in his gambols as the most frisky fugitive from the cattle yards, and the managers were no more successful in dealing with him than the average policeman in lassoing the bovine Texan.

Ready for business -- this finally seems to be the Wall Street situation. Important men have had their vacations; important interests have prepared for activity. Indications of this show in many ways in many places. Mr. Morgan has had his European rest, and so has Mr. Vanderbilt.

BARNESVILLE, Ga., July 4. -- William J. Bryan addressed the Barnesville Chautauqua to-day. There was a large assemblage, which received Mr. Bryan with enthusiasm. He was introduced by Clark Howell, editor of The Atlanta Constitution, member of the National Democratic Committee.

LEADVILLE, Col., July 4. -- The second section of the Denver and Rio Grande Passenger Train No. 2, from the west, was wrecked by a broken rail eight miles west of this city. Ten persons were injured, but none of them seriously. The train was running over the Colorado Midland tracks on account of a wash-out on the Denver and Rio Grande Road.
LONDON, July 4. -- The House of Lords to-day passed the third reading of the London Government bill.

BOSTON, July 4. -- The city's formal exercises to-day were held at Tremont Temple at 10 A.M. Nathan Matthews. Jr., ex-Mayor of Boston, delivered the annual Fourth of July oration, taking for his subject "Expansion." He said in part:
GREENWICH, Conn., July 4. -- Two games of great interest took place at the Fairfield Golf links to-day.
" We must beat those Englishmen; that is all there is to it!" exclaimed Harvard's champion broad-jumper, C.D. Daly, last night in the Fifth Avenue Hotel.

Coney Island celebrated the anniversary of the Nation's independence yesterday in characteristic style. From one end of Surf Avenue to the other, from the eastern extremity of the Bowery to Tilyou's Walk, fakirs, shod-men, dancers, cafe keepers, beggars, the vendors of the time-honored frankfurter, and exemplars of photographic art were out in force to help thousands upon thousands of sightseers remember the "glorious Fourth."

HAVANA, July 4. -- By noon to-day every Chinaman in Havana was aware that money could be made by selling firecrackers. Consequently little work was done in the laundries before sunset. The Prado and other streets of Havana were as noisy, doubtless, as any quarter of New York, Chicago, or San Francisco.

BAYONNE, N.J., July 4. -- With a total percentage of 6.203 in ten events, J. Fred Powers of St. Paul's Lyceum Athletic Association of Worcester, Mass., won the individual championship of the metropolitan district, Amateur Athletic Union, this afternoon at the Knickerbocker Athletic Club games, held on the Bayonne Field.

The peace conference which the Russian Czar has brought about will be either a flat fizzle or a solemn farce performed for the benefit of Russia. It is possible that the Czar is sincere in wishing for universal and permanent peace in the world, but though he is the autocratic ruler of the Russian Empire he will not be able to prevent Russia from carrying out whatever policy best makes for her material aggrandizement.

PHILADELPHIA, July 4. -- The People's Regatta on the Schuylkill River to-day resulted in a splendid exhibition of rowing, and the local crews carried off the lion's share of the honors. The course was not smooth, but under the circumstances some excellent time was made. The most exciting event of the day was the senior eight-oared shell race between the Pennsylvania Barge Club and the Vesper Boat Club, both of this city.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., July 4. -- Fire broke out in the establishment of the Memphis Paper Company, at the corner of Gayoso and Front Streets, late this afternoon, and caused the loss of one life, probably fatal injuries to ex-Fire Chief Cleary and serious injuries to Assistant Fire Chief James Ryan, besides a property loss of about $450,000.

The only sale of suburban real estate held yesterday was that conducted by the Jere. Johnson, Jr., Company. The property consisted of 303 lots belonging to J.V.S. Woolley, situated on Gravesend Avenue, Avenue M. and intersecting streets, just south of Washington Cemetery, in the Thirty-first Ward of Brooklyn.

The last of the yearling sales until Autumn took place yesterday at Sheepshead Bay, in the Easton Paddocks. Although there was a big crowd present to bid in the Fairview Stud stock, most of the animals went far below their value. The biggest disappointment came on the bidding of the handsome chestnut colt by Phoenix, out of Thora, a half-brother to Dobbins, Yorkville Belle, and Sir Francis.

Save for a breeze which blew across the track, and which made all chances of record making out of the question, yesterday was a perfect day for racing. It was warm enough to make the horses sweat out well, and not too warm for the crowds that filled the pretty racing park of the Coney Island Jockey Club to thoroughly enjoy themselves.

Two golf games, a brass band, and the reports of fireworks explosions in Morristown, N.J., were festivities enjoyed by the Morris County Golf Club members yesterday. Ever since the club was organized special efforts have been put forth to make July 4 particularly notable on the links.

CONCORD, N.H., July 5. -- Charles A. Busiel has invited Carl Schurz, President, and George McAneny, Secretary of the National Civil Service Reform League, to be present at the investigation of charges against Senator Gallinger, to be held here next Tuesday. The invitation is understood to have been sent them because of the spirited newspaper controversy between Mr. Schurz and Mr. Gallinger about two years ago about civil service and party loyalty.

Justice Stover, in the Supreme Court, has appointed Assemblyman Edward H. Fallows and Henry Puster receivers for the property in this State of the Metropolitan Building Company of 111 Fifth Avenue. Application was made by William H. Hamilton of Booraem, Hamilton Beckett, counsel for Henry Lembeck, a stockholder.

THE HAGUE, July 5. -- The American delegates scored a great success to-day in obtaining from the Peace Conference a unanimous vote in favor of having the question of private property at sea in time of war dealt with at a special conference, to be summoned hereafter.

RYE, N.Y., July 5. -- Mrs. M.W. Simmons and her grandson, Arthur L. Bartlett, Jr., were drowned in the Sound at Oakland Beach this morning. No one saw them drown, and no one knows what occurred. They were drowned in water which was not much, if any, over the boy's head.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., July 5. -- Alice Gray of Philadelphia, a young woman who was traveling alone, gave birth to a child this evening in the West Jersey Railroad Station here. Dr. Chew and two officers took the mother and child to the hospital. The woman is evidently well-to-do. She has considerable money and a well-filled traveling case. Both mother and child are doing well.

DETROIT, July 5. -- The first day of the preliminary of the eighteenth annual international convention of the Christian Endeavor Society opened with showers, and it was late in the day before the thousands here to attend the meetings found their way to the grounds. Before the first session opened fully 10,000 persons were within the tent, and hundreds gathered without to see and hear when the tent walls were dropped.

The friendly and competent criticism of The London Spectator upon our proceedings in the Philippines, upon which we made some remarks yesterday, raise several interesting questions. When we acknowledge the necessity of a colonial service equal or comparable to the Indian civil service, it becomes quite plain that we have no such service, and that with the best will and the most intelligent means, it will be a long time before we can get it.

LONDON, July 5. -- Sir Alexander Armstrong, K.C.B., formerly Director General of the Medical Department of the British Navy, is dead. He served five continuous years in the arctic regions, searching for Sir John Franklin and discovering the Northwest Passage.

Col. Dudley S. Phelps, Chief of the Law Division of the Custom House, received yesterday the official appraisement of such of the jewels as were selected as dutiable from those brought into this port on the St. Paul on June 24 by Mrs. Phyllis E. Dodge. The appraisement gives the foreign value of the detained jewels as $41,500 and the duty, 60 per cent. ad valorem, at $24,900, or a home value of $66,400.

A petition in involuntary bankruptcy was filed yesterday against Howard Lockwood Co., (incorporated,) printers and publishers, at 520 West Broadway. The petitioning creditors were Ewell Jamison, Eldon D. Kelts, and Hulbert Payne. On June 7, 1899, Lionel Alers-Hankey, the Treasurer of the concern, was appointed temporary receiver for it.

HAVERSTRAW, July 5. -- Roseville, the scene of the Sliney robbery two years ago, when three saloon keepers were held up and robbed at the revolver's point, and one of them together with a boarder shot, was today the scene of a fracas in which one man was shot to death, another fatally injured, and two others less seriously hurt.

RENNES, France, July 5. -- With Capt. Dreyfus the day has passed off very much yesterday, Mme. Dreyfus, Matthew Dreyfus, brother of the prisoner, and Maitre Labori, his counsel, visited him, but otherwise no special incident occurred. As an illustration of the indifference of the population, it ,is worthy of note that the words "Vive Dreyfus," chalked upon a wall in a corner of tile town, remain absolutely undisturbed.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., July 5. -- W.R. Laidlaw, who was injured by an exploding bomb in Russell Sage's office in 1891, and who has four times prosecuted his suit for damages, the verdict being in each case set aside by a higher court, said to-day that he will try to recovery for the fifth time this Fall. Mr. Laidlaw is now living in this city.

WASHINGTON, July 5. -- The news from The Hague announcing the unanimous vote of the Peace Conference in favor of holding a special conference hereafter to discuss the question of the freedom from seizure of private property at sea in time of war is a source of genuine satisfaction to the Administration.

The prospect for American art at the Paris Exposition is not a hopeful one. There is a possibility -- indeed it is more than likely -- that a number of fine works may be shown in the space reserved for paintings and sculpture by citizens of the United States, but anything like a representative display seems impossible.
Increase of $4,018 in Southern Pacific's net earnings for May, but decrease of $754,429 since July 1, 1898.

MALONE, N.Y., July 5. -- Since the acquisition by the Rockefellers of two immense tracts of land in the Adirondacks, there is much speculation as to how far their purchases may be extended. Their present Adirondack holdings are well timbered, and several lakes and rivers add to their value. Both tracts have been put into a private preserve.

The speech of State Senator Grady at the Tammany Hall Fourth of July celebration, in which he paid his respects to the methods by which the Civil Service Commission of the State conducts its examinations for clerkships and junior clerkships, has created some interest and much amusement among the civil service reformers.

WASHINGTON, July 5. -- The order directing the enlistment of ten new regiments of volunteer infantry was completed this afternoon, and will be issued to-morrow. The order was drafted after a conference this afternoon between the President and Adjt. Gen. Corbin, and directs the recruiting officers to enlist men under the law passed March 2, 1899.

ALBANY, N.Y., July 5. -- State Superintendent of Insurance Payn is in receipt of advices to the effect that the Merchants' Life Association of the United States, located at St. Louis, Mo., having authority to transact business in New York as an assessment life insurance corporation, has reinsured its business in the Franklin Life Insurance Company of Springfield, Ill., which is a company without authorization in this State.

The delay in replying to the letter of the Rapid Transit Commissioners to the Mayor, Mr. Whalen explained, was due to the unsettled condition of the city's financial condition.

If society will not be exactly in town today, it will be very near it. WASHINGTON, July 5. -- A final decision was reached to-day by the Naval Board of Bureau Chiefs to put a two-inch nickel steel protective deck on the six small cruisers about to be built. Admiral Hichborne, chief constructor, reported that the deck would not cost above $16,000 for each ship, and that no important alterations in the plans would be required. The main change will be in widening the ships about a foot.

Hundreds of taxpayers and attorneys called at the City Hall yesterday to inspect the assessment books, which will remain in the custody of the Municipal Assembly until the last week in August. Most of the callers were intent on getting the final assessed valuation placed on their property or that of their clients.

MONTREAL, July 5. -- It is announced that the newly formed Dominion Steel and Iron Company will take over the Dominion Coal Company, and will guarantee to pay at least 6 per cent. on the stock of the latter, which amounts to $15,000,000.

WASHINGTON, July 5. -- The War Department announced to-day that the aggregate receipts from customs in Cuba for the past fourteen weeks are $3,949,814. The receipts for the week ending June 17, viz., $335,931, exceeded those of any previous week by $16,084.

ALBANY, July 5. -- The civil service rules to govern New York City in accordance with the resolutions of tile State Civil Service Commission were to-day returned by mail to the commission without the approval of Mayor Van Wyck.

NEWPORT, July 5. -- While descending Grosvenor Hill, a most dangerous place in the fog which prevailed at the time, W.K. Vanderbilt, Jr., returning to his cottage in his automobile, was thrown from the carriage to the highway, yesterday evening, and received a slight cut on the head.

CHICAGO, July 5. -- Wheat was extremely weak to-day, losing 1 7/8 cents in the course of the day. All the early information was against higher prices. The English visible supply, which a year ago showed a decrease of 296,000 bushels, to-day showed an increase of 1,538,000 bushels.

CHICAGO, July 5. -- A new through line from Norfolk, Va., to Omaha. Neb., is being mapped out. From a reliable source it is learned that a large engineering corps in charge of E.C. Collins of Kirksville, Mo., said to be employed by a coterie of Chicago capitalists and the Missouri Construction Company, is surveying a line for a railroad from Quincy to Springfield, Ill.

BAY SHORE, L.I. July 5. -- John Bunn, a young negro, was found dead near the Long Island Railroad station here early this morning. He lay close to the rails, and it is thought he was murdered. There was no train that could have struck him. There is a cut over his left ear which penetrates to the brain. It looks as if it had been inflicted with a hatchet or an axe.
HENLEY-ON-THAMES, July 5. -- This was the second day of the Henley Regatta, and though the weather was beautiful Henley, on the whole, seemed much less crowded than usual.

Patrolman O'Hara of the Butler Street Station noticed a big man and a little man hitting each other early yesterday morning on Court Street, near Fourth Place, Brooklyn. The big man was Michael Mulvey of 180 Luquer Street, and the small one Thomas J. Reeves of 481 Court Street. Both had been celebrating the Fourth and were overstimulated.

There are a great many morals to be drawn from the bids that were opened by the Controller yesterday for such of the bonds of the City of New York as have been allowed by the Municipal Assembly to be issued in fulfillment of the most pressing of the municipal obligations.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., July 5. -- W. Gould Brokaw's handsome schooner Amorita carried away the honors at the first squadron run of the Atlantic Yacht Club, held on the Sound this afternoon. Mr. Brokaw's yacht dropped anchor in Bridgeport Harbor shortly after 2 o'clock, making the entire run in 3 hours 40 minutes and 04 seconds.
WASHINGTON, July 5. -- "There is not a case of yellow fever in the United States," was the statement made to a Post reporter this afternoon by Surgeon General Wyman of the Marine Hospital Service.

Broadening tendencies show throughout the stock market; activity increases and strength keeps pace. Professional grumbling seems to have gone out of fashion. Even the room traders of the Stock Exchange are parading less pessimism than has recently been the rule.

When Mrs. Russell Sage returned to her home at 503 Fifth Avenue last evening from her Summer home at Irvington-on-the-Hudson, where she and her husband had been for the past few days, she found awaiting her a letter which had been at the house for the past two days.

We wish the representatives of Great Britain, France, and Russia in the Peace Conference had felt at liberty to discuss the principle of exempting from capture private property at sea. In his position of greater freedom Ambassador WHITE discussed it, ably, frankly, and fully, presenting the American argument as it has so often been presented in congresses and conferences during the last hundred years.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., July 6. -- Indian Harbor yachtsmen sailed their circuit race at Greenwich to-day despite the threatening weather of the morning, mingled with rain, shortly before the start. There was very little breeze all the morning, and many of the boats entered did not arrive in the harbor in time to participate. Two o'clock was the hour set for the start, but the committee deemed it best to postpone it for half an hour.

WASHINGTON, July 6. -- The War Department, acting upon the advice of Gen. Otis, advertised, about June 23, that it would employ ten stenographers for duty in the reorganized courts on the Island of Luzon, the advertisement very distinctly stating the qualifications regarded as indispensable in applicants for the positions.

SOUTHAMPTON, July 6. -- The yacht Shamrock is not yet ready to engage in trial races. Workmen are still engaged in painting the craft and fixing her tackle. The Shamrock will be ready Saturday and the Britannia Wednesday, when the trials will commence.

AUSTIN, Texas, July 6. -- It is impossible thus far to give an accurate estimate of the loss of life by the Brazos River flood. The efforts of the State authorities are being devoted to the work of relieving the necessities of the survivors, many thousands of whom have been without food for several days.

Patrolman Thomas F. O'Brien of the West One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street Police Station was held yesterday in the Harlem Police Court for examination at 10 o'clock next Monday morning on the charge of stealing a gold watch and chain and two lockets from the person of Capt. George B. Rhoads of the Seventh Regiment while the latter was being taken, in a dying condition, to the J. Hood Wright Memorial Hospital.

The guests of St. John's Guild on the initial trip of the new floating hospital, the Helen C. Juilliard, yesterday saw the practical working of a notable philanthropic idea. Loaded with sick babies and their mothers from the poorer classes on the east side, the new boat sailed across the lower bay, and, together with the old hospital boat, Emma Abbott, lay at anchor off New Dorp, S.I.

Russell Sage was disposed yesterday to be chatty about gas and traction affairs, while he admitted that he had no knowledge of impending changes in the gas war or in the attitude of the passenger service systems.

The letter which Artemus J. Smith sent a few days ago to Mrs. Russell Sage, vaguely hinting at danger to her husband from some anonymous crank who looked with disfavor on rich men, was the forerunner of some surprising results yesterday which have both their odd and serious side and may lead to the severing of a once fast friendship, if not to far more unpleasant developments.

PATERSON, N.J., July 6. -- County Physician McBride to-day ordered that the funeral of Ada Fogg, which was to have been held this afternoon, be postponed until he had made an inquiry into the cause of death. This investigation showed death to be due to consumption, but an inquest will be held.

Butler Whiting, the youthful skipper who has been sailing the wonderfully speedy catboat Kazaza in the Sound circuit regattas, has a local reputation as an amateur sailor of which the Larchmont people are proud. Although only sixteen years old, he has been winning prizes at aquatic events for two or three years, and he combines with absolute fearlessness an uncommon degree of skill in the management of boats.
A calculating Kansas journal estimates that the cost of the sword to be presented to Gen. Funston by citizens of its State would buy nearly 1,300 pruning hooks.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 6. -- Jim Jeffries, champion pugilist of the world, arrived from the East to-night, and was met at the station by a large crowd of admirers and a brass band.

ALBANY, July 6. -- State Controller William J. Morgan to-day answered the charges made by the resigned Board of Managers of the Western House of Refuge for Women at Albion, characterizing the State Controller, the State Board of Charities, and the State Civil Service Commission as "officious marplots," who had been "meddling" with the refuge "in an insulting and embarrassing manner."

The New York Central and the Pennsylvania Railroads have entered into a compact unprecedented in railway history. Under its provisions the two great properties become, for practical purposes, one system. Not only are old rivalries disposed of, but there is a new policy of actual co-operation.

NEW LONDON, Conn., July 6. -- W. Gould Brokaw's schooner Amorita again led the fleet of the Atlantic Yacht Club in the squadron run to this port to-day. She defeated the Colonia in easy style. Commodore Postley's yacht met with an accident early in the race. Her fore topmast was carried away and she was compelled to enter the harbor at New London in a disabled condition.

LEXINGTON, Ky., July 6. -- Joe Thayer has sold to W.R. Brasfield, for a St. Louis turfman, the two-year-old filly Futurity Belle, by Electric Bell, dam by Red Wilkes. She has been a mile this season in 2:24, something never done by a two-year-old here at this season of the year. The price paid was $3,000.

MANILA, July 7. -- The Spanish Commissioners who went to Tarlac for a conference with Aguinaldo regarding the surrender of the Spanish prisoners in the hands of the Filipinos, returned here last night. Chairman del Rio of the commission said the release of all the prisoners had been practically arranged for, but it would be necessary to consult with the Spanish Government before the agreement could be ratified.

LONDON, July 6. -- The Liberal Party gained two Parliamentary seats to-day in the bye-elections held in the "double-barreled'' constituency of Oldham to fill the dual vacancy created by the death last month of Robert Ascroft, (Conservative,) and the subsequent resignation of his Conservative colleague, James Francis Oswald, who has just been appointed by the Chancellor of the Exchequer, Sir Michael Hicks Beach, to be Steward and Bailiff of the Manor of Northstead.

WASHINGTON, July 6. -- The order for the enlistment of volunteers for service in the Philippines was published to-day, and seven more Colonels to command the ten volunteer regiments were appointed. There are yet two Colonels to be designated. Eight Majors also were named. The recruiting will not begin until some time next week, the exact date not having been fixed yet.
NEWPORT, July 6. -- Miss Anna Depew Paulding, niece of Senator Depew, has arrived at Pinard cottage, and her uncle and his son will arrive there on Saturday evening.

The submarine boat Argonaut, built at Baltimore, and which was successfully tested in waters near that city some months ago, has recently been enlarged and altered at the Erie Basin, and was yesterday put into the water again. To say that the boat was launched would be hardly accurate, as she was taken up by a derrick and lowered into the water.

HENLEY-ON-THAMES, July 6. -- The continuation of the Henley Royal Regatta today was under favorable conditions. The weather was brilliant and the attendance of spectators largely exceeded that of yesterday. A prominent figure was Mr. R.C. Lehmann, who coached the Harvard University crew for two seasons, as he took his place to watch the First Trinity Eight, whom he had trained.

GALVESTON, Texas, July 6. -- Gov. Sayers has been asked by Representative W.H. Ellis to call a special session of the Legislature to relieve the distress resulting from the Brazos River flood. Reports received here indicate that while the property loss has been enormous, the loss of life has been greatly exaggerated.

The Brooklyns' losing streak was broken yesterday, when the team defeated the Philadelphias at Washington Park by a score of 7 to 1. The Brooklyns had lost nine straight games, and Manager Hanlon, apparently thought a little shake-up in the team would do no harm. Casey was taken out, and Dahlen played at third, and Jennings at short.

Society was quite well represented "down the bay" yesterday, and the number of well-known craft, with large parties on board, following the race between the Columbia and the Defender was more than one sees generally at this time of the year. Ex-Commodore Gerry had a large party on the Electra and Mr. J. Pierpont Morgan another, including the judges, on the Corsair.

There was a sensational opening of the racing season of twenty-seven days at the Brighton Beach Racing Association's track yesterday. Imp was the cause of it, for this game mare, winner of the Suburban Handicap in 2:05 4-5, put the Brighton Handicap, at a mile and a quarter, to the credit of her owners in 2:05 2-5.

WASHINGTON, July 6. -- Mr. Mitchell, Acting Controller of the Treasury, has replied to an inquiry from Pay Inspector Burtis on the United States flagship New York, at Port of Spain, Trinidad, as to the rate of pay to which Rear Admiral W.T. Sampson is entitled from Aug. 10, 1898, when he was commissioned a Rear Admiral, to March, 1899, the date when Congress adjourned.

The United States transport McClellan, Capt. Brickley, arrived at Quarantine yesterday from Santiago displaying the yellow flag. An inspection by the Quarantine authorities disclosed two well-developed cases of yellow fever among her passengers and two cases with many of the usual symptoms, but which have not yet been definitely diagnosed.
BELGRADE, Servia, July 6. -- Ex-King Milan, father of King Alexander of Servia, narrowly escaped assassination here this evening.

CINCINNATI, July 6. -- Arguments were made to-day before Judge Taft of the United States Circuit Court of Appeals on the receivership of the Columbus, Sandusky and Hocking Railway. S.M. Felton had been appointed receiver by the Federal Court, and N. Montseratt by the State court. Judge Taft sustained his appointment of Receiver S.M. Felton and ousted Mr. Montserratt.

Downing Clarke, the representative of David Belasco, was asked yesterday for definite information concerning the report that Mrs. Leslie Carter is to appear in "Macbeth" this Winter. He could not supply it, but said there was no doubt that Mr. Belasco had in contemplation a notable Shakespearean revival, in which Mrs. Carter would assume the leading part.

AMSTERDAM, July 6. -- Queen Wilhelmina and the Queen Mother arrived here this afternoon, and, amid a great popular demonstration, proceeded to the palace. The members of the International Peace Conference arrived from The Hague at 6:30 o'clock P.M. by special train and proceeded from the station directly to the palace, where they were received by the Queens, after which they were entertained at a magnificent banquet in the palace.

AUSTIN, Texas, July 6. -- Gov. Sayers to-day received a letter from Gov. De Forest of Wyoming, stating that he is in hearty sympathy with the anti-trust movement, and that it will give him great pleasure to attend the conference of Governors and Attorney Generals to be held in St. Louis if his plan will allow him to do so.
The United States Senatorship from Michigan is a subject that Secretary of War Russell A. Alger does not care to discuss.

WASHINGTON, July 6. -- Gen. Henderson of Iowa, the prospective Speaker of the House of Representatives, had a conference with the President to-day, but at the conclusion of his call said that no general questions had been discussed. "I have simply been looking after matters pertaining to my own district," he said.

DETROIT, July 6. -- Fully 20,000 delegates to the Christian Endeavor Convention are now in the city, besides thousands of visitors who are not connected with the society, but who are here to attend the meetings.

President John A. McCall of the New York Life Insurance Company gave a dinner last evening at the Metropolitan Club to the Prussian Insurance Commissioners -- Privy Councillor von Knebel-Doeberitz and State Councillor Baron Marshall von Bieberstein -- who have completed an investigation of the company.

FREDERICK, Md., July 6. -- Armistead Taylor, colored, was convicted to-day of the murder on May 13 of Mrs. Rosa Rosenstein at Slidell, Montgomery County. John Alfred Brown, who also stands indicted for the murder of the Rosensteins, will be placed on trial to-morrow in the same court.

The one-raters Constance, owned by the Post-Thomas syndicate, and Algonquin, the Crowninshield boat, raced thrice yesterday off Centre Island, in the Sound, over a four-mile course. Gen. Samuel Thomas's steam yacht Radha followed the 20-foot racers.

The Columbia, the new yacht built to compete for the honor of defending the America's Cup against the Shamrock, sailed her first formal race against the Defender yesterday and won by the official elapsed time of 3 minutes and 33 seconds. The corrected time could not be computed, because the two yachts have not been measured, and it is not known yet how much the new yacht will have to allow the old one.

ALBANY, July 7. -- The disclosures relative to the management of State reformatories for women and the abuse of their inmates, it is expected, will be brought officially to the attention of the Governor and Will form the basis of an inquiry, either by special attorneys or by a committee of the State Board of Charities.

Some show of activity and strength appeared at the opening of yesterday's market, and at the close there was similar manifestation, but during most of the day Stock Exchange tickers lagged and quotations seemed inclined to droop. Influence was exhibited by uncertainty in the Wall Street public's mind as to what to-day's bank statement might disclose, the extraordinary changes of last week being a somewhat depressing factor in calculations as to what may to-day develop.

LONDON, July 7. -- A number of the American, Colonial, and Continental guests of the International Congress of Women having expressed a desire to pay their respects to the Queen, Lady Aberdeen arranged a trip to Windsor this afternoon, when her Majesty assented to the suggestion that she should drive slowly through the quadrangle of the castle and receive a few of the more prominent delegates.

In a recent number of THE SATURDAY REVIEW there appeared a letter written by me in answer to one by a writter who signed himself "Holley," and who indulged in sneers at Westcott's "David Harum," demanding to know how the book had been boomed into popularity, making the point that its immense sale was due to a systematic process of log-rolling and not to its own merit.

Mrs. Yetta Schwartzman of 103 Hester Street and Mrs. Jennie Adler of 51 Orchard Street were arrested and arraigned yesterday afternoon in the Essex Market Police Court on a charge of disturbing the peace and disorderly conduct in the office of Lawyer Henry J. Goldsmith, nearly opposite the court building.

In looking through my library of TIMES SATURDAY REVIEWS I recently enjoyed an evening of unmitigated pleasure -- an evening devoted to the delights of desultory reading, a thought here, a paragraph there, and now a whole essay that had given pleasure on its first reading and upon re-reading only intensified that feeling.

Mr. Aston's "History of Japanese Literature" is the latest volume in the series of "Literatures of the World," edited by Edmund Gosse. Its plan is similar to that of the other works in the series, but its subject has made necessary certain changes in treatment in which the present volume differs from its predecessors.

The curiosity of Foreman John Falby, aroused by the suspicious actions of a gang of boys in the Westchester yards of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad on Thursday afternoon averted what might have been a bad accident to the Washington Limited, which was filled with passengers.
