The Hudson County Board for the Equalization of Taxes met in Jersey City yesterday to receive the valuations of property fixed by the local Assessors. They were as follows:

AUSTIN, Texas, July 7. -- The attention of the War Department has been called to a peculiar effect of the recent flood in the Rio Grande River. The former channel of the erratic stream passed within a few rods of Fort Ringgold, Texas, and the pumping station was so situated as to afford an adequate water supply for the army post.

Concerning your article in the last SATURDAY REVIEW on "The Delights of Reading in Summer." I notice you mention therein Ashby-Sterry's "Happy Hammockuity." As I have been looking for this poem for some time, I would esteem it a very great favor if you would print the same in full in THE REVIEW.

WASHINGTON, July 7. -- The President has completed the selection of the medical officers to serve with the regiments of volunteer infantry to be organized for service in the Philippines. These appointments, together with the former service of the appointees, are as follows:

It will be recalled that when Lord Kitchener's forces captured Omdurman they released a certain German named Charles Neufeld, who for more than ten years had been held a captive by the dervishes. The newspapers of a year ago were full of his adventures. Mr. Neufeld has written a book, entitled, "A Prisoner of the Khaleefa: Twelve Years' Captivity at Omdurman." This work will be published in the early Autumn by G.P. Putnam's Sons.

A polo game that was characterized by more than the usual number of petty accidents and by an exciting finish such as is seldom seen was the contest between the Lakewood and Meadow Brook second teams yesterday afternoon at the Rockaway Hunt Club, Cedarhurst, L.I. The match was the final contest for the Blizzard Cups.

THE HAGUE, July 7. -- The Third Committee of the Peace Conference, sitting this morning at the Huis ten Bosch, discussed the scheme for the Mediation and Arbitration Convention prepared by the Drafting Committee. Many of the delegates had only been acquainted with the proposals since yesterday and they had not had time to consult their Governments.

WASHINGTON, July 7. -- Surgeon General Sternberg to-day received a cable from Major O'Reilly at Havana saying; "Armstrong reports two deaths from yellow fever at Puerto Principe. He has made all necessary recommendations. He reports having sufficient force for any immediate exigency." Another cable says the Surgeon at Manzanillo reports two more cases of yellow fever to-day.

A Hearing in the case of Mrs. Phyllis E. Dodge, who is accused of having on June 24 made a false declaration as to her property, which came with her on the steamship St. Paul, with intent to defraud the Government, was had at the Custom House yesterday. It was held in the Collector's principal office and lasted from 1:30 to 3:20 o'clock.

A letter appeared in your last issue of THE TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW entitled "Myths of the Old Testament." It is the first of the kind I have seen for some time, and I trust it will be the last. There is no originality in the views expressed, any more than there was in Dr. Abbott's side show of Jonah and the whale.
THE HAGUE, July 7. -- The review of troops this morning was attended by the military delegates to the Peace Conference, who were especially invited to be present.

She certainly went cheap, having been knocked down in London in a public auction room for only 20 guineas, and what is a hundred dollars or so for a mermaid having a conspicuous tail? What a delightful old myth she is, after all. Frequenting the sea, she was sweet and clean, and was always bothering with her hair and combing out her tangled tresses and surveying herself in a looking glass.

In The Century for this month Mr. F.M.F. Skene, in an article entitled "Sir Walter Scott's First Love," tells of the early romance in the life of the great author. There always has been a certain amount of curiosity in regard to the relationship between Williamina Stuart (after Lady Stuart Forbes) and Walter Scott.
Redress from the evils resulting from trusts must, in the opinion of United States Senator William E. Chandler of New Hampshire, be sought from State authorities, and not from the General Government.

CHICAGO, July 7. -- In a paper read this afternoon before the Illinois State Bar Association Edwin Burritt Smith declared that the tariff breeds trusts. He urged the abolition of the protective tariff as a great step against monopolies. Mr. Smith's paper on "Trusts -- Their Legal Status," with the ensuing remarks by other members, took up the greater part of the afternoon session.

Against Mr. Justin McCarthy's "Reminiscences" a reviewer in The Manchester Guardian has made a complaint which is not likely to be indorsed by American readers of reminiscences, biographies, and historical studies written by English authors. The Guardian's grievance against Mr. McCarthy is that he "evidently does not overrate his reader's intelligence."

GREENPORT, L.I., July 7. -- After an enjoyable squadron run of twenty-six and a half miles the fleet of the Atlantic Yacht Club dropped anchor off the Manhassett House shortly before colors this afternoon. The fleet of racers had sailed over a course arranged by Col. David Austen and Louis Jackson, which gave them a good amount of windward work.

There is nothing dry and nothing sentimental in this book of popular botany. It is a straightforward, interesting, well-written account of the life of plants studied in the light of modern science. The subject is divested as far as possible of technicalities, and the "professional stateliness" which Agassiz so much deprecated in books on natural history is entirely lacking.

About the most pitiable creature in this world, be he embryo or actual millionaire, is the man whose whole mental energy and leisure are devoted to the acquisition and consideration of wealth. For such a man the world-famed books exist but in his library -- never in his thought. They make a goodly array of pretense for his learned friends to see and serve for decorative purposes in the composition of a room.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 7. -- The Ohio Association of Democratic Clubs was organized to-day with Gen. E.B. Finley of Bucyrus as permanent Chairman and Charles L. Swain of Cincinnati Secretary. The resolutions adopted reaffirm allegiance to the Chicago platform and "demand the renomination of that fearless champion of the Democracy and the people's rights, William Jennings Bryan."

All unknown colored man, riding a bicycle, was impaled on the shaft of a delivery wagon at Fifth Avenue and Forty-fourth Street yesterday afternoon. The cyclist's head was almost torn from his body. He died in Flower Hospital a few minutes later.

"Burns and Clarinda," a rare volume, published in 1843 by "Robert P. Bixby Co. of No. 3 Park Row, opposite Astor House, New York," now lies open before me. It is of course known to curious readers and students of Burns, but in its entirety it is known but to very few:
In the matter of "iste" it seemed a work of supererogation to add anything to THE SATURDAY REVIEW'S original statement, but since it has been questioned, perhaps this may be found useful.

WASHINGTON, July 7. -- Official and unofficial Washington alike were shocked today by the tragic death from an explosion of gasoline at her home just west of the British Embassy of Mrs. Margaret Dickins, one of the best-known women in social, literary, and charitable circles in Washington, and the wife of Capt. Francis W. Dickins, of the navy.

Frank Corrigan, ten years old, of 516 West Forty-ninth Street, was drowned in the river off West Forty-ninth Street while bathing yesterday afternoon. The boy was in a party of a score or more of his playmates. They had been swimming for some time and the ordinary sport growing dull, they began to "stump" each other to daring feats.

Sixty-three years ago Andrew Jackson was President of the United States, Broadway shop windows were just beginning to glisten with gas, and The New York Mirror was published at the corner of Nassau and Ann Streets. The editors were George P. Morris, Theodore S. Fay, and N.P. Willis.
Interviewed by The World's correspondent, Maitre Labori was asked:
EAU CLAIRE, Wis., July 7. -- The Wisconsin Central Railroad was sold to the Reorganization Committee to-day for $7,300,000.

The police of the West Twentieth Street Station took an aged woman out of the garret of the house 419 West Twenty-sixth Street yesterday afternoon, who is likely to die from the effects of gradual starvation and general neglect. The woman is Mary Quinn, believed to be about seventy years old.

One of the most attractive of recent books is "The Ballads of a Bookworm," by the late Irving Browne, which has just been issued by the Roycroft Press. It is beautifully printed on hand-made paper, and appears in an edition of 850 signed and numbered copies. Each ballad has a well-designed initial, drawn by hand, and illuminated in gold and colors, many of which are extremely good, and the colors are very artistically chosen.

Now that "David Harum" has made such a tremendous hit with the public, after being rejected by several houses, the usual crop of paragraphs derisive of publishers' readers for their lack of perspicacity will doubtless make their appearance, and again will the changes be rang on the old, old story of the difficulty of the unknown writer to secure a fair hearing in the publishing world.

SEATTLE, July 7. -- The two extreme results of search for gold in Alaska were presented in strong contrast yesterday, when the steamer City of Topeka arrived from the north. Miners from Dawson walked down the gangplank trembling under the weight of the gold dust they carried, while miners from Copper River staggered from weakness and disease contracted in the terrible north.

The Tremont Taxpayers' Association held a mass meeting last evening at Alliance Hall, One Hundred and Seventy-fourth Street and Third Avenue, to protest against the proposed widening of Tremont Avenue from Bathgate Avenue to West Farms. William A. Cameron, President of the association, occupied the chair, and, although the meeting was small, the protest was vigorous.

LONDON, July 7. -- At the first day of the Lingfield Summer meeting to-day, Mr. Wallace Johnstone's Harrow won the Lingfield Park Stakes of 3,000 sovereigns. "Tod" Sloan rode Mr. P. Lorillard's Sibola and finished second. Seven horses ran the straight mile. The betting was 3 to 1 against Sibola.

Mirabeau L. Towns, the poetic lawyer, has again dropped into verse, mingling it artistically with somewhat dusty legal facts. Mr. Towns's arguments and verse, which may be called his exhortation, appear in his brief in the case of the Eagle Savings and Loan Company against Jennie Samuels, in the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court.
CLAYTON, N.Y., July 7. -- An interesting problem has presented itself here which the Treasury Department may be obliged to call on the United States courts to decide.

HENLEY-ON-THAMES, July 7. -- The Henley Royal Regatta came to an end to-day under the most favorable conditions. The weather was perfect, but the attendance was not so numerous as usual. The racing contained no surprises and no close finishes.

Neither as a publicist nor as a philosopher would anybody think of comparing the late ROBERT BONNER with BENJAMIN FRANKLIN. But as a thrifty, shrewd American citizen, "getting on" by force of thrift and shrewdness, as a neighbor and a citizen in a word, Mr. BONNER was very much like a duodecimo edition of FRANKLIN.

From that mine, Justin McCarthy's "Reminiscences," inexhaustible material may be drawn. This historian and journalist, for he most justly lays claim to the first title, during the course of a long life spent both in England and the United States was on rapport with many distinguished men, and he tells in the happiest way his remembrances of them.
WASHINGTON, July 7. -- Capt. Brereton of the Twenty-fourth Infantry, who distinguished himself in the Santiago campaign, is to be apopinted to the Colonelcy of one of the volunteer regiments.

The yachts Columbia and Defender, which after the race off Sandy Hook on Thursday were towed to an anchorage opposite the New York Yacht Club station at Tompkinsville, S.I., were towed back to New Rochelle early yesterday morning. They resumed their moorings at buoys a mile off Premium Point.

NARRAGANSETT PIER, R.I., July 7. -- The members of the sub-committee of the United States Senate Finance Commission, who have come here to discuss the question of currency reform, have settled down to two sessions, aggregating six hours daily.

BERLIN, July 7. -- Measures have been taken to strike off the rolls of the Prussian Herrenhaus, or House of Lords, the name of Prince Gebhard Blucher, great-grandson of the famous General who commanded the Prussians at the battle of Waterloo. Some years ago Prince Blucher, who, it is alleged, had ruined himself at the gambling table, went to New York City, where, it is said, he became naturalized.

I have never found a literary review so completely satisfactory as THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW. I proved my allegiance by requiring every member of my sophomore class to become a subscriber. The students of this class had completed a study of Pancoast's "Representative English Literature," and the same author's "Introduction to American Literature.'' They had also pursued a prescribed course or reading in the masterpieces of both literatures.

Interest in tent services in the city is increasing. The largest tent, at Manhattan Avenue and One Hundred and Eighth Street, seats 1,200, and is found too small. Last Sunday 1,500 were in attendance. The Rev. E.E. Franke, evangelist, is the leading spirit in the enterprise, and announces that his aim is to lead people to a reverent study of the Bible.

TRENTON, N.J., July 7. -- The Great Lakes Towing Company, with a capital of $5,000,000, was incorporated here to-day. The incorporators are W.F. Coleman Carpenter, Frederick W. Klein, and Gustave Vonden Steinen.

AUSTIN, Texas. July 7. -- Scores of telegrams were received by Gov. Sayers to-day from charitable persons in all parts of the country, tendering financial aid to the flood sufferers of Texas. Frank Gould of New York wired the Governor to draw on him for $5,000 and to apply the sum where it was most needed.

The Newark Advertiser, discussing the poems of Edwin Markham, speaks of the vigor and intensity of "The Man With the Hoe," which it says is now chiseled into the memory of the American people. After discussing the elegiac character of the poems celebrating man and his work, it takes up the nature poems. One of its remarks here shows such naive ignorance of California conditions that it is delicious reading.

The Methodist Twentieth Century Fund Committee is displaying great activity just now, and it is announced that the amounts raised in England and America will exceed what was originally expected. In this country the agreement was to raise $20,000,000, while the Wesleyans of England set out to get 1,000,000 guineas.

Dr. Edward Munson of Medina, a prominent member of the resigning board, was especially indignant.

CHICAGO, July 7. -- Thomas W. Lee, for the last two years Assistant Chairman of the Western Passenger Association, with offices in Chicago, has been appointed General Passenger Agent of the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railway to succeed W.S. Holwell, who has resigned. This is the fourth Chicago man to go to the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western, the other three being President Truesdale, Traffic Manager Caldwell, and Advertising Agent Hunter.
NEWPORT, July 7. -- Mrs. John Clinton Gray entertained at luncheon this afternoon.

BALTIMORE, July 7. -- A twin-screw passenger steamer that is to run between New York and New Haven, Conn., will be launched by the Maryland Steel Company on Tuesday at 2 o'clock P.M., and guests are expected in a special car from Jersey City, Philadelphia, Wilmington, and Washington to witness the event.

The steam yacht Fra Diavolo, formerly the property of the late Hermann, the magician, now, according to Manning's Yacht Register, owned by Edward S. Stokes, was run down and sunk at 6 o'clock yesterday afternoon by the Merritt-Chapman wrecking tug Hustler in the middle of the North River, off Liberty Street.

SOUTHAMPTON, July 7. -- Interest in the Shamrock's trial has been greatly increased by the report that Emperor William is sending his yacht Meteor to participate in the trial spins expected to take place early next week.
NEWPORT, R.I., July 7. -- The North Atlantic squadron left here shortly after 10:30 o'clock this morning for Portsmouth, N.H., and Portland, Me., with Capt. H.C. Taylor of the Indiana in command.

BELGRADE, July 7. -- The man who attempted last evening to assassinate ex-King Milan, firing four shots from a revolver at him and wounding him slightly in the back, is a fireman employed by the municipality. It is supposed he was hired by an enemy of Milan.

DETROIT, Mich., July 7. -- Soon after the break of dawn to-day the Trustees of the United Society of Christian Endeavor gathered in the Hotel Cadillac to discuss several matters left undetermined at Wednesday's meeting. The most important of these was the consideration of a protest from the Ministerial Alliance of Toledo against the opening of the gates of the Ohio Centennial on Sunday.

Kearny, Commissioner of Public Buildings, Lighting, and Supplies, from making contracts for the lighting of the City of New York, because they had not been authorized by an ordinance of the Municipal Assembly.

Douglas, won the semi-finals in the amateur tournament at Onwentsia to-day, and will meet to-morrow in the deciding struggle for the championship.

With San Francisco, Chicago, and Melbourne, Sydney affords an interesting example of the rapid growth of towns of the first rank under modern conditions.

MANAWA, Wis., July 8. -- A tornado passed over Union township, five miles north of this city, last night. Only the fact that no city or village lay in its track prevented a result equaling the New Richmond horror. The storm struck the township at the western boundary and plowed a furrow across it six miles long and from fifteen to forty rods wide.

LONDON, July 8. -- Readers of these dispatches who follow British politics will not have been surprised at the sweeping Liberal victories at Oldham. I had no doubt that both Liberal candidates would be elected, but I did not expect such a tremendous change as the transformation of a mean Conservative majority of 605 into a mean Liberal majority of 1,410.

LONDON, July 8. -- The centenary review and inspection of the Metropolitan Volunteers, who were organized in Hyde Park by George III. to oppose the apprehended invasion of England by the troops of Napoleon, occurred on the Horse Guards' Parade this afternoon. About 30,000 London volunteers took part in the review, and the beautiful weather made the event the greatest spectacle of the season.

CHICAGO, July 8. -- P.R. Walter, a resident of Philadelphia, who lives at 3053 Potter Street in that city, stopped in Chicago three hours this morning, and during that brief period had a disagreeable experience.

NORTHEAST HARBOR, Me., July 8. -- There is not a great deal of life at Northeast Harbor as yet, for the bulk of the Summer population has delayed its coming. Not for another week will society begin to dance, drive, and entertain. The younger set are especially lacking at present, and so the first Kimball House dance has been postponed until Saturday evening, July 15.

Choate, United States Ambassador, declared at the banquet here July 4 that the presence of a thousand American women at the reception held at the embassy during the afternoon was the most impressive evidence he had yet received in regard to the importance of the Ambassadorship to the Court of St. James's, he gave only a faint idea of the crowds of Americans now in London.

Howard Hinkle of Cincinnati, handicap 20, won first place with a net score of 99. T.G. Condon of New York, scratch, and L.F. Brigham of Salem, Mass., handicap 12, were tied for second place, with net scores of 103.

The main topic of the day in Tent Endeavor was "Saved to Serve." "Self-Consecration" was the general theme in Tent Williston.

ROCHESTER, July 8. -- Henry F. St. Clair, aged twenty-two, who was arrested here Monday on the charge of stealing a watch from his wife, Katharine Barry St. Clair, and who was re-arrested Thursday on a new charge of bigamy, had a hearing in Police Court this morning. He was held to await the action of the Grand Jury, bail being fixed at $2,000.

SOUTHAMPTON, July 8. -- The cup challenger Shamrock quite unexpectedly left her moorings at 11:30 o'clock this morning and sailed down Southampton Water on a canvas-stretching trip. The Iverna, a cutter owned by Mr. John Jameson, also started, apparently with the intention of testing her speed against the Shamrock. Sir Thomas Lipton is on board the Iverna.

When the leaves of the tobacco plant are mature and ready for harvest, they are gathered and first laid on the ground to wilt -- that is, to wither and lose their brittleness. This done, they are collected into bundles and packed, top upward, into moderate-sized heaps to sweat. Matting is placed over the heaps and a gradual rise of temperature begins.

NEW HAVEN, July 8. -- The will of Prof. Samuel Harris of Yale University has been admitted to probate. The amount of the estate is not known, as the Appraisers have not yet filed their report. The will was drawn by Prof. Harris himself, and bequeaths the bulk of the estate in equal shares to nephews and nieces, with a reservation of $1,000 only to the widow.

TO the large majority of the American people Mr. Robert P. Porter's new book on the Island of Cuba will be a revelation. It is called "Industrial Cuba" and is published by G.P. Putnam's Sons. In considerably more than 300 pages the author tells the story of the Pearl of the Antilles; he proves the presence of great natural wealth and shows how it has been neglected by the Spaniards.

BRISTOL, July 8. -- It is the belief here that when the cup defender Columbia races against the Shamrock she will appear as an "all bronze" boat in every sense of the word. In brief, it is believed that the coat of white paint at present covering the topsides of the yacht is to be scraped off when she races in defense of the cup.

Guests are digging into Dana and talking learnedly about clay, gravel, rock, and sand deposits. Col. Dick's fashionable hotel is like one in a Western mining camp for the interest its guests have developed in the formation of the earth about here at different depths.

WASHINGTON, July 8. -- The details for the recruiting of the volunteer regiments are being arranged by the Colonels of the regiments and officers of the War Department. The recruiting will be conducted so that the new men may be organized into companies and become soldiers very soon. Each Colonel is chief recruiting officer for his regiment.

Just how All Ferrouh Bey came to be impressed with the propriety of getting out the flag of the Ottoman Empire on that morning, and to show it as if Tuesday was a day when the crescent should be displayed, no one has explained except Secretary of State Hay.

The sea carriage of India has developed in a remarkable manner -- from a total of 20,457,619 tons in 1879-80 to 33,162,547 tons in 1896-7, of which 25,171,993 tons was under the British flag. The foreign flags engaged in the foreign trade of India are chiefly German, (411,214 tons,) Austrian, (239,729 tons,) and French.

The final polo contest, played yesterday at the Rockaway Club, Cedarhurst, L.I., for the Ladies' Challenge Cup, was most exciting. Two champion teams met for the trophy, the crack Meadow Brook and the Devon team, which holds first honors in the State of Pennsylvania. The Meadow Brook four won.

CHICAGO, July 8. -- Ludwig Decker, aged ninety-three, one of the oldest residents of the fashionable suburb of Austin, committed suicide to-day by throwing himself out of second-story window because his favorite granddaughter, Miss Maude Decker, became Mrs. E.R. Dunlap, a month ago.

PARIS, June 30. -- A period of calm has followed the storm which the Waldeck-Rousseau Ministry roused both in the Chamber and in all political circles where capital is still a force. The storm while it lasted was very wild, but the Chamber, which is now one of the most pusillanimous corporations in existence, accepted M. Waldeck-Rousseau's Ministry with its usual docility, and the Government is safe until October next.

WASHINGTON, July 8. -- Gov. Roosevelt arrived in Washington to-day, and spent this afternoon in conference with President McKinley at the White House, where he will remain as the guest of the Chief Executive till Monday. Gov. Roosevelt being a man of military experience, the President wished to discuss with him the matter of the appointment of officers from the Empire State for the provisional regiments which are being formed for service in the Philippines.

LONDON, July 8. -- At St. Stephen's Hall, Westminster, this city, the chess experts met at noon to-day in order to contest in the twenty-ninth round of the International Chess Masters' Tournament, for which the pairing had been arranged according to Round 12 of the Berger system, as follows: Bird vs. Schlechter, Tinsley vs. Showalter, Tschigorin vs. Janowski, Mason vs. Pillsbury, Blackburne vs. Maroczy, Cohn vs. Lee, Lasker and Steinitz had byes.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, July 8. -- At a meeting this afternoon of the local board of thirty-two, which had charge of the National Saengerfest, it was made apparent that the deficit entailed by holding the concert here will amount to about $70,000, instead of $55,000, as at first reported. An accurate statement could not be made, as the accounts have not yet been properly audited.

Senator Chauncey M. Depew, accompanied by his son, Chauncey M. Depew, Jr., reached home from his European vacation trip yesterday morning. The steamship Campania, on which the Senator and his son were passengers, dropped anchor off Quarantine about 3 o'clock A.M. About four hours later Mr. Depew was called from his stateroom by the tooting of the whistle of the New York Central harbor boat Dispatch.

As a commentary upon the Congress of the International Council of Women, closed this past week in London, the handbook printed for members and delegates is most interesting. It was carefully arranged, and with it the guests from other countries could not well go astray. It was most comprehensive.

There is a small boy whose home is in New York who, like most small boys, has much to learn, but there is one study in which he has made great strides already, and that is botany. He studies from nature, and he has had at least one Summer to his credit since he has been old enough to study nature as she is to be found in the woods and fields.

CONSTANTINOPLE, June 20. -- The commencement exercises of Robert College were held to-day in this city, and were attended by about five hundred people, including representatives from all the learned societies. Turkish and other's, here. There were also present the British Ambassador and Lady O'Conor, Mr. and Mrs. de Bunsen of the British Embassy, Mr. Dimikoff, the Bulgarian Agent Diplomatic, and the Grand Logotheli, representing the Greek community.

OMAHA, Neb., July 8. -- The retail clerks of Omaha are to-night engaged in a struggle to see whether their employers shall observe the new labor law, which practically forces all stores to close at 6 o'clock. This of course means Saturday night closing, and that is the time in the past that the bulk of the trading has been done in this section of the West.

THE HAGUE, July 1. -- The Peace Conference still sits with closed doors, and the delegates like clams, with closed mouths. The wariest traps of reporters or the most melting smiles of the fair fail alike when attempt is made to draw out some delegate, who perchance has been buttonholed in a hotel lobby or enticed with coffee and cigars into the comforts of a drawing chair after having been well dined.

BERLIN July 8. -- Emperor William's visit to the French training ship Iphigenie at Bergen Thursday, and his cordial exchange of telegrams with President Louber, were not only received with great satisfaction here, but throughout Europe. As one paper puts it, it promises to be a turning point in the world's history.

Malcolm W. Peters, who until about May 25 was President and Acting Treasurer of the Inter-State Advertising Company, has been sued by the company for $3,249.34, which, according to the complaint, he is alleged to have misappropriated. Danner L'Esperance, attorneys for the plaintiff company, obtained an order for the arrest of the defendant from Justice Stover of the Supreme Court, which was served by Deputy Sheriff Terry late Friday night.

I read with great interest Mrs. Hale's able letter in yesterday's TIMES on the negro race problem, and I agree with every word of it. Mrs. Hale and those who think as she does are the truest friends of the colored race. There is but one way to get rid of the negro problem, and that is to get rid of the negro.

The claim of satisfactory evidence of the extreme antiquity of man in the valley of the Delaware River has been soberly discussed and intemperately ridiculed until the public, both scientific and general, have become tired of hearing the subject mentioned; but this is no valid reason why the truth should not be ascertained.

It is very encouraging to have such letters as we print to-day turning up concerning the relationship of the tenement house to the "city lot." The discussion was stimulated, we suppose, by our taking the Tenement House Committee of the Charity Organization Society to task for not having the courage of its convictions, its convictions necessarily, as we thought, being those of everybody who has given any attention to the subject.

LYONS, N.Y., July 8. -- A hot contest for local supremacy is in progress in Wayne County between the Republican leaders. Barnet H. Davis of Palmyra, President of the State Fisheries, Game, and Forest Commission, has declared against the renomination of Marvin J. Greenwood for member of Assembly.

Quietly, but none the less surely and steadily, the transformation of the east side is working. Within the past few years changes, at once gratifying and wonderful, have been made in the character and kind of buildings situated in that portion of the city bounded by Catharine Street, the Bowery, St. Mark's Place and the East River.

LEXINGTON, Ky., July 8. -- Primary conventions in Pulaski, Knox, Carter, Lewis, Boyd, Lawrence, Caldwell, Floyd, Mercer, and Henderson Counties to-day practically settled the question of the Republican Gubernatorial candidates. While Stone got the majority of the instructed delegates in to-day's primaries, enough of them went to Attorney General Taylor to insure him the nomination on the first ballot next Wednesday.

AUSTIN, Texas, July 8. -- The situation in the lower part of the inundated district where the full effect of the great Brazos River flood was felt has improved but little during the past twenty-four hours. Gov. Savers has been in constant telegraphic communication with many of the accessible points in the devastated region, and all day long appeals for aid from the sufferers have poured into the Chief Executive's office.

ON a beautiful bright day, with not a cloud in the blue sky, and the atmosphere so clear that the level and fertile plains of Long Island could be viewed for miles in every direction, Charles Murphy set out on his self-imposed task to ride a mile on a bicycle in the fastest time ever recorded.

WASHINGTON, July 8. -- Ambassador Choate has not communicated to the State Department the result of any representations he has made to Lord Salisbury in London respecting the Alaskan modus vivendi, under his instructions of yesterday. Although it is believed that it is almost hopeless to expect a successful outcome of these direct negotiations with London, it is not regarded here as inevitable that a hostile clash will follow the failure to secure a modus.

LONDON, July 8. -- Although a few great balls are still in sight, the London season is already waning. People are flitting into the country much earlier than usual. Next week will be given over to Newmarket, where there are numerous house parties for the second July meeting. During the following week the season winds up with the Duchess of Portland's ball.

Under the above heading Henry Romeike again protests against gas meters as being very unreliable, and, as usual, he is too severe and unreasonable. Gas companies are not inventors, so if they are to measure gas as they serve it to consumers they do all that ought to be expected of them when they furnish rent-free the best gas meter that call be bought.

In 1863 a man named Thomas Butcher, a laborer in the employment of a farmer at Mountfield in Sussex, was ploughing a field one fine day when his ploughshare threw up a long piece of metal like brass, with a trumpet at each end, and doubled up like a coil of string. There were several other similar pieces in the same furrow, the whole weighing altogether eleven pounds.

IT can no longer be gainsaid that German poets have friends among us. Schiller's familiar bust has graced the border of our Central Park Lake as long as the Ramble has existed. The Heine Fountain was unveiled but yesterday on the broad concourse of the Bronx, and in this number of THE TIMES a picture is presented of a monument to the greatest bard of them all, the "Altmeister " Johann Wolfgang Goethe.

It is likely that by noon to-day both the two yellow fever patients brought here on the United States transport McClellan from Santiago will be practically out of danger. Miss Clendenin, who had a mild case of the disease, will be put in the convalescent ward of the hospital on Swinburne Island to-day, unless some unexpected development disappoints the doctors.

SHELTER ISLAND, July 8. -- The fleet of the Atlantic Yacht Club laid at its anchorage in Seering's Harbor all day. There was a formidable sea running until noon, at which hour a heavy squall from the southeast, accompanied by a sharp rainstorm, and a thick bank of fog obscured the shore for more than half an hour.

PHILADELPHIA, July 8. -- The auxiliary cruiser Prairie left the League Island Navy Yard to-day with 106 Pennsylvania Naval Militia for an eight-day cruise on the ocean. The Pittsburg Division, thirty-three in number, arrived here this morning and proceeded to Queen Street wharf, where, with seventy-three from Philadelphia, they were taken to the Prairie, escorted by Capt. John L. Muckle, Gov. Stone's official representative.

MILWAUKEE, July 8. -- The sale of the Wisconsin Central properties at Eau Claire, Wis., yesterday was confirmed to-day by Judge Jenkins, in Chambers. The decree provides that the payment of the balance of the bid, amounting to $6,800,000, may be made either in cash or in first mortgage bonds of the Wisconsin Central Railway Company, which is the name of the new corporation which is to operate the road.

ALBANY, July 9. -- The criticism aimed at Gov. Roosevelt for signing the bill which allows State or city officials to apply to the courts for their expenses in defending themselves, if they are acquitted of charges, has caused this statement from an authoritative scource.

Justice Truax, in the Supreme Court, on Saturday, handed down a decision in the action for an injunction brought by the National Protective Association of Steamfitters and Helpers and Charles McQueed against the Enterprise Association and the Progress Association, both unincorporated societies of steamfitters and helpers, and their walking delegates, in which he enjoins the defendants from interfering with the members of the plaintiff association, and preventing them from procuring and retaining work.

PLATTSBURG, N.Y., July 9. -- The ninth annual session of the Catholic Summer School of America opened to-day in a heavy downpour of rain. At 3 P.M. a special train of eight coaches, containing 300 Summer school visitors from New York City and Central New York, arrived at Bluff Point, and a few minutes later they were at the Champlain Club House, on the school grounds, at Cliff Haven.

AUSTIN, Texas, July 9. -- Gov. Sayers spent the day at his office receiving reports from the numerous committees in charge of the work of rescuing and distributing food supplies to the flood refugees. The Governor received many contributions from Texas towns and from Eastern and Northern cities. Blair Co. of New York sent a draft for $500.

THE MILITARY STRENGTH OF THE TRANSVAAL AND PLANS FOR A POSSIBLE CAMPAIGN. -- There is much discussion just now in London over the military strength that the Transvaal Republic might be able to put into the field and the plan of attack or defense she has in view. Gen. Plet Joubert, who was second in command in 1889, is now Commanding General.

I was much interested in the discussion that recently appeared in your columns concerning a suitable substitute for the hybrid, barbarous, and wholly inappropriate expression automobile as a designation for self-moving vehicles. Some of the suggestions made by your correspondents are more fantastical and ingenious than correct.

WORCESTER, Mass., July 9. -- For the second time in the administration of Chief of Police Dreman the old blue laws relating to Sunday business were partially enforced to-day. The sale of cigars, tobacco, and confectionery was prohibited. All druggists, newsdealers, and restaurants lived up to the law in a general way and refused to sell except to well-known customers.

NEWPORT, July 9. -- James J. Van Alen gave his "good-bye dinner" at Gooseberry Island this evening to quite a number of his Newport friends, and leaves to-morrow for New York, and on Wednesday will sail for Europe for the season.

TACOMA, Washington, July 9. -- The party which recently went North to investigate the Alaska boundary question, including Senator Fairbanks of Indiana and Senator Addison G. Foster of this State, returned here to-day. Interviews with members of the party indicate that the watershed on White Pass, back of Skaguay and Dyea, will be accepted as the international boundary line at that point.
PARIS, July 9. -- Sir Edmund John Monson, British Ambassador to France, last evening entertained at dinner the members of the Venezuelan Arbitration Tribunal.

WASHINGTON, July 9. -- The funeral of Mrs. Marguerite Dickins, wife of Capt. Francis W. Dickins of the navy, who lost her life by an explosion of gasoline at her home Friday, took place from the residence this afternoon, the services being conducted according to the rites of the Episcopal Church.

LONDON, July 9. -- The question of the hour remains the strained relations between England and the Transvaal. In spite of the latter's concessions the English press comments are not favorable to President Kruger. To the unprejudiced mind the concessions should be considered as satisfactory, so, at least, says the Hon. W.P. Schreiner, the Premier of Cape Colony.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 9. -- Prominent citizens of Central America living here claim to have received dispatches indicating that Guatemala is on the verge of another serious revolution. President Cabreras's attempt to force $6,000,000 of paper money into circulation is the alleged cause of the whole difficulty.

Bernard J. O'Boy, thirty years old, was found dead yesterday morning in the room he occupied at 206 West Twenty-third Street, a boarding-house kept by Marcus J. Weaver. Two gas jets in the room were turned on and the gas was escaping freely.

Having lately given up business and removed from New York to the country, I have tried for some weeks to get along with the newspapers of the vicinity, but always with a feeling of dissatisfaction. Hence I enclose my subscription to the daily herewith.

ATLANTA, Ga., July 9. -- While hunting for some negroes who broke jail at Fairburn yesterday, citizens of Campbell County today shot and killed Abner Calhoun, an innocent negro The killing occurred in Campbell County, a short distance from Palmetto and Newnan, which was the scene of serious racial disturbances six months ago.
MANILA, July 10. -- It has been raining almost constantly for two days, and the country along the American south and bay lines is literally flooded. The soldiers are suffering great discomfort.

COLUMBIA, S.C., July 9. -- Many tragedies in this State have occurred recently, most of them of a peculiarly revolting character. Yesterday at Union, Sheriff Long, who has for many years been the Sheriff of the county, shot and killed Deputy Sheriff J.G. Galliam, who had been his lifelong friend.

ST. JOHN'S N.F., July 8 -- Following close upon the movement in Jamaica for annexation to the United States, a similar agitation has lately been taking shape in Newfoundland, the oldest colony of the British Crown. This feeling has been greatly accentuated by the neglect with which the colony has been treated over its two great grievances -- the French shore question and the Atlantic fisheries question.

The first half of the year has passed and the various manufacturers of textiles have summed up the business for that period. It has been an unusually successful season, and the results are far ahead of any corresponding time for many years. Cotton goods have in every case shown good business, and agents have no word of fault to find.

Harlem River oarsmen spent a busy day yesterday making final preparations for the Long Island Regatta, to be held Saturday, July 15, on the Flushing Bay course. At the boathouses the racing boats were being overhauled and rerigged to suit the crews, while on the water there were trial heats and scrub races, some of which proved very lively.

Two children met with similar accidents yesterday afternoon, by falling great distances, and each came out unharmed. Both accidents happened in the same district, within fifteen minutes of each other.

PATERSON, N.J., July 9. -- Right Fielder Woodruff of the Paterson Baseball Club was kicked in the head accidentally by Infielder Cockman while sliding for second base in to-day's game between Paterson and Ready. He was removed to St. Joseph's Hospital, where he remained unconscious for several hours. The doctors, however, think he will recover.

ROCHESTER, July 9. -- A fire occurred last night about 9 o'clock at the residence of Park Policeman William S. Goddard, in which Mrs. Goddard received terrible burns from the effects of which she died at 11:30 o'clock this morning at the Hahnemann Hospital, suffering almost twenty-four hours in the most frightful way, her body having been burned almost to a crisp.

There was a large attendance yesterday afternoon at the service in the Gospel Tent. S. Hartwell Pratt, who opened the services, read two letters that had been sent to him. Each one was signed "Anxious Mother" and begged the meeting to pray for the redemption of a son.

In golf circles during the past week the chief topic of conversation naturally has been the progress of the amateur championship tournament in Chicago. Local golfers have watched practically every stroke with the deepest interest, and while in some cases there have been disappointments that favored friends have dropped by the wayside, there has been a unanimity of opinion on the exhibition of golf.

Coney Island was in a waiting condition yesterday, so far as the excise law and the theatres were concerned. The police reported that the concert-hall proprietors were living up to the law, and the report seemed to be correct, so far as the Coney Island police understanding of the law goes. The concerts were supposed to be "sacred" in some places.

ANDERSON, Ind., July 9. -- For the first time since 1892 the Indiana gas belt industrial beehive is practically tied up by labor troubles. The strikers have reached the mob stage at one or two points. To add to the adverse conditions, the tin-plate workers' and manufacturers' wage committees have failed to reach an understanding and every plant closed indefinitely Friday night.

In concluding his address at the Independence Day banquet of the American Society in London. Cardinal VAUGHAN expressed the hope that the sentiments that animate the English and the American heart may "continue to be woven one with the other so that the missions of the English-speaking races may be carried on successfully in the new century, and that the century may see the completion in a great measure of our common mission."

In your comments on the article from The London Spectator in THE TIMES of July 5 you struck the nail on the head. The cause of England's successful management of her distant colonies is that officials are selected for their capacity and integrity to fill the position to which they are assigned, all of whom understand that they will continue to hold such positions or better ones so long as they desire to do so.

Attention having been called by the newspapers to the significance of the bill signed by Gov. Roosevelt on May 25 last to reimburse the legal expenses of public officials who have been successful in defending suits to oust them from office because of their official acts, or in defending themselves against indictments growing out of official actions, astonishment and indignation are expressed on every hand that such a measure could have become a law.

OCEAN GROVE, N.J., July 9. -- This was Home Missionary Day in Ocean Grove, the several meetings being in charge of the officers of the National Home Missionary Society of the Methodist Episcopal Church, and the deaconesses, who are connected with the society. Mrs. Clinton B. Fisk of New York City, the National President of the society, was present, as were a number of prominent missionary workers from all parts of the country.

The lgmperor of Germany has the "qualities of his defects." If he is at times arbitrary and willful beyond the limits of ordinary sovereigns, he defies the prejudices as well as the conventions of his class. His visit to the French training ship at Bergen and the cordial tone of comradeship in which he afterward addressed his message to President LOUBET is a case in point.

Under the auspices of the Epworth League societies of the Jane and Perry Street churches Police Sergeant Ezra D. Strope of the Mulberry Street Station was the principal speaker at the twilight meeting conducted from the band stand in Abingdon Square at 6:30 o'clock last evening. Sergeant Strope has lately been known as the evangelist of the Police Department, having conducted many religious meetings in connection with the Epworth League of the Jane Street Church.

The United States gunboat Annapolis, now being used as a practice ship by the senior class of Annapolis Naval Cadets, arrived yesterday from Philadelphia on a Summer cruise. The senior class, which will be graduated next June, is making a tour of inspection of the various navy and ship yards along the Atlantic seaboard. There are sixty-one cadets in the class, but only fifty-eight are on board the Annapolis.

President MCKINLEY could hardly have summoned an adviser, in the present state of things, likely to be more useful to him than Gov. ROOSEVELT, and this not only as to the specific question of officers of volunteers from New York, but as to his general policy.

BERLIN June 27. -- After holding nine and ninety sittings, the Reichstag has been prorogued until Nov. 14, and people are asking what the assembly has accomplished during its six months' session. Rarely has a legislature been so barren of positive results. The Army Increase bill, the budget, the Old Age Pensions Insurance bill, the provisional treaty with Great Britain, and the Carolines Purchase bill comprise the fruits of the Reichstag's labors.

The first annual excursion of the Societe Operaia di Montimurro, an Italian benevolent organization, took place yesterday at Cornwalton Grove, on Long Island Sound. According to one of the participants, whose story could not be verified last night, it resulted in a general riot, in which knives, baseball bats, beer bottles, blood, and hair were the leading features, and during which a score of persons were wounded.

OMAHA, July 9. -- F.M. Hans, the well-known Western detective, has returned to Omaha after a long chase after the six men who held up and dynamited the Union Pacific express train in Wyoming June 2. Hans fears the men have escaped for all time, at least as far as present efforts to capture them are concerned.

A man who was subsequently identified as E. Noroff of 336 West Fifty-ninth Street, committed suicide, shortly after 1 o'clock yesterday morning, by shooting himself, on the West Drive in Central Park, near Sixty-fourth Street. The body was discovered by Patrolman James Nash of the Park squad, who, a moment before, had heard the sound of two pistol shots coming from that direction.

We printed yesterday a very full statement of some of the practices of the unscrupulous pension attorneys and claim agents in Washington, as well as of some of the lax conduct in the Pension Bureau in the past due to their influence. The statement reveals clearly the real root of the worst evils that have grown up in connection with pension legislation and its administration.

The advocates of what is popularly called "the cause of women" cannot make much capital of the reception given by Queen Victoria at Windsor to a few prominent delegates to the International Congress of Women in London. Notwithstanding the "thrill" Miss Susan B. Anthony says she felt "when looking in her wonderful face," it is a well-known fact that the Queen does not look favorably on the woman's rights movement.

SOUTHAMPTON, July 9. -- Yachting circles in the Solent were never more excited than now over the prospects in the forthcoming race for the America's Cup between Shamrock and Columbia. Yesterday yachtsmen could be seen in all directions, and in Southampton, Hythe, Calshot, and Cowes the keenest look-out was kept for the challenger, which it was known would stretch her sails.

LONDON, July 9. -- At the conclusion of the centenary review and inspection of Metropolitan Volunteers on the Horse Guards' Parade yesterday afternoon, Capt. De Witt C. Falls and Capt. Francis G. Landon of the Seventh Regiment, N.G.N.Y., who witnessed the review on the invitation of Col. Sir Charles Edward Howard Vincent, commandant of the Queen's Westminster Volunteers, were banqueted at headquarters by this regiment, the band at intervals playing tlle American National airs.
Miss Louise Humphrey, a teacher in the public schools of Philadelphia, has resigned after fifty-three years of continuous service.

The race for the cricket championship of New York is proving this year a close and interesting contest. The first round has now been completed, and two clubs are still tied for the lead -- Team B of the Knickerbocker Athletic Club and the Manhattan Cricket Club. Neither team has yet sustained defeat.
Of the immediate market's course most depends upon what develops in interest rates. If money works toward stiff rates, those who are trying to force recessions may gain some temporary advantages.
POTSDAM, Prussia, July 10. -- Dr. Von Achenbach, the Governor of the Province of Brendenburg, is dead.

The new Surface Railroad Men's Union, affiliated with the Knights of Labor and composed of employes on the various lines of the Metropolitan Street Railway Company, has been called upon to show its strength. President Vreeland of the company yesterday defied its representatives who called upon him, and practically told them to go and do their worst.

The following changes are announced in the Canada, Atlantic and Plant Steamship Company, Limited, a branch of the Plant System: H.L. Chipman, who has been the agent of the company, at Halifax, has been made Superintendent of the line between Boston and Halifax, Oxbury and Charlottetown. The office of Superintendent is a new one.

LONDON, July 10. -- The Czar's brother, Grand Duke Michael of Russia, now heir apparent, is at present in London. He accompanied the Prince of Wales to the volunteer review on the Horse Guards' Parade Saturday.

SANTA BARBARA, Cal., July 10. -- Mrs. Ada Adis Sterke, who was to be sentenced in the Superior Court to-day for criminal libel, must now answer a charge of attempting to murder Attorney Grant Jackson. According to Attorney Jackson, Mrs. Sterke stealthly entered his bedroom some time during the night by cutting the screen from the window.

CHICAGO, July 10. -- After considering the matter four days the Presidents of all the big railroads between Chicago and the Atlantic seaboard have agreed that, on and after Aug. 1 Chicago shippers must pay from 3 to 5 cents more on each 100 pounds for the transportation of their grain to the Eastern markets.
At a meeting of the Board of Directors of the Southern Express Company, held at 12 West Twenty-third Street, yesterday, M.J. O'Brien was elected President to succeed the late Henry B. Plant.

BOSTON, July 10. -- The champions won two games from the New Yorks to-day, the first by brilliant fielding and the second through good batting by Tenney. The second game was exciting, as the visitors tied the score in the seventh, and it took two extra innings to decide the contest. Hamilton's two-bagger and a timely drive by Tenney settled matters. Attendance, 5,500.

The lease of the Boston and Albany Railroad by the New York Central and its alliance of interests with the Pennsylvania are subjects of considerable interest to students of the perplexing canal problem that awaits solution by the Government and people of the State of New York. Gov. ROOSEVELT has set a commission at work upon it, and information is being collected for his guidance in determining upon a canal policy.

NEWPORT, July 10. -- Capt. Woodbury of the Newport Yacht Racing Association returned from New York this morning to look after preparations for the races off this harbor for the trophies offered by the association, and for which event Messrs. Woodbury Kane and Ralph N. Ellis form the Regatta Committee.

ALBANY, July 10. -- There is a probability that Gov. Roosevelt will not immediately name a successor to the late David L. Follett, as Justice of the Supreme Court, Sixth District, because of the nearness to the nominating conventions.

PHILADELPHIA, July 10. -- The Press tomorrow will say: "The American Sugar Refining Company, more commonly known as the Sugar Trust, is about establishing one of the largest chemical plants in this country, the capital stock to be $1,500,000. The abandoned United States Refinery buildings, at Penn Street wharf, Camden, N.J., are to be fitted up for this purpose.

ALBANY, July 10. -- State Controller Morgan this afternoon forwarded to Gov. Roosevelt, at Oyster Bay, that part of the testimony taken in charitable institutions relating to the abuses of management, such as unsanitary methods of cleansing the inmates, solitary confinement, lashing to the floor, and strapping of inmates upon their bare bodies.

CHICAGO, July 10. -- The Genesee, the Rochester boat, won the second trial yacht race to-day by seventeen minutes, in the contest for selecting a challenger for the Canadian Cup. The Prairie came in second and Josephine third. The course was nine miles to windward and return.

POUGHKEEPSIE, July 10. -- The crusade recently started by the churchmen of this city to stop Sunday railroad excursions has broadened out into the infliction of summary vengeance on the proprietors of little shops of various sorts who have kept their doors open on Sunday to swell the scanty receipts of the week by the sale of a few more collar buttons or a shoestring or two.

WASHINGTON, July 10. -- The last Congress authorized the construction of a new bridge across the Mississippi at St. Louis, and provided that the plans should be prepared according to law by the United States Engineer Office, and be subject to the approval of the Secretary of War.

The suicide of the young woman known as Mrs. Julia Brooks, who cut her throat on Sunday morning at the Octagon Hotel, Seabright, is attributed by her friends to one of two causes -- either to nervous prostration resulting from a shock which she received several months ago, or to some secret trouble connected with her marriage.

The more we think of it, the more absurd it looks that such a body as the Municipal Assembly should have the direction and control of such a public function as the Dewey reception. The Mayor's committee is, upon the whole, an excellent committee, made up on the old familiar lines. But then there is a chance to do something new and striking in more than one direction.

DETROIT, July 10. -- The eighteenth international convention of Christian Endeavor societies closed to-night amid scenes of impressive solemnity attending the utterance of "The Last Word" by the President and Secretary in each of the great tents, respectively, followed by responses from each State and country represented, and last exhortations from Bishop Vincent of Kansas and Evangelist Chapman of New York.

The United States Local Inspectors of Steam Vessels made a report yesterday to George H. Starbuck, Supervising Inspector of the Second District of New York, concerning their investigation of the stranding of the American Liner Paris, which ran upon the rocks off the Cornish coast in the English Channel at 1 A.M. on May 21, while bound from Cherbourg to New York.

Controller Coler's plan for the conversion of Coney Island into a park was thoroughly discussed at a hearing held by the Board of Public Improvements in the Aldermanic Chamber in the City Hall yesterday afternoon. The plan of President Grout of the Borough of Brooklyn was also considered. Topographical maps of both plans hung on the walls in the room.

SANTIAGO DE CUBA, July 10. -- Gen. Leonard Wood, the Military Governor, returned this morning from the United States, and immediately began vigorous action to stamp out the yellow fever. He finds the situation more serious than he had anticipated.
Evidently the great exposition in Paris next year is bound to be successful if the efforts of the French and their friendly rivals can make it so.

DUBUQUE, Iowa, July 10. -- A proposition was made to-day by the Nutwood Driving Club to the owners of Frank Bogash, Joe Patchen, Directly, Searchlight, Star Pointer, Anaconda, and John R. Gentry, for a ace here Aug. 31 for $10,000. There is to be no entrance fee, but all are to enter to beat 2:03.

OFF RAM'S HEAD, Gardiner's Bay, L.I., July 10. -- The much-talked-of ocean race of the Atlantic Yacht Club from Shelter Island to Sea Gate, a distance of 138 miles, began this morning. The yachts which originally started out on the cruise had dropped out one by one, until at the beginning of the long race there were only four schooners and two sloops.

City officials, past and present, who have been in trouble either with municipal boards or the courts, apparently intend to take all possible advantage of the Ahearn law, which gives them, if successful in resisting proceedings to remove them from office or to convict them of crimes, the right to recover the expenses of their defense.

Walter Joshua McNeill, nine years old, who lives at 806 East One Hundred and Forty-eighth Street, has been missing from his home since Sunday morning at 10 o'clock. His father, Charles A. McNeill, a bartender at West Fifty-third Street and Seventh Avenue, is convinced that the lad has been kidnapped.

LONDON, July 10. -- Mr. Dillon, in Parliament, to-day asked the Right Hon. Joseph Chamberlain, Secretary of State for the Colonies, if any dispatches regarding the Transvaal from Sir William Butler, Commander in Chief in South Africa, had been withheld while Sir William Butler was acting for Sir Alfred Milner, British High Commissioner for South Africa. Mr. Chamberlain replied in the affirmative, but added that there was no objection to their publication.

Statement from Chicago that Atchison's earnings continue to show very satisfactory increases, notwithstanding the fact that comparison is made with the record-breaking earnings of this time last year.

In view of the right royal showing given to the Astor family in a recent article in The Pall Mall Magazine, the following little anecdote written for The New York Leader many years ago may prove interesting to you.

The Philadelphias easily outplayed the Brooklyns in the last game of their series at Washington Park yesterday. It was an off day for the Brooklyns, apparently, for they made seven errors. Jennings was the chief offender. His throwing arm still seems to be out of condition. Smith contributed a couple of wild throws, and as a whole the team could not bat. Piatt, the Philadelphia pitcher, had the home team guessing from the start.

The Metropolis Tunnel Railroad Company of New York and Brooklyn was incorporated yesterday at Albany with a capital stock of $50,000, and the privilege of increasing it to a sum sufficient to build the tunnel which the new company contemplates, which is intended to be five miles long. The company purposes to connect Brooklyn, Manhattan, and Jersey City through this enterprise.

SUMSIIT OF PIKE'S PEAK, Col., July 10. -- The Hon. William Jennings Bryan came up to-day from Colorado Springs. The entire ascent of the peak was one continued ovation, camps being decked out in the National colors, and scores of pleasure seekers from all over the country being lined up along the track to cheer the silver leader as tile train passed.

MOBILE, Ala., July 10. -- A combination has been formed by the Southern Railway, the Mobile and Ohio Railway, and the Mobile and Trans-Atlantic Steamship Company. (Horsley Brothers of Liverpool.) for facilitation of the export and import business via this port, the railroads agreeing to bring freight, and the steamship company to supply the vessels.

NEWMAN, Cal., July 10. -- A special train of nine coaches in charge of S.R. Drury of the Burlington Road, on its way from St. Louis to Los Angeles, and loaded with teachers bound for the National Educational Convention at Los Angeles, ran into a freight train near the station at this place early this morning with the result that two women were killed and eleven other passengers were injured, one most severely.

ROOSEVELT has just officially promulgated. It is quite true that the Governor himself is a New Yorker, meaning what FENIMORE COOPER used to call a "Manhattanese" as well as an inhabitant and Chief Magistrate of the Empire State.

WASHINGTON, July 10. -- "I hope the Republicans will come out flat-fooled for the gold standard," said Representative Livingston of Georgia to-day. "I understand that the new currency bill which the Republicans are preparing proposes to declare outright the gold dollar as the standard of value for this Government.

A fire which occurred last night in the infants pavilion of Bellevue Hospital might have resulted seriously but for the presence of mind and courage of the nurses and others. The building is a ramshackle one, and owing to its condition every precaution had been taken for such an emergency.

Reports from Boston that opposition to the proposed lease of the Boston and Albany Railroad to the New York Central was assuming shape among the stockholders of the Boston and Albany attract little attention from the New York Central people. Persons in authority at the Grand Central Station were disinclined yesterday to make any comment on the subject.
The cup defender Columbia lay at her moorings off New Rochelle yesterday, her crew busy overhauling her sails.

Politicians here attach much significance to the arrival at the Hoffman House of ex-Gov. William J. Stone of Missouri, who, in the absence of United States Senator J.K. Jones abroad, is practically at the head of the Democratic National Committee, which will meet in special session at Chicago next week.

John Garcia-Gonzales, four years old, has lived a year in a courtyard ten feet square, hidden and inclosed by the walls of surrounding buildings, between Twenty-fifth and Twenty-sixth Streets and Eighth and Ninth Avenues. He was kept and fed in this cage by his mother, who also kept a parrot; but the parrot is dead and its cage hangs empty.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- Mr. Herbert H.D. Pierce, First Secretary of the United States Embassy to Russia, has been in Washington several days on leave of absence from his post. It has afforded an opportunity for talks with the President and State Department officials on Russian affairs, both political and commercial, and the imparting of much interesting information which could not be brought by the channels of official reports.

HALIFAX, N.S., July 10. -- The steamer Portia, from New York for Halifax, was wrecked during a dense fog early this evening on Flinn's Island, off Sambro, a point about fifteen miles to the eastward of Halifax. The passengers and crew, 117 in all, landed on the island in the ship's boats, and all are comfortably housed there. No loss of life is reported.

NEWPORT, July 10. -- H.C. Scott and family of St. Louis have arrived at Jamestown for the season.

George Odom, the light-weight jockey who has taken the place of favorite with the race-going public held a year ago by the more or less notorious "Tod" Sloan, carried off the honors at the Brighton Beach track yesterday by winning three of the four races in which he had a mount and finishing second in the other.

Of all the evils which the opponents of expansion have pictured forth as the sure result of it the assumed necessity of incorporating the new possessions into the territory of the Union was undoubtedly the most serious. Ex-Senator EDMUNDS presented this objection with great force and all the weight of his authority as an expounder of the Constitution.

The Committee on Plan and Scope of the Dewey Reception Committee held an executive session yesterday in the City Hall, at which considerable progress was made toward arriving at definite plans for the reception. Both Gen. Daniel Butterfield, Chairman of the Executive Committee, and Gen. Howard Carroll, Chairman of the Committee on Shipping, Harbor Decorations, and Water Parade, presented tentative reports, neither of which were acted upon, although they were thoroughly discussed.

In the Declaration which this day commemorates our fathers based their claim to independence on the inalienable right of all men to liberty and the government of their choice. But for nearly a century our people violated in one direction the principles which they had proclaimed. For this they were called upon to pay the penalty through four long years of bloody struggle and anguish.

ST. LOUIS, July 10. -- Local proceedings will be instituted in the Federal Court at Chicago to prevent the operation of the Chicago Drainage Canal. The City of St. Louis will be the plaintiff, represented by City Counselor Schurnmacher.

July's second week opens with conditions similar to those which have prevailed since the fierce heats of June scattered the members of the social world who have not gone abroad to the various coast and inland resorts. Although Summer or watering place season should be now well under way, there is a dullness not usual at this period, and the Summer gayeties are still in the future.

BOSTON, July 11. -- Mr. Bayard Thayer today enlisted the aid of the Boston police in trying to find three rings alleged to have been stolen from Mrs. Thayer at the Holland House, New York, about two weeks ago.

WASHINGTON, July 11. -- A story about Gov. Roosevelt's visit to the President emanating from the War Department, but not verified at the White House, is being repeated here. Those who tell it evidently desire to find some reason other than a patriotic one to lead the Governor of New York to express his cordial approval of the policy of the President in dealing with the Philippine question.

LONDON, July 11. -- At the first day of the Newmarket second July meeting to-day Lord William Beresford's Perdicus, ridden by "Ted" Sloan, won a maiden plate. The Prince of Wales's bay colt Donizetti was second, and Mr. W.H. Walker's Ravager finished third. Sixteen horses ran five furlongs. The betting was 5 to 4 against Perdicus.

NEWPORT, July ll. -- Next week Alfred G. Vanderbilt, son of Mr. and Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt, accompanied by Messrs. Ernest Iselin, Douglass Cochrane, and William P. Burden, will start across the Continent for Vancouver, and from that point they will take passage on one of the English steamers for Japan, landing at Yokohama.

The officers of the Ordnance Department, United States Army, conducted three separate tests yesterday at the proving grounds at Sandy Hook. The tests consisted of the throwing of high explosives, the firing of a new high explosive, and the testing of a steel tower and range finder. All were accounted successful.

CONCORD, N.H., July 11. -- Representatives of the United States Civil Service Commission began a sitting here to-day for the purpose of investigating charges preferred against Senator Jacob H. Gallinger of Concord by ex-Gov. Charles A. Busiel of Laconia, a Republican, alleging violations of the civil service laws in the last campaign in this State.

That was certainly a very curious "proposition," as the department stores say, of a periodical devoted to the Anglo-American understanding, and to be devoted to the Anglo-American "understanding." Without doubt, Lady RANDOLPH SPENCER CHURCHILL, if such a periodical was to be edited by a woman, was one of three or four or five women who would have been picked out by the experienced as the possible editress, or editrix, of such a publication.

LONDON, July ll. -- The salvagers have moved the American Line steamer Paris astern for a distance of 150 yards, and have shifted the vessel's position slightly to the eastward. They hope to be able to get the after stokehold fires alight.

LONDON, July 11. -- Mr. Chamberlain and the question of the dum-dum bullet are very much to the fore, and the Radicals are doing their best to score off both. As Mr. Chamberlain has explained, he has shares in the Niger Company. The latter was bought by the Government, and all of his colleagues were aware of Mr. Chamberlain's ownership of shares in the company.

But to "stick" for weeks in a place which everybody concerned, including the man who put you in it, wants you to get out of, that is behavior which has nothing to do with your official capacity or incapacity.

Ever since the New York Clearing House adopted the rule of charging a small percentage upon the collection of out-of-town checks there has been more or less said and done about the combination of banking institutions in other cities to do a clearance business on their own account for the purpose of drawing off some of the capital from this city.
