In our financial cable dispatch of Monday mention was made of the very large total of clearings in the bankers' clearing house of London for the previous week. "They show an increase of 58,000,000," said our correspondent, "on last year's total for the same week, and at 253,412,000 represent the highest week's total ever known."

Brig. Gen. Harrison Gray Otis, United States Volunteers, talked freely with a TIMES reporter at the Hoffman House last night regarding the situation in the Philippines. Gen. Otis was in command of the First Brigade, Second Division, Eighth Army Corps, and his troops operated on the northerly line in Luzon, a short distance from Manila.

ST. PETERSBURG, July 11. -- Three months' Court mourning for the death of the Czarowitch, Grand Duke George of Russia, brother of the Czar, who died yesterday of consumption at Abbas Tuman, in the Caucasus, has been ordered.

WASHINGTON, July 11. -- The Navy Department to-day dispatched to Admiral Dewey the medal awarded to him by act of Congress to commemorate the battle of Manila Bay. The Admiral's medal is identical with those sent to each man in the fleet, with the exception that his name is engraved upon the edge.

BOSTON, July 11. -- Prof. Elihu Thomson of the General Electric Company. Lynn, admits the truth of the rumor that the company is experimenting in the manufacture of automobiles at the works in that city. Mr. Thomson said that it had not begun to manufacture, and that it was yet too early to predict anything in regard to it.

The obstructionists in the Council scored another victory yesterday by defeating action on three of the most important bond issues pending before that branch of the Municipal Assembly. These issues were that for the new Hall of Records, $2,100,000; that for repaying streets in all boroughs, $2,000,000, and that for the purchase of the plant of the Long Island Water Supply Company, $570,000.

Lovers of polo who went to the Rockaway Club field at Cedarhurst, L.I., yesterday afternoon were rewarded by witnessing a rattling good game. It was the second of the series of matches now being played for the Cedarhurst Challenge Cup, and the opposing teams were those of the Westchester Country Club and Devon, the latter being the fhampion polo four of Pennsylvania.

WASHINGTON, July 11. -- The War Department announced to-day that the customs receipts at the Port of Havana for June were $1,012,899. The total receipts for six months of 1899 are, to be exact, $5,146,830. The monthly average for six months is $857,805.

J. Edgar Leaycraft has sold for M.G. Pressinger to J. Woolworth the two three-story buildings 319 and 321 West Forty-second Street, 50 by 100.5; also, to J.K. Seagrist, the similar property adjoining, 317 West Forty-second Street, 25 by 100.5.

OMAHA, Neb., July 11. -- The commission and grain men of Omaha are considerably wrought up over the announcement of an advance of from 3 to 5 cents per 100 on grain between Chicago and Atlantic seaboard points. Grain men here assert that these rates will make grain shipments from this section almost impossible.

A fire which caused the death of a child and injury to twelve other persons started early yesterday morning in the five-story brick tenement at 101 Monroe Street. The dead child is Rachel Silver, six years old, who succumbed to her injuries at Gouverneur Hospital. Four of the other victims are in a serious condition, but no further deaths are expected.

The destitution of a once wealthy man, the affluence of a wife once poor, and the patient pursuit of old creditors were the elements of the story developed yesterday by the examination in bankruptcy proceedings of Albert Crosby, formerly owner of Crosby's Opera House, in Chicago, now the occupant of one of the show places of the Cape Cod country.

LOS ANGELES, Cal., July 11. -- At 3 o'clock this afternoon the Hon. F.Q. Storey, Chairman of tile local Executive Committee, called to order the opening session of the convention of the National Educational Association. The pavilion where the convention assembled seats 5,000, but the audience numbered far in excess of that figure.

WEST POINT, July 11. -- A disease showing strong symptoms of scarlet fever, has broken out here. Several of the cadets who have been attacked by the malady are quarantined in the barracks. All the physicians of the post are in attendance on the patients, and every possible precaution is being taken to prevent the spread of the disease.

LONDON, July 11. -- The Eccentric Club gave a dinner this evening to the members of the Lambs Club of New York City and other visitors. Mr. Lionel Brough presided, flanked by Mr. Joseph H. Choate, the United States Ambassador, and Mr. De Wolf Hopper, the American comedian.

I have just read in THE TIMES Capt. Watkins's explanation of the loss of the steamship Paris. There appeared in the June number of Harper's Monthly Magazine an article written by me on "Needful Precautions for Safe Navigation," in which I sought to arrest attention to the imminent risk inseparable from the present system, in which one man, one mind, devises and controls a vessel's course along coast lines, practically unaided and unchecked.

WASHINGTON, July 11. -- The Pension Committee of the Grand Army of the Republic arrived here to-day to begin its inquiry into the workings of the Pension Bureau. The committee consists of R.P. Brown of Ohio, Chairman; Gen. John Palmer of New York, J.W. Burst of Illinois, Col. Halbert B. Case of Tennessee, W.H. Adams of Massachusetts, and Commander in Chief W.H Johnson.

CHICAGO, July 11. -- Manufacturers of drill and seeder implements met in secret session at the Auditorium Hotel to-day and decided to make an advance of 15 per cent. on the present price of seeders and drills. This action was taken on account of the large advance that has been made in iron and steel.

CHICAGO, July 11. -- Frederick Starr, head Professor of Anthropology at the University of Chicago, returned to-day from a tour through England, where he went to present the Folk-Lore Society with a collection of Aztec and Mexican Indian curiosities.

WASHINGTON, July 11. -- The White House is fairly overrun with applicants for commissions in the volunteer army. To-day Representative Joy of Missouri, accompanied by a delegation from that State, saw the President, and presented a list of applicants for commissions. Three appointments were made yesterday from Missouri, and five more will make up the State's quota.

FALMOUTH, England, July 12. -- The coast guard reports that as the Paris began to move and to tug at her anchors this morning, the crew was obliged to let out cable, and in about an hour the liner got quite clear of the rock and into deep water.

After a weak opening, attended by continuing tight money conditions, yesterday's stock market braced up resolutely and most of the recent declines were recovered. Liquidation by actual holders of stock seemed to end in such weakness as showed on Monday. Ninety per cent. of recent sales have been for short account -- a fact to which the commission brokers of the Street are able to testify conclusively.

Important action on the equipment of the Manhattan system with electric motive power was taken yesterday at the weekly meeting of the Manhattan Railway Company. There were present President George J. Gould, Vice President Alfred Skitt, Russell Sage, Marcellus Hartley, Edwin Gould, and Samuel Sloan.

FISHKILL LANDING, N.Y., July 11. -- The same feeling which for twenty-five years has prevented the consolidation of the twin villages of Fishkill Landing and Matteawan showed itself in the vote upon the question taken to-day, and the proposition was defeated. It was the same stumbling block, the question of a name.

WASHINGTON, July 11. -- The Secretary of State has sent Ambassador Cambon of France an answer to the latter's recent letter submitting the claim of Miss Ivan Favre for $10,000 damages, attending the capture of the French steamer Olinde Rodriguez, on which she was a passenger, by the cruiser New Orleans during the blockade of San Juan.

LEXINGTON, Ky., July 11. -- The new Democratic State Central Committee held its first meeting to-day with A.W. Young, whom ex-Congressman W.C. Owens charges with having been a feud leader, as Chairman. Congressman Berry appeared before the committee with a proposition to vote on members of county committees next Fall, but his suggestion was ignored.

The John F. Baudouine bankruptcy proceedings were continued yesterday before Theodor Aub, referee in bankruptcy. As at most previous hearings, John F. Baudouine, who admits receiving an income of $2,000 or more a month, and that he could pay his debts with it if he wished, was the sole witness.

WASHINGTON, July 11. -- A report was circulated in the War Department to-day to the effect that the President is about to dispose of the long-deferred Carter case by pardoning Carter or sending him to prison. At the Judge Advocate General's office nothing was known of the origin of the report, the case having been out of the hands of that office for many months.

SOUTHAMPTON July 11. -- It is reported the cup challenger Shamrock is leaking. She has been docked for the purpose of repairing a plate which was disturbed when she grounded on her arrival at Southampton from London, June 28.

The Pittsburgs made their first appearance of the season at the Polo Grounds yesterday and were downed in a longdrawn-out but not uninteresting game. They secured what appeared to be a winning lead in the first two innings. In the third inning, however, the locals got a line on Tannehill's curves and it was practically all over with the Pittsburgs after that.

SAN FRANCISCO, July ll. -- Mail advices from Guatemala confirm the reports of an approaching crisis in the Central American Republic. That the dissatisfaction will lead to a revolution against the administration of President Cabrera seems hardly likely in view of the fact that there is no money in the country to organize anything approaching a formidable insurrection.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, July 4. -- It is now announced that the real object of the Government in sending the reciprocity delegates to Ottawa, after completing the negotiations at Washington, is to endeavor to secure the imposition by the Dominion Government of countervailing duties on European beet sugar.

HALIFAX, July 11. -- The steamer Portia, which struck on Big Fish Shoal, fifteen miles east of Halifax, last night, filled and sank during the night. The only victim of the wreck was a twelve-year-old Assyrian lad, known by the name of Basha, who was traveling second class from New York to St. John's, N.F., where his mother lives.

Dr. Southworth, her son, corrects this statement. In justice to the reputation of Dr. Gamaliel Bailey, the publisher of The Era, he says:

Gov. Roosevelt and United States Senator Platt had a conference yesterday afternoon at the office of the latter. The conference was by appointment, Gov. Roosevelt, it is understood, having come to the city at the invitation of the Senator; and the matters which were discussed were of sufficient importance to prolong the conference between two and three hours.

AUSTIN, Texas, July 11. -- No less than 20,000 hungry men, women, and children in the flooded districts of Texas were fed by the bountiful hand of charity to-day. It is probable that there were a few thousand sufferers in the remote districts of the blighted region who did not receive their quota of food, but this was through no fault of the many committees who have active charge of the relief and distributing work.

BABYLON, L.I., July 12. -- This village is considerably worked up just now over acts which indicate that within its boundaries is to be located a great cemetery for New York City. The Board of Supervisors of Suffolk County has passed a resolution giving its official consent to the use of some 1,400 acres of land for burial purposes.

The Pittsburg baseball team was again defeated by the New Yorks at the Polo Grounds yesterday afternoon, the visitors being clearly outplayed. Unlike Monday's game there was very little batting, and it was more of a pitcher's battle with some fielding of the sensational order.

Polo of the most interesting type took place yesterday on the Rockaway field at Cedarhurst, L.I., between the Rockaway and Meadow Brook Club teams. The latter won after four periods of as dashing and lively polo as is ever seen, by 1/4 of a goal. The score board recorded 8 3/4 goals for Meadow Brook to 8 1/2 for Rockaway.
TRINIDAD, Col., July 12. -- South-bound passenger train No. 1, on the Colorado and Southern Railway, was robbed by four men at a point five miles south of Folsom, N.M.

Justice Stover granted an order in the Supreme Court yesterday, on the application of Assistant Corporation Counsel Connoly in the matter of the claim of Police Captain John T. Stephenson against the city, to show cause why the Ahearn act should not be declared unconstitutional. The order is returnable Monday. It involves more than a million dollars of claims against the city.

Some interesting features of the plans of the Third Avenue Railroad Company were learned yesterday. One of these was that the company is finding it possible to reach amicable understandings with the Metropolitan Street Railway Company in that section of the city where the two lines compete for traffic on the same thoroughfares.

PITTSBURG, July 12. -- The pig iron production for the month of June was the largest in the history of the United States. The American Manufacturer has compiled figures showing that the increased weekly capacity for the week ending July 1 was 1,689 tons, as against the capacity for the week ending June 1, the month previous.

MANILA, July 12. -- A copy of the Independencia has reached Manila containing a report of the speech which Aguinaldo made at the recent celebration at Tarlac of the anniversary of the proclamation of Filipino independence. It is in substance as follows:

" George Odom has a very large pain in his very small stomach." That was the first and most important news that welcomed racegoers at the Brighton Beach track yesterday. It set owners and trainers whose horses he was engaged to ride to hustling for other light-weight jockeys who could take his place.

A wheeling party of eight young women from Brooklyn, which started yesterday Morning at the St. George Ferry landing, Staten Island, ended a short time afterward in disaster at the foot of York Avennue Hill, New Brighton, three of the riders receiving severe falls and injuries, and narrowly escaping with their lives.

CONSTANTINOPLE, July 12. -- The United States Minister to Turkey, Oscar S. Straus, has sent an urgent invitation to Admiral Dewey to visit here. In the event of his acceptance the British special service steamer Imogene will proceed to the Mediterranean to escort the Admiral to this port.

The man who will in all probability succeed Marion Butler as United States Senator from North Carolina is at the Hoffman House. He is Major Gen. Julian S. Carr of Durham, and, to use his own words, is an "anti-trust, free-silver, bare-footed, and bare-headed Democrat." For a long time he was President of the Blackwell Durham Tobacco Company, but when that corporation was absorbed by the Trust against his wishes he retired from business.

WASHINGTON, July 12. -- Secretary Long said this afternoon that he was not in possession of any new information touching the removal of the naval war college from Newport, which a Newport dispatch this morning reported Assistant Secretary Alien to be considering during his stay at Newport.

It might be interesting to those who write in opposition to our actions in the Philippines to know how one of their common every-day fellow-citizens looks at the question. They quote our struggles during the Revolution as resembling those of the Filipinos at present. The struggle is about the same, but how about the people engaged?

RICHMOND, Va., July 12. -- Gov. J. Hogg Tyler to-night makes a formal announcement of his candidacy for the Senate, in opposition to Thomas S. Martin. The Governor has been expected for a week or more to make this announcement. He, however, did not do so until he had thoroughly informed himself of the temper of the Democrats of the State, and especially those of the country districts.

The tight-money bugaboo was not in Wall Street's view yesterday, and in consequence the whole stock market was in good form. Quotations generally advanced. Not only was there disclosure of orders from interests accumulating large lines of investment stocks, but there was evidence that speculators on the short side were covering.

WASHINGTON, July 12. -- The commission which has in charge the selection of a design for the Washington Public Library Building, which will be erected with funds given by Andrew Carnegie, to-day opened the plans submitted by the competing architects. Twenty-four competitive designs have been received.

SANTIAGO DE CUBA, July 12. -- Gen. Leonard Wood, in command of the Department of Santiago de Cuba, issued General Order No. 34 to-day, establishing absolute quarantine. All officers of the Government and employes are forbidden to enter the city, with the exception of those belonging to the department. Major Carr and Surgeons Mendoza and Nunez are detailed to take charge of the fever patients in the city, which is placed under strict regulations.

CHICAGO, July 12. -- Herbert Low of Brooklyn and Genevieve, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James M. Hubbard, were united in marriage at 10:30 o'clock this morning at the home of the bride's parents, 39 Thirty-third Street. The wedding was set for this evening, and a number of invitations had been issued, but illness in the family of the bride prevented the possibility of a church wedding.

Dispatches from London tell every day of the vigor of England's preparation to meet a possible grave emergency in the Transvaal. Thirty machine guns were shipped on Tuesday, and the Seventy-third Battery of Artillery got its orders to take ship, making the fifth battery of artillery under orders for the Cape.

Justice Beckman of the Supreme Court, prompted by the number of suits for divorce which are brought where the defendants make no answer, has prepared a measure which is to be presented to the next Legislature, and which, in the opinion of lawyers and jurists alike, will prevent to a very great degree any collusion between the parties to the suit.

" Fair to-night and Thursday," was the confident prediction of the local Weather Bureau yesterday afternoon. Thereupon the original clerk of the weather, as night approached, played a joke upon the terrestrial prophet, and belied his prognostication by turning the celestial water faucets on full and letting down a deluge of such volume and violence as to render old Father Knickerbocker dizzy.

WOOD'S HOLL, Mass., July 12. -- The Maine Steamship Company's steamer Horatio Hal, bound from New York for Portland, Me., with freight and passengers, ran upon Middle Ground Shoal in Vineyard Sound during a thick fog early this morning. As soon as it was seen that the steamer was fast the tug Gypsum King went to her assistance, and the steamer was floated at 8:30 o'clock and proceeded toward her destination.

ALBANY, July 12. -- It was shown at today's meeting of the State Board of Charities that the inspection of the almshouses throughout the State had revealed a lack of proper fire protection in the line of fire escapes and apparatus for those institutions.

I was very much surprised to read the letter in your Sunday issue of July 9 of the Rev. W.A. Wasson, rector of St. George's Church, Brooklyn, on the removal of the negro. He said the negro never ought to have been brought here and ought not to remain. I hold he has a better right here than the foreign element which came without being brought, through mercenary motives.

The Brooklyn Rapid Transit Company is said to be again negotiating for the purchase of the Coney Island and Brooklyn Railroad, the only trolley system in Brooklyn not in the control of the Transit Company. The Coney Island and Brooklyn Company operates the Smith Street and De Kalb and Franklin Avenue lines. The Smith Street line is now the only independent road running to Coney Island.

The President's appointments to the enlarged army have been so evidently actuated by good motives and have been so freely praised by us that we may perhaps properly take note of the promotion of Col. BATES, over the head of his senior, to be Paymaster General of the Army.

Hall of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad Company, touching reports to the effect that the New Haven Company may be absorbed by the New York Central. Judge Hall is quoted as characterizing such rumors as "bosh" and "utterly unfounded on fact." Continuing he said:
LONDON, July 12. -- Transvaal matters are still in an unsettled condition, and much surprise has been manifested at the Government's apparent indecision in Radical circles.

PRINCETON, N.J., July 12. -- Moses Taylor Pyne, one of Princeton's most widely known millionaires, a Trustee of the University and one of its greatest supporters and benefactors, met with a painful accident this afternoon. He was kicked several times by a spirited horse at his stables on Mercer Street.

I was particularly interested, because I, too, ran with No. 5, not as a fireman, but as a boy.

FALMOUTH, England, July 13. -- The American liner Paris entered the harbor safely shortly after midnight.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., July 12. -- The most severe electrical storm of the season passed over this city to-day. William and Joseph Shirley of Perth Amboy, N.J., were struck by lightning while sitting under a tree, and the former was instantly killed. The latter was badly burned, and his recovery is doubtful.

Followers of the races who live in Yonkers, Mount Vernon, and other towns near Tuckahoe, N.Y., were obliged to find another place to put down their wagers on yesterday's races at Brighton Beach than the poolroom that has been running for some time in Tuckahoe. The room was not open yesterday, for William V. Molloy, the Sheriff of Westchester County, has determined to crowd the poolrooms out of Westchester County.

The Republican Club gave a reception and dinner last night to its President, Senator Chauncey M. Depew. About 150 members were present. The notice sent out by the House Committee warned the diners not to wear dress suits, but two members appeared in evening dress and caused some merriment at their own expense.
LONDON, July 12. -- Capt. Watkins of the American liner Paris is still with his vessel, and looks as if though shrunk to half his size.

NEWBURG, N. Y., July 12. -- After having been stabbed in the head with a pitchfork in the hands of Louis Teneych, a German brick-yard laborer named Henry Intz leaped on the back of a horse, and, with blood streaming down his face, rode rapidly to the police station at Fishkill, a distance of two miles, where he collapsed.

SOUTHAMPTON, July 12. -- The members of the athletic teams of Yale and Harvard Universities arrived by the American liner St. Louis this evening. They are all in excellent health.

PITTSBURG, July 12. -- The asphalt companies that have been competing and cutting prices have come together in "The Asphalt Company of America," with a capital of $4,000,000. The price under the competitive system was reduced from $3.50 to $1.45 per square yard, and paving will soon be again quoted at $3 per yard.

HELENA, Mont., July 12. -- Robert Bruce Wallace of Helena, who was appointed by the President Colonel of the Thirty-seventh Regiment, is a native of New York, and was appointed to West Point from Montana in 1886, being graduated with honors in 1890. He chose the cavalry branch of the service, and was immediately assigned to the Second Cavalry, then stationed in the far Southwest.
WASHINGTON, July 12. -- The President to-day appointed Col. Alfred E. Bates, Paymaster General of the Army, to succeed Gen. Asa B. Carey, retired.

We made no attempt to refute our correspondent's assertions, as we felt sure he took great pleasure in the belief that THE TIMES and the President are a bad lot.

A red cow of meek aspect was being led along Richmond Terrace in New Brighton. Staten Island, Tuesday night, when she became excited and tried to butt a trolley car off the track. At the foot of Franklin Avenue she and her custodian met the car, which was bound for Elizabethport ferry, and which was crowded with passengers who had been at South Beach.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 12. -- The United States transports Newport and Ohio, bearing the Oregon Volunteer Regiment from Manila, arrived here to-night.

ROSELLE, N.J., July 12. -- Silvestro Vincenzio caused the arrest of Stephen Malquand last week, charging him with stealing $80 from him, Justice Woodruff committed Malquand to the County Jail to await the action of the Grand Jury. On Monday Vincenzio happened to pass the spot where he and Malquand met and where he claimed the money was stolen, and there, in the grass, he found his missing money.

NEWBURG, N.Y., July 12. -- The meeting of the State Council of the Catholic Benevolent Legion ended this evening.

LEXINGTON, Ky., July 12. -- The Republican State Convention to-day completed all its work except the adoption of a platform and the nomination of a ticket. It would have nominated part of the ticket to-night but for the fact that it became entangled in misunderstandings regarding the adoption of the report on rules.

The details of the coming trip around the world to be taken by Alfred Vanderbilt, Douglass Cochran, William P. Burden, and Adrian Iselin, Jr. which were received from Newport yesterday, recall the fact that when the announcement of this trip was first exclusively published in this column last January, the same newspaper which now gives the story such prominence, vigorously denied its truth.

WASHINGTON, July 12. -- Almost complete returns to the Bureau of Immigration of the Treasury Department of immigrants arriving in the United States for the fiscal year ended June 30, 1899, show an increase of 82,579 over the fiscal year ended June 30, 1898. The returns yet to be received will not change the figures materially.

WASHINGTON, July 12. -- An order has been issued by the President extending the privileges and protection of the American flag to the shipping of Puerto Rico and the Philippines. All ships owned by residents of these islands at the time of tile exchange of them ratification of treaties are included in the order.

District Attorney Gardiner has decided to fight the Elevated Railroad Company relative to the turnstile system which is gradually being put in use at statitons where traffic is not heavy. Mr. Gardiner had occasion to use the Franklin Street station of the elevated railway the other night, in company with Assistant District Attorney Osborne.

NIAGARA-ON-THE-LAKE, Ontario, July 12. -- The Canadian championship lawn tennis tournament was continued here to-day on the courts of the Queen's Royal Hotel. The weeding-out process was kept up all day, and before the sun had set a great many of the weaker brothers had fallen by the wayside.

HELENA, Mont., July 12. -- The Supreme Court this afternoon passed upon the demurrer to the accusations in the Welcome disbarment suit, in which Fred Whiteside seeks to have the title lawyer disbarred for alleged bribery of members of the last Legislature in connection with the Senatorial fight.
HAVANA, July 12. -- Gov. Gen. Brooke has signed the decree doing away entirely with the incommunicado system.

DUBOIS, Penn., July 12. -- The strike of the soft coal miners of this district was finally settled this afternoon. All the mines in this region will resume at once. The delegates were on session here two days with General Manager Robinson before a final agreement was reached.
NEW ORLEANS, July 12. -- The Picayune prints the following:
Out of one of the ambulances that rolled up to Bellevue Hospital last night, the attendants carried a little old woman. She was thin and white.
HALIFAX, July 12. -- The body of the Assyrian lad, Basha, the only victim of the steamer Portia disaster Monday night, was found by divers to-day in the second cabin of the Portia.

GOODLANDS, I.T., July 13. -- William Goings, "Walla Tonka," the Choctaw Indian, was shot at Alikichi, I.T., to-day, under sentence of the Choctaw Court for murder. Feeling among the Choctaws was aroused by a report that an attempt would be made to stop the execution by another writ of habeas corpus.

-- Thanks to the manly frankness with which Capt. WATKINS has revealed exactly how the Paris came to be wrecked, the lesson of the disaster stands out simple and clear, and, fortunately, attention will not be distracted from it, as in previous cases of the same kind, by the memory of tragical scenes involving loss of human life and displays of heroism or its converse by passengers and crew.

BRISTOL, July 13. -- The Defender, now lying in the harbor, had a new topmast sent aloft this morning. The spar that has been in use on her ever since she went into commission this season was sent down yesterday and laid upon the deck. The new spar is the one that has been lying on the wharf for a week or more.

The formation of the British Oil and Cake Mills. Limited, a British corporation with a capital of 2,250,000, was announced in this city yesterday. The securities of the company will consist of 750,000 in 4 per cent. first mortgage bonds, 750,000 in 51/2 per cent. cumulative stock, and 750,000 of common stock.

WASHINGTON, July 13. -- In spite of the efforts of a number of Grand Army politicians and pension attorneys to induce the Pension Committee to insist upon Commissioner Evans's removal, it is not likely that he has anything to fear from its report. The committee concluded its work today, and most of the members left for home.

Up to the seventh inning at Washington Park yesterday it looked as if the Brooklyns would beat the St. Louis team in another game. In this inning the visitors bunched four hits, which, aided by two bases on balls and two errors, gave them six runs and a lead which the Brooklyns could not overcome in the face of Powell's splendid pitching.

CONCORD, N.H., July 13. -- The Civil Service Commission investigation into the charges against Senator Gallinger is over so far as the City of Concord is concerned. The final act in the drama, on the local stage, was played this afternoon by Commissioner Mark S Brewer, who gave a monologue to the members of the press who had reported the proceedings of the investigation.

BRIDGETON, N.J., July 13. -- The striking glassblowers here engaged in a riot this morning when the managers of the works tried to fill their places by importing non-union workers. About 6 o'clock this morning a special train arrived with sixteen non-union glassworkers from Indiana. They were accompanied by three detectives and Manager King of the Cumberland Glass Company.
LONDON, July 13. -- The Marchioness of Salisbury has suffered a second stroke of paralysis. Her condition is said to be improving, but her age and weight are unfortunate factors.

A.E. E.A. Karelsen have sold for Richard H. Clark, Jr., to Morris Neiman, for $100,000, the five-story factory building at the northwest corner of One Hundred and Twenty-fourth Street and Columbus Avenue, now occupied as a knitting mill by the firm of M. Neiman's Sons. The buyer gives in part payment the five-story flat.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., July 13. -- Francis Hager, a farmer of Mount Hebron, near this place, thinks he has a gold mine on his farm, and has dreams of riches. He was taking out dirt from his well to-day and noticed there was a sparkle in the mud. He caused some of the mud to be washed and true gold is said to have been found.

WASHINGTON, July 13. -- It is altogether probable that the next annual report of the Internal Revenue Bureau will recommend a number of changes in the War Revenue act. In the main, the law has worked satisfactorily and has produced almost exactly the amount estimated by the Commissioner. This, however, was something leas than the estmates generally accepted by well-informed members of Congress.

WASHINGTON, July 13. -- The monthly statement of the imports and exports of the United States shows that during June the imports of merchandise into the United States amounted to $61,686,208, of which $25,881,331 was free of duty. For the year the total imports of merchandise amounted to $697,077,388, of which over $300,000,000 was free of duty.

ATLANTA, July 13. -- A dispatch from Jackson, Miss., says: "Gov. McLaurin has attained such a lead in the country primaries that his election as United States Senator is practically certain. He has 72 votes in the primaries thus far held, and only 90 are required to elect.

In no case is it shown that concentration of control diminishes the number of shareholders in great business enterprises.

At a meeting yesterday of the American China Development Company Frederick W. Whitridge was elected a member of the Executive Committee, to fill the vacancy created by the death of Calvin S. Brice. The committee now consists of Frederic P. Olcott, President of the Central Trust Company; Richard J. Cross, and Mr. Whitridge.

NIAGARA-ON-THE-LAKE, Ontario, July 13. -- As the struggle in the Canadian championship at lawn tennis nears the crucial stage the interest increases, and to-morrow's matches promise to arouse the greatest excitement of the meeting.

CANTON, Ohio, July 13. -- Canton Germans are out in a set of resolutions expressing themselves opposed to the policy of the Government in prosecuting the Philippine war. To-day a translation of a resolution adopted at a mass meeting of the German organizations of the convention Wednesday was forwarded to the President.

The New Yorks lost a chance to win their third straight game from the Pittsburgs at the Polo Grounds yesterday because of the worst kind of fielding. The Pittsburgs made fifteen hits off Seymour, but this would not have been enough to win had there been clean fielding. Seymour, besides being hit hard, was the chief offender in the way of making the victory easy for the visitors.

WHITE PLAINS, July 13. -- A suit has been decided by Supreme Court Justice Michael H. Hirschberg involving the liability of the City of New York for debt due or contracted at the time of the annexation of Westchester County territory to the city. The case was that of Miss Victoria E. Bell of Wakefield, town of East Chester.

The "week end," as the English term the Saturday to Monday holiday, will see New York more deserted this week than at any time except over July 4 since the close of the Winter season. It is drawing near to August, that month most loved by Summer hotel proprietors, bank clerks, and devotees of yachting and outdoor sports, and most loathed by city hotel keepers and club stewards and House Committees.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., July 13. -- The Horse Show opened to-day at Inlet Park under favorable circumstances. Fourteen classes were shown, embracing harness horses, ponies, saddle horses, and hunters, together with fire engines and delivery wagons.

PITTSBURG, Penn., July 13. -- J.C. Morsow, ex-President of the Western Pennsylvania Firemen's Association, a Democrat, and others of the Entertainment Committee, recently engaged W.J. Bryan of Nebraska to make a speech at the tournament to be held in Scottdale, Aug. 8, for $250.

Controller COLER will do well not to be discouraged by the set-back received for his plan of a public park at Coney Island. He is more likely to see a still more adequate plan carried out than to see this one finally rejected. Most of the objections made to it are of little weight and will tend to disappear under the pressure of public demand as time passes.

DETROIT, Mich., July 13. -- It was reported in Pingree circles this morning that the Governor, as soon as the Council finally adopts the municipal railway ordinances, will bend his energies to securing a special session of the Legislature for the purpose of providing for the submission of a Constitutional amendment to the people permitting the City of Detroit to go into the municipal ownership of street railways.

Form players at the Brighton Beach races were all at sea yesterday because there was a track that was both heavy and holding. It was, with the exception of one day at the Morris Park track, the only one this year on which horses have been asked to race in the mud since the beginning of the metropolitan racing season.

PLATTSBURG, N.Y., July 13. -- It is reported on good authority that the American Steel and Wire Company has purchased the iron mines and mining property of Witherbee. Sherman Co., at Port Henry, Essex County. The price paid is said to have been $1,500,000.

ELIZABETH, N.J., July 13. -- A railroad accident which might have cost many lives was narrowly averted this morning at Elizabethport by the prompt action of the tower operator at that point. The junction of the Newark Branch of the Central Railroad of New Jersey and the main line at that place has long been considered a very dangerous crossing.

BERLIN, July 13. -- The newspapers continue to discuss Emperor William's message on the unveiling at Bielefeld last Tuesday of the tablet commemorating his speech in 1897 promising protection to National labor, in the course of which he expressed his intention of presenting to the city a cast of a statue of the Great Elector.

Wall Street's frabricators were up and doing yesterday. They provided strikes for all the local street railways, had grave foreign complications, both political and financial; were informed of the impending collapse of a big new industrial corporation -- and, incidentally, were mysterious about a long list of other things which will be discouraging, as soon as they come true.

ROSLYN, L.I., July 13. -- The stables and barns of William C. Whitney's country home, Wheatley, at Westbury, were destroyed by fire to-night. The stables, which were on a palatial scale, were only about 150 feet from the residence itself, but the latter was not injured in any way.

The chief public importance of the resolution of the Board of Trustees of the New York Life Insurance Company to dispose of the company's holdings of stocks and to confine its investments in future to bonds and mortgage securities lay in the fact that it was liable to be gravely misunderstood.

A meeting was held at the Waldorf-Astoria last night to consider the preparation of a bill, to be presented to the next session of the Legislature to regulate the practice of the mental healers and Christian Scientists. The attendance of the opposition was so large and its conduct was so aggressive that it may be said that the meeting was practically captured by mental healers.

President Clinton L. Rossiter of the Brooklyn Rapid Transit Company yesterday characterized the reports of a threatened trolley strike in Brooklyn as stock-jobbing talk. Mr. Rossiter declared positively that there was no probability of a strike. He enjoys the confidence of the men, he asserted, and was satisfied that they were contented with their lot.

There is now every reason to believe that the mutilated and dismembered body of a man that was found floating opposite the house of the Crescent Athletic Club at Bay Ridge on June 12 was that of Frederick Lunberg, who resided at 404 East Fifty-fourth Street, this borough, a flathouse of which his wife, Charlotte Luneberg, is janitress.

The cabled story that the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company of Pittsburg, Penn., will build works at Manchester, England, and employ 5,000 men, and that Georg Westinghouse will direct the enterprise, was not corroborated yesterday at the Westinghouse offices in the Equitable Building.

Mrs. Louise Hitchcock Davis, at 11:01 o'clock yesterday morning, started from the Herald Building for a trip to San Francisco in an automobile. The trip will be the longest, if completed, ever made by an automobile. The automobile is equipped with a gasoline motor. Many other automobiles surrounded the one that was to make the long journey.

Everett P. Wheeler, who recently wrote Secretary of the Treasury Gage a public letter on the subject of the President's order exempting certain positions from the competitive list under the civil service law, spoke emphatically yesterday on both the Federal and municipal civil service situations.

The construction of the new electric road between Brooklyn and Rockaway Beach by the New Jersey Construction Company has been begun. Piles for the trestle work at Goose Creek are being driven. The new i road will be built by a syndicate headed by Patrick Flynn of Brooklyn, and wlll cost$1.000.000.

Carl Carlsen, the veteran watchman of the Columbia Yacht Club, was reported drowned on Wednesday night, but turned up alive, dry, and well, to the joy of the club and the disgust of two undertakers who were seeking the job of burying him.

CHICAGO, July 13. -- Play in the Western championship tennis tournament closed to-day with a quarrel. A postponement, on account of rain, of the semi-final round of doubles, which is one of the most important matches of the week, called forth complaints from players and spectators, and may cause a rupture in the tournament.

The particular evil aimed at by the law as to divorces proposed by Justice BEEKMAN is probably an increasing one. It is the evil of divorce by collusion. Certainly the number of cases coming to the attention of the courts is larger than in the past, whether or not they form a larger percentage of the total of marriages.

The action of the Board of Trustees of the New York Life Insurance Company in amending its laws so as to provide for the disposal of all its investments in stocks, was discussed yesterday by life underwriters generally.

NEWPORT, July 13. -- Mr. and Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt are entertaining a house party of young people, who will attend the picnic which will be given Saturday at the Vanderbilt farm in Portsmouth in honor of their son, Alfred G. Vanderbilt, and the young men who will accompany him on his tour around the world. At the picnic only the young people will be present.

YONKERS, N.Y., July 13. -- There have been five cases of tetanus in the hospitals here. One of the patients died. Two of the sufferers are very seriously ill. The fatal case was that of Gustave Salinski, sixteen years old, of Walnut Street. A firecracker exploded in his hand on the Fourth, and the wound did not heal.

Mr. TERENCE V. POWDERLY, aforetime General Master Workman of the Knights of Labor, is now performing the functions of Commissioner of Immigration, and they seem to have had a certain broadening and humanizing effect upon his mind. He is now seeking the co-operation of State boards having charge of labor statistics and the like, in the plan of distributing immigrants where they are most likely to find employment.

Official announcement is to be made tomorrow of the election of John S. Kennedy to the Board of Directors of the Northern Pacific Railroad Company. In the financial world there will be surprise. Railway managers will recognize astounding changes in Northwestern prospects. Of recent developments in American railway affairs, accomplished or predicted, none has been more important in its bearings.

CHICAGO, July 13. -- The officers of the American Tin Plate Company and the Wage Committee of the Amalgamated Association of Iron and Steel Workers, who have been in daily conference for the past two weeks over the question of wages of the tin workers employed by the American Tin Plate Company, agreed on a scale to-day.

According to the information of The Commercial Advertiser, there is a strong opposition on the part of Republican Senators to a genuine committal of the party by legislation to the gold standard. On the same authority, the President has discovered that he has no views on the subject, and is preparing to "leave it to the judgment of Congress."

FALMOUTH, July 13. -- On entering the tidal harbor to-day, the Paris, under the influence of the wind and tide, became temporarily unmanageable. Her stern swung round and struck the end of a wooden pier upon which a large crowd of people had assembled.

The big timber dry dock at the Brooklyn Navy Yard was found yesterday morning to be in a partly wrecked condition as a result of the storm of Wednesday night. The rush of water about the dock had washed away the earth filling behind the walls and caused one side of the structure to collapse. The damage is estimated at about $200,000.

CHICAGO, July 13. -- President Harper's quarterly statement of the condition of the University of Chicago was published officially to-day. During the last year there has been a total enrollment of 2,959 students. On the footing of a nine months' school year, which is the basis for comparison with other colleges, the register shows a total of 1,942 students.

In many respects the sale made by Messrs. Christie, Manson Woods of the Marlborough gems was a most remarkable one, and sure to be cited in the future. The gross total of the sales realized 34,823. Some twenty-four years ago the collection was sold en bloc for 36,750.

The very courteous and kind review of "The Missouri Compromise and Its Repeal," which appeared in THE TIMES of June 10, contained a statement which the author begs leave to correct in as kind and courteous a spirit as that in which the review was written. It is this: "She [Mrs. Dixon] seems to see but little good in the men of the North, except Webster."

LONDON, July 14. -- Shamrock in crossing the Atlantic will have a longer boom than she carries in the trial races. This will increase the spread of her canvas. The first trial with the Britannia will occur on Tuesday.

The Rapid Transit Commission yesterday mailed copies of a memorial, which it had prepared, to the Board of Estimate and to the Municipal Assembly, asking these bodies to delay the authorization of any increase of the city's debt so as to leave a margin available for the cost of a rapid transit road until there shall have been a reasonable opportunity for the letting of a rapid transit contract.

The police interfered, but were beaten back and maltreated. Mounted gendarmes and troops were then summoned to restore order, but the disorders were continued to a late hour.

ROSLYN, L.I., July 14. -- According to a statement made by one of the employes on the Whitney place this morning, none of the thoroughbred horses was burned last night in the fire which destroyed the stable. The seven or eight animals lost, he said, were used for general work about the place, and were of no special value.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., July 14. -- There was another large crowd at the Horse Show at Inlet Park to-day. The show has been such a success that it is almost certain it will be a permanent fixture of the season hereafter.
OXFORD, Mass., July 14. -- Mrs. Julia A. M. Barton, a cousin of Miss Clara Barton of Red Cross fame, died at her home here this morning at the age of eighty-six years.

FORT WAYNE, Ind., July 14. -- A decree was handed down in the Circuit Court of this county to-day for the sale of the Fort Wayne Consolidated Street Railway to satisfy a mortgage held by the Guaranty Trust Company of New York for $724,629, and another held by the Guardian Trust Company of Cleveland for $2,085,321.

At the recent meeting of the Bibliographical Society in London, Sir E.M. Thompson read a paper on early "English Handwriting." Present common forms of letter, Sir E.M. Thompson thought, were due in no small part to old Irish teachings. The subject matter of the lecture had mostly to do with handwriting from the eighth to the fourteenth century.

WASHINGTON, July 14. -- Consul General Rose, the German official who has been one of the foremost figures in the recent events in Samoa, called at the White House to-day and was introduced by Secretary Hay to the President.

NEWPORT, July 14. -- The picnic at the Vanderbilt farm, in Portsmouth, in honor of her son, Alfred G. Vanderbilt, and his traveling companions will be given by Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt to-morrow afternoon. The guests will be taken to the farm known as Oakdale on four-in-hand coaches and brakes. Two of the whips will be Alfred G. Vanderbilt and Robert L. Gerry.

WASHINGTON, July 14. -- In the interest of an organization whose object is to agitate for a thorough amalgamation of German-born citizens with the American people, Gustave A. Gayer of New York arrived here to-day. He intends to obtain an audience with President McKinley, and lay before him the organization's indorsement of the Administration.

Ex-Mayor W.B. Kirk of Syracuse, for many years a member of the Democratic State Committee, talked on public questions with a reporter for THE NEW YORK TIMES at the Hoffman House last night. Mr. Kirk is a wealthy contractor, and has done much work for State and local governments.

NIAGARA-ON-THE-LAKE, Ontario, July 14. -- The climax of the Canadian Championship Lawn Tennis Tournament was reached here to-day, and a big crowd of enthusiastic people saw the matches played. To the surprise of all, J.P. Paret beat E.P. Fischer, his fellow-New Yorker and the holder of the Metropolitan championship, after a fast match, in the semi-final round of the championship singles.

In reply to Walter Scott Jarvis of 75 Jefferson Avenue, Brooklyn, let me say that the old Willett homestead and its old-fashioned garden belong, alas! to the things of the past. The widow of Col. Marinus Willett of Revolutionary fame died there in 1866 at a great age. Soon after the property was sold, and the quaint old farmhouse was torn down.

LONDON, July 14. -- Karl Neufeld, the German who was liberated at Omdurman by Lord Kitchener of Khartoum, is the latest lion here. He has sold the story of his captivity and torture, but submits to interviews.

LONDON, July 14. -- At the first day of the Sandown Park second Summer (Eclipse) meeting to-day Sir R. Waldie Griffith's Swirl, ridden by "Tod" Sloan, won the Ditton Selling Plate. Sixteen horses ran five furlongs. The betting was 100 to 12 against Swirl.

The Grand Jury held a three hours' session yesterday, half an hour of which was devoted to a discussion of the evidence of the handwriting experts called Thursday before the jury in the case of the People vs. Roland B. Molineux, charged with the murder of Katherine J. Adams. More witnesses in the case will be called to testify at Monday's session.

I am very much interested in all criticisms relating to modern fiction, and would heartily welcome any opinions concerning "The Fowler," by Miss Harraden, author of that popular book, "Ships that pass in the Night." These two novels have certain things in common; both prove the influence one person may assert over another, and both stories are told in the same simple, attractive style.

In the column of questions and answers I notice the request of U.F.I from Ansonia. Conn., for a list of ten or twenty best books for a fire company. Having been a member of the fire department in my own town for fifteen years. I feel sure the following list is a good one.

The "Man With the Hoc," by Edwin Markham, now published in book form with other poems by the same author, has attracted considerable attention by its expressive force and poetic quality. Upon reading and noting the import of this poem one may perceive the fiery message thundered from the poet's heart, decrying man's inhumanity to man and picturing the wrongs of the downtrodden laborer, the lowest type of the human race.

In your issue of to-day a correspondent, William L. Stone, asks an interesting question concerning the inconsistency of Shakespeare's "Hamlet." The first part of his inquiry is debatable, but the second portion of it, pertaining to the ghost existing as a delusion in the brain of Hamlet, is a point which can be settled without much preamble.

George M. Valentine, for the past six years cashier of the Middlesex County Bank, in Perth Amboy, N.J., and, for a briefer period, also Treasurer of the Perth Amboy Savings Institution, surrendered himself to a county Sheriff in New Brunswick yesterday afternoon, a confessed defaulter.

Gov. Theodore Roosevelt has gone to his home on Long Island for rest, and he is going to have it if it can be found in Sagamore Hill and in the purlieus of Oyster Bay. The first part of his holiday has been very busy and his quiet has been greatly disturbed by an invasion of office seekers and local politicians.

Who are, or what is, "Horgan and Slattery "? That is a question that is coming to be viewed with more and more apprehension and alarm by tile architects of the city and by the persons interested in the embellishment thereof. Whenever there is a decent and considerate project of architecture involved, Horgan and Slattery are invoked to give the weight of their professional opinion to the proposition that it is "no good."

ALEXANDRIA BAY, N.Y., July 14. -- The New York State Bankers' Association assembled here this morning for its sixth annual convention, with 125 members from all parts of the State in attendance. The leading topic announced for discussion was the present system of bank taxation by the State, and the recommendations to be made to the commission appointed by Gov. Roosevelt to suggest modifications of the existing laws.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., July 14. -- Mr. and Mrs. John D. Davis, who started from New York yesterday to make a trip to San Francisco in an automobile, arrived here at 7:45 this evening, having covered only fifty miles of their journey since early morning, and having passed an eventful day of little mishaps and delays.

WASHINGTON, July 14. -- Mrs. Rich is to be surrendered to the Mexican authorities to be tried for the murder of her husband. For days past telegrams and letters have been coming to the President and to Secretary Hay, some almost hysterical in the strength of their protests against the extradition of the woman.

BLOOMFIELD, N.J., July 14. -- The Hotel Essex, at the corner of Bloomfield Avenue and Washington Street, was nearly destroyed by fire this morning shortly after 3 o'clock. The fire, which was discovered by Policeman Gilbert Smith, is believed to have started in the shoe store of Joseph Lewis, in the building.

LIVINGSTON, Mont., July 14. -- As the result of a violent quarrel which took place on the range about forty-five miles up the Shields River Valley, W.D. Smith lost his life last night at the hands of Robert Stephens, his neighbor. The quarrel which terminated in the tragedy, was the outgrowth of a feud of long standing.

PARIS, July 14. -- Magnificent weather to-day favored the National Fete Day. The public and many private buildings were decorated with flags. A feature of the day was the ovation accorded Major Marchand at Longchamps.

Nothing is more persistent than archaeological jealousies, and when Assyriologists have a row it always is of a rancorous kind. The English explorers at Susa, in Persia, complain of the "French pin pricks." The old capital of the Chaldean Kingdom, which is Susa, has been given up to a "Delegation Scientifique Francaise en Perse." An archaeological Marchand was there, and arranged a treaty between the French and Persian Governments.

Among recent English writers there is no one of whom so much has been expected as of Neil Monro. His volume of short stories. "The Lest Pibroch," certainly justified the public's expectations. These were, in a measure, fulfilled in "John Splendid." His new book, "Gilian the Dreamer," still further confirms theme.

Rumors that $5,000,000 of gold will be exported by to-day's steamers did duty for bear speculators at the opening of yesterday's stock market. The names of bankers were freely reported as interested in shipments and various circumstantial details were quoted to give the story an authentic look. Effect was produced.

LONDON, July 5. -- The art season here reaches its height simultaneously with the social season, and declines with the latter, so that it is now on the wane. It has not been as important in many ways as usual, but there have been and continue to be a number of interesting exhibitions, and the crowds which attend them indicate that the public interest in art in England is even more keen than ever.

Edwin J. Stalker, Assistant Cashier of the Chase National Bank, returned to duty yesterday after a short vacation at Amityville, L.I. His outing gained him an adventure in which he, his wife and son, and two other lads saved three lives at no small risk to themselves.

NEWPORT, July 14. -- The Dorothy won a very pretty race in the thirty-footer contest to-day by a few seconds from the Vaquero II. The course was a triangular one from Bishop's Buoy to Beaver Tail. The start was at 3:31. The summary:

The will of Mary Johnson, over which there was a prolonged contest before Surrogate Arnold, the evidence covering 1,175 typewritten pages, was yesterday admitted to probate by Surrogate Varnum, before whom it was brought, as Judge Arnold's successor. Mrs. Johnson was fifty-six years old when she died, on March 10, 1897.

When the passengers on the busses from Charing Cross have been riding for a long time westward without a turn, and Hyde Park has passed into Kensington Gardens, and the long stretch of green has been almost forgotten in a new crowding of houses on either side, then the visitor to the home of George Frederick Watts, the artist, ought to alight.

Mr. Rowland E. Prothero, in his third volume of "The Works of Lord Byron," presents many letters which have never before been published. The period embraced is between January, 1814, and November, 1816. There are not less than 233 letters, of which 118 are new.

The more one reads Mr. Mackail's biography of William Morris, of which a second notice is printed elsewhere in this issue of THE SATURDAY REVIEW, the stronger the impression it leaves, not only of William Morris's versatility, but of the ardor with which he threw himself into each new pursuit and the patient zeal with which he followed it up until he had reached a result as near perfection as possible.

TRENTON, N.J., July 14. -- Mrs. Mary Ellen McGuinness of Newark has filed in the Court of Chancery a suit for divorce from her husband Thomas McGuinness of Jersey City, in which she charges him with cruelty extending over their twenty years of married life. The two were married in St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church by the Rev. John Callahan on July 19, 1879.

George Coster, cashier of the Gilbert Barker Manufacturing Company, 82 John Street, and Frank Furst, fifteen years old, a messenger, were injured by Broadway cable cars yesterday afternoon -- one at John Street, the other at Cortlandt, within a block of each other -- as the result of the same combination of circumstances and almost within a minute of each other.

CHICAGO, July 14. -- W.S. Bond went down before Sam Neel in the Western championship tennis tournament at Kenwood to-day. The defeat of the big Kenwood player, whom many picked to win first prize in the singles, was the surprise of the day.

A man who would attempt to organize a strike among the employes of a large corporation in order that he might profit by the fall in the value of its shares in the stock market would be justly regarded as a public enemy. President ROSSlTER of the Brooklyn Rapid Transit Company charges that the talk of a strike on the trolley roads in Brooklyn has been gotten up for stockjobbing purposes.

Two days without a polo game proved to be too much for the enthusiasts who have been keeping the Rockaway Club field active during the past two weeks at Cedarhurst, L.I., so yesterday a practice game was arranged between the Lakewood and Philadelphia Country Club teams. The Lakewood men won by the score of 11 goals, to 2 3/4 for Philadelphia, the latter losing one-quarter of a goal for a safety in the second period.
Cuba, in the opinion of Gen A.G. Greenwood, who wants to build a railroad from Santa Clara to Santiago de Cuba, is the most fertile piece of land under the canopy of heaven.

Johan Ludvig Runeberg, (1804-1877.) surnamed the Homer of Finland on account of the vividness and power with which he describes the heroic sufferings and fortitude of the Finlanders in the war thrust upon them by Russia in 1808, treats in the following poem of the most noteworthy incident of that war, which put an end to Swedish rule in Finland, and brought the country into union with the Muscovite empire.

Taking into consideration the condition of the European Uitlanders in the Transvaal, and believing that had we as Americans lived there, (that is, in its large a proportion as are the Englishmen.) a conflict would have taken place long before this, Canon Little's recent study of Southern Africa brings vividly before us the exact situation.
