The death of Lady Shelley is announced. She was the widow of the Hon. C.R. St. John, and in 1848 she married Sir Percy Shelley. Sir Percy took slight interest in his father, but Lady Shelley was devoted to the memory of her father-in-law. It was at her suggestion that Mr. Thomas Jefferson Hogg wrote in 1858 "The Life of Shelley."

It often happens that the author of a book is a very selfish person. He is, of course, interested in the books he is writing himself, and if others are not, so much the worse for them. Because of this we frequently find a book crowded with technical terms and expressions familiar enough of course to those who have studied the things of which the author writes, but are all Greek to the lay majority.

PATERSON, N.J., July 14. -- The county authorities were to-day notified of a bold robbery at Wanaqua, which occurred on Monday, but for some reason was not reported to the county officers until to-day.

WASHINGTON, July 14. -- Ex-Gov. Oates of Alabama, who has sometimes been spoken of as a promising candidate for Senator upon the retirement of Senator Morgan, was in Washington to-day. When asked concerning the dominant political feeling in his State, he said: "I think our State will send a Bryan delegation to the next Democratic Convention.

Ever since the first issue of THE SATURDAY REVIEW, I have taken a great interest in the remarks and opinions of your informal correspondents. In THE REVIEW of June 24 there is a letter from a professor of languages, accompanied by two lists of words, which he maintains make up the elements of conversation.

The London Bible Society has begun to publish in its magazine the letters which passed between George Borrow and the society, and which Dr. Knapp failed to secure for his "Life of George Borrow," published by G.P. Putnam's Sons. These letters are particularly interesting as they are said to disprove Dr. Knapp's dicta. It now seems that the conjecture that Joseph John Gurney first introduced Borrow to the Bible Society is wrong.

WASHINGTON, July 14. -- Webb C. Hayes has been appointed Lieutenant Colonel of the Thirty-first Infantry, one of the new regiments of volunteers. He was Major of the First Ohio, and saw service in Cuba and Puerto Rico.

I have enjoyed Prof. Charles Pemery Robinson's joke about 500 words in your two-column communication from him of June 17. As possibly I am one of the few readers who have read the two lists through, I hope the good professor will pardon me if I beg

There are some individuals who declare that New York is a dull city in the Summer, and who betake themselves to Narragansett or Long Branch for recreation. The opinion of these persons would have been effectually and permanently changed could they have "gone around" with the naval cadets from the gunboat Annapolis who had shore leave yesterday.

In last week's cable letter to THE TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW was given a statement which Rudyard Kipling had made in The Author, a monthly periodical published in London, in regard to his suit against Messrs. G.P. Putnam's Sons. A few days ago the Messrs. Putnam issued a statement in parallel columns giving THE SATURDAY REVIEW'S dispatch and their reply to each item in Mr. Kipling's complaint.

Chief William S. Devery's claim for compensation under the Ahearn act came up in the Supreme Court yesterday before Justice Bischoff, in the shape of an application to compel the Corporation Counsel, on behalf of the City of New York, to show cause why a referee should not be appointed by the Supreme Court to inquire into his claim, which amounts to $15,475.04.

Will you please inform a reader who was the son of a Harvard College librarian, who is mentioned in your issue of July 1, in noticing Col. Higginson's "Old Cambridge," as being the compiler of a book of epitaphs in Cambridge Cemetery. Hoping that you will pardon my ignorance, I remain yours truly,

Samuel Goldsticker has sold for Janpole Werner to Edmund Coffin the plot of about eight and one-half lots, 212 by 100.11. on the south side of One Hundred and Twelfth Street, 358 feet west of Fifth Avenue. This property is part of the old Polo Grounds. and the transaction completes the resale of the twenty-nine lots in this block recently bought by Janpole Werner through Mr. Goldsticker.

LONDON, July 4. -- Of course you have learned already that the "Choate Jest Book" has been suppressed. It is asserted that Mr. Choate bought up the entire English edition before it saw the light. This ought greatly to encourage the compiler, and lead to an extensive imitation of his methods. He has shown struggling authors how to sell an entire edition of a book before it is published.

The State Commerce Commission appointed to inquire into the falling off of the commerce at the Port of New York held another meeting at the Produce Exchange yesterday. The Commissioners present were Charles A. Schieren, who presided; C.C. Shayne, Alexander R. Smith, and Hugh Kelly.

WASHINGTON, July 14. -- The report of railway statistics for the year 1898, compiled by the Inter-State Commerce Commission and made public to-day, shows that eleven roads went into the hands of receivers, and forty-five were taken out, while the mileage of receivership roads was reduced by 6,116 miles operated and 5,133 miles owned.
LONDON, July 14. -- The hope is expressed that Admiral Dewey will stop at an English port and come to London. He would be certain of an enthusiastic welcome.

Can it be that your correspondent, Charles E. Savage, is a humorist, or does he seriously believe that there is in the English service such a body of men as the "Royal Horse Marines"? unless, indeed, it be on board the well-known Gilbertian ship, Pinaforce. If so, he will, I fancy, have a difficulty in explaining the part the horses play in the daily routine of a British man-of-war.

Mr. Edward McCrady in a first volume showed what were the very beginnings of South Carolina, and now in a second volume he opens with the overthrow of the Proprietary Government, generally spoken of as "the Revolution of 1719." Did the movement originate with the colonists? History seems to show that a Collector of the King's customs, one Edward Randolph, began the agitation.
LOS ANGELES, Cal., July 14. -- The National Educational Association Convention finished its business and adjourned to-day.

Possibly there are no two colleagues in the Senate, unless they be representatives of very untutored communities, whose public quarreling would attract less attention than the public quarreling of the Senators of New Hampshire. New Hampshire seemed to DANIEL WEBSTER, according to a popular legend, a good place "to emigrate from," and the present Senators of the Commonwealth have not promoted the notion that it is a good State in which to remain.

BOSTON, July 13. -- Miss Alice Brown's "Meadow Grass," thirteen tales of New England life, now in its tent thousand, and "The Road to Castaly," her first volume of poems, have been transferred from the list of Messrs. Copeland Day to that of Messrs. Houghton, Mifflin Co., the publishers of her latest book, "Tiverton Tales."

Roman Catholics of New York are building new churches and establishing new parishes in all directions. They have three edifices just ready for the Archbishop's formal blessing, three more projected, and three new parishes are being formed. Besides all these, a new Polish immigration house is contemplated; the Poles of Bayonne are to build a new church, and the Jesuits are to erect in Seventeenth Street a school building to cost $100,000.

PHILADELPHIA, July 14. -- The Philadelphias defeated the Cincinnatis to-day in an exciting game. The bad feature of the contest was the continuous wrangle of both teams. In the fifth inning Umpire Latham was compelled to remove Cooley of Philadelphia and Miller of the visiting team for constant kicking. Subsequently Miller began to abuse Latham from the bench and he was removed from the grounds.

HAVANA, July 14. -- Many Cuban papers flatly deny the existence of "plots" against American visitors who remain here a few days and then return to the United States, but there is undoubtedly a considerable element endeavoring to sow dissensions among the Cubans and using every means to array them against the Americans.

PITTSBURG, Penn., July 14. -- George Westinghouse, Jr., yesterday cabled here from Europe that the Westinghouse Air Brake Company had secured a contract from the Russian Imperial Railway Commission to equip all its cars during the next four years with Westinghouse automatic air brakes.

WASHINGTON, July 14. -- Surgeon General Sternberg has received a letter from Major Havard, Chief Surgeon at Santiago, which gives an interesting review of the yellow fever situation there. The letter is dated July 5 and says:

WASHINGTON, July 14. -- Secretary Hay received a call this morning from W. Barclay Parsons, the engineer representing the American railway concessionaires controlling the projected railroad from Canton to Hankow, China. Mr. Parsons explained at some length to the Secretary the obstacles that have been encountered by his company in carrying out its concessions.

In THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW of July 1 I read an article on "Collectors and Department Store Books." It would seem as if the article were written by a person who never had the advantage of visiting a first-class department store.

The St. Louis team played its initial game of the season in Manhattan at the Polo Grounds yesterday, and won an interesting contest from the New Yorks by a score of 3 to 1. A singular thing about the game was that the New Yorks made nearly three times as many hits and fielded as well as the visitors, but still were compelled to accept defeat.
The Bureau of Statistics has just issued the figures of the imports and exports for the fiscal year closing June 30, corrected to July 13. The returns are also given by months for the past six years.

Mr. William L. Stone asks the question, whether Shakespeare was not inconsistent when in the first act of "Hamlet" he causes the ghost to appear, and yet subsequently in the "soliloquy" he makes Hamlet say, "That undiscovered country from whose bourne no traveler returns."

BOSTON, July 15. -- Chairman Mark S. Brewer of the Civil Service Commission Board, which has been conducting a hearing at Concord, N.H., of charges against Senator Gallinger, was in Boston to-day. Mr. Brewer said that, although the public hearings were ended, the work of the Commissioners is still in progress, and the results may depend largely upon what is learned by the secret inquiry.

The National anniversary of the greatest event in American history has different appellations to different sections. In staid New England it is "Independence Day." In cities and towns of the South and West it is a plume from the pinion of the orator in his flight -- "the glorious Fourth!" In rural regions generally it is plainly and simply the "Fourth of July!"

LONDON, July 15. -- Kipling is having trouble in England, too, with his copyrights. He has been mildly advertised by big prices, but big prices have turned on him. Kipling has been trying to buy himself, and finds himself too dear. Years ago he wrote "Departmental Ditties," and sold the copyright outright to Thacker, the Indian publisher, for $150.
The successful administration of the pacificator, Gen. Porfirio Diaz, President of Mexico, is inviting the attention of scientists, investors, and settlers the world over.

BRUSSELS, July 4. -- In governing its new possessions in the Far East the United States has much to learn from the Dutch, who have long since solved the problem of how successfully to rule a Crown colony. It certainly is a matter for wonder that the little Dutch people should be able to maintain their authority over the 35,000,000 inhabitants of the East Indies.

PINE RIDGE, S.D., July 15. -- The Pine Ridge posse of police in pursuit of the Sioux band of Swift Bear, which has defied the authorities, and is being chased by three posses from as many different directions, has sent in a courier who says the Indians are making for the Bad Lands as fast as their tough little ponies can travel.

BERLIN, July 15. -- Emperor William's telegram to Dr. Hinzpeter, the former tutor of his Majesty, furnishes the press with welcome relief from the midsummer dullness. His Majesty's assertion of his unshaken determination to continue, in spite of all resistance, in the way he considers right is generally interpreted as referring to the Anti-Strike bill.
NIAGARA-ON-THE-LAKE, Ontario, July 15. -- The Canadian championship lawn tennis tournament was brought to a most successful finish here to-day, with the challenge for the Dominion championship.

Pauline Smith, twenty-three years old, who said that she was the sole support of her widowed mother at their flat, at 107 East One Hundred and Seventh Street, was arrested at the sporting goods store of Goodkind Wood, 65 Cortlandt Street, last night, and locked up in the Church Street Police Station on the charge of petit larceny.

GAINESVILLE, Ga., July 15. -- A mob of about thirty men surrounded the Hall County Jail early this morning, and by a clever ruse tricked the Sheriff into admitting them into the jail. Five of them went to the cell of "SI" Smith, the murderer of W.B. Bell of Atlanta, and shot him to death, riddling his body with bullets and spattering the cell walls with his blood.

The New Yorks gave a splendid exhibition of baseball at the Pole Grounds yesterday, defeating the St. Louis team by a score of 3 to 0. The game included some sensational fielding and the best kind of pitching. The visitors were outplayed at every point.

IN every sphere of duty to which he has been called Ashbel P. Fitch has shown ability, integrity, and determination. Whether as a legal practitioner, Member of Congress, City Controller, or President of a trust company, his course of action is strongly marked by these qualities.

After a long search, or since December of last year, Charles Coates and Miss Katherine Klopfer, of 232 East Nineteenth Street, found the body of George Coates last night through a photograph in the Morgue. The man was found with a gash in his forehead, Dec. 7, in a basement at 34 Division Street, and it may be that the man was murdered.

LONDON, July 15. -- It would be difficult to imagine a more charming picture than the Queen's Club grounds presented this afternoon when the American University athletic teams made their first appearance upon the scene of next week's contest. It was a typical English day, with balmy air and a half-clouded sky, which combined to make athletics a pleasure.

The New Woman alone will work successfully for the abolition of war. The woman of yesterday, in spite of isolated complaints and warnings, did the contrary; she incited silently or aloud to war -- silently by the admiration which she cherished for heroism, and the pleasure which she found in uniforms; aloud by direct encouragement to fight.

ST. JOHN'S, N.F., July 15. -- British warships are gathering for a naval demonstration here next week. The cruisers Comus and Columbine are already here, the Alert and the Buzzard are due from the French Shore on Monday, and Admiral Bedford, with five ships, will arrive to-morrow, making nine war vessels in all.

The first three-cornered motor-cycle-paced bicycle race ever seen in America was the feature at the Manhattan Beach track yesterday afternoon. Harry Elkes of Glens Falls was the winner and covered the twenty-five miles in 45:11 3-5, crossing the tape a lap and a half ahead of Burns Pierce and over two miles in the lead of Earl Stevens.

A Japanese lady is noted for her courage, her strength of mind, and self-possession. It is wonderful to think what physical trials and dangers these fragile little creatures will undergo in an emergency. The late Prime Minister's life was saved by the courage and presence of mind of his wife.

" If all other resources fail," says a Western girl, "I am sure that among a certain set of people I have a sufficient reputation to get a position as a cook. If it is a picnic cook, so much the better, for it was at picnics that my reputation was made. At home the particular set of young people to which I belong is devoted to picnics.

At the last meeting of the French Academy of Sciences A. Muntz read a paper on the late watering of the vine. He said that though the quality of wine produced from small yields of grapes at the end of a dry season is superior to the average, the increased value does not compensate for the diminished quantity.

New York is the great canal State of the Union. It has nearly 1,000 miles of these artificial waterways, which, together with the favorable location of its lakes and rivers, afford facilities for inland navigation unequaled in any other State and unsurpassed in any other part of the world except in Holland and in portions of China and France.

LIMA, Peru, July 15. -- The National Mining Society has appointed John A. Loredo, an engineer, and the Lima Commercial Exchange has appointed Messrs. A.G. Hetherington and J. Mesterm delegates to the Philadelphia Commercial Museum. The State Government will render the delegates every assistance, but will not appoint an official representative.

HUDSON, N.Y., July 15. -- The Board of Managers of the House of Refuge for Women met at that institution this afternoon. There were present Mrs. Marcia C. Powell, Mrs. C. Herbert Halcomb, Dr. Thomas Wilson, Fulton Paul, and Herbert E. Mills. The board was organized by the election of Herbert E. Mills of Poughkeepsie. President; Mrs. Marcia C. Powell of Ghent, Secretary, and Fulton Paul of Hudson, Treasurer.

Supreme Court Justice Maddox, in Brooklyn yesterday, handed down a decision declaring the Ahearn law to be unconstitutional. The decision was made on the application of A. Lawrence Jensen, who was Warrant Clerk in the office of the Controller of the then City of Brooklyn, for a referee under the Ahearn law to pass upon his accounts for expenses incurred by him in his successful defense against an indictment for felony.

Nearly everybody in New York has seen the minor accidents in the streets, which are so frequent that they are not recorded by the newspapers, but the official methods of dealing with such cases are not familiar to the general public.
Notwithstanding that business has very much improved, it is just as hard to-day for a salesman a find a position as ever before.

LEXINGTON, Ky., July 15. -- Mrs. Kate M. Sanford, aged sixty, was adjudged a lunatic here this afternoon by a jury in County Judge Bullock's court. She is the widow of Col. John Sanford, a distinguished Confederate soldier, who was killed by William Goebel now Democratic candidate for Governor of Kentucky and author of the famous election law which bears his name.

One afternoon, about 3:30 o'clock, while fishing for tarpon, I received a terrible blow in the back of the head which threw me out of the boat into the water and almost stunned me. I was pulled back by my guide into the boat, which was floating full of water, and found, lying full length in it, a porpoise about nine feet long, which probably weighed over five hundred pounds.

LONDON, July 15. -- It is generally supposed here that the United States are depopulated. The opinion at the Embassy is that there are 40,000 Americans resident in London; add another 40,000 for recent arrivals, and the supposition is not difficult to imagine. Americans are seen as well as heard even in so huge a city as this.

ALEXANDRIA BAY, N. Y., July 15. -- The second and last day of the New York State Bankers' Association opened here to-day with an address by Frank M. Eastman of Harrisburg, Penn. Mr. Eastman's subject was the Pennsylvania system of taxation for State purposes, with special reference to the taxation of banks.

LONDON, July 15. -- Mr. William Harper of the Philadelphia Commercial Museum, who is just completing a two years' tour of the world, collecting samples of the chief articles of the various nations' imports is about to forward to the United States a collection of the most remarkable sample cases ever amassed.

Some cyclists treat their machines as if they never needed any attention, and this carelessness causes a lot of inconvenience and unnecessary expense. Riders become so accustomed to seeing the machine perform wonders that they look upon it as a matter of course. These careless riders never think of looking after the machine while it performs its allotted work without a hitch.

Every reader of THE TIMES, and every member of Tammany Hall, can now plainly see that John C. Sheehan's former claims to being a loyal Tammany Hall man were false; that every position he has taken since he commenced his fight for political survival has been against the organization and against its executive officers, and not against Richard Croker alone, as he contended.

The salaries of 300 employes of the Post Office have been raised by Postmaster Van Cott in accordance with instructions from Washington. These increases amount in some cases to $100 and in others to $200 a year.

ST. JOHN'S, N.F., July 15. -- The Peary expedition steamer Diana sailed for Sydney at 11 A.M. to-day She has supplies for two years and carries a crew of eighteen men, well accustomed to arctic navigation.

BAR HARBOR, Me., July 15. -- The second handicap golf tournament on the Kebo Valley links was won by A.D. Childs of Englewood, N.J., whose score was 88 gross, 78 net. Mr. Childs is a Princeton man, class of 1901, and a member of the Princeton golf team. His playing to-day was steady and consistent throughout.

One of the queerest and most complicated cases that ever puzzled mortal lawyer is one which Herbert T. BIRMINGHAM, Ala., July 15. -- A dispatch from Ishkooda, Ala., says: Two negroes were killed outright and another fatally shot in a one-sided battle here to-night between striking miners and negroes who have been imported to take their places. After the first brush the firing became almost general throughout the mining camp, and the deputies hurriedly sent to the spot have not had time to investigate.

Wall Street waited patiently for the publication of the weekly bank statement yesterday, showing an indisposition to do anything in the market until that uncertainty should be cleared up. The traders talked confidently of a bad showing, and much of the stock sold by the professionals in the morning was put out on the theory that the weekly Clearing House figures would be disappointing.

Quinby of Scranton, Penn., one of the most noted men of the turf and a prominent poolseller for many years, was found dead in his bed at the Hotel Vincent to-day. NEWPORT, July 15. -- To-day was by far the busiest day socially thus far this season. Never before in the history of the golf club have there been so many players on the links as this afternoon.

Halsey, who has been pastor of the church for seventeen years, and is leaving it to fill the position of Secretary of the Presbyterian Board of Foreign Missions.

VICTORIA, B.C., July 15. -- Marconi's system of wireless telegraphy is to be put in operation in Hawaii as a means of communication between the different islands of the group. An organization has been formed, capital is subscribed for the project, and some material for the system is already on tile way. There is only one channel between Islands in the group than is wider than the English Channel.
