S. Ingraham, First Grand Chief of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers, said tonight: "There will be no...

LONDON, July 17. -- Some members of Parliament are growing humorous over the Transvaal difficulty. Sir Wilfrid Lawson, Liberal member for the Cockermouth Division of Cumberland, to-day asked the Parliamentary Secretary for the War Office, Mr George Wyndham, if the three batteries of artillery recently ordered to the Cape were going as reserves or reinforcements.

CHESTER, Conn., July 17. -- Harry Chadwick, aged twenty-four years, of New Britain, who came here Saturday night to visit a young lady to whom he was paying attention, and started for home on his bicycle last night, is missing, and Joseph Hough, a rival in the love affair, is so severely cut that he may die.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 17. -- The City Council to-night, by a vote of 15 to 3, impeached and removed from office Joseph W. Dusenbury, Director of Public Safety.

WASHINGTON, July 17. -- A few days ago the statement was made that Gen. Corbin, in announcing some of the appointments of officers to the new regiments of volunteers, suggested that care was being taken in providing the officers, that the regiments might later on be merged in the regular army, if Congress should give its approval to the proposition to increase the regular force to 100,000 men.

NEWPORT, July 17. -- As regards the coming race between the Columbia and the Defender, under the auspices of the Newport Yacht Racing Association, the impression prevails that in this series of the best three out of five but one cup is to be offered, when in fact there are to be three cups for the fixture, one to be won outright after each race.
LONDON, July l8. -- The Daily Mail, which gives what it calls the "secret of Shamrock's construction, hitherto carefully guarded to prevent it being utilized by America," says.

Timothy J. Hogan, thirty-two years old, who escaped from Blackwell's Island Penitentiary on Jan. 4, 1897, and who got away from the Columbus (Ohio) Penitentiary on May 2 last, was arrested last night at Fortieth Street and Second Avenue by Deputy United States Marshal McAveeny, Post Office Inspector Jacobs, and Assistant Superintendent George S. Dougherty of Pinkerton's National Detective Agency, representing the American Bankers' Association.

The Dominion of Canada has its own "Geographic Board," to which are referred all questions concerning the spelling, , of geographic names in the Dominion, and its decisions are final with all departments of the Government.

THE HAGUE, July 17. -- The Third Committee, or Arbitration Commission, of the International Peace Conference held a plenary meeting this afternoon, discussing international commissions of inquiry and adopting, with certain amendments, Article 56, respecting the expenses of the tribunal.

The final game of the present series between the Brooklyns and Chicagos, at Washington Park yesterday, resulted in another victory for the Brooklyns. The contest was not as cleanly played as the two previous games between these teams. The Broklyns fielded better than their opponents, and also hit the ball harder.

The Furniss estate, represented by Miss Sophia R.C. Furniss, has sold the plot of twenty-six lots, occupying the block front on the west side of West End Avenue, between One Hundredth and One Hundred and First Streets, and extending 325 feet along either street. Miss Furniss declined to be interviewed in regard to the transaction last evening, and the name of the buyer of the property could not be learned.

There was excitement at the Long Island City end of the Thirty-fourth Street Ferry yesterday afternoon, when Charles H. Hass, forty-nine years old, of 178 Eighth Street, Long Island City, was arrested upon a charge of stealing a bicycle. A woman chased Hass as he hurried along the street with the bicycle. She shouted, "Stop thief!"

WASHINGTON, July 17. -- A story originating in Tennessee has been telegraphed over the country to the effect that Pension Commissioner H. Clay Evans is a candidate for the Republican nomination for Governor of that State. The Commissioner laughed at the story when told of it to-day, and said it was untrue. "I tried that once," he said, "and had enough of it. I don't want to try it again."

WASHINGTON, July 17. -- Regarding statements that cable dispatches received in Washington and other news regarding the war had been censored, contrary to the usual custom, Adjt. Gen. Corbin said to-day:

A published statement, in the form of an affidavit, by Walter S. Swayne, a chemist, of New Haven, who claims that in March and October, 1897, he compounded for one "H. Cornish" poisonous preparations sufficiently deadly to kill any human being to whom they were administered, was the only development in the Molineux case yesterday.

V'ASHINGTON, July 17. -- Assistant Secretary of the Treasury Vanderlip returned to duty to-day from a long trip to the Pacific Coast. His attention was directed to a dispatch from Omaha carrying the information that there was a scarcity in that section of small hills. Other intimations of g similar scarcity in other places have been made. Referring to these complaints,Ire Vanderlip says'

The 375 freight handlers on the Pennsylvania Railroad Company piers, at the foot of Hubert Street, North River, who struck on Sunday evening for higher pay, practically were shut out yesterday, as the railroad company announced that there will be no more night work on the piers. In the future the cars will be unloaded in Jersey City by the consignees.

NEW ORLEANS, July 17. -- Charles L. Rockel, a runner for the Metropolitan Bank, had just entered the bank to-day to begin his duties, when Engelhart Bieber, a discharged soldier, slipped up behind him and, taking deliberate aim, fired.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 17. -- A dispatch from London, Ky., tells of a report reaching there of the outbreak of another feud in Clay County by which five men lost their lives to-day. The dead are said to be Robert Philpot, Edward Fisher, Aaron Morris, James Griffin, and Hugh Griffin.

WASHINGTON, July 17. -- Among many strange applications for permission to enter the army received by Secretary Alger is one from a Frenchman at Brussels, who suggests that the "Citizen Minister" telegraph the Consul at Brussels to give him "a free-cost ticket and an indemnity of m passage" to America.

The vacation schools of the Boroughs of Manhattan and the Bronx opened yesterday with an aggregate attendance of 6,000 pupils. There are ten schools, and they will remain open from 9 o'clock until noon each weekday for five weeks. This is the second year of the vacation school system, and the work has grown beyond all expectations.

MANILA, July 11., via Hongkong, July 17. -- The constantly increasing strictness of the censorship of the press dispatches from Manila, which has prevented the cabling to the United States of anything that did not reflect official views of important events and conditions, resulted in a united effort on the part of correspondents here to secure an abatement of the rigor of the censorship.

BOSTON, July 17. -- Worthington C. Ford, former Chief of the Bureau of Statistics of the Treasury Department, whose dismissal one of the main charges brought against Secretary Gage by George McAneny, Secretary of the National Civil Service Reform League, says that Mr. Gage in his denial is guilty of misstatement of facts.

In commenting on the Fourth of July speech of Senator GRADY, allusion was made in THE TIMES to recent action by the State Commission intended to make civil service examinations more practical tests of fitness for employment. Mr. WILLIAM MILLER COLLIER, a member of the commission, has since sent us a copy of the report made by him on which this action was taken. It is an excellent report.
Horace N. Allen, United States Minister to Korea, arrived with his family on the Umbria on Sunday, and is at the Holland House, where he was seen last night by a TIMES reporter.

Copies of the new rules for the conduct of the city's civil service, as adopted by the State Civil Service Commission, were received from Albany yesterday and made public by the Municipal Civil Service Commission. The new regulations are much more rigid than the old, and their effect will be to transfer to the competitive class many places that are now exempt.

WASHINGTON, July 17. -- Harbor Master Sutton is looking for a stray dog. If one should happen to stroll into the neighborhood of the Harbor Master's headquarters, he will be immediately apprehended and drowned, and then buried in dry salt.

CHICAGO, July 17. -- Hackett and Allen today won the right to hold the title of Western tennis champions in doubles and to represent the West in the National Championship Tournament at Newport. They defeated Myers and Wardner in an exciting contest. The latter team put up a strong fight, and although Hackett and Allen won in straight sets they were compelled to work hard for their victory.

WASHINGTON, July 17. -- A union of Democrats and anti-Quay Republicans, which will elect a Democratic Legislature in Pennsylvania, is regarded as probable by ex-Representative Kerr, who is in Washington to-day.

WASHINGTON, July 17. -- The present week closes the period of two years prescribed by Section 4 of the Dingley tariff law within which reciprocity treaties may be negotiated, and, as a result, there is much activity in the foreign quarters having reciprocity negotiations pending.
CHICAGO, July 17. -- Mayor Carter H. Harrison to-day sent the following letter to the committee in charge of arrangements for the Democratic meeting at the Auditorium July 20:

As Chairman of the Church Association for the Advancement of the Interests of Labor, (C.A.I.L.,) I called on Mr. Clinton L. Rossiter, President of the Brooklyn Rapid Transit Company, and had a brief interview with that gentleman, in which he was exceedingly courteous.

EAST LAS VEGAS, N.M., July 17. -- A pitched battle took place to-day at Cimarron between a Sheriff's posse and a gang of outlaws. Marion Litrell, a live stock inspector, who arrived here to-night, gives details of the fight as he learned them at Springer.
WASHINGTON, July 17. -- This statement was prepared at Army Headquarters to-day and given out for publication:

WASHINGTON, July 17. -- The Treasury commission engaged in investigations at the Appraiser's Stores, New York, has submitted a report to the Secretary of the Treasury upon the subject of charges against the examiner of tea, Isaac McGay.

BRISTOL, R.I., July 17. -- Yachtsmen here say there seems to be no question now about the popular demand for a native-born American skipper, or, in other words, a Yankee sailing master for the cup defender Columbia. They say there is a widespread feeling as to displacing Capt. Charles Barr, a Scotchman born and a naturalized American citizen, by one of the many cracks who are to the manor born.

CINCINNATI, July 17. -- M.E. Ingalls, in response to a query as to the report that he was about to leave the Big Four Railroad to become the arbitrator for the Pennsylvania and the Vanderbilt and Morgan interests, telegraphed to-day from Hot Springs, Va.: "There is not a word of truth in the report."
NEWPORT, July 17. -- James T. Woodward of New York has arrived at Pinard Cottage No. 1 for the season.

OMAHA, Neb., July 18. -- The expedition to the fossil fields of Wyoming left Omaha to-day in charge of Alfred Darlow of the passenger department of the Union Pacific Railroad, of which company the 300 scientific gentlemen, representing every large university in the country, are guests. The company pays all expenses in order to develop the possibilities of the vast region, so rich in relics of the dinosaur period.

The curiosity we expressed about Horgan and Slattery the other day is in the way to be assuaged. We have to admit, what we really did not know, that there is an actual incarnate HORGAN and an actual incarnate SLATTERY, and that they call themselves architects unless they call themselves architects.

COWES, Isle of Wight, July 18. -- On the actual difference in the times of Shamrock and Britannia at the finish of to-day's race, it does not appear that Shamrock has a great chance of winning the America's Cup. These signs, however, may be deceptive.

Hillary Bell of the Mutual Reserve Fund Life Association issued a statement yesterday in regard to the suit of Mrs. M.L. Spencer of East Orange, N.J., against the association for $5,000, the amount of a policy upon the life of her husband, J.W. Spencer, in which he states:

An attempt was made at 1:45 o'clock this morning to blow up the station of the Fifth Avenue Elevated Railroad at Thirty-sixth Street, Brooklyn. It is supposed to have been the work of some of the strikers.

Five hundred persons saw the Devon polo team of Pennsylvania defeat the Philadelphia Country Club men yesterday on the Rockaway Club field at Cedarhurst, L.I., in the finial contest for the Cedarhurst Challenge Cup This is the fifth year that the trophy has been played for, and it must be won three times by one club before becoming the property of that club.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., July 18. -- The Ladies' Catholic Benevolent Association, composed of Catholics in every part of the country, began its fifth biennial session here this morning. Five hundred delegates are here besides a large representation of friends and relatives. Mass was celebrated this morning by Bishop McFaul of Trenton, at the Church of the Holy Spirit.
William A. White Sons have sold for Emil Block to a client, for $200,000 cash, the eight-story business building 64 and 66 East Eleventh Street, on a plot 42.5 by 95.

It is the lawful function of the National Committee of a party to tune up the instrument, but not to strike any keynotes on the same. The present Democratic National Committee exhibits its rawness by the nature of the preparations it is making or permitting to be made for its meeting in Chicago to-morrow, which is to be an advance ratification of BRYAN'S nomination.
WASHINGTON, July 18. -- The following is the Weather Bureau's weekly summary of crop conditions:

THE HAGUE. July 18. -- It is understood that Capt. Alfred T. Mahan of the United States Navy, (retired.) one of the American delegates to the International Peace Conference, has decided to withdraw his proposed amendments to the scheme for adapting the Geneva Convention to naval wars, owing to objections on the part of Great Britain and other powers.

BALTIMORE, July 18. -- Mrs. Letitia A.R. Perot, divorced wife of William Yates Perot, who abducted her eleven-year-old daughter Gladys last Thursday and hurriedly left Baltimore, is now on the ocean, having sailed last Saturday from Montreal. Mrs. Perot obtained a divorce from her husband about one year ago.

A touch of Autumn coolness in the early morning hours, and the absence of that humidity which made the town and suburbs so trying on Sunday and Monday, brought many of the feminine sex who had been waiting an opportunity to do some Summer shopping into town yesterday, so that the Avenue, the shopping districts, and the Astoria and Delmonico's at luncheon time saw more familiar faces than for some weeks past.

CHICAGO, July 18. -- Col. L. Victor Baughman of Frederick, Md., was the first of the Eastern politicians to arrive in Chicago to-day for the meeting of the Democratic National Committee. Col. Baughman is the political representative of Senator Arthur P. Gorman and holds his proxy as National Committeeman.
NEWPORT, July 18. -- The thirty-footers had a splendid race this afternoon over the Jamestown course, with the wind strong from the northwest. The start was made at 3:15 o'clock. The summaries:

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., July 18. -- George M. Valentine, the defaulting cashier of the Middlesex County Bank, at Perth Amboy, was sentenced this afternoon by Judge Woodbridge Storm, in the Middlesex County Court, to six years in the State prison. There was no trial, as Valentine pleaded non vult.

SOUTHAMPTON, July 18. -- The first trial race between Shamrock and Britannia took place to-day. The result was a victory for the cup challenger, which won easily, beating Britannia by 16 minutes and 25 seconds. Both yachts were handled with admirable skill. The Prince of Wales was on board Britannia.

Light fields, no matter what the class of the horses engaged, are generally not conducive to enthusiasm with a racing crowd, but occasionally there is a two or three horse race that arouses the interest of the spectators, and the fourth race at Brighton Beach yesterday, the Peconic Stakes, was such a one.

Your editorial on Horgan Slattery represents the feeling of all architects who are not "architects." Their virtual appointment as city architects is an insult to the whole architectural profession. But, so far, at least, as concerns the Tombs prison, you ought to bear in mind that the "architects" could not have had their way without the complicity of an architect.

An opinion, written by Judge Shipman, was handed down by the United States Circuit Court of Appeals yesterday affirming the decision of the Circuit Court, Judge Wallace, in favor of the New York Air Brake Company. For the past two years there has been litigation between the Westinghouse Air Brake Company and the New York Air Brake Company over an alleged infringement of patents by the latter corporation.

Inspector James Jackson, employed by the Fruit Dealers' Association of this city, had fifteen confectioners and druggists and others before Magistrate Mayo, in the Essex Market Police Court, yesterday morning, to show cause why they should not be punished for violating Section 407 of the Revised Statutes of 1892 prohibiting adulteration of food and food products.

WASHINGTON, July 18. -- Senator Tillman, who passed through Washington to-day on his way to the National Committee meeting in Chicago, said that "goldbugs and traitors," assisted by Republicans, were trying hard to get free silver omitted from the next Democratic platform. He thought that these goldbugs and traitors would make a very stiff fight when the convention met, but he was sure they would not succeed.

PERTH AMBOY, N.J., July 18. -- The news from New Brunswick that George M. Valentine had been sentenced to but six years in State prison for wrecking the Middlesex County Bank created great dissatisfaction here. It was felt that the term should have been much longer.

TRIESTE, July 18. -- Mr. Addison C. Harris, United States Minister to Austria-Hungary, and Messrs. Charles V. Herdliska, Secretary of the American Legation, and Frank W. Mahin, Consul at Reichenberg, have arrived here to greet Admiral Dewey upon the Olympia's reaching this port.
LONDON, July 19. -- The Times this morning commenting on the Shamrock-Britannia race says:

The New Yorks lost the first game of the series with the Chicagos at the polo grounds yesterday, but it was anything but an easy victory. The game throughout was interesting. There was good fielding and batting and clever base running.
WASHINGTON, July 18. -- The following cablegram has been received from Gen. Otis:

The striking employes of the Brooklyn Rapid Transit trolley road system lost more ground yesterday, but have not yet formally surrendered, nor has there been the stampede to make peace which was looked for after the good showing of ability the managers made to operate their lines on Monday.

Ladies' Day of the Larchmont Yacht Club was so successful that it excited the enthusiasm of the oldest timer. Fully a hundred pleasure craft rode at anchor, dressed in all their bunting, yesterday morning. There were 20,000 Japanese lanterns hung among the trees. These preparations for the night illumination were not confined to the grounds, but extended around on Brokaw Point, while all of the yachts and numerous floats participated in the pyrotechnical display.

NEWPORT, July 18. -- The Newport Yacht Racing Association this evening issued the instructions for the Columbia-Defender races to be held here under the auspices of the association. The dates of July 21 and 25 remain unchanged, but, at the request of W. Butler Duncan, the third race, which was to have been sailed on the 27th, has been postponed to the 29th.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., July 18. -- The Times to-morrow will publish an interview which took place May 18 at San Isidro, Luzon, between its special correspondent and Major Lorenzo L. Zialcita, leader of Aguinaldo's cavalry and one of the Filipino Commissioners who went to Gen. Otis with proposition for an armistice.
Purchase of 104,000 gold bars by the Bank of England in the open market and receipt by that institution of 80,000 gold from Holland.

LONDON, July 18. -- Shamrock was tested by Britannia to-day. The result is considered most satisfactory to Sir Thomas Lipton and others who are anxious to see the America's Cup return to this country.
LONDON, July 19. -- The correspondent of The Times at The Hague, describing Monday's debate, says:

We have not for a long time encountered any statement upon public affairs more sickening than the announcement that ex-Congressman LEMUEL ELY QUIGG was in Washington to present to the President certain candidates for appointments in the newly ordered volunteer regiments as having the "indorsement" of the Republican "organization" of this county, of which he is the Chairman or equivalent official.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., July 18. -- Mayor Fiske of this city and the Union Railway Company are at odds. Unless things go as the Mayor wishes, he will to-morrow lead the police, firemen, and city laborers in a raid on the tracks of the company on South Fulton Avenue.

WASHINGTON, July 18. -- The Agricultural Department's foreign crop report for July states that the commercial authorities estimated the shortage in the Russian wheat crop at from 85,000,000 to 120,000,000 bushels, as compared with last year. The deficiency is most serious in the regions most favorably situated for export. In the North unseasonably cold weather has affected all the crops of hay, potatoes, and all grains except oats.

ALBANY, N.Y., July 18. -- It is learned from a reliable source that Gov. Roosevelt, at Oyster Bay, and Adjt. Gen. Andrews have been in consultation over the possibility of the need of assistance of the National Guard in maintaining order in the Borough of Brooklyn during the strike on the Brooklyn Rapid Transit system.

A curious proposition is under favorable consideration by the committee having charge of the reception to Admiral DEWEY. It is that representatives from the leading magazines and newspapers of the country shall be invited to be the guests of the city at the time of the reception.

The filing of plans by the estate of John Jacob Astor for a three-story office building to be erected at the southeast corner of Fifth Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street occasioned a little surprise among real estate men yesterday both because the business part of Fifth Avenue has not yet advanced to Fifty-fifth Street and because the Astors had decided to build nothing more pretentious than a three-story building on the plot.

WASHINGTON, July 18. -- From some remarks made to-day by a well-informed officer of the Administration, who is hopeful of the renomination and re-election of Mr. McKinley, the resignation of Secretary Alger will be hastened with as much speed as the Secretary will stand, in order that he may be got out of the way before the Republicans begin to make preparations for the conventions of next Spring to select delegates to the National Convention.

Everett P. Wheeler, who was Chairman of the former Civil Service Supervisory and Examining Board of this city, said yesterday that he thought Worthington C. Ford's statement, published in THE NEW YORK TIMES, presents the matter of his forced resignation in a light that is not at all favorable to the administration.

The effort of the Tammany leaders to break the bond issue-hold-up in the Council was repeated yesterday, and again it failed. When the meeting adjourned, however, Councilman Oakley expressed the hope that the dead-lock would be broken next week.

SYRACUSE, July 18. -- With a strong entry list of twenty-two experts, including Fischer Paret, Little, and Grant of New York, the State championship lawn tennis tournament opened here this afternoon at the Sedgewick Farm Tennis Club. A wonderful amount of interest is shown in the matches by the local enthusiasts, and a large crowd turned out to-day to see the first contests in the championship event.

CHICAGO, July 18. -- The Democratic National Committee probably will be reorganized at Thursday's meeting with ex-Gov. Stone of Missouri as Chairman. It is possible that Senator Jones's Ways and Means Committee will be abolished. It probably will be put on a new basis, at any rate.

The strike epidemic which has been prevalent for several days among the longshoremen on the railroad and steamship piers along the water fronts of the city has become general. Three new strikes were declared yesterday, and although of the strikes previously declared, at least one was settled, there were during the day 600 men idle.

A large number of writs of certiorari to review the assessments made on personal and real property by the Commissioners of Taxes and Assessments were issued by Justice Andrews in the Supreme Court yesterday.

The consideration of the Molineux case was continued by the Grand Jury at its session yesterday. A large number of witnesses were on hand, but they were very carefully guarded from being interviewed by any one, being practically held prisoners by the District Attorney's officers in the office of Mr. Osborne until such time as they were needed in the Grand Jury room.

CHICAGO, July 18. -- Catholics of Chicago and the West are stirred by the rumor that the Rev. Father Lambert, S.J., one of the most prominent Jesuit priests and scholars in the country, has withdrawn from the Order of Jesuits.

-- Though the existence of "kissing bugs" is more than questionable, the bites credited to them are real enough for every practical purpose, and therefore a trained observer's description of the mythical creature's indubitable work is of value and interest. Such a description is given in The Medical Record by Dr. F.A. BURRALL of this city.

LONDON, July 18. -- Messrs. Jackson, Wendell, Morrison, and Brooks of the International University Advisory Committee held a final meeting at the Queen's Club, Brighton, this afternoon, to complete arrangements and decide upon the order of Saturday's events in the athletic contests between Yale and Harvard and Oxford and Cambridge.

Mrs. Guy V. Henry, wife of Gen Henry of the United States Army, who was with her husband in Puerto Rico during the time that he served as Military Governor of that island, addressed a large meeting of down-town business men, in the assembly room of the Merchants' Association, yesterday noon. She described the conditions existing in Puerto Rico and explained the needs of the people living there.

APIA, Samoa, July 11, via Auckland, New Zealand. July 18. -- In fighting which occurred at Sofata, in the Suateles district, July 4, one Malietoa chief was mortally wounded and two Mataafa chiefs and one Suatele were killed and three others wounded.

The strike which General Master Workman Parsons has been predicting as imminent on the lines of the Metropolitan Street Railway Company will not, according to Mr. Parsons, begin until to-night, if indeed it takes place at all. The labor leader made a statement to this effect immediately after the mass meeting in Cooper Union.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 18. -- At the fourth annual meeting of the stockholders of the San Francisco and San Joaquin Valley Railroad, held to-day, a complete transfer of all the property of the road was made to the Santa Fe Company. It was a perfunctory ceremony, in which most of the stock was voted by proxy, 24,618 shares out of 24,652 being represented.

Officials of the Metropolitan Street Railway Company felt confident yesterday that there would be no strike on their system, and they declared that all the talk of impending trouble came from men who were not employes of the company, and that a careful census of the employes proved beyond all doubt that no great dissatisfaction with the company's methods existed among the men.

WASHINGTON, July 18. -- It was announced at the War Department to-day that no attention whatever would be paid to the round robin of the Manila correspondents. The protest was not sent to Gen. Otis, and, it is said, will not be, and Gen. Otis will not be called upon for an explanation.
THE HAGUE, July 19. -- The Third Committee of the Peace Conference met to-day, M. Bourgeois of the French delegation presiding
NEWPORT, July 19. -- Miss Elsie Jackson of New York is the guest of Mrs. Admiral Baldwin, and will depart for Bar Harbor to-morrow morning.

HAMPTON, Va., July 19. -- The annual negro conference, which is always held in July, began its three days' session this morning for the discussion of topics vital to the best interests of the race. There are about 200 colored men and women in attendance from Washington, Baltimore, most of the Southern States, and some of the Western cities.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., July 19. -- After five weeks' deliberation the Coroner's jury reached a verdict this morning in the case of Sarah Mumford, the seventeen-year-old girl adopted by Henry Tripp of Pendleton from a Rochester asylum, whose dead body was found on the Central's tracks near Shawnee, June 9, at 2 o'clock A.M.

WASHINGTON, July 19. -- According to Dr. L.O. Howard, Chief of the Division of Entomology of the Agricultural Department, the much advertised kissing bug is an old acquaintance of ours, and not a stranger within our gates. A new terror is added to the kissing-bug craze by Dr. Howard, who declares that we have got to unlearn the name "pici pes" and practice on that of "Opsecoetes peronatui."

The employes of the Long Island Railroad have been notified that beginning last Saturday the company will use a system of debit and credit marks in recording their services. For every six months served without cause for reprimand two credit marks will be given. In addition to this all acts of meritorious service or faithfulness to duty will be cause for additional credits.

Your editorial on the Transvaal indicates a somewhat one-sided view. To the impartial observer it appears that England's attitude in South Africa is illiberal, and inconsistent. We all know that Oom Paul has a peculiar disposition in matters of State. Nevertheless, his leadership is wise and statesmanlike.

PHILADELPHIA, July 19. -- A large number of the members of the New York Board of Trade and Transportation, together with some of their friends, visited the grounds of the National Export Exposition here to-day. They were met in Jersey City by representatives of the exposition, and brought to this city in special cars.

SYRACUSE, July 19. -- The second day's play in the New York State championship lawn tennis tournament attracted a large crowd to the Sedgwick Farm Tennis Club here to-day. Both of the New York experts survived the second round, and they are expected to meet in the finals on Friday. In the semi-final to-morrow, Fisher meets Little, the Princeton champion, while Paret plays Jenney, the former champion of Princeton.

AUSTIN, Texas, July 19. -- A sensational bit of political gossip is contained in a letter received here to-day by a prominent Democrat from a well-known Bryan sympathizer now in the East. It is to the effect that an element of the National Democratic Committee is seeking to elect ex-Gov. James S. Hogg of Texas to the position of Chairman of the committee to succeed Senator James K. Jones.

CHICAGO, July 19. -- Representatives of the Chicago platform Democrats of the State of New York to-night issued an address "to the members of the Democratic National Committee and to the Democratic voters of the United States." as follows:

Policeman Daniel S. Garvey of the Bergen Street Precinct, Brooklyn, distinguished himself yesterday by stopping a runaway horse in Ninth Avenue in Brooklyn. The horse, which was attached to a milk wagon, was being driven along First Street when, it became frightened and dashed away. AS it passed Garvey the latter ran to the middle of the street and caught the bridle, but he lost his hold.

WASHINGTON, July 19. -- Bids were opened at the Navy Department to-day for the sale of several vessels purchased by the department at the beginning of the war with Spain, but which, having been found unsuitable for service, have been condemned. First was the Governor Russell, a wooden ferryboat, which has been converted into an auxiliary gunboat.

LONDON, July 19. -- The nervousness and dread that have characterized the markets for some time past are rapidly disappearing with confirmation of the welcome news of President kruger's franchise concessions. Under this influence consols rallied to-day and money was easier. The impression is gaining ground that a further immediate advance in the bank rate will not be necessary.

Midsummer dullness, nobody of importance engaged in active operations, results in a market exceedingly uninteresting. Encouraging business developments pile atop of one another, but such progress finds no market reflection -- none that is immediate. But, so the veterans of Wall Street agree, there never yet was a situation so thoroughly favorable that failed eventually to have satisfactory sequels, and on this faith evidently the strong men of the Stock Exchange district are evidently banking.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., July 19. -- The pluck and presence of mind of Mrs. Nellie Sullivan prevented a disastrous wreck on the Chicago and Alton Railroad this morning. Mrs. Sullivan lives near the track two miles north of Pontiac. She is the wife of a farmer, and was alone when she awoke early yesterday morning and noticed that there was a fire on the railway right of way at a gully near her home.

While Mr. ARCHER was still in this country, to which he had been accredited as a dramatic critic, and with an ostensible mission to inquire into the dramatic art thereof, this journal had the privilege of printing, in co-operation with a London journal, his impressions of American life.

WASHINGTON, July 19. -- Mr. A. von Mumm, the German Envoy Extraordinary and Minister Plenipotentiary to the United States, who arrived here recently and on last Monday presented to President McKinley his credentials, was seen at the German Embassy to-day, and for the first time since his arrival consented to talk in a general way concerning current topics of interest between the two Governments.

LONDON, July 19. -- At the Queen's Club to-day J.T. Roche and J.T. Harrington, both of Harvard, contested for the honor of being the partner of C.D. Daly (Harvard) at the broad jump in the athletic games on Saturday between teams representing Yale and Harvard and Oxford and Cambridge. Roche covered 22 feet 3 inches and gained the place.
Secretary Alger's resignation is now in the hands of the President. That it will be accepted goes without saying. In the appointment of a successor a solemn duty devolves upon Mr. McKinley.

-- One of our readers objects in a sufficiently gentle and courteous way to certain remarks that appeared in this column about the two Seventh Regiment Captains to whom accident or intention has assigned the somewhat trying role of representing abroad the citizen soldiery of the United States. It was the levity of our remarks that displeased the critic.

BRISTOL, July 19. -- Those who have been commenting on Capt. Barr's retention as sailing master of the Columbia might just as well keep their spleen to themselves. Mr. Iselin said to-day that he was perfectly satisfied with Capt. Barr, and that the latter would remain in command of the Columbia until she went out of commission.
LONDON, July 20. -- The Standard this morning, in an editorial article on the resignation of Secretary Alger, says:

SANTIAGO DE CUBA, July 19. -- Notwithstanding the fever epidemic only sixteen deaths from all causes were reported last week. This is the lowest mortality record the city has ever known. No new cases of yellow fever have been reported in five days, and nearly all patients in the hospitals are convalescent. The medical officers claim that the danger is past.

CHICAGO, July 19. -- Word was received here to-night that Col. Bryan had left Omaha, but that he was undecided whether he would speak at to-morrow night's meeting. Before deciding he will confer with his friends in this city. He does not wish to be involved in the factional fight now on hers.

CHICAGO, July 19. -- Acting Chairman William J. Stone of Missouri will call to order the Democratic National Committee at 10 o'clock to-morrow morning at the Sherman House. The Democrats gathered here expect to be busy with questions of political moment during the whole of the day.

SEABRIGHT, N.J., July 19. -- The investigation into the affairs of the Borough of Seabright, which has been under way for some time by Supreme Court Commissioner Stevens, is almost at an end, and Commissioner Stevens to-day heard testimony as to the management of the borough affairs.
WASHINGTON, July 19. -- Secretary of War Alger has retired under fire.

CARLYLE'S "French Revolution" abounds in reflections, how innocent, how happy, how useful might the principal malefactors have been if only they had not had the evil fate, which they thought a good fate, to he thrown to the top "in times of convulsion and disjection." Poor Secretary ALGER probably meant no harm in aspiring to be Secretary of War in what he expected to be time of peace.

A grain elevator and two warehouses belonging to the Brooklyn Wharf and Warehouse Company, at William Street and Atlantic Basin, South Brooklyn, were burned about 8 o'clock last night. The loss was estimated at $150,000 by the President of the company, J.B. Martin.
Officials of the National Steel Company not concerned about action to be brought against it by the Attorney General of Ohio under the anti-trust law.

The members of the committee here on the selection of a statue to the late Senator Vance are much surprised to see the article in your paper of the 15th headed "Sculptors Are Indignant." So far as we are concerned they had no cause whatever for their indignation. No member of the committee, except one, had any acquaintance whatever with any of the competing artists.

WASHINGTON, July 19. -- All the field officers of the new volunteer regiments have been appointed, the list being completed today by the selection of the remaining Colonels. The officers and their assignments with the new commands follow:

No. 23 William Street, a five-story structure adjoining the Lord's Court Building, has been sold. The sale of this parcel was reported and subsequently denied last week, along with various other rumors involving other properties in the same block, but the foregoing statement in regard to 23 William Street was made yesterday by a direct representative of the owner, Mrs. Sarah Marvin.

Among the letters to the editor printed in THE TIMES of Sunday was one from a traveling salesman who in the midst of plenty complains of want. Business has very much improved, he writes, but it is hard for a salesman to get a place. There are many applicants for every vacancy, yet the business is far less remunerative than in days gone by.

The situation in the Brooklyn trolley strike was, if anything, better yesterday from the standpoint of the Brooklyn Rapid Transit Company. There was less violence and less demonstration against the motormen and conductors than had previously characterized the running of cars since the strike.

After a long meeting of the self-constituted Executive Committee of the discontented employes of the Metropolitan Street Railway Company, held early yesterday morning, a strike was declared on the electric lines operated by that company. In response to this declaration, a comparatively small number of motormen and conductors quit work, with little apparent effect on the lines against which the strike had been declared.

The attempt to tie up the electric lines of the Metropolitan Street Railway Company is the result of bad advice and bad judgment. General Master Workman PARSONS, who is not always a sober-minded or safe guide for the men, advised against it, and it is perfectly evident that only a small part of the motormen were in favor of going out.

WASHINGTON, July 19. -- Surgeon General Sternberg has received a cable from Havana saying a second case of yellow fever has appeared in the Fifteenth Infantry, and a teamster in the Eighth Cavalry has also been stricken. Both of these regiments are in Puerto Principe. The Fifteenth will move into a new camp.
HALIFAX, N.S., July 19. -- A special from Canso says: "The schooner Hattie E. Worcester of Gloucester, Mass., was wrecked on able Island on Monday night last.

PERTH AMBOY, N.J., July 19. -- The full effects of the wrecking of the Middlesex County Bank are beginning to be felt. Many of the tradesmen of Perth Amboy and Woodbridge have had difficulty in straightening out their credit with wholesalers in New York and Newark. Money due to the wholesalers cannot be paid because it is tied up in the bank. Many business men had cheeks out, and these have been returned as worthless.

The second half of the 72-hole four-ball golf match between Walter J. Travis and the Oakland professional, David Hunter, and James A. Tyng and the Baltusrol professional, Willie Anderson, was played yesterday on the Morris County links, at Morristown, N.J. Like the first half at Oakland, over two weeks ago, the result was a tie.

MINEOLA, L.I., July 19. -- Harbor Hill, the highest point on Long Island, has now passed into the possession of William K. Vanderbilt. Some months ago it was known that the main portion of the Stephen Tabor estate had been bought by Mr. Vanderbilt, and that it was his intention to erect a handsome country house there.

The Secretary of War has resigned at last. It might be inappropriate to say that nothing in his occupancy of the office became him like the leaving of it, for he ought to have laid it down before, and the final act lacked the grace which would have been recognized in an earlier response to the requirements of a situation that he himself had from the first made difficult and of late impossible.

The Fall River Line steamer Puritan and the steamer Richard Peck of the New Haven Steamboat Company were in collision about 6:10 o'clock yesterday morning, at Hunt's Point, near the southern end of Long Island Sound. The Puritan had her after bulwarks stove in for a distance of nearly 100 feet on her starboard quarter.

SARATOGA, July 19. -- A fierce fire, which originated near the corner of Broadway and Congress Street, at 9:30 o'clock this morning, destroyed the Favorite Spring Building and the Congress Park Hotel, besides a dozen or more stores, together with their contents, causing altogether a loss of $100,000. Only the effective work of the firemen prevented a disastrous conflagration.

The third race of the Larchmont Yacht Club race week series was sailed yesterday off Larchmont in a fluky northwest breeze that disabled some of the boats and damaged others. The wind varied from a fifteen-mile clip to mere zephyrs. There was a big list of entries and a goodly number of starts, though a few of the yachts entered did not sail, among them several of the schooners.

BOSTON, Mass., July 19. -- The Brooklyn Rapid Transit Company is endeavoring to secure men here to operate its lines, and free transportation is furnished men who will go to New York. An office has been opened by J.W. MacNaughton, employment agent, 39 Cambridge Street, and twenty-eight conductors and motormen left tonight for Brooklyn via Fall River.

ALBANY, July 19. -- All probability of a criminal prosecution of ex-Superintendent of Public Works Aldridge and ex-State Engineer and Surveyor Adams or any other State employe, based on the testimony adduced before the Canal Investigation Commission, was ended by the report of the special counsel.

The market for outside securities was dull yesterday, except during the last half hour, when there was fairly active trading in several issues. Prices were irregular, and some stocks ended the day with a net loss of 1 point, while a number of issues advanced sharply and closed with substantial net gains.
TRIESTE, Austria, July 20. -- The United States cruiser Olympia, with Admiral Dewey on board, arrived here this morning.

NEWPORT, July 20. -- All the yachting interest here is centred on the first of the series of races between the Columbia and the Defender, which begins off this harbor to-morrow morning. The warning signal will be at 11 o'clock; the preparatory signal ten minutes later, and the starting signal at 11:15 o'clock.

We have long entertained the belief that Prof. C. LOMBROSO, an Italian person who has written many books on crime and criminals, was fully two-thirds charlatan and not over one-third scientist Not many months ago we had occasion to expose the worthlessness of his statistics, reasoning, and conclusions in an article he had written about the prevalence of crime in his own country.

The Grand Jury yesterday indicted Roland B. Molineux, charging him with murder in the first degree for having caused the death of Mrs. Katherine J. Adams. Molineux will be taken from the Tombs to-day to plead to the indictment. The indictment is similar in verbiage to that presented by the May Grand Jury which was dismissed by Justice Williams because of the admission of illegal evidence.

The Executive Committee of the New York Fire Insurance Exchange is considering the advisability of calling a joint meeting of the standing committees as a substitute for the July meeting of the Exchange.

KANSAS CITY, Mo, July 20. -- Two years ago Rufus H. Davis, a wealthy saloon keeper of this city, sued his wife, Blanche, for divorce and obtained a decree. Now the former wife is suing her former husband for $10,000 for failing to keep his promise to remarry her.

A decided novelty in polo was given yesterday at the Rockaway Club, Cedarhurst, L.I., when a contest was played between two teams of boys. An appreciative audience, including several proud fathers and fond mothers, together with many brothers, sisters, and other relatives more or less distantly connected, gathered at the clubhouse to see the fun.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., July 20. -- The New York State championship lawn tennis tournament was continued here to-day at the Sedgwick Farm Tennis Club, and an enthusiastic crowd watched the players. The feature of the day was the semi-final round of the championship singles. The two New York experts, Fischer and Paret, were opposed by Little and Jenney, the present and the former champion of Princeton.

CHICAGO, July 20. -- A large meeting of representatives from the New England States was held this morning at 9 o'clock in the rooms of the Ways and Means Committee in the Unity Building for the purpose of organizing the New England Bimetallic League. An organization was effected with the following officers: Geore W. Greene of Woonsocket, R.I., President; Homer S. Cummings of Stamford, Conn., Secretary, and William J.H. Bohannon of Stamford, Conn., Treasurer.

BALTIMORE, July 20. -- The National Executive Committee of the National Society of the Spanish-American War held its first annual meeting in Baltimore today. Prof. Guy Carlton Lee of Johns Hopkins University presided.

SOUTHAMPTON, July 20. -- Sir Thomas Lipton, owner of the America's Cup challenger Shamrock, was interviewed to-day by an Associated Press correspondent on board the yacht Erin regarding the damage, if any, sustained by Shamrock in grounding off Southsea at the conclusion of yesterday's trial race with Britannia. Sir Thomas said:

An attachment against property of the United States of Mexico and the States of Tamaulipas and San Luis Potosi in that country has been granted by Justice Giegerich of the Supreme Court to John G. Hassard of this city, in a suit brought to secure payment of $3,075,000, with interest at 7 per cent. per annum, from Sept. 1, 1865, to September, 1885, on 3,075 bonds made by the defendants in 1865.

THE HAGUE, July 20. -- The Third Committee of the International Peace Conference to-day adopted the thirty-four articles of the arbitration scheme, with the exception of the five clauses relative to International Courts of Inquiry, action on which awaits the result of instructions from the Roumanian and Servian Governments to their delegates.

The fourth general meeting of the New York Yacht Club was held yesterday afternoon at Delmonico's, in Beaver Street. Commodore J. Pierpont Morgan, Secretary J.V.S. Oddie, and S. Nicholson Kane, Chairman of the Regatta Committee, were among the officers present, the Commodore presiding.

WASHINGTON, July 20. -- Major Gen. Miles was asked to-day what truth there was in a report reaching here from Boston that he desired to go out to the Philippines. He only smiled at the question, and when it was suggested that it seemed to be the wish of some of his Eastern friends he only answered, "All of the Eastern people may not be my friends."

WASHINGTON, July 20. -- Admiral George Dewey to-day filed suit as a libellant in the District Court of the District of Columbia to recover the prize money due him and the officers and crew of his fleet for the vessels sunk in the battle of Manila and the property subsequently recovered by the naval force under his command.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., July 20. -- On Monday of this week Walter Hart, on of Mr. and Mrs. William Hart, of Chester Hill, Mount Vernon, and grandson of the late William Hart, the landscape artist, together with two sons of ex-Mayor Brush of this city, went into camp on a farm belonging to Dr. Brush, on the hills, near Bedford, Westchester County.

HAVANA, July 20. -- The schooner Gallite cleared from this port in April last for report in Pinar del Rio Province, but never reached her destination. Her Captain, at the time of sailing, had in his possession the sum of $6,000, and was accompanied by his nephew, an eight-year-old boy.

The reported sale to W.K. Vanderbilt of the Harbor Hill property at Roslyn, L.I., is denied. Smith Stewart, real estate agents, said yesterday that they had purchased some land at Harbor Hill for a client, whose name they refused to give, but that they had had no dealings with any member of the Vanderbilt family.

Of all the stormy racing days Brighton Beach has known this season, yesterday was the stormiest, for there were so many matters for the racegoers to gossip over that one was not thoroughly discussed before another was broached.

Friends of the property say that the new Central-Southern Pacific securities will probably be issued late in August or early in September, and are intimating that activity in the stocks of both companies will anticipate this development. The Southern Pacific management, however, says that there is no way of telling now just when the securities will be out.
WASHINGTON, July 20. -- The President has made the following appointments in the volunteer army:
Hamilton Busbey, State auditor of the accounts of trotting associations, has sent in his resignation to Gov. Roosevelt.

CHICAGO, July 20. -- Col. Bryan arrived in Chicago just in the nick of time to-day. He found when he reached the Sherman House early in the morning that there was a conflict of ideas between the leaders of the bi-metallic organization and the National Democratic Committee which threatened complete disruption of the Democratic Party.

STOCKTON, Cal., July 20. -- All efforts to discover the whereabouts of Grant Cullom of this city, who was with the Tenth Pennsylvania at Manila, have been unavailing, and word has just reached here from a comrade that Cullom was shot as a spy in sight of American outposts near Calocan.

HAMPTON, Va., July 20. -- Vital statistics and sanitary problems were discussed by the negro conference in its second day's session here this morning. Dr. F.J. Shadd, a prominent physician of Washington, presented considerable data gathered from Southern cities with reference to the mortality of the negro.

If Senator Platt has his way, Major Gen. Francis Vinton Greene will succeed Gen. Russell A. Alger as Secretary of War. Senator Platt expects the appointment to come to this State, and Gen. Greene is his candidate.
Contemporaneous with the sitting of the International Peace Conference comes the announcement of a new invention by which torpedoes are to be rendered more deadly in modern warfare than heretofore.

Three gentlemen named BROWN, THOMPSON, and ABBOT, "acting as a committee created and authorized by the Chicago Platform Democracy of the State of New York," have addressed the National Democratic Committee and the wide, wide world, asserting with solemnity and earnestness that the Democracy of this State are ready to boil over with fervent enthusiasm for W.J. BRYAN, and would, in fact, so boil over but for RICHARD CROKER, who is sitting on the lid.

-- A circular issued by the Weather Bureau describes the recent Texan floods in great detail, but frankly admits that the science of meteorology is not yet sufficiently advanced even to begin an explanation as to why such torrents of rain fell in that particular region at that particular time. All through June the atmospheric conditions in the Brazos Valley were curiously calm and commonplace.

The Pittsburgs proved easy for the Brooklyns at Washington Park yesterday. Two base on balls, two hits, and a couple of wild throws gave the Brooklyns four runs in the first inning, more than enough to win the game. Score:
MANILA, July 20. -- Lieut. J. Moore of the Iowa Regiment shot himself to-day while temporarily insane.

ALBANY, July 20. -- State Superintendent of Public Instruction Skinner to-day replied to the communication of A. Emerson Palmer, Secretary of the New York City Board of Education, relative to the power of the State Superintendent to license persons to teach in the City of New York.

The affairs of the Mercantile Co-operative Bank of New York, at the corner of Lexington Avenue and Twenty-third Street, are in a very bad way. "Something has got to be done to put this association in shape," said State Bank Superintendent F.D. Kilburn at a meeting of the shareholders yesterday afternoon at the Young Men's Christian Association Hall, 52 East Twenty-third Street.

OCEAN CITY, Md., July 20. -- Ellis H. Roberts, Treasurer of the United States, to-day delivered an address before the Maryland Bankers' Association, on "The Use of Gold." In the course of his speech, Mr Roberts said:

CLEVELAND, Ohio, July 20. -- Rioting was resumed in the street railway strike this evening, serious outbreaks having occurred in several places. About 9 o'clock a dynamite cartridge was exploded under the wheels of a Euclid Avenue car, at the corner of Erie and Prospect Streets. The wheels of the car were destroyed by the explosion, which was heard for a distance of two miles, and one woman, a passenger, fainted, but nobody was injured.

CHICAGO, July 20. -- Four thousand people crowded into the Auditorium to-night despite the sweltering heat to attend the Altgeld political meeting. It was from first to last a silver meeting, an Altgeld meeting, an anti-trust, and anti-expansion meeting. All of the speakers, save ex-Gov. Stone of Missouri, who was ill, and talked for less than two minutes, declared in favor of sixteen to one and against the war in the Philippine Islands.

WASHINGTON, July 20. -- One of these days, after a new Secretary of War has had opportunity to look about the War Department and examine the report of Col. Garlington, made by him while the Wade court was preparing the second coat of whitewash for the beef contractors and purveyors, the views of that officer may reach the light and obtain the publicity which they deserve.

BANFF SPRINGS, N.W.T., July 20. -- Charles Counselman, accompanied by his family and a party of friends, arrived here to-day from Chicago. They will remain in the Canadian National Park until the arrival of the Albert Vanderbilt party from New York, when all will proceed to the great glacier of the Selkirks, where several days will be spent in exploration.

The man whom the President shall call to the War Department will have a hard task. To any one whom he ought to call, the taking of the task should in itself be a sacrifice; above all others this office should seek the man. Only one conscious of generous devotion to a duty, honorable indeed, but difficult, can meet its requirements.

AUSTIN, Texas, July 20. -- The Federal authorities of the Western District of Texas have received reliable information of the reorganization of the "Black Jack" band of train robbers, whose present rendezvous, it is said, is the Chispa Mountains, in Presidio County. It is expected that an attack on the Southern Pacific overland express train is contemplated by the robbers, and the express company officials have been notified of the situation.
Thomas Moloney has sold, for about $100,000, the two five-story mercantile buildings 117 and 119 Mercer Street, 50 by l00.

The strike among the employes of the Metropolitan Street Railway Company showed every sign yesterday of a most complete collapse. With a few trifling exceptions, there were no delays to traffic, and no disturbances of any consequence took place.
CINCINNATI, July 20. -- The Post this evening prints an interview with Gen. Thomas Anderson in which he is quoted as making serious reflections on the conduct of the war in the Philippines.

Another race between the crack fifty-one-footers, the beating of the Maxwells' new Possum by the new O'Shima Sam, and the disabling of the Oiseau were the features of yesterday's yacht races at Larchmont.

Ten-year-old James Freeman, who lives with his parents at 370 Lorimer Street, Brooklyn, is in the Eastern District Hospital suffering from an electric shock and internal injuries. Young Freeman was injured yesterday afternoon on the bridge which spans Bushwick Creek at Kent Avenue and North Thirteenth Street.

BISLEY, July 20. -- The principal event here to-day was the shooting in the second stage of Her Majesty the Queen's Prize. The conditions were ten shots at 500 yards and fifteen shots at 600 yards range, the winner taking a silver medal. At the first distance the Canadians scored as follows: Crowe, 49; Fleming, 44.

PERTH AMBOY, July 20. -- The depositors of the Middlesex County Bank, wrecked by Cashier Valentine, met to-night to discuss ways and means to protect their interests. At least five hundred persons attended the meeting, and as many more could not get into the hall.

"The thunders of heaven are sometimes heard to roll in the voice of a united people," we took occasion yesterday to say at the end of an article celebrating, if we may say so, the enforced withdrawal of Secretary ALGER from the place from which he had defied the President to put him out. The quotation was made from a distant memory of Lord BROUGHAM'S "peroration" in behalf of the Reform bill.

CINCINNATI, July 20. -- The death of Thomas McDougall, the lawyer, may summon home Bellamy Storer, Minister to Spain. Upon the death of Judge Longworth, in 1890, Mr. McDougall became a trustee of the Joseph Longworth estate, and upon the resignations, in 1892, of Larz Anderson and Julius Dexter, the remaining executors, he became co-trustee with Bellamy Storer to the estate, Mr. Storer having been selected as successor to the retiring executors.

WASHINGTON, July 20. -- There were many rumors to be followed to-day about a forthcoming successor to Gen. Alger as Secretary of War, but from the best information obtainable to-night it is possible only to conclude that the President has once more assumed a listening attitude and will hearken to the voice of the country before deciding upon his next adviser on questions of war.

General Master Workman PARSONS is no better satisfied with the conduct and policy of the police as to the disorders attending the strike in Manhattan than he was with their course in Brooklyn. He says:

Since you invite correspondence with your readers, whether agreeing with you or not, I am moved to write you in protest against your treatment of Mr. Atkinson and of the "anti-expansionists" in general.

NEWARK, July 20. -- The Rev. Joseph Segal, until last May the rabbi of the Congregation B'nai Abraham, has begun suit against the trustees for $30,000 for breach of contract. He asserts that his contract was for three years ending Jan. 1, 1901, and that the trustees discharged him without cause. Rabbi Segal had some trouble recently because his daughter Rose went to live at the home of John M. Reiner in Elizabeth.

CHICAGO, July 20. -- William Allen White, editor of The Emporia (Kan.) Gazette, was in town to-day and said: "This is a 'nine year' in Kansas, and by tradition and precedent it should be a year of wonderful crops.

WASHINGTON, July 20. -- Arrangements have been made by the Committee of One Hundred for Washington's share in the reception to Admiral Dewey upon his arrival in this country. On the day when he is expected to arrive the committee will send a delegation to New York to extend a welcome to him from the people of Washington. He will be escorted to this city and to his hotel by this delegation.
A correspondent, William L. Stone, asks for light on the questions: Is Shakespeare "inconsistent" or the ghost of Hamlet's father "a figment" of Hamlet's brain?

TRIESTE, July 21. -- Admiral Dewey, accompanied by Capt. Benjamin P. Lamberton and Flag Lieut. T.M. Brumby of the United States cruiser Olympia, landed here to-day to return yesterday's visits to the Admiral and to call officially upon the Governor of Kustenland, Count Goess, who yesterday returned from a tour of inspection of the province. The American officers also called upon the Mayor of Trieste.

The theme of Max Pemberton's latest story, "The Garden of Swords," is the old one of love. The pretty child-wife and her handsome soldier lover elicit all sympathy and interest from beginning to end. There had been a vast assemblage at the famous old Cathedral of Strasburg on a beautiful June morning about a quarter of a century ago, when the young English bride, Beatrix Hamilton, was wedded to the gallant French lancer. Edmond Lefort.

A truthful account of the Klondike country comes as near to novelty as a modern writer may reasonably hope to get, and Mrs. Hitchcock's narrative is marked by an assiduous veracity, in which she is aided by her excellent health and mirthful temper. In some respects the picture she constructs for us is oppressively civilized.

In yesterday's market strength was manifested throughout almost the entire list. Only in exceptional cases was there any lagging. Nowhere was any showing of weakness. Commission house transactions were relatively large and evidences were many that public interest in the security market has not abated -- that it stands ready to respond with prominence and vigor to anything like resolute leadership.

WASHINGTON, July 21. -- To quiet the apprehension that has been aroused as to the treatment of Mrs. Rich by the Mexican provincial authorities, the State Department has taken steps to insure an absolutely impartial trial for her. She is now at El Paso awaiting surrender to the Mexican authorities under extradition proceedings on a charge of murdering her husband, John B. Rich, in Mexico.

CHICAGO, July 21. -- The "factor" plan in the distribution of refined sugar -- that is, on terms dictated by the Sugar Trust -- is in jeopardy, and may be abolished at any time. A meeting of wholesale grocers and jobbers heretofore interested in furthering the plans of the American Sugar Refinery Company was held at the Commercial Exchange to-day, and the trade situation, as affecting sugar, was discussed.

Roland B. Molineux was arraigned in the Court of General Sessions yesterday morning to plead to the indictment for murder in the first degree found against him the day before by the Grand Jury. District Attorney Gardiner was on hand to represent the people, while Molineux's interests were looked after by Weeks Battle.

HAVANA, July 21. -- A cable message received here to-day stating that Senor Carlos Garcia was in Washington for the purpose of conferring with President McKinley and others interested in Cuban affairs, and alleging that he had asserted that Cuba's greatest need is the substitution of civil for military government, has been the subject of considerable comment.

Your correspondent La Giocondo is evidently a woman gifted with a bright intelligence and good common sense, who has also a happy combination of literary and domestic tastes and qualifications. She is no "blue stocking," yet seems to be as fond of a literary life as any "blue stocking" could be, while she is about as fond of home and domestic life as she is of literature.

There were more sensational features at the Brighton Beach track yesterday. George Odom, the light-weight jockey, took a bad fall from John Fritz in the first race, and was carried from the track in a badly battered condition. Dr. Purdy, who examined the lad, found that his left hip was dislocated, and that the attention of a specialist would be necessary at once in order to obtain the best results.

Disciples of Christ, a religious body very strong in the Middle West and growing in the East, will undertake a vigorous missionary campaign in this city this Fall. The Disciples' Club, organized two years ago, will enlarge its membership by admitting women, and will then undertake to form a lay helpers' association, designed to secure competent speakers and workers.

In the correspondence which terminated the official career of Mr. ALGER, both he and the President exhibited a touching solicitude about each other's health. "I wish for you continuous health," wrote Mr. ALGER in his letter of resignation. "I desire * * * to wish you a long and happy life," wrote the President in accepting the same.

In a recent issue a correspondent criticises the style of Mr. Alden's literary letter, and a propos of some comments on Borrow's "Lavengro," accuses Mr. Alden of "a toplofty dismissal of every book or writer that fails to interest him." This heavy indictment amused me somewhat by its naivete.

The Century Company announces for issue in October a book by Frederic Courtland Penfield, ex-Consul General at Cairo. It is entitled "Present-Day Egypt." In the pictures of the modern cities of Alexandria and Cairo, of the Suez Canal, and the great projected irrigation scheme, will be shown how the British rule has worked out the destiny of this reclaimed country. Egypt as a health resort is the subject of a special chapter.

Relief over the easier money market conditions and anticipation of a favorable bank statement to-day exerted considerable influence upon the stock market yesterday. Among bankers there was, as usual, reluctance to forecast to-day's Clearing House figures, but current calculations predicted a decrease in loans and a resultant increase in reserves.

PHILADELPHIA, July 21. -- The bulletin of the American Iron and Steel Association has received from the manufacturers complete statistics of the production of all kinds of pig iron in the United States in the first half of 1899. The total production of pig iron in that period was 6,289,167 gross tons, against 5,869,703 tons in the first half of 1898 and 5,904,231 tons in the second half.
"Please don't buy The Evening Journal and World, because the newsboys has striked."

It is characteristic of the brilliant and erratic man we have just lost that it would be as strange as it would be conventional to describe him, even now that he is dead, otherwise than as "BOB" INGERSOLL, "Col." INGERSOLL or even ROBERT G. INGERSOLL we should hardly identify.

The new story of sea life which Frank T. Bullen has been writing for D. Appleton Co. will be entitled "The Log of a Sea Waif: Being Recollections of the First Four Years of My Sea Life." In his new book, Mr. Bullen sketches the events of voyages to the West Indies, to Bombay and the Coromandel coast, to Melbourne and Rangoon.

In a letter in last SATURDAY'S REVIEW, "Inquirer" makes a statement to the effect that the tendency of the English language at present is to discard strong verbal forms for weak ones. This statement, although not infrequently heard, is quite erroneous, for exactly the reverse is true. There was a time -- I refer to the three centuries after the Norman Conquest -- when several originally strong verbs gradually went over to the weak inflection.

The subject of this memoir, Robert Herbert Quick, was the eldest son of James Canthew Quick, a London merchant of considerable means, and was born in London on Sept. 20, 1831. He was educated at Harrow, and by private tutors, entering Trinity College, Cambridge, in 1854, where he paid especial attention to mathematics, although his tastes all lay in the direction of the classics.

The appearance of a recent book on this subject, "Books Worth Reading," which has just come out, both in England and America, brings to mind the old question whether such lists are ever worth while.

In reply to Mr. Thomas Johnston's article on "Leonardo's Inaccuracies" allow me to say that the anachronisms in Da Vinci's "The Last Supper" are so well known as to call for very little comment at the present day. They are the rule, and not the exception, to be met with in all the paintings of the Renaissance period in which ancient scenes are portrayed.

HAMPTON, Va., July 21. -- A paper on "The Negro in Fiction, as Portrayed and as Portrayer," by Prof. W.S. Scarborough of Wilberforce University, was read before the third and last day's session of the negro conference here this morning. It was a scholarly review of the manner in which the negro character has been represented in story and of the truth or falsity of that representation.

The residents of East Fifty-fifth Street were startled a little after midnight yesterday by the raising in song of a number of male voices, whose owners stood on the sidewalk just in front of 329. Few were disposed, however, to grumble at the disturbers of the night's quiet, for the airs sung were beautiful, if unfamiliar.

A new labor party was born last night in Grand Central Palace. It was brought into being by about 300 labor men, who had met at the call of General Master Workman John N. Parsons of the Knights of Labor. This is Mr. Parson's idea of bringing about the reforms in the conditions of labor, and of not only ending the present street car strikes but of putting all other strikes out of the question.

Prof. James L. Bryce recently delivered an address on "The Prospects of Literature," before the London Authors' Club. He was introduced by Lord Monkswell as an author, but declared that he did not know that he deserved the character of an author. Literature was now divided into three branches -- journalism, poetry, and fiction.

DETROIT, Mich., July 21. -- Gov. Pingree to-day gave out a prepared signed interview, giving what the Governor asserts to "be facts which are absolutely reliable bearing upon the relations between Gen. Alger and President McKinley with which the public are not familiar."

Miss Clara Barton, the President of the National Red Cross Society, who arrived here from Cuba on the Ward Line steamer Havana, on Thursday, is the guest of Dr. Lucy Hall-Brown, at the latter's home, 158 Montague Street, Brooklyn. Miss Barton spent the last two months in Cuba directing the work instituted by the society of which she is the head, in behalf of the reconcentrado orphans on the island.

TALLULAH, La., July 21. -- Five Italians were lynched here last night for the fatal wounding of Dr. J. Ford Hedge. The dead men are of a class which has been troublesome for some time. Some, it is said, had families in Europe, but had no relatives here.
LONDON, July 21. -- Even the theatres cannot compete with the weather. The latter has been so intolerably hot that even "The Belle of New York" suffers from the general collapse of poor humanity.

WASHINGTON, July 21. -- The circulars to be sent to shipbuilders to acquaint them with the purposes of the Government in constructing the Denver type of cruisers, six in number, have not yet been issued by the Navy Department, although the advertisements for contracts are much delayed and there is a general desire to have the ships under way at once.

WASHINGTON, July 21. -- Admiral Dewey having cabled approval of the plans for his reception at the National capital, the committees in charge of that event are free to proceed at once with the necessary preparations.

Smiling placidly into the anxious face of his wife and without a tremor of distress, Robert G. Ingersoll died a few minutes before noon yesterday of heart disease. He was seated in a low-backed rocking chair in his own room on the second floor of the country home of his son-in-law, Walston H. Brown at Dobbs Ferry.

Fischer won the first two sets easily, lost the third, and then took the fourth.

WASHINGTON, July 21. -- A successor to Secretary Alger man be named by the President to-morrow. Without an announcement, official or unofficial, from anybody, it is the general belief among interested public men that Alger's successor will be Elihu Root of New York. The assertion that the Secretary may be named to-morrow is justified by the remark made to-night by Senator Platt after a visit to the White House and a conversation with the President.

The strike on the electric lines of the Metropolitan Street Railway Company showed further signs of disintegration yesterday. While the leaders of the movement talked to prove their contention that it was a success and to keep up the courage of the malcontents whom they have induced to quit work, the officers of the company declared that many of the strikers have returend to work, and that the car service on all lines was uninterrupted.

BAINBRIDGE, Ga., July 21 -- A sensation is stirring Decatur County, and a double lynching may follow as the result of crimes heaped upon J.E. Ogletree and his wife last night, at their home at the little station of Saffold, on the Plant System, a few miles from here, by two negroes.

THE HAGUE, July 21. -- Baron de Staal presided at the plenary session of the International Peace Conference to-day, to place the final seal upon the labors of the First Committee. W.G. Max-Muller, the Secretary of the legation, has been here for a week arranging for the transfer of the legation from Washington.

CHICAGO, July 22. -- Troop L. Third United States Cavalry, now stationed at Fort Sheridan, has been ordered to the Philippines to assist in the reinforcement of Gen. Otis's command. It will leave within a few day's and sail from San Francisco for Manila before Aug. 10. Troop B of the same regiment has been ordered to report for duty at Fort Myer, Va.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., July 22. -- James Russell and Robert Wade, two colored men, who are thought to be the murderers of Rabbi Louis Grenzberg at Binghamton, N.Y., July 4, were arrested in this city this evening by Inspectors Boyle and Quilty. The Inspectors have been watching for the men for several days, and Friday they thought they were in the city, but could not locate them.

DETAILS OF THE FRENCH ROYALIST PLOT. -- An authoritative statement concerning the plot of the royalists to overthrow the French Government last March has just been published in La Gazette de France. The statement not only shows by what mean the conspirators hoped to place the Duc d'Orleans on the throne, but it seriously implicates Comte Boni Castellane and other members of the Jeunesse Royaliste and the leaders of the so-called patriotic leagues as well.

ROCKLAND, Me., July 22. -- Clement R. Sherwood, President, manager, and editor of The Star Publishing Company, was found dead in bed at his home here to-day. Coroner Judkins was at once summoned, and it was at first thought that death was the result of heart disease. Later symptoms of poisoning developed, and an autopsy was held, but as yet no definite cause of death has been ascertained.

WILMINGTON, Del., July 22. -- The launching of the steel steamship Ponce, which is being built at the shipyards of the Harlan Hollingsworth Company for the New York and Puerto Rico Steamship Company, took place to-day at noon in the presence of 2,000 people. Miss Elizabeth B. Gilpin of this city performed the christening ceremony.

Jackson, Bursar of Hertford College, who had charge of the Oxford-Cambridge ream, said after the contests to-day: "I am really sorry that the Americans had to lose, but they did it in a sportsmanlike manner, which is highly appreciated by every Englishman who was opposed to them and by all who saw their performance.
