Stewart carpet mill at Glenham for many years, but the closing down of the mill had thrown him out of employment. He was considerably over seventy years of age, still he refused all offers of aid from friends and threw himself upon the county.

TOPEKA, Kan., July 22. -- New York and New England holders of Western Kansas bonds, were they to take a trip through that country, would see evidences of the speculative boom of twelve and fifteen years ago still standing, silent reminders of the craze, which took possession of the people and sent them headlong into a debt from which they cannot hope to recover.

WASHINGTON, July 22. -- The lynching of five Italians in Louisiana yesterday promises to assume an international aspect through the action of the Italian Government. Count Vinchi, the Italian Charge d'Affaires, called at the State Department at an early hour this morning, and made representations to the officials concerning the atrocity in Louisiana.

FOSTORIA, Ohio, July 22. -- Ex-Secretary of the Treasury Charles Foster related an interesting reminiscence this afternoon regarding the appointment of Gen. Miles to the command of the Army of the United States, which is particularly pertinent at the present time. It fell to the lot of President Harrison to appoint the several Brigadier Generals necessary for the conduct of military affairs. Gen. Otis was one of the appointees.

The Talmud requires that a benediction be given to the betrothed when they enter into a contract, with the injunction, however, that they must not enter upon the conjugal life before the nuptials take place. The nuptials are termed Chuppa or Nissuin, and were usually held in the young husband's dwelling, and seven days were allowed for the celebration.
SATURDAY JULY 29. -- On the premises, at 2:30 P.M. by Philip A. Smyth, public auction sale, 60 villa plots at Edgemere, L.L.

LONDON, Ky., July 22. -- Advices from Manchester, the county seat of Clay County, say that the situation there is worse than ever. The Whites and Howards are gathering there, armed to the teeth, and they are trying to find if the Bakers are being offered protection by the Philpots. If they find this to be true they will make open war on the Philpots.
WASHINGTON, July 22. -- The President to-day issued his proclamation publishing to the world the reciprocity agreement between the United States and Portgual.

LONDON, July 22. -- The concluding half of the golf match between William Park and Henry Vardon was played to-day at Ganton, Yorkshire, in the presence of 1,000 spectators. Vardon had a lead of two holes in the first half of the match, which was played in Scotland, and he won to-day by 11 up and 10 to play.

EAST MORICHES, L.I., July 22. -- John T. Hartigan, a lawyer, who resided at 71 East One Hundred and Twenty-fourth Street, New York City, was drowned while bathing here to-day. Louis B. Gerow, who was with Hartigan, almost lost his life in trying to save his companion. He was saved by Washington Hyde, a fisherman.

During the past five years, while personally superintending some of the finest plumbing work, such as that of Grant's Monument and the Flower Hospital, I have carefully studied the sanitary conditions in New York City, and I feel that a plain statement of facts may improve matters considerably.

I have noticed that, with few exceptions, the press is hostile to the workingmen on strike. The tone of THE TIMES's editorial this morning is one of condemnation, from which one can glean no possible reason for giving a mote of sympathy to a class of people who in times of peace are conceded to be overworked and ill-paid.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., July 22. -- Revenue officers have returned from the Tennessee mountains, where they had one of the most successful raids in the history of Tennessee moonshining. Wednesday they left Knoxville and went to Madisonville, and leaving that place traveled forty miles into the mountains, where they located an illicit distillery that has been operating for several years.

The present population of Nicaragua is estimated at about 400,000, or only about eight to the square mile. Of each hundred inhabitants there are 50 Indians, 1 negro, 45 of mixed blood, and 4 whites. They are sharply divided into classes, the Caballeros, or "gentlemen," and the peons, or laborers, who can be distinguished by their costume as far as they can be seen.

To women and children especially the enforced banishment from the Popular little park brings much regret for the time being, and they are blaming the destroyers of the English sparrows last Spring for the infliction."
The City Directory of 1897 gives Horgan Slattery as "builders," and I know that about that time they were soliciting work in my office in that capacity.

WONDERFUL tales are often told of the aquatic feats performed by the South Sea Islanders or by the Hawaiians, until one almost becomes convinced that the art of swimming is carried to perfection among them. In general this is true, but it need not be so.

DOVER, July 4. -- When the coal boring was put down at Dover about six or eight years ago by Mr. F. Brady on the site of the old Channel tunnel works, there were indications in the cores of the presence of iron ore in the strata between 500 and 600 feet from the surface. The indications have now proved correct.

The announcement from The Hague that the Emperor of Germany has instructed his representatives at The Hague to support the only proposal submitted by France, for the express reason that it was submitted by France, was the kind of thing that was to be expected from him.
There was plenty of local cricket yesterday, and the championship games of the Metropolitan League and the New York Cricket Association all proved interesting.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- Apropos of Gen. Alger's retirement. It is a curious fact that the Secretary of War has never held office as long as Secretaries of other departments have held it. Twenty-five Presidents of the United States have had fifty-two War Secretaries, while the number of Secretaries at the heads of others departments has been much less.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., July 22. -- The shooting match scheduled for this afternoon at Elkwood Park was postponed. There was some misunderstanding about the date, and not enough contestants appeared when the match was called. Phil Daly, Jr., announced that all entries would stand, and set next Wednesday as the new date.
OMAHA, Neb., July 22. - "If Jeffries and Sharkey fight it will be in New York." So said tile big champion last night, in a talk with Sandy Griswold, the sporting writer, who went out to meet him.

Gov. Roosevelt was the guest of Senator Thomas C. Platt at the Oriental Hotel, Manhattan Beach, last night, and will also be his guest to-day and to-morrow. The Senator came from Washington in the afternoon, dressed hurriedly, and sat with his wife on the veranda for several hours waiting, with some little show of impatience, the arrival of the Governor.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., July 22. -- Several persons were seriously injured and, it is feared, two lives lost in a wreck near Gallatin this evening on the Chesapeake and Nashville Railroad.

The Milk Lady lives down on Centre Street. That is, at least, what the children think. The Milk Lady is a great institution in the economic affairs of New York, and the children all around in the lower portions of the city know her well.

BERLIN, July 22. -- The Philippine campaign has been alluded to frequently this week. The Kreuz-Zeitung says the Americans are making no progress in spite of exertion. The Tageblatt says the campaign looks for tile present like a farce, because the Americans have not sufficient troops in the Philippines to undertake any serious operations.

A large number of diamonds are white, though a clear, colorless, transparent stone is rarer than might be supposed. Besides white diamonds there are red, blue, green, yellow, brown, black, and pink ones. Heat often changes the color, and after awhile the acquired hue becomes permanent. Yellow diamonds perhaps afford the greatest variety of shades.

The will of Anna Sutherland, which was contested by her daughter, Mrs. Hagan, mainly upon the grounds of testamentary incapacity and undue influence, was yesterday admitted to probate by Surrogate Varnum. The decedent first married in 1863, when about eighteen years old, a Mr. Kimball, by whom she had one child, Mrs. Hagan, the contestant

The sudden death of Russell A. Dennison in Hudson Street Hospital last evening ended an old man's long, cheerful, hopeful, and courageous fight against adverse fortune, which might have daunted the energy and strength of youth.

BISLEY, July 22. -- This was the closing day of the annual meeting of the National Rifle Association, and witnessed the conclusion of the shooting for the Queen's Prize and the St. George's Challenge Vase. Three Canadians had been left in the final stages of each competition. O.M. Mundsen won the St. George's, adding 46 to his score this morning. The Canadians, Huggins and Fleming, added 42, and Graham 40 to their scores.

ALBANY, July 22. -- Diphtheria in a mild form is raging at the Willard State Hospital, and the State Board of Health has established a rigid quarantine in the big Institution, with its 2,000 or more inmates. Of the thirty-four cases no deaths have yet been reported.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., July 22. -- Malcom D. Whitman, the National lawn tennis champion, to-day won the New York State championship for the second time by beating E.P. Fischer, the metropolitan champion, three sets to one, in a brilliant match. The largest crowd of the week thronged the courts of the Sedgwick Farm Tennis Club, and the enthusiasm ran high in the third set of the match.

CHICAGO, July 22. -- A special from Kansas City says:

Certain ill-natured persons connected with newspapers -- which some may consider a sufficient explanation and justification of their ill-nature -- have been making sport of a New Orleans bridegroom for soliciting an artillery company, in which he was an officer, to fire a salute in honor of his nuptials. New Orleans, it must be remembered, is far behind the great cities of the Central West in some things.

LONDON, July 22. -- Following the lead of their more enterprising brethren in the United States, the medical world of Europe is eagerly debating the developments in serum therapeutics. Recent demonstrations in Berlin and Paris of American success in this direction are the subject of widespread comment in the medical journals.

LONDON, July 22. -- Judging from an announcement made by several speakers at the dinner given by the Queen's Club tonight to the contesting teams, it is evident that the two English Universities contemplate a return visit to America next year.
ROME, July 12. -- News reached Rome yesterday of the death of Cardinal Theodolphus Mertel at Allumiere, the Cardinal's home, early yesterday afternoon.

CAPE TOWN, June 20. -- In the course of a lengthy interview with a representative of the South African News, Col. James G. Stowe, Consul General of the United States, has given his views on South Africa. The South African News is a morning paper recently started in Cape Town in the interests of the Bond or Dutch as against the Progressive, or Rhodes, Party.

NEWPORT, July 22. -- In spite of conflicting reports, the Columbia and Defender had a friendly brush for a couple of hours this afternoon, beating off from Brenton's Reef Lightship for four miles in a very light and baffling breeze, and then running back again under a grand breeze from the southeast, which sent them along at a ten-knot gait.

The prospects for a good display of American art at the Paris Exposition are, according to Director of Fine Arts Cauldwell of the United States Commission, better than has been stated. Mr. Cauldwell, when seen yesterday, said that he had every reason to expect that the showing of American painters, sculptors, and illustrators would be a representative one, and would include the best work done by citizens of this country in the last ten years.

As the result of a detective's shot following a highway robbery and assault on the beach at Coney Island early yesterday morning, Henry Johnson, thirty-one years old, colored, of 221 West One Hundred and Twenty-fourth Street, is in the Norwegian Hospital, Brooklyn, in a supposedly dying condition.

NEWPORT, July 23. -- During the week the ships of the North Atlantic Squadron will engage in landing drills at the training station, permission having been granted to Capt. Taylor, who is now in command of the fleet. The drills will consist of infantry and artillery battalion and brigade practice and probably arm and away boats.
The Seventh International Geographical Congress will meet in Berlin on Thursday, Sept. 28, and will hold sessions until Wednesday, Oct. 4, during which period several scores of papers will be read.

LONDON, July 15. -- William Harper, Chief of the Bureau of Information of the Philadelphia Commercial Museum, an organization affiliated with the Chambers of Commerce of all the leading cities of the United States, is about to return home at the conclusion of one of the most important missions ever connected with the export trade of the United States.

Seemingly in peaceful slumber the body of Robert G. Ingersoll lay on an improvised bier yesterday in the bedroom in which he died, on the second floor of the home of Walston H. Brown, his son-in-law. Upon it, glowing deeply red against the white sheet by which it was partly covered, were a few hollyhocks and poppies, his favorite flowers.

The Brooklyn trolley strike, to all appearances yesterday, had petered out completely. The strikers were still out, but the company declares that this is merely making a virtue of a necessity, for the reason that the strikers can't get back. Nominally the strike was still on; actually, it seemed to have become a thing of the past.

TRENTON, N.J., July 23. -- The Rev. Dr. Frank P. Parkin of the State Street Methodist Church referred to Col. Ingersoll in his sermon to-night. He said Col. Ingersoll's teachings were responsible for such crimes as that of bank wrecker Valentine. Ingersollism taught a general moral laxity, it created alleged excuses for suicides, theft, and all forms of wrongdoing.

WASHINGTON, July 23. -- Secretary Alger has always felt pride in the manner in which the War Department met the problem thrust upon it by the necessity with which it was suddenly confronted during the war with Spain of disposing of the thousands of Spanish prisoners captured in Santiago Province.

CITY OF MEXICO, July 23. -- Commenting on the present outlook here. The Mexican Herald says: "Whoever thinks that J. Pierpont Morgan is going to stop with selling $25,000,000 Mexican gold bonds does not know that great financier, whose plans are continental in their scope, and now begin to embrace Mexico's business and financial field.

ASBURY PARK, July 23. -- The closing session of the biennial convention of the Ladies' Catholic Benevolent Association of the United States continued until nearly midnight, Saturday. The delegates spent the entire day in electing three Trustees, there being so many candidates for this position.

LEXINGTON, Ky., July 23. -- Major P.P. Johnston, formerly Chairman of the Democratic State Central and State Executive Committees, who was superceded last month by Allie Young, is bitterly opposed to the election of William Goebel, who was nominated for Governor by the Democratic State Convention.

The family of the swindling cashier of the bank in Perth Amboy have offered to make up to the depositors in the savings bank the fear thousand dollars that he stole from that institution. If, as is stated, they are in no wise obliged by law to do this, it is a generous and creditable act.

BRISTOL, R.I., July 23. -- The cup defender Columbia came up from Newport this afternoon in tow of her tender and anchored about half a mile off from the Herreshoff dock. The new steel mast is all ready for stepping, but first the Columbia will be hauled on the ways for a short distance that her underbody may be cleaned. The cradle for hauling her out is all ready.

The list of entries for the twenty-seventh annual regatta of the National Association of Amateur Oarsmen was decided upon at a meeting of the Regatta Committee yesterday afternoon at the Marlborough Hotel. F.R. Fortmeyer, the Secretary of the association, said that it was confidently expected that this year's regatta would be a finer one than any yet held.

CHICAGO, July 23. -- Arrangements for the Fourteenth National Convention of former soldiers of the German Army now living in the United States have nearly been completed. The convention will be held from Aug. 13 to 15 inclusive. More than 5,000 ex-soldiers with their families and friends will come to Chicago from all parts of the country.

TOLEDO, Ohio, July 23. -- The Cincinnati, Hamilton and Dayton Elevator, situated in East Toledo, was totally destroyed by fire to-night. The loss on building and contents is nearly $1,000,000. It is not known how much insurance there is on the 900,000 bushels of wheat burned, but on the building there is $185,000 in various companies.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 23. -- The Trustees' ball at the Shinnecock Hills Golf Club took place last night, and, despite the threatening weather, there was a large attendance. The full moon upon which much reliance had been placed to lend to the affair a romantic effect was not in evidence.

-- Long and disquietingly businesslike is the "libel" against the Spanish fleet defeated at Manila and the military supplies captured in the Cavite arsenal, which Admiral DEWEY has filed in the Supreme Court of the District of Columbia as the basis of his claim for prize money for himself, his officers, and his crews.

LONDON, July 23. -- The cloud has lifted from the money market as swiftly as it arose. On Wednesday an easier tendency first began to display itself, and dealers with credit began to think that the bank rate need not necessarily be changed. No change was made, and the weekly bank statement indicated that the absorption of gold and notes into circulation had paused, if not come to an end.

A correspondent takes THE TIMES sharply to task for what he calls its defense of combinations in industry and trade, commonly called trusts. He argues that the protective tariff being the father of trusts, we cannot hold that the trusts have been of some advantage to the country without repudiating all that we have ever said against protection.

Policeman Edwards of the Clymer Street Station, Brooklyn, trapped an alleged burglar yesterday in the grocery of John Dietjen, at Lynch Street and Lee Avenue. The prisoner is John Bierenger, fifteen years old, whose parents live at Williams Street and Atlantic Avenues, Maspeth.

The conference which meets on Sunday in the rooms of the Social Reform Club, under the Chairmanship of Edward King, discussed the Brooklyn and Manhattan surface railroad strikes last night with vigor. The most interesting feature of the meeting was the reading by Mr. King of a letter from the Rev. Father Ducey, pastor of St. Leo's Roman Catholic Church.
WASHINGTON, July 23. -- Ex-Secretary Hoke Smith, who is in Washington to-day, was interviewed on the subject of the campaign in the Philippines. He said:

CHICAGO, July 23. -- The Chicago platform Democrats are much aggrieved that Mr. Bryan has joined forces with the Harrison-Gahan-Watson machine. They intend to lay their grievances before Senator Jones, Chairman of the National Committee, and ask his support in organizing the news standing committees in their interest.

Notwithstanding the efforts of the United States Fish Commission to restock the waters along the New England coast with lobsters, the annual supply of 2,500,000 pounds from Maine is nearly exhausted, and the Government, having become alarmed, has sent the Fish Commission steamer Grampus, Capt. Griffin, to this coast to buy female lobsters and transplant them at the hatcheries in Gloucester.

LONDON, July 23. -- The third season of grand opera at Covent Garden under the direction of Mr. Maurice Grau closes tomorrow evening. Financially it has been the most successful of the three, and artistically it has been equally as gratifying. Among its brilliant features have been the reintroduction to the London public of Mme.

CHICAGO, July 23. -- For fifty minutes this morning Lincoln Park became a Sahara, and had a genuine ostrich hunt. The conclusion of the exciting chase found the ostrich transformed from a land bird into a waterfowl, and disclosed Animal Keeper De Vry backed up against a tree giving reasons that made him believe the ostrich had contemplated committing suicide when it effected its escape from the Zoo at sunrise.

Again and for the third time ex-Commandant Comte WALSIN-ESTERHAZY has confessed that he wrote the bordereau. For the third time he presents the supplement: "I wrote it by the orders of Col. SANDHERR to establish material proof against DREYFUS where moral proof already existed."

MANILA, May 25. -- Again during the past week the Governor General has been visited by another commission purporting to come from Aguinaldo, and again their proposals for "an armistice to enable the leaders to consult the wishes of their countrymen" has been rejected. The fact is, as mentioned in previous correspondence, the military contingent of the disaffected has seemingly all to say.

ROME July 23. -- The Popolo Romano, referring to the recent lynchings of Italians at Tallulah, La., says the United States has given assurances that it will prosecute rigorously all who were concerned in the commission of the crime.

PEORIA, Ill., July 23. -- Memorial services in memory of the late Col. Robert G. Ingersoll, who was for many years a prominent resident of Peoria, were held in the Tabernacle here this afternoon. Over 500 of the dead orator's old-time friends were in attendance, quite a number being members of his old regiment, the Eleventh Illinois Cavalry.

Justice BEEKMAN has decided that the law of 1898 was violated by Fire Commissioner SCANNELL in removing two firemen whose positions had been taken from the competitive schedule by the City Civil Service Commission without the approval of the State Commission. The men will now be restored, and will hold their places under the new rules.

BUFFALO, July 23. -- The police allowed but one inning of the Buffalo-Minneapolis game to be played to-day. Then the eighteen players were arrested, taken to the police station, and bailed out by President Franklin of the home club. No attempt was made to resume the game.

There was a notable increase in immigration during the fiscal year ended June 30. The Immigration Bureau reports the total at 311,707, as against 229,299 for the preceding fiscal year. The number is by no means so great, however, as in past years of great prosperity, when this country seemed all gold to the impoverished and struggling peoples of the Old World.

WASHINGTON, July 23. -- Articles required in manufacturing and food stuffs not produced in the United States form the largest items of the increase in importations in the fiscal year just ended. The Treasury Bureau of Statistics has prepared a statement covering all articles or classes of articles of which the importation increased or decreased as much as $1,000,000.

I am glad to learn from your editorial in to-day's issue that The Tribune has raised a protest against the absurd, annoying, and useless alteration of position in the names of streets on the public lamps. In the first place, may I ask whether the former method to which we were accustomed was a subject of complaint, necessitating alteration?

HAVANA, July 23. -- William Willard Howard, General Manager of the Cuban Industrial Relief Fund, speaks hopefully of the work being done at the two relief farms at Cieba Mocha, twelve miles west of Matanzas, where the managers have applications for more employment than they have funds to provide for.

OCEAN GROVE, N.J., July 23. -- "Floral Day," the anniversary of the organization of the Young People's Meeting, was observed at the camp meetings here to-day. Both the temple and auditorium were elaborately decorated with flags, palms, potted plants, and cut flowers. Hundreds of clergymen from all parts of the country were present and joined in the celebration.

YORK, Neb., July 23. -- Capt. Grant M. Tod, who was arrested in Deadwood at the instance of the York Mining Company, has started for this place with the Sheriff, having abandoned habeas corpus proceedings. A sensation in social as well as business circles was created here by Tod's arrest. He came from New York a year ago and posed as an officer of the British Army and a mining expert.

The hull of the new torpedo boat destroyer Bailey, which is being built for the United States Navy by the Gas Engine and Power Company, at their works at Morris Heights on the Harlem River, is completed with the exception of a few finishing touches, and it is hoped that the new craft will be launched about July 29, when a favorable tide is expected.

WASHINGTON, July 23. -- The Department of Agriculture has received through the Department of State notice that the Imperial Free Economical Society of St. Petersburg will hold an exhibition of Russian dairy products and an international exhibition of machines, apparatus, kinds of packing, and appliances for transportation of milk products at St. Petersburg during September, 1899.

Developments favorable to the security market are due. Announcements of important accomplishments from important quarters may be expected. There has been some waiting upon money market conditions, but in the view of influential interests there is no further occasion for apprehension over a scarcity of funds or squeezes in rates.

The textile markets all continue to show activity, and even the knit goods division has sprung into life. Travelers are on the road, and some Spring lines have already been shown, although reports do not say that much business has been done as yet. Cotton goods are active, and some of the Fall printed goods have been well sold up.
GREENOCK, July 23. -- Sir Thomas Lipton's America's Cup challenger Shamrock arrived to-day at Rothesay, Island of Bute.

HAVANA, July 23. -- The commission of prominent Cuban lawyers appointed by Gen. Ludlow to decide upon and report as to the best methods to be adopted for checking public gambling, recently made a complete report, which was referred to Mayor Lacoste.

LONDON, July 24. -- All the morning papers publish editorials expressing congratulation on the immense success of the athletic meeting at the Queen's Club on Saturday and expressing the hope that it will not be the last of such contests. All compliment the members of the American team upon their splendid performances.

RICHMOND, Va., July 23. -- The campaign for the United States Senatorship is now in full swing and promises to be an unusually interesting one. The candidates are Thomas S. Martin and Gov. J. Hoge Tyler. The former, who defeated Gen. Fitzhugh Lee in the memorable contest four years ago, is an aspirant for re-election.

A notable engineering feat was done yesterday by the substitution of a new 500-ton drawbridge for an old and much lighter one where the Pennsylvania Railroad tracks cross the Passaic River near the Market Street Station, Newark. The actual substitution of one bridge for the other was made in eighteen minutes and a half.

TRENTON, N.J., July 23. -- Wilbur Reed, a fifteen-year-old Trenton boy, had a thrilling experience with a burglar at the home of his uncle, Charles A. Reed, at Reed's Mills, between this city and Pennington, yesterday. The burglar, who apparently was a tramp, had entered the house and was packing some silverware when young Reed walked in.

Although the trolley strikes in the city are practically dead, they will in all probability not be called off officially for quite some time yet, or at least until the new labor political movement born at the labor conference held at the Grand Central Palace at the instance of General Master Workman Parsons is well under way.

CHICAGO, July 24. -- A dispatch from Ames. Iowa, says: "Prof. D.A. Kent, late of the Iowa State Agricultural College, has been selected as an instructor in farming to the Turkish Empire. The Sultan needed a man versed in the cultivation of wheat, corn, and fruits, and requested the Turkish representative at Washington to procure such a person.

Edwards of 123 Duffield Street, who accuses Mrs. De Brinke of sending her threatening letters.

One Hundred and Forty-second and One Hundred and Forty-third Streets, but if any of them were successful they guarded their knowledge very carefully.
HALIFAX, N.S., July 24. -- A steamer, reported to be the Daniel, entered the harbor this afternoon, towing the steamer Alnmere, which is disabled. The Alnmere halls from Newcastle, England.
CINCINNATI, July 24. -- Cincinnati is at present threatened with an epidemic of stomach trouble, due practically to embalmed meat.

The strikers in Cleveland, who declared on Saturday that force could be used with advantage to attain their ends, were not slow in acting on their theory. On Sunday evening a car run by "scabs" was blown to flinders, and several passengers were injured, two of them probably fatally. What do the strikers gain by this?
Daly's Theatre passed yesterday into the hands of Charles Frohman.

WASHINGTON, July 24. -- There has been much more of astonishment than alarm here following the speeches of Sir Charles Tupper and Sir Wilfrid Laurier in Ottawa on the Alaskan boundary question. Both of these gentlemen, in the course of their remarks, gave some account of the reasons that inspire this Government to make it firm and calm, but the attitude of the Department of State has never been quarrelsome.

NEWPORT, July 24. -- Woodbury Kane, Herman B. Duryea, and Ralph N. Ellis, who constitute the Regatta Committee of the Newport Yacht Racing Association, have decided to have additional races for trophies besides those offered for the Columbia-Defender races.

James H. Eckels, Controller of the Currency in the second Cleveland Administration, and now President of the Commercial National Bank of Chicago, was asked by a TIMES reporter at the Holland House last night for his views on the financial and political outlook. He said:

NEWPORT, July 24. -- The first paper chase of the season occurred at Jamestown this afternoon and was enjoyed by a large number of Newport cottagers, who will have a similar event at Jamestown each Monday afternoon during the season, only that in the last chase a live fox will be used. Quite a number of cottagers followed the chase in their carriages and saw a good afternoon of sport.

LONDON, July 25. -- Early this morning thousands of newsboys are shouting that President Kruger has resigned. A dispatch from Johannesburg says that he has done so on account of revelations concerning the dynamite monopoly. If half of what returned prisoners have related be true, this is not wonderful, as it is said he is deeply implicated.

LONDON, July 24. -- The disposal of the large estate which practically controls the finest views of the lakes of Killarney is the cause of keen disappointment to many wealthy Irishmen residing in England.

Despite the fact that the courts have held the Ahearn law to be unconstitutional, claimants arise on every side. Twenty-seven new claims were filed with Controller Coler yesterday. The largest of these was that of Acting Deputy Chief of Police William W. McLaughlin, who demanded $35,751.91 for expenses incurred in defending himself against an indictment for bribery in accepting $25 from a contractor for permitting him to use the sidewalk for storing building material.
LONDON, July 24. -- The opera season closed to-night-with "Romeo and Juliet," Mme. Melba appearing as the heroine.

BOSTON, Mass., July 24. -- The Longwood lawn tennis tournament opened here to-day, and if the entry list is any criterion, the play will surpass that in any tournament of the year except Newport. The principal features of the week are the scratch singles for the Eastern championship and the Longwood Challenge Bowl now held by the champion, Mr. Whitman.

CLEVELAND, July 24. -- Rioting broke out afresh here to-night and a second attempt to wreck a car was made. A Pearl Street car, speeding south near Holmenden Avenue, carrying, besides the motorman and conductor, a guard, successfully ran a gantlet of missiles thrown from the roofs of houses, only to run upon a can of nitroglycerine, which exploded with terrific force.

LONDON, July 24. -- The attention of all England is again turned toward the Transvaal. The Times says Premier Schreiner of Cape Colony cannot incite Kruger to make further concessions. This statement is generally accepted as reasonable in the face of Schreiner's explanation that he advised Kruger to wait until he heard from the Imperial Government.

PITTSBURG, July 24. -- Pittsburg won two games to-day by remarkable finishes. Williams was the star in the first game and Beaumont in the second. In the first Leever gave four hits and three runs in the first inning and allowed no more until the ninth, when five hits and five runs were made. In Pittsburg's half of the ninth, with Beaumont and McCarthy on bases, Williams made a home run.

An individual signing himself "A Horrid Man" writes to THE TIMES: "The advocates of what is popularly called 'The Cause of Women' cannot make much capital of the reception given by Queen Victoria at Windsor to a few prominent delegates to the international Congress of Women in London."

LONDON, July 25. -- All the morning papers devote editorials to the closing of the International Peace Conference at The Hague, and note with satisfaction the progress made in the direction of arbitration, which, cheapened by the institution of a permanent court, will tend to a more wide resort to arbitration in minor disputes, and, if successful, will accustom the powers to its gradual extension to more serious matters.

A meeting of the State Railroad Commission was held yesterday at the Fifth Avenue Hotel, and the feature of the proceedings was the application made by the Third Avenue Railroad Company of this city for permission to increase its capital stock from $12,000,000 to $40,000,000. This is to pay for a change of motive power on Third Avenue and Forty-second Street and a floating debt of $10,000,000.

LONDON, July 27. -- The speech of Sir Wilfrid Laurier on Saturday has provoked much comment here. The majority of the newspaper head lines quote the words "Arbitration or War." All the papers scout the idea of war and say in effect that there cannot be war. The St. James's Gazette said yesterday:
Some 2,000 or more residents of the east side were yesterday in various stages of convalescence from the effects of a pleasure excursion in which they had participated on Sunday.

My attention has just been called to an editorial in your issue of Friday, June 30 ultimo. The editorial is under the heading, "The Crime of Doing Business." As you refer to a ruling which I made, and as you have exactly reversed the position which I took, and in doing so you placed both myself and the State in a false attitude, I trust that you will make the proper correction.

NEWPORT, July 24. -- To-day there is little else talked of here save the report that the crew of the Columbia has become very restless and might send a round robin to Mr. Iselin, the managing owner of the Columbia, asking that a change be made in the command of the yacht.

Yale's failure to win a single point in the recent international athletic meet in London still further intensified the unfortunate condition of Yale's athletic record during the past year. It is no wonder that the athletic advisers and old-time managers and coaches realize that some radical changes must be made before another college year opens, and the recent meeting of Yale men in New Haven shows how seriously the situation is regarded.

WASHINGTON, July 24. -- At the time Capt. Crowninshield was appointed Chief of the Bureau of Navigation, just at the beginning of President McKinley's Administration, the place had been offered to Capt. Henry C. Taylor, then in command of the battleship Indiana.

The striking newsboys held a rousing mass meeting in New Irving Hall, on Broome Street, near Norfolk Street, last night. They were to have had a parade with a band of music prior to the meeting, but for reasons explained at the meeting by "Racetrack Higgins" this feature of the demonstration was abandoned. Chief of Police Devery had refused to give the necessary permit.

For the first time since the wabbling of the price of silver began, nearly a quarter of a century ago, and the question of exchange became a bothersome one to the Government of India, a committee of experts has come to a unanimous conclusion as to the direction to be taken by the policy of the empire.

Nothing could be handsomer or more satisfactory to Americans than the manner in which the result of the athletic meeting at the Queen's Club has been treated by the London press. Of course it has received a good deal more attention upon international grounds than it was entitled to intrinsically as a "sporting event."

AUSTIN, Texas, July 24. -- The Mexican Government has refused to grant the application for the extradition of John Keeton, in jail at Juarez, Mexico, on a charge of complicity in the robbery of a Texas and Pacific passenger train and the killing of the fireman, over a year ago. The ground for the refusal is that the new extradition treaty contains no authority for the extradition of an accomplice in crime.

-- It is now thirty-six years since there appeared in The Atlantic Monthly an unsigned short story entitled "The Man Without a Country." The name of the author did not long remain a mystery, and the tale of Philip Nolan's crime and punishment won and has always retained an amount of fame that is rarely secured by literary works of size and kind in any land.

HAVANA, July 24. -- The rainy season having begun in earnest, Gen. Ludlow has issued instructions to his command, saying that, though he is satisfied with the existing conditions and arrangements, he thinks extra care may be beneficial.

It has remained for a British sea Captain, just arrived from England, and full of enthusiasm over the new cup challenger, to start the betting ball a-rolling on the coming international yacht races. The news of his offer to bet 1,000 even on the Shamrock appears, however, to have been for private circulation, and so far as can be learned, his offer has found no takers.

CLEVELAND, July 24. -- The grand circuit races began to-day with favorable weather and track conditions, but the attendance was somewhat disappointing, owing in the main to the street railroad strike. There were four events on the programme -- the 2:14 trot, 2:16 pace, 2:27 pace, and 2:19 trot. Only two races were finished, one being postponed entirely and the other going over unfinished. In appointing Mr. ELIHU ROOT Secretary of War the President chose the best possible way to make the people speedily forget ALGER and Algerism. He evidently resolved not merely to undo his former error, but to make the correction so emphatic and conspicuous that it should arrest attention and command universal approval.

Yesterday in Wall Street was the dullest day of the Summer. Total transactions were small, fluctuations insignificant. Interest of any sort appeared nowhere. Even the bear contingent was inclined to rest.

The letter in your issue of July 20 which discusses the beginning of the new era awakened sympathy in my mind for that vast majority of naive thinkers who still insist that the twentieth century begins with Jan. 1, 1900 A.D. To say that the Christian age is divided into periods of 100 years each, the first beginning with the year 1, , is true enough, but does not reveal the real difficulty.

The three days' celebration of the fortieth anniversary of the organization of the Equitable Life Assurance Society was opened yesterday morning in the Astor Gallery of the Waldorf-Astoria. Several hundred agents assembled to hear the address of welcome by President James W. Alexander.

Recent catches of salt-water fish, particularly bluefish and weakfish, have forced wholesale prices up sharply and placed such fish almost out of reach of the poorer classes. Old fishermen and experts in the business have been depressed by the poor catches and unfavorable conditions, but when they were lucky enough to make a good haul their profits amounted, for the number of pounds sold, to much more than at any time for years.

LEXINGTON, Ky., July 24. -- The opposition to William Goebel did some hard work to-day in the various parts of the State. Mass meetings were held in several counties, at which delegates were elected to attend the Lexington meeting on Aug. 2, when a formal call for a State Convention will be issued.

It is announced that Mr. PAUL BARTLETT'S model for the monument to LAFAYETTE to be erected by subscriptions of the school children of the United States has been accepted by the municipal authorities of Paris, upon the recommendation of the Architect of the Louvre, under whose supervision the monument is to be erected.

TRIESTE, July 24. -- A correspondent of the Associated Press to-day visited Admiral Dewey on board his flagship Olympia and was cordially received. Admiral Dewey said that although he had received many invitations from Americans sojourning at Carlsbad, he had never intended going there.
The vestry of St. Mark's Protestant Episcopal Church, Second Avenue and Tenth Street, has unanimously called the Rev. Dr. Loring W. Batten as rector, and he has accepted.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Col., July 24. -- In referring to the recent attack on the electric line by fanatical natives in Seoul, Korea, E.E. Rittenhouse of this city, who was connected with the construction of the road, said:

GREENWICH, Conn., July 24. -- Commodore E.C. Benedict defeated his son Frederick in a naphtha launch race off Greenwich on Saturday, and Tuesday night will give a dinner at the Indian Harbor Yacht Club house in celebration of the event. The Commodore owns a twenty-foot naphtha launch called the Oneida, after the Commodore's large steam yacht.
THE HAGUE, July 24. -- The final act embodying the results of the International Peace Conference, after enumerating the names and qualifications of all the delegates, says:

BOWLING GREEN, Ky., July 24. -- The anti-Goebel meeting here to-day was largely attended. Ex-Congressman W.C. Owens sent a letter condemning the nomination of Goebel for Governor and criticising the work of the Louisville Convention generally.

Racegoers who made the journey to the Brighton Beach race track were put all at sea in their calculations yesterday, for they have been so used to a clear day and a dry track this year that the overcast sky, the drizzling rain and in consequence the sloppy track left them without much chance of getting a line of the work in such going of the horses in the several events.

PRETORIA, July 24. -- President Kruger had been absent from the Government Building since Friday afternoon, and it was understood that, owing to the opposition shown him by the Executive Council and the Volksraad regarding the questions of the Johannesburg fort and the dynamite monopoly, he had arrived at the conclusion that he no longer possessed the Volksraad's confidence and threatened to resign.

WASHINGTON, July 24. -- The long pending reciprocity treaty negotiations between the United States and France were brought to a successful close at the State Department late this afternoon, when Ambassador Cambon, in behalf of France, and Commissioner Kasson, in behalf of the United States, affixed their signatures to the treaty.

SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, July 24. -- Francis B. Loomis, United States Minister to Venezuela, who is here on a visit to relatives of his wife, was with President McKinley in Washington when Alger brought in his resignation. Speaking of the matter to-day he said:

Senator John F. Ahearn formally launched his boom for Sheriff yesterday, and, incidentally, gave a steamboat load of east side voters a hot time and had the lower east side painted a vivid red, besides other colors. The weather was about as bad as it could be for a Summer excursion, but, as one excursionist remarked, "wedder don't bodder de gang, see?"

The sub-committee of the United States Industrial Commission whose special line of inquiry is the condition of labor and capital employed in general business, which includes the subject of immigration, began its hearings in this city at the Chamber of Commerce yesterday. Only three members were present -- ex-Congressman John M. Farquhar of Buffalo, Ellison A. Smythe of North Carolina, and Col. Albert Clark of Boston.

Thanks for your yesterday's editorial, "Building for the Future," to which I say amen. Argus-eyed sociologists who have studied the race troubles of the South and the alienation between labor and capital of the North see the adjustment of these conditions in the epoch-making movement inaugurated by the Newport News Shipbuilding Company and "contractors in Portsmouth," (Va.,) in the employment of negro labor, which "gave such satisfaction that more were asked for."

WASHINGTON, July 25. -- Lieut. Commander J.C. Fremont, United States Navy, Supervisor of the Harbor of New York, has submitted to Gen. Wilson Chief of Engineers, a very exhaustive report upon the conditions of that harbor. The report is extremely satisfactory to Gen. Wilson, as it gives all the desired information upon the harbor and what is being done for its preservation.
WASHINGTON, July 25. -- The features of the Cabinet meeting to-day were the farewell of Secretary Alger and the presentation of his successor, Mr. Root.
ADELAIDE, Australia, July 25. -- 0scar Gerard, an American comedian, who has been playing here with "The Belle of New York" company, is dead.

WASHINGTON, July 25. -- The thirty-fourth annual report of the Secret Service Division, submitted to Secretary Gage by Chief Wilkie to-day, shows that in the fiscal year ended June 30, 1899, there were arrested for making or passing counterfeit money and similar crimes, 679 persons. Of these 218 were convicted and 293 are awaiting the action of the courts.

SOUTHAMPTON, N.Y., July 25. -- A driving rainstorm did not prevent the golfers from taking part in the annual invitation tournament of the Shinnecock Hills Golf Club, which began to-day, and will continue through the week. Those who made an early start were thoroughly drenched before they left the first tee on their long journey over the links. Of the 116 entries, there were 104 starters.

The only chance for disagreeable outcome in the matter of the Alaska boundary dispute lies in the secrecy that has been observed officially on both sides as to the essential steps in the negotiations. We are aware that the traditions of diplomacy require great reserve in matters still pending, but the traditions are old and musty and deeply charged with the bacilli of irritation.

There is a hearing set down for this morning in the Supreme Court in Brooklyn on the application made by the State for the appointment of a receiver for the New York National Building and Loan Association, of which J.N. Walter is President.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 25. -- A meeting was held here to-night in furtherance of the plan of disaffected Democrats, to effect an organization in this State, hold a convention and nominate a State ticket in opposition to the one headed by William Goebel, who was nominated here in June.

HATTIESBURG, Miss., July 25. -- Henry Novels, a negro, who attacked Miss Rosaline Davis Saturday evening, was captured yesterday, and was identified by Miss Davis. He was immediately tied to a tree and shot to death by the angry crowd.

Petras Bedneyeff, an Armenian, arrived at the Barge Office yesterday, having traveled all the way from the Orient in search of good set of false teeth, of which he stands sadly in need. Hhe carried in his belt $1,675, in gold, and was considered a Croesus in his native land, but the tooth question saddened his whole life.

The Hague conference ends with the recommendation to the Governments represented of three conventions or treaties, of which the most important relates to "the pacific settlement of international disputes." The others, relating to the laws and customs of war on land, are not radical in the changes they propose, nor do they have so nearly the unanimous support of the delegates.
CLEVELAND, July 25. -- The presence of a large body of troops in the city has prevented any serious disturbance by the street-car strikers and their friends.
LONDON, July 26. -- The South African question remains in statu quo. Advices from the Cape say that Krueger resigned only conditionally.

SHELTER ISLAND, N.Y., July 25. -- The board of naval officers appointed to examine into and report on the application of the Holland Torpedi Boat Company to change the motive power of the submarine boat Plunger met at the Manhanset House to-day. The Plunger is now under construction at Baltimore, where the board held its previous meetings.

Your issue of to-day contains the solution of the street-lamp problem of how to benefit the trolley riders by placing cross-street signs where they can be read from the cars. Put the lamp signs back to their old positions. Let the Commissioner duplicate the cross-street numbers or names on the car-track side of the lamps, and the thing is done.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., July 25. -- Albert Behrman of 341 South Street, Philadelphia, a guest at the Howland Hotel, was found dead in his room this afternoon. Death is supposed to have been due to heart disease, although there are rumors of suicide. Behrman had been at the hotel for one week, and little is known of him.

Through an advertisement that appeared in one of yesterday morning's papers asking for information concerning Frank Camera, thirty-seven years old, the mother of the man learned that her son ad been killed by a Long Island Railroad train on Friday, and that his body was in the Morgue in Long Island City.

A rumor that 41 and 43 Wall Street, running through to 45 and 47 Exchange Place, had been sold, caused something of a stir in down-town realty circles yesterday. The property is owned by the heirs of Christopher Roberts, for whom R.M. Gallaway, President of the Merchants' National Bank, is trustee.

CHICAGO, July 25. -- "There may be a prospect that the people of Chicago can put two teaspoonfuls of sugar in their coffee without bankrupting their savings accounts if some of the wholesalers in this city do not come to terms quickly," said Manager Watson of Franklin, MacVeagh Co. to-day.

PRINCETON, N.J., July 25. -- The citizens of this town were awakened from their sleep last night by the sound of several pistol shots fire by Night Watchman Adams in his efforts to capture two men who were forcing an entrance to Prof. Paul Van Dyke's new house in Library Street.

PERTH AMBOY, N.J., July 25. -- The City Council last night voted to issue $40,000 more in bonds to meet the exigencies of the City Government, resulting from the wrecking of the Middlesex County Bank. Mayor Compton recommended that four-fifths of the licenses account be transferred to the sinking fund, and that for the present work on all public improvements be stopped.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 25. -- San Francisco has witnessed another of the war horrors which have made this Nation sick at heart. The hospital ship Morgan City came into port with 500 sick and wounded fighters from the Philippine war. They were weak and wasted. Some of them could not leave their beds.

THE HAGUE, July 25. -- An arrangement was agreed to to-day with regard to the objection raised by the American delegates to the International Peace Conference to the use of the word "duty" in Article 27 of the final act in a way that would imply an obligation on the part of the United States to interfere in disputes between European Governments, and vice versa.

Magistrate Crane, in the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday, successfully pleaded the case of Louis E. Wilson, an eighteen-year-old lad who was brought before him for stealing $18.90 from the Scovill Adams Company. Wilson had worked for the company for two months, and failed to turn in the money he received from a purchaser.

NEWPORT, July 25. -- Before the War College class this morning Capt. B.H. McCalla read a paper entitled "Lessons of the Late War," continuing his subject, "The Want of Preparation for War." He said, in conclusion:

The committee appointed by the shareholders to investigate the affairs of the Mercantile Co-operative Bank of New York met at the banking house at Lexington Avenue and Twenty-third Street at noon yesterday and remained in session until 6 o'clock. The investigation will be continued to-day.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., July 25. -- The Commercial Law League of America opened its annual convention in the assembly room of the Brunswick, here, this morning. The address of welcome was made by Mayor Ten Broeck, and Judge David Harvey, Jr., William A. Wright of New Haven, and J. Lane Stern of Richmond responded. Mr. Stern read a number of telegrams supposed to have been received from prominent persons.

LONDON, July 26. -- The Daily Mail this morning, in a rather strong editorial on the Alaskan boundary dispute, contends that the interpretation of the treaty is preeminently a matter for arbitration. "Yet," says The Daily Mail, "the United States declines to arbitrate simply because the political pressure from the Pacific States is so strong that the President fears his reelection might be endangered if he took the just course.

NEWPORT, July 25. -- Rain interfered with the outside entertainments to-day, and but for the Golf Club the cottagers, for the most part, would have been compelled to remain indoors. Despite the rain, there were quite a number of bathers at Bailey's Beach.

HIOGO, July 4. -- All Japan is talking of the changes which will be wrought in the status of foreigners in this country when the new treaties go into effect. The effect of the treaties may best be shown by a sketch of the conditions existing to-day.

WASHINGTON, July 25. -- The acuteness of the Alaskan boundary situation has been so much relieved as a result of the conferences yesterday between Secretary Hay and the British Charge, Mr. Tower, that those who have taken most active part in the negotiations feel they can leave the city for a Summer Vacation.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., July 25. -- The funeral of Mrs. Charles H. Barnes, the Christian Scientist, was held from her home this evening. The ceremonies were conducted according to the custom of Christian Scientists without a token of mourning or an acknowledgment of the presence of death. Mrs. Laura Lathrop, first reader of the Christian Science Church of New York, officiated, assisted by Mr. Allison Butts, and J. Edward Smith.

WASHINGTON, July 25. -- Capt. A.S. Barker, who succeeded Admiral Dewey in command of the United States naval forces in the Philippines, has made a report to the Navy Department, dated Manila, June 13, 1899, giving an account of naval operations in and about Manila since he took command. He says, in part:

BOSTON, July 25. -- A dispatch from Ottawa says that a statement as to the facts in the Alaska boundary dispute, from the Canadian standpoint, has been given out by a high official, whose position renders it certain that every word he says in this matter is absolutely authoritative.

When the Kaiser of Germany starts out to conciliate anybody he slavers him all over, like the anaconda in GOLDSMITH'S "Animated Nature." But between his national and his personal effusion he seems to be in danger of going a little too far.

Fire on the roof of the seven-story Windermere apartment house, at Fifty-seventh Street and Ninth Avenue, caused a panic among the tenants at 3 o'clock yesterday morning and resulted in considerable damage. Robert C. Goodsell, Superintendent of the house, lives in specially, constructed apartments on the roof of 400, where he had a little garden and some chickens and pigeons.

Health Officer Doty yesterday gave a brief summary of the treatment of yellow fever by the use of the new serum, in the case of Oscar F. Lackey, who contracted the disease at Santiago, Cuba, and arrived at this port on the transport McClelland, July 6. Mr. Lackey was discharged as cured July 24.

Miss Annie M. Jones, daughter of the Rev. Griffith Jones, the first Welsh Bishop in the United States, walked into Bellevue Hospital yesterday afternoon and asked to be examined as to her sanity. She was held for observation.

AUSTIN, Texas, July 25. -- The Attorney General's department has received information of the consolidation of six of the largest cottonseed oil companies in Texas into one corporation, named the Continental Cotton Oil Company, with headquarters in New York City.

One of the conspicuous traits of Col. John McAnerney, President of the Seventh National Bank, is his attachment to the officers of the institution, and not infrequently he exhibits it in most substantial fashion. Yesterday Cashier George W. Adams's face glowed with satisfaction as he showed his friends a handsome watch and chain.

The latest dispatches seem to leave it doubtful whether the disagreement of President KRUEGER with his Volksraad has or has not led him to the length of resigning his office. It is quite certain that there is nobody else capable of guiding the republic with so sure a hand. There is nobody else so capable of withstanding the successive waves of modern civilization that are breaking and advancing over the Transvaal.

BOSTON, July 25. -- Lawn tennis had to take a beck seat here to-day as dripping skies and sodden courts forced a day's postponement of the Eastern championship matches. It rained at intervals almost all day, but the committee managed to dispose of a few of the less important matches between the showers in the afternoon.
MONTREAL, July 25. -- A great sensation was caused here to-day by the news that the Villa Marie Bank, one of the oldest institutions in the city, had suspended payment.

A slight improvement in weather conditions yesterday afternoon was warmly welcomed by the thousands who since Saturday night last have been housed at the hundreds of coast and inland resorts, and who at the former have been shivering in hotels and boarding houses not fitted or built for cold or chilly weather.
CINCINNATI, Ohio, July 25. -- The strike of messenger boys that began last Saturday has reached serious conditions.

CHICAGO, July 25. -- Referees in bankruptcy for many States gathered at the Chicago Beach Hotel this morning to attend a three days' convention to discuss the practical workings of the new Bankruptcy act, and to consider plans for having the law amended to remedy it present defects.

The second of the three days' celebration of the fortieth anniversary of the founding of the Equitable Life Assurance Society was devoted yesterday to the convention of Equitable agents. The convention, which was held in the Astor Gallery of the Waldorf-Astoria, was opened at 10:30 o'clock in the morning.

Funeral exercises more simple than those held over the body of Col. Robert G. Ingersoll yesterday there could hardly be. From the fact of this very simplicity they were singularly impressive. The body lay uncoffined on the improvised bier upon which it has rested since Friday in the darkened room at Walston, on the heights of Dobbs Ferry, in which Col. Ingersoll passed away.

The hearing of the sub-committee of the United States Industrial Commission which is inquiring into the working of the immigration law at this port was resumed in the rooms of the Chamber of Commerce yesterday. The examination of Assistant Commissioner of Immigration McSweeney, who was on the stand when the committee adjourned Monday, was resumed.

Mrs. Ely E.F. Witthaus, who recently secured a divorce from her husband, Prof. Rudolph Witthaus, made application, through counsel, to Justice Stover, in the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, yesterday to have the terms of the divorce decree changed. At the time the decree was granted Mrs. Witthaus accepted $3,640 in a lump sum in lieu of all future alimony.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., July 25. -- Before Judge Barnard to-day there was a hearing in a sensational case from New Rochelle, involving an attempt on the part of the five children of Mrs. Rosaline Hill, formerly Liukert, a wealthy and aged woman, to restrain her from disposing of property valued at $60,000, which the children aver was accumulated by their father, Victor Liukert, and should be held in trust for them.

The anti-Bryan wing of the Democracy is to have a conference at Saratoga Springs early in August. Ex-Justice Augustus Van Wyck, the Democratic candidate for Governor of this State in the last election and a prospective candidate for the Presidential nomination, is already at the Springs. His brother, the Mayor, is expected there by the 1st of August, and so is John F. Carroll. Others are looked for a little later.

WASHINGTON, July 25. -- New vigor has been infused into the pension attorneys' campaign against Commissioner H. Clay Evans, and from now on until the September Encampment of the Grand Army of the Republic every kind of pressure will be brought to bear upon the President for his removal.

PARIS, July 25. -- At the meeting of the Cabinet this morning the Minister of War, Gen. Marquis de Galliffet, announced that Gen. d'Alstein had been appointed to the military command of Paris, vice Gen. Pellieux, who, the Minister said, had been appointed to the command of the Forty-fourth Brigade, located at Quimper, Department of Finistere.

More messenger boys struck yesterday at various points, a number returned to work -- for double pay, as they said -- and a good many new boys were engaged to take the places of strikers. At the Postal Building at 253 Broadway, Manager Wilson began hiring new boys in the morning and taking back those who had been frightened into the strike on Monday.

WASHINGTON, July 25. -- The Coast and Geodetic Survey has received a report from G.R. Putnam, who is out with a party at St. Michael, regarding the recently opened gold fields around Cape Nome.

BOSTON, July 26. -- Despite the continued unfavorable weather to-day, the Eastern championship lawn tennis tournament was continued this afternoon at the Longwood Cricket Club. It poured all the morning, but the clouds broke about 2 o'clock in the afternoon; and two hours later matches were in progress on several courts.
Increase of .$5,:{:4 in Chesapeake and Ohio's net earnings for June, making an increase of $126.205 for the fiscal year.

The house which is to be built for Andrew Carnegie on the block fronting Fifth Avenue, between Ninetieth and Ninety-first Streets, will be one of the finest private residences in the city. In one respect it will be the finest, for the large amount of land -- the whole width of the block -- acquired by Mr. Carnegie will make possible an elaborate scheme of landscape gardening, supplementing and completing the architecture of the house.

The Municipal Assembly met in joint session yesterday and received the report of the Joint Committee on Finance on the assessment rolls for the year 1899. No action was taken on the report, which was laid over for a week, and ordered printed in The City Record.

From all the indications the cruise of the New York Yacht Club this year will be the biggest affair of its kind that has ever taken place in American waters. In this respect it will be in keeping with the season's yachting affairs generally, the war last year and the following business prosperity having crowded the interest and activity of two seasons into one.

WASHINGTON, July 26. -- It is stated at the War Department that Gen. Otis has made no communications to the department regarding the organization of any provisional Governments in the islands or provinces, but it is presumed that he may be doing so if conditions warrant.

WASHINGTON, July 26. -- No information was received up to 9:30 to-night from the Consular representatives of the United State in San Domingo regarding the assassination there to-day of President Heureaux. Pending official advices of the assassination, no formal action will be taken by this Government.
As I am an enthusiastic New Yorker, and faithfully read your valuable paper, I am impelled to write you with regard to the existing state of our so-called "charitable" institutions.

SARATOGA, N.Y., July 26. -- The heavy showers of last night showed little or no effect on the Saratoga track to-day, and a good card, remarkably free from scratches, was run off in fast time. Swiftmas captured the fourth race in 1:48, which equals the track record. The crowd was rather light, but the society element was much larger than in former years.

UTICA, N.Y., July 26. -- The monument to Founder Rathbone of the Pythian Order was dedicated this afternoon with appropriate ceremony and unusual pomp. The parade moved at 2 o'clock and was an imposing one. In one of the carriages preceding the marching bands and companies were Miss Sarah D. Rathbone of Washington, and Miss Lucetta S. Rathbone of Alexandria, Va., daughters of the founder of the order.

SOUTHAMPTON, N.Y., July 26. -- The two young golfers, Harry Hollins, Jr., and George C. Clark, Jr., who had swept everything before them last year, even vanquishing such men as Walter J. Travis and Foxhall P. Keene in the semi-finals, Hollins winning and Clark being the runner up, and of whom so much had been expected this year, were both put out to-day in the first round of the match play for the President's Cup.

The final session in this city of the subcommittee of the United States Industrial Commission, which is probing the subject of immigration, was held at the Chamber of Commerce yesterday. The sub-committee after hearing several witnesses adjourned to meet in Washington in September.

Justice Stover, in the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, heard argument yesterday on the application of the Attorney General for an injunction and a receiver for the property of the New York National Building and Loan Association. The Attorney General was represented by Deputy Attorney General Coyne and George Hoadly of Hoadly, Lauterbach Johnson, and Lawyer Quinlan of Strauss Quinlan appeared for the association.

William Botler Duncan, Jr., the managing owenr of the yacht Defender, arrived in town from Bristol yesterday morning. He said that there would be no race on Saturday between the Columbia and the Defender for the reason that the Herreshoffs had failed to complete the work on the Columbia's steel mast at the time promised.

The striking freight handlers in this city met again yesterday at Hudson Hall in Spring Street, near Hudson Street, and great dissatisfaction was expressed with the Rev. Father Brady of St. Mary's Church, Jersey City, who dissuaded the 700 freight handlers employed by the Pennsylvania Railroad in Jersey City from striking.

The Montreal express which went out at 7:30 last night from the Grand Central Station carried Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt, the youngest son of Cornelius Vanderbilt, and three companions, who purpose to make a tour of the world. Mr. Vanderbilt's companions were Ernest Iselin, William F. Burden, and Douglas Cochran.

While Wall Street rests the rumor mongers display some disposition to be active. The Street is full of more or less sensational reports, the usual form of which is innuendo. Most of the representations bear evidences of invention. In so far as market effect is involved, nothing shows, but in a listless way the circulating fables get some attention.

EVANSVILLE, Ind., July 26. -- Rioting prevailed at two of the local mines to-day. As the colored non-union miners employed at the First Avenue Mine came from work they were met by a crowd of small boys, who carried tin horns and tin cans. They followed the miners for about a block and kept up a continual yell. Finally the negroes turned on the boys and pulled their pistols.

Burnett, United States District Attorney, in proceedings to condemn the jewelry alleged to have been smuggled into this country by Mrs. Phyllis E. Dodge, on June 24. The accounts which come from various sources of the terrible famine now raging in the Eastern Provinces of Russia show a very distressing and fearful state of affairs. The lack of crops in Russia, caused by the long-continued drought, has affected an immense tract of land, and millions of peasants are, in consequence, in a most distressing condition.

CAMDEN, N.J., July 26. -- Detectives Cherry and Smith to-day investigated the case of a boy being kept in close confinement for thirty-six days. The case was reported to the Prosecutor, and he directed that the investigation be made. The complaint was made by neighbors of the boy's parents, who claimed the boy was being ill-treated.

WASHINGTON, July 26. -- The State Department is anxious to know what has become of a murderer named Kelly, who at last accounts was held in a Japanese jail under sentence of seven years' imprisonment from the Consular Court at Yokohama.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., July 26. -- R.J. Smith, a business man of this city, regained to-day a diamond stud which he lost fifteen days ago. It was worth $100. He left it in a shirt which went to the laundry. At the laundry it disappeared. It was found to-day. It had been dumped into the street gutter with the wash water, and was close to the sewer opening when found.

Richard M. Montgomery Co. have sold for Henry Parish, as trustee, to William F. Havemeyer, the seven-story office building 67 Wall Street, on the southerly side of that thoroughfare, about 115 feet West of Pearl Street. The property adjoins 69 Wall Street, a similar building, already owned by Mr. Havemeyer, and on its westerly side the twelve-story Sampson Building.

The impudence of the Grand Army man in sending a committee to Washington to "investigate" the official conduct and policy of Pension Commissioner EVANS excited a good deal of indignation in communities where fraudulent pension-hunting is looked on with a proper degree of contempt as the most despicable business in which an American citizen can engage.

There were vacant spaces in the grand stand at the Brighton Beach race track yesterday and big breaks in the ranks of stools on which the bookmakers perch themselves in the betting ring, for not only have many of the "regulars" followed the scene of racing to Saratoga, but a number of bookmakers have done the same.

There are thousands of other Democrats, just as firmly attached to the cause of sound money and uncompromisingly hostile to Bryanism, who voted for MCKINLEY or did not vote at all.
FORT DE FRANCE, Martinique, July 26. -- Gen. Ulises Heureaux, President of the Republic of San Domingo, was assassinated at Moca at 4:30 o'clock this afternoon.

ALBANY, July 26. -- Controller William J. Morgan has written to Superintendent of Public Works Partridge refusing positively to pay T.J. Dwyer Co. the sum of $39,057.15, an alleged balance said to be due on a canal contract for improving the Erie Canal from the east line of Oneida County to Lock 46.

-- What was before simply our opinion as to the proper method of placing street name signs has now been changed into a firm conviction by action of the Board of Aldermen. That remarkable body has settled all doubts on the question by the adoption of a resolution instructing Commissioner KEARNY to innovate no more, and to put back in their own places such signs as he has changed.

WASHINGTON, July 26. -- Senator Morgan of Alabama may find his chance for a re-election to the Senate impaired by continued indifference or opposition to Col. Bryan. Representative Clayton of Alabama, who represented his State as a member of the National Committee at Chicago, comes here with a conviction that Bryan will be nominated, with the help of a solid delegation from Alabama.

LONG BEACH, L.I., July 26. -- An unhappy resemblance made trouble here yesterday evening for Paul T. Kenny of Brooklyn. He has been a guest at the hotel, and among his fellow guests was a man known as C.E. Merrill. There was a strong resemblance between the two men, which was frequently remarked.

NEWPORT, July 26. -- Capt. H.C. Taylor of the Indiana, who now commands the North Atlantic Squadron, and who was formerly President of the War College gave a lecture on the subject of naval tactics this morning. In the course of his remarks he said:

BAR HARBOR, Me., July 26. -- After a long delay, the season opened to-night with a decidedly brilliant and successful dance at the Malverne. Society here, especially the younger set, has been waiting impatiently for an opportunity to dance, and the most was made of the occasion to-night. Saturday night there will be another dance, and during August these affairs will be given regularly twice a week.

ALBANY, July 26. -- In view of the statement made by Controller Coler of New York City to the effect that he would resign his office unless the State Civil Service Commission made a revision of the classification of positions effecting his department. Assistant Secretary Birdseye said this afternoon:

In an article in Tuesday's TIMES referring to the operatic season which has just terminated in London, the strange assertion is made that "German opera, which before Wagner's time was for the English public non-existent, is now represented at Covent Garden by Wagner exclusively."

NEWPORT, July 26. -- The butlers of the cottagers are going to have a very swell dance in September, and judging from arrangements thus far made, the dance and the dinner will be elaborate affairs. They have engaged the orchestra which played for the cotillions here during the past two seasons, and the Committee of Arrangements is selecting favors for the cotillion, which will be one of the features.

NEWARK, N.J., July 26. -- Alice Henson, a colored woman, is in the City Hospital in a critical condition as the result of a beating given her this morning by her husband, Joseph Henson. The police are searching for the husband.

WASHINGTON, July 26. -- Adjt. Gen. Corbin is highly gratified by the reports from the different recruiting stations concerning the raising of the ten new volunteer regiments of United States infantry. At the close of business yesterday the number of men enlisted was 5,000. Col. Pettit, commanding the Thirty-first, has secured 1,049 men, at Fort Thomas, Ky.

A full-fledged strike originated in the Criminal Court Building yesterday, raged through all the degrees of demands, ultimatums, tie-ups, arbitration and conferences, and was incontinently squelched all within the brief space of an hour. A couple of boxes of disease germs caused the trouble. Truckmen were removing the furniture of the Health Department from the building to the new quarters at Fifty-sixth Street and Sixth Avenue.

White, United States Ambassador at Berlin, and head of the American delegation, in which the Ambassador, after referring to the earnest desire of the American people for a comprehensive arbitration scheme, said:
