Controller Coler yesterday declared he would resign unless the civil service rules recently promulgated by the State Commission were modified, so far as they apply to his office. The Controller feels that his work will be seriously hampered, if the rules are insisted on, and rather than have this happen he is willing to quit.

That was a very curious and even an astonishing announcement that Tammany made the other day when it betrayed an eagerness for two "places" in the Street Cleaning Department, one of them being the place of the head clerk, Mr. DOE, and the other the place of the Deputy Commissioner, Capt. GIBSON.

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., July 26. -- The seventh annual convention of the United States League of Local Building and Loan Associations opened this morning. President Fred Bader of Cincinnati in his annual address declared than the present meeting marked the beginning of a new era in the popularity and development of the American building and loan system.

A decision by Justice Beekman, in the Supreme Court on Saturday, granting the application of one Mehegan for a writ of peremptory mandamus, is of importance to hundreds of office holders in this city.

LENOX, Mass., July 26. -- The marriage of Miss Edith S. Barnes to S. Warren Sturgis took place in Trinity Church, Lenox, at 4 o'clock this afternoon. The bride is the oldest daughter of Capt. and Mrs. John S. Barnes of New York, who have a beautiful country place here. She is a very popular young woman, having a host of friends who were present.

Attention was directed yesterday to the affairs of the American Malting Company by a sudden drop in the quotations of its unlisted securities. Its common stock opened at 17 3/4, sold at 15 1/4, and closed at 15 3/4, a net decline of 2 1/4. Preferred stock opened at 69, sold at 61, and closed at 64, a net decline of 5 1/4.

WASHINGTON, July 26. -- Secretary Root, when he takes office next week, will, it is intimated at the War Department, give early attention to bringing about some much needed reforms in the administration that will need the approval of Congress, but which he will have some months to prepare for the consideration of the two houses.
CLEVELAND, July 26. -- The Iron Trade Review to-morrow will say:

We believe, at least we hope, that there is no reader of THE TIMES so hardened to "business" that he was not touched by reading, if he read it at all, the report in yesterday's paper of the manner in which Magistrate CRANE dealt with the case of a confessedly embezzling boy. To reading readers it will recall a sketch of Mr. RUDYARD KIPLING'S, entitled "The Amir's Homily."

ASBURY PARK, N.J., July 26. -- The second day's session of the fifth annual convention of the Commercial Law League of America was held to-day. It was taken up in the discussion of "bankruptcy." The first speaker was E.C. Brandenburg of the Department of Justice, in Washington, D.C. He is the author of "The Law of Bankruptcy," a "Digest of Bankruptcy,"

HELENA, Mon., July 26. -- A letter received here from Capt. W.B. Hanna of Helena, who for some time has been Captain of the Port at Ioilo, gives further details of the death of the late Capt. George H. Tilley, formerly of New York. Hanna made an official investigation into Capt. Tilley's death, securing the statements of the officers on the British cable ship Recorder, on which Capt. Tilley had sailed to Escalante.

The fight of what is known as the Five States Milk Producers' Association against the wholesale merchants forming the New York Milk Exchange, with the object of controlling the production of milk entering this city and forcing higher prices, has been renewed with vigor. The Five States Milk Producers' Association comprises farmers in New York, New Jersey, Pennsylvania, Connecticut, and Massachusetts.

" Jim" Jeffries, the champion heavy-weight pugilist, will sail for England to-day, where he has arranged to meet Charley Mitchell and Jem Smith in a stipulated number of rounds. Jeffries arrived from the West yesterday, where he has been giving exhibitions since he won from Fitzsimmons.

WASHINGTON, July 26. -- Consul McCook sends, under date of May 24, June 8, and June 20, reports in regard to conditions in Dawson City and vicinity. The city, he says, is being rapidly rebuilt after the recent fire. The following extracts are from his reports:

Men, women, and children, on crutches or leaning painfully upon walking sticks; blind persons guided by loving hands; the deaf, the sick -- in a word, sufferers from almost every imaginable ill, passed in long procession yesterday from dawn to eve through the little red brick French Church of St. Jean Baptiste, on East Seventy-sixth Street.

WASHINGTON, July 26. -- The President to-day commuted to life imprisonment the sentence of William K. Reed, colored, convicted in May, 1899, in this city of murdering Elizabeth Logan, and sentenced to be hanged Aug. 4, 1899.

The formalities attending the passing yesterday to the Government of the titles to the various plots of what has become known as the Bowling Green site by the various owners and holders of equities in the properties on which the new Custom House will be built were interesting. The proceedings were held in the offices of the Lawyers' Title Insurance Company, 37 Liberty Street.

WASHINGTON, July 26. -- The conversion of coupon bonds of the 3 per cent. Spanish war loan into registered bonds continues to go forward rapidly. When the loan was first issued, there were $30,814,000 registered bonds issued on original applications. Since that time there have been exchanged $67,646,540 coupon bonds for registered, so that the total amount of registered bonds of this issue, outstanding for the payment of the dividend due Aug. 1, is $98,460,540.

The recovery of $50 by Miss Lillian C. Moeran, in Municipal Court, First District, before Justice Wauhope Lynn, in her suit against the New York Poultry, Pigeon, and Pet Stock Association. Limited, as the value of a Manx cat which she delivered to the defendant for exhibition at its show at Madison Square Garden, was yesterday affirmed by the Appellate Term of the Supreme Court.

Mr. CHAUNCEY DEPEW, who is perhaps the primate of post-prandial speech makers in this country, which without doubt means that in that specialty be holds "the world's record," is believed and said to have observed that, to make a hit with an after-dinner speech, it was absolutely essential to leave "somebody's hide on the fence."
Daly's Theatre will open early in September with E.H. Sothern in "The King's Musketeer," Virginia Harned playing Miladi.

Owing to the increase in the price of iron the contractors who were awarded the contracts for building the One Hundred and Fifty-third Street and Melrose Avenue viaducts in the Borough of the Bronx show no disposition to hasten the work, and in consequence there is a general complaint from residents and property owners.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 27. -- On board the transport Ohio, which with the Newport sailed at midnight last night for the Philippines, was Benjamin Givens, private of Company H, Fourth United States Infantry, manacled and guarded, to be returned to Manila for trial upon the charge of "desertion in the face of the enemy," the penalty for which is death.

LONDON, July 27. -- The Paris correspondent o The Dally Telegraph says that the story of the engagement of M. Paul Deschannel, President of the Chamber of Deputies, to Miss Terry is emphatically contradicted.

SEATTLE, July 27. -- The bodies of two prospectors who died in Alaska were brought here yesterday on the steamer Elihu Thompson from St. Michael. One is that of G.E. Lawrence of Keswick, New Brunswick, who died at Dawson last November of typhoid.

A cry of "Fire!" started several hundred patrons of Smith McNell's hotel and restaurant, at Washington and Vesey Streets, a few minutes past noon yesterday. There was a general rush for the street, but when it was learned that the fire was on the top floor of the building and under control of the firemen the panicky feeling subsided.

FORT DE FRANCE, July 27. -- A financial crisis having arisen in San Domingo and an insurrection being feared, owing to the number of the malcontents, President Heureaux went to the north and west of the island to prepare for all eventualities. He was about to leave Moca for Santiago de las Caballeros when he was killed.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., July 27. -- Three transports sailed for Manila early this morning. They were the Ohio and Newport, which left the dock shortly after midnight, and the Tacoma, which steamed out toward the Heads at 3 o'clock. Four companies of the Nineteenth Infantry, comprising about 500 men, were evenly distributed on board the Newport and Ohio, besides several hundred recruits. The Tacoma took 300 horses for the Fourth Cavalry.

WASHINGTON, July 27. -- John R. McLean, who lives in Washington, but who seems to be the favorite with Ohio Democrats for the nomination of his party for Governor against the Republican, Nash, has many admirers in this city, but they say that if he accepts the nomination he will choose an unfortunate year to try the experiment of proving that he is so much stronger than his party that he will be elected.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 27. -- At the annual meeting of the Newport Reading Room next month the question of building a new and elaborate clubhouse on the avenue is to be considered. The site of the present clubhouse on Bellevue Avenue and Church Street is one of the very best in the city for such a purpose.

Miss Adeline Muller, twenty-two years old, a public school teacher, of 116 North Oxford Street, Brooklyn, while riding a bicycle on Atlantic Avenue, that borough, yesterday afternoon, was run over by a trolley car. Both of her legs were cut off above the knees. She died in the Brooklyn Hospital at 1:30 o'clock this morning.

KANSAS CITY, July 27. -- The tragic scene which attended the death of Corporal Leonard B. Hayes, America's only traitor in the Philippines, was witnessed by Sergeant George A. Lamarch of Company H, Twentieth Kansas Volunteers, now in this city.

ALBANY, July 27. -- From the statements of trust companies, in addition to those published last week, made to the State Superintendent in Banking of their business for the six months ended June 30, and of their condition on July 1, 1899, these abstracts are made:

In his life of OLIVER CROMWELL, CARLYLE, contrasting the English Puritan Commonwealth, which was his Utopia, and one of the queerest that the whimsicality of man has ever devised or apotheosized, with the attempt of the Irish at the same time to form a republic of their own, compares the Irish to the monkey who imitated his owner in shaving, and more than intimates that what men may do monkeys may not.

Jockeys Maher and Mitchell had things all their own way at Brighton Beach yesterday, for between them they won all of the six races -- Maher taking four and Mitchell the other two. Incidentally, it was favorites' day at the track, for four first choices were returned winners, and Dunblane, the winner of the second race, was second choice.
RENNES, July 27. -- The illness of Capt. Dreyfus, reported yesterday, was but slight, and he has recovered. His friends say that his mental and bodily condition is excellent.

CHICAGO, July 27. -- The Grand Jury to-day heard another story of bribery. According to the testimony presented before the jury, a man who had accepted bribe money had threatened to sue for the balance due him for "hanging" a jury, and possibly had actually brought suit.

W.T. Hotchkiss of the brokerage firm of Hotchkiss Willcox, 50 Broadway, has just returned from Venezuela, where he secured from the Government an attractive concession for a railroad which, beginning at Puerto Cabello, on the Caribbean Sea, will traverse the States of Carabobo and Lara and end at Barquisimeto.

ALBANY, July 27. -- Gov. Roosevelt today appointed Carl S. Burr, Jr., of Suffolk County, Supervisor of Accounts of trotting race meetings for the First District to succeed Hamilton Busby, resigned, and Howard Townsend of New York City as a manager of the House of Refuge for Women at Hudson, to succeed Dr. Christian A. Herler, who resigned because of lack of time to attend to the duties of the office.

LONDON, July 27. -- On the arrival of the Dominion Line steamer Cambroman at Liverpool this morning Sergt. Pollins of Scotland Yard and Sergt. Belt of Liverpool arrested Mrs. William Y. Perot of Baltimore on the charge of the abduction of her daughter from Baltimore. Mrs. Perot was accompanied by a tall, military-looking man, and the party had taken passage as Mr. and Mrs. Pierce and daughter.

SHELTER ISLAND, N.Y., July 27. -- The final trials of the Holland submarine boat, so far as the Naval Board is concerned, were held over the course in Peconic Bay. The trials were for the purpose of ascertaining the effect of wave motion on the vessel when going at a high rate of speed while on the surface and to see if a high speed could be attained at any increased power.

OMAHA, Neb., July 27. -- Yesterday Nebraska's vast corn crop was on the verge of destruction from heat. To-day the crop is practically assured, for rain has fallen in great volumes all over the State. The downpour has continued since early last night. It is raining to-night in nearly every county in the State, and it is conceded that this rain makes the crop certain.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., July 27. -- The sixth annual horse show of the Monmouth County Horse Show Association was opened this afternoon, and will continue the remainder of the week. On the grand stand was represented the beauty and fashion of Monmouth County, with many visitors from other counties.

BOSTON, July 27. -- The Eastern championship tennis tournament was continued here to-day on the courts of the Longwood Cricket Club, both morning and afternoon. The weather was all that could be desired for tennis, except that the heat and humidity were very intense during the middle of the day.

CINCINNATI, July 27. -- Meekin pitched effectively until the eighth inning, when he was hit for three singles, two triples, and a double. Hahn's batting was a feature. Warner's mask was struck by a foul tip in the eighth and his forehead was cut, forcing him to retire. Score:

LEXINGTON, Ky., July 27. -- The anti-Goebel Democrats have been unusually aggressive this week, and the announcement of ex-Gov. John Young Brown that he would accept the nomination of the new convention for Governor has given an impetus to the movement against Goebel that will cause him much trouble to overcome.

It was with considerable surprise that I read in your yesterday's issue the account of Magistrate Crane's plea in behalf of a lad who had openly confessed his wrongdoing. For a Magistrate and a lawyer to flagrantly ignore the basic principles of our code of morals by practically insisting upon the withdrawal of the complaint in question because the boy received only $5 per week is straining the "quality of mercy" with a vengeance.

Magistrate MOTT has his own ideas of the duties of motormen and passengers. In dismissing the complaint against a motorman for starting his car when a passenger was on the running board, the Magistrate sharply condemned the recklessness of passengers in alighting from cars in motion.

NEWBURG, N.Y., July 27. -- A severe thunderstorm passed over the Hudson River Valley shortly after 4 o'clock this afternoon. A number of trees were struck, and a brickyarder named Patrick Kelly was instantly killed by one of the bolts.

WASHINGTON, July 27. -- The midsummer Naval Register, just issued by the Bureau of Navigation of the Navy Department, is interesting in many ways. It is larger than the July Register for 1898; it is typographically better in arrangement, and it has the officers arranged for the first time in any Register according to the provisions of the Personnel bill passed by the last Congress.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., July 27. -- On Monday Mrs. John Llewellyn left her home in Pittston to join a party of eleven others who went to the Wilkesbarre mountains to pick huckleberries. A dense forest covers the mountains for eighty miles. Bears and other wild animals are there in plenty. On Tuesday Mrs. Llewellyn became separated from the others and was soon lost in the woods.

New life was infused into the Sheehan-Goodwin fight in the Tammany organization of the Ninth Assembly District last night by a meeting held under the auspices of the Goodwin faction at the headquarters at Eighth Avenue and Twenty-fourth Street. Over 300 men were crammed into a space that would not comfortably accommodate a half of that number, and a hundred more congregated in the hallways and on the sidewalk about the doors.

MANILA, July 27. -- An expedition composed of troops from San Pedro Macati, Pasig, and Morong, under Brig. Gen. R.H. Hall, yesterday captured Calamba, an important trading town on the south shore of Laguna de Bay.
J.V. Signell has sold to a cash buyer, for about $40,000, 1,410 Fifth Avenue, 28 by 100, one of two three-family flats just completed.

WASHINGTON, July 27. -- The State Department has received, confirmation of the death of the President of San Domingo in a dispatch from the United States Consul at Puerto Plata. Consul Reed at San Domingo also confirms the report, but does not give any details.

CLEVELAND, July 27. -- At a special meeting of the City Council this evening the purpose of which was to start an investigation of the differences between the strikers and the street railways looking to an adjustment, Mayor Farley opposed such action vigorously. He claimed that the work of a special committee on investigation would interfere with the plans of the Executive for the crushing out of disorder.

George Bockowan, a river pilot, fifty-one years old, is in the New York Hospital, where he was sent yesterday by the physicians of the Pasteur Institute, who say that he is suffering from hydrophobia and cannot live. Bockovan was employed on the freight steamer Corona on June 12, when that boat was lying at the foot of East One Hundred and Fifty-first Street.

CAPE HAITIEN, July 27. -- Details of the murder of President Heureaux of San Domingo received here are to the effect that he was assassinated as he was about to leave Moca yesterday on horseback for Santiago de las Caballeros. The assassin, Ramon Caceres, surrounded by several accomplices, approached the President as he was talking with some friends, and fired twice with a revolver.

Justice Giegerich of the Supreme Court yesterday issued an order to show cause why twenty members of the Council should not be punished for contempt of court in refusing to obey the peremptory writ of mandamus issued by Justice Fitzgerald last Friday directing the Municipal Assembly, the Board of Estimate, and the Controller to issue $2,100,000 in bonds for the erection of the new Hall of Records.

It was reported yesterday that the members of the Municipal Assembly who are in contempt of the Supreme Court did not expect to be sent to jail. Of course they do not. Nevertheless, they are eminently fitted to adorn a jail, and it is to be hoped that the hearing on Judge GIEGERICH'S order to show cause why they should not be adjudged in contempt will result in their commitment.

All that the earth holds of Robert Green Ingersoll lies a heap of white ashes in a costly urn at the house his living presence cheered not many days ago. His body was taken from Walston, the Ingersoll country residence, at Dobbs Ferry, yesterday, and consumed in the crematory at Fresh Pond, L. I.

PARIS, July 27. -- The Temps, in an article printed to-day, expresses the belief that fuller light upon the Franco-American treaty would not be superfluous, adding: "What is known, however, is sufficient to cause rejoicing at the rapprochement of which it is testimony. The interests of the United States and France are far from being as irreconcilable as some have been trying to show, but are in reality easily adjusted.

The Committee on Canals of New York State has issued a pamphlet containing the answers of a number of well-known public men to the circular letter of May 1, in which opinions were requested as to what should be done with regard to the canals.

Society in the suburbs and at the near watering places continues its gayety at somewhat of a jog trot, but with the promise of something more exciting in the weeks to come. The Alfred Vanderbilt party having left Newport and the long-prolonged festivities at the Breakers having ceased, that place has gone back to dinners and luncheons and automobiles for its daily entertainment.

LONDON, July 27. -- The members of the Yale-Harvard athletic team who participated in the inter-university contests at the Queen's Club on Saturday were entertained in the Parliament Buildings to-day, where their clean-cut appearance elicited much admiration from former athletes who are now members of the House of Commons.

SOUTHAMPTON, N.Y., July 27. -- It was a battle of the champions to-day at the Invitation Tournament of the Shinnecock Hills Golf Club, and the great crowd which visited the links to watch the play in the first and semi-finals for the President's Cup were treated to a display of scientific golf such as is seldom seen upon the links.
BUFFALO, July 27. -- The New York Commerce Commission, appointed to investigate the causes of the decline of commerce in New York, resumed its inquiry at noon.

We trust that Controller COLER will not act hastily on his reported determination to resign unless the civil service rules are altered as he thinks they should be. He is too good an officer to lose unless there is an unavoidable necessity, and that hardly seems to exist.

WASHINGTON, July 27. -- The suggestion heard at the War Department that it would be a wise thing to raise some troops in Cuba to relieve the American troops now on duty there, and to provide them with American officers in part, does not meet with the most cordial support from men who are acquainted with the conditions that would have to be met.

The Corn Exchange Bank, availing itself of the provisions of the law which permits State banks to establish branches, will early in the Fall operate the Queens County Bank of Long Island City as a branch, making this its fourth branch bank since the law went into effect, the others being the Broadway branch the Astor Place Bank, and the Hudson River Bank.

NEW ORLEANS, La., July 27. -- Senior Luis F. Corea, Minister of Nicaragua, has reached New Orleans, and will remain here for a day or so before leaving for Washington. In coming to the United States Senor Corea is charged particularly with facilitating the building of the Nicaraguan Canal.

RUTLAND, Vt., July 27. -- The stockholders of the Rutland Railroad at their annual meeting, held here to-day, elected these Directors: Percival W. Clement of Rutland, George H. Ball of Boston, John W. Stevens of Middlebury, Vt.; Horace G. Young of Albany, N.Y.; W. Seward Webb of Shelburne, Vt.; E. V.W. Rossiter of New York, Edgar Harding of Boston, George Bird of New York, and Wallace C. Clement of Rutland.

TRENTON, N.J., July 27. -- The Tractor Truck Company was incorporated here to-day, with a capital stock of $2,500,000. Of this amount $1,000,000 is to be in preferred stock bearing 7 per cent. non-cumulative dividends. The company is to operate automobiles for the carrying of passengers, freight, and express matter.

The case of Francis T. Walton, better known as "Plunger" Walton, who on April 10 last filed a petition in bankruptcy, was before Judge Thomas, in the United States District Court, on Wednesday on appeal against a ruling of Referee Royal S. Crane, who reported in favor of Mr. Walton and recommended his discharge.

PLATTSBURG, N.Y., July 27. -- The Presidential party arrived at Bluff Point Station at 8:45 o'clock this morning, exactly on time. The President and his wife entered an open carriage, drawn by a pair of handsome bays, and were driven rapidly up the long hill to the Hotel Champlain. As they entered the grounds the President's flag was hoisted to the top of the flagpole, where it will remain during the President's stay.

Nothing, perhaps, could have brought home to the Man in the Street the realization of what the freight handlers' strike, were it to become general and be prolonged, would mean to the public so much as the announcement in the newspapers yesterday that no fewer than 700,000 pounds of decayed fruit and vegetables have been seized by the health authorities since Saturday.

BOSTON, July 28. -- To-day's tennis matches at the Longwood Cricket Club were by far the most exciting of the week, and a large and enthusiastic crowd of spectators cheered the players all through the long day's play.

Dwight L Moody was the principal speaker at the Gospel Tent, Fifty-sixth Street and Broadway, last night, and an audience which completely filled the large tent and overflowed into the grounds beyond, listened to him. Mr. Moody was a little late in reaching the meeting, and while the great crowd awaited his coming, four or five hymns were sung in the manner peculiar to these gospel tent services.

There is more in the spectacle of between fifty and sixty Presbyterian pastors of New York going to Northfield, Mass., for three weeks than appears at first glance. For example, Presbyterian laymen subscribed $1,800 with which to reserve Weston Hall there and entertain, not members of the New York Presbytery during the season, but pastors of Manhattan and the Bronx Presbyterian churches and chapels.

WASHINGTON, July 28. -- The opposition of M. Meline, the former Premier of France, to the reciprocity treaty between the United States and that country has caused considerable amusement in official circles here. It is one of the recorded facts of the recent negotiations that M. Meline, who is now attacking the new treaty, offered far greater concessions on American goods than the present Ministry permitted to be inserted in the treaty as finally framed.

PERTH AMBOY, N.J., July 29. -- President U.B. Watson of the wrecked Middlesex County Bank to-day refused to talk about the papers found in the private desk of George M. Valentine, the defaulting cashier. His brother, J.T. Watson, Vice President of the bank, stated that the $25,000 note of Valentine's found there was never before the Board of Directors, and he is at a loss to know how it was discounted.

FORT-DE-FRANCE, July 29. -- Tranquility prevails at Monte Christi, but all the people are anxiously awaiting the important events which it is expected will occur shortly. Gen. Pichardo, the Governor of the city, has taken all possible measures to repel any attack which may be made by the followers of Senor Juan Jiminez, one of the candidates for the Presidency of the republic.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., July 29. -- The return match between the Richmond County Country Club and the Englewood Golf Club was played on the Englewood's links this afternoon. Englewood succeeded in wiping out the bad beating she had at Richmond County in the previous match, and finished with the very decisive score of 23 to 11 in her favor.

Publication has just been given the lists of personal property assessments for the South Town, compiled from the sworn schedules of the property owners themselves, submitted under the new revenue law.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., July 29.--A large and fashionable crowd assembled to-day to witness the events of the last day of the sixth annual Horse Show of the Monmouth County Horse Show Association. Among the visitors was ex-Senator David B. Hill, who occupied a chair in the box of F.P. Earle.

SARATOGA, N.Y., July 29. -- The Universalist Church of America began its eighteenth annual National Summer meeting in Saratoga to-night, and will continue in session for ten days. This denominational body met for sixteen consecutive years at Weir, N.H., until last year, when it assembled here and returned this year. A large majority of the delegates arrived on special trains this afternoon and evening.

Bartlett of Philadelphia, who died suddenly at the Inns of Court Hotel with symptoms of poisoning, has been inclosed in a metallic casket and placed in charge of Major Frigout of the American Consulate. HAVANA, July 30. -- A mass meeting was held to-day under the auspices of the Sociedad Democrtico, a branch of the Cuban National Society of Independence. A procession paraded the streets for two hours, headed by a band and bearing banners with the inscription "Cuba is and by right ought to be free" and "Peace work."

LIMA, Peru, July 30. -- The United States cruiser Newark will probably remain at Callao for a fortnight and then proceed to San Francisco to receive Admiral Kautz. Afterward she will proceed to Honolulu, and, according to some rumors, may go to Manila.

The current Harper's Weekly has an amazing page which it behooves all Americans to ponder. It is a page containing a little text, which is neither here nor there, and which we admit we have not read. But mainly it is a page of portraiture, of illustration. The portraits are those of the leading members, meaning the most conspicuous members, of the Democratic National Committee.

NEWBURG, July 30. -- The cornerstone of St. Francis's Church was laid to-day with impressive ceremonies. The Right Rev. Joseph Mooney, Vicar General, of New York, had charge of the exercises, assisted by the Rev. Dr. Edward McGlynn of Newburg, the Rev. John J. McGrath of Fishkill Landing, and the Rev. Terrenco F. Kelly of Matteawan.

CHICAGO, July 30. -- John V. Farwell, who owns immense tracts of land on the Panhandle in Texas, verifies the report that he is interested in the proposed combination deal by which the promoters of the Consolidated Cattle Company expect to round up 600,000 head of cattle on the big ranches of Western Texas and Eastern New Mexico for breeding, fattening, and marketing.

Detective Sergeant Welles and other Central Office men who are at work on the alleged dynamite conspiracy case for which Francis J. Curran was arrested last Friday evening, had discovered nothing up to a late hour last night to strengthen the belief that Curran had confederates in the plot to blow up the property of the Metropolitan Traction Company, particularly the car barns at Second Avenue and Ninety-sixth Street.

The introduction of the Japanese ivy into this country was undoubtedly a boon. Like the country from which it comes, it is a wonderfully quick grower, and in American cities it has wrought great changes. In the rural regions it has not supplanted the native plant known to botanists as ampelopsis quin-quefolia, and to plain people as Virginia creeper, over which the chief advantage of the imported article is its amazing rapidity.

The lawn tennis tournament that opens to-morrow on the courts of the Meadow Club, Southampton, L.I., marks the revival of the former Long Island championships, that have lapsed for several years. This tournament was arranged by ex-Judge Henry E. Howland and his son John Howland, the old-time Yale player, immediately upon the receipt of the decision of the English players, Dr. Eaves, Doherty, and Mahoney, to abandon their proposed visit this year.

PARIS, July 21. -- The most interesting outcome of the present political situation is the General Socialist Congress, to be held at an early date for the purpose of considering whether M. Millerand's acceptance of a Cabinet portfolio was treason to Socialism or not. M. Jules Guesde, who is, in a sense, the Nestor of Collectivism, says it is.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., July 30. -- Charles Ackron, proprietor of the Tivoli Garden, and William Wharton, alias Somers, alias Hall of New York, are held by the local police awaiting extradition to New York, charged with swindling. Wharton leased a bathhouse here in early Summer, conducting it together with Mrs. Wharton.

Ex-Mayor Patrick J. Gleason of Long Island City is to fight the Queens Borough tax rate. He instructed his counsel on Saturday to appear before the Municipal Assembly and make an effort to have the rate in Queens made lower, or, failing in this, to go into the courts and fight the case. Mr. Gleason says that if he was not a prisoner he would go before the Assembly himself.

The Nova Scotia bark Glenrosa. Capt. Henry Card, from Port of Spain, Trinidad, was towed into this port early yesterday morning in a disabled condition by the tug James Ray. Every one of the vessel's topmasts is gone, and her lower masts are badly strained as a result of a drubbing given her by a storm seven days ago off Scotland Lightship, after the Glenrosa had almost poked her nose into port.

The rapid increase in the number of prairie dogs in Western Nebraska has caused the experiment station connected with the State University to experiment with a view to suggesting means for their extermination.

CHICAGO, July 30. -- The "Senators" outplayed she "Orphans" at all stages of the game to-day, wmning as they pleased. The clean fielding of the visitors and Freeman's hitting were the features. Score:
LONDON, July 31. -- The morning papers all devote space to the closing of the Peace Conference.

CHICAGO, July 30. -- Ralph M. Easley, Secretary of the Civic Federation of Chicago, returned to-day from the East, where he has spent two weeks furthering the interests of the coming conference on combinations and trusts, to be held in this city September 13-16. While in Washington he arranged with the State Department for a circular of inquiry to the Consuls throughout Europe, asking for information concerning trade combinations of all kinds.

CLEVELAND, July 30. -- A crowd of soldiers who belong to the troops called here on account of the street railway strike halted an ice cream wagon to-day and took from it a four-gallon freezer full of cream. They offered money for the cream, but the driver of the wagon refused to accept it, saying he could not sell it.

NEWPORT NEWS, Va., July 30. -- There are thirty cases of what is believed to be genuine yellow fever at the National Soldiers' Home, near Hampton, and three deaths from the disease were reported today. There were several other deaths at the institution yesterday, but it cannot be stated to-night that all of them were caused by yellow fever.

NEWPORT, July 30. -- Woodbury Kane, Ralph N. Ellis, and H.B. Duryea of the Regatta Committee of the Newport Yacht Racing Association have decided to have a special regatta on Saturday next for races between the two big single stickers, Navahoe and Vigilant, and between the sloops Syce and Kestrel, and a prize will probably be offered for a racy between the thirty-footers.

What will happen in the sterling exchange market this week? This is the inquiry chiefly interesting Wall Street circles. If exchange quotations decline there will be immediate expectation of gold imports, and rates will have to advance very sharply if anything further whatever is to be heard of gold exports.

PORT JERVIS, N.Y., July 30. -- At 11 o'clock last night, Erie passenger vestibuled train No. 7, for Buffalo and Cleveland, leaving Jersey City at 7:30 o'clock, was wrecked and burned two miles east of Lackawaxen, only two cars escaping the flames. The train consisted of a mail car, express car, cafe car, and three Pullman cars.

A little colony of gypsies sojourning hard by a road house on the outermost confines of Netherwood, N.J., appears to have bunkoed most of the press and a considerable proportion of the people of this country with a story of a coronation of a gypsy queen called "Laurel." Nobody knows who is the press agent of the camp or the road house or both, but he has made and established a new press-agent record.

The announcement that the late Col. Robert G. Ingersoll would speak in the spirit last night was sufficient to draw an audience of two hundred or more persons to Lyric Hall, Forty-second Street and Sixth Avenue. The prospect of an evening's entertainment was so alluring that each readily contributed the 25 cents demanded.
MADRID, July 30. -- The Senate met today, and approved the tax on interest on the debt.

BRISTOL, July 30. -- The past week has been a busy one at the boat shops where Columbia and Defender were being fitted for racing. There was as much activity about the boat shops as there has been at any time since the construction of Columbia was begun. All departments were being operated to their greatest capacity.

Had the conspiracy against DREYFUS been conducted with no regard for dramatic possibilities, the case would hardly have been heard of outside of France. Whether ESTERHAZY would have been convicted, we are not prepared to say.

The letter of Mr. Neal H. Ewing advocating an agreement to recognize the coming century as beginning Jan. 1, 1900, which appeared in your issue of July 22, is an excellent argument on the disputed point. His position may be strengthened, however, and made, it would seem, unanswerable.
Nearly all the criticism of the new bankrupt law is directed to its failure to secure accountability for fraudulent or dishonest acts on the part of debtors.

ALBANY, July 30. -- During the first six months of 1899 there was paid into the savings banks of Greater New York by depositors an amount in excess by $20,000,000 of that withdrawn by depositors. With the statement of the Franklin Savings Bank lacking, the deposits over withdrawals are $19,010,576.

LONDON, July 30. -- As swiftly as it arose, the tightness in the money market seems to be passing away. Early last week it appeared probable that the Bank of England could maintain its hold over the market, and Stock Exchange loans to end in August were rarely granted under 4 per cent., and often 4 1/2 per cent.

DORVAL, Quebec, July 31. -- The second race for the Seawanhaka Cup came off to-day on Lake St. Louis, and was won by the American boat Constance by 55 seconds, this making two wins out of five races, against none for the Glencairn, and, as the course to-morrow will be to windward and return, the Constance should have a good chance.

ATLANTA, July 31. -- Gov. Candler tonight issued an appeal to the people of Georgia to join hands and put an end to mob violence in the State. The Governor tells of the reproach heaped upon the State by the repeated outbreaks and says:

CHICAGO, July 31. -- An important special meeting of the stockholders of the Diamond Match Company was held here to-day. Of the total of 110,000 shares of stock 96,092 shares were represented at the meeting. It was voted unanimously to increase the capital stock from $11,000,000 to $15,000,000. It was also voted to increase the number of Directors from five to seven.

The Woman's Club of Jersey City, composed of 200 of the leading women of the community, has undertaken to reform the Street Cleaning Service there. Much improvement has resulted from the persistent personal efforts of the members. Now a number of influential women are considering the proposition that the club shall itself take the contract for cleaning the streets, and will call it up for serious discussion.

Mrs. Nellie Melford and Mrs. Lizzie Cullen, living at 64 and 67 Bedford Street, respectively, were at Bedford and Carmine Streets last night, when they saw a young woman come along, pick up a little child from the street, kiss it, and give it a penny.

ALBANY, July 31. -- The operation of the State canal system during the current season shows a marked increase in the total tonnage carried, as compared with the statistics of the corresponding period of 1898. The increase indicates that the season will be one of the most successful in the waterway traffic of the State in a long period of years.

WASHINGTON, July 31. -- Mrs. Kate Chase Sprague, wife of a former Governor of Rhode Island, and the daughter of Salmon P. Chase, at one time United States Senator, Lincoln's Secretary of the Treasury, and Chief Justice of the United States Supreme Court died at her homestead Edgewood, in Washington's suburbs, early this morning.

No person upon being introduced to Librarian Werner Jonghaus of the Twenty-third Street Branch of the Young Men's Christian Association would ever suspect that he belongs to that class often referred to in the sporting columns of the newspapers as "athletic Christians." He weighs 325 pounds and stands more than six feet in his stockings.

In opposing the suggestion that the Alaska boundary dispute be settled by our leasing to Canada a harbor where she might enter and clear ships as from a harbor of her own, The Saturday Review sounds several loud and simultaneous notes of warning which cannot fail to awaken vague alarms in the bosoms of that part of the British public to which it appeals:

DENVER, Col., July 31. -- The Board of Arbitration to-day filed its report on the investigation of the smelter strike. The decision reached is a compromise between the demands of the smelter men and the officers of the American Smelting and Refining Company, commonly known as the trust.

If the streets of New York are not clean it is not because of lack of enthusiasm among the juvenile leagues of the Department of Street Cleaning. They held a grand celebration last night in honor of the first anniversary of the founding of their headquarters in the Progress Assembly Rooms, at Aven e A and Second Street.

KANSAS CITY, July 31. -- A party of explorers, headed by two Kansas City men, Weldon E. Williamson and Marcus E. Kirk, which left here in March 1898, and has not been heard of since June, 1898, is now believed to have been exterminated by a hostile tribe of Indians in the western part of Brazil.

There are indications that there will be a hot time at the meeting of the Madison Square Republican Club to-night. It will be the result of the failure of the Governors at the last meeting to elect Wilbur F. Wakeman, Appraiser of the Port of New York, to membership. And thereby hangs an interesting tale.

Allow me in the columns of your widely read paper to express my hearty concurrence in all "H.D.M." has said in her letter appearing in your issue of to-day. Being neither young nor "spry," and unable to walk long distances, I am one of the many who daily regret the comparative comfort of the horse-cars, with their low steps, and who long for a cheap cab service, which is inevitable when New York becomes civilized.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 31. -- An officer of one of the volunteer regiments in the Philippines has written the following letter to The Associated Press under date of Manila, June 27:

NEWARK, July 31. -- Edward S. Campbell has been appointed permanent receiver for the Middlesex County Bank of Perth Amboy, which was wreaked by its cashier, George M. Valentine, who is now serving a term in State prison. The appointment was made this morning by Vice Chancellor Pitney. His bond was fixed at $50,000.

CAPE HAITIEN, July 31. -- From a dispatch just received from a reliable source it is learned that a revolution will be proclaimed to-morrow or the day after to-morrow in the Republic of Santo Domingo in favor of Don Juan Isidro Jiminez.

There was a marked difference in the treatment of the strikes on the electric roads in this city and in Brooklyn, and a difference still more notable in Cleveland. In New York the trouble was slight and brief; in Brooklyn it was much more extended and bitter; in Cleveland it was violent and is not yet settled.

Charles J. Richman, lately the leading man or Augustan Daly's stock company, and for the last five years an "opposite" to Ada Rehan, has been engaged by Charles Frohman for the present season. He will appear in various special productions which are being arranged for Mr. Frohman's New York theatres.

WASHINGTON, July 31. -- The yellow fever situation in Hampton, Va., appears to become more and more serious as time passes, and is causing much concern to the officials of the War Department and to the physicians of the Marine Hospital Service. Late to-day an order was issued by the Secretary of War directing the removal of the garrison at Fort Monroe to some place of safety.

AMHERST, Mass., July 31. -- Eugene Pakahpuer, a graduate from the Indian school at Carlisle, Penn., shot and killed Edith Morell, aged seventeen years, at the home of Mrs. J.F. Morell, in South Amherst, early this evening. The Indian had been employed on the farm for about a year, and during the time had paid much attention to the girl.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., July 31. -- Oriental advices by the steamer Gaelic give the details of a series of dynamite outrages at Seoul, capital of Korea, evidently the work of a band of conspirators whose head is Prince Pak-Yung-Hyo and whose efforts were directed to demolishing the homes of the Premier and members of the royal household department.

At a special meeting of the Brotherhood of Boilermakers and Iron Shipbuilders, District No. 2, Atlantic Seaboard, held at Military Hall last evening, a strike was formally declared in all of the shops that have refused to grant the demand for a reduction in the hours of labor. The strike will affect shops in Manhattan, Brooklyn, Port Richmond, Greenpoint, Hoboken, Jersey City, Elizabethport, and Bayonne engaged in the shipbuilding industry.

PHILADELPHIA, July 31. -- Something quite unusual in the history of popular gatherings will be witnessed at the opening of the International Commercial Congress which is to assemble jointly with the National Export Exposition in this city next Fall, when the entire Diplomatic Corps in Washington will appear in full uniform.

Charles F. Bates, better known to horsemen and others as "Fatty" Bates, appeared in the Centre Street Court yesterday morning in company with his lawyer, David Neuberger, determined to be revenged upon his former friend, James T. Hyde, who is prominent in social and horse circles in this city and at Long Branch and Narragansett Pier.

NORFOLK, Va., July 31. -- The excitement over the discovery of the cases of yellow fever at the Soldiers' Home, at Hampton, across the bay, has subsided to some extent and the fear that the fever would spread to this city and thence abroad has been allayed by the absolute quarantine against the three peninsular towns adjacent to the infected spot declared at midnight Sunday and enforced rigidly to-day.

WASHINGTON, July 3l. -- Rear Admiral William T. Sampson has filed a suit in the Supreme Court of the District, libeling the Spanish vessel of war Maria Teresa and miscellaneous stores and supplies captured upon her and other Spanish war vessels.
WASHINGTON, July 31. -- The War Department to-day received the following death report from Gen. Otis, at Manila:
CORY, Penn., July 31. -- Frank Reynolds of Ripley, Chautauqua County, fell 3,000 feet to his death to-day. The Findlay's Lake Assembly opened at Findlay Lake, fifteeen miles from this city.

NEWPORT NEWS, Va., July 31. -- After a day of intense excitement over the yellow fever outbreak at the National Soldiers' Home. Newport News rests to-night with a feeling of comparative security. The city officers and the various municipal bodies have been busy since early morning, and it is hoped now that no loophole has been left through which the scourge may find its way to this city.

CAMDEN, N.J., July 31. -- Four boys drove spikes into the frog of a switch on the West Jersey and Seashore Railroad at Berlin, sixteen miles from this city this afternoon. The fast trains from Philadelphia to Atlantic City were almost due, and but for a fortunate chance the first one along might have been derailed.

WASHINGTON, July 31. -- Capt. E.P. Hall and Dr. Thomas R. Featnerstonhaugh, both of this city, have returned from Harper's Ferry, where they have been exhuming the bodies of seven of John Brown's raiders. The bodies have been sent to North Elba, N.Y., where they will be buried near the grave of the leader under whom they fought and died.

NEWARK, July 31. -- Miss Eliza Sandford of Bloomfield, whose father fought in the Revolutionary War, died this morning in the Mountainside Hospital, at Montclair. She was eighty-four years old, and had been very feeble recently.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., July 31. -- Charles E. Ackron, proprietor of the Tivoli Garden, New York, and William Wharton, who are held here to await extradition to New York for swindling the Brooklyn Chair Company, have retained ex-Prosecutor of the Pleas Samuel E. Perry to defend them. Mr. Perry to-day secured a writ of habeas corpus from Judge A. Bendicott, who will to-morrow have the prisoners brought before him.

WASHINGTON, July 31. -- The last official advices received up to 8 o'clock to-night show a total of thirty-seven cases and seven deaths from yellow fever at the Soldiers' Home at Hampton, Va. One new case occurred at the home to-day.
BOSTON, July 31. -- Messenger boys of the Boston District Company started a strike here to-day to enforce a demand for an increase in the rate per message, under which system they are paid.

WASHINGTON, July 31. -- The prospects of Gen. Miles are becoming much brighter, and the stories which appeared when Mr. Root's appointment as Secretary of War was first made known, to the effect that he was going to put the finishing strokes to Alger's work in reducing Miles to a mere figurehead, have all vanished.
OTTAWA, Ontario, July 31. -- For the first time in the history of Canada a Speaker of the House of Commons has died during the session.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, July 25. -- The severe drought that has recently prevailed in the vicinity of Kingston and the districts of the southern coast has been broken, there having been heavy rains, accompanied by thunderstorms, throughout the past week. These storms are reported to have resulted in two or three deaths.

The Newport season proper, which has lagged as to its opening, really began on Saturday, on which day there were several large yachting parties, the largest assemblage yet seen at the Golf Club in the afternoon, and numerous luncheons and dinners. It is evident that yachting is to be the sport most favored this season at Newport.
LONDON, July 31. -- Hardly a year has passed since the conviction for the murder of her husband in 1889 that the friends of Mrs. Maybrick have not made some sort of an attempt to secure her freedom.

NARRAGANSETT PIER, R.I., July 31. -- The Dedham second team defeated the Philadelphia Country Club seconds in the polo finals for the Rhode Island cups at the Point Judith Country Club this afternoon, the Dedhams scoring 18 points, while the Philadelphias lost their one goal handicap on fouls and safeties.

The cruising fleet of the Corinthian Yacht Club of Philadelphia, which spent Sunday at Oyster Bay, where the yachtsmen were the guests of the Seawanhaka-Corinthian Yacht Club, proceeded yesterday to Morris Cove. The yachts will to-day race to Shelter Island. There will be a race to-morrow from Shelter Island to New London, where on the following day there will be races for the gigs and dinghies of the fleet.
LONDON, July 31. -- The Archbishop of Canterbury delivered a decision to-day upon the question of the legality of the use of incense and lights in the Church of England.

Verly little is left by the commission of 1899 of the General Act passed by the conference of Berlin in 1889. As a matter of county to their predecessors the later Commissioners call their proposition "a modified and amended version" of the former organic law of Samoa, but as a matter of fact, it is an almost total repeal and modification of that instrument.

BALTIMORE, July 31. -- The Democratic primaries to elect delegates to the State Convention, which meets in this city on Wednesday next to nominate candidates for Governor, Controller, and Attorney General, were held in this city this afternoon.

NEWPORT, July 31. -- With bathing, golfing, luncheons, and receptions to-day, the cottage colony was on the move from early till late. Until the close of the season there will be scarcely a resting hour, so numerous have been the cards issued since Thursday.

FREEHOLD, N.J., July 31. -- When the hearing in the bankruptcy proceedings of Dr. George S. Gagnon was resumed this morning before Referee Frederick Parker, Mrs. Gagnon, the doctor's wife, was placed in the witness chair. The lawyers retained by the creditors sought to ascertain the amount of Mrs. Gagnon's income and the amount which she gives monthly to her husband.

Inquiry at the executive offices of the different gas companies in this city yesterday elicited the assurance in each instance that there is no change in the gas war situation. Some days ago Russell Sage, President of the Standard Gas Company, expressed the hope that the end of the war was near, and more recently he has remarked that "it is a useless and wasteful war and ought to be stopped."
A.F. Holly has sold to Lowenfeld Prager, for about $50,000, the old buildings on a plot 60 by 85 at the southwest corner of Houston and Cannon Streets.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, July 31. -- The boycotting movement growing out of the street railway strike has reached a point where it is almost impossible for any one who rides on the Big Consolidated cars to purchase the necessaries of life. This is especially true in the outlying districts of the city.

As pretty a race as has taken place in this harbor in years was reeled off yesterday morning, and resulted in the Long Branch flier Monmouth being beaten for the first time since she was built, ten years ago, and made a record all her own between here and the Highlands. A steam yacht did the trick -- the Kanawha, built for John P. Duncan of this city.

The Mazet committee will resume its sittings to-day at 10:30 o'clock, occupying the Trial Term, Part IX, of the Supreme Court. About twenty witnesses have been subpoenaed, but Frank Moss, counsel for the committee, would not say yesterday who they are or what subjects they will be questioned on.
Eleven persons, of whom seven were women, had an exciting experience in a falling passenger elevator in the six-story business building at 32 and 34 Lafayette Place at 7 o'clock yesterday morning.

CHICAGO, July 31. -- A yellow fever panic raged in the provision pit, and the market was in a badly demoralized condition all day. All classes of holders sold at the best prices they could get, and as the demand was light at all times, prices melted away with remarkable rapidity. The market opened weak and lower for all commodities, and under steady selling pressure ruled weak to the close.

MALONE, N.Y., July 31. -- The village of Tupper Lake was almost entirely wiped out by fire in a few hours Sunday morning. Save two hotels, the Opera House, Catholic Church, and a few straggling tenement houses on the outskirts, not a single block or house remains. Not a business establishment of any kind escaped.

CHICAGO, July 31. -- With almost everything favoring lower prices at the opening wheat started at a decline of a full cent for September, that option opening at 69 7/8@70. In the course of the first half hour's trading a further slight decline took place, September touching 69 3/4@69 7/8c. Liverpool showed a decline of about 1 1/4d, while Continental markets, all showed weakness.

BOSTON, July 31. -- The Eastern tennis championship in doubles was captured here this afternoon in the final round of the Long-wood tournament by Dwight Davis and Holcomb Ward. Davis comes from St. Louis and Ward from Orange, but both are juniors at Harvard. Last season they captured the Western double championship at Chicago, and later beat the Eastern representatives, and then came within a single stroke of winning the National championship at Newport.

TRIESTE, July 31. -- Admiral Dewey spent the day at the Hotel de la Ville, while his flagship, the United States cruiser Olympia, was being coaled. Hewill return to the ship to-morrow, and expects to sail in the afternoon.

About sixty firemen, oilers, and water-tenders employed on the Norwich Line steamer City of Lowell and the Stonington Line steamer New Hampshire struck yesterday afternoon for an increase of $5 per month in their salaries. The men thought that they should receive larger salaries than they have been getting.

WASHINGTON, July 31. -- Mr. Root has notified Secretary Alger that he will be in Washington and ready to assume control of the War Department at 11 o'clock to-morrow. Gen. Alger will leave at 11:45 o'clock for Michigan.
NEWPORT, July 31. -- The Columbia arrived from Bristol this evening in tow of the tender St. Michaels. To-morrow she will go out for a tuning-up trial.

If ever a horse on the Eastern turf was an inconsistent performer, that horse is Imp, the winner of the Suburban, the Brighton Handicap, and of the Islip Stakes yesterday. As form is figured on previous races, Imp should have been last in the four-horse race yesterday, but on the form that applies to her only she should have finished just where she did -- in front of the other three.

CINCINNATI, July 31. -- The stockholders of the Baltimore and Ohio Southwestern Railway Company, successor to the Baltimore and Ohio Southwestern Railroad Company, to-day elected Directors as follows: E.R. Bacon, New York; W.M. Greene, George Hoadly, Jr., J. Chauncey Hoffman, Edward Colston. Edward W. Strong, Cincinnati; Hugh D. McMillan, Aurora, Ind.; E. Colly Pierce, St. Louis, and Frank W. Tracey, Springfield, Ill.

LONDON, Aug. 1. -- The Hague correspondent of The Times regards the increased friendship resulting from the Peace Conference as one of the striking features of the meeting at The Hague, and says it has been effected at nobody's expense and without seeking selfish ends of any kind. It has been done in the promotion of a good work destined to benefit humanity at large, and, thus more likely to prove sound and durable.

An extraordinary case of a probably fatal accident, to which the police did not give sufficient attention either to make an arrest in connection with it or to report it to a police station, occurred at Twenty-seventh Street and Lexington Avenue yesterday afternoon. Marc Meyer, a Frenchman, sixty-six years old, and a veteran of the Crimean war, fell from a south-bound cable car at that point and received a badly fractured skull.

OTTAWA, July 31. -- Sir Wilfrid Laurier, the Premier, interrupted the regular business of the House of Commons to-day to move the following resolution in regard to the British subjects in the Transvaal:

SING SING, July 31. -- Lewis Pullerson and Michael McDonald suffered the death penalty at the State Prison here this morning. Pullerson was executed in the electric chair at 8:22 o'clock and McDonald twenty minutes later. Only two applications of the electric current were required to kill Pullerson, while in the ease of McDonald the current was applied four times before he was pronounced dead.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- The monthly statement of the public debt, issued at the Treasury to-day, shows that at the close of business July 31, 1899, the debt less cash in the Treasury amounted to $1,161,587,671, an increase for the month of $5,267,436. This increase is accounted for by a corresponding decrease in the amount of cash on hand.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 1. -- The United States transport Senator arrived to-night from Manila, with her flag at half mast, on account of the death of Col. Alexander Hawkins, commander of the Tenth Pennsylvania Regiment, United States Volunteers.
LONDON, Aug. 1. -- The Gazette announces to-day that William Waldorf Astor was naturalized a British subject July 11 of the present year.

CHICAGO, Aug. 1. -- The situation in the brickmakers' strike assumed a new aspect during the morning, when it was reported at labor headquarters that all the non-uion men who have remained at work on the north side, while those on the south side were striking, had at last agreed to join the strike, thus completely shutting off the supply of brick, both union and non-union products.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 1. -- Many of the champion and ex-champion lawn tennis players were unable to reach here in time to commence the Meadow Club tournament to-day, so the opening matches were postponed until to-morrow morning at 10 o'clock. Nearly all of the men were in attendance at the Longwood meeting at Boston, and were obliged to stay there for the finals, which were finished yesterday.

Your correspondent, F.A. Voss, in his letter of to-day seems to find some connection between the American system of gaining a knowledge of any particular trade or business and the case of embezzlement to which the above heading refers.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 1. -- Major Charles W. Raymond, Chief Engineer of the United States Army for this city, left to-day for Sault Ste. Marie, Mich., to attend a meeting of the Deep Water Way Commission, of which he is President. The commission will discuss and compare the final surveys made for the contemplated route of the waterway from the great lakes to the Atlantic Ocean.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1. -- Three new cases of yellow fever in the Soldiers' Home at Hampton and one death is the official report received to-night by Surgeon General Wyman from Dr. Wasdin, the yellow fever expert on duty at the institution. Added to Dr. Wasdin's figures sent to Dr. Wyman yesterday, this makes up to date forty cases in all which have occurred at the home, of which eight have proved fatal.

With your kind permission and the indulgence of your readers, allow me to give herewith my views in regard to our so-called improved (?) system of naming the streets, as invented by our present Commissioner. If enough time had been taken to study the matter thoroughly before putting it in operation, the impracticability of its adoption would have been manifested by the many objectionable features that would have presented themselves.

NEWPORT, Aug. 1. -- Now there is to be an automobile parade, and Mrs. Hermann Oelrichs, noted for her original entertainments, will arrange for the event, which is expected to occur this month. It has been talked of for some time, but not until today was it known who was arranging details. Night is thought likely to be a better time for the parade than day.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1. -- William H. Elliott, Director of Posts for Puerto Rico, visited Acting Postmaster General Perry S. Heath to-day to confer with him about postal affairs in the island. To a reporter he said that the Postal Service in Puerto Rico was very satisfactory and constantly improving.

LONDON, Aug. 1. -- Detective Gault of the Baltimore police force, with extradition papers, is expected in London to-morrow. The officials of the United States Embassy suppose that the Perot child's grandfather accompanies the detective.

The Mazet Legislative Investigating Committee resumed its sittings yesterday, occupying Part IX. of the Supreme Court in the County Court House. The day was given up almost wholly to an effort to develop the real relations between the firm of Horgan Slattery, architects, and the present city administration.

The probate of the will of Miss Susan O. Hoffman at Newport, which gives the value of her estate at $75,000, all of which goes to her sister. Mrs. George Macculloch Miller, and her two nieces, Miss Edith and Miss Elizabeth Miller, her sister's unmarried daughters has caused some comment, both here and in Newport, as it was thought that Miss Hoffman had a much larger estate.

OMAHA, Neb., Aug. 1. -- Mrs. William Wellington to-day filed a petition for an absolute divorce, alleging as a reason that her husband made her bathe in ice water. The people are well known in Omaha, Mrs. Wellington being a vivacious member of several clubs. Mr. Wellington is a merchant.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 1. -- Judge Kirkpatrick, in the United States District Court, has rendered a decision in the Van Orden case. Mrs. Margaret J. Van Orden obtained a divorce from her husband, John M. Van Orden, in the New York courts, and was awarded $150 a month alimony.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 1. -- The entire local list was buoyant in the early trading, being helped by the declaration of a dividend of 50 cents a share by the Bethlehem Steel Company, payable Sept. 1 to holders of record to-day. A continuation of the boom in Consolidated Lake Superior shares was the feature.

Alderman Dennis J. Harrington, who stirred up the Irish societies of two continents by his proposal to flaunt the National, State, and municipal flags from the City Hall on the anniversary of the birth of Queen Victoria, and who subsequently received a rousing vindication at the hands of his brother Aldermen, had his troubles yesterday.

As the race meeting at Brighton Beach draws to a close the members of the talent find it becomes harder and harder to pick winners with which to get enough money for the trip to Saratoga. What with such startling changes of form as that shown by imp and several other horses at the seaside track, it is little wonder that the crowd grows smaller every day, and bettors less satisfied.

HAVANA, Aug. 1. -- Seldom since the American occupation of Cuba has the Military Government been obliged to interfere in civil affairs, but the course of El Reconcentrado having made the exercise of forbearance no longer possible, an emphatic order has been issued by Gen. Ludlow for the suppression of the paper.

YONKERS, N.Y., Aug. 1. -- District Attorney Andrews on Saturday last, before Justice MacLean of the Supreme Court, sifting at White Plains, moved the dismissal of the indictment pending against Dr. Valentine Browne of Yonkers. The District Attorney said it would be impossible to prove the case against Dr. Browne, and the indictment was dismissed.

DORVAL, Quebec, Aug. 1 -- With weather favorable to his boat and good seamanship Duggan, the skipper of the Canadian defender, Glencairn, won his first race and the third of the series for the Seawanhaka Cup this afternoon. From the very start, when Glencairn crossed the line nine seconds ahead, it was apparent that the Canadian boat had a great advantage over the American challenger.

COWES, Aug. 1. -- The regatta of the Royal Yacht Squadron was opened to-day, with beautiful weather and big crowds afloat and ashore. The event of the day was the race for the Queen's Cup, which was won by Emperor William's Meteor. There was a capital sailing breeze.

MADRID, Aug. 1. -- The second session of the court-martial of Gens. Toral and Pareja, who are charged with surrendering Santiago to the Americans without having exhausted all means of defense, was held to-day.

A novel feature in strikes this year is the imposition of fines aggregating $10,000 by a trades union on an employers' association for undertaking to break it up, the union organizing another in its place. It was not an outright stand and deliver piece of business, but it was the carrying out of a vendetta by the Journeymen Stonecutters' Society against the New York Stone Trade Association, that had nearly succeeded in breaking it up.

LOUISVILLE, Aug. 1. -- The Louisvilles bunched their hits in two innings and, aided by the New York's error, seored another easy victory. Wagner stole home in the fourth inning while Meekin held the ball. Tiernan was to-day given his unconditional release by the New York Club. Tiernan is the last of the once famous Giants.

The Chicago Chronicle does not assent to the suggestion of THE TIMES that the National conventions of the two parties be put off until September or October next year in order that the least possible disturbance to business may be occasioned by a Presidential campaign of which the predestined result is already foreseen.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 1. -- According to a special to The Globe Democrat, from Ortiz, Mexico, the report that the Yaquis are on the warpath has been confirmed, and to-day it was reported there that several Americans and Mexicans had been killed in pueblos, or towns, in the Yaqui River valley, east and southeast of that station.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Aug. 1. -- This is the sixteenth day of the street car strike in this city and apparently it is no nearer a settlement now than when it began. The boycott movement, which began in connection with the strike, has spread so rapidly that it has now reached the big down-town wholesale and department stores.

BOSTON, Aug. 1. -- One of the most important considerations in the money market just now is the decided weakness in sterling exchange. Sterling exchange rates have declined nearly 1 1/2c in the pound within ten days, and for the first time since the middle of April are below the international parity. Sterling exchange is 1/4c lower. Clearing House rate 3 per cent. New York funds, 5 per cent. Call loans, 4@5.

ALBANY, Aug. 1. -- The State Board of Railroad Commissioners has granted the application of the Central New York and Northern Railroad Company for permission to build a steam road, which is to be an extension of the Central New York and Western Road. It will run from Perkinsville, Steuben County, and will connect with the West Shore Road at Macedonia.
Decrease of $9,539 in Denver and Rio Grande's surplus for June, making a decrease of $46,523 for the fiscal year. The latter was due to an increase of $354,750 in the amount of dividends paid.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Aug. 1 -- Delegates are coming in to attend the anti-Goebel conference, to be held here to-morrow, and from present indications a large crowd will be here. Theodore Hallam, Harvey Myers of Covington, and John Whallen of Louisville arrived to-night, and ex-Gov. John Young Brown, who was expected to arrive tonight, will be here to-morrow.

Charles Frohman received a cablegram from Daniel Frohman yesterday, in which the latter agreed to an arrangement for Annie Russell to appear at the Lyceum Theatre next season. She will appear for the first time on Sept. 7, producing Jerome K. Jerome's new comedy, entitled "Miss Hobbs." Charles Richman will play the leading male part. The scenes of the play are laid near New Rochelle, N.Y.

NORFOLK, Va., Aug. 1. -- There is no change in the local situation, except that the authorities have redoubled their vigilance to prevent yellow fever being introduced into this city from Hampton or elsewhere. The Mayor, Chief of Police, and patrolmen are doing eighteen hours' duty daily, and special officers, Inspectors, and physicians are working day and night perfecting the quarantine against Hampton and neighboring points on the peninsula.

The informal cruise arranged by the Larchmont Yacht Club to enable the owners of yachts going to rendezvous with the New York Yacht Club at New London to proceed down the Sound under cruising conditions is officially announced in a special order of the Commodore, sent out by Fleet Captain Joseph H. Sterling.

NEWPORT, Aug. 1. -- There was much entertaining on shore and afloat to-day. W.K. Vanderbilt took a party of guests to Narragansett to witness the polo game, and Mr. and Mrs. John R. Drexel did likewise. In the forenoon the Casino concert was well attended, and at Bailey's Beach the number of bathers was the largest of the season.

NARRAGANSETT PIER, R.I., Aug. 1. -- The Narragansett polo tournament was again favored with ideal weather to-day, the event being the third contest for the Point Judith Cup. Meadow Brook met Myopia first team and won by a score of 3 1/4 to 2 3/4. As both were crack teams, the attendance was exceptionally large.

-- A letter just received by the father of M.J. TUMILTY, a Rochester boy serving with the Sixth Artillery in Manila, contains two notable passages. One of them, and by far the more important of the two in some ways, reads as follows: "How are the harvest apples back of the barn? Are they ripe yet? Great Scott! if we only had them down here; bet your life they'd taste good."

MANILA, Aug. 1. -- Sunday's fight at Calamba was a fierce one. The insurgents were unwilling to abandon the place, which is the key to the Lake Road. Gen. Hall, hearing that Gen. Malbar was preparing to make an attack, sent Major Weisenberger with three companies of the Twenty-first Infantry, three troops of cavalry, and one of Hamilton's guns to attack the insurgents.

BOSTON, Aug. 1. -- The Longwood tennis tournament was brought to a most successful end here this afternoon, with the final match for the club's handsome challenge trophy, and once more the National champion, Whitman, proved himself superior to his challenger, who in this instance was Dwight Davis, who beat Larned in a brilliant match on Saturday in the final round.

SAN FRANCISC0, Aug. 1. -- Lewis Morrison, the tragedian, will leave for the East to-day to make arrangements to take a company of players to Japan. It is Mr. Morrison's intention to leave here in May with a company of twenty-two people, scenery, , and play a year in Japan. From there the company wlll go to Australia.

LONDON, Aug. 1. -- In the cricket match between the Marylebone Club and the Australian eleven, which began at Lord's yesterday, the Australians were all out in their first innings to-day for 319 runs. The Marylebone players in their first innings yesterday were all out for 258 runs. At the close of play to-day Marylebone in their second innings had scored 85 runs for five wickets.

MONTREAL, Quebec, Aug. 1. -- The uneasiness engendered by the announcement of the Jacques Cartier Bank suspension yesterday had the effect of causing a sharp run to-day upon the other French banks, but especially the Bank of Hochelaga, whose main office is in the Imperial Building. The run continued until noon, but through the afternoon it had considerably slackened.

MONTREAL, Quebec, Aug. 1. -- The uneasiness engendered by the announcement of the Jacques Cartier Bank suspension yesterday had the effect of causing a sharp run to-day upon the other French banks, but especially the Bank of Hochelaga, whose main office is in the Imperial Building. The run continued until noon, but through the afternoon it had considerably slackened.

ANDERSON, Ind., Aug. 1. -- The local Glassmakers' Assembly has decided to institute legal proceedings to prevent the window-glass companies of Indiana joining the proposed combine. Advantage is taken of an old section of the statute, which provides that in case any corporation shall depart from the purposes for which it was organized its charter may be forfeited and the concern placed in the hands of a receiver.

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 1. -- Gov. Voorhees this afternoon decided to personally investigate the charges of cruelty in the management of the State Industrial School for Girls made against Mrs. Eyler, the Principal, by the Rev. Dr. Maddock and P.J. Fitzgibbon of the Board of Trustees. The Governor had his stenographer at the school to take notes and will make a thorough investigation, which will be conducted publicly.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Aug. 1. -- Henry S. Terhune, who handles all the law business of Philip Daly and his son, Philip Daly, Jr., said to-day that there had been no papers filed in any action for separation or other suit aginst Mrs. Philip Daly, Jr., by her husband.

The re-establishment of the old Steamboat Squad of police, to be known as the Eighty-first Precinct, went into effect at 6 o'clock last evening, when Capt. Anthony Allaire, three Sergeants, three rounds-men, and 122 patrolmen -- all picked men-assembled at their new quarters at Pier A, North River, ready for business.

WICHITA, Kan., Aug. 1. -- Miss Agnes Dervy values Private John Kenny, a hero of the Twentieth Kansas, at more than $50,000. She has relinquished that sum in order that she may become the wife of the soldier boy who followed the fortunes of Funston in the Philippines. Kenny came home Thursday and found his sweetheart faithful to him, and they will soon be married.

READING, Penn., Aug. 1. -- A number of important changes in the official staff of the Reading Railway Company took place to-day. O.S. Doolittle, who has been Superintendent of the Reading and Columbia Division for the past two years, retired from the service. Previous to taking charge of the Reading and Columbia Division he was the General Storekeeper of the company in this city.
Frank Campbell, ex-State Controller, and New York's representative on the Democratic National Committee, read the members of that body a sharp lesson at the recent meeting in Chicago.

WOODBRIDGE, N.J., Aug. 1. -- Harry Webber, seven years old, and Frank Mesick, aged nine, were sent to Sewaren, about one mile from here, yesterday afternoon to take some things to young Webber's sister, who is employed as a domestic there. After they had delivered the bundle the two boys started to walk toward Boynton Beach.

Four years and three months was the sentence imposed upon Policeman Thomas F. O'Brien by Judge Blanchard, in Part I., General Sessions, yesterday. O'Brien had on the previous day been permitted to plead guilty to grand larceny in the second degree, although indicted for that crime in the first degree.

NEWPORT, Aug. 1. -- With a gentle southwest wind blowing up the bay and the water as placid as a reflector, the prospects tonight for the race between the Columbia and the Defender to-morrow are excellent. A stronger southwest wind, under fair skies, is expected, and this will give the big yachts a chance to work in light weather.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1. -- The Navy Department has rendered a decision construing the eight-hour law that will be of importance to all labor interests, as well as to Government contractors. The Commandant of the Washington Navy Yard recently asked authority from the department to permit the contractor, who is building the new gunshops in the yard, to employ his workmen ten hours per day.

Both John C. Sheehan and Frank J. Goodwin, the rival candidates for the Tammany leadership in the Ninth Assembly District, yesterday attended the annual "chowder" of the Columbia Club, which has its existence in the district. During 364 days of the year the club is in a dormant condition, but on the three hundred and sixty-fifth it springs suddenly into life, with a vigorous appetite for clams and beer.

MINEOLA, L.I., Aug. 1. -- The Nassau County, Bank, the first important business enterprise started since the new county of Nassau was created, opened its doors for business this morning at 9 o'clock. Inside of a minute the first deposit was made. Benjamin D. Hicks was the depositor and the amount of the deposit was $1,000.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1. -- Elihu Root took the oath of office as Secretary of War at 10:45 this morning. The ceremony occurred in the large office of the Secretary of War, in the presence of a large number of officers of the army in uniform and other employes and officials. The oath was administered by Judge Cole of the Supreme Court of the District of Columbia.

Dodge and others, for an injunction to restrain the carrying out of certain plans of reorganization by the defendants, as a committee of bondholders of the railroad company, was yesterday denied by Justice Beckman in Supreme Court, Special Term.

HARRISBURG, Penn., Aug. 2. -- The Pennsylvania Steel Company to-day shipped forty-three carloads of bridge and construction steel to one of the Pennsylvania Railroad docks in New York City, and from there it will be sent by ship to India. It comprises one-half of the iron to be used in the building of the huge viaduct across the Goktelk Gorge, about eighty miles west of Mandalay. The company will get $700,000 for the work.
