NORFOLK, Va., Aug. 2. -- In so far as Norfolk is concerned there are no new developments with reference to the yellow fever situation. The rigid quarantine measures which have been put into effect and the unanimity of action on the part of the different health authorities of the State and city have done much toward restoring confidence.

FREEPORT, L.I., Aug. 2. -- There is a telephone war on in this section of Long Island between the New York and New Jersey Company and the South Shore Company. Eighteen months ago the South Shore Company was organized by local capitalists, and a large number of telephones were placed in stores and residences in Freeport, Baldwin, Rockville Centre, Lynbrook, East Rockaway, Hempstead, and Merrick.

There was posted on the dead walls of Mott, Pell, and Bayard Streets last Friday a big red poster gorgeous with golden letters. It referred to Lee Kon's being ousted from the Ming Tuck Tong Society, one of the principal highbinder organizations of Chinatown. Lee's expulsion had long been gossip, but never before had a society taken the trouble publicly to post such a fact.

At all the suburban and Summer resorts the aquatic and road and field sports seem to be so popular as to overshadow any plans for formal entertainments. Newport yesterday was bitterly disappointed in the accident to the Columbia, which spoiled Its i day, and Narragansett had a fine time ot polo, while tennis was the attraction atI Southampton, and golf at Bar Harbor.

CHICAGO, Aug. 2. -- Real estate and loan companies almost without exception refuse to make loans on certificates of title granted under the Torrens law. This additional hardship placed upon those bravely fighting to make the law a success is one of the most severe factors in making the operation of the law slow and tortuous.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2. -- The present outbreak of yellow fever at the Hampton Soldiers' Home will give the Army Medical Corps an excellent opportunity to extend an investigation they have been prosecuting for two years past into the nature of yellow fever and the best modes of combating it.

The Municipal Assembly, in joint session yesterday, confirmed by a vote of 69 to 6 the tax levy for 1899, and fixed the tax rates in the several boroughs as was suggested by the joint Committees on Finance last week. These rates are: Manhattan and Bronx, 2.4804; Brooklyn, 2.36424; Queens, 3.27445; Richmond, 2.42373.
TORONTO, Aug. 2. -- The Washington National League Club defeated the Torontos to-day in an interesting exhibition game before a large crowd. Score:

SOUTHAMPTON, N.Y., Aug. 2. -- The former Long Island lawn tennis championships were revived here to-day on the courts of the Meadow Club. The morning matches were started promptly, and there was a large gathering about the courts to witness the play of the experts who are entered here. There was an abundance of excellent sport.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Aug. 2. -- A windstorm of terrific violence swept through this city this afternoon, cutting a path 1,000 feet wide through the very heart of the business and residential districts, in which two church steeples were tumbled down and scattered over the streets, and the roofs of scores of houses lifted and hurled to the ground.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 2. -- Suit was entered to-day in Covington, Ky., by E.J. Green, State Auditor's agent for Kenton County, against the National Starch Company, familiarly known as the "Starch Trust," for $300,000 for back taxes for a period of five years. The taxation is based on a capital stock of $10,500,000, and the suit will occasion general surprise.

At a meeting of the Tripler Air Power Company yesterday afternoon the number of Directors was increased from five to seven by the election of R.L. Ferguson of New York and H.W. Moeller of Newark, N.J.

NEWPORT, Aug. 2. -- A most unfortunate accident to the Columbia to-day marred the pleasure of what promised to be a thorough test of the relative speed of that boat and the Defender in a nice topsail breeze, and late this afternoon the new boat was towed up to her builders' works at Bristol a total wreck above decks.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 2. -- Searchlight to-day paced the three fastest heats of the season -- 2:03 1/4, 2:04 1/4, and 2:04 -- and clipped a half second off his record. The 2:04 pace, despite the fast time, was won by Searchlight apparently without an effort. The official time by quarters of the first heat was 0:30 1/4, 1:01, 1:29 1/4, 2:03 3/4.

FLEMINGTON, N.J., Aug. 2. -- During the severe thunderstorm which passed over this place this afternoon lightning struck the Opera House at Clinton, near here. The building was set on fire, and was gutted. Had it not been for the prompt work of the Fire Department, the entire building would have been in ruins. The loss will probably reach several thousand dollars.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Aug. 2. -- The town of Carrabelle, a prosperous port on the Gulf of Mexico, southwest of this city, is reported almost completely destroyed by a terrific wind and rain storm which passed through this section during yesterday and last night. Many boats which were in the harbor have been wrecked, and the greater portion of the long wharf is gone, together with large quantities of naval stores.

PERTH AMBOY, N.J., Aug. 2. -- Banking Commissioner Battle's report shows the Perth Amboy Savings Institution nearly $15,000 short in its accounts. Of this sum 15,000 will be made good by Treasurer George M. Valentine's bondsmen. By waiving the July dividends another $2,500 will be provided for.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2. -- The Navy Department has finally decided to fit up the little torpedo boat Sommers, bought in Germany during the war. Rather than abandon her, about $6,000 will be spent in making her serviceable.

NARRAGANSETT PIER, R.I., Aug. 2. -- There was only one polo contest to-day, instead of the two billed at Point Judith Club, as Myopia Second forfeited the third contest for the Narragansett Cups, with Dedham first. The Westchester Country Club firsts met Point Judith Country Club firsts and the former won by a score of 15 to 8 3/4. The Westchesters were handicapped seven goals.

DORVAL, Quebec, Aug. 2. -- To-day was another Glencairn day, the Canadian boat winning her second and the fourth race for the Seawanhaka Cup. During the race there were all kinds of breezes, from east to west and from north to south, and it was difficult to say at times just which boat had the advantage as to wind.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Aug. 2. -- Gov. Bradley to-night gave out a statement covering all the phases of the Clay County feuds. He says there have been seven men killed in the Baker-Howard feud -- Burch Stores, Wils Howard, George Baker, Will White, John Baker, Frank-Clark, and Tom Baker -- in a period of something more than one year.

CHICAGO, Aug. 2. -- Gen. Anderson, in charge of the Department of the Lakes, was exercised considerably this morning when he found some one had sent him by mail "Columbia's Apostasy," by Robert Stevens Pettet of Philadelphia. The author accuses the United States soldiers of practicing many kinds of barbarity in the Philippine campaign, and declares that innocent women and children are being shot down by hundreds in every battle with the Filipinos.

MADRID, Aug. 2. -- The defense of Gen. Toral, on trial by court-martial charged with surrendering Santiago de Cuba to the Americans without having exhausted all means of defense, is that Santiago was not a fortified town within the meaning of the regulations, which fact modified the circumstances from the point of view of military justice.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Aug. 2. -- Rabbi Stephen S. Wise, who for five years has been in charge of the Congregation B'nai Jeshurun, in Madison Avenue, New York, has accepted a call to the Temple Beth-Israel of Portland, Oregon. Dr. Wise is now in this city, visiting his brother, Otto I. Wise, at 1,360 Post Street.

COWES, Isle of Wight, Aug. 2. -- Brilliant weather prevailed at the regatta of the Royal Yacht Squadron to-day. The prize competed for was 100, and the course sailed over was the Queen's Cup Course, Meteor winning the race.

RENNES, Aug. 2. -- The witnesses summoned in behalf of Capt. Alfred Dreyfus include Capt. Lebrun-Renault, to whom the prisoner is alleged to have made a confession, which has since been denied; Senator Scheurer-Kestner, formerly Vice President of the Senate; M. Trarieux, formerly Minister of Justice; M. Bourgeois, formerly Premier and Minister of the Interior; Major Hartmann of the Twenty-second Artillery; Capt. Freysteatter; Major Forzinetti, and other officers and journalists.

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 2. -- The Lancaster Motor Company, with a capital of $5,000,000, filed papers of incorporation here today. The incorporators are Percy C. Hamilton, Pittsburg; George S. Stidwell, T. Reginald Horley, and Byron Traver, New York City, and Joseph V. Clark, Jersey City. The purpose of the company is to control the American patent of Frederick William of Lancaster, England.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Aug. 2. -- The anti-Goebel State conference which met here this afternoon was composed of 400 delegates, representing every Congressional district in the State and more than half the counties. The enthusiasm was great, and the movement against the election of William Goebel, the Democratic candidate for Governor, may now be said to be under full headway.

NEW YORK, June 30. -- The word Algerism has become of late so familiar in the United States as to need no definition or explanation. Words of this kind coin themselves, and also explain themselves, at least to those who know something about the exploits of the man whose name is the root of the new substantive.

The resignation of Mr. Alger, the Secretary of War in President McKinley's Cabinet is a decided victory for public opinion and public morals over political organizations. Our correspondent in New York, whose trenchant comments on "Algerism" we published a few days ago, has clearly explained what the evils are that are identified with the personality of the retiring Minister, and how powerful are the influences that have hitherto sheltered his incompetence, if not his corruption.

The recent experiments of Prof. Atwater are of great interest to physiologists and chemists since they throw much light upon one of the doubtful questions of physiological chemistry or pharmacology, that of the metabolism of alcohol in the body.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Aug. 2. -- A sensational incident enlivened the trial of the case of Mertil Liukert and others against Rosalie Hill before Judge Barnard to-day. This is the action in which the children of Victor and Rosalie Liukert are seeking to enjoin their mother from disposing of the fortune left by their father, who is dead.

NEWPORT, Aug. 2. -- Miss Edith Clapp and Miss Elsie French to-day gave a picnic at Coddington Cove, formerly a favorite place for such entertainments. Mrs. William Payne Thompson chaparoned the party, which included Count Gluseppe Della Gherardesca, the Misses Potter, William Woodward, Miss Gray, the Misses Stone, Miss Daisy Post, Miss Lily Oelrichs, Miss Whiting, and others.

The Brooklyn trolley added another victim -- the fourth within a week -- to its long list yesterday. The latest victim is Francis McCreery, ten years old, who lived at 1,156 Third Avenue. The boy met death in very nearly the same place where a man was killed by the trolley only last Thursday, at Third Avenue and Fortieth Street.

GREENOCK, Aug. 2. -- The Shamrock started from here with the flood tide, and after adjusting her compasses proceeded in the direction of Fairlie. Her departure was witnessed by thousands of people lining the quays. They gave the yacht an enthusiastic send-off.

PLATTSBURG, N.Y., Aug. 2. -- President McKinley received a call this morning from the officers of the Twenty-sixth Volunteer Regiment, stationed at Plattsburg Barracks. He received them in a parlor of the hotel. Col. Edmund Rice, who is an old friend of the President, presented the officers to Mr. McKinley and Postmaster General Smith.

Not one of the men who had been adjudged by Justice Fitzgerald to be in contempt was willing to stand a term in jail, and every one of them asseverated that he wanted to do whatever the Court commanded.

Edward Harvey, eleven years old, of 1,362 Fulton Street, Brooklyn, is dying in St. John's Hospital, that borough, as the result of a peculiar accident. The boy, with his brother William, thirteen years old, climbed upon the Kings County Elevated Railroad structure on Fulton Street on Tuesday night, and while walking on one of the girders both grasped an electric light wire.

NEWPORT, Aug. 2. -- Columbia's crew turned to bright and early. The cover was taken off the mainsail, stops cast off, and throat and peak halyards manned by 8:30 o'clock and an hour later the mainsail was set flat as a board, with the club topsail towering above it and the jib holsted in stops on the stay.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Aug. 2. -- A bolt of lightning struck the shipyards of C. Hiltebrand at South Rondout this afternoon with fatal results. Henry Matthias was killed and twelve men were injured. Doctors from this city were at once called to the scene. Matthias was employed in the shipyard as calker at the time of the accident.

A man who gave the name of Henry H. Pennock, thirty-two years old, and said his address was the New York Athletic Club, fell from a Fourth Avenue trolley car yesterday afternoon in front of 483 Fourth Avenue and wrenched his kneecap. He was taken away in a cab after an ambulance surgeon had dressed his injury.

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 2. -- The investigation into the management of the State Industrial School for Girls here was resumed to-day. Trustee Fitzgibbon was unable to be present, and the Governor permitted him to be represented by John H. Backes, a lawyer, although the Governor said such a proceeding was irregular.
NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 2. -- The exports of lumber and products of wood from Southern ports during the fiscal year ending June 30, 1899, were larger than any in the history of the trade.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 2. -- The Democratic State Convention was held in this city to-day, and John Walter Smith was nominated for Governor amid much enthusiasm. The convention was unusually harmonious, and all the nominations were made by acclamation. Edwin Warfield, Mr. Smith's strongest opponent, withdrew at the last moment and placed the successful candidate in nomination.

DETROIT, Mich., Aug. 2. -- Whatever may be the personal feelings of the late Secretary of War, Gen. Russell A. Alger, concerning recent incidents of his official career, all sentiments save those of genuine happiness were very evidently banished from his mind this afternoon and evening by the magnificent welcome tendered him by the people of his own city and State.

Room traders on the Stock Exchange show some disposition to renew bearish activity, and at the close of business yesterday they fell upon the market and knocked quotations off somewhat. Small indications appeared of anything like selling for the account of interests actually owning stocks.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Aug. 3. -- The withdrawal of several companies of troops was followed to-night by another dynamite outrage on the part of the street railway strikers or their sympathizers. Fortunately nobody was hurt. The explosion occurred under a Jennings Avenue car, on which were six passengers.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3. -- Acting Secretary of State Adee has received a cablegram from Minister Powell, at Port au Prince, Haiti, confirming the newspaper reports of the violation of his legation by police officers who were making an arrest. The Minister added that the person who was arrested (Du Vivier) is a citizen of Haiti, and he seeks to know what disposition shall be made of him upon his return to the legation.
LONDON, Aug. 3. -- Mr. William Y. Perot, who came here from Baltimore, Md., and who was arrested on the charge of abducing her daughter, was again remanded in the Bow Street Police Court to-day.

COWES, Aug. 3. -- The sensation of the day amid the social gayeties attendant upon the yacht races was the announcement of the engagement of Lady Randolph Churchill to Lieut. G.F.M. Cornwallis-West, son of the famous beauty, Lady Cornwallis-West. It is that the marriage will occur in October next.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Aug. 3. -- There were many curious visitors from New York, Newark, and the surrounding country here to-day to view the work of the tornado which swept through the centre of the city yesterday. The work of clearing the streets went on all night, and by this morning things were in fair shape.

There is a lively scramble for the Judgeship of Delaware County, made vacant by the elevation of Judge A.H. Sewall to the Supreme Court bench. About twenty candidates are in the field. Politicians here and papers in Delaware County express a belief that Senate Clerk Lafayette B. Gleason of Delhi can have the place if he wants it.

PERTH AMBOY, N.J., Aug. 3. -- The Perth Amboy Savings Institution, through its Board of Managers, who met here last night, has issued a partial statement. The resignations of Robert N. Valentine and Howard Valentine, father and uncle of the late Treasurer, George M. Valentine, were accepted. The vacancies were not filled.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 3. -- The second day's play in the revival of the old-time Long Island lawn tennis championships on the courts of the Meadow Club, at this place, brought together the best of the experts entered here and provided sufficient excitement to keep the onlookers at a high pitch of enthusiasm.

The Finance Committee of the Senate has not completed its work on the Currency Reform bill, and we have agreed not to discuss its provisions for publication. I do not believe the committee will hold another meeting until shortly before the assembling of Congress. I know nothing of an early session at Narragansett Pier. -- Senator O.H. PLATT of Connecticut.

Another day in which only one favorite landed the money added to the woes of the regulars at the Brighton Beach race track yesterday, but pecuniary losses did not seem much to worry the men who follow racing year in and year out, for they had sustained another loss that outweighed financial considerations.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 3. -- The fire which broke out in the big power house and car sheds of the South Orange division of the North Jersey Railway Company, at South Orange, last night, after they had been struck by lightning, proved far more disastrous than at first supposed. When the ruins were in such shape this morning that an inspection could be made, it was found that nearly, eighty cars had been destroyed.

ALBANY, Aug. 3. -- Of the forty cities in the State but seven have codes of civil service rules and regulations drawn in compliance with the White law. This statute was enacted April 19, and provides that within sixty days the Mayor of each city shall appoint a local commission, and that such body within sixty days after its appointment shall submit to the State Commission a code of local rules and regulations.

NEWPORT, Aug. 3. -- The tennis match of the season was played for nearly two hours this morning on the Casino court, between Mrs. John Jacob Astor and J.E. Postlethwaite on one side, with the Earl of Yarmouth and Miss Anna Sands on the other, while a number of their friends sat upon the box stand of the horse show and witnessed the playing, which resulted in a victory for Mrs. Astor and Mr. Postlethwaite.

The most prominent character of the old Eighth Ward and one of the best-known figures in the life of New York City for the last third of a century vanished yesterday with the death of "Smiling" John Kelly after a lingering illness. Mr. Kelly died at his home, 252 West Seventy-fifth Street, where he had lived since his retirement from business a few years ago.

The announcement in yesterday morning's cable dispatches that the Vatican had officially protested against the attitude of the Italian Government in shutting out the Holy See from the Peace Conference need not be taken as seriously as the alleged phrasing of the "note to Nuncios" would seem to imply.

Charles M. Lowe's action for the annulment of his marriage to Ruth A. Winchell was dismissed yesterday by Justice Bookstaver in the Supreme Court. Lowe claimed that his marriage should be annulled because when he married the defendant his first wife was still alive.

James W. McKinnon of 713 East One Hundred and Thirty-eighth Street gave an exhibition of a new device for launching lifeboats at the American Line piers, Jersey City, yesterday afternoon. The device consists of two chains working over sprocket wheels, the ordinary pulleys being done away with.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3. -- The dispatch boat Dolphin put in at Wood's Holl yesterday, and forwarded to the Navy Department a report on the recent collision with the ferryboat New York, in New York Harbor. It was based on the findings of a board convened on board the Dolphin immediately after the accident, and in accordance with naval regulations.

COWES, Isle of Wight, Aug. 3. -- In the race for the Town Cup to-day, which was won by Emperor William's Meteor, in the regatta of the Royal Yacht Squadron, the Meteor, the Prince of Wales's Britannia, and Rainbow crossed the line together at the start. Bona was last. The course was round the East Lepe buoy, to the Warner lightship, twice around.

NEWPORT, Aug. 3. -- C. Oliver Iselin, Woodbury Kane, and Herbert Leeds came to Newport this afternoon in a fast steam launch owned by Dr. Hopkins. Mr. Iselin said he would try to have the Columbia ready to race with the Defender on Saturday. "We have not decided," said Mr. Iselin, "whether we shall give her a steel spreader or not."

PEORIA, Ill., Aug. 3. -- Peoria's memorial monument to Col. Robert G. Ingersoll is attracting wide attention. Since the plan was announced contributions have been pouring in from all parts of the United States, and letters relative to the movement have been received from Europe.

ALEXANDRIA, Egypt, Aug. 3. -- George Averoff, the wealthy Greek, whose gift of a million francs for the restoration of the Stadium at Athens led to the revival of the Olympic games a few years ago, died here to-day in his seventieth year.

LONDON, Aug. 3. -- England is absolutely indifferent concerning the projected visit of M. Delcasse, French Minister of Foreign Affairs, to Russia, which seems to be generally misunderstood. The Czar's attitude toward the Republic of France caused real consternation.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Aug. 3. -- The world's bicycle record for 1,000 miles, held by T.A. Edge of London, England, and made over an ordinary turnpike road, has been broken by A.A. Hansen, who finished his long ride early this morning, covering the distance in 92 hours and 44 minutes. The time made by Edge was 105 hours 19 minutes.

NEWPORT, Aug. 3. -- Ralph N. Ellis, Chairman of the Regatta Committee of the Newport Yacht Racing Association, said tonight that in case the Columbia is not ready to race Saturday the association will offer a handicap cup to be raced for by the Defender, Vigilant, and Navahoe.
NEW CASTLE, N.H., Aug. 3. -- The open lawn tennis tournament at the Hotel Wentworth was continued here to-day, and both events reduced to the semi-final stage.

DORVAL, Quebec, Aug. 3. -- The last race of the series of races for the Seawanhaka Cup between the Constance and the Glencairn was to-night awarded to the Glencairn by the Sailing Committee. The Canadian yacht had heretofore won two races, and thus the cup remains in Canada.

BRISTOL, L.I., Aug. 3. -- The Columbia's broken mast was taken out this afternoon by the big derrick of the steamer Archer. The work was performed where the yacht lay, off Herreshoff's wharf, and the mast was deposited on the wharf at exactly 6 o'clock. It was then too late to do anything about stepping the pine mast, and that work was postponed until to-morrow.
WILMINGTON, Del., Aug. 3. -- The National Match Company, in which prominent matchmakers are interested, was incorporated to-day, with a paid-in capital of $250,000.

The sensations which were expected to result from the appearance of members of the Municipal Assembly before the Mazet committee yesterday did not materialize. Five Councilmen and four Aldermen were examined during the day, and a number of criticisms of the charter and of the results of consolidation were evoked, but there was nothing startling in any of the testimony, and the session was totally devoid of exciting incidents.

The United States transport McClellan arrived yesterday from Cuba and Puerto Rico, after a trip of nineteen days from New York. She called first at San Juan, sailing thence on July 22 for Santiago, where she anchored in the upper bay for thirty-six hours. The passengers and crew were not permitted to land, and the passengers who came on board had been quarantined ten days.

George A. Wallace, who says he is a Philadelphia merchant, stopping at the Grand Union Hotel, was walking along Forty-second Street near Fifth Avenue last evening about dark when two men asked him for 10 cents. He gave them a dime, but, considering them very suspicious looking, watched them after they had passed by and saw them accost another man, who refused them.

F. De R. Wissmann has sold for Alexis M. Leon and others to Mayer S. Auerbach, for about $70,000, the old building 26 East Twenty-second Street, on a plot 31 by 100. It is said that a twelve-story mercantile building will soon be erected on the site.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3. -- A woman and two small children, who are believed to be now at Bound Brook, N.J., ran the guard at Hampton, Va. on Tuesday night and escaped from the yellow fever district. The mother, who had suffered great privation, but who carried out her plan with indomitable courage, was in this city yesterday trying to get transportation to Bound Brook, and it is believed that she succeeded.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Aug. 3. -- Dr. Frank L. Southern, a lecturer in the University of Pennsylvania, went sailing yesterday afternoon, when his yacht was capsized in the sudden storm that came up, and all night he and a friend clung to the bottom of the boat. At daylight to-day they were rescued by employes from Fenton Leeds's boathouses.

It was my intention on arriving at my office this morning to write President Rossiter of the Brooklyn Rapid Transit Company, calling his attention to one particular man in the employ of that company who is worthy of more than ordinary mention. I refer to Motorman No. 235 of the Seventh Avenue line which came to Manhattan between 8 and 9 o'clock this morning -- Car No. 402.

FAIRLIE, Aug. 3. -- The cup challenger Shamrock started from here this morning on her journey to America, but after proceeding a short distance had a slight mishap to her bowsprit and was compelled to return. This delayed her departure until 5 o'clock this evening, when the yacht again set sail, the steam yacht Erin, which is to escort her across the Atlantic, being close at hand and gayly decorated with flags.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3. -- The number of enlistments yesterday was 384, making a total of 9,063. Col. Bell's regiment, the Twenty-seventh, at Camp Meade, is now above its quota, making two regiments complete.

According to official reports, there has been no spread of the contagion since yesterday, nor has any one of the cases now under treatment proved fatal since that time.

Singers for the opera have been engaged as follows: Sopranos -- Yvonne de Treville, Grace Golden, Selma Kronold, Adelaide Norwood, Cecile Hardy, Gertrude Quinlan, and Mary Carrington; contraltos -- Lizzie Macnichol.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Aug. 3. -- The first train from Carrabelle, through the storm-stricken Gulf section since Monday, reached here this afternoon.

BERLIN, Aug. 3. -- The Deutsche Tages-Zeitung to-day publishes a sensational article, predicting a great panic in the German money market The paper said that during the last six months 1,595,000,000 marks of new shares were issued, of which 518,000,000 marks were industrial securities, which, it is added, exceeds the whole issue of 1898.

OCEAN GROVE, N.J., Aug. 3. -- Gov. Roosevelt of New York was the guest of honor at the Ocean Grove Summer School to-night, when he delivered an address upon "Practical Politics and Decent Politics" before a large audience. Gov. Roosevelt left New York over the Central Railroad of New Jersey, taking the 4:45 o'clock train for Ocean Grove.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Aug. 3. -- At 9 o'clock this morning the Pennsyvania troops disembarked from the transport Senator and commenced the march to the Presidio reservation, where the soldiers will go into camp preparatory to mustering out.

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 3. -- The third day's investigation into the management of the State Industrial School for Girls began today with Mrs. Myrtle Eyler, the Principal and the alleged chief offender, on the stand. Mrs. Eyler was closely questioned by the Governor, and made a detailed statement of the punishment in each of the cases of alleged cruelty.

YONKERS, N.Y., Aug. 3. -- The Union Railway Company which has been fighting the Connecticut Traction Company for the rights of way through this city won its battle to-night when the Board of Aldermen voted the Union Company rights of way over some twenty miles of Yonkers streets.

SYDNEY, July 5. -- The Victorian colonists have been much stirred by an Anglican clergyman in one of the rural townships who has delivered from the pulpit a series of fierce denunciations of ballrooms and those who frequent them. Although the preacher bears the name of Gladstone, he is no relation of the famous statesman, but the son of an Australian actor not altogether unknown on the American stage.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3. -- A contribution to the discussion as to where John Paul Jones was buried has been made in a letter sent from Randolph, Ky., by James G. Johnson to Secretary Hay. It comments on a statement made by the Secretary of State, to the effect that the American Embassy at Paris is certain that the first American naval hero was not buried in the cemetery where the remains of Lafayette lie.

NORFOLK, Va., Aug. 3. -- Dr. F.S. Hope, quarantine officer of this port, who is in charge of the quarantine here, gave out an interview to-day which is regarded as being a correct and concise statement of the yellow fever situation as regards Norfolk and vicinity.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3. -- The annual report of the Harbor Master of Hongkong, a summary of which has been forwarded to the State Department by Consul General Rounseman Wildman, shows an increase in American shipping in 1898 over 1897, which has all taken place since August, or within a period of four months.

Herman Hauser, Treasurer of the Herald Square Theatre, jumped from the Brooklyn Bridge yesterday afternoon. Unless he received internal injuries, which cannot be known definitely until to-day, he will experience no serious result from his plunge of 125 feet into the river.

PLATTSBURG, Aug. 3. -- The President to-day had a call from Dr. A.D. Richardson of West Chazy; an old farmer seventy years of age, who walked all the way from his home to the Hotel Champlain, a distance of fifteen miles, to "shake hands with the President of the United States." Mr. McKinley greeted him warmly and talked with him several minutes.

The procedure was for the "smooth man" of the clique to present his card at the door of a residence and ask for the owner or tenant.

NARRAGANSETT PIER, R.I., Aug. 3. -- The third event for the Narragansett Cups came to a close this afternoon at the Point Judith Country Club, when Devon first met Myopia first. Both being strong teams, the attendance exceeded the average. Conditions were favorable, the breeze being light and temperature high. Myopia won by a score of 10 to 9 1/2, Devon having 4 handicap, but being penalized 1/2.

CHICAGO, Aug. 4. -- Controller Kerfoot has conceived a plan which, if executed, he thinks will drive the 10-per-cent.-a-month money lenders out of business. He will communicate with Dunlap Smith, the city's member of the Board of Directors of the Municipal Pawners' Association. The object will be to have this organization make arrangements for loaning money to city employes at a reasonable rate of interest.

Chapin, professor of diseases of children at the Post Graduate Hospital, declared yesterday that the new form of paralysis in children, which first made its appearance in Poughkeepsie about two weeks ago, and which has been spreading with alarming rapidity, is, in his opinion, infectious but not contagious.

Semke, came up to-day before Justice Gittens. The hearing was not very satisfactory, owing to the inability of some of the interested parties to understand English.

SALEM, Mass., Aug. 4. -- Frank L. Weston,. who was arrested in New York several days ago charged with stealing the yacht Takeiteasy from Salem Harbor on June 15, and who was brought here a few days ago, pleaded guilty in the District Court to-day, and was held in $2,000 for the Grand Jury.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Aug. 4. -- Attorney General Taylor, at the request of the State Medical Board, to-day furnished an opinion as to the right of osteopaths, faith curists, mental healers, and others to practice in the State. There has been much doubt as to the adequacy of the present medical laws, and several test cases have been carried to the courts to settle the matter.

CHICAGO, Aug. 4. -- Judge Windes of the Circuit Court handed down a decision to-day which will prove of more than ordinary interest to labor unions. The case involved was that of Fraser Chalmers against the Chicago branch of the Iron Molders' Union, besides a large number of other persons, some of them former employes of the manufacturing firm.

NEWPORT, Aug. 4. -- By long odds the largest social function of the season was to-day given by Senator and Mrs. George Peabody Wetmore in the form of a reception, for which over 600 cards were sent out. The reception was one of those delightful events of seasons past, which were so fashionable before the days of fads, which are being introduced daily by the cottagers.

LONDON, Aug. 4 -- Literature at present in stagnant here. Publishers and authors have gone on their holidays. Not even the Fall announcements are ready to any particular extent. Nothing is selling; not even the six-penny edition of Maurice Hewlett's "Forest Lover," issued by the Macmillans. The six-penny editions are being overdone. They have lost their uniqueness, and the public is satiated.

HAVANA, Aug. 4. -- Gen. Juan Isidro Jiminez, when his attention was called to-day to a cable summary of an alleged declaration made by him here recently and published in the United States to the effect that he was about to proceed to the United States to organize an expedition against the existing Government of Santo Domingo, replied that he had not made the statement attributed to him.

Collins of Bradford, Penn., and Harold Havens of Oakland, Cal., students at Le land Stanford University, at Palo Alto, the expedition sent out by that institution, under the guidance of Dr. J.C. Branner, Vice President of the university, to explore the reefs on the Brazilian coast, had a very hard time. This was due in the main, so the students assert, to the unkindly acts of the Brazilian Government.

I was to be introduced to Mr. Fletcher Harper of the original firm by a gentleman who knew him well, and who promised me that I should meet a very affable individual and no ogre.

SOUTHAMPTON, England, Aug. 4. -When the cricket game which began here yesterday between the Hampshire eleven and the visiting Australians was adjourned for luncheon to-day, the Australians, in their first innings, had scored 155 runs for 3 wickets down. The Hampshire players, in their first innings, yesterday, were all out for 393 runs.

HONOLULU, June 1. -- The competition of coolie labor, with their low rates of wages and contentment to live on rice and fish, will make Honolulu undesirable for the workingman. Laborers receive about $16 a month and feed themselves. Even the expert Japanese head men in sugar factories, where intelligence and the utmost care are required in observing and controlling the sugar process, or great loss would ensue, are only paid about $1.25 a day.

A letter has just been received by Mrs. Horace See, Treasurer of the Colonial Aid Society of the United States, from Mrs. Lavinia D. Hoff, Vice Presidents of the Woman's Aid Society, located in San Juan, Puerto Rico. She thanks all the contributors to her work, especially those who contributed to two boxes which were sent to her by the steamer Arcadia.

MARSHALL, Mich., Aug. 4. -- A mortgage was filed with the Register of Deeds today by the Columbus, Marshall and Northeastern Railroad Company to the New York Security and Trust Company in the sum of $2,800,000. Bonds, in sums of $1,000, will be issued at once.

Very marked is the illustration which weekly is given in the reports which THE NEW YORK TIMES quotes from the Commercial Agency reviews. Among the others who called upon Mr. McKinley to-day were Henry Loomis Nelson of Harper's Magazine, Frank A. Munsey of Munsey's, and Capt. Dodd of Troop D, Third United States Cavalry, who has just been ordered to the Philippines.

PERTH AMBOY, N.J., Aug. 4. -- Hugh Ramsay, a Perth Amboy shipbuilder, today contradicted in detail the stories that $150,000 of the Middlesex County Bank's money was lost in dredging operations. The story was that Valentine spent $80,000 for repairs. Ramsay made the repairs, and he says they cost less than $5,000.

UTICA, N.Y., Aug. 4. -- E.L. Stevens of Rome has handed in his decision as referee in the habeas corpus proceedings brought by Edward C. Briggs, a wealthy dentist of Boston, against his wife, Lou Lord Briggs, to obtain the custody of his six-year-old daughter Dorotha.

Justice Fitzgerald failed yesterday to sign the order confirming his decision, and it was announced that he would not be at the court house to-day.

ALBANY, Aug. 4. -- The general court-martial convened to try First Lieut. Wesley E. Bryde of the Ninth Regiment, N.G.N.Y., for directing the names of Sergt. Bodamer and Corp. Reidy to be placed upon the muster and pay roll of Company F, Ninth Regiment, N.G.N.Y., as qualified for service in the volunteer regiment and entitled to pay as members of the National Guard of New York, submitted its findings to the Adjutant General to-day.

DENVER, Col., Aug. 4. -- A horse show will be held here Friday and Saturday, Sept. 29 and 30. It will open with a $100 prize parade by the Denver Driving Club. Twenty-eight classes of horses and riders will be judged during the two days' exhibition, and three prizes will be given in each event, ranging from $100 to $10 each.

Surrounded by a hooting, jeering crowd of several hundred persons, William Waldorf Astor was burned in effigy last night in Long Acre Square. There was no policeman in sight until the work was well advanced, and when one finally did arrive there was little left of the image of the millionaire who lately renounced American citizenship.

MANCHESTER, Mass., Aug. 4. -- Senor Aspiroz, the Mexican Ambassador to the United States, who is spending the Summer here, was much interested in the report last night of the departure of President Roca of the Argentine Republic, with the Minister of Foreign Affairs and thirty Senators from Buenos Ayres.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4. -- An order was signed yesterday by Justice Cole directing the appearance of Emilia Trentanove in the suit for divorce brought against her by Gaetano Trentanove. Senor Trentanove is the sculptor who made the much-talked-of statue of Pere Marquette, now in the Capitol, which was attacked so fiercely by the American Protective Association.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4. -- The Street Cleaning Department of this city has now on file a report of one of its Inspectors on the condition of Thirty-first and South Streets, Georgetown. The report should be ranked as a classic in official literature. Complaint had been made to the District Commissioners that the streets were dirty and that weeds were growing in them.

NEWCASTLE, N.H., Aug. 4. -- The semifinals in the lawn tennis tournament at the Hotel Wentworth courts to-day furnished a big surprise in the defeat of Fischer by Wright. The New Yorker led in the first up to 5 -- 2 and 40 -- love, and in the second up to 4 -- 1 and 40 -- love, but each time young Wright finished strong and won the set.

The crowd that attended the meeting was one of the smallest since the season at Brighton Beach opened, but those who did make the journey were more successful in picking winners than they had been either Wednesday or Thursday.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 4. -- The fact has just come to light that Lucius F. Mellen, ex-Superintendent of the city infirmary and ex-General Agent of the Cleveland Humane Society, was terribly beaten by strike sympathizers last Wednesday. Mr. Mellen is sixty-eight years old and is in a precarious condition. His family did not report the matter to the police for fear of further violence.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4. -- Official reports to the Marine Hospital Service from the Soldiers' Home at Hampton show that the yellow fever situation there continues favorable. Surgeon White reports to Dr. Wyman that there is nothing suspicious in the town of Hampton.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5. -- Haiti is in a state of ferment, perhaps from sympathy with the neighboring State of Santo Domingo. United States Minister Powell has cabled to the State Depatment that the presence of a United States warship may be required if the present threatening conditions continue, to insure the safety of the United States Legation and Consulates.

Just before the Ministerial Council accepted the terms of this important arrangement a statement was spread abroad in the press to the effect that France would never agree to the conditions which the United States Government had formulated.

NEW HAVEN, Aug. 5. -- The yachts of the Larchmont contingent of the New York Yacht Club, bound for the cruise rendezvous at New London, started this morning from Larchmont for the first run of the cruise, arranged by the Larchmont Yacht Club. The destination was Morris Cove, this port, and to-morrow the second run will be made from here to New London.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5. -- The Navy Department opened bids at 1 o'clock to-day for the new timber dry dock at the United States Navy Yard. League Island, Philadelphia, which is to cost not more than $825,000, according to the provision made by Congress, and is to be one of the most spacious docks on the Atlantic Coast for the accommodation of warships.

NARRAGANSETT PIER, R.I., Aug. 5. -- Interest during the week has naturally centred at the Point Judith Country Club, where the annual polo tourney is in progress on the grounds at Wildfield Farm. Between 2 and 3 o'clock these fine afternoons of early August there is a constant stream of traps and gay turnouts en route to the polo grounds along the Ocean Road.

CHICAGO, Aug. 5. -- Working men and women had their first opportunity this week in Chicago to test the advantages of the new State employment agencies. Three were opened in the city, and on the first day the system was put into operation -- Wednesday -- there were nearly 3,000 personal applications for places, while 700 employers sent requests for help.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Aug. 5. -- It was hoped until to-day that the epidemic of infantile paralysis, which has created so much consternation in the households of this city, would disappear soon, since nearly a week had elapsed without a single new case reported. That hope disappeared this afternoon, however, when Dr. D.M. Sheedy, who was the first to call public attention to the prevalence of the disease, was summoned to attend two new cases.

NEWPORT, Aug. 5. -- Master Vincent Astor, son of Col. and Mrs. John Jacob Astor, is one of the youngest whips here, and can be seen almost any morning driving a red- wheeled basket cart to and from Bailey's Beach. Of course, he is always accompanied by a maid, and in this case at least he has the satisfaction of "holding the reins."

LENOX, Aug. 5. -- Among the more distinguished visitors in Lenox this week are Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Hippisley, who are the guests of Mr. and Mrs. Richard C. Dixey. They came up from New York on Wednesday, and are being entertained by the cottagers, who are giving dinners and other social functions in their honor.

LONDON, Aug. 5. -- Anna Dassojewa, the peasant woman of Abbas Tuman who saw the Czarowitch pass away, furnishes a most affecting narrative of his end. It appears that the Czarowitch's motor-tricycle was going at a great pace when he caught up to a cart in which was the milkwoman, Dassojewa.

BERLIN, July 24. -- The newspapers are amusing themselves by trying to solve the conundrum: Why has the Kaiser given up his promised visit to Dortmund to open the Dortmund-Ems Canal? All the true and false prophets venture solutions, most of them having to do with the international situation.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 5. -- The season waxes, and in a fortnight more it will have reached its height, although the wise counsels which placed the Horse Show in September's opening week -counsels not removed from real estate and other considerations -will prolong even the crowding gayeties well into September.

THERE is no handsomer vessel in the navy than the revenue cutter McCulloch, one of the eight "first raters" of the Cutter Service, a picture of which, as she lay at an anchorage in San Francisco Harbor, just before her transfer back to the Treasury, is reproduced from an excellent photograph.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 5. -- Impressive and significant was the funeral of Col. Hawkins, late commander of the Tenth Pennsylvania Volunteers, this afternoon.

THERE is a building on Duane Street, near Elm, which belongs to the Edison Electric Company, and indicates on its front a certain connection with electrical matters by a row of sculptured heads, among which those of Franklin and Morse are readily distinguished.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 5. -- St. Christina Home, formerly known as the Finley estate, which several years ago was purchased by Spencer Trask, the New York banker, who generously donated it to charitable purposes, was on Thursday afternoon and early evening the scene of a most successful lawn party.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Aug. 5. -- The Governors of Kansas, Nebraska, Minnesota, Iowa, Montana, and presumably all other States having volunteers in or en route home from the Philippines, have received letters from the San Francisco Labor Council, bitterly denouncing the policy of having the returning volunteers mustered out in San Francisco, and asking the Governors to use their influence toward bringing about a change.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Aug. 5. -- The strike at Louis Nixon's shipyard continues. All the platers, riveters, caulkers, boilermakers, and their helpers are idle. This means that all iron work in the yard is at a standstill. The strikers held their daily meeting at Mitchell's Hall. It was decided to pay to all members now on strike $7 a week as long as the trouble lasts.

John W. Keller, Commissioner of the Department of Public Charities, returned to the city on the steamer Lahn yesterday after an eight weeks' tour in England and Frence. Although he went abroad for a vacation, Mr. Keller spent considerable time in studying the charitable institutions of London and Paris.

Articles of incorporation of the tobacco firm of Buchanan Lyall have been filed with the Secretary of State at Albany. The company is capitalized at $4,000,000, all paid in. The stock of the new company will not be listed on the Exchange nor will it appear in the public market.

FAR ROCKAWAY, Aug. 5. -- The storm which struck here late this afternoon was one of the most violent ever known in this vicinity. Little damage was done here, but outside of this place some havoc was wrought by lightning. The guests at the Arverne Hotel were driven out into the storm in a panic by a bolt that struck the hotel.
NEWPORT, Aug. 5. -- This day and night were the busiest in the social history of Newport for the past five years.

ABOUT two miles from the bustling, modern town of Paterson, N.J., stands a house, which during the year 1780 was for three months the headquarters of Gen. Washington. It is beautifully situated in the midst of an undulating plain, bounded by the Preakness Mountain, the Passaic River, and First Mountain. Through the clefts in the hill lovely vistas of the far-reaching mountains may be seen.

Thurston, Inspector of Small Arms Practice. In the conditions governing the team matches it is laid down that "one-third of the members of a successful team shall be debarred from again competing in the same match for the next three years."

Curiosity, that merciful characteristic, which enables us in our deepest sorrows to take an interest in the affairs of our neighbor, reaches great heights even when means of its gratification are at hand.

The pneumatic mail tubes have been of great benefit in the dispatching of first-class mail, but the accumulation of mail matter of the second, third, and fourth classes, newspapers, publications, and merchandise, is a serious question.

As a climax to a day of great discomfort owing to the excessive humidity and absence of any refreshing breeze, a storm of unusual violence, although of brief duration, broke over Greater New York shortly after 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon. While the storm was at its height the wind reached a velocity of sixty-six miles an hour, and the downpour of rain drove people from the streets in a mad rush for shelter.

Two children who had been brought to this city from Albany yesterday to pass their vacations were deserted at the People's Line, Pier 41, North River, and left to the tender mercies of the officers of the line and later to the care of the police.

CAPE MAY, N.J., Aug. 5. -- During the past fortnight the visitors to Cape May have been coming in large numbers and New Yorkers have come in larger numbers than in any week during the present season or in seasons past. The hotels are filled with guests, while the cottage colony, which is this year enormously large, is entertaining a great many visitors.

Chairman B.B. Odell, Jr., of the Republican State Committee arrived yesterday morning on the St. Louis, accompanied by his family. They have been away exactly six weeks. They spent the entire time in Great Britain. All were in good health. After a short stop at the Fifth Avenue Hotel they took the 11:35 train for Newburg.

SYDNEY, July 8. -- A new and practical development of the co-operative principle is rapidly gaining ground in the Australian agricultural districts. It is known as the shares system, and represents combined effort on the part of landlord and tenant in agricultural production, the profits, after payment of expenses, being divided in proportions mutually agreed upon beforehand.

RENNES, Aug. 5. -- Rennes has awakened from its normal condition of sleepiness, and with the arrival of hundreds of journalists from all parts of the world, and witnesses and other actors in the Dreyfus drama, the town is assuming an animated appearance. The terraces in front of the cafes are full of people warmly discussing the coming trial, which opens on Monday morning at half-past 6 or 7 o'clock.

ALBANY, Aug. 5. -- A most formidable opposition to William Barnes, Jr., the Republican leader in this city, and his following, has recently developed. This extends to every ward, and unless the leader is able to counteract the influences which are now at work he will certainly be defeated at the Republican primaries.

LONDON, Aug. 5. -- Lord Pauncefote, the British Ambassador to the United States, continues to receive numberless congratulations on his elevation to the peerage. A mysterious telegram from Denver, Col., speaks of the danger of a premature death befalling the Golden Girl, without making it clear what disease it is that is likely to terminate the life of the lady in question. There seems to have been a contract for $12,000, which the telegram speaks of as a payment for the name Golden Girl of Colorado.

LONDON, Aug. 5. -- Fog spoiled the naval manoeuvres. The squadron sent to find and convoy the make-believe grain ships from America was unimpeded by the fog, proceeded to the rendezvous, and returned to the harbor undetected by the enemy's squadron, which encountered forty hours of fog.

NEWPORT, Aug. 5. -- This evening when the steamer Manisees, which plies between Narragansett Pier and Newport, was leaving the former place laden with society people and the members of the Westchester Polo Club, the purser, to guard against the loss of fares by the company, called upon one of the deck hands to serve as a guard at the stairway, until the fares from the passengers on the lower deck had been collected.

LONDON, Aug. 5. -- The session of Parliament practically ended yesterday evening, and the prorogation will take place Wednesday. There seems to be a very general belief that it will be the last full session of the present Parliament, shrewd political prophets predicting that a general election will be held next July, at the latest.

" Tod" Sloan, the so-called premier jockey of America, was literally refused accommodation at the Waldorf-Astoria yesterday. At least that was the statement made by an attache of the hotel. Other attaches denied that this was the case. They admitted, however, that Sloan had been at the house during the day.

"Yes, it's a howling shame," went on the baby. "That's just the way it is with those women; give them an inch and they take an ell.

BERLIN, Aug. 5. -- Events in the Transvaal are keenly watched here. The press comments liberally on the week's news. No doubt a strong undercurrent of sentiment exists, shared by every class, in favor of the Boers against Great Britain. Every German one meets expresses this freely, and the press, except the portion inspired by the Government, sides more or less strongly with the Boers.

COWES, Aug. 5. -- Count and Countess Boni de Castellane and their party, on the steam yacht Valhalla, have certainly been the social success of Cowes week. Their triumph culminated in the dinner on the vessel on Thursday to the Prince of Wales. Everything connected with the yacht was as smart as possible.

STOCKBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 5. -Stockbridge will be well filled with people from New York and other cities the rest of the season. Nearly all the cottagers are here, and many of them have guests at their country places.

WINTER HARBOR, Me., Aug. 5 -August has opened propitiously. The cottagers are now all here and the Inn is well filled with guests.

CAPE TOWN, July 12. -- At Delagoa Bay, the Portuguese possession on the east coast of South Africa, much speculation was occasioned recently by the approach to the outer anchorage of a man-of-war. The ship was discovered to be the American cruiser Chicago, which anchored seven miles from the town. She is a second-class cruiser of 7,000 tons, has a crew of 740, and is armed with four 8-inch and ten 5-inch quick-firing guns.

HAVANA, Aug. 5. -- The release from custody of L.L. Sloane, recently arrested on his arrival at New York, at the request of the Havana authorities on a charge of robbery, on the ground that there is no extradition treaty between the United States and Cuba, has astonished the lawyers and Judges of Havana, as well as Gen. Ludlow, the Military Governor.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5. -- The Treasury Department to-day made requisition upon the Bureau of Engraving and Printing for the printing of $10,000,000 in gold certificates of the denomination of $20 each. The Treasurer now holds a large unissued supply of certificates of the larger denominations.

NARRAGANSETT PIER, R.I., Aug. 5. -- Probably the best polo game ever seen at the Point Judith Country Club was played this afternoon between Westchester of Newport, and Meadow Brook, as a final contest for the Point Judith cup. Westchester won by a score of 4 1/2 to 4 1/4.

The Ost-Asiatische Lloyd points out that America is now building forty-six war vessels, and that the construction of twelve more was ordered during the last session of Congress.

LONDON, Aug. 5. -- The sensation of the moment is M. Blowitz's story of the intended abdication of the Czar. It has been a godsend in a way to the press, as all matters of special interest had apparently been killed by the weather, and there was nothing in sight but the Dreyfus case.

BERLIN, Aug. 5. -- From a gentleman in the entourage of the Emperor it is learned that the Emperor was greatly elated at the success of his yacht Meteor at Cowes. He exclaimed, when he received the news: "Now I have sent them home, beaten in their own waters." His Majesty then ordered champagne for everybody on board the Imperial yacht Hohenzollern.

The Germantown Cricket Club of Philadelphia paid a visit to the Knickerbocker Athletic Club yesterday at Bergen Point, and would in all probability have returned home defeated had not the storm intervened and turned the game into a draw.

If seven-year-old Gracie McDonald dies -and the doctors at the hospital say she cannot live -- the Brooklyn trolley will have scored its two hundred and fiftieth victim. Little Gracie, hurrying to keep a tryst with a playmate, was run down by a car in front of her home on Fifth Avenue, Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon, and both her legs were cut off by the wheels.
William Durant of Boston, who is just past eighty-three years of age, has for sixty-five years led a placid life as an attache of The Boston Transcript. He is now its Treasurer.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Aug. 6. -- The split in the Democratic Party is growing so rapidly that it is now deemed necessary to form a complete organization of anti-Goebel men, and yesterday the first steps were taken. The Fayette County Democrats opposed to the election of William Goebel, the head of the Democratic ticket, met here and made preparations for the coming State Convention on Aug. 16.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug. 6. -- At least twenty persons were drowned to-day at Mount Desert Ferry, eight miles from here, by the breaking of a gangplank on which they were walking from the wharf to a steamer which was to have conveyed them to this place. They were members of an excursion party from Bangor and other points on the line of the Maine Central Railroad.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Aug. 6. -- Another case of infantile paralysis developed to-day, and for the first time since the epidemic began the patient was more than five years of age. Patrick Fitzpatrick of Union Street called Dr. Sheedy to atend his seven-year-old daughter, and upon examination the doctor found that she is suffering from a pronounced attack of poliomyelitis.

The front of the Maronite Church, at 83 Washington Street, in the Syrian colony, was gayly decorated yesterday with festoons of evergreens and roses. LONDON, Aug. 6. -- The position last week did not materially differ from that of the previous week. We now wait the course of events, take our holidays, and leave speculation pretty well alone. The supreme question is still dear money -- is it coming or not? The Bank of England people say "Yes, it must come," and they do their best to keep the market from slipping away.

CHICAGO, Aug. 6. -- Chicago and Cleveland "split even" to-day. Pitcher Phyle's poor work gave Cleveland the first game, his wildness being followed by a bunching of hits. Garvin had the Clevelands at his mercy in the second game until the game looked safe, and then "let down" and was found freely at the finish.

SANTIAGO, Aug. 6. -- There are nearly 5,000 Cuban soldiers in town this evening, expecting to be paid here to-morrow. The remainder of the Cuban troops in the Province of Santiago will be paid at the towns of San Luis, Cristo, Songo, and El Caney. Col. Moale, on the United States transport Ingalls, arrived yesterday with the money. All the incoming trains are crowded with Cubans.

MANILA, July 2. -- This Island of Luzon is so large, the country is so hilly, and at this rainy season of the year the roads are so very bad that, in spite of the fact that communication is carried on with remarkable rapidity, considering the primitive methods employed, news really travels slowly and frequently gets mired in the deep muds or extinguished by the tropical downpour long before its destination is reached.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6. -- Dr. E.W. Allen, Assistant Director of Experiment Stations in the Agricultural Department, has just returned from an extended tour of the West, made for the purpose of inspecting the various stations in that section of the country.

PLATTSBURG, Aug. 6. -- President McKinley, accompanied by Secretary Cortelyou, attended church this morning, driving from the Hotel Champlain behind a pair of grays. Although the driver had lived in Plattsburg all his life, he drove the two to the Presbyterian Church instead of to the Methodist Church, making the President about fifteen minutes late.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6. -- John Goodnow, Consul General of the United States at Shanghai, has rendered a decision as referee in the consular court which will be of far-reaching importance during the continuance of the war in the Philippines. The case was in relation to the steamer Abbey, charged with taking arms from Canton to Luzon.

RENNES, Aug. 6. -- The town is extremely animated to-day, but everywhere perfect tranquillity prevails. Among those who have arrived are Gens. de Boisdeffre, Gonse, and Roget, all in mufti; M. Godefroy Cavaignac, former Minister of War, and M. Casimir-Perier, former President of France.

CHICAGO, Aug. 6. -- Robert G. Ingersoll, as a man, was praised and mourned by 1,500 Chicago admirers at Studebaker Hall tonight. Veterans of the cavalry regiment which he commanded during the civil war and members of the newly formed Ingersoll Memorial Association united in the memorial meeting.

CHICAGO, Aug. 6. -- Members of the Chicago Board of Trade and others directly interested in the handling of Western grain are looking forward to the meeting in this city to-morrow of the Inter-State Commerce Commission, and the executive officers of the Eastern and Western railroads. It is the general expectation that the meeting ultimately will result in a definite settlement of the long-standing question of export rates and "territorial rights."

NEW ORLEANS, La., Aug. 6. -- By the premature discharge of a small cannon yesterday on board the Celeste at Bay St. Louis, Miss., the nine-year-old daughter of Charles Janvier, President of the Sun Mutual Insurance Company of New Orleans, was badly mangled. The child was brought to New Orleans and placed in a sanitarium for treatment.

TACOMA, Washington, Aug. 6. -- Frenchmen have secured valuable mining concessions in the interior of China. M. Landauer, a Parisian banker and cousin of the Rothschilds, left here to-day for New York and Paris. He has been in China for four years representing a Parisian syndicate for which he has secured coal, quicksilver, and other mineral concessions in China valued at $100,000,000.

BAYONNE, N.J., Aug. 6. -- William A. Eddy's hot-air balloon, eight feet in diameter, was sent up at 4:15 o'clock Saturday afternoon as the big storm was approaching. Its course confirmed deductions Mr. Eddy had made from previous tests. The wind was slowly increasing in velocity for some time before the storm, but at the moment the balloon was released there was a temporary calm.

AUSTIN, Texas, Aug. 6. -- A special dispatch received here to-day from Terrasa, Chihuahua, Mexico, which is located near the scene of the Yaqui uprising, states that the Indians are arranging for a prolonged war. It is asserted that the Mexican Government will need a long time and a large force of troops to quell the rebellion.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Aug. 6.--The greatest catastrophe recorded in Connecticut for nearly half a century occurred shortly before 4 o'clock this afternoon on the Stratford extension of the Shelton Street Railway, when a loaded car went off the trestle over Peck's Mill Pond, at Oronoque, about six miles north of Bridgeport, and sank in the flats forty feet below.

PITTSBURG, Aug. 6. -- Whitney and Stephenson, who have been financiering the big river coal combination which is to be known as the Monongahela River Consolidated Coal and Coke Company, have completed the allotment of stock according to subscriptions received. The stock was oversubscribed by $1,250,000. The first payment by stockholders on par preferred stock is payable at the Union Trust Company's offices, this city, on Aug. 21.

NEWARK, Aug. 6. -- The most interesting event of the regular Sunday meet at the Vailsburg bicycle track this afternoon was an inter-city pursuit race. Teams from Newark, New Haven, Philadelphia, and New York were entered. By the terms of the race each contestant had to drop out when overtaken, so that the man who lasted longest would be winner.

DETROIT, Mich., Aug. 7. -- J.L. Hudson, receiver of the defunct Third National Bank, to-day received notice from the Controller of the Currency that a further assessment of 16 per cent has been ordered upon the capital stock. The first assessment was declared in February, 1894, soon after the bank closed, for a total of $252,000.

An examination of the body of James McGuire, formerly a paretic patient at the Manhattan State Hospital on Ward's Island, who died in that institution on Saturday, led to the arrest last evening of four keepers, who may have to answer to a charge of murder. The arrests were made on the strength of the report of Coroner's Physician Hamilton Williams, who conducted the post-mortem and reached the conclusion that McGuire met death by violence.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 7. -- The first production on any stage of Clinton Stuart's "Fairy Godmother" was given at the California Theatre to-night by the Frawley Company. The play is an adaptation of one of the elder Dumas's comedies. Miss Blanche Bates played the leading part. The period of the play is the sixteenth century.

CHICAGO, Aug. 7. -- The Inter-State Commerce Commission, which has recently been investigating charges of indiscriminate cutting of Western grain rates, met here to-day in another conference with the executive officers of the Western roads. The commission adjourned without taking action of any kind, and its members left for Denver to attend the annual meeting of the National Association of Railway Commissioners.

Job's Pond, the remarkable lake in this town, which has since early history puzzled scientific men by its phenomenal actions, is again furnishing material for curious speculation. It has no outlet, and in some places is from 40 to 60 feet deep. Dr. Field, in his history, says it rises and falls as much as fifteen feet, but not from such causes as affect other ponds.

RENNES, Aug. 7. -- The ancient capital of Brittany was never less moved, never more sluggish, than on this memorable day. It seemed a hundred thousand miles away from Dreyfus and his exciting case. He [Dreyfus] was known to be a good deal excited, but he had been keeping a stiff lip, and yesterday he refused to see the last set of photographs of his children brought from Paris by his brother-in-law.
BARROW-IN-FURNESS, England, Aug. 7. -- F.J. Quinlan of Harvard won a 100-yard dash here to-day.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug. 7. -- A careful examination by divers in the vicinity of the Mount Desert ferry slip, the scene of the terrible accident yesterday, and investigations on shore by the officials of the Maine Central Railway and others, up to 10 o'clock this forenoon seem to indicate that the twenty victims reported in last night's dispatches are all who perished as a result of the catastrophe.

BOSTON, Aug. 7. -- One of the local officials of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Road said this morning, when speaking on the present prosperity of the country, so far as business on his road is concerned, that he had never known a time when traffic moved in such enormous volumes as now.

There are literally millions of Russians who are starving and suffering from the torturing diseases that result from want of nourishment.

Some of the taxpayers of the Borough of Richmond, as well as those of Queens, are dissatisfied with the results of consolidation, especially since the publication of the tax rate. In Richmond County the taxes formerly were paid in several separate portions, the State, county, and town taxes falling due at one time, the school taxes at another time, and the taxes in incorporated villages forming another item.

RUTLAND, Vt., Aug. 7. -- The ceremony of laying the cornerstone of the Stark Monument as Peru, to-day, passed off successfully. Burton of New York, and the Stark Monument Association, formed three years ago, has done the work.

NEWPORT, Aug. 7. -- The Earl of Yarmouth made a number of calls to-day on the younger set of the cottagers, to ask their assistance in the amateur performances which are to be given during the first week in September at the Casino. The cast will be selected this week, and rehearsals will be held at the Casino theatre during the evenings and mornings when possible.

OCEAN GROVE, N.J., Aug. 7. -- An immense audience, that packed to overflowing the big Auditorium, heard the Hon. J.B. Dolliver of Iowa speak to-night on "Morbid Sociology." Bishop Fitzgerald presided.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7. -- Consul General Wildman has reported to the State Department from Hongkong on the growing trade of the West River, in China, which taps one of the most fertile sections of the empire, and in this connection he appends a memorandum giving an account of the depredations of Chinese pirates along this river.

PLATTSBURG, N.Y., Aug. 7. -- The President has had a busy day. He witnessed the races of the Champlain Yacht Club this afternoon on board Dr. Webb's yacht the Elfrida, in company with Vice President Hobart and Mrs. Hobart and party. Later he took a short drive with Mr. Hobart. This evening he held a long conference with Secretary of War Root, who arrived on the 7:10 P.M. train.

This corresponds with the list sent out last night, no additional casualties having been discovered.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Aug. 7. -- There was a big gathering of Democrats here today, the occasion being the meeting of the State Committee. The members of the committee formed but a small portion of the gathering, as almost every county in the State was represented.

NAPLES, Aug. 7. -- Admiral Dewey, who arrived here Saturday morning from Trieste on board the United States cruiser Olympia, positively refuses to discuss his operations in tile Philippines or his relations with the German Navy.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7. -- Charles F.W. Neely, Director of Finance for the Post Offices of Cuba, had a long conference with Acting Postmaster General Heath to-day. He said to a reporter that the Cubans were much pleased with the new Post Office system, which was improving daily. He thought it was a mistake to have military men govern the Cuban people.

LONDON, Aug. 8. -- A writ of habeas corpus for the custody of Gladys Perot, the daughter of Mrs. William Y. Perot, who is charged with abducting the child from Baltimore, has been granted to Newton Crane on behalf of W.H. Perot, father-in-law of Mrs. Perot, but has not yet been served.

TORONTO, Ontario, Aug. 8. -- Some splendid batting was again seen here to-day, when the annual cricket match between Canada and the United States was resumed. The Canadians concluded their innings with a lead of seventeen runs over the Americans' first innings score. This was brought about by the unlooked for good batting of H B. McGiverin, who hit vigorously for twenty-three, not out.

CHICAGO, Aug. 8. -- The General Conference of the Methodist Church, which has never met in Chicago, but will meet next May in the Auditorium, will not only have to select a number of Bishops, but will discuss the propriety of shortening the Bishops' term of office to eight or even four years.

PLYMOUTH, England, Aug. 8. -- The officers and men of the United States training ship Alliance, from New London, Conn., July 3, which arrived here July 29, made a tour of inspection of the dockyard this morning.

BOSTON, Mass., Aug. 8. -- Mayor Quincy has been asked by the "Board of Strategy," as the inner circle of the Democratic City Committee is called, if he will be a compromise candidate for Mayor this Fall, and he has told the board positively and finally that he will not run.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8. -- The Navy Department to-day opened the bids for the machinery of the Brooklyn Dry Dock, which was destroyed by fire last Spring. There were a large number of bidders, and it will take several days to determine which of them is the lowest in the several classes.

CHICAGO, Aug. 8. -- "Necessary changes in the interstate commerce law" was the question under discussion at the banquet of the National Association of Merchants and Travelers at the Auditorium, held last evening, and the two speakers invited to address the gathering were Chairman Knapp of the Interstate Commerce Commission and General Manager Paul Morton of the Santa Fe system.

The Committee on Plan and Scope of the Dewey Reception Committee held a meeting in the Mayor's office yesterday and received reports from the various sub-committees intrusted with the details of the celebration. Senator John Raines and other members of the committee appointed by the State Legislature were present and took part in the discussion.

NEWPORT, Aug. 8. -- At a meeting of the stockholders of the Newport Reading Room held to-day George H. Norman, Jr., was elected a stockholder and Mr. Stuyvesant Leroy a Governor. The annual meeting will occur next Wednesday.

UTICA, Aug. 8. -- The -- Rev. J. Hughes Parry, pastor of the Moriah Welsh Calvinist Methodist Church of this city, died of exhaustion following a fast of forty-eight days at Lake St. Catherine, a resort near Poultney, Vt., to-day. Mr. Parry fasted from May 15 to July 2 in the hope of curing himself of chronic catarrah of the bowels, the disease which caused the death of his father.

HAVANA, Aug. 8. -- Manzano, who was the Spanish Inspector of Police here during the war, when landing recently upon his return from Spain, was recognized by the son of a Cuban who was sent to the Isle of Pines, the Spanish penal settlement off the south coast of the island, owing to information given by Manzano.

Funeral service for Myer Stern were held in the Temple Emanu-El yesterday forenoon, and many men prominent in business and fraternal circles were present. Rabbi Gustav Gottheil and his assistant, Dr. Joseph Silverman, officiated. In an earnest eulogy Rabbi Gottheil spoke of Mr. Stern's philanthropic character, and of his activities in various organizations.

BAR HARBOR, Aug. 8. -- The day has been very gay at Bar Harbor. This morning, shortly after daybreak, the battleships Texas and Brooklyn, which have been at Rockland for two days, dropped anchor in the harbor. Admiral Sampson now has a complete blockade of the harbor with his flagship New York and the battleships Massachusetts, Indiana, Texas, and Brooklyn.

MANILA, Aug. 8 -- 4:50 P.M. -- Aguinaldo has appealed to the powers for recognition of "Filipino independence," in a document dated from Tarlac, July 27, and signed by Buencamino. It has been received by all the foreign Consuls in Manila, with the request that they forward it to their respective Governments.

Four young inmates of the House of Refuge on Randall's Island made a desperate and partially successful attempt to regain their freedom yesterday by jumping overboard. The attempt was premeditated, and had been well planned. Two of the boys reached the Long Island shore and escaped, after a long and perilous swim through the waters of Little Hell Gate.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 8. -- The Argentine squadron escorting President Roca of the Argentine Republic has arrived here. Fetes, lasting nine days, have been arranged in honor of President Roca's visit.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8. -- The number of enlistments yesterday were 442, making a total of 10,769. The Twenty-sixth Regiment, commanded by Col. Rice, has 1,312, which is more than the full quota, and the Thirtieth, commanded by Col. Gardner, has 1,305, only four short of the required number.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8. -- The rapid rise of Hungary toward a position of domination in the dual monarchy will soon make her a factor to be reckoned with in American foreign commerce. In four years Hungary will dictate the terms on which business shall be done with the outside world; and within a decade she may be dealing with other countries independently of the now dominant half of the monarchy.

NARRAGANSETT PIER, Aug. 8. -- A ball and reception was tendered to Gov. Elisha Dyer, staff, and ladies to-night at the Gladstone. The hotel was especially decorated for the occasion. The balconies were hung with Chinese lanterns and the smooth, spacious lawn was brightened by varicolored lights.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Aug. 8. -- President B.E. Rich of the Southern Mormon Society left to-night for Frankfort, Ky., to call on Gov. Bradley to bring to his attention the anti-Mormon outbreak in that State and to demand protection for the Elders.

PLATTSBURG, N.Y., Aug. 8. -- Secretary of War Root made a definite announcement this evening to the effect that the war in the Philippines is to be prosecuted with the utmost vigor, which should result in its speedy close. Mr. Root was seen in the office of the Hotel Champlain, just after he had said good-bye to the President, and was preparing to take the train for Washington.

The change in the Weather, with its rather chill atmosphere and its faint suggestion of Autumn and possible frost, was keenly felt at the watering place yesterday, especially at the mountain resorts, where great log fires were lighted at some of the camps and hotels, and there was a wintry note in the atmosphere. Already there are rumors of dances and elaborate functions.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8. -- The State Department is entirely without information as to any address by Aguinaldo to foreign powers for the recognition of the Filipinos, either as belligerents or as constituting an independent Government. The appeal is looked upon, however, as creating no particular change, as it has been the desire of Aguinaldo and his associates from the first to secure such recognition.
