Mrs. Annie Kronman, who was attacked with a hatchet by some person or persons unknown in her flat at 266 West Thirty-fifth Street Monday afternoon, died in the Roosevelt Hospital shortly before 9 o'clock yesteray morning. It was realized from the moment she was taken there that she could not survive her wounds.

President Vreeland of the Metropolitan Street Railway issued an order yesterday morning which marks a new era in the history of street railways. All conductors and motormen who remained loyal to the company during the strike on July 19 and 20 are to enjoy three days' vacation, with full pay.

Nearly half a hundred detectives, including some of the smartest men in the service of the Central Office, worked assiduously upon the Kronman murder case yesterday, but were no nearer a solution of the mystery last night than when they started to solve it. Two alleged important clues turned out to be valueless.

Miss Jessie Bartlett Davis arrived in the city yesterday. She went to the Netherland Hotel, where she will remain for three weeks, during which time she will determine what she will do this season. Miss Davis said she had received two flattering offers from prominent managers in this city, and to this fact was principally due her visit to New York at this time.
An American syndicate has just purchased for $1,000,000 two islets, La Cruza and La Ramon, off the coast of Cuba.

Andrus Hambosky, a young Hungarian, with $10 as his mite to start life in the New World, arrived here in the steamship Kaiser Wilhelm der Grosse, and was yesterday permited to land in the care of the Hungarian Society by the immigration officials. He did not at once take advantage of his liberty to leave the Barge Office, and was noticed lingering around in a seemingly despondent mood.

SORRENTO, Me., Aug. 9. -- The second day's play in the Maine State championship lawn tennis tournament to-day reduced the championship struggle to the four visiting players, all of the weaker players having been weeded out.

John Schaefflin of 541 Bergen Avenue, Jersey-City, thinks he has discovered a gold mine in the cellar under a double brick house he owns at 692 and 694 West Newark Avenue. This cellar until recently was only three feet deep. Mr. Schaefflin decided to make it six feet deep, to accommodate his tenants.

" Si" Seymour, the New York's pitcher, had one bad inning, the first, in the game with the Louisvilles at the Polo Grounds yesterday afternoon. He allowed the Louisvilles to hit his pitching for a three-bagger, a double, and two singles, yielding three runs -- a lead that the New Yorks could not overcome in the face of the splendid pitching by Phillippi.
NEWPORT, Aug. 9. -- Tennis still reigns supreme at the Casino, and the courts are continually in use during the entire forenoon and for a goodly portion of the afternoon.

The Board of Classification of the United States General Appraisers yesterday announced a decision regarding what are known as the St. Gall cases. These cases have been pending for some time.

BOSTON, Aug. 9.--One week ago there was discovered a case of smallpox in Everett. The patient was immediately taken off to the pesthouse, down the harbor, the premises thoroughly disinfected and roped off, and the inmates quarantined. The following day every inhabitant of Ward No. 1 was vaccinated.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9. -- Assistant Secretary Vanderlip was asked to-day about reports that he had ordered a reduction in salaries of several chiefs and assistant chiefs of division in the office of the Auditing Department because he had visited the offices and found these chiefs and their clerks reading newspapers and loitering during work hours.

Mrs. William B. Lowe of Atlanta, Ga., President of the National Federation of Women's Clubs, who is at the Waldorf-Astoria and will leave to-day for Europe said last night that the women's clubs of America will have an exhibit at the Paris Exposition. Mrs. Lowe has called a meeting of the honorary members, who live in the French capital, so that she may confer with them concerning the work of organizing clubs there.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9. -- The Bureau of Construction of the Navy .Department has ordered the work of outfitting the converted yachts Wasp, Frolic, and Dorothea to proceed at the Norfolk Navy Yard..

Kimball, Assistant Quartermaster General of the Army, and who during the war was in charge of the New York Depot of the Quartermaster's Department, which furnished most of the supplies for the army, has just completed a report of the work done by his office during the fiscal year ending June 30, 1899.

With the incorporation of the Sloss-Sheffield Steel and Iron Company, to operate with a capital of $20,000,000 in the coal and iron fields of Alabama, the most important of the recent consolidations of Southern mineral properties will be started this week under the laws of New Jersey.

ANACONDA, Mon., Aug. 9. -- At 3:30 o'clock this afternoon a terrific thunderstorm broke over the city. Suddenly an especially loud detonation was heard up Sheep Gulch, which runs far back into the mountains, and spectators could see the walls of the gulch whitened by a sudden flood.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Aug. 9. -- Five hundred business men of Cleveland held an anti-boycott meeting this afternoon in the Chamber of Commerce rooms. A fund of $10,000 was started to ferret out the criminals who are dynamiting cars and creating discord in the city. In a few minutes' time not less than $5,000 was subscribed, and the rest of the amount will be fully made up to-morrow.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 9. -- Since the 1st of January Baltimore has enjoyed an unprecedented boom in trust companies, and the financial world has been set in a flutter by the number of these corporations which have sprung up like mushrooms after a Spring shower. The success of all of these new concerns is regarded as problematical, though some of them have already made large profits.

BERLIN, Aug. 9. -- According to the Berliner Tageblatt, Emperor William received Congressman George Edmund Foss of Illinois and United States Naval Attache Beehler on board the imperial yacht Hohenzollern last Wednesday at Kiel, granting them an audience of three-quarters of an hour.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9. -- The report that Marseilles is now menaced by the plague lends interest to a report just received from Consul Robert P. Skinner of that city, and published to-day by the State Department.
LONDON, Aug. 9. -- There was a considerable dash of excitement in the last hour of the session of Parliament which has just closed.

At a watering place third as to rank in point of size and fashion one finds the Summer residents as much slaves of their engagement books as in Winter at their city homes. Insensibly the round of visits, luncheons, dinners, and receptions has increased until the burden of them has so gained ground that a business man merely finds the change of scene a change of business.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 9. -- The decree of Bishop Janssen of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Belleville, Ill., excommunicating the members of St. Patrick's congregation of East St. Louis who are in rebellion against his authority in the matter of appointing a German-born priest to succeed an Irish-American rector, went into effect at noon to-day, when the communicants held a meeting in defiance of the prelate.

OCEAN CITY, Md., Aug. 9. -- Charles R. Bliss of Washington, cashier of the New England Mutual Life Insurance Company, was drowned while bathing in the surf opposite the Ocean City Life-Saving Station here this afternoon at 12:30. He was out in the breakers, and having been swimming for some time had become exhausted, when he was suddenly thrown into an eddy, and this, with a strong current, soon took him beyond his depth.

LONDON, Aug. 9. -- William A. Brady is experiencing considerable difficulty in finding a hall suitable for the proposed Jeffries-Mitchell boxing exhibition, the Sporting Club being closed. But he is still endeavoring to succeed.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9. -- Hundreds of houses have been destroyed and several persons killed by the hurricane that has swept over the West Indies, according to official advices received late this afternoon at the War and Navy Departments.

Hale the four-story dwelling, 112 West Thirty-fourth Street, adjoining at the rear, 16.8 by 95.9. The buyer will alter the premises for business purposes.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Aug. 9. -- The Chicago Platform Democrats, thirty in number, who assembled in conference, at the Empire House, here to-day, formed a permanent organization because Colvin R. Keach requested them not to do so.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9. -- Col. A. Cervantes and Ricardo Arnanto, the editors of the suppressed Havana newspaper El Reconcentrado, arrived here to-night. They made known the nature of the charges against the administration in Havana, which they are to lay before the Secretary of War in support of a demand for an investigation.

YOKOHAMA, July 28. -- Life among foreigners here under the new treaties is progressing as smoothly as under the old, and the fears of those who imagined that on the 17th of July, when we passed under Japanese jurisdiction, tumbrils would be backed against our doors and all foreigners carried away to jail, have not been justified.

Col. William E. Sinn, for twenty-four years proprietor of the Park and Montauk Theatres, in Brooklyn, died suddenly last night in the Maplewood Hotel, Pittsfield, Mass. He was sixty-five years of age, and was one of the best-known men in Brooklyn.

QUITMAN, Ga., Aug. 9. -- At the meeting of the Georgia State Agricultural Society here to-day the race problem came prominently to the front. Pope Brown, President of the society and a planter of the State, asserted, amid loud applause, that the white man and the negro are now at the parting of the ways, and said the former should assist the latter in his efforts to leave this country.

CHICAGO, Aug. 9. -- A dispatch from Victoria, B.C., says that Senator Beveridge of Indiana returned by the Empress of China to-day from Manila, which point he left on July 10, accompanied by Mrs. Beveridge and two leading residents of the Philippine colony of Americans, Dr. J. Donelan and R.D. Wood, each of whom has made Manila his home for more than a quarter of a century.

The Council at yesterday's meeting adopted by a vote of 22 to 5 the resolution authorizing the issue of $2,100,000 in bonds for the erection of the new Hall of Records. This action of the Council will in all likelihood summarily end all proceedings in the contempt case which grew out of previous refusals to authorize the bonds referred to.

NEWPORT, Aug. 9. -- This evening Mrs. John R. Drexel entertained twenty young people at dinner at her cottage on Ochre Point, and later fully fifty others came in and danced. The dancing included a cotillion, which was led by William Hugh Nelson and Miss Fell of Philadelphia, and for which pretty and unique little favors were given for each figure.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Aug. 9. -- Telegrams from Greytown report the arrival there of fourteen members of the United States Canal Commission, and forty more are expected in a few days to restudy the proposed canal routes across Nicaragua. All are reported to be in good health.

LONDON, Aug. 9.--The success of Americans in obtaining British contracts is exciting some alarm here. The question was raised in Parliament last April, by Sir Alfred Hickman, who wanted to know why the contract for building the Atbara River (Soudan) bridge had been given to an American firm.

BIDDEFORD, Me., Aug. 9. -- Arrangements are being made for the removal of the Springvale Cotton mills of Springvale, Me., to Fort Valley, Ga. The removal will be the second of the kind from York County. About one year ago the Portsmouth Cotton Mill of South Berwick, a small corporation, went South.

A square table was spread on the deck. In the centre of the table there was a space of ten feet square confined to floral decorations.

Lieut. Gov. Timothy L. Woodruff returned to Brooklyn from the Adirondacks and Bluff Point yesterday for a brief stay. He had a conference with Senator Platt during the day, at which, it was said, the feud in the Republican Party in Brooklyn, which is daily becoming more serious, was discussed.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9. -- The reports so far received from Sub-Treasury cities indicate that the call for gold certificates in exchange for gold coin will be considerably less than the Treasury officials expected. San Francisco, Chicago, Cincinnati, St. Louis, and New Orleans, however, have not yet been heard from, and consequently there is no proper basis upon which to estimate closely the result of the Secretary's recent order.

BOSTON, Aug. 10. -- James Gauley was before Judge Hardy in the Equity Session of the Superior Court Thursday for contempt. HAVANA, Aug. 10. -- In an open letter published to-day by La Lucha, Gen. Maximo Gomez says he has remained in Cuba to fulfill a great duty. Now that exaggerated and mistaken notions are current regarding the state of Cuba, he desires to explain the true situation.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10. -- Returns of United States Shipping Commissioners (except from Norfolk) for the fiscal year ended June 30, 1899, show 75,106 shipments and reshipments of seamen and 45,444 discharges, compared with 72,643 shipments and reshipments and 43,752 discharges for the previous fiscal year.

FORT DE FRANCE, Island of Martinique, Aug. 10. -- The authorities of the Island of Guadeloupe are still without news from the interior, owing to the interruption of telegraphic communication, as a result of the recent hurricane. But other advices which have reached Pointe-a-Pitre, say that the coffee and cocoa crops have been nearly totally destroyed.

Dr. A.C. Johnson, house surgeon of the Home for Incurables on One Hundred and Eighty-eighth Street, and Miss Emma Wilson of 1,580 Washington Avenue, were waylaid and knocked down by a negro at 9 o'clock Wednesday night, as they were walking on the aqueduct. William H. Jackson, a negro, thirty-three years of age, employed on the Morris Dock, was subsequently arrested and identified by Dr. Johnson as the assailant.

CHICAGO, Aug. 10. -- A sensation was caused at the meeting here to-day of executive officers of Western railroads by the announcement that the Grand Trunk Railway, in connection with the Burlington Road and the Maine Steamship Line, had established a rate of 80 cents per 100 pounds on first-class freight from New York to Kansas City.

BOURNE, Mass., Aug. 10.--Deputy Sheriff Edward H. Burgess of Monument Beach was shot by burglars here early this morning, but his wound is not considered dangerous. Stillman Smalley, a watchman at Buzzard's Bay, who came to Bourne on his wheel to assist the Deputy Sheriff, also was shot, but was only slightly hurt.

BOSTON, Aug. 10.--General Manager Chamberlain of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad emphatically denied to-night the report of a consolidation of that road with the Boston and Maine and Canadian Pacific. WHITE PLAINS, Aug. 10. -- George M. Pullman, son of the late George M. Pullman of palace-car fame, came here this morning and took up his residence at the Carpenter boarding house. He was accompanied by his negro valet. After being settled at the boarding house, he registered at the Keeley Institute, and a little later lined up, with a score of others, to take the injection.

Is it not time now to compel the trolley companies to place their death-dealing wires under ground? I am a constant reader of THE TIMES, and am surprised at the terrible loss of life that I read of every day from the trolley cars and the breaking of the wires. It is horrible and should be stopped. New York has never allowed the wires to be overhead.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10. -- According to the advance sheets of Pension Commissioner Evans's statement for the fiscal year ended June 30, the Spanish war resulted in no less than 16,986 applicants for pensions. Of this number the claims of only 295 were allowed. During the year there was a considerable falling off in the number of pensioners.

A rainstorm of exceptional severity came upon the city yesterday morning. For the time it lasted -- from about 6 A.M. to 10:10 A.M. -- the waterfall was the greatest that the city has had this Summer. A fall of two and a half inches of rain in this vicinity in twenty-four hours is called excessive by the Weather Bureau.

LONDON, Aug. 10.--The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes: Total reserve increased 534,000, circulation decreased 231,000, bullion increased 303,425, other securities decreased 263,000, other deposits increased 510,000, public deposits decreased 257,000, notes reserved increased 471,000, and Government securities decreased 4,000.

HAVANA, Aug. 10. -- El Diario de la Marina devotes considerable space to-day to a riot which occurred in Cienfuegos. It appears that a bread cart, having a Spanish flag painted on it, with the name of the owners beneath, was stopped by a party of Cubans, who threatened to kill the driver if he attempted to resist.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Aug. 10. -- The Elizabeth and Westfield Street Railroad last night excavated under the Central Railroad tracks at Westfield and put down its rails. This action was taken to head off the Kean road, which also wanted the crossing at the same point.

SAN JUAN DE PUERTO RICO, Aug. 10. -- A hurricane broke over the south coast at 1 o'clock Tuesday morning and swept northwest. There was no abatement for nine hours, the greatest damage being done between 8 and 10 o'clock in the morning. The wires were down, and communication with the interior was for a time impossible.

An expert testified that the fame of New York City as a "wide-open" town has gone over all the world, and that disreputable characters are flocking here, not only from other cities of this country, bug even from England. There really seems to be no depth of infamy in the degradation of the City Government which has not been reached. -- The Evening Post on the testimony before the Mazet committee.

Prof. G. Sanarelli of the University of Bologna, Italy, has compiled some observations and controversial remarks on the specific cause of yellow fever, which will appear to-morrow in the form of a paper in The Medical News, as a reply to his American critics. That journal will say, by way of editorial comment:

NEW ORLEANS, La., Aug. 10. -- Among the many stories of personal heroism narrate in the press dispatches during the Santiago campaign was one that still lingers in the memory of many readers. On July 2, the day following the remarkable storming of San Juan Hill, a little detachment of the Tenth Infantry lay in trench to the left of the activity in the focus of a four-cornered Spanish fire.

Acting on a warrant issued by Deputy Chief Cortright, Roundsmen Grady and Devery, with Detectives Darcy, Brown, Gilday, Ware, and Haughey of the Central Office, and ten patrolmen of the West Sixty-eighth Street Police Station, yesterday morning raided an opium smokers' resort on the top floor of the fiat house at 28 West Sixty-fourth Street.

QUEENSTOWN, Aug. 10. -- The British ship Nelson, Capt Perrian, which sailed from Lyttleton, N.Z., May 5 for London, and which has arrived at this port, reports that she passed, July 3, in latitude 48 north, longitude 21 west, a three-ton cutter, containing one man, steering in the direction of Ireland. The occupant of the boat made no reply to the Nelson's signals.

SORRENTO, Me., Aug. 10. -- Both events in the Maine State championship lawn tennis tournament were reduced to the final stage to-day, and Fischer and Paret, the two New York players, were the winners. To-morrow they will come together in the finals for the right to challenge H.H. Hackett for the State championship and challenge cup representing this title.
NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 10. -- An attempt was made to see Mrs. Sigsbee in relation to the report of the secret wedding of her daughter, Miss Mary Ellen Sigsbee, to Balfour Kerr of New York.

Controller Coler said yesterday that within a few weeks he would advertise the sale of a portion of the issue of $2,100,000 Hall of Records bonds, and that, in his opinion, the bonds had been legally authorized.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10. -- In diplomatic quarters copies of the report just presented to the Houses of Parliament by the committee which investigated the currency of India have been received. It is on this report that Lord George Hamilton, Secretary of State for India, has based his announcement within the last few days that India would go to the gold standard.

If Richard Croker had been present at the meeting of the Tammany Hall General Committee of the Ninth Assembly District at the Pequod Club last night he would have heard something which would have made his ears tingle. The same may be said of Councilman Frank J. Goodwin and Thomas F. Smith, who are leading the fight against John C. Sheehan for the leadership.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 10. -- Private information received here from Santiago, where the Earn Line steamship Sutherland now lies quarantined with yellow fever raging among its crew, confirms the report of the serious illness of Capt. Percy Nibbs, her commander. No hope whatever is entertained for his recovery.

Under this cozy title have been collected eleven of Bernard Capes's short stories, including among them "Jack and Jill," "A Lazy Romance;" "Dark Dignum," and "A Voice from the Pit." All of the contents of the volume, with the exception of three articles, have been published in either The Cornhill, Macmillan's, Pearson's, or Sketch Magazine.

BAR HARBOR, Aug. 11. -- Mrs. Sands of Glen Ridge, N.J., the wife of William P. Sands, cashier of the Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York, dropped dead upon the deck of the United States cruiser New York this afternoon.
The total sales of "David Harum" during the month of July were 40,008. The book is now selling in its two hundred and fortieth thousand.

After a desperate struggle with the ringleader of an illicit distillery of unusually large capacity in the outskirts of Jersey City last night, Revenue Agent F.G. Thompson and seven deputies succeeded in capturing the plant and arresting four of its operators.

Major Arthur Griffiths and M. Goron, authorities on English and French criminology, furnish us with what are the actual facts relating to thieves, bandits, and swindlers in business, as has Prof. Lombroso given us what are possibly their psychological or anthropological conditions. During the last five years the perfect rascal is occupying the attention of the maker of fiction, and we are largely increasing our stock of picaresque literature.

Sonn Brothers, have bought from the Carns estate the plot at the northeast corner of Amsterdam Avenue and One Hundred and Eighty-fourth Street, 130 by 200. Application has been made for the opening of One Hundred and Eighty-fourth Street at this point, which will necessitate the acquisition of a thirty-foot strip by the city, leaving a plot 100 by 200.

BOSTON, Aug. 11. -- President Clark of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad was asked to-day how much of truth there was in the rumors of the contemplated consolidation deals by the company with other transportation properties. He replied that there was not a grain of truth in the reports.

The increasing demands for space in THE SATURDAY REVIEW (so far as good available matter in concerned THE TIMES might easily issue a twenty-four-page number each week instead of a sixteen-page one) make it necessary for the editor to beg readers who contribute to the Questions and Answers department to be brief and pointed and to write only on matters of real value and interest.

In exceedingly attractive form Stevenson's "Morality of the Profession of Letters" comes to us from "The Brothers of the Book." The essay originally appeared in The Fortnightly Review for April, 1811; has since been included in both the Edinburgh and Thisile editions of Stevenson's works, but has never before been issued as a separate reprint.

ST. MICHAEL'S, Azores, Aug. 11. -- The British steamer Cayo Hono, Capt. Friend, from Zaza via Kingston, Jamaica, July 26, for Genoa, has put in here for coal. She reports that on Aug. 7, in latitude 35 north, longitude 40 west, she passed the Hamburg-American Line steamer Venetia, Capt. Schulke, from Hamburg via Grimsby, July 27, for the West Indies and New Orleans.

Bret Harte has often been severely criticised for endowing that fascinating and famous character Jack Hamlin the gambler, with the polish, bearing, and refined tastes of a cultured gentleman. There is, in fact, no reason why a gambler should not possess all these qualities, and it is quite probable that he often does.

-- A writer who has, we understand, a right of long growth to call himself, as he does, "a practical politician," discusses with marked ability in the last number of The Independent the questions whether the political boss is a necessity under our form of government, whether it is possible to destroy or abolish the power of such bosses, and, if so, how it can most easily and speedily be done.

The Victoria History, announced in England, will be a national historic survey of every county in England, which is designed to show the several conditions of these counties at this the end of the nineteenth century.

A voluminous opinion by ex-Senator George F. Edmunds was yesterday forwarded to Secretary of War Root as to the right of the War Department to use military force to prevent the Commercial Cable Company from landing on its own property in Cuba at the Cuban end of its proposed cable line, between that island and the United States.

BAR HARBOR, Aug. 11. -- Capt. Charles D. Sigsbee of Admiral Sampson's squadron, formerly commander of the battleship Maine, has confirmed the report of the secret marriage of his daughter Mary, an art student, to Balfour Kerr, a New York artist. When asked as to the truth of the report to-day, Capt. Sigsbee said:

The Mazet Investigating Committee took a recess yesterday until Sept. 12. This was done over the protest of Assemblyman Hoffman, the Tammany member, who insisted that the committee should remain in session continuously until its work was completed. The inquiry into the letting of contracts and the purchase of supplies by the various departments will, it is understood, be resumed when the committee meets again.

The Tribune philosopher is laying an anchor to windward for subsidies preparatory to the next session of Congress. Now all this that he says is perfectly true, but how will subsidies help the situation unless they are paid directly to our manufacturers instead of to favored steamship lines?

I am shocked to see the pernicious spirit of discrimination against the foreign-born citizen crop up in your letters anent the coming yacht races. If the foreign-born citizens did not "come over," the real natives of America might still be dodging behind bushes on the Bowery to save their scalps from their savage neighbors.

FREEHOLD, N.J., Aug. 11. -- The wedding of Charles Campbell and Lydia Storer took place to-night, three days late. Campbell is a young man who has the right to vote, and is therefore supposed to be beyond the reach of parental discipline, but it would appear that he had been subjected to it in a very severe manner.

William Miller has embodied in his volume entitled "Travels and Politics in the Near East" the observations of four trips to the Balkan Peninsula in the years 1894, 1896, 1897, and 1898. He is a keen observer, and, having thoroughly studied the Eastern question, is well qualified to select features which are of interest in a subject which has been the study of diplomats and authors for centuries.

Local Methodists have under discussion a big plan. It is a united effort to raise a great sum of money as an end-of-the-century offering, pay off the indebtedness resting upon all Methodist churches within the limits of the greater city, and then hold two immense jubilee services to offer thanks and to burn all of the mortgages.

The price of meats to consumers, which has been gradually raised recently, is to be still further advanced two or three cents a pound, owing, it is claimed, to a marked shortage in the supply. The Greater New York Retail Butchers' Association has practically decided upon raising prices, and final action will be taken by the members of the association, to be held next Tuesday night at 915 Eighth Avenue.

BERLIN, Aug. 11. -- Emperor William to-day attended the opening of the Dortmund-Ems Canal. Replying to an address of the Burgomaster, his Majesty said he regarded the canal as a work to form part of a greater whole, which he and the Government had inflexibly determined to further, and he hoped the nation's representatives would place him in the position to do so before the end of the year.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11. -- There is no doubt that Secretary Root will, in due course, take such measures and make such alterations in the plan of campaign in the Philippines as may be advisable, but most of the wild rumors that have been floating about the city ever since he took office, and which have gathered momentum during the past few days, are without foundation.

LONDON, Aug. 12. -- The correspondent of The Times at Rennes says: "Four days of examination have revealed the utter flimsiness of the secret dossiers. The diplomatic dossier contains proofs of Esterhazy's treason, attested by foreign agents."

BOSTON, Aug. 10. -- Dr. W.E. Griffis's "The American in Holland," soon to be published by Messrs. Houghton, Mifflin Co., comes none too soon to describe the land of the Peace Conference to Americans. Dr. Griffis beheld Queen Wilhelmina's coronation during the latest of his five visits to the kingdom.
In their weekly review of the trade, R.G. Dun Co. to-day will say:

KINGSTON, Jamaica, Aug. 11. -- A letter from Santo Domingo dated Aug. 3, via Haiti, confirms the cable dispatch telling of the spread and significance of the revolution throughout the Dominican Republic. Prominent men in civil and military circles, it appears, are taking the field, with the understanding that Jiminez is the prime mover and that he will soon arrive there from Cuba with munitions of war.

CHICAGO, Aug. 11. -- Charles A. Beard, who assisted Walter Vrooman of St. Louis to establish Ruskin Hall at Oxford, England, last February, and thereby inaugurated a new social movement, which has proved very successful, has arrived in this country, and is en route to Chicago, where he will establish the first branch of the movement in the United States.

CHICAGO, Aug. 11. -- The Union Traction Company is about to adopt the system of bonding its gripmen, motormen, and conductors, according to the report which prevailed among its employes. While President Spalding denies that there is any foundation for the report, it is believed by the men and has become the prevailing topic of discussion around the barns and among the employes who will be affected.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11. -- Secretary Hitchcock and other Government officials in this city have received copies of a circular signed by Edward Atkinson, which the author says has been or will be sent to the commissioned and non-commissioned officers of each returning regiment of troops from the Philippines, together with copies of pamphlets containing articles on the Philippine situation from an anti-imperialist point of view.

The Folk-Lore Society gave a dinner in London to Prof. Frederick Starr of the University of Chicago, and, led by Mr. Andrew Lang, the folk-lorists in general had a most jolly time. In fact, discussions on folk-lore do lead to an unquenchable thirst -- say, for knowledge. The Queen and the President of the United States were toasted, and then Mr. Andrew Lang followed with a clever speech.

The accounts of the hurricane in Puerto Rico are of a nature to make all Americans think pretty seriously. It is evident that the acquisition of the new territory in the West Indies which has recently been added to our possessions has brought with it some burdens of which no thought was taken at the outset.

MONTREAL, Aug. 11. -- Indications of rain kept down the attendance at the bicycle races to-day. In the first heat of the five-mile professional handicap Nat Butler made a world's competition record. Before the start in the second heat some one stuck a pin in the front tire of Major Taylor's wheel, and, although it was discovered, he started on the wheel; but had to quit after going a couple of miles.

Negotiations are in progress which may terminate in the building of an immense hotel, casino, and bathhouse at Far Rockaway. John F. Caroll and Randolph Guggenheimer are said to be interested in the project, and will spend half a million dollars.

I should like to ask Mr. Baxter a plain question and to receive a direct answer. How, Mr. Baxter, do you yourself define "unhouseled"? In your first letter to THE TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW you gave, as its equivalent, viaticum, the Latin form for "the eucharist," with, I suppose, a particular reference to the time of its administration, viaticum being the Roman word for "a last meal taken just before leaving home for a journey."

ATLANTA, Aug. 11. -- The Atlanta Athletic Club has secured a sanction from the National Lawn Tennis Association to hold Aug. 23, 24, 25, and 26 a Southern inter-State championship. Trophies will be given to the winners of the singles and doubles.

Mr. Powers tells in prose and verse the incidents of Virginia life, and it is Uncle Isaac, the faithful old man, who is the poet. The devotion of these old servants is barely expressible in words. It was a part of their lives. The honor of the white family they upheld. In quaint language they kept up the family traditions and imparted these to the white children.

It is a very common mistake to think that the most successful writers in fiction have attained their highest distinction while in the first flush of youth, inspired by the glow of youthful romance and passion. If we look back over the lives of our greatest novelist we shall find that this was far from being the case.

The interest now taken by collectors in the history of book gathering, which has long centred about the auction room, has led to the writing of the latest volume in the series known as "The Book Lover's Library." In "Book Auctions in England in the Seventeenth Century," John Lawler, the compiler of the catalogues of the famous Sunderland and Ashburnham sales, has produced a readable little book which posseses much bibliographical interest.

That is really a most interesting suggestion that comes from Washington that Gen. MERRITT should take charge of the campaign in the Philippines, allowing Gen. OTIS to relapse into the Governorship General of Luzon, or the Governorship of Manila, as the case might be.

All story lovers who followed the serial publication of Mr. Frederic's "Market Place" must have been most disagreeably surprised by the singular falling off, in interest and construction, of the last two chapters. This masterpiece of fiction was practically left unfinished, and the mark of a less skillful hand is clearly traceable.

State Senator William F. Mackey of Erie County, reached the city with a boom for the Democratic nomination for Governor yesterday, and spent the day telling his friends how he should nurture it. The field of this development at this early stage will be at the house of the Prospect Gun Club, at Freeport, L.I., and a number of up-State and local politicians are, according to Mr. Mackey, to take part in the affair.
SANTIAGO DE CHILE, Aug. 11. -- Severe storms throughout Chile continue to do immense damage.

Certain amateur book collectors in this city have long expressed the desire for a broader range of selection than the limited number of auction rooms offer. An attempt will be made to meet this desire By Mr. John Anderson, Jr., who some time in October will open auction rooms in the vicinity of Broadway and Twenty-eighth Street.

Under this heading in the department of Questions and Answers, THE TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW will from week to week print items from its readers concerning scarce and out-of-print books they are in search of, books they wish to exchange, and other items of similar character. Judging from the growing volume of letters in this line that are received, the editor believes that readers will find this column a convenience.

CHICAGO, Aug. 11. -- A special to The Times-Herald from Deadwood, S.D., says that the lives of ninety-three teachers were saved from possible destruction by fourteen-year-old Manley Beaver to-day. As a reward for his presence of mind a free course of instruction in the State Normal School at Madison has been tendered him.
Mrs. Isabel Hoyt, when seen yesterday in regard to the report that her father, Col. William E. Sinn, had left her the lease of the Montauk Theatre, refused to say anything about it.

RENNES, Aug. 11. -- The Dreyfus court-martial concluded its secret sessions at 9 o'clock this morning, when M. Paleologue of the Foreign Office completed his explanations of the secret dossier. The court will meet again at 6:30 to-morrow morning.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11. -- A customs secret service is to be organized to break up smuggling in Cuba, which has now assumed the proportions of a lucrative industry. Nearly every port on the island has a thriving smuggling trade. Some fast seaworthy launches are to be purchased and used to patrol the coast.

Frenchmen are the most industrious of historians, that is, when they discuss the events occurring in their own country some 300 or 400 years ago, and so their chroniclers of the Valois family are as many as they are trustworthy. Such material in English, not being readily accessible to us, Catharine Bearne's "Lives and Times of the Early Valois Queens" is of historic value.

The new labor political party met again last evening at Clarendon Hall, and the Credentials Committee announced that eleven more labor organizations had sent delegates, making 116 in all. The attendance was not as large as on the first day, but this was accounted for by the statement that many unions held individual meetings last night.

The facts of a love romance in the life of Elihu Burritt, "the learned blacksmith," might have been lost permanently but for the chance recovery of a few letters, four in number, written by himself to the object of his idolatry. These letters, which were found some years ago in a mass of paper mill stock in the town of Manchester, now belong to Henry E. Rogers of that place.

Signor Rodolfo Lanciani tells in The Athenaeum about the sale of a great picture, the "Madonna and Child" of Sandro Botticcilli which picture certainly was the gem of the Chigi collection. The Italian Government supposedly exercises some kind of watch and ward over the sale of rare pictures Perhaps an effort is made so as to prevent their getting into unappreciative hands.

Heads of city departments are busily engaged in preparing their estimates for the conduct of their offices during the fiscal year of 1900. Some of these estimates have already been sent to the Controller, and the rest will be in by the end of this month.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11. -- Senator Jones, who is reported by ex-Gov. Stone to be a sick man, but whose correspondents in this city say he is in good health, is coming home about Oct. 1. When he gets here he will have an opportunity to deny, on Mr. Stone's behalf, the reports that the latter is trying to supplant him as chief man in the Democratic National Committee.

I was interested in your diatribe on posters in the issue of July 8, and beg to call attention to some mistakes in names. These, to be sure, might have been mere typographical errors. Doubtless the writer is gnashing his teeth over the blunders of the horrid printer, because anybody who knows anything about posters would surely not be guilty of such mistakes.

To comment rather on what is good than what is bad discoverable in current magazine fiction has been the inclination of THE TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW. An exception to what might be called a good-natured optimism on our part is to find fault with a story of Mr. Marion Crawford, published in one of the magazines for this month.

BOSTON, Aug. 11. -- General Manager Chamberlain of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad, into whose hands the controversy between the road and its telegraph operators has been placed, states that he does not anticipate a strike, but that if one should take place the road would simply return to the original principles of railroading whereby running time, stops, and meeting places were established and observed by fixed rules.

Permit me to suggest to "M.J.A.," who writes in your issue of July 15th, on French books for girls that the list of French fiction issued by the American Literature Association in 1898, and republished by you in the same year, was issued to meet the want to which allusion is made. I have recently received a work on the same lines, but much more extensive.

Julia Arthur, who was in this city during the early part of the week on business connected with her new play, "More than Queen," by Emil Bergerat, returned to Boston yesterday. Before leaving she consented to make public some of her plans for the new production. She says if her hopes are realized the play will be spectacular in the extreme.

Without making pointless and unwarranted "deductions," let us come to the heart of this question of surface transit in a city. 1. Cars are run to carry passengers. 2. To leave at their respective destinations the greatest possible number of passengers in the shortest possible time it is essential to have time schedules, and to run by those schedules as closely as it can be done.

The annual report upon the British Museum has been issued with Parliamentary papers. The number of visitor to the museum in Bloomsbury in the year 1898 was the highest on record since the year 1883,amouting to a total of 612,275, as against 586,439 in 1897 The visitor on Sunday afternoon's numbered 41,858,as against 37,594 in 1897

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11. -- The rehabilitation of Gen. Miles is practically complete. Nothing has been apparently said or done to change the conditions of semi-warfare which existed at Army Headquarters during Secretary Alger's regime; there has been no blare of trumpets and no public reinstallation of the commanding officer of the army, but he has simply assumed his proper place as commander, and his position as such is recognized.

"The Man with the Hoe" has been forced out of his niche in the newspapers by "The Man with the 'Load,' " "The Man with the Lawnmower," "The Woman Under the Heel of the Man with the Hoe," and by other literary burlesques.

PONCE, Aug. 11. -- The worst storm ever experienced here struck this place Tuesday morning at 9 o'clock, and continued two hours. It came from the northeast.

When "Big Bill" Elliott goes on an expedition to rob again -- if, indeed, his certain long term in Sing Sing doesn't cure him of the habit -- he will use more discrimination in picking places to enter than he did yesterday afternoon.

SING SING, Aug. 11. -- For the sixty-eight Summer of their organization, the Methodists of the New York and Hudson River Camp Meeting Association are marshaling their forces for their annual campaign against sin. Crowds of devout soldiers of the cross are flocking to Sing Sing Heights, and before the ten days of the meeting have elapsed they hope to convert many in the Hudson Valley.

The discoveries made in July last by Dr. Karl Peters of ancient ruins in a valley through which runs a branch of the Zambesi may be summarized as follows: Near the ruins rises the Fura Mountain, which is in Portuguese territory. Whether the cyclopean walls which encircle a hill were used for a building erected for metallurgical, commercial, or religious purposes, Dr. Peters has not yet determined.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Aug. 11. -- A large proportion of the police force of Cincinnati and a sprinkling of City Hall officials made a disastrous venture in the turf line to-day, and to-night they are mourning the loss of their pocket money. A certain race horse running at Hawthorne under the name of Dr. Tarr is responsible for their unfortunate investment.

There is a little work in circulation entitled "A Message to Garcia: Being a Preachment by Elbert Hubbard," done into a booklet by the Roycrofters at the Roycroft Shop, which has been noticed in THE TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW, attracted considerable attention.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 11. -- The Philadelphias to-day sustained the first shut-out of the season. Leever had the local batters completely at this mercy. The fielding of both teams was perfect. Score:

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 11.-- Henry Gumble has been appointed receiver of the Great Southern Hotel and Theatre Company. This step was caused by apprehension resulting from the appointment of a receiver for the company operating the hotel, and was taken for the protection of creditors. The Great Southern Hotel and Theatre represent an investment of over $600,000.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11. -- Major Charles E. Kilbourne, Paymaster of the army, has been appointed to duty as Treasurer of the Philippine Islands and the Island of Guam. All moneys of the civil government of the islands will be placed in his hands.
BOSTON, Aug. 11. -- Gov. Pingree of Michigan is in Boston. To a reporter he talked freely to-day concerning the outlook, political and otherwise, in Michigan and the country.

Local bankers flouted yesterday as absurd stories that at the twenty-fifth annual convention of the American Bankers' Association, Sept. 5 to 7, Western bankers are to force an issue on the question of charges for the collection of checks and that the New York Clearing House system, which went into effect April 3 last, is to be upset.

RENNES, France, Aug. 11. -- All the notable Dreyfusites here are satisfied with the result of the examination of the secret dossier. They have urged their newspaper friends in Paris to clamor for full publicity, knowing that it it is granted the Military and Nationalist parties will be utterly disgraced. They are convinced that the Diplomatic and War Office dossiers teem with forgeries.

OMAHA, Neb., Aug. 11. -- The volume of business throughout Nebraska to-day is almost double what it has been in previous years. This applies to almost every industrial and commercial line. There is not one exception. The jobbers of hardware, dry goods, and farm implements are working their forces late into night trying to keep orders cleared up.

Boswell's "Life of Johnson" incloses a wealth of treasure, a literary El Dorado. Everybody is supposed to have read this greatest of English biographies. Few biographies have been so eagerly read, and there are few, if any, of the voluminous records of human life and achievement so worthy of reperusal. Boswell, in his punctilious methods of narration, diligent research, and vigorous grasp of detail, is the Plutarch of the English race.

NEWPORT, Aug. 11. -- Notwithstanding the inclement weather of Thursday, the attendance at the Casino dance was good, numbering almost fifty guests. Many beautiful gowns were seen, and there were fewer white ones than are usual at such a gathering.

Ward Drummond have just published for George W.F. Birch, D.D., LL. D., a well-known New York pastor, a volume of a historical character. It will be welcomed among the increasing number of valuable contributions to local history from which the future student and historian will draw ample data for his twentieth century work.

ALBANY, Aug. 11. -- Gov. Roosevelt has appointed the following delegates to the conference on trusts, to be held in Chicago beginning on the 13th of September next: Chauncey M. Depew, John G. Carlisle, Dr. Albert Shaw, W. Bourke Cockran, George Gunton, F.B. Thurber, and Henry White. It is possible that this list may be added to at a later day.

MANILA, Aug. 11 -- Gen. MacArthur's troops remained last night at Calulet. The rebels had evidently fled far beyond rifle range, for the American outposts were not disturbed, and not a shot was fired during the night. At daybreak this morning a reconnoitring party, consisting of a battalion of the Seventeenth Infantry, with one field piece, started up the railroad track toward Angeles, four miles north.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 11. -- Upon the petition of fifty resident wheelmen of Westchester County, Judge Smith Lent has appointed the following Board of Sidepath Commissioners of Westchester County: Stephen H. COLUMBIA, S. C., Aug. 11. -- The citizens of Greenwood County two months ago permitted R. M. Tolbert, whom they banished after the election riots last November, to return to his home. A change of feeling in Tolbert's favor was brought about.

The uncertainties of baseball were never better illustrated than during the past two weeks. Previous to that time it looked as though the Brooklyns would win the much-coveted championship easily, but since then Boston, by consistent playing, has cut down Brooklyn's lead to a few points. LONG BRANCH, N.J., Aug. 12. -- The annual horse show of the Norwood Park Association was held to-day, and was a success from every point of view. The entries filled well, and the animals shown were all high class.

The principal organs of the Russian press do not, it is true, openly blame the Government in this matter -- the press censorship would prevent them from so doing -- but, nevertheless, they cannot conceal their ill-humor.

Sousa has an attractive programme for both of his concerts at Manhattan Beach to-day, and will introduce two soloists, Misses Grace See Carroll and Clara Douglas Carroll, the former being the soloist for the afternoon and the latter for the evening concert. He regarded the high winds of to-day at Jupiter and other points in the southern part of the State as mere forerunners of the storm, which is yet to come.

Daniel Frohman arrived home from Europe yesterday on the American liner St. Paul. He spent his time while abroad in England, France, and Spain. Mr. Frohman said his trip was a most agreeable one. The Newark Cricket Club team played the Manhattans their return league game at Prospect Park yesterday and were defeated by 111 runs and 7 wickets. J. Adam and C.S. Moore made a splendid stand for the winners, and the former got within six runs of a century by vigorous hitting. WASHINGTON, Aug. 12. -- Secretary Root was asked this afternoon concerning the establishment of a secret service for duty in the Philippine Islands, Cuba, and Puerto Rico. He replied that he had no idea of such a project. No proposition looking toward the establishment of such a secret service had been submitted to him, and he was not thinking of establishing one.

LAKE PLACID, Aug. 12. -- One round of pleasure follows another at Lake Placid, so that the weeks pass as though they were mere days. Baseball, tennis, boating, mountain climbing, and golf are the chief diversions. All the hotels, cottages, and camps are full, and people are being turned away every day.

OMAHA, Aug. 12. -- Attorney General Smyth to-day began proceedings in the District Court of this county against the Standard Oil Company under the Nebraska anti-trust law. He asks that the company, which, he alleges, is a trust and controls the price at which petroleum and its products are to be sold, be ousted from the State and enjoined from doing business therein.

LONDON, Aug. 12. -- The war feeling is growing stronger. Departing troops are madly cheered by tremendous crowds, and when the volunteers go into camp, just as volunteers do in the United States, their departure is witnessed by great numbers of people amid scenes of extraordinary enthusiasm.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug. 12. -- With the reception on board the flagship New York this afternoon given by the officers of the fleet to the Summer residents of Bar Harbor the gayety of squadron week was brought to a close. The fleet will sail early to-morrow morning, as the fog was too dense to-night to put to sea, as had been planned.

PARIS, Aug. 12. -- Paul Deroulede, founder of the League of Patriots and member of the Chamber of Deputies for the Angouleme division of Charente, was arrested at 4 o'clock this morning at his estate at Croissy, near Paris. M. Deroulede was taken into custody by four gendarmes and was driven to Paris. On his arrival here he was incarcerated in the Conciergerie Prison.

Paret, the New York expert, who was the challenger for the title, was beaten by Hackett, last year's winner, after an exciting three-set match.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Aug. 12. -- George Williamson, a visitor from New York, desperately fought against two life guards who sought to-day to save him from drowning in the surf. They succeeded in landing him on the beach, however, all three being greatly exhausted.

CHICAGO, Aug. 12. -- The Illinois State Bar Association has issued a circular containing the proposition unanimously adopted by it on July 7 for the celebration of "John Marshall Day," Feb. 4, 1901.
