The statement in The London Times that ESTERHAZY carried on his treasonable practices with the late Lieut. Col. HENRY for partner seems to have created some excitement in England. There is nothing new in the allegation. M. JOSEPH REINACH made it last Autumn and reiterated it in his letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES published last Sunday.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Aug. 13. -- A dispatch from Great Falls, Mon., says that George Henson of Paradise Valley, near Chinook, on Milk River, is the victim of the first White Cap outrage in Montana. He was to have been a witness in an assault case at Chinook Saturday morning. Seven men masked in white called about midnight Friday at his house, enticed him out, and beat him severely.

Commissioner General Ferdinand W. Peck of the United States Commission says that the American Coal Exhibit will be one of the most interesting and prominent at the Paris Exposition in 1900. The Commissioner General has appointed Frederick E. Saward of this city, editor and owner of the Coal Trade Journal, and an expert of thirty years' experience in this line of industry, to take charge of this department.

-- Curiously persistent ill-luck must have pursued the members of the Board of Health, else would the search which President MURPHY says they have been making for the past eleven months after a case in which the "Christian Scientists" have violated the laws governing the practice of medicine would have been rewarded long ago.

So much out of the ordinary were last week's developments in the money market that theorists along old lines can hardly hope to make trustworthy forecasts. No calculation is worth attention that leaves out the effectiveness of new western financial conditions. The West takes now in its National relationships much the same situation that the United States has been able to assume relative to the finance of the rest of the world.

John Baptist de la Salle, the celebrated founder of the community of Brothers of the Christian Schools, is now a saint. The decree of canonization issued by the Congregation of Rites in Rome has been affirmed by the Pope. This fact has been made known to the Christian Brothers throughout the world, and there is universal rejoicing in the community in consequence.

Three buggies came together on the One Hundred and Fifty-fifth Street viaduct yesterday afternoon with disastrous results. James O'Brien of 14 Beach Street, the occupant of the rig, was thrown out and received a scalp wound. William Monsky of 38 Carmine Street, the occupant of the second, was hurled from his rig, and his right leg was seriously fractured.

BRISTOL, R.I., Aug. 13. -- A carload of steel plate for the Columbia's new steel mast, arrived this afternoon by express from Philadelphia. It is evident that no time will be lost in getting the defender fitted with a steel mast again.

Five persons, a hostess and her four guests, were seriously poisoned yesterday at 130 East Houston Street, by eating freely of "mushroom" stew. The victims were Mrs. Anna Grasser, forty years old, living at the above number; Jane Robbins, twenty-seven years old, and Annie Klein, twenty-three years old, dressmakers; Rose Cohen, twenty years old, a trimmer, and Louis Ullman, forty-two years old, a tailor.

The congregation of the Church of the Archangel, of which the Rev. George C. Pratt is rector, has for several weeks past been holding service in the crypt of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, on Morningside Heights. Yesterday morning, in the absence of the rector, James Hulme Canfield, librarian of Columbia University, who recently received his credentials from the Bishop as a lay reader, occupied the pulpit.

LONDON, Aug. 13. -- Perplexity still haunts our money market, rendering business difficult. In the early part of last week New York exchange frightened us, and led to talk of gold going to the United States. The Bank of England rate would be sure to go up on Thursday, so gossip ran, to protect the reserve against this danger.
NEWPORT, Aug. 13. -- The Newport Golf Club has changed one of the rules relating to the handicap matches, so that women can enter and play in Class B hereafter.

PROVIDENCE, Aug. 13. -- The body of the man found off Scarborough Beach, Narragansett Pier, last Friday morning, apparently the victim of a murder, was identified this morning as that of Frank H. Shaw, thirty-eight years of age, formerly an Inspector on the Brooklyn Rapid Transit Railway, living at Seventy-second Street and Second Avenue, Bay Ridge, Brooklyn.

NEWPORT, Aug. 13. -- If it were not for the fact that both Columbia and Defender have entered the race to-morrow for the Astor Cups the event would be almost featureless, for to-night, out of a fleet of over sixty sloops and schooners, the owners of only three of each class have signified their intention of entering the contest.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Aug. 13. -- Samuel Sheets, who last night shot himself after shooting and killing his brother-in-law, William H. Carson, Assistant Prosecutor of Camden County, did not survive his victim long and died a few hours after the shooting at the Monmouth Memorial Hospital, in Long Branch.

The race for the cricket championship of New York has undergone another change, for Team B of the Knickerbocker Athletic Club has now assumed first place, and it is its intention to make a mighty struggle before it yields it up. All six clubs entered for the competition will be engaged next Saturday, and the Manhattan will then wind up their series with a game against Staten Island at Prospect Park.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 13. -- Japan and her new tariff, treaties, and relations to foreigners are the subjects of a monograph just prepared by the Treasury Bureau of Statistics.
DETROIT, Mich., Aug. 13. -- Mayor Harrison is favored as a Vice Presidential candidate next year by Chairman F.A. Baker of the Democratic Committee of this State. He says:

SEATTLE, Washington, Aug. 13. -- A private letter from Capt. Slamm of the revenue cutter Grant, now with the sealing patrol in Bering Sea, relates that the inhabitants of Attou Island were found by him in straitened circumstances, but in no danger of starvation. The inhabitants, numbering 73 -- 23 men and 50 women and children -- were in a pitiable condition.
NEWPORT, Aug. 13. -- The Casino concert was largely attended this evening by the cottagers and the townspeople, every seat about the plazzas and lawns being in use.

Mr. CROKER went to England an advocate of expansion and an opponent of BRYAN. He returns an anti-imperialist and a convert to the belief that BRYAN is "one of the greatest men that America has produced.

RENNES, Aug. 13. -- The battle has begun in earnest. Its political bearings are shown in the arrest of Paul Deroulede, the Deputy and poet, and twenty-three of his numerous Royalist and Bonapartist allies, who have pooled with him against the republic. As in the Boulangist conspiracy, the pool would be of little consequence but for the military caste, which has found representative men in Gen. de Negrier and some other Generals having great commands.

The report of Capt. MACKENZIE of the Prairie on the work of the first detail of the Naval Militia of this State during its recent cruise on that vessel will undoubtedly astonish and disappoint many who have long held the belief that this was one of the crack militia organizations of the State.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 13. -- At the Vailsburg track to-day over 4,000 persons saw Joe Downey, the sixteen-year-old bicycle racer, lower all the New Jersey State records for from one to five miles, which were made by Jimmy Michael on the same track on Oct. 14, 1897. Downey's riding was almost of the phenomenal order.

PARIS, Aug. 13. -- Demonstrations occurred this evening outside the offices of the Anti-Semite League, where M. Guerin, President of the League and M. Max Regis, the former Jew-baiting Mayor of Algiers, against whom orders of arrest were issued yesterday on charge of conspiring to bring about a change of government, are still besieged by the police.

NORWAY, Me., Aug. 13. -- Since the paper makers commenced to build big sulphite mills in the Maine woods the price of spruce timber lands has doubled, and in some cases trebled. Next to spruce, the timber in greatest demand is clean and thrifty white birch, which is sawed into bars and sent by the shipload to Scotland to be used for thread spools.
It is impossible to read the testimony of ex-President CASIMIR-PERIER before the Rennes court-martial without the question arising. Why did he not speak before?

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13. -- Francis B. Loomis, United States Minister to Venezuela, in his official report bearing date Caracas, June 30, deals with the Venezuelan pearl fisheries and their possibilities. He says:

The Brooklyn trolley cars put in another busy day yesterday providing work for ambulance surgeons and undertakers. In addition to a man killed on Gravesend Avenue, about a dozen persons were injured as a result of trolley accidents during the day. One accident, which was remarkable for the fact that no one was injured under the circumstances, occurred at Rockaway Avenue and Avenue G, Canarsie.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 13. -- Andrew Semassena, Jr., who haidled a large amount of real estate in this city, has filed a petition in bankruptcy. His liabilities are $138,254.81 and his estimated assets $134,585.37.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13. -- Two dispatches from the Governor General of Puerto Rico, giving additional details of the fearful havoc wrought by the hurricane of last week, were received at the War Department to-day. Gen. Davis reported that one-fifth of the dwellings in the island were destroyed, and their former owners are without shelter or food.

One indication appears of changing disposition upon the part of the professional speculative contingent on the Stock Exchange -- an indication reflected by the suddenly developed industry of forming pools. Trader who have been ramming and jamming the market for months part without much profit to themselve are taking the other side by the process of jcinning in these pools which have for their object effort to advance market quotations.

Daniel Harris of Cigarmakers' Union No. 144 was yesterday elected by the Central Federation of Labor as its delegate to the convention of the Workingmen's State Federation that will be held in Albany in September.

The Rev. Aloise Russell Nevins of the Community of the Paulist Fathers died yesterday morning at the home of his physician, Dr. H. Robinson, at 352 West Fifty-eighth Street. Born in the Protestant Episcopal Church, and brought up for the ministry of that Church, he at an early age became convinced that the Roman Catholic was the true Church, joined it, and became a zealous missionary in its service for the remainder of his life.
The funeral of Col. William E. Sinn, the well-known theatrical manager of Brooklyn, who died at Pittsfield, Mass., on Wednesday, was held yesterday afternoon in Plymouth Church, Brooklyn.

A tenement house exhibition will be held in this city in December next under the auspices of the Tenement House Committee of the Charity Organization Society. The exhibits will include a number of models representing a block of existing tenements taken from some block in the city, a block of tenements as it would appear if each house were built on the present "dumb-bell" plan, and a number of blocks of model tenements scientifically planned.

The game between the New Yorks and Louisvilles at Weehawken yesterday did not bring out a large crowd. The 2,500 persons that turned out, however, were treated to a fine batting contest, in which the New Yorks took a very prominent part. The Louisvilles used Phillippi, the pitcher who shut out the New Yorks without a hit early in the season.

The Rev. G. Campbell Morgan of New Court Congregational Church, London, conducted the services at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church yesterday. Mr. Morgan is attending the Northfield Conference, and was invited to occupy the Fifth Avenue Church pulpit yesterday by Dwight L. Moody, who has undertaken to provide preachers for the church during this month.

We have more than once referred to it as a good thing that the American spirit was introducing more openness into the customs of diplomacy, doing away with some of the mystery which pervades international discussions, and taking the public more or less into confidence by informing it how matters are going.

SANTO DOMINGO, Aug. 13. -- The United States cruiser New Orleans and the gunboat Machias returned here this morning. The former put to sea on the morning of the 8th, to avoid the expected hurricane, and the latter left the previous day for Punta Macoris.

HAVANA, Aug. -- 13. -- An interesting argument has developed in official correspondence between Director of Posts Rathbone and Mr. Griffith, the British Consul General, regarding letters belonging to Senor Morales, which the former has detained on the ground that they were found to contain lottery tickets.

The police of the Hamburg Avenue Station, Williamsburg, vainly tried yesterday to establish the identity of the woman who on Saturday night, while riding a bicycle in Bushwick Avenue, ran into Josef Rebhan, thirty-two years old, of 266 Troutman Street. Rebhan is in St. Catherine's Hospital with a fracture of the skull.
LONDON, Aug. 14. -- The Johannesburg correspondent of The Daily Mail says:

CHICAGO, Aug. 13. -- A convention of the Afro-American Council of Colored Men will be held at Bethel Church, beginning Wednesday, and lasting until Saturday evening. This convention will probably be one of the most important gatherings of colored men that has been held for some time.

Architects may be interested to learn that Herr WALLOTT, who is perhaps the most prominent architect in Germany, has come to America to act as a juryman in a competition of designs for buildings to suit the needs of the University of California. He will proceed soon to San Francisco, where the contest is being held.

CHICAGO, Aug. 13. -- One hundred thousand German-American citizens participated to-day in the celebration incident to the opening of the fourteenth annual convention of the Krieger Bund and the twenty-fifth annual reunion in America of the Deutscher Krieger Verein. The former includes veterans of the German Army and the latter veterans of the Franco-Prussian war.

BOSTON, Aug. 13. -- The great League of American Wheelmen Meet, the twentieth in the history of the organization, will begin in this city to-morrow. The trains arriving to-day were filled to overflowing with wheelmen. Large delegations arrived Saturday, and more are expected Monday. It is probable that at least 7,000 visitors, mostly League of American Wheelmen men, will be here during the week.

MANILA, Aug. 13. -- A reconnoissance yesterday by troops of Gen. Samuel B.M. Young's brigade, with the object of discovering the whereabouts of the enemy near San Mateo, northeast of the San Juan Reservoir, about ten miles from Manila, resulted in the occupation of San Mateo.

RENNES, Aug. 13. -- To-morrow's session of the Dreyfus court-martial is awaited with the greatest anxiety and expectation, in view of the confrontation of Mercier by Casimir-Perier, when the former will virtually be in the prisoner's dock. A dramatic scene is inevitable.

MORE BULLFIGHTS IN FRANCE. -- In spite of the fact that M. Waldeck-Rousseau, the Premier of France, has said that no more bullfights would be tolerated, Senor Mazzantini, who keeps the ring in Boubaix, and M. Bidel, the Paris menagerie man and lion tamer, have bidden people to come to Roubaix on Sept. 3 next to see another lion-bull encounter.

OLD ORCHARD BEACH, Me., Aug. 13. -- This has been the most remarkable day in the life of Dr. A.B. Simpson of New York, leader of the Christian Alliance Society. It was the closing of the two weeks' convention, and the annual collection was taken. Both Dr. Simpson and his assistants positively refuse to state the amount received, but it is generally understood that it is nearly if not quite $120,000.

DENVER, Aug. 13. -- Two policemen were killed here at 1 o'clock this morning by a recruit belonging to Company L, Thirty-fourth Volunteer Infantry, now stationed at Fort Logan. Three soldiers had been raising a disturbance in Louis Klipfel's saloon, at the corner of Market and Twentieth Streets, during the night, and Policeman Thomas Clifford was notified of their action and asked to keep his eye on them.

WASHNGTON, Aug. 13. -- Secretary Root is beginning to get a firm grasp on the administration of the War Department. At the outset Mr. Root set about familiarizing himself with the more important details of the department, much as a lawyer prepares a statement of facts as a basis for legal analysis.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 13. -- Anson Phelps Stokes, the New York millionaire, who was thrown from his horse and seriously injured yesterday, is resting comfortably to-night. He has not been in great pain during the day and has slept a good deal of the time. The physicians, Dr. Charles McBurney, Dr. F.K. Paddock, and Dr. Armstrong, held a consultation this afternoon and are well satisfied with the progress that Mr. Stokes is making.

NEWPORT, Aug. 13. -- A number of the cottagers here have sent orders to New York grocers and provision dealers for goods to be shipped on the United States transport McPherson, in aid of' the destitute Puerto Ricans.

YONKERS, N.Y., Aug. 13. -- Thomas Mulvahill, eleven years of age, of 34 Riverdale Avenue, and James Wilson, nine years of age, of 26 Riverdale Avenue, are under arrest charged with stealing a horse. James J. Wall is under arrest charged with receiving stolen goods. He purchased, it is alleged, the horse from the boys.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 13. -- The United States transport Centennial arrived here from Manila to-day after a very exciting trip. She narrowly missed a couple of typhoons, was ashore on a coral reef, where the entire crew barely escaped capture at the hands of the Filipinos; one of the sailors was killed by a parting hawser, and one of the Quartermasters was stabbed by a colored cook.

ATLANTA, Aug. 13. -- A dispatch from Brunswick says: "The barometer has been fallinw slowly since 4 o'clock. At that hour dense clouds rolled up, and there were heavy winds which continued for some time, sending clouds of dust in every direction. The people are somewhat alarmed. Everything portable has been put where the least damage can be done, and shipping is held in port.

OMAHA, Neb., Aug. 13. -- The police are to-night busy with a mysterious murder which occurred in the station, and in a room next to where a dozen officers were congregated. J. A. Smith, a colored vocalist, was the victim. Anton Inda, a policeman, who had Smith under arrest at the time, is locked up charged with the murder Smith and a companion were arrested for loud talking on the street.

A down-town business man has just completed a deal with his tailor which he thinks beats David Harum's horse trade. On the recommendation of his family physician he patronized a new tailor in a fashionable avenue up town.

Some of your correspondents object to the Columbia being sailed under a British Captain, and they are right. That both Captains will do their best to win there is no doubt, but the fact remains that the victorious vessel will owe its success, so far as skillful handling goes, to an Englishman.

NORTH ADAMS, Mass., Aug. 13. -- Mrs. Samuel Sagarin, aged twenty-two, and Mrs. George Gasper, aged thirty-eight, of Adams, took strychnine in mistake for headache powders last night, and as a result Mrs. Gasper died three-quarters of an hour afterward and Mrs. Sagarin's condition is critical.

Miss Helen Keller, having completed under the tutorship of Mr. Merton S. Keith her preparation for college in three years instead of in the four which had been assigned by some of her friends for the purpose, went to Cambridge in June last to take the regular entrance examinations for Radcliffe.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 13. -- The entertainment given at the Meadow Club last evening, for the benefit of the George Junior Republic, was, from a social point of view, a brilliant success. Society seized it as a favorable opportunity to show itself in force. Those of the Summer residents who did not attend were few, and the large theatre of the clubhouse was crowded.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Aug. 14. -- William A. Ainsworth of Fabius, his two sons, fifteen and eighteen years of age, and Robert Hall, also of Fabius, were instantly killed by the Southwestern Limited at Canastota, twenty-five miles east of this city, on the New York Central Road, at 7:35 this evening.

I am always ready to answer Mr. Smith's questions, and have already contributed to the demolition of his crazy scheme of differential duties, which he and his party have been forced to abandon as utterly impracticable.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14. -- Judson Lyons, Register of the Treasury, who was reported as among those who were to be present at the Afro-American Council in Chicago, said to-day that he would not attend. He said that he did not think any resolution condemning the President for not using Federal authority to suppress lynching would be seriously urged.

MOUNT HOLLY, N.J., Aug. 14. -- Mrs. Annie Yorke of Riverside was gored by a cow this morning, and received painful injuries which, however, it is thought will not result seriously. Mrs. Yorke entered the field in which a cow was grazing with a young calf, and approaching the calf fed it and petted it.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 14. -- The Secretary of War this afternoon issued the following appeal to Governors of States for aid for the storm sufferers in Puerto Rico:

Patrolman William H. Duggan of the Bronx Park Station was tried before President York of the Police Board yesterday afternoon on a charge preferred by Mrs. Bridget Sheedy of 352 West One Hundred and Twenty-fourth Street that he made an arrangement last year with her to get her husband.

PARIS, Aug 14. -- The office of the Anti-Semite League, in which MM. Guerin, President of the league, and Max Regis, the noted Jew-baiter and ex-Mayor of Algiers, sought refuge from arrest on Saturday, are still besieged. M. Guerin, his friends declare, will, if attacked, fire on the troops. After attempting to gain them to their side, the besieged men threaten to pour boiling oil on the besiegers.

DES MOINES, Ia., Aug. 14. -- The leaders of the Iowa Democracy are gathering here to-night in anticipation of the Bryan meeting to-morrow and the State Convention Wednesday. Cato Sells of Vinton, who is the State Committee's candidate for the Gubernatorial nomination, was among the first arrivals.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 14. -- The annual struggle for the National championship at lawn tennis opens here to-morrow morning on the courts of the Casino. All day to-day the experts, with rackets under their arms, have been gathering from every direction, and the Mecca of all good lawn tennis players is rapidly filling up with the best talent the country affords.

Whether or not the coat of arms of the City of New York may be used on the title page of a waltz dedicated to ex-Mayor William L. Strong without offending the law is a question that is perplexing the composer of the music, Miss Lavinia H. van Westervelt-Dempsey, Queen of the Holland Dames.

CHICAGO, Aug. 14. -- Admiral Dewey has written a letter to the Sunday School of the United Presbyterian Tabernacle of Ravenswood in response to a notice sent to him that he was elected an honorary member of the school when it celebrated the one anniversary of the battle of Manila Bay. The letter, framed, was hung in the church yesterday and reads as follows:

RENNES, Aug. 14. -- The drama at Rennes grows tragical. This long-becalmed town is being stirred into a more violent passion than Paris. The Parisians are uproarious. The Bretons are silent and passive by their belief or idea, whatever it may be.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Aug. 14. -- The Wednesday convention of bolting Democrats promises to be one of the largest ever held and will doubtless be the largest meeting of factionalists ever held in Kentucky. Capt. James Barclay of the committee for the State at large said to-night that he expects about eighteen hundred men here.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14. -- The impression here is that Croker is a convert, of ex-Speaker Reed on the expansion question. Mr. Reed is one of the original anti-expansionists, beginning with opposition to the annexation of Hawaii.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Aug. 14. -- Henry M. Neill, the cotton-crop expert of this city, who predicted the enormous crops of 1894-5, 1897-8, and 1898-9, is out with a forecast indicating that the crop now maturing will exceed any of these, and may reach the unprecedented total of 12,000,000 bales.

BOSTON, Aug. 14. -- An alleged conspiracy to flood this city, New York, and other cities with worthless English sight drafts appearing to have been accepted by a London commission firm, has been brought to light as a result of the arrest of Frank E. Holliday of Turner's Falls, Mass., who, it is claimed, is the principal operator here.
LONDON, Aug. 15. -- The correspondent of The Times at Rennes, who comments upon the "prodigious drama being enacted here," and the "loss to the Dreyfus cause through the disablement of Labori," says:

A case to establish the value of five boxes of silks that were attached by the Sheriff in a suit of Samuel J. Brenner of Montreal to recover $2,500 from M.L. Weisman, also of that city, came up yesterday afternoon before a Sheriff's jury. Weisman opened a large factory for the manufacture of silk goods and women's underwear in Montreal about two years ago, and also did business as an importer of laces.

I was pleased to read in an evening paper last Saturday that Magistrate Cornell had expressed the opinion that there was too much unnecessary clubbing done by the police of this city, and that he proposed to investigate the case to which his attention had been called.

LONDON, Aug. 14. -- The progressive forces in this country have received an agreeable addition in the person of the Countess of Warwick, who announces she has not merely been converted from Toryism to Liberalism, but, further, has now embraced the Socialist faith. It is The Essex County Chronicle which conveys the most definite intelligence on this point.

-- Even more impressive than the statistics by which The Arkansas Democrat proved the inaccuracy of Gov. JONES'S assertion that lynchings in the South are "generally" the result of infamous attacks by negroes on white women, is an interview with Sheriff W.H. FURLOUGH of Calhoun County, copied in the same paper from one in St. Louis.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Aug. 14. -- The business men's anti-boycott committee which was appointed as a result of the meeting held the other day met this afternoon and decided to hire lawyers to prosecute merchants and others who violate the civil rights law in compliance with the demands of the boycotters.

NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 14. -- M. Wormser, alias M.C. Weilly, the aristocratic hotel thief, who swindled the Grunewald Hotel of this city out of $500 a short while ago, was to-day sentenced to eighteen months in the penitentiary at hard labor. Wormser pleaded guilty to the charge in order to escape with a light sentence.

A diamond robbery, which the police of this city are trying to keep quiet, occurred in New York on July 17 last. Nine articles, none of which has been recovered, were taken. The complete list of the stolen articles, as furnished to the police, is as follows:

Increase of 919 tons in east-bound shipments of dead freight from Chicago for the week as compared with the previous week and increase of 45,423 tons as compared with the corresponding week last year.

CHICAGO, Aug. 14. -- Norman Selby, better known as Kid McCoy to folks who are familiar with ring matters, wanted to come to Chicago, and, being desirous of exercising with the padded gloves in a decorous and gentle manner, wired his friends of the Griddle Club that it would give him much pleasure to add to the amusement they had planned for Saturday evening.

I am pleased to read in your paper that the Hon. Elihu Root, Secretary of War, has taken hold of the War Department in the right manner by making all the departments harmonious. I am glad that he has restored to Major Gen. Miles his proper position as head of the army.

Fresh from an extended sojourn in Alaska and a tour of the Pacific Coast, United States Senator C.W. Fairbanks of Indiana arrived in the city yesterday in excellent health and spirits and talked freely on public questions at the Fifth Avenue Hotel. "Yes, I read Richard Croker's interview," he said.

ATLANTA, Ga., Aug. 14. -- Mayor James G. Woodward, against whom impeachment proceedings had been contemplated for some time by the City Council and whose resignation had been asked for by that body, made a solemn promise to the Councilmen and Aldermen at a meeting this afternoon that he would not take another drink during his term of office.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14. -- The monthly statement of the imports and exports of the United States, issued by the Treasury Bureau of Statistics, shows that during the month of July the imports of merchandise amounted to $59,925,178, of which nearly $26,000,000 was free of duty. The increase as compared with July, 1898, was about $9,000,000.

The cartoon which our contemporary The Herald has published depicting the Island of Cuba helpless in the serpent coils of the Western Union cable monopoly is an impressive composition. The Western Union Company's control of the island seems to be complete and exclusive.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Aug. 14. -- Gov. Voorhees, who spent Sunday at Tarrytown, N.Y., reached his office this morning. He said that while passing through New York he met Managing Trustee Cook of the Girls' Industrial School. The Governor told Mr. Cook he had received Mr. Fitzgibbon's resignation as a Trustee, and asked Mr. Cook what he intended to do in the matter.

CHICAGO, Aug. 14. -- Fay Conover, eleven years old, died at the home of her parents, 473 Champlain Avenue, yesterday of diphtheria. She was unattended by a physician. The Conovers are Christian Scientists, and during the child's illness she was under the ministration of Mrs. May V. Blaine.

Events crowd upon each other in France. A plot to overthrow the Government is frustrated and arrests are made. Maitre LABORI is shot down. An ex-President of the republic practically gives the lie to his sometime Minister of War. From this distance affairs seem to have assumed a very serious aspect.

President S.R. Callaway of the New York Central system scanned the detailed report of earnings submitted to him yesterday morning, with much interest. "The earnings at each station on our line for last week show a large increase over the same week a year ago. The indications are that this will be a good month for railroad business.

George W. Lederer of the Casino, New York, and Shaftesbury Theatre, London, who has collaborated with Hugh Morton and Gustave Kerker for the past four years in the production of plays which have been commonly known as reviews, has severed his relations with the composer and librettist.

In his "Polite Conversation" Dean SWIFT has the exclamatory remark: "Lord! I wonder what fool it was that first invented kissing." The fallacy in this saying is the attributing of the invention to a fool, for if he was a fool he was a very wise one indeed to invent a thing for which so many men have paid so much.

HAVANA, Aug. 14. -- Gen. Juan Isidro Jiminez, the aspirant to the Presidency of the Republic of Santo Domingo, has received, it is reported, news of a decisive victory of the revolutionists near Monte Christi, which place is now besieged. The garrison there may offer some resistance, as the Governor last year shot six adherents of Jiminez after the revolution that failed.

The West Forty-seventh Street Station police are searching the city for Michael Spaad. They want him for the murder of his baby, Winifred, sixteen months old. Spaad, his wife, Mary, and two children lived in a basement at 546 West Fiftieth Street. The children were Thomas, six years old, and the baby, Winifred.

Perhaps the most significant item in the latest budget of news cabled from the Cape to London is the announcement that, after the Government of the Transvaal had refused to submit the controversy to arbitration, it consented to do so on the condition that "the independence of the Transvaal should not be impugned."

CHICAGO, Aug. 14. -- "Hoch, hoch, hoch der Kaiser!" This was the shout of thousands of Germans at Sharpshooters' Park when Henry Hachmeister, President of the Veterans' Society of the German Army, read the dispatch from the Acting German Ambassador to the Bundes Krieger Verein that Emperor William had presented a banner to the society.

The Clevelands made things interesting for the New Yorks in the last inning of the game at the Polo Grounds yesterday afternoon, and came within one run of tying the score. This was probably due to a little overconfidence on the part of Gettig, the locals' pitcher. He settled down after three consecutive hits were made off his delivery.
Judge Ferris of Cincinnati has ruled that the costs incurred in contesting a will cannot be ordered paid out of the inheritance. This is likely to make some of the Cincinnati lawyers weary and wary.

NEWPORT, Aug. 14. -- This evening Mrs. John R. Drexel gave a large dinner at her villa, after which a number came in and enjoyed informal dancing. Mrs. Drexel has the little English dancer Miss Moxler, and her guests were delighted with the child's performance.

The army transport McPherson sailed at 4 o'clock yesterday with the first lot of relief supplies for the hurricane sufferers in Puerto Rico. The provisions consisted of the 1,200,000 pounds of rice and beans sent by the War Department and a portion of the private contributions from this city and Boston.

RENNES, Aug. 14. -- To-day's sitting of the Dreyfus court-martial was most dramatic An immense sensation was caused by the announcement of the attempted assassination of Maitre Labori. Mme. Severine, the well-known writer, was so upset that she broke a blood vessel and had to be removed.

NEWPORT, Aug. 15.--Under the clearest of skies, and in as fine a topsail breeze as one could desire, the Columbia put the finishing touch on her series of trial races against the Defender, in the presence of the New York Yacht Club fleet to-day, winning the twenty-one-mile race by 8 minutes and 52 seconds.

CHICAGO, Aug. 15. -- To-morrow the Erie Railroad will announce a rate of $18.45 for the round trip between Chicago and New York. There is at present no round trip between the two cities, the standard one-way rate being $20. The rate to be made by the Erie is therefore less than a single fare.

PLATTSBURG, N.Y., Aug. 15. -- President McKinley, accompanied by Private Secretary Cortelyou, left the Hotel Champlain this morning at a few minutes past 11 o'clock and was driven down to the auditorium on the grounds of the Catholic Summer School of America, at Cliff Haven, on Lake Champlain.

Bessie Crosley, thirteen years old, daughter of Charles Crosley, and Annie and Susie Bailey, five and ten years old, respectively, daughters of William Bailey, went into the outskirts of Canaan Mountain to pick berries.

BOSTON, Mass., Aug. 15. -- The forty-seventh annual report of the Trustees of the Public Library of the City of Boston has just been issued. It shows that the cost of maintaining the library during the year 1898-9 was $264,580.04, divided as follows: Salaries, $162,690.48; books, $29,035.04; periodicals, $5,900.06; newspapers, $2,146.44; general maintenance, $64,808.02. Of this amount the city appropriated $246,855.87, and the trust funds yielded $13,674.11.

A scheme for the consolidation of the Louisville and Nashville and the Southern Railway is well under way. To permit of its legal consummation the Atlantic Coast Line will be an interested party, so that a Constitutional provision preventing the Southern from acquiring a direct lease of the Georgia Railroad, a necessary link, may be overcome.

PARIS, Aug. 16. -- President Guerin of the Anti-Semitic League still defies the representatives of the majesty of French law and justice, and his latest declaration, made to-night after repeated conferences with emissaries from his besiegers, was that he would not surrender under any conditions. He would rather starve than capitulate.

The experiment of a public golf course at Van Cortlandt Park has shown that a large number of persons who do not belong to golf clubs have taken up the Scotch game and are zealously sticking to it. Such public contests as have been held on this, the only free course in this neighborhood, have developed a very fair measure of skill among golfers quite unknown to fame on club links.

Our veterans ask for histories, that the schools may not misread the past, and honest men differ as to the record of simple facts, but it is not in the light of battles and laws and proclamations that a truthful knowledge can most safely be gained; the modern historian has learned that wars and Kings and Governments are erections of conditions, and seldom make history.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 16. -- John R. Gentry's winning two straight heats in today's great pacing races was a surprise to many of the old horsemen who looked for Searchlight, the younger stallion, to win. The betting was also strongly in Searchlight's favor, odds of 100 to 60 being offered by the bookmakers before the first heat.

PRINCETON, N.J., Aug. 16. -- Much excitement prevails here and at Kingston over the mysterious disappearance of Carrie Snedecker, the little daughter of Frederick Snedecker, a well-known farmer residing near Kingston. The little girl went out to play at 9 o'clock yesterday morning, and an hour later was missed by her mother.

Rather violent squabbles between two or three groups of third-rate traders furnish Wall Street some midsummer interest; but importance attends very few current Stock Exchange transactions. Local traction stocks are jammed, Sugar and some of the other trust stocks are suddenly marked down, there is much exclamatory hysteria -- but little is done that is really of consequence. Big men still waiting, the market waits with them.

BOSTON, Aug. 16. -- Although the Robert Treat Paine, Jr., boom for Mayor is a very little one, it is said to be gathering headway. One of the stories circulated to-day is that Martin M. Lomasney, William S. McNary, and P.J. Daly are credited with holding the balance of power.

The New Yorks outplayed the Cincinnatis at every point of the game at the Polo Grounds yesterday, and easily defeated the team that made a record for consecutive games won. It was a fine exhibition of baseball throughout. There was good batting, clever pitching, and some well-judged base running.

HARRISON, N.Y., Aug. 16. -- In a comfortable little frame cottage, not far from the railroad station here, lives Thomas M. Siddons, who has every appearance of being a quiet, inoffensive man, and who is fifty-eight years of age. He is the source of a great deal of anxiety, however, from all reports, to Gov. H.S. Pingree of Michigan, from the fact that he has threatened to shoot him the first time he sees him.

Several appeals have been made recently for a revival of the international rifle matches, which were at one time a source of intense interest to the people of the United States and Great Britain. The history of these matches is not known to many of the younger persons now living in this city, but it is none the less a glorious one.

BAY SIDE, N.Y., Aug. 16. -- By record playing Walter J. Travis, champion of the Oakland Golf Club, defeated Dave Hunter, its professional, on the links here this afternoon. Travis's score was one more than the record, held by himself, which he established last June in two consecutive rounds with Hunter and Jasper Lynch of Lakewood.

NEWPORT, Aug. 16. -- The Greens Committee of the Newport Golf Club, consisting of John Bolt, Chairman; Victor Sorchan, and Arthur T. Kemp, has completed the fixtures for the tournament which opens on Aug. 29. The fixtures, which are more numerous than ever before, consist of the President's Cup, offered by Buchanan Winthrop; Consolation Cup, offered by the Governors of the club; Handicap Cup, offered by W.K. Vanderbilt, and the Scratch Medal.

BOSTON, Mass., Aug. 16. -- The Bureau of Statistics of Labor of Massachusetts has issued the "Thirteenth Annual Report of Statistics of Manufactures" in the State for 1898. The number of establishments considered in the report is 4,701, as against 4,695 in 1897, and 1,027 in 1886, when the first report was made.
LONDON, Aug. 16. -- American securities, after a dull opening, were firmer, but rather inactive, owing to the settlement now going on. The market closed steady.

HAVANA, Aug. 16. -- Gen. Juan Isidro Jiminez, the aspirant to the Presidency of the Republic of Santo Domingo, will probably leave Havana for Santo Domingo to-morrow, going by a south coast steamer from Batabano. He will be accompanied by two friends and will travel unarmed.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Aug. 16. -- From every county but nine of the 119 in the State one of the most remarkable gatherings of Kentuckians ever assembled in the interest of any political cause met to-day, in accordance with the call of Chairman F.P. Johnston of the State Anti-Goebel Democratic Committee, for the purpose of nominating a full ticket to oppose the ticket nominated at Louisville in June, and headed by William Goebel.

FLEMINGTON, N.J., Aug. 16. -- The eighth annual picnic of the Hunterdon County Farmers' Alliance opened here today. About 100,000 persons were present. Amusements of various kinds occupied the attention of the women and young folks, while the men were discussing the political situation.

WASHINGTON, D.C., Aug. 16. -- Realizing that the time is short in which to complete arrangements for the reception to Admiral Dewey, the Washington authorities and the local committees are pushing plans and preparations as rapidly as possible.

The Clevelands, who, by the way, are not strong enough to beat a team of semi-professionals, were a mark again for the Brooklyns at Washington Park yesterday. Hughes had the "Exiles," as they are now known, at his mercy. Donovan pitched the last inning, and they managed to get two runs. Score:

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Aug. 16. -- Five brutal attacks by a negro on white women have occurred in Little Rock in the past twenty-four hours. It is generally believed that all these crimes were committed by the same man, but three suspects have been arrested, and if the right man can be positively identified he may receive summary punishment.

CHICAGO, Aug. 16. -- It was said in Packing Town to-day that a drop in the prices of prime and medium grades of beef, recently raised, might be expected to-morrow. Some reaction is almost certain to follow the high prices of the last week, as the natural influx of cattle, due to the high prices, will bring it about.

Mrs. Mary Kilcunnon, twenty-four years old, her husband John, twenty-eight, and their only child Peter, two, were severely burned yesterday morning in a fire in their home on the ground floor of 409 West Fifty-third Street, caused by an explosion of oil. Mrs. Kilcunnon's injuries were fatal and she died at 7 o'clock P.M. in the hospital, to which she had been removed.

There were about four hours of real, live baseball yesterday afternoon at the Polo Grounds, where 3,000 persons had the pleasure of seeing the New Yorks score a double victory over the Cincinnatis. In both contests the visitors were clearly outplayed.

The tennis tournament at Newport, the golf games, the preliminaries for the horse show at Southampton, and the weekly dance and the customary golf, the golf and the dances at all the shore and inland watering places, have taken away again the male population -- from a modish standpoint -- of the town.
ST. PETERSBUiRG, Aug. 17. -- Reports from Southwest Tussla say that the recent drought in that portion of the country has caused the utter loss of the Winter and Spring wheat crops.

PLATTSBURG, N.Y., Aug. 17. -- The Twenty-sixth Regiment Band marched up to the Hotel Champlain from Plattsburg Barracks, where the regiment is quartered, to-day, and gave a concert on the lawn in front of the hotel annex, in honor of President and Mrs. McKinley, who sat in the balcony outside their apartments.

NEWPORT, Aug. 17. -- The fleet of thirty-footers raced this afternoon over a triangular course from Brenton's Cove to Jamestown, thence to Bishop's Buoy, once round. The race was for a sweepstakes. The wind was from the south, and the start was made at 3:27 o'clock. The summary:

CHICAGO, Aug. 17. -- The Sons of Vermont residing in this city are called upon to contribute $1,500 toward the erection of a statue of Admiral George Dewey, to be placed on the porch of the Vermont State House at Montpelier.

RENNES, Aug. 17. -- The feature of the sitting to-day was a duel of words between Gen. Roget and Maitre Demange, the senior counsel for the defense. In spite of his prejudice against Capt. Dreyfus, Roget's evidence has this value, that it reduces the entire question of the prisoner's guilt to the consideration of the bordereau and its true authorship.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17. -- An order was issued to-day directing that ten additional regiments of infantry volunteers be organized for service in the Philippines. The regiments will be numbered from Thirty-eight to Forty-seven, and will be organized at the following places, in the order named: Jefferson Barracks, Mo.; Fort Crook, Neb.; Fort Riley, Kan.; Fort Niagara, N.Y.; Fort Ethan Allen, Vt.; Fort Leavenworth, Kan.; Fort Snelling, Minn.; South Framingham, Mass., and Camp Meade, Penn.

CHICAGO, Aug. 17. -- A new use has been found for the three-State free employment agencies, which were opened here a fortnight ago. The farmers throughout Illinois, and even in other States, have commenced to come in, or have written to the bureaus asking the officials to procure wives for them.

LONDON, Aug. 18. -- The correspondents of the London morning papers are unanimous in the opinion that the tide has finally turned in favor of Dreyfus. The evidence yesterday (Thursday) was so favorable to him that even some of the anti-Dreyfusites would fain admit that the scales were falling from their eyes.

-- Repeated appearances in the public prints of stories of citizens who complain that they have been the victims of the policeman's club make it impossible to doubt that the ancient pernicious activity of the lawful weapon of offense has been revived. Usually, it appears, when the victims of these clubbing outrages are arraigned in court, that they were beaten by the policeman for speaking impudently to him.

CHICAGO, Aug. 17. -- Charles T. Yerkes, in a bill filed in the Superior Court to-day, asks for an accounting on a contract between himself and S.E. Gross, real estate man and author. The statement is made that in 1887 the defendant sold to the street car manager over eight blocks of property in Gross Park for the sum of $140,000.
Sale at foreclosure of the Lebanon Springs Railway for $100,025 to parties acting for W.C. Roberts of this city, who recently bought a large amount of the tax claims against the company.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Aug. 17. -- The appearance of Frank Ackerman of Hackensack, N.J., here establishes a strange case of mistaken identity. About three years ago Ackerman disappeared from home, deserting his bride of a month and leaving behind numerous creditors. Some time later he was heard from in Baltimore.

NEWPORT, Aug. 17. -- The flagship New York arrived here this evening with the Indiana, Massachusetts, and Brooklyn. The Texas will rejoin the fleet to-morrow. Since the ships left Bar Harbor Sunday morning they have been engaged in fleet manoeuvring and target practice. The fleet will remain until next Thursday, when it will go to sea for further drill, returning later to Newport.

LONDON, Aug. 17. -- At the third day of the Stockton 1899 meeting to-day Martin, the American jockey, won the Durham County Produce Plate, 1,000 sovereigns, on Mr. J.E. Platt's Sweet Marjorie. Seven horses ran one mile and two furlongs.

CHICAGO, Aug. 17. -- The National Afro-American Council of the United States met at Bethel Church to-day in a convention, which will close Saturday evening. Among those in attendance are Bishop Alexander Walters, President; Booker T. Washington, Tuskegee, Ala.; Edward E. Brown, Boston; Bishop W.H. Turner, Colorado, and W.A. Pledger, Atlanta.

I am glad to see that THE TIMES has not joined in the general newspaper sneers at Russell Sage. It has tried to treat him with some sort of justice. I scarcely know him personally, having met him but once or twice, but my impressions and information do not agree with the current newspaper talk.

Fall, RIVER, Mass., Aug.17. -- Offers were made to-day for the. stocks of nearly all the seventy print cloth mills in this city by the New York promoters of the combination of yarn mills which was formed some time ago. The print cloth mills of Fall River are controlled by thirty-six corporations. The offer was made to the various Treasurers, with a view of forming a great print cloth trust.

A number of Democrats from various States who favor the nomination of Augustus Van Wyck of New York for President began to gather in this city yesterday. To-day the conferences in the interest of the ex-Justice's candidacy, which were to have been held at Saratoga, will take place at the Hoffman House.

The arrival of the Ward Line steamship Mexico at Havana yesterday leads to the belief that it was the Mexico and not the overdue steamship Vigilancia which was seen off Jupiter Inlet on the Florida Coast on Wednesday.

Charles Frohman is to establish a system of cab service in connection with his theatres, by which his patrons will be relieved of the present exorbitant prices imposed by liverymen and street "cabbies." The plan will be put into effect at the Empire Theatre a week from next Monday night.

SAVANNAH, Aug. 17. -- C.V. Miley, a Georgia officer, and a deputy accompanying him, who were sent from Georgia to Denmark, S.C., with requisition papers for G.M. Williams, an alleged refugee from justice, were to-day required to give bond for appearance at the Superior Court at that place on the charge of forging the name of the late Gov. Ellerbee to requisition papers for Williams.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 17. -- George C. Starck, President of the Stone Hill Wine Company of Hermann, Mo., one of the largest wine making concerns east of California, was brought to this city to-day by United States Marshal Bohle, who had arrested him on the charge of defrauding the Government by making and disposing of brandy on which the revenue tax had not been paid.

NEWPORT, Aug 17. -- Lispenard Stewart entertained at dinner last evening, at White Lodge, in honor of Mrs. Astor. The guests who met Mrs. Astor were Mr. and Mrs. W.D. Sloane, Mr. and Mrs. A. Lanfear Norrie, Mr. and Mrs. Nathaniel Thayer, Mr. and Mrs. H. McK. Twombly, Mr. and Mrs. H. Mortimer Brooks, Mr. and Mrs. Potter Josephine Johnson, Richard Peters, and Palmer, Mr. and Mrs. C. Oliver Iselin, Miss Egerton L. Winthrop.

I wish to file my protest, as an underwriter and as a citizen, against the Ramapo water scheme, which came so near being approved by the Board of Public Improvements yesterday. It is a stupendous and bold attempt to burden the taxpayers of a great city for the enrichment of private individuals.
BUFFALO, Aug. 17. -- Gov. Roosevelt covered much territory in and around Buffalo and Niagara Falls to-day, and was greeted everywhere with the greatest enthusiasm.

Frank J. Gould is organizing a fiduciary corporation to be known as the Federal Trust Company of New York, and his brothers, his sister, Hiss Helen M. Gould, and others members of the family are likely to be the chief stockholders of the company. It will be incorporated in this State, and the capitalization, as at present arranged, is to be $1,000,000, with a surplus of $500,000.

The case against William Neufeldt, accused of the murder of Mrs. Annie Kronman in her flat at 266 West Thirty-fifth Street on Aug. 7, is complete, in the opinion of Capt. McClusky, Chief of the Detective Bureau. Neufeldt's mother is the second cousin of Mrs. Kronman, and the murdered woman's purpose to help her relative caused her tragic death.
RENNES, France, Aug. 17. -- The Paris Figaro to-day exposed another alleged forgery in the Dreyfus case, which caused consternation in the ranks of the anti-Dreyfusards.

We wonder if sober-minded Frenchmen are conscious of the absurdity of the cry of the anti-Semites in Paris, "France for Frenchmen"? Do the perpetrators of the noise imagine they are arousing the emotion of fear? The cry has been heard before, but never a phantom has put in an appearance. Why do MM. DEROULEDE, GUERIN, DRUMONT, and their friends take themselves so seriously?

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17. -- The heads of the different bureaus are now at work as required by law preparing their estimates for the next fiscal year. These will be submitted to Congress at its opening for the Appropriation Committee. Most of the departments will show but little change other than in the line of increase of employes.
RENNES, France, Aug. 17. -- Gen. Roget, M. Bertulus, the investigating magistrate, the widow of the late Lieut. Col. Henry, and Col. Picquart were on the stand today.

TROMSOE, Island of Tromsoe, Norway, Aug. 17. -- Walter Wellman, and the survivors of the polar expedition led by him, arrived here this evening on the steamer Capella, having successfully completed their exploration in Franz Josef Land. Mr. Wellman has discovered important new lands and many islands.
The convention of the new labor political party met again last evening at Clarendon Hall and adopted the name "The Independent Labor Party."

RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 17. -- The visiting Argentine Congressmen in taking leave of the members of the Senate and Chamber Of Deputies to-day received unusual honors. All the high Brazilian officials paid a visit to the Argentine warships San Martin, Buenos Ayres, and Patria, which accompanied President Roca on his visit to this country.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., Aug. 17. -- Good time and racing was had at the meeting of the Central New York circuit in this city to-day. Summaries:

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Aug. 17. -- The Goebel Democrats are already beginning their campaign against ex-Gov. John Young Brown, the nominee of the bolting Democratic State Convention held yesterday at Lexington.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 17. -- The general opinion here among prominent officials and members of the New York Yacht Club is that the official trial races between the Columbia and Defender will be held off this port. The whole matter, however, rests with the committee in charge of the cup races, sometimes called the Challenge Committee, and as yet the members of that body have reached no decision.
Counterfeit coins, especially half dollars, have been freely passed at the recent camp meetings in Delaware.

PATTERSON, N.J., Aug. 17. -- Arthur W. Bishop, President of the Passaic County Society for the Prevention of Cruelty, to Children, intends to bring criminal proceedings against Mrs. Myrtle B. Eyler, Matron, of the State Industrial School for Girls, at Trenton, based on the testimony taken at the recent investigation.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17. -- According to Gen. R.G. Dyrenforth, Commander in Chief of the Union Veterans' Union, a sort of strike by that order is to be declared at the annual encampment to be held at Des Moines beginning Aug. 22.
RENNES, France, Aug. 17. -- With the usual attendance and without any noteworthy incident the trial of Capt. Alfred Dreyfus was resumed this morning.

The very interesting question whether a Governor can block or obstruct the proceedings involved in submitting amendments of the Constitution to the people has arisen in Pennsylvania, and has approached One step nearer settlement or solution by the decision of a Common Pleas Court, which sustained Gov. Stone's right to veto a proposition to amend.

ASHFIELD, Mass., Aug. 17. -- The twenty-first annual dinner of the Sanderson Academy to-day developed into a joint debate over the policy of the Administration in dealing with the Philippines, and for a time the discussion was decidedly warm.

LONDON, Aug. 17. -- Sir Charles Tupper left London to-day for a brief stay in the country. He came across to attend, as Chairman, the annual meeting of the British Columbia New Gold Fields Company, which, after only two years of active work, declares a dividend of 20 per cent.

The reception to Admiral Dewey began yesterday to assume definite form when the Committee on Plan and Scope considered the allotment of funds to the various subcommittees charged with the details of the celebration. Although these sub-committees have been working independently of each other, the total of their estimates was only $38,500 above the appropriation of $150,000 made by the Municipal Government.

Mary Ferry of 46 Mulberry Street had her husband, Michael Ferry, arrested yesterday afternoon for non-support. She told Magistrate Brann, in the Centre Street Police Court, that they had been married eight months, and that for a few months he allowed her $2 a week, but recently cut her allowance down to 14 cents a day.

There were two items of news in the papers two days ago which were interesting and gratifying, each by itself, but which became very remarkable when they were produced in "confrontation." One was the announcement that the contract for an electric plant, about to be installed in Great Britain, had been given to an American bidder.

NEWPORT, Aug. 17. -- Dwight Davis and Holcomb Ward won the championship of America in doubles at the Casino here today, after a clever three-set match with Leo Ware and George Sheldon, who had held the title for two years. Every one expected a long and stubbornly contested struggle, but Sheldon and Ware both showed their lack of practice, Sheldon being particularly unsteady.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17. -- Preparations for the observance of the one hundredth anniversary of George Washington's death are being actively conducted by the committee of the Grand Lodge of Masons for the State of Virginia and by the local lodges. The Masonic observances which will take place in Alexandria and at Mount Vernon Dec. 13 and 14 next are being thoroughly discussed and planned.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17. -- The final meeting of the jury for the Phoebe A. Hearst Architectural Plan for the University of California will be held in San Francisco Sept. 1. The jury is composed of the following architects: R. Norman Shaw, England; J.L. Pascal, France; Paul Wallet, Germany; Walter Cook, New York, and J.B. Reinstein, San Francisco.

Some weeks ago, in noticing Mr. COLER'S very noteworthy article in The North American Review, we had occasion to say that there were two municipal office holders who had gained reputation by taking municipal office. One of them, of course, was Mr. COLER himself; the other was Mr. GUGGENHEIMER.

SARATOGA, Aug. 17. -- The race for gentlemen riders to-day resulted in a victory for Buela, on which Mr. Paget had the mount. Clawson was set down for two days for "impudence at the post." The summary:

PASSAIC, N.J., Aug. 17. -- The Continental Match Company's factory in this city has closed its doors. Ever since Edwin Gould sold his interests to the Diamond Match Company it had been expected here that the factory would shut down.
RENNES, France, Aug. 17. -- M. Labori, counsel of Dreyfus, who was shot on Monday, is now progressing most satisfactorily.
PARIS, Aug. 17. -- The Guerin situation has become acute. The siege is still on and Republican Guards now surround the house.
RENNES, France, Aug. 17. -- M. Labori, counsel of Dreyfus, who was shot on Monday, is now progressing most satisfactorily.

LONDON, Aug. 4. -- Dr. Robertson Nicoll is unquestionably one of our most competent critics. He has intelligence, culture, honesty, and fearlessness. These qualities constitute a strong equipment. Nevertheless, there are many people who, now that Dr. Nicoll has repeatedly made it evident that he has a poor opinion of Mr. Kipling, will insist that as a critic he is entitled to no respect whatever.

PATERSON, N.J., Aug. 18. -- White the Sabbath observance blue laws of New Jersey are permitted to rust unused here by the classes who generally insist on their observance, the barbers and icemen, many of them foreign-born or of foreign birth, are insisting that against them those Jaws shall be enforced. The result is that Paterson is now in a position which no other considerable city in the United States shares with her.

ABINGDON, Ill., Aug. 18. -- Robley E. Heller of this city has written and published a drama entitled "Zebedee," a religious spectacular play, which has received the approval of Daniel Frohman of New York, who has notified Mr. Heller that he will accept the play.

The Pope has issued invitations to delegates from different countries, who are to attend a conference to be held this year at Einsiedeln, in Switzerland. The question to be considered is the better preservation of books and manuscripts in great libraries.

Murphy of 70 Fifth Avenue, charged that when they were arrested Tuesday night the latter was clubbed by Policeman Carmody of the West Thirtieth Street Police Station.

President Converse of the National Tube Company announced yesterday the acquisition by that company of the Pittsburg Tube Company's plant at Pittsburg, Penn. The deal is said to have been highly advantageous to the National. The books of the National Tube Company were closed yesterday for the exchange of the temporary certificates to permanent ones.

NEWPORT, Aug. 18. -- Another bright day greeted the lawn tennis experts here to-day, but the heat was rather severe and the humidity intense during the middle of the day, making it very exhausting for the players. The bright sun, however, drew out a big crowd, and the Casino grounds were well filled during the forenoon.
LONDON, Aug. 18. -- James Fitzwalter Clifford Butler, twenty-fourth Baron Dunboyne, is dead.

Any change in the direction of Boston's standard and now almost venerable magazine, The Atlantic Monthly, is always of interest to the literary public. The retirement of Mr. Walter H. Page from the editorship, to accept a position in New York, is cause for regret to the many friends he has made here, but the managers of the publication seem to have been very fortunate in the choice of his successor.

The recent development of the iron and steel industry is considered by business men of this city as one of the most remarkable as well as most encouraging facts of the present year. It has for years been usual to regard this industry as the most trustworthy barometer of general trade and prosperity, and its tremendous growth during the year 1899 is looked upon as the surest sign of continued and increasing prosperity.

Fields. It is dated Lenox, June, 1851.

When Charles Edward makes his escape to France, there being a price put on Ranald's head, he takes ship in Holland, and reaches Amsterdam.

The people are for the most part poor, and the women, besides lacking the means and taste necessary, know very little about sewing.

PETERSBURG, Aug. 1, -- It seems hardly necessary to contradict the absurd rumor, published in certain French sheets, concerning the sensational telegram sent by the Czar to Prince Louis Bonaparte. Nobody in Russia considered this telegram as being anything but a canard. The very terms of the dispatch were sufficient to prove that it had never been sent by the Czar to Prince Louis.

The Philadelphia oarsmen are out on the Schuylkill practicing daily, while on the Harlem the local oarsmen are constantly in training.

The Admiral enlisted in the navy in 1853, and is naval aide de camp to her Majesty, with whom he is a great favorite. This is not to be wondered at, as he has the hearty, unassuming manner that properly constructed sailors are always supposed to have.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19. -- Washington unwillingly gave up all hope of securing Admiral Dewey first on Thursday, with the coming of the dispatch plainly indicating that the Admiral is prepared to bear the greatest pressure of New York upon his landing, upon the assumption, possibly, that if he can stand that he can stand anything.

CHELTENHAM, England, Aug. 19. -- In the cricket game between a Gloucestershire eleven and the visiting Australians, which began here Thursday, the home players, in their second innings, to-day, were all out for 300 runs. In their first innings Thursday the Gloucestershire men were all out for 203 runs.

NEWPORT, Aug. 19. -- It is expected that the Columbia will sail for Bristol on Monday morning to have her steel mast stepped, and when she comes back to Newport the trial races will be held. Everything on the Defender is complete in every detail, and ready for the trial races.

Several overdue steamers came into port yesterday after running the gantlet of the hurricane which wrought such havoc in Puerto Rico. The Mallory Line steamer Lampasas, which was overdue three days, was among the first to enter port. Capt. Staples, her commander, said that he had not experienced such a storm in seventeen years.

The Civil Service Commission yesterday announced a large list of appointments in various city departments. The salaries of the appointees range from $4,500 to $600 per year. The minor appointments were for surveyors in the Fire Department, court attendants, clerks, and stenographers.

NEWPORT, Aug. 19. -- Newport to-night was a hot town until the midnight hour, for, with tennis at the Casino in the morning, followed by luncheons, polo, golf, dinners, musicales, and informal dances, there was not a moment of let-up in the social gayeties. While the tennis play was not so largely attended as on the previous days, the full quota of the cottage colony turned out in force, with many from New York added.

The crowds over Sunday grow larger each week, and the marvel is where Col. Dick manages to put all the people.

NEWARK, Aug. 20. -- Five events for money and trophy prizes called together on the Vailsburg quarter-mile track to-day many of the famous professional cycle racers of the country, and a goodly number of amateurs. About 3,000 persons witnessed the racing, which was uniformly good, and in two events, the five-mile professional handicap and the half-mile amateur handicap, unusually exciting.

We agree fully with our neighbor The Sun that "to Controller COLER every honest citizen of New York is deeply indebted" for opposing and exposing the Ramapo Water Company job. It is true that to the vigilance and courage of that upright officer we owe our escape from the enormous burden which the rascals in the Board of Public Improvements were about to fasten upon this city.

-- The Scientific American, in a timely and pointed article, calls attention to the weakness of the plans for the six new cruisers recently authorized. The Naval Board of Construction has produced plans which are, as The Scientific American very properly points out, a distinct step backward.

SEATTLE, Washington, Aug. 20. -- M. Leon Bureau of Parts, formerly private secretary to M. Labori, is in the city, a guest of Dr. Adriene Monod, French Vice Consul. He said to-day that the present trial of Dreyfus will result in his acquittal. If a verdict of guilty is returned, the Court of Cassation, the higher French authority, will at once set aside and order another court-martial, and so on until he is acquitted.

Twelve firemen were overcome by smoke and gas at the fire which occurred in the seed store of Peter Henderson Co., at 35 and 37 Cortland Street, early yesterday morning. Nine of the men recovered rapidly after being brought out to the fresh air. Peter Carberry of Engine No. 7 and William Byell of Engine No. 12 were found to be so seriously injured that they were immediately taken to the Hudson Street Hospital.

RICHMOND, Va., Aug. 20. -- The result of the primary meetings in this State yesterday practically assures the renomination of United States Senator Thomas S. Martin. About a dozen counties yesterday chose Democratic candidates for the Virginia Legislature. Of these Martin carried all except one.

LONDON, Aug. 20. -- Our monetary position is decidedly better, and unless an unforeseeable change for the worse comes, no advance in the Bank of England rate is probable until well into next month. I do not recall such harmony of action between the Bank and the open market as exists now.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 20. -- The International Commercial Congress, to be held during the National Export Exposition, promises to be the most notable gathering ever held for the discussion of trade and commerce. Thirty-one foreign Governments have so far accepted the invitation to be represented at the congress, and have named delegates, many of whom are men of world-wide reputation.

The end of August approaches with none of those dreadful things at hand which all the professional prophets of Wall Street have been forecasting. Money market conditions are not choking business in Wall Street or anywhere else. Instead of funds "rushing in a deluge," (such has been the pessimistic metaphor,) we have a bank statement showing the actual strengthening of reserves.

NORWAY, Me., Aug. 20. -- The 1898 crop of spruce gum gathered from the forests of Maine has been sent to the market, the last batch of six tons having been sent last Wednesday. The total amount of the crop is in the neighborhood of thirty tons, the largest in the history of the State, and represents about $63,000.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 20. -- William C. Whitney, his daughter, Dorothy, and the Misses Randolph arrived at Mr. Whitney's country place on October Mountain, Saturday night, and will remain for several days. Mr. Whitney has a stable of saddle and carriage horses here, which were sent up from New York early last week. Mr. and Mrs. Harry Payne Whitney are expected up from Newport before Sept. 1.

RENNES, Aug. 21. -- The third week of the second trial by court-martial of Capt. Alfred Dreyfus began without incident at 6:30 this morning, but before the sitting was concluded it developed sensational features.

The Ramapo scandal gives an intimation of how the people's money is wasted when municipal ownership could save the taxpayers fabulous sums. Undoubtedly, if the contracts for other privileges in the city's pigeon holes were overhauled and investigated, the revelations would be as startling as this Ramapo business is.

BERLIN, Aug. 21. -- During the afternoon a Cabinet meeting was held at the residence of Prince von Hohenlohe, the Imperial Chancellor, and the whole Cabinet agreed to resign. The acceptance of the Ministers' resignation is uncertain.

The New York and Philadelphia baseball teams gave two interesting exhibitions at the Polo Grounds yesterday afternoon before 3,000 persons. Each team won a game. Both games abounded in brilliant plays.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug. 21. -- The usual open handicap tournament for the cup offered by A. Howard Hinkle, Secretary of the Kebo Valley Club, beings to-morrow on the Kebo links. There are a large number of entries, including those of some well-known players.

FREEHOLD, N.J., Aug. 21. -- There was an explosion in the centre of the town this evening which startled every one for a mile in all directions and injured two men. It occurred at the drinking fountain. The fountain was wrecked, and there was much excitement.

FISHKILL LANDING, N.Y., Aug. 21. -- Since last Thursday night, when, sitting on the piazza of his country home, Craigside, at Cold Spring, Gen. Daniel Butterfield was attacked with what appeared to be a fainting attack, but which afterward proved to be a pronounced case of aphasia, he has been a very sick man, much more so than has been supposed.

The appearance of the bubonic plague at Oporto, Portugal, brings the danger of invasion of this dreaded scourge so near the United States that some alarm is felt concerning its approach. That the quarantine authorities are alive to the danger is believed, and to ascertain what precautions, if any, have been taken, Health Office Doty was seen yesterday.

The unfortunate and untimely Anarchist riots bear testimony to the excitement that prevails in France, but their testimony is only cumulative, and was not needed to establish the fact. There are testimonies of quite another order which establish it abundantly. One of them is the statement cabled the other day from the Journal des Debats, protesting against the course of the foreign press concerning the trial at Rennes.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 21. -- A meeting of the stockholders of the Scott-Janney Electric Company, recently incorporated at Trenton with a capital of $30,000,000, was held in this city to-day, and the following were elected Directors:

The fight against the Ramapo Water Company's attempt to seize the city's water supply showed no signs of relenting yesterday. Controller Coler and Bridge Commissioner Shea, who are directing the attack, believe that the scheme has been beaten into insensibility, but they will give no quarter until it is effectually killed at the meeting of the Board of Public Improvements on Aug. 30.

PARIS, Aug. 21. -- M. Decrais, Minister of the Colonies, has received a dispatch from the Governor General of French West Africa, fully confirming The Figaro's story of the killing of Lieut. Col. Klobb and Lieut. Meunier by members of a French expedition, under the charge of Capt. Voulet and Capt. Chanoine, in the French Soudan.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 21. -- Mrs. Eva A. Ingersoll, widow of Robert G. Ingersoll, declared yesterday that she believed her husband, who died recently at Dobbs Ferry, left no will. She has made diligent search and inquiry for a will, but has not found any or obtained any information that he ever made one.

CRIPPLE CREEK, Col., Aug. 21 -- Fire has entirely destroyed the business portion of the city of Victor, causing a loss estimated at $2,000,000. Beginning shortly after noon, the fire raged until night, consuming everything its own way. It had its origin, it is thought, in the Merchants' Cafe, adjoining the Bank of Victor. A strong wind from the south fanned the flames, and in a few minutes all the surrounding houses were afire.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Aug. 21. -- Senator Jacob Rice of Ulster County, who resides in this city, denies the published report that he withdrew a bill introduced by him at the last session of the Legislature, incorporating the Lake Kiskatom Water Works and Electrical Power Company of Catskill, Greene County, at the request of Senator Ahearn, his colleague, on behalf of the Ramapo Water Company.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Aug. 21. -- A big row among theatrical people began here to-day. Harry Davis, who has been associated with Keith and other circuit managers, has been managing the Grand Opera House and Avenue Theatre for many years. Frank McCann, the lessee and representative of the corporation, dispensed with Davis's services. The latter refused to be discharged, having been a half owner two years ago.

When Richard Croker cames back to town he will find an active rebellion in full swing in his own Assembly district. That district is the Twenty-ninth, of which John F. Carroll was long the leader. Rollin M. Morgan now discharges the duties of that position, and the first open steps in a movement to displace him were taken last night at a meeting of Democrats held at Tuxedo Hall, Madison Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street.
ITHACA, N.Y., Aug. 21. -- President Schurman reached Ithaca to-day, accompanied by Mrs. Schurman and Mrs. Schurman's mother, Mrs. Munroe.
LONDON, Aug. 22. -- The correspondents of the London papers at Rennes are beginning to comment upon the changed aspects of the trial.
SEATTLE, Wash., Aug. 21. -- Passengers on the steamer City of Topeka, which arrived last night from Skagway, Alaska, bring news of the first legal executions in the Klondike.

NEWPORT, Aug. 21. -- W.K. Vanderbilt to-night entertained at dinner on board his steam yacht Valiant, which has been shifted into her moorings in Brenton's Cove. The yacht was brilliantly illuminated and prettily decorated with plants and ferns, while on a large dinner table in the dining saloon red lilies were effectually used.

The war between the American Sugar Refining Company and its competitors unexpectedly broke out anew yesterday, and before the day was out developed into a decidedly interesting fight, which promises to grow more bitter with time.

CHICAGO, Aug. 21. -- William Hoyne, a commission merchant, was suddenly forced to play the part of a toreador against an infuriated steer last night, and he narrowly escaped death, while his horse was killed by the enraged beast. While he was jogging along on horseback near Shields Avenue, where he lives, the steer, which had escaped from its pen at the Stock Yards, dashed around the corner and rushed at him.

Notwithstanding the fact that the week beginning Sept. 3 will bring the Yarmouth theatricals and the Horse Show at Newport, this present week, with its multifarious entertainments and the Vanderbilt dinner, dance, and ball, will really be the crowning week of the season. The tennis tournament closed in a blaze of glory yesterday. Polo is still an attraction in the afternoon, and every evening brings from three to four dinners.

HAVANA, Aug. 21. -- The son of Jiminez is still being annoyed by would-be filibusters. Many former Cuban soldiers and Italians are offering their services, in spite of the fact, often repeated by young Jiminez, that he does not wish to organize an expedition.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 21. -- At the opening session of the American Association for the Advancement of Science President Orton replied to the address of welcome with a review of the important discoveries of science, contrasting especially twenty-four of those of the nineteenth century with the fifteen or sixteen of the eighteenth century as classified by Wallace.

CHICAGO, Aug. 21. -- The next Democratic Convention may be held as early as February, and will not be later than March, 1900. Among the party leaders the sentiment in favor of an early convention has been crystallizing, and ex-Gov. Stone is the originator of the plan. He made up his mind after Richard Croker had declared for Bryan.

NEWPORT, Aug. 21. -- The fleet of thirty-footers raced over the Jamestown-Bishop's Buoy course this afternoon for the cup offered by John R. Drexel, owner of Raccoon. The wind was strong from the south, and the start was made at 3:22 o'clock. The summary:
