ST. LOUIS, Aug. 21. -- Young, the home team's pitcher, was in excellent form to-day and blanked the Chicagos. He had good support. Score:

CAPE TOWN, Aug. 21. -- The report, as cabled from here last night, that the Transvaal Government had handed its reply to the British agent at Pretoria, to be forwarded to Sir Alfred Milner, British High Commissioner for South Africa and Governor of Cape Colony, is confirmed.

To-day's TIMES contains an article which makes it appear that the Rev. Dr. Clendenin and his vestry believe there is a close connection between the burning of their church, St. Peter's, and their refusal to have the ordination of Dr. Briggs take place in the lately burned edifice.

HARRISBURG, Penn., Aug. 21. -- A charter was isued by the State Department to-day to the American Iron and Steel Company, with a nominal capital of $1,000. The company has purchased several large iron and steel plants at Reading and Lebanon, and will increase its capital.
LONDON, Aug. 22. -- Sir Thomas Lipton, in an interview with a representative of The Daily Mail, has expressed himself as delighted at the reception accorded the Shamrock by the Americans.
LONDON, Aug. 21. -- The Lord Mayor has remitted 1,500 as the first installment of the West Indies relief fund.

OMAHA, Neb., Aug. 21. -- The silver allies of Nebraska will to-morrow meet in joint convention for the fourth time in the State's history. With the hotels filled to-night with delegates of all three conventions, and with the leaders in conference, it is almost a foregone conclusion that fusion will be accomplished with little effort.

Rudolph A. Wagner, a wealthy box manufacturer, of 464 Palisade Avenue, Weehawken Heights, who disappeared from his home two weeks ago, has been found in the Long Island State Hospital, Flatbush. He was admitted there from the detention ward of the Kings County Hospital, under the name of John Doe.

PLATTSBURG, Aug. 21. -- President McKinley and party will leave here on Friday evening for Pittsburg, Penn., where on Aug. 28 a celebration will be held in honor of the return of the Tenth Pennsylvania Volunteers from the Philippines. From Pittsburg the President hopes to go to East Liverpool, Ohio, to spend one day with his old friend, Col. J.M. Taylor.

READVILLE, Mass., Aug. 21. -- The grand circuit fixture for the Readville mile track began this afternoon, with splendid prospects for the week of light harness racing. The track was never in better shape, and several horses were obliged to make new figures for themselves. The attendance was very large.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Aug. 21. -- A desperate fight, in which four officers of the Thirty-first Regiment, stationed at Fort Thomas, were the principals, occurred on a Fort Thomas car this morning. Lieut. Sprit and three other officers, with several privates, boarded the car at Fountain Square, Cincinnati, and proceeded across the river to Covington.

LONDON, Aug. 21. -- The Colonial Office, in confirming the dispatch telegraphed from Cape Town saying the Transvaal Government had handed its reply to the British agent at Pretoria, says that Sir Alfred Milner has telegraphed a message to that effect.

TORONTO, Ont., Aug. 21. -- The Knickerbocker Athletic Club of New York to-day began the first of a six days' series of matches against the crack cricket clubs of the Dominion. They had Toronto-Rosedale as their first opponents on the Rosedale grounds, where the international match between Canada and the United States was decided two weeks ago.

TORONTO, Ont., Aug. 21. -- The first race for Canada's Cup for thirty-five foot yachts between the Genesee of Rochester, the American challenger, and the Beaver of Toronto, the defender, ended in an all-round fluke. Weather and position favored the Canadian yacht at the start. The wind was blowing twenty-five miles an hour, and the Genesee came out in double-reefed sails, and was lee rail under at that.

PARIS, Aug. 21. -- The papers of this city, in commenting on the riots which took place here yesterday are unanimous in pronouncing the situation to be of the most serious character. The Conservative and Nationalist organs accuse the Government of provoking yesterday's bloodshed by unjustifiable arrests.

The parish is historically one of the most interesting in Bishop POTTER'S diocese, and the church building, especially the interior as it was rebuilt and decorated some twenty years ago, after the former fire, is architecturally one of the most interesting churches in the suburbs of New York.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 21. -- In the sweltering heat the cottage colony braved weather conditions this morning to watch the tennis match between Paret and Davis and the faithful Jamestown contingent was present in full force. Costumes of the previous days were simply outdone, as it was agreed that the gowns seen were the most superb of the tournament.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21. -- A report was printed here to-day, with the admission that it would not be verified, that a decision would soon be reached in the case of Capt. Carter, which has been pending before the President for more than a year. Together with this statement is one that Mr. MacVeagh, Carter's counsel, who is about to return from Europe, would ask for a new trial.

HARRISBURG, Penn., Aug. 21. -- The State Republican Convention will meet in the Harrisburg Opera House on Thursday to nominate candidates for State Treasurer, Judge of the Supreme Court, and Judge of the Superior Court. The nomination for Supreme Court Judge is equivalent to an election by reason of two vacancies to be filled, no elector being entitled to vote for more than one candidate.

ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 21. -- Foster M. Voorhees and the last New Jersey Legislature were denounced at the afternoon session of the annual State Congress of the Federation of Trades and Labor Unions, held to-day in the Common Council Chamber. WASHINGTON, Aug. 21. -- The Dewey Home fund passed the $19,000 mark to-day. The contributions were $367, making a total of $19,128.

The Executive Committee of the Republican City Committee met yesterday afternoon at the Fifth Avenue Hotel, remained in session for fifteen minutes, transacted some purely routine business, and adjourned without having taken any action of political significance. The plan for harmonizing the anti-Tammany forces in the coming campaign was not referred to in the proceedings, though there was much discussion of it among the members before and after the session.

RENNES, Aug. 21. -- The chief item of news to-night is in consequence of a remark made by the President of the court to-day in connection with Lieut. Col. Picquart. Maitre Demange will formally accuse Col. Jouaust of partiality.

The challenger Shamrock and her consort, the steam yacht Erin, were moved yesterday morning from their anchorage off Tompkinsville, S.I., to the Erie Basin. The Erin is now in the dry dock having her underbody scraped and painted, and the Shamrock is tied to the new pier, No. 3, which had been made ready especially for her reception on Sunday.

CHAPPAQUA, N.Y., Aug. 21. -- The excitement in Westchester County caused by the burning of St. Peter's Church, in the village of Westchester was increased this morning by the attempt to burn the barn on the old Horace Greeley estate, which is the Summer home of Dr. Clendenin, rector of St. Peter's Church.

Edward Tiesdale, sixty years old, of 109 Union Avenue, Brooklyn, was fined $10, in the Lee Avenue Police Court yesterday, for assaulting his wife. There was at least one person in court, however, who felt that the prisoner was a much misunderstood man. He was Court Officer Sweeney.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22. -- The official report on the mineral production of the United States for the calendar year 1898 was made public to-day by the Geological Survey. It shows that since 1880 the total value of the mineral production of the United States has increased from $36,319,000 to $697,880,002 in 1898, nearly 90 per cent.

RENNES, Aug. 22. -- (Copyright, 1899, by The New York Times.) -- Maitre Labori received grand ovation to-day on returning to the court. He had nothing of the usual appearance of an invalid. On the contrary, he seemed to be in splendid health.

BOSTON, Aug. 22. -- At a meeting of the Democratic State Central Committee here to-day it was voted to hold the State Convention in Mechanics' Hall. Boston, Sept. 21. William S. McNary of Boston will preside and George Fred Williams of Dedham will be Chairman of the Committeee on Resolutions.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22. -- Letters from Cuba may soon be looked for with the new Cuban stamps affixed to pay postage. The Post Office Department has just shipped to Havana to be distributed to the Post Offices in the island the first lot of the stamps prepared expressly for Cuban use.

GOSHEN, N.Y., Aug. 22. -- The Orange County Circuit races opened here to-day. There was a good attendance and good racing, with the track in fine condition. To-morrow John R. Oentry and Joe Patchen. the pacers, will contest for a purse of $2,000. For the four days' races 17 horses have been entered. The summary:

NEWPORT, Aug. 22. -- The thirty-footers began this morning a series of races to determine the championship of the fleet of little craft.
VILLEFRANCHE, France, Aug. 22. -- The United States cruiser Olympia, which left Leghorn, Italy, yesterday, arrived here at 6:40 o'clock this morning.

HELENA, Mont., Aug. 22. -- Capt. Louis P. Sanders, Aide de Camp on the staff of Major Gen. Otis, has written to his father, former Senator Sanders, a letter describing a trip made by himself and Col. Potter under orders from Gen. Otis to ascertain the true situation in the Sulu Archipelago and North Borneo, and the attitude of the Sultan towards the United States.

The reappearance of M. LABORI yesterday in the courtroom at Rennes was, according to the reports, a frightfully imprudent thing for himself. It is to be supposed that he had taken counsel of his physicians and that he would not have ventured upon the reappearance if they had gone so far as to warn him that he made it without their sanction, and that if he made it, they washed their hands of the case.

RENNES, Aug. 22. -- Maitre Labori, leading counsel for the defense, who was murderously assaulted Aug. 14. was present in court this morning when the trial of Capt. Dreyfus was resumed. The proceedings opened at 6:30 A.M.

RENNES, Aug. 22. -- To-day was Maitre Labori's day at the Lycee, where Capt. Alfred Dreyfus is standing trial on the charge of treason. He was the central figure of the scene. Labori did what people had expected. He galvanized the dormant defense into an active, living thing. Maitre Demange was conciliatory.

The New Yorks showed a reversal of form at the Polo Grounds yesterday, where the Philadelphias scored another victory without an apparent effort. The playing of the locals lacked the life that marked their display in the last two games. They seemed to have forgotten how to use their bats.

W.S. Vosburgh, The Jockey Club handicapper, has assigned the following list of weights for the candidates for the Fall Handicap, at three-quarters of a mile, which is to be run on Saturday at Sheepshead Bay:

BRISTOL, R.I., Aug. 22. -- When the cup defender Columbia meets the English challenger Shamrock in the first of the international cup races off Sandy Hook next October the American yacht will be more heavily sparred and will carry more canvas than she has had in any race this season.

GREENPORT, L.I., Aug. 22. -- An elopement which took place from Shelter Island on Saturday night has just become known. The parties were Clara Britton, the eighteen-year-old daughter of Eugene V. Britton of 324 Clinton Avenue, Brooklyn, and Louis Hutchinson, the nineteen-year-old son of J.L. Hutchinson, once connected with the old Barnum, Bailey Hutchinson circus.

PATERSON, N.J., Aug. 22. -- A Jewish congregation at Passaic, which is presided over by Louis Harris, a rabbi, who lives in this city, waited in vain on Saturday afternoon for him. While the congregation waited the minister was yelling himself hoarse in a stable in this city, where he had bee locked in.

BOSTON, Aug. 22. -- The Brooklyns compelled Meekin to retire after two innings to-day and won easily. Willis, who succeeded him, was very effective, the only run scored off him being Daly's home run in the fifth. In the ninth Tenney and Long singled, but were retired in a fast double play, Casey to Daly. Attendance, 6,200. Score:

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 22. -- The State Conference of Chicago Platform Democrats, called by Calvin E. Keach, to-day appointed as permanent Chairman William Hepburn Russell of New York City, and also named an Executive Committee. Resolutions favoring William Jennings Bryan were adopted.

The Coroner yesterday held William Neufeld without bail for the murder of Mrs. Annie Kronman Aug. 7, and almost simultaneously with the Coroner's action the Grand Jury returned a true bill charging Neufeld with murder in the first degree. The prisoner will be arraigned this morning in Part I. of the General Sessions Court to plead to the indictment.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug. 22. -- One of the largest and most brilliant balls of the season was given at the Malvern to-night by a number of well-known New York and Philadelphia society women. In spite of the rainy night, society, or at last that portion of it which was fortunate enough to secure invitations, was out in full force.

Papers in a suit for an injunction to restrain the Board of Public Improvements from authorizing a contract between the city and the Ramapo Water Company were served on some of the officials who favor the steal yesterday. The suit was brought by The New York World, which obtained the temporary restraining order from Justice Bookstaver of the Supreme Court late on Monday night.

BAR HARBOR, Aug. 22. -- The first games in the golf championship for the Hinkle Cup were played to-day at the Kebo Valley Club. Thirty-four competitors started, and, although the weather was bad, some good golf was shown, and a large crowd of fashionables were out to see the play.

LONDON, Aug. 22. -- The Perot case has been finished in rather a peculiar manner. Until to-day the grandfather and the mother of the child were apparently at daggers drawn. Now Mr. Perot has won, and he also seems to have made his peace with Mrs. Perot. Hitherto Neptune Blood has always done the honors when Mrs. Perot and her sister were leaving court.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22. -- The assertion of Adjt. Gen. Corbin that the recently recruited regiments of volunteers are even better bodies of men, physically, than the regulars that went into the Spanish war at the beginning of hostilities is supported by a pay officer who has been on duty at Camp Meade, Penn. He says he has been constantly reminded of the superior class of men obtained by seeing them at their various duties.

TORONTO, Ontario, Aug. 22. -- The Genesee, the American challenger for Canada's Cup, won the first race of the series to-day by a narrow margin. The weather was the Genesee's to a nicety, as a moderate northwest wind prevailed. The course was twenty-one miles, in a triangle. The start was free, with a run to the southeast.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22. -- The Populist "leaders," who do not appear to be very numerous or prominent in Washington just now, are said by a Democrat here, who has found a new cause for Democratic worriment, to contemplate a rush on the Democrats next Spring, with the purpose of compelling them to follow instead of taking the lead as they did in 1896.

NEWPORT, Aug. 22. -- The wedding of Miss Dora Havemeyer, daughter of Mrs. Theodore A. Havemeyer, to Lieut. Commander C. McR. Winslow, United States Navy, Flag Lieutenant of Admiral Sampson's staff, will occur here on Sept. 18. The details of the wedding have not as yet been completed, nor will they be for several days.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22. -- The Commissioner of Internal Revenue has reversed the ruling of his bureau concerning the affixing of stamps to pawn tickets which contain a clause charging for storage, except where the charge is bona fide in the case of cumbersome articles or articles requiring special care for their preservation. This charge for storage on all articles has been a custom of pawn brokers to evade the State laws against usury.

NEWPORT, Aug. 22. -- The National championship lawn tennis tournament was brought to an end here to-day at the Casino, with the challenge match for the championship between Malcolm D. Whitman of Brookline, Mass., last year's winner, and J. Parmly Paret of New York, who won the all-comers' tournament yesterday and challenged Whitman for his title.

Francis Wilson and his opera company are busy rehearsing at the Knickerbocker Theatre the comic version of Cyrano de Bergerac that Mr. Wilson expects to make a big hit this season. The company works day and night, with music and without music, and is being trained with the greatest attention to detail by Mr. Wilson and his stage manager, A.M. Holbrook.

DURHAM, Me., Aug. 22. -- Serious charges have been made against the Rev. Frank W. Sanford, leader of the Holy Ghost and Us Society on Beulah Hill, and it is probable the evangelist and his assistant, Mr. Gleason, will be arrested before Mr. Sanford sails for England next Saturday.

NEWPORT, Aug. 22. -- The greatest race that has ever been rowed in this harbor took place between twelve-oared cutters manned by the flagship New York tars and Old Colony Boat Club members this afternoon, and was witnessed by thousands of persons, including the officers and men of the North Atlantic Squadron and all Newport, who were afloat in every conceivable craft.

PLATTSBURG, N.Y., Aug. 22. -- President and Mrs. McKinley, accompanied by Secretary Cortelyou, drove over to Plattsburg Barracks this morning. They did not make a stop there, but drove slowly to watch the soldiers of the Twenty-sixth Regiment who were drilling on the parade ground.

PRETORIA, Aug. 22. -- It is ascertained on the highest authority that no definite reply has been sent to the proposal of the British Secretary of State for the Colonies, Joseph Chamberlain, to submit to a joint commission of inquiry the question of the effect upon the Outlanders of the recent franchise reforms.

MANILA, Aug. 19 (Via Hongkong, Aug. 22.) -- The Filipino rebels appear to retain much more of a fighting spirit than might be expected after their recent San Fernando experiences and Gen. Lawton's drubbings in the south.

Consolidated Gas fell 3 more points yesterday, but there is no slackening in the mystery of what Mr. William Rockefeller and his associates propose to do at the impending dividend meeting. Directors of the company seen yesterday by representatives of THE NEW YORK TIMES were all indisposed to discuss the situation.

KINGSTON, N. Y., Aug. 22. -- Thousands of acres of the farm and forest lands in the Catskill Mountains are under option by the Ramapo Water Company. Options on these lands have been secured by representatives of the company, and it is stated upon reliable information that the company now has agents in the Catskills arranging for the consummation of the sale and the delivery of much of the land mentioned within a short time.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 22. -- The Union Reform Party to-day nominated the following State ticket:

While a trolley car of the North Hudson County Railway was descending the trestle leading from Jersey City Heights to the Hoboken ferry at a late hour Monday night with a load of passengers the trolley pole left the wire. While Matthew Sheridan, the motorman, was looking back to see if the conductor had adjusted the pole he lost his balance and fell from the car to the trestle, and thence to the street.

PRINCETON, N. J., Aug. 22. -- Prof. J. B. Hatcher of the geological and palaeontological department of Princeton University has just returned from an expedition to Patagonia, where he has been making extensive researches in geology and palaeontology during the past eight months.

NEW HAVEN, Aug. 22. -- The semi-official statement made in Boston last Saturday and authorized by President Charles P. Clark of the New York. New Haven and Hartford Railroad, that he may, on account of poor health, find it necessary to resign in the Fall, has been the cause of great surprise at the head offices of the road in this city.

-- In these prosaic times of ours there is little hope for the survival of the good old world-thoughts on which our forebears thrived. Every year the leaves and the old traditions fall, and every year the hard hand of science or law, or just mean common sense, is laid on the pulse of some old fairy tale and it just stops.

The cup challenger Shamrock was seen under conditions yesterday at Erie Basin which somewhat modified preconceived views of yachtsmen who had seen her as she appeared off Tompkinsville in her cruising yawl rig and deep laden with stores. The Shamrock lay yesterday at Pier 3. Erie Basin, without spars, rigging, or voyaging weights, and, as a result, floated light.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, Aug. 15. -- A letter just received here via Barbados from a trustworthy and well informed correspondent at Rio throws some light on a recent Rome dispatch to a London newspaper, which stated that there was some talk of an alliance among the South American republics against the United States.

POTAM, Mexico, Aug. 15, via Nogales, Arizona, Aug. 22. -- On Thursday Gen. Torres gave the order to advance on Vicam. Three sharp engagements were fought before the troops succeeded in entering the stronghold. The Indians met the Government forces first about a half mile from Vicam and fell back.

The racing mast of the yacht Shamrock was not stepped yesterday. However, work preparatory for stepping the mast was done. Her interior was stripped and work was done on her sides. All day a gang of her sailors was busy at the topsides, working on floats. There was some scraping done, and some touching up with green paint.

LOUISVILLE. Ky., Aug. 23. -- At the first meeting of the bolting Democrats' Central Committee this afternoon at the Louisville Hotel there was a full attendance. The State Executive Committee was authorized to appoint a Campaign Committee to be composed of one man from each of the eleven Congressional Districts and five from the State at large, the appointments to be subject to revision by the State Central Committee.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, Aug. 15. -- The political situation now is not a constitutional fight for maintaining the balance of representation, but a struggle for the retention of the Constitution itself, since the report of Sir David Barbour. Imperial Commissioner to Jamaica, recommended that financial control should be taken out of the hands of the Legislature, and Joseph Chamberlain, the Colonial Secretary of State, stated in Parliament that West Indian constitutional privileges were already too extensive.

The Sub-Treasury in this city received yesterday $280,000 of the new $20 gold certificates recently printed by order of Secretary Gage. This is the first lot of these certificates that has arrived here from the Bureau of Engraving and Printing. The new notes are like the old ones of similar denomination except that they are signed by J.W. Lyons, Register of the Treasury and Ellis H. Roberts, Treasurer of the United States.

NEWPORT, Aug. 23. -- Newport had the worst sort of weather to-day, but socially there was no end of affairs to keep the cottage colony moving about quite rapidly. The chief event was the sailing party and dinner on the steam yacht Narada, given by Henry Walters. The night was anything but one fit for such an event, but the spacious accommodations on board more than made up for the inclemency of the weather.

The announcement that "war is inevitable" in South Africa is a most lame and impotent conclusion from the previous accounts. Moreover, war is not inevitable, and, if it comes, the party responsible for it before the world will be the stronger party.

PLATTSBURG, N.Y. Aug. 23. -- Attorney General Griggs made the following statement to-night regarding the case of Capt. Oberlin Carter, charged with misappropriating United States Government funds while in charge of the work of improving the harbor of Savannah, Ga.:

The United States transport McClellan, loaded with supplies for the Puerto Rican storm sufferers, left the United States Quartermaster's dock, at the foot of Pacific Street, Brooklyn, at 2:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon, carrying in her hold and on deck 1,600 tons of clothing, provisions, medicines, and building material.

LONDON, Aug. 24. -- Robert P. Porter left for the Continent to-night after a two days' stay here. He is rather fagged out after visiting the principal countries of the world, but after a short rest he will begin the preparation of his report on his mission.

READVILLE, Mass., Aug. 23. -- The Massachusetts Stake of $10,000 value, the biggest event on the card at to-day's Grand Circuit racing on the Readville track, by decision of the judges at dark, is unfinished, and three horses have an equal chance to win it to-morrow, with two heats each.
LONDON, Aug. 24. -- The Rennes correspondent of The Times says:

The Union Steel and Chain Company, which was organized some months ago under the laws of Delaware, is reaching out in every direction to control, so far as possible, the blast furnaces, Bessemer converters, ore mines, coking and steam coal mines, rolling mills, and chain and iron works of the country.

A considerable portion of Republican citizens of New York were duped two years ago by the local machine into the belief that the dignity of their party required a regular Mayoral candidate, even though the race was hopeless, and that Gen. Benjamin F. Tracy had given a magnificent example of unselfish loyalty to the party by allowing himself to be its rallying centre.

The gold standard is already established by law, and no further enactment can establish it any more thoroughly or prevent political assault upon it in 1900. Nothing is possible to Congress at the next session, so far as that matter goes, except to reenact the act of 1873, which made the "gold dollar the unit of value," and took away from silver the privilege of free coinage.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23. -- The Fifty-fifth Congress appropriated for the maintenance of the army, including all expenses except those for the construction of fortifications, about $80,000,000.

The Rev. Dr. Benjamin F. De Costa, rector of the Protestant Episcopal Church of St. John the Evangelist, will shortly terminate his connection with that charge. His resignation is already in the hands of his Wardens and Vestrymen. Dr. De Costa desired to resign over five years ago, but held his post at the unanimous request of his Vestry.

LIMA, Peru, Aug. 23. -- The transport Lima will bring the revolutionary leaders in the Southern Departments to Callao. The prisoners will be tried by court-martial. The transport Constitucion will arrive at Callao Aug. 29, bringing President-elect Romana and the Commissioners who went to fetch him. The Clerical and Civil Democratic parties are preparing to receive the new President.

When the Municipal Assembly made about the only unanimous and spontaneous grant of public money they have made for any object, in the form of a grant of $150,000 for the reception to Admiral DEWEY, a great part of the public stood aghast. We made ourselves the organ of that part of the public.

-- How many readers of this paper have seen a man extract succulent chewing gum from the alluring penny-in-the-slot machine and instantly felt that the interior of his own mouth would be evermore filled with fur unless he went and did likewise? And did the horrid suspicion ever dawn on the reader's. mind that the man was a decoy? Yet he may have been.
There does not seem now to be any doubt of the reality of M. LABORI'S convalescence. He put in evidence yesterday a very impressive testimony to his robustness of body and mind.

SEABRIGHT, N.J., Aug. 23. -- The West End Express on the New Jersey Southern Railroad, due here at 6 o'clock, ran into a carriage containing a driving party at the North Borough crossing this evening. Three of the occupants were instantly killed, and the other three more or less badly injured. The dead are:
RENNES, Aug. 23. -- Maitre Labori, leading counsel for the defense, and Mme. Labori were present in court when the trial of Dreyfus was resumed at the Lycce at 6:30 this morning.

The Committee on Plan and Scope of the Dewey Reception Committee yesterday made the final apportionment of its fund of $150,000 among the various sub-committees which have in charge the details of the celebration, and from this time on preparations for the affair will go on actively.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23. -- The State Department has been informed through a diplomatic channel that Gen. Otis has applied the Chinese exclusion laws to the Philippines. The information was a surprise to the authorities here, both State and military, as the matter has been under consideration for some time, and it was not known that Gen. Otis had put the exclusion laws into force.

CHICAGO, Aug. 23. -- Wholesale jobbers of sugar and grocery houses of the city, identified by the trade as trust and anti-trust establishments, have locked horns in a hard fight. The action of the American Sugar Refining Company in reducing the price of sugar last Monday 18 cents 100 pounds precipitated the battle here.

SANTIAGO DE CUBA, Aug. 23. -- Five men are dead and ten wounded as the result of a fight last night between gendarmes and disappointed Cuban soldiers at Cuevitas, three miles from Santiago, where the payment of the Cuban troops is progressing. Five thousand Cubans had gathered there to receive pay, and, after three days, only 580 had been paid.

PEORIA, Ill., Aug. 23. -- Gus Leimer, who works at the Peoria Arms Company, will probably not load shells for hunters after his return from Little Rock, Ark. He was called there to-day by a banker who is custodian of a fortune of about $20,000 awaiting him.

PLATTSBURG, N.Y., Aug. 23. -- Lieut. Col. William P. Duval of the Twenty-sixth Regiment, now stationed at Plattsburg Barracks, has been offered and has accepted the Colonelcy of a new colored regiment which is to be organized for service in the Philippines.

KINGSTON, N.Y. Aug. 23. -- There are from 150,000 to 200,000 acres of farm and forest lands in Ulster, Delaware, and Greene Counties under option by the Ramapo Water Company. Options have also been secured on thousands of acres of lands in Schoharie, Albany, Dutchess, Putnam, and Orange Counties.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Aug. 23. -- Three-year-old Johnny Wring was kidnapped to-day from his home, in West Philadelphia, taken to the woods near by, beaten, and choked until his life could not be saved. The woods about Forty-eighth and Walnut Streets are not dense, and residents in that section use them as a short cut between the main thoroughfare, Market Street, and the many little side roads that branch out into the country.
BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug. 23. -- The Malvern was the scene of considerable gayety to-night, the occasion being the weekly hop preceeded by several dinners given by prominent society people.

BUFFALO, Aug. 23. -- The National Association of Newsdealers held an executive session this morning, at which a representative of Typographical Union No. 6 detailed the trouble between The New York Sun and the union.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23. -- Representative Hepburn of Iowa, who last session frequently made known his dissatisfaction with some of the rules of the House, is again agitating modifications for the next Congress, and is hopeful that Speaker Henderson will lend his assistance in bringing about sundry changes which he, Hepburn, considers essential to free expression of opinion and the wider consideration of business.

HARRISBURG, Aug. 23. -- There is nothing to indicate to-night that there will be any change in the programme arranged for to-morrow's Republican State Convention by Senator Quay and his lieutenants. Even the most radical opponents of the Senator concede that he will control the convention, and that the ticket and platform will be framed in accordance with his wishes.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Aug. 23. -- A dispatch from Duluth says that the Ontario and Rainy River Railroad, the link in Canada's new transcontinental line, has just bought a large acreage of dock and water front lands at Port Arthur. It has also bought all the terminals. , of the Port Arthur, Duluth and Western Road.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Aug. 23. -- Further developments in the sale made a few days ago of the Hillman shipyard of Kensington occurred to-day. The man who arranged the deal was John Dougherty of New York, formerly Auditor at the Cramp shipyard. Mr. Dougherty is said to have represented the interests of Seligman Brothers, the New York bankers, while at Cramps.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 23. -- By the decision of Justice Joseph F. Barnard, the assessed valuation of the properties of John D. Rockefeller at Mount Pleasant has been reduced from $639,275 to $393,482.50. The decision was filed in the Westchester County Clerk's office to-day.

All of the two-year-olds that will try for the rich Futurity at Sheepshead Bay Saturday, when the Coney Island Jockey Club opens its Fall meeting, are now quartered in the vicinity of the course over which the struggle will be made. The youngsters that were trained at Saratoga have reached New York after a good rest at the spa, and are quartered at Sheepshead Bay, Gravesend, or Brighton Beach.

The session of the annual convention of the New York Grand Lodge of Odd Fellows began yesterday morning with the presentation of a fifty-year veteran's diamond to Past Grand Master George F. Gardner of Syracuse by Grand Sire Pinkerton. Mr. Gardner acknowledged the honor by an appropriate speech of thanks.

BOSTON, Aug. 23. -- Gov. Wolcott has designated Lieut. Gov. Crane, President Smith of the Senate, and Speaker Bates of the House a committee on the part of the Commonwealth to confer with Mayor Quincy, representatives of the Home Market Club, and Chamber of Commerce, and arrange for a reception to Admiral Dewey when he visits Boston.

A Washington Populist represents to a newspaper correspondent that the minds of the leaders of his party are divided about the policy of holding their convention and nominating BRYAN before the Democrats nominate him, in order, as he says, to force the hands of the Democrats.
The New York Central Railroad is to establish a model cab service. Officers of the company say that when completed the plans will provide the best service of the kind in the world.

Matters yesterday were again comparatively quiet in the social world at the Summer resorts. The city and suburbs are, of course, still socially dead. The weather is not propitious at Newport, Narragansett, and Southampton, and it seems a pity that the August moon, which ought to afford opportunity for many evening entertainments out of doors, should not bring these, owing to the clouds and mist and fog which still invest the Atlantic seaboard.

TORONTO, Ontario, Aug. 23. -- The American challenger Genesee has another victory to her credit to-day, after a sensational and exciting finish. The course was nine miles to winoward and return. The start was delayed for an hour, waiting for the wind, which had changed from northward to southwest.

CHICAGO. Aug. 23. -- In furtherance of the efforts of the Chicago Grand Army posts to have the National encampment of the Grand Army in Chicago in 1900. America Post. No. 703, has arranged to send to the annual encampment, at Philadelphia Sep 4 to 9, a committee to act with the committee regularly appointed to secure the selection of Chicago.

SAVANNAH, Ga., Aug. 23. -- Henry Delegat, a negro man, who is charged with an assault, voluntarily surrendered to the Sheriff of McIntosh County and was brought to Savannah to-night under military escort for safe keeping.

LONDON, Aug. 23. -- Sir Thomas Lipton, in an interview to-day, said: "I am just as excited as a schoolboy as the race draws near. I have read the remarks of American yachting experts, many of whom have seen the Shamrock through their telescopes. But while these good people know all about yachts, they have no data upon which to base opinions except patriotic wishes.
ST. LOUIS, Mo., Aug. 23. -- The St. Louis butchers have formed a plan to fight the "Big Five," consisting of Armour, Swift, Cudahy, Morris, and the Schwarzschild-Sulzberger house.

The statement was made yesterday from an authoritative source that negotiations are about completed for the absorption of the trolley systems controlled by the New York and Queens County and the New York and North Shore Railroads by the Brooklyn Rapid Transit Company. The negotiations for this transfer were commenced some time ago, but a defect was found, it is said, in the charters of these two companies.

RENNES, Aug. 23. -- I hear to-night that M. Godefroy Cavaignac, ex-Minister of War, is about to publish a brochure in which he will attempt to explain his attitude in the Dreyfus affair. He will analyze those telegrams the original text of which is in German, and will endeavor to prove Capt. Dreyfus's guilt thereby.

Secretary Toman of the Empire City Trotting Club has invited horsemen to visit the new track which ex-Corporation Counsel William H. Clark has built between Mount Vernon and Yonkers, next Saturday, to witness a half-mile exhibition by Nathan Straus's Cobwebs, 2:12. Mr. Straus will drive his speedy chestnut, and as the latter's speed is just on edge now, his exhibition will be a good test of the speed of the track.

Another big trust was born at the Waldorf-Astoria yesterday. It is to be known as the American Automobile Company and will control the manufacture and operation of all the automobiles and motors in which kerosene or gasoline is used, not only in this country, but in France, Germany, and other countries in Continental Europe.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Aug. 24. -- Chief Justice Chambers of Samoa is in Birmingham, where he is attending to private business matters. In an interview to-day he said he was for annexation of the islands. He declined to say to which of the three powers he wanted the islands annexed, but indicated that his American citizenship would show which he meant.

Permit me, Sir, on behalf of many taxpayers of this city, to express gladness and delight over the decision rendered by Justice McAdam that the Ahearn act is unconstitutional. From the accurate report in your paper, it plainly appears to every citizen and every taxpayer that the city parasites who have endeavored to take advantage of this act have tried their luck with several Judges of the Supreme Court.

EASTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 24. -- The two hundred and fiftieth anniversary of the day when the Puritans first established their homes here was fittingly celebrated to-day. There were over 2,000 visitors in the village, and the day was made a general holiday. The houses were handsomely decorated with flags, bunting, and bright-colored lanterns. Green stringers and wreaths were also used in profusion.
LONDON, Aug. 25. -- The Transvaal crisis continues to hold its own as a topic of the first importance. The most contradictory reports are published.

SARATOGA, N. Y., Aug. 24. -- Ex-Judge Henry Hilton of New York died at 5:30 o'clock this afternoon at his Summer home, Woodlawn Park, after a long illness. He suffered a relapse early this afternoon. At the bedside were Col. and Mrs. A. B. Hilton, Mrs. Horace Russell, his daughter, and Dr. John C. Miner, his physician. Funeral services will be held and the remains taken to Greenwood.

RENNES, Aug. 24. -- When the trial of Capt. Dreyfus was resumed at the Lycee at 6:40 A.M. to-day, Col. Jouaust, President of the court, ordered that the evidence given by M. Penot, a friend of the late Col. Sandherr, Chief of the Intelligence Department, be read by the Clerk of the court.

Justice McAdam, in the Supreme Court, yesterday ordered that a peremptory writ of mandamus issue in the suit brought by Henry W. Sherrill, James McKeen, and Willis L. Ogden against the Council to compel the authorization of $570,000 in bonds for the purchase of the plant of the Long Island Water Supply Company.

William Carr, eighteen years old, who resides at 56 Sixth Avenue, New Brighton, S.I., had an exciting experience while riding his bicycle along Richmond Terrace at 4 o'clock yesterday morning. It was just after the shower, and as the roadway was wet and muddy he turned up on the cinder path on the northerly side of the terrace at Snug Harbor Station.

CINCINNATI Ohio, Aug. 24. -- Montgomery Phister, the dramatic critic and writer, has completed a new comedy, which has been accepted by Fanny Rice, the comedienne, and which will be staged during the season.

MYSTIC, Conn., Aug. 24. -- The thirty-first annual convention of the Universal Peace Union is now in session at Peace Grove, near this village. To-day Alfred H. Love of Philadelphia was re-elected President of the union. The following resolutions were adopted at the morning session of the union:

The retail butchers of New York gave further evidence last night that their fight against the beef trust is to be vigorously waged, and that they have not been idle in perfecting the details of their plan to establish an independent packing house in this city where all the cattle used by the 35,000 butchers in this city will be slaughtered and distributed.

LONDON, Aug. 24. -- In spite of the elaborate precautions taken to guard Queen Victoria when she is abroad, none worth mentioning are taken when she is at home, and this is particularly the case when the Queen is at Windsor, Osborne, or Balmoral.

In the interview published in our London dispatches yesterday Mr. ROBERT P. PORTER intimates a "warning" to our people in regard to two matters. One is the probable exaggeration of our hopes of foreign trade; the other is the "resurrecting of the silver question."
The President would do well to look carefuly into the case of one CHARLES J. ALLISON, reported to be his nephew and a recent emigrant from Ohio to Birmingham, Ala.

BOSTON, Aug. 24. -- Chief Inspector Watts to-day received a telegram from Inspector McGarr, who is in New York, stating that he had located 20,000 pounds of coffee which had been shipped from this city two weeks ago, and which, it appears, was obtained from a warehouse on a forged order, bearing the firm name of Chase Sanborn.
NEWPORT, Aug. 24. -- To-morrow evening the much heralded ball to be given by W.K. Vanderbilt will occur at the Newport Golf Club.

-- If Sir THOMAS LIPTON does not become a favorite with the public in this country it will not be for the want of ability to say pretty things. He is now quoted as saying that he believes that the Shamrock will be as safe in the hands of the Americans as she would be in his own. To the fair spirit of our people he does no more than justice when he speaks thus.

The "affaire Dreyfus," by the way, was brought to the notice of the Attorney General in an unexpected way a few weeks ago in Washington. As he told the story here yesterday his eyes twinkled with a mixture of amusement and wrath.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24. -- Gen. Otis today cabled the War Department that Gen. Bates has returned from his conference with the Moros and confirmed previous dispatches as to the results of the mission. Gen. Otis says:

PLATTSBURG, N.Y., Aug. 24. -- News has reached here that H. Walter Webb, a brother of Dr. W. Seward Webb, is critically ill at H. McK. Twombly's camp on Upper St. Regis Lake, four miles from Paul Smith's Hotel.

LARCHMONT MANOR, Aug. 24. -- Nearly a thousand persons enjoyed "As You Like It" in the open air on the grounds of the Larchmont Yacht Club to-night The stage was a level of sward springled with leaves in an opening in a grove of oaks, elms, and hickories, which formed wings, background, and proscenium arch.

All doubt, it is believed, as to the complicity of Richard Croker and Tammany Hall generally in the plot to deliver the city over to the Ramapo Water Company was removed yesterday when Corporation Counsel Whalen, Mr. Croker's most intimate friend and political adviser, said: "This contract should not be condemned by the public until the water company's side has been heard.
John R. Davidson has sold for John Harper, for $22,500, the five-story flat 96 West One Hundred and Third Street. Mr. Harper takes in part payment a small piece of property at King's Bridge.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24. -- It took some time to-day to ascertain at the War Department that about everybody in that department was quite ignorant and apparently indifferent about the rate of expenditures by that department and the prospect that the $80,000,000 appropriated last year seems likely to be exhausted before the middle of November.

That is really an amazing dispatch which Admiral DEWEY has just sent to the Acting Mayor, and it must be more or less vaguely felt to be so by everybody who has read it. "Will arrive on Thursday, Sept. 28, as requested -- DEWEY."

BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug. 24. -- A large dinner, followed by a dance, was given at the Malvern to-night by Lewis Niles Roberts. He belongs to the younger Boston set now at Bar Harbor. The affair was a distinct success, and was undoubtedly the most elaborate private entertainment given here this season.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24. -- The State Department does not apprehend any international complications will arise out of Gen. Otis's course in excluding Chinese from the Philippines, as this is said to be only a temporary military expedient, leaving the general question to be determined by Congress.

CAPE TOWN, Aug. 24. -- The Barberton News claims to have information regarding the intention of France and Germany as to the question of interference with a view to participating in the proposed inquiry. It says the Transvaal Government entertained the demands regarding the dynamite contracts with the hope of making it an international question.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Aug. 24. -- Senator Tillman is hard at work on his fences. The annual State Convention of the Farmers' Alliance, held here on the last of July, with twenty-five members present, and five of those office holders in this city, demonstrated the extent to which that organization had petered out. Immediately after it the Senator began attending picnics, reunions, and barbecues in various parts of the State, making speeches in his old vein.

NICE, Aug. 24. -- Admiral Dewey, accompanied by Flag Lieut. Brumby and the United States Vice Consul here, this morning returned the visit made yesterday by M. Granet, Prefect of the Alpes-Maritimes. M. Granet showed the visitors through the rooms of the Prefecture, the former palace of the Kings of Piedmont.

ROME, Aug. 11. -- The Italian papers have been filled for some days past with indignant protests against certain of the alleged toasts which were reported to have been drunk at the recent banquet to Admiral Dewey and his officers at Naples, at which several Italian military, naval, and civic officials were present.

CHICAGO, Aug. 24. -- Having received consent from Chairman Jones to go ahead, Vice Chairman Stone of the National Democratic Committee will proceed within a few days with the reorganization of that body, as called for by the rules adopted at the July meeting.

TANGIER, Aug. 24. -- The Sultan of Morocco has notified the powers that he is destroying the native boats on the Riff coast and is establishing a gunboat service, in order to protect foreign shipping from piracy.

CAMDEN, N. J., Aug. 24. -- Comrade Jaxnes Rapp of Marinette, W'is., arrived here to-day to attend the Grand Army of the Republic convention, which is to be l'eld in Philadelphia. He will be tile guest of Capt. Volk of this city during the encampment.
TOLEDO, Ohio, Aug. 24. -- In speaking of his campaign, Mayor Jones said to-day:

SEATTLE, Washington, Aug. 24. -- Leon Bureau, the private secretary of Maitre Labori, the leading counsel for Dreyfus, who has been in Seattle visiting the French Vice Consul, Dr. Monoda, has left for Paris.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Aug. 24. -- Although the tremendous storms that have been raging for a fortnight throughout Chile continue, there has been some abatement. Advices from various points indicate widespread distress and misery. Valparaiso and other cities have suffered severely.

ALBANY, N.Y., Aug. 24. -- Gov. Roosevelt is determined that the court of inquiry appointed to determine the fitness of Major Clinton H. Smith of the Seventy-first Regiment shall continue with the investigation.

TORONTO, Ont., Aug. 24. -- The Genesee of Rochester won to-day's international race and the Canada Cup, and to-night American yachtsmen are in possession of the town. The cup was presented to the Chicago Yacht Club at the dance at the Royal Canadian Yacht Club's island quarters to-night.

CHICAGO, Aug. 24. -- The proposed New York formation of a combination embracing the dry goods department establishments and wholesale houses was discussed to-day by the leading representatives of large dry goods houses. Some of the proprietors of the large department stores appear to favor such an organization, while the representatives of wholesale dry goods establishments are inclined to doubt the success of the venture.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 24. -- The sporting carnival opened here this afternoon on Dr. T. Gaillord Thomas's field. The programme consisted of pony and gymkhana races. There was a large attendance. ALBANY, N.Y., Aug. 25. -- Representatives of the Mutual Reserve Fund Life Association of New York City appeared to-day before Superintendent Louis F. Payn of the State Insurance Department. Under Section 39 of the insurance law, the Superintendent is required to give the officials of a company which has been examined an opportunity to be heard before the report is accepted by him.

LONDON, Aug. 25. -- Theatrical business has fallen to almost nothing on account of the intense heat. The thermometer registered 88 degrees in the shade yesterday and again to-day, and that seems awful to Londoners. The only fortunate plays seem to be the two American exotics, "The Belle of New York" and "El Capitan," the last-named having made a tremendous hit after a dubious reception the first night.

STROUDSBURG, Penn., Aug. 25. -- Charles D. Newhart, candidate for the nomination for County Treasurer, died at his home, near Saylorsburg, on the eve of the election. The primaries will be held to-morrow.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 25. -- The cotton duck consolidation, which is one of the most important industrial combinations of the South, has been completed. The fourteen mills acquired are now in the hands of the Continental Trust Company of this city, syndicate manager, awaiting transfer to the Mount Vernon-Woodberry Cotton Duck Company, which has been incorporated under the laws of the State of Delaware.

Judge Addison Brown, in the United States District Court, has refused to grant the petition in bankruptcy of the former members of the firm of Meyers Brothers, dealers in cloaks and garments at 622 Broadway. G. H. Meyers and Amelia Meyers filed separate petitions, one on Feb. 11, the other on Feb. 27, 1899. The firm failed on Nov. 27, 1896. Attention has been called to the success obtained in cultivating the tree in the Campagna di Roma, Italy. Where, it is said, eucalyptus is now recognized as rendering the whole territory much less unhealthful.

RENNES, Aug. 27. -- The most remarkable thing to-day is the diversity of opinion in the French newspapers in regard to the Freystaetter-Mercier incident. Both sides omit important facts. The nature of the conflicting opinions of their papers shows how difficult it is for the French public to obtain a true idea of the case.

Your well-timed editorial on seaside country resorts calls my attention to another very peculiar condition, which is open to vast improvement. I refer to accommodations along the seashore (within an hour's reach) for the great majority of people in very moderate circumstances. It seems that there is a vast field for enterprising capitalists in this direction.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Aug. 27. -- A special dispatch received in this city to-day reports the mysterious disappearance of Howard Lykes, a citizen of Tampa, in Havana. He is a son of the cattle king, Dr. K.T. Lykes of South Florida, and was in Cuba attending to business for his father. It is supposed that it is a case of kidnapping.

There was a spirited race in the East River yesterday morning between the steamer Charles G. Ivins, Capt. John Malcolm Hawkins, and the steamer Lenox, Capt. Charles McLaurin. The Ivins had aboard the members of "The Man in the Moon" and "The Rounders" companies, who were on their way to Rye Beach for a clambake.

YOKOHAMA, Aug. 11. (via Victoria, B. C., Aug. 27.) -- Five thousand American troops have now come and gone, roaming through the streets of Yokohama and Tokid for an average of two days, without causing a ripple of disturbance. The American community here is small, but intensely American.

The advance of $5 per ton in the price of structural steel that was agreed on at the conference of the principal producers in this city last week seems to be entirely justified by the cost of the raw material. Both iron and fuel have increased in price beyond the ratio of increase determined on, and other iron and steel products are as a rule higher in proportion.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 27. -- The regular Sunday racing of professional and amateur cyclers on the Vailsburg board track was witnessed to-day by a crowd of 2,000 spectators. Features on the card were the Priscilla quarter-mile professional handicap, and a mile multi-cycle handicap for amateurs.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 27. -- A change is made in the dates for the exhibition of the Philadelphia Dog Show Association to Nov. 22-25, the American Pet Dog Club in turn changing the dates for its show to be held in New York City to the week following, and to include Thanksgiving Day.

SALEM, N.J., Aug. 27. -- The authorities here are struggling with what is thought to be a murder mystery. They do not know who the murdered person was or who the murderer is. They have not even an unidentified body to start with as a clue, although the detectives worked all night and to-day trying to find one.

We do not believe that the tone of Mr. JOSEPH CHAMBERLAIN'S talk on the Transvaal affair gives much satisfaction to self-respecting Englishmen.

PHILLIPSBURG, N.J., Aug. 27. -- The Morris Canal broke from its banks this morning and did great damage here. There was a violent thunderstorm at 1 o'clock, the rain falling in torrents. The canal wall on the river side was weakened by the strain and the soaking it received and gave way in three places.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27. -- Officials of the Weather Bureau are not yet able to predict the extent to which the cyclone reported south of Martinique will develop. At present the information received here indicates only a slight disturbance south of Santo Domingo. The locality affected now, however, is entirely outside of the scope of the reporting stations, and until the storm moves further north it will be impossible to determine its extent.

A trolley accident similar to the one which occurred at Bridgeport recently was averted in Brooklyn yesterday afternoon by the merest chance. A runaway car, with one wheel broken off and crowded with passengers, sped down the steep grade at Fifth Avenue and Sixty-fifth Street, jumped the rails, and came to a stop with the front end hanging over the edge of the fifty-foot cut of the Manhattan Beach Railroad at Sixty-seventh Street.

LIGHT FROM A RUSSIAN GENERAL ON THE DREYFUS CASE. -- The memoirs of the Russian General Annenkoff will be published in Berlin some time in September. It is announced by the Berlin press that the work will include certain evidence tending to prove that both Henry and Esterhazy delivered War Office documents to the agents of several foreign powers.

Because a white man in the Raines law hotel at 155 Bleecker Street indiscreetly remarked last night that "every nigger in Georgia ought to be lynched," James Wilson, thirty-eight years old, of 133 West Third Street, a colored man, then and there and with all the vigor he had, endeavored to annihilate such portion of the white race as happened to be present, ten men and two women.

President Edward Maher of the Union Railway Company, which has a monopoly of trolley lines in the Borough of the Bronx, has announced that a new line from Bedford Park to William's Bridge will be constructed during the coming month. By the 1st of October cars will be running from the Bedford Park terminal to the White Plains Road. William's Bridge, where transfers north or south will be given.

Chief of Police Murphy of Jersey City recently gave orders to the police to arrest all persons carrying bundles through the streets at night unless they gave a good account of themselves and submitted their bundles to inspection. This order made no trouble until 2 o'clock A.M. yesterday, when Patrolman Thomas Kelly saw a man with a parcel in Bergen Avenue.

LONDON, Aug. 28. -- There is little fresh news from South Africa, but it is announced that the Government of Natal has refused to allow the transit of empty cartridge cases intended for the Transvaal.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Aug. 27. -- The record of Governors furnished by the Richardson family of South Carolina far surpasses that of the Walcotts of Connecticut. The remarkable facts are recalled by the death of John Peter Richardson, the last Governor of the "old regime."

The great increase in international trade within recent months and the belief that this country has but begun the development of its foreign markets have served to call the attention of Wall Street to some certain matters which heretofore have not impressed themselves as of any peculiar significance.

WATERTOWN, Wis., Aug. 27. -- The body of John T. Flavin, Superintendent of Schools of Dodge County and President of the State Teachers' Association, was found at 10 o'clock this morning hanging from a tree on his farm in the town of Emmet. He had been absent from his home since 5:30 o'clock yesterday morning, and it is supposed that while insane he hanged himself a short time after.

SCRANTON, Penn., Aug. 27. -- President Parsons of the National Letter Carriers' Association has protested to the local carriers against their action in permitting non-union carpenters to erect the arches and columns which form the main feature of the decorations for the Letter Carriers' National Convention, to be held here next week.

O'Brien of the Granite Cutters has repeatedly complained that the plans and specifications for that building were violated by using the stone of the old building, which was of a quality inferior to the material mentioned in the specifications for the new building.

Millions have been borrowed in the last few years by Southern concerns in Baltimore, Philadelphia, New York, Boston, Chicago, the highest rate being 5 per cent.

The Speedway was the centre of attraction for lovers of horses yesterday, and from early till late there was a constant stream of vehicles flowing in and out the entrance at One Hundred and Fifty-fifth Street. It was by far the liveliest day on the road since last Spring, and there were many spirited brushes to amuse the crowds that flocked to see the sport.

PORTLAND, Oregon, Aug. 27. -- A draw poker game was played here in one of the down-town hotels Friday night by three recently arrived Alaskans -- George Munford, Harker Hamlin, and Henry Smith -- which in point of recklessness has scarcely ever been equaled. The limit was $10, and a new deck was opened each deal.

At the Church of St. John the Evangelist yesterday morning, the Rev. Dr. De Costa gave his last sermon as rector from Mark, iv., 28: "First the blade, then the ear, after that the full corn in the ear." He made no allusion to parting, as his resignation remains to be acted upon this week. His utterances, however, were regarded as significant.

Giovanni Turini, the sculptor, died suddenly yesterday morning at his home, 8 Morningside Avenue. He had not been feeling well on Saturday evening, but it was not supposed that anything serious was the matter with him. He rose at 7 o'clock yesterday morning and entered his wife's room. He had got half way across the room when he fell to the floor and died almost immediately.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Aug. 27. -- Dr. Max Thorner, a brilliant young pupil of Dr. Virchow, the Berlin laryngologist, was found dead in the bathroom in the residence of his brother, Justus Thorner, early this morning. Death was apparently due to heart disease.

DARIEN, Ga., Aug. 27. -- There have been no hostilities between the blacks and militia today, although the negroes remain armed and the troops are prepared for anything that may occur. That the situation is better, however, is evident, since Col. Lawton, commanding the First Regiment, has returned to Savannah eighty-six men and three officers, whose services are no longer needed.

Several contracts have been lost to them lately on account of the impossibility of getting material for vessels, and some owners -- among them A.B. Wolvin of this city -- have been figuring on using English steel for ships to be built during the coming Winter at lake yards.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 27. -- Two clipper ships, the Tillie E. Starbuck, built of iron, and the St. Francis, a wooden vessel, both owned in New York, left this port to-day to race to San Francisco, for stakes aggregating $10,000, put up by prominent shipping men. Their time will be counted from the moment they reach Cape Henlopen Light.

NEWPORT, Aug. 27. -- Despite the chilly atmosphere the attendance at the Casino this evening was the largest of the season. Every inch of dining space was in use, and a number of cottagers who wished to give dinner parties were forced to forego that form of entertainment for the want of space. Some of the handsomest costumes seen this season were worn to-night.

John Henry Norman, the well-known English writer on money and exchanges, has just published another work entitled "Money's Worth." Mr. Norman styles himself an "expert in the science of and practice with money." His wide reputation as an expositor of the confused monetary systems of the world has given him color of title to the claim.

PITTSBURG, Aug. 27. -- President and Mrs. McKinley spent their Sunday rather quietly. Mr. McKinley, carrying out his usual custom, arose at 7 o'clock and spent an hour in the library looking over his mail. After breakfast he took a stroll with Mrs. McKinley and Mrs. Pitcairn through the extensive grounds surrounding the Pitcairn residence, and then spent another hour in the library.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27. -- Secretary Root and Adjt. Gen. Corbin paid a flying visit to the army camp at Camp Meade, Penn., today. They left here last night at midnight and returned to the city late this afternoon. Their object was to inspect the two new regiments of volunteer infantry, the Twenty-seventh and Twenty-eighth, which have just been recruited and are now rendezvoused at that camp, preparatory to their departure for the Philippines.

FREEPORT, L.I., Aug. 27. -- Albert Golden of Greenwich Point and Furman Hicks of Hempstead hired a boat this morning from Nelson Terry of this place to go out to the beach. They were caught in a squall when near the new inlet and their boat was. capsized.

OCEAN GROVE, N.J., Aug. 27. -- To-day's services reached the climax in the series of great camp meetings that have been held here this week. At the sunrise meeting a great flag, bearing the inscription "In the beginning God," was raised in the presence of over 1,000 revivalists, who awakened the Grove with the morning hymn.

The course to be pursued by the Republicans of Kings County in the coming campaign was the subject of a long conference at the Oriental Hotel, Manhattan Beach, yesterday, between Senator Platt and Michael J. Dady, Chairman of the Brooklyn Executive Committee. In the course of this conference the Senator is said to have urged Mr. Dady to use every effort to secure the co-operation of the Citizens' Union and independent voters this Fall.

ZANESVILLE, Ohio, Aug. 27. -- Some of the workers for candidates arrived here to-day for the Democratic State Convention which meets here next Tuesday and Wednesday. The delegates meet by Congressional districts Tuesday afternoon to select members of the new State Central Committee and of other committees, including a new one on Party Reorganization.
RENNES, Aug. 27. -- This evening it is rumored that the Government has decided to arrest Gen. Mercier, but the rumor is not confirmed.

BOSTON, Aug. 28. -- The charges preferred by Jesse M. Weissman of New York against Policeman George Jordan of Division No. 4 were heard by the Police Board to-day. Jesse M. Weissman, the complainant, is a manufacturer residing at 2 East Eightieth Street, New York. He charged the officer with assaulting him in Police Station No. 4 while a prisoner on the night of July 24 last.

The indications are that there will be a lively fight between the ninety-five independent distillers of Kentucky and the Kentucky Distilleries and Warehouse Company, a branch of the Whisky Trust. The answer expected yesterday to the proposition submitted by the independents to the trust on Friday relative to the allotment of production was not received.

It is carefully stated that the scarcity is in the market, otherwise some would be inclined to laugh the story to scorn. It is quite possible that it is not easy to buy diamonds at a reasonable figure just at present.

" For the good of the service," as he explains it Chief of Police Devery yesterday shifted eight Police Captains, and reduced six ward detectives to patrol duty. The Chief yesterday declined to go into any explanation of the matter, and used the stereotyped phrase by which he explains all of his orders.

CHICAGO, Aug. 28. -- Twelve steel arches, each weighing thirty-three tons, which were to have supported the superstructure of the Coliseum Building, in course of erection on Wabash Avenue, between Fifteenth and Sixteenth Streets, fell to the ground late this afternoon. It is known that nine lives were crushed out.

NEWPORT, Aug. 28. -- The wedding of Miss Julia Dent Grant, daughter of Gen. and Mrs. Frederick Grant, to Prince Michael Cantacuzene of Russia, was announced this evening to occur at All Saints' Memorial Chapel, at noon on Monday, Sept. 25. The ceremony will be anything but a large affair, which is the wish of the bride and groom, as well as of their relatives.

PORTLAND, Me., Aug. 28. -- The comedy "In Paradise" was presented here to-night for the first time on any stage in America at the Jefferson Theatre. Both play and company made a decided hit. The piece is full of lively action.

The last week of August opens with a sense of change in the social atmosphere which well accords with the suggestion of Autumn that yesterday's cool winds brought. The week will be one of preparation for flittings from seashore to mountains, and from mountains to seashore, while the clubs and country houses in the suburbs are being swept and garnished and put in order for the near and expected home-coming of members, owners, and guests.

PITTSBURG, Aug. 28. -- With cannon booming, bells clanging, whistles shrieking, flags waving, and mighty cheers from thousands of threats, the brave Tenth Pennsylvania Volunteers were welcomed home to-day after more than a year's gallant service in the Philippines. The reception tendered the returning soldiers will always be remembered in this city as one of the greatest demonstration of patriotism that has ever taken place in this country.

SPARKILL, N.Y., Aug. 28. -- A stubborn fire, springing up suddenly at 1 o'clock this morning in one of the outer buildings of the St. Agnes Convent and Orphanage, and sweeping with incomparable speed through nine of the ten buildings of the institution, scattered terror among more than four hundred inmates, caused the death of four persons, injured seven seriously, twenty-five slightly, and completely wrecked the entire property.
RENNES, Aug. 28. -- The balance of the evidence to-day, for a change, was in favor of Dreyfus. Five witnesses were for him, and two against him.

HULL, England, Aug. 28. -- Walter Wellman, the leader of the Wellman Polar expedition, who returned to Tromsoe, Norway, Aug. 17, after having successfully completed explorations in Franz Josef Land, arrived here to-day. He walks with the aid of crutches, as his right leg is still useless.

NEWPORT, Aug. 28. -- This morning the Columbia and Defender got under way from their moorings and with a strong northeast wind stood out toward Point Judith. For a time the two boats kept well together, but later they parted company, as the Columbia, with Nat Herreshoff on board, was out for a special purpose, that of testing her angle of heel.

President Holahan of the Board of Public Improvements complained yesterday of the treatment accorded to his board by the newspapers, and said that no arguments had been advanced which would tend to convince him that the Ramapo contract was not the best thing for the city. "I have been right all the time." Mr. Holahan said, exultingly, "and I'm right now.
NEWPORT, Aug. 28. -- To-morrow the annual tournament of the Newport Golf Club begins, and will continue until Sept. 2.

SARATOGA, Aug. 28. -- The midsummer meeting of the New York State Chess Association was opened here this morning at the United States Hotel, the tournament for the Association Challenge Cup being the feature of the day. Two entries were made for this tournament. Lipschuetz played for Manhattan and Marshall for Brooklyn.

One of the most puzzling incidents in the general puzzle of French affairs at this moment is that of M. GUERIN and his little "garrison" in the building of the Anti-Juif. The Government -- centralized, powerful, and really military as it is -- hesitates to enforce the warrants of its courts, and keeps the streets in the neighborhood of his refuge barricaded by large bodies of troops for week after week.

The Shamrock advanced a stage further yesterday in her rig, and consequently in improved appearance. Her topmast, which had been housed after being sent aloft on Saturday, was stepped, her jibtopsail stay was set, her shrouds and stays were tautened, her bobstay and bowsprit stays and spreaders were set up, and, of not the least importance, work was completed on the repainting of her sides.

ALBANY, N.Y., Aug. 28. -- Several weeks ago, before the inauguration of the great fight progressing between the citizens of New York and the Ramapo Water Company, three maps of waterways in the southern end of Albany County were filed by the officials of the company.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 28. -- In the United States Circuit Court to-day, Judge Thayer granted a temporary injunction to restrain the Missouri Pacific Railway, the Chicago, Rock Island and Pacific Railroad, and the St. Louis, Keokuk and Northwestern Railroad from boycotting the Pittsburg and Gulf Railroad because of its cut freight tariffs from New York to Kansas City.

Wayne MacVeagh, counsel for Capt. Oberlin M. NEWPORT, Aug. 28. -- Reginald Brooks and James Thompson, the latter a brother of William Payne Thompson, were about the cottage colony to-day saying good-bye to their friends, and to-morrow will be off for New York, en route to Wyoming for a stay of two months for the purpose of hunting big game about Woods Hole.

HAVANA, Aug. 25. -- Since the beginning of the year there have been many changes in the political conditions in Cuba, and during the last two months the general opinion, which was formerly in favor of immediate independence, has been considerably modified. Some of the most enthusiastic independentists now urge a continuance of the American occupation for at least a year or two longer.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Aug. 28. -- The Socialist Labor Party of Union County is the first in the field with a full set of nominees for the county offices. The nominations are as follows: For Senator -- Charles Burns of Plainfield; Assemblymen -- John Miles of Plainfield and Michael McGarry of Elizabeth; Sheriff -- Alwin Koerner of Elizabeth; County Clerk -- Frank Kullen of Plainfield; Coroner -- Charles R. Wallender of Plainfield.

CAPE TOWN, Aug. 28. -- Replying to the latest propositions of the British Secretary of State of the Colonies. Mr. Joseph Chamberlain, the Government of the Transvaal has notified him that it adheres to its latest offer, and will not make any further concessions.

PARIS, Aug. 28. -- The Cabinet has almost determined to summon the Senate to sit as a High Court for the trial of M. Paul Deroulde, member of the Chamber of Deputies, and President of the League of Patriots, and the other prisoners arrested on the charge of conspiring against the Government.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 28. -- The National Manufacturers' Association has purchased in Shanghai, China, a building containing 40,000 square feet of floor space, and as soon as practicable a permanent exhibition will be established there. One hundred firms have asked for space, and all but two have signed contracts.

BUFFALO, Aug. 28. -- Judges, statesmen, and lawyers of National prominence, composing the American Bar Association, met in the Aldermanic chamber of the Common Council of Buffalo at 10:30 this morning and were welcomed to the city by Sherman S. Rogers of the local Bar Association and by Walter S. Logan of the State Bar Association.

MONTREAL, Aug. 28. -- The Rev. P.G.J. Meiring, pastor of the Dutch Reformed Church of Johannesburg, is in Montreal on his way to Washington as the representative of the Presbyterian Church of South Africa at the Pan-Presbyterian Congress which meets in the American capital early in September.

Mary W. Earle, fifty-five years old, a servant in the employ of J.M. Hannan of 4,187 Park Avenue, attempted to end her life yesterday morning by inhaling gas in the house of her employer. She is now in the Fordham Hospital, where it is said that the chances are against her recovery.

Our troops in the Philippines, the Eighth Army Corps, will read with keen pleasure the words in their praise uttered by their Commander in Chief, the President of the United States, in his brief address at Pittsburg. Next to his own sense of duty well done, the soldier's highest reward is the commendation of his commander.

EAST LIVERPOOL, Ohio, Aug. 29. -- President McKinley and his party arrived from Pittsburg at 11 o'clock last night. Fully 5,000 persons greeted Mr. McKinley at the station. The President and wife were driven to the home of Col. John Taylor through streets ablaze with electric illuminations and fireworks.
