The three-act farce produced by Mr. Charles Frohman in the newest of his New York playhouses last night, had received so much valuable advertising from the army of returning tourists who had seen it in dear Paris, that its first performance was bound to be a notable "event," the first of the new season.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29. -- The Treasury to-day received $3,210,000 from the sale of the old Custom House site in New York City. The receipt of this money makes a material change in the Treasury statement. It brings the receipts of the day up to $4,579,396, and as the expenditures were $532,000, gives a surplus of $4,047,396.

It is very fortunate for Capt. O.M. CARTER, now or lately of the Corps of Engineers of the United States Army, that WAYNE MACVEAGH is his counsel. Because this counsel is as well known for his character as for his ability. "Legal ethics" are often puzzling to laymen, who cannot make out how far they authorize a lawyer to go in pursuance of his retainer.

BANGOR, Me., Aug. 29. -- The Maine Fish and Game Commissioners have granted during the past month about 200 special licenses to guides and visitors from out the State to hunt and kill deer, moose, , during the month of September. This action is a new departure in Maine, for heretofore no one had been allowed to kill big game until the law was off, the 1st of October.

BUFFALO, Aug. 29. -- When the American Bar Association resumed its session this morning it was apparent that the number of delegates had very greatly increased. The Aldermanic Chamber was filled. Among those present were many of the most famous lawyers of the country. A number of new members were elected at the morning session, one of whom is John G. Milburn, President of the Pan-American Exposition Company.

Wall Street worried yesterday over Great Britain's Transvaal embarrassment. Having abandoned their worries over the destruction of crops, (still undestroyed,) having ceased from troubling over money market corners, (still uncornered,) there was forlorn vigor in yesterday's distress over the awful predicaments which England is marching into in the land of the Boers.

Railroad men from all parts of the country gathered at the Metropolitan Street Railway Company's car barns, at One Hundred and Forty-sixth Street and Lenox Avenue, yesterday, to witness the tests of brakes told of in THE TIMES yesterday.

The Greater New York Retail Butchers' Association, composed for the most part of butchers doing business on the west side of town, held a special meeting at 915 Eighth Avenue last night to receive the reports of the Executive Committee relative to the plan for establishing in this city an independent packing house with which to fight the Chicago Beef Trust.

Fired by the prowess of the sculptors in offering an arch to DEWEY and the city, and authorized thereto by a special request on the part of the Committee on Land Parade, the mural painters have sprung to the rescue of the managers of the festival with a plan to decorate the section of Fifth Avenue between Thirty-fourth Street and the arch.
LONDON, Aug. 30. -- The Pretoria correspondent of The Daily Chronicle, telegraphing Tuesday, says:

Samuel Howe of this city, who arrived from England on Saturday, accomplished while he was in London a feat that can be regarded as little short of astonishing. He is the first American, indeed, the first art critic of any nationality who has succeeded in causing the modification of an important public work in London after it had been partially carried out.

RICHMOND, Va., Aug. 29. -- In view of the fact that the Legislature which is to be elected this Fall will have to enlarge the revenues, to meet the increased interest on Virginia's debt, the State Auditor's report this year is of unusual interest. It was this debt which caused the political revolution which is a short time turned the Democracy out of power.

The managers for Sir Thomas Lipton of the yacht Shamrock showed how well they are obeying the injunction to observe strict secrecy when they had the Shamrock towed out of Erie Basin early yesterday afternoon down to an anchorage off Tompkinsville. This move was entirely unexpected by outsiders, and many who went to the Erie Basin to inspect the yacht during the afternoon were dumfounded on reaching there to find no Shamrock.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 29. -- The mid-Summer meeting of the New York State Chess Association was continued at the United States Hotel to-day with the second game of the series of five for the Association Cup tournament between Lipschuetz of Manhattan and Marshall of Brooklyn. After an interesting contest Lipschuetz won, and the score now stands 2 to 0 in Lipschuetz's favor.

There was quality as well as quantity in the day's programme at Sheepshead Bay yesterday, and both of these have been sadly lacking on the Eastern race tracks recently, but they failed to call out the large attendance it was reasonable to suppose they would. Patrons of the sport could not grumble at the splendid programme held out, but there were more vacant chairs in the grand stand than even on Monday.

Benjamin H. Hill of Georgia is at the Waldorf-Astoria. Mr. Hill came to New York as attorney in winding up the sale of the extensive mining properties of the Augusta Mining and Investment Company in Virginia, Georgia, and Alabama. This company failed several years ago, and the properties were sold to ex-President Joseph W. Reinhart of the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railroad.

HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 29. -- The racing at Charter Oak Park to-day was marked by close finishes and tile winning of the favorites. Owyhee took the 2:19 trot without difficulty, and Lady of the Manor won out in the 2:07 pace, Geers driving a sensational finish in the third heat, passing Nicol B. and Prince Albert within ten feet of the wire.
M. L. Hess have sold for Thomas McKeone to Josef Steiner for about $185,000 the eight-story business building recently completed at 16 East Seventeenth Street, on a lot 25 by 92.

BOSTON, Aug. 29. -- David Barrie, the American representative of Sir Thomas Lipton, owner of the Shamrock, was in this city to-day, accompanied by Capt. Matthews of the steam yacht Erin, to inspect the steamer Plymouth, which has been secured as a tender for the Shamrock. To-day's visit was for the purpose of making a critical examination of the craft, and Mr. Barrie made notes of improvements which will be made.

Justice Bookstaver, in the Supreme Court, yesterday signed a restraining order forbidding the Board of Public Improvements from acting upon the Ramapo water contract until a hearing can be had on a motion for a permanent injunction. In addition to the members of the board, the City of New York and the Ramapo Water Company are made defendants to the action.

According to a report of the operations of the Law Department for the week ending June 22, which was published in The City Record yesterday, there were 212 suits brought by taxpayers during that week against the Commissioners of Taxes and Assessments to compel the reviewing of the assessments placed on real estate and personal property.

Richard Croker, disappointed the district leaders of Tammany Hall and several hundred of their followers by failing to appear at the meetings of the Executive and General Committees, held last evening at the Fourteenth Street Wigwam. Not only was Mr. Croker not there, but those of his intimates who were professed dense ignorance as to his whereabouts.

STOCKBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 29.--The Stockbridge Golf Club commenced its annual tournament to-day with twenty-nine contestants, who played the preliminary rounds to qualify for the Stockbridge Cup, which is now held by T. Markoe Robertson of the Shinnecock Club. The weather was perfect, and a large number of people, who are staying in Lenox and Stockbridge, came to witness the sport.

SARANAC LAKE, Aug. 29. -- After an exciting chase extending over two days through dense forests and wildernesses, the man who assaulted and robbed Miss Isabelle Guerber of Philadelphia has beer caught.

HAVANA, Aug. 29. -- The threatened strike of bakers here has been settled. The men according to the terms of the agreement, are to receive an increase of $7.50 per month. Both sides promise to abide by the decision of the arbitrator.

DUBUQUE, Iowa, Aug. 29. -- Idolita, owned by Frank Jones of Portsmouth, N.H., pulled down the winner's share of the rich Horse Review Stake for three-year-old trotters to-day. The little bay walked away from the field in each of the three heats and won hands down. The purse was worth $20,000, and was the third of a series of Futurity offerings put up by John C. Bauer of Chicago.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29. -- Attorney General Griggs is expected to return to Washington to-morrow, but it is possible that he may not reach here until next Monday. No one here knows when the Attorney General will make his report on the Carter court-martial case to the President, although there are persistent intimations that it will be made soon.

LONDON, Aug. 30.--The Times, referring this morning editorially to the statement of William P. Schreiner, the Premier of Cape Colony, that in the event of war he would do his best to keep the colony aloof from the struggle, says:

DARIEN, Ga., Aug. 29. -- Four troops of cavalry have been ordered to relieve the infantry on duty here since last Thursday. The cavalry will be under command of Col. Lawton of the First Georgia Regiment, and will remain as long as it is deemed necessary to keep troops for the preservation of order.

LONDON, Aug. 29. -- American securities fluctuated somewhat after a steady opening, and then declined with the rest of the market. The weakness was due to the Transvaal situation. The closing was dull, with sellers predominating.

NEWPORT, Aug. 29. -- The open tournament of the Newport Golf Club began today. In the preliminary round for the two cups of thirty-six holes, medal play, nearly eighty players participated, many of whom gained National reputation in the game. The play was very keen, and it took 183 to qualify for the President's Cup, while the highest score for the Consolation Cup was 191.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., Aug. 29. -- Mrs. Celestina Kuder, a member of the Arion Singing Society of New York, died suddenly to-day on the Arion's special train east-bound from Denver.

RENNES, Aug. 29. -- The absolute insignificance of ex-Minister de Freycinet's evidence was the most surprising feature of the session of the court-martial to-day. The "Little White Mouse" looked whiter than ever, but diplomacy showed no signs of falling off with age.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 29. -- Capt. Richard P. Leary, United State Navy, a native of Baltimore, has arrived at Guam, Ladrone Islands, and has established the sovereignty of the United States. A letter received here incloses a copy of the first proclamation of Capt. Leafy, as Governor of the island, to the natives. It is in part as follows:
HORNELLSVILLE, N.Y., Aug. 30. -- Gov. Roosevelt made an important speech, in which he referred to the canal question in explicit terms, here to-day.

CAPE TOWN, Aug. 30. -- There was a violent scene in the Cape House of Assembly to-day when Mr. Cecil Rhodes repeated his conviction that the Transvaal secret service fund was largely used during the last Cape Colony elections for the expenses of the Afrikander candidates. He said he hoped that in the forthcoming Transvaal settlement the secret service payment list would be destroyed, as otherwise many Cape families would feel uncomfortable.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Aug. 30. -- Thirty-five hundred persons witnessed the ceremonies at the reinterment of John Brown's followers in the little graveyard at the John Brown Farm at North Elba, about two miles from here, this afternoon. The date is the forty-third anniversary of the battle of Ossawatomie.

TURNER, Me., Aug. 30. -- Rear Admiral Bradford, Chief of the United States Navy Bureau of Equipment, is visiting his old home here for a few days. He was to-day asked how much longer he thought the war in the Philippines would last. His reply showed his complete confidence in the ability of the United States to fight the thing through to a successful issue.

HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 30. -- The big event of the Grand Circuit meeting at Charter Oak Park to-day was the first two-minute pace ever scheduled. There were five starters, John R. Gentry drawing out after a contest in which there was a dispute between the park management and the owner. The trouble arose over a misunderstanding as to whether the event was a two heats in three or a three in five.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30. -- The Insular Commission, consisting of Gen. Kennedy, Judge Curtis, and Major Watkins, which has given six months' study to the conditions of the Island of Puerto Rico, to-day made its report to Secretary Root. It recommends a form of civil government of the islands to take the place of the present military regime, and submits for adoption a code of laws.

Mrs. A.E. Koefoed, widow of Albert Koefoed, who was five years ago a broker in this city, has disappeared from the home of her stepfather, Charles G. Wilson, at 156 West Eighty-seventh Street. Dr. Wilson formerly was President of the Board of Health. He is now President of the Consolidated Stock and Petroleum Exchange.
ALBANY, Aug. 30. -- Owing to previous engagements Gov. Roosevelt has had to decline the invitation to head the delegation that will meet Sir Thomas Lipton, the owner of the Shamrock.

The first public speed trial on the new trotting track of the Empire City Trotting Club, at Mount Vernon, took place yesterday before a small gathering of horsemen. Nathan Straus drove him gelding, Cobwebs, a half mile over the new track in 1:05. Mr. Straus's gelding holds the Speedway championship.

RENNES, Aug. 30. -- When the trial of Capt. Dreyfus was resumed at the Lycee this morning, M. Paul Meyer, member of the Institute and Director of the School of Ancient Manuscripts, was the first witness called. He deposed in favor of Dreyfus.

LONDON, Aug. 30. -- At the second day of the Derby September meeting to-day the race for the Loudoun Selling Plate of 106 sovereigns, for two-year-olds, the winner to be sold by auction for 50 sovereigns, was won by La Mascotte. Mr. H. Barnato's chestnut colt Swears, ridden by Tod Sloan, was second. Fourteen horses started; distance five furlongs, straight.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30. -- There are pending in the United States Court of Claims, to be taken up and disposed of at such time as may be decided to be appropriate by the authorities, suits against the United States to recover about $450,000, alleged to be due the Atlantic Contracting Company. These suits grow out of the celebrated Carter case.

NEWPORT, Aug. 30. -- The perfect weather to-day brought the golf tournament on the Newport links an immense gathering, and the list of ladies who followed the players or who sipped tea in the clubhouse embraced the entire cottage colony.

" Abe" Coakley, one of the best-known crooks in the country, came nearly meeting early yesterday morning the fate that usually comes to those of his class, and is now lying in Bellevue with a four-inch stab wound in the left breast that came close to touching the heart and ending his career.

A "number of prominent persons," according to the reports in yesterday's papers, attended the lecture of the previous evening at Asbury Park upon "Uncle Sam and the Czar." The lecturer was Mr. O.G.J. STADT, former tutor to the present Czar of Russia.
ARLINGTON, N.J., Aug. 30. -- "Put up your red flag, boys; look out for the train behind you!"

CHICAGO, Aug. 30. -- The Chronicle to-day says that harmony in the ranks of the Democracy will supply the leading theme of a series of speeches to be delivered in New York and other cities in the East by ex-Gov. John P. Altgeld during the next two weeks. Mr. Altgeld will leave Chicago on his Eastern trip to-morrow or Friday.
CANTON, Ohio, Aug. 30. -- For the first time in nearly a year President and Mrs. McKinley are among their relatives, neighbors, and friends in Canton for a few days of rest.

McLean for Governor as a joke, but there are some Republicans here from that State who consider it a very serious proposition to meet. One of them, a very warm friend of the President, said to-day that it would not do to belittle the candidacy of McLean.

It is a clear and strong, except for the tautology at the beginning we should say an unexceptionable, statement of the principle upon which the Ramapo job, and any other similar job that may hereafter be produced, should and will be defeated.

PONCE, Puerto Rico, Aug. 24. -- The furious storm during the day of Tuesday, Aug. 8, and the exceedingly heavy rains which accompanied and followed the wind, were the most destructive combination of elements that have visited this island since Aug. 22, 1772.

Foley Sniffin have sold for the Peyton estate to John E. Thrall the northeast corner of Washington and West Eleventh Streets, a plot 125 by 75, on which the buyer will erect an eleven-story fire-proof warehouse.

Announcement was made at the close of business yesterday of the formation of the Bankers' Trust Company and the acceptance of its Presidency by George William Ely. Secretary of the New York Stock Exchange. This severs Mr. Ely's official relations with the Stock Exchange when he enters on his duties as head of the trust company.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 30. -- A combination car on the Willson Avenue Line was blown up by a powerful explosive between Scovill and Quincy Streets to-night at 9:30. There were six passengers on board, five of whom sustained broken legs. The other passenger and the crew of the car escaped without injury.
LONDON, Aug. 31. -- The Pretoria correspondent of The Morning Post says:

PEKING, Aug. 30. -- Mr. Joseph Walton, Liberal, Member of Parliament for the Barnsley Division of the West Riding of Yorkshire, has had audiences with Li Hung Chang and Prince Ching. He urged them to settle promptly the differences of China with other nations and to employ English, American, and Japanese officers in the immediate reorganization of the Chinese army and navy as the only hope of averting the partition of the Chinese Empire.

HAVANA, Aug. 30. -- Gov. Gen. Brooke does not know that Jimenes, the aspirant to the Santo Domingo Presidency, has been arrested at Santiago de Cuba, as reported.

Carl E. Miller, alias J.A. Ludwig, was arrested yesterday in the office of Clausen Price's Brewery, and is held at the East Fifty-first Street Police Station on a charge of fraudulently collecting money to buy the Betsy Ross Home, in Philadelphia. He had already secured several hundred dollars, it is said, from prominent local brewers.

RENNES, Aug. 30. -- The air of Rennes this evening is filled with rumors of conspiracies and predictions of coups de theatre, but nothing precise can be ascertained.

It is better to discuss trusts than to rail at them, and the conference that has been called by the Civic Federation of Chicago for that purpose bids fair to be very useful. The Governors of twenty-one States have named delegates, including a number of the Attorneys General as well as numerous men of high standing as economists and some business men.

Those who have claimed for Sadducee all through the racing season that he was the best two-year-old of the year, simply because he had run through an unbroken string of victories, had their claims somewhat damaged yesterday, for Sadducee was called upon then to meet some of the really good two-year-olds of the year, with the result that he was a badly beaten gelding at the end.
LONDON, Aug. 31. -- The Times, in an editorial this morning on "The American Imperialist Policy," says:

At the close of a stormy meeting, in which the proposed contract between the city and the Ramapo Water Company was discussed at great length, the Board of Public Improvements yesterday placed itself on record as against the private control of the city's water supply and committed itself to the acquisition by the city of whatever additional watersheds may be necessary.

LONDON, Aug. 30. -- Mrs. Jones and George Stephenson, who are said to have eloped from Wilkesbarre, Penn., taking with them money belonging to the woman's husband, have been remanded at Bow Street until next Tuesday. The United States Embassy is asking for their extradition.

BUFFALO, Aug. 30. -- The American Bar Association to-day adopted a resolution expressing sympathy with M. Labori in his suffering and his struggle for justice in the Dreyfus case. It met with much opposition, some believing it might work evil to Dreyfus. It was finally carried by a vote of 130 to 69.
WINNEMUCCA, Nev., Aug. 30. -- William J. Bryan passed through Winnemucca to-day on his way to California, and delivered an address to a large crowd. He said in part:

BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug. 31. -- Mrs. Percy Madeira of Philadelphia won the Draper Cup to-day by defeating Miss McLane in the finals of the Ladies' Handicap Golf Tournament, 6 up and 5 to play.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31. -- Notwithstanding the fact that many persons underwent examinations here in the hope of receiving appointments to the Census Office force, only to be informed that they could not be named unless they were on the quota of some member of Congress, examinations continue to be held, some having recently taken place in Boston under conditions similar to those that prevailed in this city.

BUFFALO, Aug. 31. -- The eighteenth annual conference of the International Law Association opened this morning with scarcely a score of delegates present, although many members are in the city. In the audience were the wives and daughters of a number of the British lawyers.

Secretary of War Root spent yesterday at Sandy Hook as a spectator at a proving ground meeting of the Board of Ordnance and Fortifications. All of the members of the board were present, including Gen Miles, its President; Gen Royal T. Frank, Congressman J.H. Outhwaite, Capt. J.E. Kuhn of the Engineer Corps, Capt. C.B. Wheeler, and the recorder of the Board, Capt. S.M. Lewis of the Ordnance Department.

ATLANTA, Ga., Aug. 31. -- The Jewish Sentiment, in its regular weekly edition tomorrow afternoon, will print a story bearing on the Dreyfus trial. For the first time, it is believed, the mode of carrying the documents from the French War Office to the German Government is given.

The Department of Bridges has finally decided that the projected bicycle path over the Brooklyn Bridge is not feasible, and that therefore it will not be built. This decision was arrived at after C.C. Martin, Chief Engineer of the Brooklyn Bridge, had made a supplemental report, following a conference with the committee of members of bicycle organizations who favored the plan.

The conference of the Independent Labor Party was held last evening in Clarendon Hall. The work of admitting reform and political bodies to membership was begun. Among these were the West Side Social Democratic Party, Branch No. 20 of the Social Democracy, and the Social Democratic Associations of the Fourth, Fifth, Eighth, and Twenty-fourth Assembly Districts; the Americus Latin Club, and the Progress Club of Harlem.

CHICAGO, Aug. 31. -- Too ill to continue his journey to Washington without a day's rest, Dr. Edward Bedloe, United States Consul at Canton, China, halted in Chicago and while here took occasion to deny the report that he is under suspension and to discuss the charges that have been filed against him with the State Department.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31. -- Frank A. Vanderlip, Chairman of the Dewey Home Fund, and Ellis H. Roberts, Treasurer, to-day issued the following statement to the public regarding the fund:

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 31. -- The project of certain capitalists to organize a United States and China trading company to control the bulk of the trade of China has excited much comment among the commercial people of this city, some of whom give the scheme, formulated by the Chinese Consul General, their unqualified approval.

The market is narrow; traders talk of uncertainties over the coming holiday; important interests seeking the market's improvement seem content to await new co-operation. All this tends to keep things in a rut; and, though business developments of consequence are crowding, slow progress is made toward that cheerful market situation so much prophesied, so long looked for.

PRETORIA, Aug. 31. -- The entire correspondence between the Imperial and Transvaal Governments was read in open session of the Volksraad to-day, and President Kruger asked the Raad to meet secretly to-night for the purpose of considering a reply.

LONDON, Aug. 31. -- Mrs. Langtry made her reappearance on the stage to-night at the Haymarket Theatre in Sydney Grundy's new play "The Degenerates." The title of the play thoroughly illustrates its character.

The pea-green Shamrock did not go out for a sail-stretching trial yesterday, in spite of the many announcements that she would. She lay at her anchorage off Tompkinsville, as pretty a picture as ever pleased a sailor's eye. Steamboats laden with light-minded excursionists passed close to her, and their bands played "God Save the Queen," "Rory O'Moore," and "Wearin' o' the Green," according to the taste or fancy of the bandmasters.

HELENA, Mon., Aug. 31. -- There is considerable excitement in Maryville, this county, over a rich strike that has been made. A lead of very rich ore has been struck almost at the grass roots. The Troufer brothers, who have been prospecting on a claim on the east side of Drummond Hill, in Six Mile Gulf, struck rock at a depth of only 14 feet that assays as high as $135 a ton in gold.

In view of the fact that Gen. Daniel Butterfield is gaining strength so rapidly that he may be expected to resume his duties as Chairman of the Dewey Executive Committee any day. Acting Mayor Guggenheimer has called a meeting of the Committee on Plan and Scope for next Wednesday, at which time several new propositions relating to the celebration will be discussed.
PLAINFIELD, N.J., Aug. 31. -- An attempted murder and suicide occurred at 6:30 this morning at 24 Clinton Avenue, the home of John Kuckle, alias John Smith.

" The Colonial Dames of America" have failed in their application to Justice Bookstaver of the Supreme Court in suits brought against "the Colonial Dames of the State of New York" and the unincorporated association calling itself "the National Society of the Colonial Dames of America," Justine Van Rensselear Townsend as President, for an injunction to restrain the defendants in each case from continuing to use the names severally adopted by them.

The search for Mrs. A.E. Koefoed, who disappeared from her home ten days ago under circumstances which her friends think point to the conclusion that she may be under the influence of designing persons, has brought to light certain facts which lead her stepfather, Charles G. Wilson, President of the Consolidated Stock and Petroleum Exchange, to believe that her discovery may be made within a few days.

RENNES, Aug. 31. -- Dreyfus had the most trying day he has gone through. The strain proved too great for him, and for the second time in the course of the trial he gave way to his feelings and sought relief in tears.

RENNES, Aug. 31. -- Capt. Dreyfus again changed his attitude to-day, probably through the recollection of the scene of the degradation being recalled. Capt. Lebrun-Renault's evidence stirred a deep emotion in the prisoner. He became hysterical when he tried to explain the unreasonableness of his sandwiching in a confession between two protestations of innocence.
LITTLE VALLEY, N.Y., Aug. 31. -- To-day was a record-breaker in the way of crowds in this village. Thousands came to the fair to hear Gov. Roosevelt, who was billed to deliver an address.

HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 31. -- The feature of the day at Charter Oak Park was Star Pointer's great mile, which was in 2 minutes fiat, without slip or break, beating the track record made by the same horse last season -- 2:00 1/2. Dave McClary drove Pointer, and he was aided by two running horses, one going to the half and both coming down the stretch either side of the pacer.

GENEVA, N.Y., Aug. 31. -- Ira L. Peck, the convert to the Christian Catholic faith, whose statements concerning the efficacy of divine healing have caused much comment in this part of the State, is dead.

Backers of favorites have had a hard row to hoe since the Sheepshead Bay meeting opened last Saturday, and if the favorites do not do better before the meeting closes, the members of "the talent" will have light bankrolls with which to start at the Gravesend meeting. Only in one instance yesterday did a favorite land the money, and when the sixth race was over, there was weeping and gnashing of teeth among the speculators.

DREYFUS is reported to have owned his debt to his wife will move even more hearts than have been touched by the tragedy of wrong and suffering in which he has borne the most conspicuous role. The most conspicuous, but one hardly more heroic than that he now ascribes to the patient, brave, undespairing woman to whom he owes more than life.
SANTO DOMINGO, Aug. 31. -- President Figuereo has resigned.

NEWPORT, Aug. 31. -- Golf again drew the cottagers in large numbers to the grounds of the Newport Golf Club. To-morrow evening the cottage colony will be busy socially, as there are several large dinners on, the largest to be given by Mrs. Ogden Mills, while there will be an impromptu dinner dance and other affairs.

STOCKBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 31. -- There was a good attendance on the golf links to-day, and the weather continued favorable for tournament play. The event was the contest for the loving cup offered by the President of the club, Dr. Charles McBurney. There were fifteen entries, but six withdrew in the morning, including McBurney and Robertson, who are in the semifinals.

SANTIAGO, Cuba, Aug. 31. -- Gen. Juan Isidro Jimenes, the revolutionary aspirant to the Presidency of Santo Domingo, will leave Santiago to-morrow, on a specially chartered steamer, the Georges Croise, Gen. Leonard Wood, the Military Governor, having received instructions from Gov. Gen. Brooke to release him from custody, unless there are indications that he is promoting a filibustering expedition.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Aug. 31. -- Last Monday the Gubernatorial nominee William Goebel attacked ex-Congressman W.C. Owens in a bitter speech at Bowling Green, saying that the reason he was opposing his election was because he, Goebel, had caused to be passed a law making gambling a felony, thereby interfering with the regular business of Owens.

SARATOGA, Aug. 31. -- Play in the tournaments of the New York State Chess Association at the United States Hotel made good progress to-day, two of the class divisions in the general tournament finishing their games. A. McMartin of Johnstown won first prize in the second class with 4 1/2 to 1 1/2.

DULUTH, Minn., Aug. 31. -- There is to be a new ore road in St. Louis County. The Carnegie interests, through men connected with the Oliver Mining Company, filed articles of incorporation to-day. It will be known as the Virginia and Ely Railroad Company. The corporation begins Jan. 1, 1900, and is to last for fifty years.

PITTSBURG, Aug. 31. -- It looked like New York's game when in the first inning six hits scored five runs. In the fourth Pittsburg, with five hits, equaled this, and had the game well in hand after that. Six double plays were made, each team completing three. Attendance, 1,500. Score:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31. -- The Secretary of the Navy has directed that all estimates for the requirements of the naval service next year shall be submitted by to-morrow, Sept. 1, thus giving him three months for co-ordinating them for submission to Congress. All the estimates, with the exception of those relating to armor and ordnance, will be in hand to-morrow.

Controller COLER has done a sound and sagacious thing in following up his triumph over the Ramapo job with the announcement that plans for increasing the water supply from the city's own works will be at once taken up. The Ramapo scheme is virtually dead, but there is a lingering chance that it may be revived.

PITTSBURG, Aug. 31. -- A meeting of window glass manufacturers of this country is in session here for the purpose of discussing the wage question and the general situation. All the factories in the American Glass Company and a majority of the independent factories are represented.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31. -- The annual report of H. Clay Evans, Commissioner of Pensions, shows that during the year there were added to the pension roll 40,991 names and 43,186 were dropped, 34,345 of these by reason of death.

Undoubtedly Gov. ROOSEVELT'S reputation for entire temperance in the use of "alcoholic beverages" is well established and justified, and, considering the excesses to which his fervid imagination and pugnacious disposition drove him at Hornellsville on Wednesday, it is appalling to think what he might say under the influence of "the bottle."
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 31. -- The William Cramp Sons Shipbuilding and Engine Company to-day announced that the works will be closed from Sept. 1 to Sept. 11.

The Clevelands suffered their one hundredth defeat yesterday, being easily beaten by the Brooklyns at Washington Park. The game was one of the series transferred from Cleveland, but only a small crowd came to the park. The Clevelands played splendidly for about four innings, but the pace they set was too fast, and in the last four innings it was simply a practice game for the Brooklyns.

Twelve thousand people enjoyed the free excursion to Union Grove, Carteret, N.J., given to the women and children of the west side by the Tammany organization of the Seventh Assembly District yesterday. The crowd was conveyed to the grove on the steamer Bay Queen and the barges Susquehanna, Sands, Spear, and Columbia.

NEWPORT, Aug. 31. -- The best race of the week was sailed by the thirty-footers this afternoon over the Dyer's Island course, with the wind strong from the southwest. The fleet raced for a sweepstakes, and started at 3:07 o'clock. The summary:

RENNES, Aug. 31. -- The session of the court-martial of Capt. Dreyfus opened behind closed doors in the Lycee to-day and lasted until 9:15 A.M. Majors Hartmann and Ducros and Gen. Deloye, all of the artillery, were present. The court discussed the secret documents relating to the artillery subjects of the bordereau.

PUERTO PLATA, Aug. 31. -- President Figuereo yielded his executive authority to his Council of Ministers at 12 M. to-day. Official notice of the change in administration has been received from the capital by Gen. Imbert, who is the Provisional Governor of this city by direction of the Revolutionary Committee.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 31. -- A large audience greeted the Rogers Brothers in the new vaudeville farce by John J. McNally, which was presented for the first time in the Hyperion Theatre to-night. The new piece is entitled "The Rogers Brothers in Wall Street," and was received with every demonstration of success.

Prof. MUNSTERBURG of Harvard, who occupies the chair of psychology vacated by Prof. WILLIAM JAMES, has touched on many of the reasons for a certain strain in the relations between Germany and the United States. His able article will be found in the September Atlantic Monthly.
NEWPORT, Sept. 1. -- Many of the yacht owners will entertain guests on board the yachts to-morrow during the yacht races.

Your Mr. W.L. Alden is undoubtedly a thing of beauty, or he could not be a joy to your readers during their forever. The merry gentleman has it in your SATURDAY REVIEW this week that, he flatters himself, and Mr. Kipling, he thinks he thinks, "Kipling is the greatest master of prose and verse that the Anglo-Saxon race has yet produced."

" Cynic" need not have any fear that "The Awkward Age" will be read by those interested in "the degenerates," for they will look for something more crisp than this "lovely frost picture piece," so called by another critic.

PARIS, Sept. 1. -- Cardinal Richard, Archbishop of Paris, paid a visit to-day to Premier Waldeck Rousseau on behalf of M. Jules Guerin, the anti-Semite agitator, and his companions now besieged in the headquarters of the Anti-Semite League, on the Rue de Chabrol, and urged a peaceful solution of the difficulty.

In spite of the indiscreet talk of a good many British newspapers, the conviction is making its way in Great Britain that the conquest of the Transvaal is a very serious undertaking. A British invader would have to keep open a line of supplies of a good many hundred miles through a population a large part of which is not friendly.

In your issue of last week it was stated that the McKee and the Daly libraries were not to be sold at present, and that "while this is a good deal of a disappointment to many young collectors who desire to secure some of the many books in the two libraries, it is good news to the older possessors of libraries formed on similar lines.

In THE SATURDAY REVIEW of Aug. 19 -- sent to me by a friend -- the old story of "Columbia, the Gem of the Ocean," comes up again in a new form, wherein Mr. Henry Russel is credited with being the composer.

Publishers of the United States should no longer pride themselves on producing a fair number of books -- for apparently they do not. That is what Mr. Ronald Smith declares, for if his statement be correct, the United States turns out less books, or say rather titles, than does Italy. Think of that now! But where does the proud Britisher stand? The United Kingdom is fourth on the list, and Italy leads it.

Some weeks ago, in THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW, attention was called to the immense and at present almost unrecognized possibilities of colored tiles for exterior decoration. It seems that while architects in this country have not as yet realized what a perfect material lies ready to their hands for the purpose of relieving and decorating blank surfaces, those in London have recently been making extensive use of ceramics.

PARIS, Sept. 1. -- The Matin to-day publishes details of the investigation into the conduct of Capt. Voulet and Capt. Chanoine, charged with barbarous cruelties to the natives in the French Soudan, which led to the sending of an expedition under Lieut. Col. Klobb after them.

There is a quaint New England and Middle States phrase which describes better than any more literary locution the condition to which the persecutors of DREYFUS, the military hierarchy of France, have been reduced. The prosecution is "runnin' empt'in's."

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Sept. 1. -- The fifth annual tennis tournament for the Ruggles Cup commenced here on the Meadow Club's courts to-day. The semi-final round will be played during the morning concert to-morrow, which will be the last of the season. The finals will take place on Labor Day.

The Brooklyns easily defeated the Clevelands in two games at Washington Park yesterday afternoon, thus increasing their lead for first place. About 3,000 persons turned out for the two games for one admission, but, except for seven innings in the first game, did not see much that was interesting in the baseball line.

This is one of the most delightful stories of the year, and well merits the exquisite introduction given it by Harriet Prescott Spofford, in which she characterizes the work as a "sweet, strong, fine story, set in the scene of the coast of Maine, with its added wealth of humanity, of love, and sorrow and joy."

Fire Commissioner Scannell announced yesterday the dismissal of twenty-one temporary appointees, under the provisions of the White civil service law, which went into effect Aug. 10. Since their appointment, shortly after Commissioner Scannell took up the reins of office, in January, 1898, they have been drawing salaries at the rate of from $1,000 to $2,500 a year. Among those dismissed are nine Assistant Fire Marshals, distributed among all the boroughs of Greater New York.

Dr. Garnett, in his annual report of the British Museum, states that in the department of printed books there has been an accession of some 114,050. Among the rarities the most notable acquisitions have been the purchase of three Caxtons. With "The Doctrinal of Sapience," bought in 1897 at the first Ashburnham sale, during the last two years the library has obtained more Caxtons than from 1851 to 1896.
ST. PAUL, Minn., Sept. 1. -- To-day James N. Hill, eldest son of President James J. Hill, became Third Vice President of the Great Northern Railroad Company, a position newly created.

PRETORIA, Sept. 1. -- The Volksraad has deferred the discussion of the correspondence exchanged between the imperial and Transvaal Governments until Monday, when a motion regarding the presence of British troops on the Transvaal border will be debated secretly.

SING SING, Sept. 1. -- A stage containing a dozen small children was dashed down a twenty-four-foot embankment at this place to-day, and some were painfully hurt, while all received cuts and bruises. Dr. Barnum dressed their wounds, and all left for their homes in New York shortly after the accident.

Not know "W.G."? Then you never heard of bat or ball or wicket. Why "W.G." stands for W.G. Grace, the greatest, the most accomplished, the Ajax and the Nestor combined of cricketers, and the strongest batter in the world, and he has in a volume, with the title "W.G.'s Cricketing Reminiscences and Personal Recollections," told in a sprightly and entertaining manner about the finest of games and the one especially adapted to Englishmen and Americans.

Major George R. Dyer was unanimously elected Colonel of the Twelfth Regiment last night, to succeed Col. Robert W. Leonard, appointed Lieutenant Colonel of the Twenty-eighth Volunteer Infantry. It was expected that the friends of Lieut. Col. Charles J. Seiter would put him in the field, but the Lieutenant Colonel declined to run.

There is a pretty little story behind the announcement, made a few days ago, that the late David Barnett, the Brooklyn lawyer, had bequeathed to Deputy Bridge Commissioner Beam a crayon entitled "The Lion." Mr. Beam told the story yesterday.

LONDON, Sept. 1. -- "The Degenerates" is dubbed unsatisfactory by nearly all the London newspaper critics, and the author of the new play, Sydney Grundy, is blamed not only for the total lack of originality the piece betrays, but for its insufficient motive. For no obvious reason the play shows only the baser side of human nature.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Sept. 1.--Another riot broke out at 9:30 o'clock to-night on Central Avenue, near Giddings Avenue. A small torpedo exploded under the wheels of a Central Avenue car and a large crowd of foreign workingmen assembled. They soon began to throw stones at the passing cars and at a patrolman, who ordered them to disperse.

One of the favorite gibes of the Tammany office jobber or office seeker these later days against the merit system of appointments is the declaration that it is "Chinese." If they knew more about the affairs of China they would see that their epithet is a misfit. The fundamental principle of the Chinese service is precisely that which Tammany lives to apply.

When the Stewards at Sheepshead Bay make up their minds to mete out a little punishment to the jockeys, as those at Saratoga did, Jockey McCue, who rode, among other horses yesterday, K.C.B., the favorite in the second race, will probably be one of the first to come in for some attention.

The hall of Cooper Union was well filled last evening with laboring men, who had assembled to ratify the platform of the new Independent Labor Party. There were a great many Socialists and Social Democrats present, as was evident from the cheers for those parties, and two of the speakers, John Chace, the Social Democratic Mayor of Haverhill, Mass., and Joseph Barondess, announced themselves as social Democrats.

In his most recent work, "The Six Systems of Indian Philosophy," Prof. Muller has given us an account of the chief orthodov systems of philosophy in ancient India. The names of these six systems are Vedanta, Purva-Mimamsa, Samkhya, Yoga, Nyaya, and Vaiseshika. In his interesting introductory chapters the author gives us his ideas as to what the intellectual condition of India must have been in the periods antecedent to all records.

Melville White, six years old, of 503 West Fifty-seventh Street, was run over by a Tenth Avenue horse car at Fifty-sixth Street last night and his right leg was so mangled that it had to be amputated when the boy was taken to Roosevelt Hospital. The boy died soon after the operation.

The "anti-imperialists" will make as much as they can of the views of Admiral DEWEY as reported by the correspondent of The London Daily News. And, with all due allowance for probable error in such a report, these views are interesting and, so far as they go, important. But in the direction of pointing the way to any policy different from that so far pursued by the President they do not go very far.

A word with the dear "would-be Cynic." By addressing you I do not only intend to break a lance for Mr. James's latest novel, which I do not find half as good as "Millie W. Carpenter," but at least sixty-six shades whiter than you want to color it. The letter you wrote to our SATURDAY REVIEW interests me mainly as an individual problema.

CANTON, Ohio, Sept. 1. -- To an accompaniment of enthusiastic cheers from the large crowd that thronged the station platforms, the special train bearing President and Mrs. McKinley steamed out of Canton at 9 o'clock to-night. The President from the rear platform bowed his acknowledgments for the kindly demonstration.

Indications, vague ones, having to do with infringement of copyright are fairly discernible in Starparola. Possibly no one has had the patience to trace them to their source. Herr Pumpenschwengel, in his "Verveilfaltingungsrecht," treats the subject, as is his wont, in the manner of a pavers-rammer and crushes the life out of what seems to be a dainty story.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 1. -- Gov. Roosevelt and party arrived here at 8:35 this morning on their special car. A drizzling rain was falling when the train pulled into the station, but the inclemency of the weather did not prevent a large and enthusiastic crowd from assembling at the station to greet the Governor.

Although recently issued and already suppressed in London in consequence of a copyright suit brought by The London Times, this volume of Lord Rosebery's "Appreciations and Addresses" has gone into a second edition in America. The fact that the book was published without Lord Rosebery's sanction, the matter being appropriated from the reports of the various speeches as they appeared from time to time, adds new interest to the book, apart from its literary value.
HAVANA, Sept. 1. -- The United States transport Ingalls, formerly the Clearwater, will be converted into a gunboat for work against the pirates along the south coast and also to prevent smuggling.

Will THE SATURDAY REVIEW kindly permit me to say a few words in reply to Mr. Goddard in last week's issue, that my critique on "The Message to Garcia" was "picking to pieces that delightful little tract" -- a sermon teaching loyal and unflinching devotion to duty. This is, of course, sound and approved doctrine.

The brig Fredericka Schepp came into port yesterday, towed by the tug Ivanhoe, after an exciting two weeks' experience. The brig presented a peculiar sight as she came up the bay, her hulk standing out of the water, and with no sign of mast or sail, both having been carried away in the hurricane of Aug. 17.

LONDON, Sept. 1. -- This evening the Secretary of State for the Colonies, Mr. Joseph Chamberlain, issued the text of the Transvaal dispatches of Aug. 19 and 21, and of the reply of the Imperial Government on Aug. 28. The publication is accompanied by a note emphasizing the advisability of making the correct versions known, owing to the fact that an incorrect version has been published in Pretoria.

Mrs. Annie Howells Frechette, the youngest sister of William Dean Howells, who will always be remembered as a writer of charming stories and other good magazine work, is at the old home of the family for the Summer, in Jefferson, Ashtabula County, Ohio. Her own home is at Ottawa, Canada, where Mr. Frechette resides officially as the French translator of the Dominion Parliament.

" Deficient Saints," a unique title, fits admirably this interesting story. We all, perhaps, are familiar with one or more of that peculiar type of people who pose as good, extraordinarily good, and who, when remodeled by circumstances, became the genuine, noble Christian character admired by all.

There is infinite pathos in the contemplation of Mr. Ruskin's home life in the seclusion of his beloved Brantwood. The master, as so many still love to think of him, is failing fast. He has passed his eightieth birthday, and the weaknesses incidental to such an advanced age have taken possession of mind and body. He is now practically confined to the house, save for occasional airings in a bathchair on sunny mornings.

In last week's edition of THE TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW your correspondent, S.B.H., asks "why I should congratulate myself on having secured Ruskin's 'Mornings in Florence' for 10 cents," of which book he disposes with the title of "insufferably snobbish." All the spare leisure and energy that one could command or extort from a business life would be needed to traverse, ponder, and explore the various fields of Ruskin's activity.

Commander Jefferson F. Moser of the United States Navy, in his "The Salmon and Salmon Fisheries of Alaska" makes a lengthened report of the operations of the United States Fish Commission steamer Albatross for the year ended June 30, 1898, in Northern waters. The instructions given Commander Moser were to visit Alaska for the purpose of investigating the salmon and halibut fisheries.

In The Nineteenth Century for the month of August, there is an article by the Hon. Frederick Leveson-Gower certain to attract much attention, the title of which is, "Did Byron Write 'Werner'?" The startling announcement is made that Lord Byron did not write "Werner." but that its author was the Duchess of Devonshire, the grandmother of the Hon. Frederick Leveson-Gower.

Three complete sets of the Kelmscott books having been sold at Sotheby's during the current year, at prices which were a surprise even to those who had long appreciated their artistic and financial value -- this appreciation in price having increased very rapidly since William Morris died -- the facts afford very striking examples of the triumph of handwork over ordinary methods.

LONDON, Sept. 1. -- Adams, the agent here of William Waldorf Astor, confirms the report from New York saying that the real estate of Mr. Astor is to be sold. He adds that the sale of the Astor estate in America will take place at an early date, "but by private treaty." Adams declined to say whether the sale would be to a syndicate, neither would he give any details, adding:

NEW ORLEANS, La., Sept. 1. -- President Bush of the Crescent City Jockey Club has announced that the club will inaugurate steeplechasing as a feature of the Winter meeting in New Orleans. The management is now building and will have completed before the opening of the meeting a first-class steeplechase course and one or two races for this class of horses will be given each week, weather permitting.

There seems to be only one letter extant addressed to Shakespeare, and the topic of the epistle is by no means a singular one, though written some 301 years ago. Richard Quiney addressed the letter to Shakespeare Oct. 25, 1598, asking for the loan of some few pounds. The place where the epistle was penned was the Old Bell Tavern, in Carter Lane, St. Paul's.

The recent death of Mr. Babcock, an artist from Boston, is announced. Mr. Babcock went abroad some forty years ago, and it is believed, never returned to this country. With the Hunt Brothers, he was among the first to appreciate Millet, and with Millet he maintained the closest intimacy. He lived almost the life of a peasant, and in a cottage at Barbizon was Millet's near neighbor.

-- An English interviewer quotes our great Admiral as prefacing a confident assertion that the Filipinos have all the qualifications for immediate self-government by the statement: "I know them intimately." Admitting the accuracy of the interview, and, of course, disclaiming any intention to treat lightly the words of a man like Admiral DEWEY, we are tempted to express a little surprise that he should have made a claim so broad as this one.
Your issue of Aug 19 publishes a letter from Mr. Canfield, the new Librarian of Columbia University, on the agricultural colleges, and on that of Ohio in particular.

Pretty generally an intelligent world is down not on France in general, but on a vast number of individual Gauls, who by heredity seem to have taken on at the close of this century the ways, habits, and vices of their heathen and uncivilized ancestors. But you may not decry French pluck. It is continually cropping out.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1. -- The opening of the markets of China is revealing every day the great possibilities of the trade of that vast empire. Consul Johnson, in a report issued here by the Bureau of Foreign Commerce, Department of State, says there is a promising field in China for the sale of American fruits.

The will of Henry Hilton, which is in the handwriting of the ex-Judge, was filed for probate in the Surrogate's office yesterday. A statement which accompanied the will said the entire estate amounted to $6,000,000, $5,000,000 of which was in real estate and $1,000,000 in personal property. There was no charitable bequest whatever.

Mrs. T.E.S., Box 196, Hempstead, N.Y.: "I have complete sets of Harper's Magazine from 1868 to 1871, inclusive; also eight numbers of 1867, in good order, which I would like to dispose of. A reasonable offer will be accepted.

The Bishop of Ripon a few weeks ago unveiled a window which had been placed in Haslemere Parish Church as a memorial to the late Lord Tennyson, who lived for many years in the neighborhood. The subject of the window, which has been adapted from a design by the late Sir E. Burne-Jones, is "The Attainment," and represents Sir Galahad at the little chapel where the vision of the Holy Grail first comes to him.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Sept. 1. -- A boiler explosion at the Republic Iron Works shortly before daylight to-day killed five men and seriously injured seven others. A fire which broke out following the explosion added to the horror. The mill was partly wrecked and the entire plant was compelled to close down.

News recently reached London of the death on July 12, of Swami Bhaskarananda, near Benares, Hindustan. Swami was probably the most famous of the Indian yogis of this century. Various reports were current around Benares as to what was his station in life before he donned the yellow robe, the staff, and gourd of asceticism.
Reorders who make replies to these appeals should address their communications to those who make the appeals, and not to the editor.
Our thanks are due to a gentleman who occupies the leading position in New York art for having given us some interesting details concerning Rosa Bonheur as recently imparted to him by Mr. Gambard.

The choice for occupants of prominent New York pulpits is narrowing down, so that there is reason to believe that some selections will be made this Fall. In the Fifth Avenue Baptist Church, Forty-sixth Street, just west of Fifth Avenue, the pulpit of which was made vacant by the election of the Rev. W.H.P. Faunce to the Presidency of Brown University, three men are under consideration by the officers of the church.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Sept. 1. -- New York won the match with Pennsylvania to-day at the meeting of the New York State Chess Association by the score of 26 1/2 to 22 1/2 in forty-nine games played in the seven rounds. Lipschuetz of Manhattan wins the prize of $35 for the best individual score.

Everybody knows and appreciates the profound learning of Prof. J.P. Mahaffy, but as much as anything else, our respect comes from the sensible manner in which he has imparted information. His method is the furthest removed from the dry-as-dust and cobwebbed ways of the scholars of the last century.
RENNES, Sept. 1. -- The most important news of the day has just transpired. M. Cavaignac returned to Rennes this evening, bringing the points of Du Paty de Clam's deposition before Capt. Tavernier.

The laying of the foundations of a material temple and the upbuilding of the superstructure are two very different things. The one is a comparatively simple operation, and is quickly performed, although everything depends upon it. The other is a matter of engineering skill, careful elaboration, patient industry, and much time. It is that, moreover, upon which all eyes are fastened, while the foundation attracts but very little attention.

MANILA, Sept. 1. -- Of the troops about to return to the United States the Kansas men will leave on board the transport Tartar, the Washington regiment on board the Pennsylvania, and the Nevada cavalry on the Ohio. All these departures will occur within the next week. Eight hundred men of the Kansas regiment will return and 200 will remain at Manila, 150 of them re-enlisting.

On the Fourth of July last, the one hundred and twenty-third anniversary of American independence, at the International Conference, assembled at The Hague, the United States Commission, in pursuance of instructions received by the American Secretary of State, laid a wreath upon the tomb of Hugo Grotius, in the Niewe Kirk, in the City of Delft.
SANTO DOMINGO, Sept. 1. -- The revolutionists have formed the following Provisional Government:

LONDON, Sept. 1. -- Elkin Matthews will shortly publish a series of letters by Charles Lamb and William Hazlitt which have been for fifty years in the possession of Mr. Yates, a friend of Hazlitt's son. A number of Hazlitt's letters tell about school life. Lamb's letters are addressed to friends and are chatty. None of them has been printed before.
PORT AU PRINCE, Haiti, Sept. 1. -- The revolutionary forces of Santo Domingo occupy Puerto Plata and Santiago. A Provisional Government has been established at Santiago.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Sept. 1. -- William A. Neal is the first South Carolina State official to be indicted for embezzlement or the wrongful use of public funds. The evidence of thievery in the days of the carpet bagger is contained in the "fraud reports," but the guilty ones were not prosecuted, the Hampton administration deciding to put that brand upon them and let them go.

The departures yesterday evening and this morning of quite a little army of men for the various resorts promise a very gay holiday. The weather is most propitious. At many of the watering places there are special attractions. At Southampton there was the dance at the Meadow Club and the tennis tournament, and at Seabright there was the first of a series of similar affairs.

Your most interesting budget of "Stray Topics" in the last SATURDAY REVIEW reminds me that George R. Sims for fifteen years offered contributions to numberless newspapers, magazines, and periodicals, which were all politely declined, though many of them have since been published with success in the "Dagonet Ballads," , and he never in all those years asked for remuneration; there was a clique in those days that would not use his work as a gift.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 1. -- To-night was one of the gayest nights of the season. The surprise party tendered Mrs. Stuyvesant Fish kept the Summer colony on the move during the evening, while golf had the call during the afternoon. Some few weeks ago a surprise party in honor of Mrs. Fish was talked of, then arrangements were begun.

BOSTON, Aug. 31. -- The "Hiawatha Primer" is to be issued in German, a clever teacher having discovered by experiment that it is well adapted to the needs of children beginning to study the language. It will be printed in German type and in vertical German script. As a pedagogic measure the plan of instructing the children of German parents in American legends seems very wise.
A new volume, similar in design and execution, but not rivaling, the stories of Maclaren and Barrie, comes from the pen of Le Roy Hooker.

NEWPORT, Sept. 1. -- All preparations for the formal trial races between the Columbia and the Defender are completed, and the first race will be sailed to-morrow. These races are for the purpose of enabling the America's Cup Committee to make its official selection of the yacht which will meet the Shamrock in October.

With much pleasure we read the editorial article in last week's SATURDAY REVIEW headed "Rewards Not Pecuniary." Its few simple references to facts not generally known affected us as would a sudden disclosure of the personalia of the editor's sanctum. We heartily agree with the dictum of your remarks touching on the possible benefits of good literature above and beyond that of mere amusement.

Mrs. Sherwood's article in the last SATURDAY REVIEW has a double interest to an old New Yorker, in view of her reminiscences and literary experiences. Mrs. Sherwood always writes well, and her wide acquaintance with men of note, both here and in Europe, and her sprightly style in giving the benefit of the same to your readers is doubly pleasing.

At last the French are to have a complete translation of "The Arabian Nights' Entertainment." Dr. J.C. Mardrus has performed the feat, giving a literal and unexpurgated rendering of the authentic Arabic texts. Brentano's are the first in this country to receive an installment of "Le Livre des Mille Nuits et un Nuit," which in its entirety will include fifteen volumes of about 600 pages each.
CHICAGO, Sept. 1. -- "Capt. Dreyfus will again be convicted of treason to France," said Dr. Emil G. Hirsch, rabbi of Sinai Congregation, upon his return to Chicago from Europe to-day.

ALBANY, Sept. 1. -- The tabulated report of the State Board of Health of the mortality in New York State for July, just published, shows that of the total of the 11,291 deaths the maritime district furnished 7,324, and of that number Greater New York's deaths were 6,808. Manhattan is credited with 3,571, Bronx 397, Brooklyn 2,381, Queens 285, and Richmond 164.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1. -- The North Atlantic Squadron sailed to-day from Newport for Philadelphia, where the ships will be one of the features of the Grand Army demonstration. Owing to the deep draught of the battleships they probably will remain well down the bay.

There is a little lady up town in New York who is working her way to fame and fortune by illustrating "coon" songs. It may not be what is known as high art, but it requires a large amount of skill to do it satisfactorily. It is a business in which there is not much competition, and it is profitable.

LONDON, Sept. 2. -- Few here believe that the Shamrock will bring back the America's Cup, but many hope that she will do so. Her victory would give an immense impetus to yacht building here, as at least half a dozen yachtsmen would give orders for defenders.

The Stewards of The Jockey Club have at list meted out punishment to Jockey Patrick A. McCue. They met yesterday afternoon and decided to suspend him indefinitely after listening to a report from the Stewards of the Coney Island Jockey Club and of the Saratoga Racing Association.

STUART ROBSON hitherto has been so closely associated in the public mind with purely comic roles that his assumption in "The Gadfly" of a character of strongly tragic import will be an extraordinary event in theatricals. Most habitual readers of fiction have read Mrs. Voynich's novel and account it a powerful work.

LONDON, Sept. 2. -- The Americans connected with the unclaimed money investigations have made no fresh move. They still hope to get their money out of G.W. Thatcher, and are preventing any criminal actions being taken against him. Thatcher has given Deputy Sheriff Fachter what purports to be a genuine demand on an attorney in Stuttgart to hand over certain moneys said to be in the attorney's hands.

The complete revolution effected in the architecture of high buildings in large cities during the last dozen years has recently been emphasized by the action of the Society of Architectural Iron Manufacturers of New York in placing a tablet on the Tower Building at 50 Broadway.

The two celestial events looked forward to each successive year, in the month when the sunbeam's crimson glare seems a little shaded with a tinge of gray, are the harvest moon and the autumnal equinox, both of which will take place this September as usual. The sun enters the sign of Libra on the astronomical 22d day of the month, so that on that day Autumn begins.

The commission that has been in session at Buffalo studying the question of uniformity in State laws received from its committee a report on the basis of divorce to be recommended to the various States for embodiment in a uniform State law. The committee was not ready to report finally, but submitted a summary of the causes for absolute divorce on which it would frame a law for consideration next year.

The last contingent of theatrical celebrities due to arrive in this country before Maurice Grau and his operatic stars make their annual visit to America arrived in this city yesterday morning as passengers on the American liner St. Paul. Among them was Manager George W. Lederer of the New York Theatre, the Casino, and the Shaftesbury Theatre of London.

GIBRALTAR, Sept. 2. -- Active preparations are being made here for the arrival of Admiral Dewey on board the Olympia. The cruiser is due at Gibraltar on Monday. It is expected that she will remain here a week.

The Liberal organs are almost as pugnacious as the Conservative. The Radicals, on the other hand, assert that President Kruger's latest offer is quite equal to Milner's "irreducible minimum," if not more generous.

ROSELLE, N.J., Sept. 2. -- During a fierce race riot last night between Italians and negroes an Italian named Pasipale Viciatte of New Orange was murdered by a negro named Ben White. White crushed his skull with a heavy stone, and then escaped.

Those who follow military rifle shooting are greatly interested in the eighth annual meeting of the New Jersey State Rifle Association and National Rifle Association, which begins at Sea Girt, N.J., to-morrow and continues until Saturday next. Although New York will not be represented by a rifle team this year, many of its crack shots will be present to compete in the individual matches.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Sept. 2. -- The British steamer Woodruff, Capt. Milbrun, arrived from Hamburg to-day. On Aug. 31, 250 miles south of Charleston, the Woodruff picked up Maurice Anderson and Goodman Thomasen, survivors of the Norwegian bark Drot, wrecked Aug. 15 off the Florida coast. The Drot was bound from Pascagoula to Buenos Ayres.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Sept. 2. -- Congressman W.B. Shattuc, who returned to Edward Atkinson of Boston some anti-expansion literature and indorsed thereon, "I am no traitor to my country," has received another letter from Mr. Atkinson, boasting of the receipt of "many letters of sympathy and approval, with a large demand for the pamphlets which you do not desire to have sent to you."

MANILA. Sept. 2. -- Argo Gula, the most impregnable stronghold of the bandits which have been destroying plantations and levying tribute on the people of Negros was taken Tuesday by the Sixth Infantry under Lieut. Col. Byrne. The only means of reaching the town was up a perpendicular hill, covered with dense shrubbery and a thousand feet high.
RENNES, Sept. 2. -- There was a large attendance of Generals at the Lycee this morning at the opening of the session of the court-martial of Capt. Dreyfus.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Sept. 2. -- John Pollock was shot and killed, William Thayer was seriously wounded, and about eight men were hurt in a fight between the strikers at the collieries, in West Pittston, and a repair gang to-day.
Fire Chief Edward Croker suffered a fall after a fire in the tobacco factory of Bernard Stahl Co., at Seventy-fourth Street and First Avenue, yesterday, and was seriously bruised.

The tendency will be, as it has been before, to extensive nervous excitement, the reckless and dangerous flight of those who are exposed to communities unprepared to guard against infection, and a spreading of the dreaded disease.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Sept. 2. -- Another week and Bar Harbor will be dead. The past week, however, has been quite lively, the life of the season being sustained by the tennis tournament at Bogue Chitto, the Canoe Club races, ladies' golf tournament, and quite a few small dinners and receptions.

ST. PETERSBURG, Aug. 8. -- "No one is more useful to the cause of the Karageorgevitch than ex-King Milan himself," said Prince Karageorgevitch when interviewed the other day in Geneva on the subject of the present crisis in Servia. There is little doubt that Milan is the worst enemy of the Obrenovitch dynasty, and that the course he is pursuing means the ruin not only of the dynasty, but of Servia as well.
Michael Roderick, forty-nine years old, a painter of 377 Fourth Street, was taken to Bellevue Hospital last night with a fractured left leg.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Sept. 2. -- Charles H. Bishop, agent here for the Pillsbury Flour Company of Minneapolis, Minn., filed nineteen separate suits in the United States court against as many grocers in Cincinnati this morning to enjoin them from selling an inferior grade of flour and representing it as "Pillsbury's Best." A temporary restraining order is asked for.

CHICAGO, Sept. 2. -- Walter F. Koeller, a young man who was graduated from Dixon College last June, was murdered as he lay upon a sick bed at the house of his brother to-night by two unknown men, who appeared to be farmers, or at least from the country. They made their escape and the whole police force is looking for them. Every railway station is watched.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 2. -- Gov. Stone to-day called a meeting of the sub-committees of the Democratic National Committee for Sept. 17 and 18, at the Auditorium Hotel at Chicago. The committees in question are the Executive, composed of eleven members; the Ways and Means, composed of seven members, and the Press Committee, composed of five members. So far as party work is concerned, this will be the most important meeting of the year.

NEWPORT, R.I. Sept. 2. -- The first of the trial races between the Columbia and the Defender, to select the defender of the America's Cup for 1899, was sailed off this port to-day. The former won a handsome victory, and, in addition to new honors looking toward the great international contest, won a cup given by W. Gould Brokaw, owner of the schooner Amorita.

Among the arrivals on the St. Paul yesterday was Gen. Charles H. Grosvenor of Athens, Ohio, who is generally regarded as President McKinley's personal representative on the floor of the lower house of Congress.

BERLIN, Sept. 2. -- The general opinion expressed here is that war between Great Britain and the Transvaal is almost unavoidable. Many articles from the pens of well-known writers have appeared this week to that effect. There is no doubt that the Government, if not exactly friendly to Great Britain in this quarrel, has resolved to abstain frown active interference.

WAUKESHA, Wis., Sept. 2. -- Mr. and Airs, John Miles, who have been spending the Summer with Mrs. Miles's parents, will leave soon for Toronto, where Mr. Miles will enter McMasters's Theological School to fit himself for the Baptist ministry.

BELLMORE, L.I., Sept. 2. -- The members of the Presbyterian Church in this place are divided in their opinion of the value of the methods of their pastor, the Rev. C.L. Clist. About six weeks ago the pastor came from the town of Lawrence with a proposition to open the church for evening services and to accept as compensation the proceeds of the regular collection.

The affairs of the Walter A. Wood Mowing and Reaping Machine Company, one of the largest corporations of its kind in the world, are about to be investigated by Deputy Attorney General Parsons, as the result of an action to this end brought by Ernest T. Fellowes, as attorney for Gen. Eliphalet Wood and Mrs. Seraphina C.W. Pattison, the widow of Rear Admiral Pattison, who are stockholders in the concern.

NEWPORT, Sept. 2. -- On the various yachts which followed the race between the Columbia and the Defender there were many guests being entertained on board, while several picnics were given on the island during the afternoon. The chief entertainers afloat were Mr. and Mrs. John R. Drexel, Henry Walters, Mr. and Mrs. Pembroke Jones, W.K. Vanderbilt, Commodore J.P. Morgan, Eugene Higgins, Mr. and Mrs. Royal Phelps Carroll, and several others.

All the indications are that the Retail Butchers' Association will fail to do any business with George B. Loving, and consequently will have to purchase, as here o-fore, from the Meat Trust unless some other organization springs into existence.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 2. -- Fear that Attorney General Crow would institute proceedings against the Union Casualty Company under the anti-trust laws of Missouri is the ascribed cause of the deal between the Union and Maryland Casualty Companies.

HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 2. -- Secretary Thrasher of the Law and Order League superintended a raid on the bookmakers at Charter Oak Park to-day. The races had been declared off on account of the rain and no business was done, but six men were arrested on the charge of poolselling. The accused are George Hill, S. Conrad, Frank Herdic, Samuel A. Stout, Samuel S. Glasson, and William Riley.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2. -- Prof. J.G. Schurman, President of the Philippine Commission, arrived here late this afternoon from Ithaca, N.Y. To-night he had a conference lasting several hours with President McKinley at the White House. Secretary of State Hay was present during a part of the conference.

LONDON, Sept. 2. -- The prevalence of the plague in Portugal has put the authorities here on the qui rive. The quarantine in 1892 against the cholera, when it raged in Hamburg, did not prevent its entrance into England or the United States, and, taking a lesson from this, the authorities no longer favor the quarantine system.

It will be interesting to compare the plans, as now published, for the reorganization of the Kansas City, Pittsburg and Gulf Railroad, by the Philadelphia committee and the readjustment plan proposed by the New York committee.

CHRISTIANIA, Sept. 2. -- The Cabinet has decided to forward a copy of the law for the introduction of a purely Norwegian flag to the Swedish and Norwegian Minister of War, Baron Rappe, in order that he may notify foreign powers.

LONDON, Sept. 2. -- At the Sandown Park Club September Meeting to-day the race of the Michaelmas Stakes was won by Lord William Beresford's black gelding Blacksmith, ridden by "Tod" Sloan, the American jockey. Nine horses ran five furlongs. The betting was 5 to 2 on Blacksmith.

RENNES, Sept. 2. -- Elation is the only word that expresses the feelings of the Dreyfusards after to-day's proceedings. The tide has turned at last, they say, and Dreyfus cannot be condemned after the evidence given this morning.

OF Prince Ranjitsinhji, the great Indian cricketer, should come to this country with his crack cricket team, as is now proposed, this country will see one of the finest cricketers of the times, and one who, since the retirement of the veteran W.G. Grace, stands without a peer.

"They never wheeled so much, and there is a constant demand for children's bicycles. In fact, their sale gives the backbone to the bicycle trade. The members of the Board of State Tax Commissioners -- Martin Heermance, George M. Priest, and J. Edgar Leaycraft -- accompanied by their counsel, J. Newton Fiero, went down to Oyster Bay yesterday and held a conference with Gov. Roosevelt on the question of the means and methods of enforcing the new Franchise Tax act. The Commissioners arrived at Oyster Bay shortly after noon and remained with the Governor for several hours.

General Master Workman Parsons, Joseph Barondess, and Samuel Prince, who were appointed by the Independent Labor Party as a committee to invite the two factions of the Socialist-Labor party to join that organization in the coming campaign, will fall short of their purpose, but they, most probably, will be cordially received by the National Executive Committee of the dominant faction.

The managers of the International Photographic Exhibition, which is to be held in Madison Square Garden from Oct. 21 to 28, have received from England a valuable and important collection of photographic objects. They belong to the Royal Photographic Society of Great Britain and private collectors, who have loaned them for the coming exhibition here.

PARIS, Sept. 2. -- La Lanterne to-day says that Col. Schneider, the Austrian Military Attache here, has telegraphed to the Austrian Charge d'Affaires to ask Gen. Roget if the reference made to him by Roget, in his reply to Picot's testimony in the Dreyfus court-martial, was intended as an insult.
