WHEN Levi P. Morton was a clerk in a country store in Enfield, Mass., about sixty years ago, he acquired a local fame for politeness and faithful attention to business. The country-folk for miles around sang his praises. "We like that Morton boy," they said, "because he is always so pleasant and we can believe what he says."

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 2. -- A movement is under way toward the formation of a large brick trust, which will include the principal brick concerns of New York and New England. All the brickyards within 125 miles of Boston are to join in the movement. News of the project has been kept from the public, presumably for the reason that the plans have not yet been matured.

Micawber would have been a saint in Wall Street. Forever and ever the New York Stock Exchange district is waiting for something to turn up. Dates are always just ahead when developments are to transmute dullness into activity, weakness into strength. Latest of expectations red lettered in the calendar has been the time just now appearing -- the beginning of September, the opening of Autumn.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2. -- The War Department is making every effort to secure the removal of the two batteries of artillery garrisoned at Key West, but has so far been unable to do so because of the strict quarantine drawn by the Florida State officials.

STOCKBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 2. -- Markoe Robertson, Captain of the Yale Golf Club, won the Stockbridge Cup to-day over George C. Clark, Jr., ex-Captain of the Harvard Club, by one up. It was a thirty-six-hole match, and Clark was one up at the end of the first eighteen holes, Robertson being sometimes three down, but he played a fine game, overtaking Clark at the thirty-first hole.

BERLIN, Sept. 2. -- The army manoeuvres, which will begin to-morrow and will end Sept. 15, will be of more than usual interest and importance. The operations will be conducted on the same ground as and will be largely patterned after the Napoleonic campaign of 1805. Half the troops engaged -- the Fifteenth Corps -- will approach the opposing force -- the Sixteenth Corps -- by forced marches through the Black Forest passes.

With the issue of next Sunday, Sept. 10, the price of the Sunday edition of THE NEW YORK TIMES will be reduced to three cents a copy and The Illustrated Magazine Supplement will be discontinued. It is intended that henceforth THE TIMES, on Sunday as on week days, shall be strictly a newspaper.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 2. -- The Indian Harbor Yacht Club sailed its Autumn regatta to-day in weather that was very threatening, and up to noon had been very moist. There were forty entries and twenty-six started. The long course was fifteen miles, and the shorter ten miles, both being inner courses near the clubhouse.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2. -- It was thirty-four years ago in Marcia that the Congress of the Confederate States of America held its last session, less than a month before Lee surrendered at Appomattox and Grant's victorious army occupied Richmond, the capital of the Confederacy. From time to time, during the war for the Union, the meetings and acts of the Confederate Congress were reported in a fragmentary way in the Northern papers.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Sept. 2. -- Full but still unofficial returns of the recent special election in the Eighth, or Bland, Congressional District, in this State give the following vote: Shackleford, (Dem.,) 19,272; Vosholl, (Rep.,) 15,829, Hale, (Pop.,) 790; Shackleford's plurality, 3,443; his majority, 2,653.

James William Elwell, the senior member of the commission and shipping house of James W. Elwell Co. of 47 South Street, died yesterday at his home, 70 Lefferts Place, Brooklyn of pneumonia. He had been ill for some days. He was seventy-nine years old. He began to sink rapidly yesterday morning and died in the afternoon.

EMANUEL LEUTSE'S well-known painting of "The settlement of Maryland by the English Under Leonard Calvert," which is owned by Henry Newman of New York, Illustrates the formal landing of the English, in April, 1634, after they had erected a storehouse nearby for protection and possible defense.

Watson of this city, who has just distinguished himself in killing a great gray wolf in a hand-to-hand struggle, with a small revolver as his only weapon.

MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., Sept. 2. -- This place was left in darkness last right, and there is a prospect of its being in the same condition for at least four weeks owing to what some of the residents term the stupidity of the Board of Village Trustees.

The company last week decided to do its own clearing and to dispense with the services, as its clearing agent, of the Western National Bank, of which it remains a customer.

The woman was unconscious when discovered. Mason had her carried aboard the dredging steamer, where restoratives were applied.

The Scotch Sabbath was observed yesterday on board the Shamrock and her attendant fleet of auxiliaries that swung lazily at their anchors off the New York Yacht Club station at Tompkinsville. The crews of the various craft, from Captain down to the "grub spoiler," as the Scotch tars irreverently call the cook, had a day of absolute rest, and Sir Thomas Lipton, who remained on board the Erin all day, received few visitors.

It is true that there are contributions from other cities, and that our Government has forwarded supplies. The benevolence of our people is great, but among 100,000 sufferers $60,000 amounts to but 60 cents each.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 3. -- With the Columbia's decisive victory over the Defender on Saturday and an anticipated repetition of the feat to-morrow, very few yachtsmen here are looking for a third formal contest between the two boats on Wednesday, at least not under the auspices of the America's Cup Committee, for that body has practically made up its mind as to the relative merits of the two yachts.

CHICAGO, Sept. 3. -- More than 100 Chicago German societies, having 12,000 members, to-day celebrated the one hundred and fiftieth anniversary of the birth of Goethe. Over 35,000 persons attended the celebration, at Sunnyside Park. A specially selected orchestra of 100 pieces played selections from "Faust" and other works inspired by Goethe's poems.

Hosiery is booming, underwear is doing a fair business, cotton goods are handicapped by hardening prices, and short supplies and silks are in the same position.

DALLAS, Texas, Sept. 3. -- Arrangements are rapidly being completed for the big Democratic National carnival, which takes place here on Oct. 2 and 3, concluding on the latter night with a "dollar dinner," covers for from 1,500 to 2,000 being arranged for. The dinner will take place at the New Auditorium, at the State Fair Grounds.

It is evident that the officials of the Big Consolidated Street Railway Company are nervous, for a notice was posted in all the barns to-day cautioning the men against recklessness to-morrow.

You will have noticed that the famous Atbara bridge, built by an American firm to the considerable annoyance of some Englishmen, was officially opened Aug. 26. A London newspaper, The Evening News, in commenting on this, has said: "It remains to be seen whether this pin-built structure, built on lines condemned by all English engineers, will stand the Atbara's floods."

With the issue of next Sunday, Sept. 10, the price of the Sunday edition of THE NEW YORK TIMES will be reduced to three cents a copy and The Illustrated Magazine Supplement will be discontinued. It is intended that henceforth THE TIMES, on Sunday as on week days, shall be strictly a newspaper.

The sixtieth anniversary of the birth of Henry George was celebrated yesterday by a public meeting at Grand Central Palace under the auspices of the Manhattan Single Tax Club. About 800 to 1,000 persons had gathered in the hall by 2:15, and had to wait nearly an hour before the meeting was opened. There seemed to be other things wrong with the programme, as only one of the advertised speakers, John N. Parsons, was present.

The announcement of the completion of an alliance between the League of American Wheelmen and the Cyclists' Touring Club of England marks the end of a series of negotiations which are of paramount importance to American wheelmen who make tours of Europe in the future. This accomplishment is to be directly credited to President Keenan of the League of American Wheelmen, who made a trip to Europe this Summer especially to conclude the arrangements.

Among the passengers who arrived yesterday on the steamship Caribbee from Barbados were thirty-six of the thirty-nine passengers of the Lamport Holt steamer Wordsworth, which put into Barbados with engines disabled. The passengers stated that the Wordsworth broke down on Aug. 16, about 500 miles south of Barbados, while on the voyage from Rio Janeiro for New York. The head of the low-pressure steam chest blew out, instantly killing Chief Engineer Archibald Thomas.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 3. -- This Sunday in Newport among the cottagers was decidedly the liveliest of the season after the church services were concluded. At the places of worship the atendance was noticeably large, and later the cottagers drove to Bailey's Beach and enjoyed their daily plunge in the surf. Then the entertaining began and continued well into the night.

MANILA, Sept. 3. -- Many Spanish prisoners are escaping from the Filipinos and bring into the American lines stories of hard treatment. They agree that the Filipinos are exceedingly short of rations, and that a large section of their troops is reduced to the use of home-made black powder.

The Sleepy Hollow Lawn Tennis Club will set the round of Fall tournaments going on the club courts at Tarrytown-on-the-Hudson this morning. This is the seventh annual open tournament of the club, and the entry list is unusually long and numbers many crack players.

The following letter from the Secretary of the Manhattan Pharmaceutical Association to C.A. Mayo, editor of The American Druggist, in relation to a banquet which the retail druggists of this city propose to tender to the apothecary of Admiral Dewey's flagship Olympia, and the apothecaries of Admiral Sampson's escorting fleet, was made public yesterday:

Recent dispatches from Albany regarding the overcrowding of the State asylums for feeble-minded children in Newark and Syracuse reveal a state of affairs which call the attention of intelligent philanthropists and of all public-spirited citizens to the necessity of a thorough reform and reorganization of such institutions along the lines of medical science.

A serious riot took place in "Chinatown" shortly after 6 o'clock last evening. Revolvers were fired and knives were used. Mott and Pell Streets were blocked by a crowd of more than 1,000 Chinamen and white people. Several persons were badly injured, and the whole district was thrown into a state of panic.

What is the meaning of the term, "A Breach of the Peace "? I ask for information. Does it mean unnecessary and unseemly noise, that which annoys law-abiding citizens and disturbs the harmony of law and order? If it does mean this, why are hucksters licensed to split our ears with their discordant cries, instead of being compelled to ring our door bells like any other peddler, and why.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Sept. 3. -- Disastrous forest fires are raging in the southern portion of Calhoun County. Already great damage has been done, and unless rain comes soon the loss will be incalculable. Fire fighters are working day and night. Many have become exhausted, and several have been prostrated by the heat while fighting the flames.

A continuation of the quietness in local golfing affairs, which has prevailed for the last two months, hung over the links last week, but every course in the mountains and at the seaside was full of life and play. At Newport the sixth annual open tournament attracted one of the best fields, both in numbers and quality, which has gathered this year.

In the Singapore Free Press of Monday the 10th inst., (July,) mention was made of the discovery on the previous day of the body of a European washed up on Blakan Mati, who had been evidently drowned from or in trying to reach some ship in the harbor. This proved on inquiry to be the body of an American sailor missing from the United States ship Yosemite.

With the opening of the Empire City Trotting Club's new track to-day light harness racing takes a new lease of life in the neighborhood of New York. Since the abandonment of the old Fleetwood track at Melrose several years ago the running horse has monopolized the turf in Greater New York.

MEXICO CITY, Sept. 3. -- Three emissaries of the hostile Indians in the southern part of Yucatan have appeared in towns in the British colony of Belize, pretending to wish to purchase cloth, but it is believed they are trying to obtain arms and ammunition, the sale of which to Indians is prohibited by the colonial authorities.

HAVANA, Sept. 3. -- The much-advertised fight between the French athlete Romulus and a bull took place at Regla to-day. The animal turned out to be a half-starved steer. The show was badly attended, and the crowd, annoyed at the fiasco, called for the rehabilitation of "decent bullfighting."

In the manifest contest for supremacy between the old orthodoxy and more liberal views, now going on, some specially significant fact now and then emerges, showing which is likely to prevail. The Rev. Dr. Hillis, an orthodox preacher, announces a book called "Ten Masterpieces of Literature and Great Books as Life Teachers."

ELIZABETH, N.J., Sept. 3. -- Residents of Union Township, to the north and west of this city, are excited over the proposed action of the Township Committee, which will meet Tuesday night to act upon the question of a sewer. There are some who intimate the proposed sewer will prove a heavier tax proposition upon the section affected than the recently proposed Ramapo water deal upon New York.

Patrolman Patrick O'Keefe of the East One Hundred and Twenty-sixth Street Police Station, lies blinded and dying in the Harlem Hospital from bullet wounds in the head and right breast inflicted by Michael Farrelli, an Italian saloonkeeper at 2,348 Second Avenue, whom he was about to arrest yesterday afternoon for violation of the excise law.

SOUTHOLD, L.I., Sept. 3. -- Lena Comiski, a Polish girl, who had been working for John Young, a Bay View farmer, was to have been married to-day to Joseph Fulda, a farm hand employed in Peconic. There was no wedding, however, because the bride was arrested yesterday on a charge of stealing jewelry, money, and clothing belonging to Mrs. Arthur Hand of New York, a guest of the Young family.

DENVER, Sept. 3. -- Of all the wonderful feats of railroad engineering ever undertaken, there is none, it seems to me, more marvelous than the mountain railroads in Colorado. They wind in and out among the craggy steeps, they turn and twist in serpentine curves, and overlap their own windings in the most dizzying fashion.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 3. -- The thirty-third National Encampment of the Grand Army of the Republic will begin here to-morrow. The vanguard of the veterans has already reached this city. Admiral Sampson with his fleet of fighting ships arrived to-day. The city is crowded with strangers, while the incoming trains from all sections are bringing thousands to help swell the throng.

CHICAGO, Sept. 3. -- Another follower of "Healer" Dowie has died. The latest victim is Mrs. Charles Robinson, who, with her husband, belonged to the Zion Temple. She fell ill about two months ago, but no physician was called. Instead she was visited by J.H. Lagrange, who is an elder in the Dowie congregation.
The Stock Exchange adjourned and all Wall Street business suspended in celebration of a holiday for labor would have seemed not so very long ago an exhibition exceedingly curious.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, Aug. 27. -- A departmental report has just been issued by the Collector General of Jamaica, which gives a striking and interesting view of the increase in the principal items of island produce exported to the United States between April 1 and Aug. 12 of the current year, as compared with the corresponding period last year. This makes the following showing:

MEXICO CITY, Sept. 3. -- The Clerical press is greatly excited over the probable visit of President Diaz to Chicago this Autumn, and the papers have many caricatures bearing upon the Presidential journey to the land of the Yankees, mostly conceived in great good humor, and depicting the audacity of the Chicago committee, who were received here as semi-royal personages, according to the humorous papers.

LONDON, Sept. 4. -- A dispatch from Johannesburg to Reuter's Agency definitely announces that the reply of the Transvaal Republic to the British communication withdraws the franchise proposals and agrees in principle to a conference at Cape Town.

ALBANY, N. Y., Sept. 4 -- The Governor General's 'oot Guards of Ottawa, Canada, on a visit to Albany as the guests of the Tenth Battalion, made a tour of the Capitol to-day and vlMited the Executive Chamber. In the absence of Gov. loosevelt, the following message from him was read to the guards by Col. Treadwell, is Military Secretary:

With the issue of next Sunday, Sept. 10, the price of the Sunday edition of THE NEW YORK TIMES will be reduced to three cents a copy and The Illustrated Magazine Supplement will be discontinued. It is intended that henceforth THE TIMES, on Sunday as on week days, shall be strictly a newspaper.
PRETORIA, Sept. 4. -- The reply of the Transvaal Republic to the demands of Great Britain increases the period of residence necessary in order to obtain the franchise.

Mrs. Rochalie Lesso, a comely Italian woman with snapping black eyes, stood before Magistrate Meade in the Centre Street Police Court yesterday accused of having violated the Sunday closing law by shaving a man the day before. She is associated with her husband in conducting a small barber shop at 13 1/2 Oliver Street, and her cleverness with the razor is the magnetic feature of the shop.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Sept. 4. -- To-day at Johnson Springs a mounted armed mob of about 200 men took charge of a court, Sheriff, and the litigants, and by main force put a stop to a very sensational criminal proceeding. For a time a wholesale lynching appeared inevitable.

The body of Thomas C. Oakley, who was drowned in Mohegan Lake Sunday afternoon, was brought to his late home, 78 Riverside Drive, yesterday afternoon by his brother, Gilbert Oakley. The funeral services will be held this evening at 8:30 o'clock at the family residence. The burial, which will be private, will take place to-morrow morning in Woodlawn Cemetery.
The Brooklyns landed two more victories yesterday, defeating the New Yorks in both games by one run.

A desperate attempt was made again yesterday morning to deal out summary justice to Michael Farrelli, the Italian saloonkeeper, of 2,348 Second Avenue, who on Sunday shot and mortally wounded Policeman Patrick O'Keefe of the East One Hundred and Twenty-sixth Street Police Station when the latter attempted to arrest him for violation of the excise law.

RENNES, Sept. 4. -- The coup of the Austrian officer was one of the most dramatic things that have been sprung upon the defense. Commandant Carriere, the Government Commissary, gave no warning of his appearance.

Labor Day was a lucky one for the racing firm of Bromloy Co. With their two rather commonplace horses, Mesmerist and Previous, they managed to win both of the stakes set for decision during the afternoon, O'Connor piloting both animals to victory. The stakes were the Autumn, for two-year-olds, worth $2,500, which Mesmerist won, and the Twin City Handicap, at a mile and a quarter, which was worth about $5,000 to the winner, Previous.

SHEBOYGAN, Wis., Sept. 4. -- Passenger Train No. 11 on the Northwestern Road struck a carriage containing three men-named Holle, Fox, and Shlerick -- at Cedar Grove, twelve miles south of here, last night, and killed them instantly. The bodies of the men derailed the train, but, though the coaches were filled with passengers from Milwaukee and other points, there were no other casualties.

Wall Street can begin to-day its Fall campaign -- if Fall campaign there is to be. It has been much predicted. Optimists in the Stock Exchange district count still confidently upon the early establishment of buoyancy, if, indeed it doesn't lead to a duplication of old time "booms." Among some authorities, who are entitled to consideration, however, no show appears of extravagant anticipation.
LONDON, Sept. 5. -- The Johannesburg correspondent of The Standard says:

The Fall regatta of the Larchmont Yacht Club was sailed yesterday in a heavy northerly wind on Long Island Sound. Interest centred in the race between the Vigilant, Quissetta, and Amorita. The latter lost her chance of winning by going around the wrong stake, thus giving the prize to Vigilant.

GIBRALTAR, Sept. 4. -- The United States cruiser Olympia, with Admiral Dewey on board, which arrived here at 9:15 o'clock this morning, fired the usual salute in honor of the garrison and the compliment was returned by the batteries on shore and by the British battleship Devastation.

NYACK, N.Y., Sept. 4. -- A severe thunderstorm last night broke up the evening meeting of the Christian Alliance Convention in the Gospel Tent and made the hundreds gathered there flee for shelter from the rain, but this morning Dr. Simpson's followers in the alliance work were at their places as usual with smiling faces in the Tabernacle. Dr. Simpson preached a sermon on the "fourfold gospel."

Otto Overmann and William Schenckerberg of Hoboken are dying in the City Hospital in Jersey City of wounds received late on Sunday night in an encounter with Fernando Farley, a special policeman of Secaucus, whom they had attempted to kill when, in the course of his duty, he placed them under arrest on a charge of having broken into a boathouse on the Hackensack River, near Secaucus.
LONDON, Sept. 4 -- Arthur Henry George Vaughan, who was sixth Earl of Lisburne, is dead. He was born July 30, 1862.
NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 4. -- The third season of the Newport Horse Show opened at the Casino this afternoon.

Hundreds of people gathered in Crotona Park yesterday to witness the second day's events in the gymnasium tournament between teams of boys representing the various play schools and open-air gymnasiums in the Boroughs of Manhattan and the Bronx maintained by the Board of Education during the Summer.

CHICAGO, Sept. 4. -- J.G. Johnson of Kansas is to be the active manager of the work of the Democratic National Committee until the adjournment of the next National Convention. He is slated to assume charge of the permanent headquarters that will be opened in Chicago immediately after the conference to be held at the Auditorium a week from next Monday.

RENNES, Sept. 4. -- The fifth week of the second trial by court-martial of Capt. Alfred Dreyfus of the artillery, charged with treason in communicating secret papers to a foreign Government, began to-day with the largest attendance yet seen in the Lycee. The interest in the trial grows as the denouement approaches.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Sept. 4. -- Society can talk of nothing to-day but the fining of Mrs. Jules Reynal of New York for alleged violation of the State game laws. A few choice partridges, served at a dinner Saturday night, were the cause of all the trouble, and Mrs. Reynal, after paying the $150 fine, has left Bar Harbor with a threat never to return.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 4. -- In his address to-day at the celebration of Labor Day, Mayor Jones made an interesting departure from his accustomed speech. This departure was his reference to the Zanesville Convention and John R. McLean, Democratic nominee for Governor. In speaking about bosses he said:

The Chicago Platform Democracy held a mass meeting at Cooper Union last night, at which ex-Gov. John P. Altgeld of Illinois, James P. Tarvin of Kentucky, and Congressman J.J. Lentz of Ohio were the principal speakers. The object of the meeting was to indorse the Chicago platform and to carry on the campaign in its favor in this part of the country.

The Anchor Line steamship City of Rome, which sailed from Glasgow Saturday, Aug. 26, and Moville, Ireland, the same day, with 993 passengers and a crew of 297 men, all told, reached here yesterday, a few hours late, all aboard well and giving thanks that they were able to tell the story of a collision with an iceberg.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 4. -- The trial races between the Columbia and Defender are over. The champion of 1899 defeated her of 1895 so decisively to-day that the Challenge Committee, or Cup Committee, as it was formerly called, decided that there was no further need of competition between the two yachts.

The great Jewish Feast of Rosh Hashanah, the new year, was ushered in last night with appropriate and elaborate ceremonies in all of the regular and improvised synagogues throughout the city, and crowds of the faithful repaired to the various places of worship to lay at the foot of the Throne of Grace their petitions for a prosperous year in response to the summons sounded by the shofar.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 4. -- President McKinley arrived here at 9 o'clock to-night to participate in the Grand Army Encampment. He was accompanied by Secretary of War Root, Secretary of Agriculture Wilson, Prof. Schurman, President of the Philippine Commission; J. Addison Porter, the President's private secretary, and Assistant Secretary G.B. Cortelyou.

CHICAGO, Sept. 4. -- Before a notary public, Herman Hundhausen, who, with Richard Honeck, was arrested late Saturday night charged with the murder of Richard Koeller, their former schoolmate, made a full confession of the crime to-day. Revenge and not jealousy of a woman, according to Hundhausen, was the motive, and the stabbing was done by Honeck with the knife found by the police in his satchel.

An anonymous, or rather a pseudonymous, contributor to The North American Review who signs himself "Diplomat" undertakes, in the current number of that periodical, to answer the article upon which we have heretofore commented in a previous number by Mr. SIDNEY BROOKS upon the Transvaal.
BELGRADE, Sept. 4. -- Jean Ristitch, the distinguished Servian statesman, who was twice Regent, died to-day in his sixty-ninth year.

It is reported that Mr. MCCARTNEY of the Street Cleaning Department is to be displaced and his position given to one NAGLE, a favorite of Mr. CROKER. Mr. MCCARTNEY'S retirement is only a question of time, and the unfortunate condition of his health may readily serve as an excuse for hastening it.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 4. -- W. Butler Duncan of the Defender sent word to Mr. Iselin at 7 o'clock this evening that he would not race Wednesday, and the race for the Goddard Cup will take place at 2 o'clock to-morrow afternoon.

The rifle ranges at Creedmoor presented a gay sight yesterday with the 700 uniformed National Guardsmen who competed in the rifle and pistol practice. Only a small percentage of this number succeeded in qualifying, owing to the uncertain "fishtail" wind that whistled over the grounds from early morning until nightfall, turning the shots out of their course and sending chills through the marksmen.

LOUISVILLE, Sept. 4. -- A report has been going the rounds all day to-day, and is generally credited by the Brown Democrats, that the managers of Senator Goebel's campaign are attempting to induce him to get off the track.

BAYONNE, N.J., Sept. 4. -- The Knickerbocker Athletic Club Labor Day carnival at Bayonne resulted in one new world's record made by John Flanagan of the New York Athletic Club, who threw a sixteen-pound hammer from a nine-foot circle, Irish style, a distance of 164 feet 6 inches. The old record was 151 feet 10 inches, made by Kelly of Ireland.
POUGHKEEPSIE, Sept. 4. -- The aces of the Poughkeepsie Bicycle Club at the Hudson River Driving Park to-day were witnessed by 2,500 persons. Summary:

BALTIMORE, Sept. 4. -- President John S. Wilson of the Baltimore, Chesapeake and Atlantic Railroad has confirmed the reported purchase of a controlling interest of that road by the Pennsylvania Railroad, which, together with its valuable properties of rail and steamboat lines, becomes part of the Pennsylvania system immediately.

LENOX, Mass., Sept. 4. -- The qualifying round of thirty-six holes, medal play, for the cup given by David W. Bishop was played to-day on the Lenox golf links. A stiff west wind prevented low scores. Eighteen players entered, but some of them dropped out after the morning round of eighteen holes. Samuel Frothingham made the lowest score but had a close second in E.A. Thomson.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4. -- The Cabinet today was in session for more than two hours, and a variety of matters which have accumulated during the President's absence were discussed. It was Secretary Root's first attendance, the other members present being Secretaries Hay, Gage, Hitchcock, and Wilson.
STRASBURG, Sept. 4. -- Emperor William arrived here to-day for the purpose of attending the Autumn army manoeuvres. He received an ovation.

CHICAGO, Sept. 4. -- By defeating Miss Myrtle McAteer of Pittsburg in the championship round of the woman's Western championship tennis tournament at the Kenwood Country Club to-day Miss Juliette P. Atkinson of Brooklyn retained her title of champion of the West in singles. The play throughout was exciting and brilliant.

LONDON, Sept. 4. -- Rejuvenated by a course of treatment at German baths and a Summer's visit to Europe, United States Senator Mark A. Hanna has returned to London for a few days' rest previous to sailing for the United States on board the American Line steamer St. Louis on Saturday next.

After a period of comparative quiet, the Morris County golf course at Morristown, N.J., was formally opened for the Fall season yesterday by a competition which the committee chose to style a "kickers'" handicap. More than twenty members took part, and all played with such zeal that the uninitiated might well wonder why the event secured its suggestive name.

A result of Sunday night's storm was ideal weather for the celebration of Labor Day. The streets were swept to immaculate cleanliness by the deluge and had time to dry, the temperature permitted activity and a steady breeze was a factor in general pleasant conditions. The holiday was everywhere recognized in bunting.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Sept. 4. -- A petition has been filed in the Circuit Court for a pro forma decree of incorporation of the American Equal Wage Union. This is an entirely educational and philanthropic organization. Its officers are: President -- Richard D. Kaltherns; Secretary -- Arthur S. Lyman; Treasurer -- Robert S. Owen.

There were two incidents reported in yesterday's paper which to a superficial observer might seem to illustrate, one with a suggestion of tragedy, the other in pure farce, the imperviousness to civilization of the North American Indian. One was the announcement that some Mexican Indians are endeavoring to procure ammunition in Belize for the purpose of resisting the payment of taxes on their favorite beverage of aguardiente.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4. -- Chief Justice Chambers of Samoa is here to confer with officials and to submit his report to the three powers represented in Samoa. While avoiding a discussion of pending diplomatic questions, Judge Chambers, when seen today, spoke on some of the general conditions in Samoa, and also cleared up some misapprehensions as to his own status and plans.

An altogether unaccountable tendency on the part of domestic cats to get into organs, to remain in them regardless of hunger and thirst, to so dispose their bodies as to render futile the combined efforts of organ blower or organist to evoke music from the instrument, appears to have developed in widely separated sections of the country, the most notable instance being that reported from Richmond as having occurred on Sunday last.

-- Few people ever think of St. Helena except as a rock in the sea on which NAPOLEON lived a while miserably and then more miserably died. That the greatest of anti-climaxes was not the end of the little island's history is hard to realize, possibly because a poet or a romancer would have made it the end, and a continuation is therefore more or less unnatural and absurd.

Harness racing at the Empire City track reduced the attendance at the running races yesterday very materially, so far as the clubhouse contingent was concerned at least. There was the usual crowd in the grand stand and in the field, and these seemed delighted when "Danny" Maher won two races with Erwin and Azucena.

We are now able to publish a full statement of the legacies and charitable bequests given by the late Clara, Baroness von Hirsch, formerly Bischoffsheim, of Eichhorn, near Brunn, in Austria, and of 2 Rue de l'Elysee, Paris, who died on April 1 last, aged sixty-six years, widow of Baron Moritz von Hirsch.

Yesterday's market was narrow, but was strong -- so narrow and so strong as to upset many of the theories of Wall Street philosophers. Commission house business seemed practically at a standstill; at various times during the day it looked as if the chief buyers were bear speculators short of stocks.

NEWPORT, Sept. 5. -- The talk at the Horse Show this afternoon and wherever society congregated was about the encounter between Foxhall Keene and the Earl of Yarmouth at the dress rehearsal at the Casino on Monday night.

The public schools of this city will reopen on Monday morning next, and the attendance promises to be much larger than ever before. The total capacity of the public schools in the Boroughs of Manhattan and the Bronx this year will be over 250,000. Eight new school buildings will be ready for occupancy, and will accommodate 20,000 pupils. These new schools are as follows:

LONDON, Sept. 5. -- At the first day of the Doncaster September meeting to-day the race for the Fitzwilliam Stakes was won by Mr. Mr. Duke's five-year-old horse Joe Ullman, ridden by L. Reiff, the American jockey. Eight horses ran, three quarters of a mile.

NYACK, Sept. 5. -- The weather to-day has been splendid at the Christian Alliance Convention on Nyack Heights, the atmosphere being clear and refreshing on the mountain top. In his morning sermon, which began at 11 o'clock, Dr. Simpson became more animated than usual as he talked of the power of the Holy Ghost. "I tell you, beloved," said he, "drink of the Holy Spirit.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5. -- The matter of making an effective blockade in the Philippines, and especially around the Island of Luzon, so as to prevent the insurgents from obtaining ammunition and supplies, is one that is giving the Administration considerable concern. It has not been deemed feasible to proclaim a blockade, as it would indicate a state of war and possibly open a way to the recognition of the insurgents.

ALBANY, Sept. 5. -- The State Board of Tax Commissioners reports that the taxable property of the State, based on Assessors' reports for 1898, shows an increase over the year preceding of $177,785,805. The total assessed value of real estate is $4,349,801,526, and of personal $649,364,694. The total equalized value of real estate for taxation is $5,076,396,824 and of personal $662,548,328.

The market showed few signs of recovery yesterday after what had been virtually a three-days' cessation of business. There were no sales scheduled at auction, and those reported at private contract were of slight importance.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 5. -- The twenty-fifth annual convention of the American Bankers' Association was called to order in the auditorium of the Chamber of Commerce Building to-day, with probably the largest attendance in the history of the organization. Nearly 1,500 bankers, representing all sections of the country, were present.

A study of the map of South Africa is calculated to dampen the ardor of the British admirers and followers of Mr. CHAMBERLAIN, whose voice is still for war and who profess a contempt for "wiles more inexpert' in dealing with the Boers of the Transvaal. For which very reason such a study may be commended to them.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 5. -- President McKinley was the hero of to-day's exercises of the Grand Army of the Republic Encampment. He began the day by driving over the route of the parade, which took place later, accompanied by members of his Cabinet and other distinguished visitors. The party reached the reviewing stand a 10 o'clock, and soon afterward the procession of veterans began to move.

CHICAGO, Sept. 5. -- Angus Sinclair of New York, proprietor of Locomotive Engineering, and for ten years Secretary of the Master Mechanics' Association, who is visiting Chicago, is authority for the statement that as soon as competent men can be secured to be placed at the head of it a gigantic plant for the building of locomotives and other rolling stock is to be established in Switzerland by a company of American and European capitalists.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5. -- It is constantly repeated that in spite of all the clamor against Gen. Otis there is no intention of recalling him. This is true, but it is a very different thing from saying that he will direct the active military movements in the Fall campaign.

There is a point that is carefully concealed from Americans in England's claims against the Boers. England demands that the South African Republic grant to Uitlanders (foreigners) naturalization and the right to vote without their forswearing allegiance to their foreign Governments. Of course, soon after being naturalized they will vote to become part of the British Empire, and, as they already outnumber the Boers three to one, the whole thing is a farce.

RENNES, Sept. 5. -- The diplomatic side of the Dreyfus affair has taken a sensational turn. Maitre Labori to-night wired on his own responsibility the German Emperor and the King of Italy, begging them to release Cols. Schwarzkoppen and Panizzardi, respectively, from their oath of professional secrecy.

Sir Thomas Lipton's cup hunter again took advantage of the smoking southeasterly breeze that swept up the coast, and had another glorious sail-stretching spin on blue water. She strengthened the good impression she made in Monday's trial over a sea that was lumpy in the extreme, and whose wave crests were carried off to leeward in driving spindrift.

BOSTON, Sept. 5. -- A crusade against women who have no apparent means of livelihood is on. It started with the appointment, three months ago, by Gov. Wolcott of Harry Adams, a bank cashier, to the Police Commission. Mr. Adams pledged himself to purify Boston to the best of his ability.
STRASBURG, Sept. 5. -- A grand banquet was given this evening at the imperial palace, and Emperor William delivered the following address:

SARATOGA, Sept. 5. -- The Floral Peace Jubilee, covering three days, which opened here to-night, was participated in by over 75,000 visitors and cottagers from all parts of the United States and Canada. The weather fortunately proved pleasant, and the opening event of the Jubilee, conducted under the management of the Saratoga Floral Association and Carnival Committee, proved a glittering success and far exceeded expectations.
PUERTO PLATA, Santo Domingo, Sept. 5. -- Gen. Juan Isidro Jimenes landed here to-day, coming from Cuba. He touched at Cape Haitien on the way.

RENNES, Sept. 5. -- M. Cernuschi, the political refugee and reputed scion of Servian royalty, who appeared yesterday before the Dreyfus court-martial as a witness for the prosecution, was not examined by the court during the time it sat behind closed doors to-day. The examination of the secret espionage dossier mentioned by Capt. Cuignet at yesterday's sitting occupied the greater part of to-day's secret session of the court.

The Board of Aldermen spent the greater part of its session yesterday in wrangling over small matters, and as a result succeeded in accomplishing little work of any benefit to the city. In lieu of anything of more importance, the trouble arose over the Dewey reception, and Alderman McCall, the Tammany leader, was the cause of it all.

John Y. McKane died last evening at his home, Emmons Avenue, Sheepshead Bay. The cause of death was given by the family physician, Dr. J.O.F. Hill, as embolism of the brain, which produced paralysis. Contributary ailments were acute indigestion, Bright's disease, and fatty degeneration of the heart and blood vessels.
CAPE HENRY, Va., Sept. 5. -- The Monongahela was anchored inside the Capes this morning, and signaled, "Report me all well."

It is to be hoped that the recent return from Europe of Rear Admiral CROWNINSHIELD. Chief of the Bureau of Navigation in the Navy Department, is not the reason for the resumption of the attack upon Rear Admiral SCHLEY.

NEWPORT, Sept. 5. -- The long looked for amateur theatricals for the benefit of the Newport Hospital, under the management of the Earl of Yarmouth, took place at the Casino last evening and proved an artistic as well as a financial success. The efforts of the Earl and Mrs. John Clinton Gray will add several thousand dollars to the coffers of the hospital.

Frederick W. Hells, Secretary of the United States Commission at The Hague Peace Conference, was a passenger aboard the North German Lloyd steamship Kaiser Wilhelm tier Grease, which arrived yesterday from Bremen. He bears with him the report on the labors of the commission. Mr. Hells characterized the work of the conference as a pronoUnced success.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 5. -- Had it not been for the intervention of the Sons of Veterans, who are in charge of the camp at Fairmount Park, there might have been no tents left this morning. Last night was cold, a heavy dew fell on the plain where the tents were pitched, and the aged veterans suffered from lack of bed clothing.

In your paper of Sept. 4, 1899, in reporting the meeting held in the Grand Central Palace, on Sunday, to celebrate the sixtieth anniversary of the birth of Henry George, you state that in my address, as Chairman of the meeting, I said that "private property is a greater crime than slavery."

This was the second day of the Newport Horse Show, which was well attended in the morning and in the afternoon was crowded. The weather was delightful until 5 o'clock, when a cold wind blew over the grounds.

RENNES, Sept. 5. -- Maitre Labori this afternoon telegraphed personal appeals to Emperor William and King Humbert to grant permission to Col. Schwarzkoppen and Major Panizzardi, German and Italian Military Attaches in Paris in 1894, to come to Rennes to testify at the trial of Capt. Dreyfus. The appeals were couched in eloquent terms, invoking the assistance of their Majesties in the name of justice and humanity.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5. -- The navy is beginning to feel seriously the effect of the heavy advance in the steel market. To-day the shipbuilding firm of Lally Co. of Boston asked a year's extension from Oct. 1 in building the torpedo boats De Long and Blakely, now under construction in their yards.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5. -- According to Dr. D. Percy Hickling of this city, who has just returned to Washington from Europe, and who lunched with Admiral Dewey at Leghorn, the troubles from which the cartoonists have represented the Admiral as suffering in consequence of his popularity are real.
GIBRALTAR, Sept. 5. -- Admiral Dewey said to-day that he did not expect to go on sea service again except in the event of war, and that he will probably retire under the regulations.

The Building Code Commissioners yesterday presented to the Municipal Assembly a code of building law comprising 164 sections, divided up into thirty-six parts or chapters. The work is contained in a book of 168 pages, and provides for every possible phase of construction.

SEA GIRT, N.J., Sept. 5. -- The second day of the annual rifle meet was devoted to the first stage of the two regimental team matches and to the revolver team contest, with a continuation of the individual matches, which began yesterday. Lieut. F.C. Wilson of the crack Georgia team created a stir among the shooting enthusiasts by making thirteen consecutive "bulls" at 500 yards in one of these events.

NEWPORT, Sept. 5. -- In the finest kind of sailing breeze to-day the cup defender, the Columbia defeated the older one, the Defender, by 3 minutes and 11 seconds, over a twenty-mile coarse, ten miles to windward and return. She rounded the windward mark 2 minutes and 33 seconds ahead of the Defender, besides making up a handicap at the start of 81 seconds.

NEWPORT NEWS, Va., Sept 5. -- The battleship Kearsarge is the fastest vessel of her class in the United States Navy. She went out on her trial trip this morning, leaving the shipyard at 6 o'clock, and returned this afternoon at 5 o'clock, with all colors flying, and a broom, the symbol of victory on the water, nailed at each masthead.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5. -- Ex-Congressman Vincent A. Taylor of Ohio said to-day that much uneasiness existed in Ohio political circles over a report that Kurtz, Bushnell, and McKisson intended to support Mayor Jones for Governor, or else to make a deal with McLean in-return for votes for their local ticket.
NEWPORT, Sept. 5. -- On Thursday the Newport Clambake Club will have a clambake and oyster roast at their clubhouse.
CAPE TOWN, Sept. 5. -- Arrangements are being completed for safe-guarding telegraphic communication with the Cape in case of war between Great Britain and the Transvaal.

The conference which Corporation Counsel Whalen hoped to have with George L. Rives of the Rapid Transit Commission and Edward M. Shepard of the counsel for the commission yesterday was postponed until this afternoon because of the absence from the city of Mr. Shepard. Mr. Rives, who is in the city, did not care to discuss the contract with Mr. Whalen unless Mr. Shepard, who drafted it, could be present.

SANTO DOMINGO, Sept. 5. -- The Provisional Government, which arrived here to-day, met with a splendid reception. Festivals of all kinds had been prepared by the people, who are anxious to demonstrate their satisfaction at the change of Government.

Cheers from the throats of a large crowd of Democrats in Cooper Union at the mention of AGUINALDO as "one of the heroes of the world" are a sign of the times which it would be folly to ignore and which it is easier to sneer at than to explain away.

OTTAWA, Ont., Sept. 6. -- The frogleg industry will become a wholesale business in Cleveland, Ohio, and Canada is being made the purveyor for that city. Perhaps the next trust in the United States will be the frogs' legs combine. Commendation of the new policy of THE NEW YORK TIMES relative to its Sunday edition continues to come from old readers and friends of this newspaper. The theory that a metropolitan newspaper can find an ample held for development in its legitimate sphere meets with general favor throughout the community.

SALEM, N.J., Sept. 6. -- Because the City Council last night, by a vote of 5 to 1, refused to confirm Mayor Gwynn's suspension of two policemen, he resigned the Mayoralty of the city. The City Council will select a Mayor to fill the position until the next election.

The revival of interest in trotting brought out a large attendance at the Speedway sale of trotters and pacers held in the American Horse Exchange last evening. The sale will be continued tto-night. Incorporation at Trenton of the Southern Light and Traction Company, with a capital of $2,500,000.

NEWPORT, Sept. 6. -- The Newport Horse Show came to a close this afternoon with every inch of room in the boxes and reserved seats occupied. There were two exhibitions to-day, and in the morning the attendance was also very large.

For the fourth time this week the New Yorks were beaten by the Brooklyns, the final game of the series played at the Polo Grounds yesterday resulting favorably for the League leaders by a score of 6 to 4. A little enthusiasm was aroused in the eighth inning, when the locals scored three runs, but they could not follow up this advantage because of McJames's steady pitching.

SEA GIRT, N.J., Sept. 6. -- The third day of the annual rifle meet was devoted to the second stage of the inter-regimental team matches and the revolver team contest. The company team match and the carbine team match were also started. The greatest interest centred in the skirmish stage of the regimental matches, which consisted of skirmish firing at unknown distances.

Albert Stickney, the referee appointed by the Supreme Court to inquire into the charges of mismanagement preferred against the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children, filed his report yesterday. The report is voluminous and covers thirty pages. In it the referee sustains in every instance the claims and defense put in by the society and praises it upon the conduct of its business.
I have received, by last week's Pacific mail, a letter from Mr. Everett N. Bee, an American merchant connected with the San Francisco firm of Otis, McAllister Co., doing business in the Far East.

Col. John J. Scanlon of the First Regiment, Irish Volunteers, is to leave that organization and will become Captain of Company E of the Sixty-ninth Regiment. He is a Lieutenant in the supernumerary list of the Sixty-ninth, and last evening Col. Duffy sent an application to the Adjutant General asking that Col. Scanlon be assigned to active duty here.

RENNES, Sept. 6. -- The salvation of Capt. Dreyfus hangs on a word from Emperor William. This is the general opinion here to-night. If the Kaiser consents to allow Col. Schwarzkoppen, the German Military Attache in Paris in 1894, to testify before the court-martial, or to send a deposition, or, what is considered still more probable, to allow his deposition to be accompanied by the actual documents mentioned in the bordereau, then Dreyfus is saved.

WILMINGTON, Del., Sept. 6. -- A syndicate in which J. Edward Addicks, his State Chairman, J. Frank Allee, and John D. Hawkins are interested was balked yesterday by the Kent County Levy Court in an attempt to prevent the recently formed Delaware General Electric Company from securing permission to build a trolley road through the principal towns of Kent County.

CHICAGO, Sept. 6. -- Henry C. Adams, Professor of Political Economy and Finance in the University of Michigan, and a member of the Michigan delegation to the conference on trusts and combinations, arrived in the city during the morning.

MEADVILLE Penn., Sept. 6. -- An open switch caused a wreck on the Erie Railroad at Miller's Station, a short distance from this city, today, in which three Meadville men were killed and one injured. One tramp was also killed and another injured.

NEWPORT, Sept. 6. -- The betting on the result of the international yacht race between the Shamrock and the Columbia took a sudden change here this evening, and large bets were made during the exhibition of the horse show. Among the betting fraternity the Shamrock appeared to be the favorite.

Proxies to be voted in favor of the lease of the Boston and Albany Railroad are being sent in freely by New York Central stockholders, a special meeting of whom has been called for Sept. 27 to act on this matter. The proxies are to be voted by Cornelius Vanderbilt, W.K. Vanderbilt, Chauncey M. Depew, and S.R. Callaway, who constitute the Proxy Committee.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6. -- It was announced at the headquarters of the Tabernacle Society in this city to-day that Mrs. Ryan, the Wife of Thomas F. Ryan of New York, had purchased from St. Paul's Parish, this city, ground upon which will be erected a convent and chapel for the Sisters of the Perpetual Adoration. The plans for the building are now being prepared in Rome, and work will be begun immediately upon their arrival.

TACOMA, Washington, Sept. 6. -- Two big and warlike cannon point out over the banks of the Yukon from Eagle. They stand on a great, broad plateau, rising thirty feet above the stream, commanding the mighty river for miles. This interesting information is brought by S.A. Warren, who has just arrived from Eagle.

The eloquence and reason of Mr. FREDERIC HARRISON'S appeal from Mr. JOSEPH CHAMBERLAIN to Lord SALISBURY are so clear upon the face of his appeal that we owe no apology to any intelligent reader for transferring it bodily to our columns. But it may be worth while to point out that that must be a very unusual case which compels or induces a man like Mr. HARRISON to take sides in a political question.

MONTEREY, Cal., Sept. 6. -- The test of the relative skill of the four National lawn tennis champions from the Atlantic seaboard and the experts of the Pacific Coast was finished to-day on the courts of the Hotel Del Monte and resulted in a decisive victory for the Easterners.

It is likely that this is one of the stories that the bitter fight in Kentucky has set going, but if it be not true the mere fact that it is expected to be believed is significant.

Damage estimated at $75,000, including the sacrificing of many valuable paintings and much bric-a-brac, was done at a fire that nearly gutted last night the residence of Anthony Wallach, at 12 East Sixty-third Street, a retired jeweler who formerly did business at 37 and 39 Maiden Lane, but who is now traveling in Europe with his wife and brother Adolph.

CHICAGO, Sept. 6. -- The hotels in Chicago are at present doing such a big business that one is reminded of World's Fair times. More commercial travelers are coming to the city than for years. People traveling for pleasure are coming in throngs, and they stay not one night or two, but a week or a fortnight.

The season at Newport each day shows signs of wear and tear. People are leaving rapidly. Col. and Mrs. John Jacob Astor pass through the city to-day en route to their country seat on the Hudson. Mr. and Mrs. Ogden Mills and Miss Sands leave at the end of the week, and Mrs. Clarence Mackay, Mr. William K. Vanderbilt, Jr., and Mrs. Hermann Oelrichs are to depart by Sept. 20.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 6. -- There were lively times at to-day's session of the four-teenth annual convention of the National Association of Naval Veterans. A resolution providing for the admission of participants in the Spanish war to membership in the association started a rumpus and the result is that there is now a split in the organization.

NEW PORT, R.I., Sept. 6. -- Without doubt one of the most original and charming social functions of the season was given at Elms Court to-night by Mrs. Burke-Roche, and in many ways its originality was a topic not only of congratulations but of the admiration of the guests.

CAMDEN, N.J., Sept. 7. -- There were some peculiar happenings aboard the ships of the North Atlantic Squadron on Tuesday when the President's party was preparing to leave the pier in Philadelphia to board the New York. Of the five ships in the fleet not one had in its lockers a President's flag, which the regulations command shall be raised when the President boards a ship and not lowered until he leaves.

Authentic information received here from Washington is to the effect that President McKinley is giving his personal attention to the case of Appraiser Wakeman of this port. He has gone over closely the report of the commissioners who investigated Mr. Wakeman's office, but he is not satisfied with that report, and intends to call the commissioners before him, in order that he may question them personally on certain points not made clear therein.

LONDON, Sept. 7. -- Prices on the Stock Exchange to-day were generally depressed. Kafirs closed slightly steadier. American securities fluctuated somewhat after a steady opening, and then declined on fears that German houses would sell American in order to pay for mining shares. The closing tone was dull.

BURLINGTON, N.J., Sept. 7. -- Charles Diggs and his wife went away from home this morning to work. The fire grew very hot and set the house ablaze, and within a few minutes the whole structure was in flames.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9. -- Secretary Root has signed an order modifying the duty on coffee exported from Puerto Rico to Cuba. The rate on Puerto Rican coffee in entering Cuba will hereafter be $3.40 per hundred kilograms. The former rate was $12.15 per hundred kilograms, and this duty will be maintained against all coffee, except that which is brought to Cuba from Puerto Rico.

Rogers, President of the National Transit Company, one of the branches of the Standard Oil Company, on the stand. He said he had consulted with Mr. Archbold before the latter made his statement, and that he fully concurred in all that, Mr. Archbold had said.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Sept. 9. -- A sensational episode occurred at this morning's session of the Methodist Episcopal Conference at Grace Church, Newport, Ky. The Rev. D.B. Holt of Dayton, Ky., said that it had come to his personal knowledge that certain Ministers in the conference were violating one of their sacred vows.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Sept. 9. -- The National Guard of Illinois will not take part officially in the Dewey day celebration in New York. The Governor to-day directed Adjt. Gen. Reece to grant leave of absence to such organizations as shall desire to go at their own expense, but there is no appropriation from which State money can be drawn for that purpose.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Sept. 9. -- In view of the utterances of Congressman John J. Lentz and others the opinions held by a Cincinnatian, who is a soldier "by trade," and whose opinions must be accepted by all as unbiased, are of interest. Herman Wilke is a member of the Twelfth Infantry, and has been a soldier in the regular army for years.
The Sunday edition of THE TIMES appears to-day as a newspaper strictly, and at the reduced price of three cents.

Arrangements for the opening of the public schools to-morrow are complete. Later returns received by Superintendent Jasper confirm the estimates of the attendance of pupils which he made for THE NEW YORK TIMES on a recent date. The number of scholars will be greater than ever before, and the accommodations will be far better.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Sept. 9. -- The Rev. William Copley Winslow is spending a few weeks here. He was formerly an Episcopal clergyman in Lee, and is making his first visit to the Berkshires in thirty years. He is noted as an archaeologist, being the Vice President for America of the Egypt Exploration Fund.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Sept. 9. -- After a profitable season nearly all of the hotels here closed their doors this week. Many families who heretofore have lived at the hotels this season took cottages in preference. Cottage life is becoming more popular every Summer here. Those who are occupying cottages at present expect to remain in them until quite late in the season.

Market effects have not shown largely on such account, for during most of the week Wall Street has been extremely inactive and fluctuations have reflected important influences in few quarters.

The modesty of Mrs. Bridget Stacum, sixty years old, of 111 Harrison Street, Brooklyn, is the cause of her being in the Long Island College Hospital with a fractured skull. She was taking a bath yesterday afternoon when some visitors called at her flat. After the bath she looked out of her bathroom door and discovered that she could not get back to her bedroom where her clothes were without being observed by the callers.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 9. -- The closing week of the Summer season proper here has been appropriately the gayest and liveliest of the Summer, and although there are several interesting events and numerous incidents on the programme of the present month, the climax of the present season has been reached and passed.

Grace Matthewson Henderson has been appointed musical critic of The Los Angeles Times. She is an experienced teacher of music and has high ideals of her art. She has lately published a book of primary instruction in music with the title of "Seven Little People." The book is intended for the instruction of the very young, and the relations of the elements of music are explained in a fanciful and ingenious manner.

Two big century runs will be held to-day, the New York Firemen's Cycle Club and the Royal Arcanum Wheelmen starting runs this morning. Of the two the New York firemen will probably obtain the most patronage. It is not the firemen's first attempt in this direction, and more than 500 cyclists are expected to take part if the day is clear.

Attempting to advance somewhat the solution of the problem, THE NEW YORK TIMES has collected the views of the Governors of a number of Southern States on how lynching is to be prevented. It must be admitted that the result is not very satisfactory. All that is absolutely learned is that a Governor is not ex-officio an authority upon the solution of any social problem.

An attempt to beat bogey was made yesterday by the members of the Morris County Golf Club at Morristown, N.J. The tournament was a handicap, or else many of the competitors would have given up in despair, for it is heartbreaking to a ninety-five man to be told to break the bogey score of eighty-six, the score used on the Morris County links.

NEWPORT, Sept. 9. -- The largest gathering ever assembled at the Newport Golf Club since its organization was present this afternoon. At one time it appeared as if the entire cottage colony, with their guests, were either about the clubhouse park waiting for the golf club tea or watching the players competing for the cups offered by the club in handicap competition.

After remaining out of sight for nearly three weeks, Richard Croker returned to the city yesterday. His reappearance was as sudden and unexpected as his occultation for three weeks had been inexplicable, but in his usual unperturbed way he turned up smiling a mysterious smile and apparently as self-satisfied as though he had nightly been receiving the homage of his adherents at the Democratic Club.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9. -- President William McKinley and William J. Bryan were honored to-day by the newly formed association of Spanish War Veterans. Col. Bryan was elected a member of the Council of Administration, and President McKinley was elected as the first honorary member of the association. Both were elected unanimously.
NEWPORT, Sept. 9. -- Mr. and Mrs. A. Cass Canfield, who recently returned from Europe, are visiting here. They will take a cottage for next season.

With its issue of to-morrow THE NEW YORK TIMES takes an important step in its Sunday edition. The Sunday magazine supplement will be discontinued and the paper will be issued as a newspaper "on Sunday as on week days," the price being reduced to 3 cents.

A gentleman from Cincinnati was looking out of my office windows to-day -- twentieth story -- and as he looked toward the Hudson River he exclaimed: "Well, that's just like the Ohio!" What he referred to was half a dozen boats, mostly tugs, from the smokestacks of which dense black clouds were pouring.

SARANAC, Sept. 9. -- The open golf tournament on the Ampersand links took place this week. Three beautiful silver cups were put up and played for. Carriages from the hotels brought visitors to the links, which were crowded from early until late each day. Mr. Walter J. Travers carried off the handsome Ampersand Cup, and Mr. W.Y. March came in a close second.

Labor Day, followed by the Jewish holiday on Tuesday, acted as a severe handicap on business in the early part of the week with the result that the market's showing for the last six days has been unsually poor even for this season of the year.

A well-dressed man was driven to Bellevue Hospital yesterday in a carriage from Jersey City. He was paralyzed in both legs. He gave his name as William F. Painter, and said that he had just arrived from Augusta, Ga. His hair and mustache were gray. He handed the cabman 25 cents, saying that was all he had in the world.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Sept. 9. -- The last dance of the Summer at the Malvern generally means the termination of the season, yet it is said that there are many functions still to be held. The weekly dances at the Malvern this Summer have been welcomed heartily by the dancing portion of the Summer colony, as, save while the ships were in port, few opportunities have been afforded for dancing.

More than 12,000 persons were at Washington Park, Brooklyn, yesterday to see the final game of the season between the Brooklyns and the Bostons. As in Friday's game, the Bostons were beaten without making a run. It was one of the best exhibitions of pitching on the part of McJames, the home pitcher, that was ever seen on a local ball field.

The rehearsals of "Peter Stuyvesant, Governor of New Amsterdam," William H. Crane's new play, are now under way and are in charge of Bronson Howard, who, with Brander Matthews, wrote the work. The cast is a large one, and, in addition, there are a number of supernumeraries.

It is therefore with profund regret and in fact distrust and disgust, that I note your advocacy of the cowardly McKinley "war" in the Philippines.

The yacht Shamrock did not leave her mooring in the Horseshoe yesterday, but, nevertheless, it was not a day of rest for her crew. Soon after breakfast they were put to work setting up the standing rigging, which had become slack during the hard trials of the past week. The sailmakers, under direction of Mr. Ratsey, then unbent the mainsail and sent it on board the tender Plymouth.

LONDON, Sept. 9. -- Mrs. James Brown Potter reappeared this evening at the Comedy Theatre in an adaptation of Herman Heyerman's "The Ghetto," which will be produced in New York next week. The performance was witnessed by a large and interested audience, including the Prince of Wales and Prince Charles of Denmark.
LONDON, Sept. 9. -- E.S. Montgomery won the Dibble Shield on the Crystal Palace cycle track to-day, breaking the record for twelve hours by covering 267 miles and 400 yards.

PARIS, Sept. 9. -- From an early hour the boulevards presented a scene of unwonted animation, the crowds came double and triple for the successive editions of the various papers giving hourly accounts of the progress of the trial at Rennes.

LENOX, Mass., Sept. 9. -- The Lenox Autumn season has now fairly begun. It is ushered in by a large afternoon reception given by Mrs. H.H. Cook and Mrs. Carlos de Heredia at Wheatleigh this afternoon. It is the largest society event that has ever taken place at Wheatleigh, as nearly all the cottage colony is present.

September's second week finds Newport still gay, Bar Harbor with only a few cottagers left, and Narragansett with closed doors. People are lingering on at Southampton, and the Adirondack hotels are still well filled with guests. Saratoga has a large number of visitors remaining later than usual and Lenox is beginning its season well.

PRETORIA, Sept. 9. -- In the course of an interview to-day, State Attorney Smuts said that the Transvaal having withdrawn its offer of a five-years' franchise, the condition thereto attached, namely, the relinquishment of suzerainty, also falls to the ground. He understands the Transvaal's last dispatch as an acceptance of the proposal for a joint commission of inquiry.

RENNES, Sept. 9. -- The expected has happened. Dreyfus has been condemned; though a majority of those in the courtroom this afternoon fully expected the verdict, they were completely stupefied when it was given, and the silence which prevailed in the room and the way men turned pale and caught their breaths were more impressive than any other manifestation could have been.

LONDON, Sept. 9. -- T.P. O'Connor's M.A.P. (Mainly About People) says that though Lord William Beresford has every prospect of being second on the list of winning race-horse owners at the end of the season, if is doubtful whether he will be financially ahead, as he always has been really to lay great odds on his American horses.

He disappeared mysteriously, and until he is found they cannot prosecute William Joyce of 226 East Thirty-ninth Street, who, they allege, did the stabbing.

BERLIN, Aug. 29. -- The ominous murmurings of the Governmental Aetna have not been followed by the appalling upheaval so universally expected. The Kaiser returned suddenly to Berlin, the whole Prussian Ministry rushed out to Potsdam to meet and remain closeted with him for half a day, and then -- quietly returned to Berlin with sphinxlike countenances, and, behold! nothing happened.

In relation to your special dispatch from Washington of to-day, re the Carter case, I should like to know on what authority your correspondent founds his assertions. He makes bald statements of alleged facts, but no names are given as authority. The authority, however, is undoubtedly the same as that which prompted all other statements against Capt. Carter.

Your issue of to-day contains an editorial on the Carter case which would surprise me more than it does did I not recall to mind the soothing and emollient effects of time and words. Newspapers, I thought, had longer memories than their readers, and yet in twelve months you seem to have forgotten all details of the testimony before the Carter court-martial.

It is likely that the Tenement House Committee of the Charity Organization Society will make a strong protest against the adoption by the City Council of the new Building Code. The code which has just been drafted by the Building Code Commission will be taken up for adoption by the City Council Tuesday, after a final public hearing to-morrow afternoon.

SPRING LAKE, N.J., Sept. 9. -- So little has been said about the season at Spring Lake, despite the fact that so many well-known Philadelphia families summer there, that only at the threshold of its closing scenes does it transpire that it has been very gay indeed this year. The most brilliant entertainment of the Summer was given by Mr. and Mrs. W.W. Gibbs and the Misses Gibbs at the Casino on Monday night.

VIRGINIA HOT SPRINGS, Sept. 9. -- The Homestead Hotel here has just entered upon the closing month of the most successful season in its history, and the bookings for September indicate that the Fall business will be equally heavy. It has been a gay Summer throughout, and rooms have been at a premium.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Sept. 9. -- The condition of Gen. Daniel Butterfield of the Dewey Reception Committee, who is ill as his country home, Craigside, at Cold Spring, is not encouraging. To-day it was reported that the General was sinking, and that his death was hourly expected, but the report proved to be untrue.

In to-day's TIMES I note the terrible crime committed in the shooting of Policeman O'Keefe by that saloon keeper, Farrelli. It is only another evidence of the brazen way in which the saloon keepers and Raines law hotel keepers violate the law. The saloon is getting so bold and open in its flagrant violation of law that it is hard to tell where it will land next.

LONDON, Sept. 9. -- England is amazed that Dreyfus has been convicted and sentenced to ten years' imprisonment. The reason for amazement is that the retrial occupied weeks, and no evidence was offered to prove him a traitor. No case in the world was ever more thoroughly sifted. A latitude even amazing was permitted. The whole world held up its hands and said, "There was nothing like this before."

Trevor at her residence, Meadowmere, last evening, there were scarcely any events of sufficient interest to merit chronicling. The Trevor dance was a gay affair, at which the married set reigned supreme, and there were over 150 guests present.

BRIGUS, N.F., Sept. 10. -- The Peary-Harmsworth steamer Windward, Capt. John Bartlett, from Etah, North Greenland, Aug. 26, arrived here to-day, reporting all well on board. She will be followed in a week by the Peary Arctic Club's steamer Diana, Capt. Samuel W. Bartlett, also from Etah. The Windward reports that all on board the Diana were well at the time the vessels separated.

No marked increase in activity showed in the market for outside securities during the past week. The beginning of September, it was expected, would be marked by a partial return, at least, to the activity shown earlier in the year, and although these anticipations may not have been fully realized, some change for the better seems to have been brought about.

There is an air of quiet prevailing in the woolen and worsted goods market that looks strange, after the bustle and life that has been in evidence for so long. The buyers have practically deserted the city, and the active part of woolen textiles is now at the mills. The clothiers are not going to get their sample pieces in very good season, and will be writing and wiring for them very soon.

A thousand wheelmen and wheelwomen scorching along in several more or less compact squadrons was the sight witnessed by the inhabitants of many Long Island villages yesterday. The gallant thousand were quite distinct from the straggling army of independent bicyclists which every Sunday invades these villages.

SAULT STE MARIE, Mich., Sept. 10. -- The embargo on Lake Superior navigation caused by the sinking of the steamer Douglass Houghton in the Soo Passage last Tuesday was lifted at 3:30 o'clock this afternoon. The largest fleet ever accumulated on the lakes began to move soon afterward, and one vast procession headed down the lakes, while another started on its way to Lake Superior.

LONDON, Sept. 11. -- It would be difficult to describe adequately the indignation the verdict of the Dreyfus court-martial has evoked everywhere in England. The excitement in the Jewish quarters of London is only natural. Special prayers were offered throughout Saturday in all the synagogues on behalf of Dreyfus, and as soon as the verdict was known Jews and Jewesses were seen at every street corner, expressing execration, and many sobbing bitterly.

ALBANY, Sept. 10. -- State Controller William J. Morgan received a letter in July last from Superintendent of Public Works Partridge asking if he was in possession of any facts or information which would lead him to refuse to honor drafts for the payment of the final accounts on nine of the canal improvement contracts named on which the work was reported to have been completed.

RENNES, Sept. 10. -- Dreyfus has borne the terrible shock of his reconviction with marvelous fortitude -- one might almost say with unnatural calm. Yesterday he seemed stupefied when Maitre Labori communicated to him the verdict, but he has since rallied. He passed a quiet night, and he rose when his orderly brought him water at 5 o'clock this morning just as he did during the trial, when it was necessary.
