TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 10. -- The final settlement of the estate of Isaiah D. Williamson of Philadelphia, who died ten years ago, is now being made, and about $6,000,000 will be distributed equally among the thirty-seven grandnephews and grandnieces, most of whom live in this city and Bucks County, Penn.

EL PASO, Texas, Sept. 10. -- Southern Pacific Train No. 10, which left El Paso yesterday afternoon in charge of Conductor Parker and with Engineer Rich at the throttle, was held up and its express car robbed by four outlaws just before midnight Saturday at Cachise, Arizona.

HONOLULU, Sept. 2. -- The 2,000-share deal in Hawaiian Sugar Company stock which was announced recently on the Honolulu Stock Exchange brings to the island $450,000 of foreign capital, and in the opinion of men of affairs this ought to go far toward relieving the situation here.

The annual athletic games between the Pastime Athletic Club, the Xavier Athletic Association, and the Star Athletic Club, at Celtic Park, Long Island, yesterday were witnessed by about 4,000 spectators. The weather was perfect, and there was not a flaw in the programme from start to finish.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 10. -- The last concert of the season occurred at the Casino this evening. The Sunday concerts have never been so well attended since the Casino was established as they have been this season, while the grill rooms have been crowded every Sunday night. The picture of the grill rooms from the lawn was a pretty one, for some of the most charming costumes seen this season were worn by the ladies.

Public announcement was made yesterday of the engagement of Miss Emma Windolph, daughter of Aqueduct Commissioner John P. Windolph, to Mr. Henry Siefke, a wealthy young builder of this city. Miss Emma Windolph is Commissioner Windolph's third daughter. Her father was Republican Member of the Assembly from the Thirteenth Assembly District in 1885-6.

A repetition of the Kilkenny cat fight between unions belonging to the American Federation of Labor and the Knights of Labor was yesterday brought to the attention of the Central Federated Union. The Knights of Labor control the India Wharf Brewing Company of Brooklyn, and a long and bitter fight was formerly waged between them and the Brewers' National Union, which is affiliated with the American Federation of Labor.

When Richard Croker was submitting himself to the ordeal of being interviewed soon after his sudden return to the city on Saturday, he refused to say anything about rapid transit, remarking that he was not sufficiently in touch with its newer phases. He consented yesterday, however, to talk on the subject.
The hotel keepers of the Borough of Manhattan are making money as they have never made it before. The clerks are earning their salaries and exhibiting a patience that Job could not have excelled.

Not since early this Spring has there been such a representative gathering of riders and drivers on the Speedway as there was yesterday. From early morning it was crowded, and judging from the number of old-timers and their fast steppers on hand the vacation season is at an end. From now on until the first snow falls regular morning brushes will be in order.

ROME, Aug. 29. -- Yesterday morning, on the summit of the Mountain of Rocciamelone, in Piedmont, 12,500 feet above the level of the sea, the monument dedicated by the children of Italy to the Madonna was duly unveiled in the presence of thousands of onlookers.

WHEELING, West Va., Sept. 10. -- The convention of the Sixteenth (Ohio) District Republicans for the purpose of placing in the field a candidate for the seat in the National House of Representatives made vacant by the death of Capt. Lorenzo Danford, will open in Martin's Ferry Tuesday morning.

SING SING, Sept. 11. -- In Robert Louis Stevenson's "The Dynamiter" the author tells in graphic detail the agony of apprehension and the reaction experienced by a man who, while carrying a box of dynamite on his shoulder, is jostled by a woman in such a manner as to cause the explosive to fall, although it does not explode.

MONTREAL, Quebec, Sept. 11. -- Capt. Batty of the British steamer Manchester Trader, here from Liverpool, reports that on Wednesday last he passed the American schooner Eva, Capt. Comers, of New Bedford, flying signals of distress.

Since the Atlantic Coast Line secured a one-half interest in the lease of the Georgia Railroad, which extends from Augusta, Ga., to Atlanta, forming an important link in the railroad map of the South so far as traffic is concerned many rumors have been set afloat concerning the meaning of the deal with reference to the three great competing systems of the South, the Southern Railway, the Louisville and Nashville, and the Atlantic Coast Line.

CHICAGO, Sept. 11. -- The Record to-morrow will say that when Mayor Harrison returns from his vacation this week he will put himself at the head of a movement which is expected by the Democracy of Chicago to land the next National Convention of that party in this city. The gathering of Democratic National Committeemen in this city next Sunday will be taken advantage of to make friends for Chicago as the convention place.
We have received the following letter from the head of a house of brokers in this city:
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11. -- The rumors of possible combinations among the States of Central and South America directed against the United States are received with some concern by the officials here.

NEWCASTLE-ON-TYNE, Sept. 11. -W.D. Stevens, a shipowner, and Royal Commissioner to the Paris Exhibition, has declared that as a result of the Dreyfus verdict he will not put his foot on French soil. He adds that thousands of his countrymen will do the same.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Sept. 11 -- To-day Chancellor Carmichael rendered a decision foreclosing the mortgage of $2,500,000 held by the Maryland Trust Company against the Elyton Company of this city and ordering the sale of the property of the company after proper advertisement. The decree was rendered in the case of Semmes, Tompkins vs. Elyton Company and the Maryland Trust Company.

PARIS, Sept. 12. -- The Aurore publishes this morning a long letter from M. Emile Zola, the novelist, which is a pendant to his famous "J'Accuse" letter in the early stages of the revision movement. It concludes as follows:

France by its chosen organ, the army, is once more guilty of a savage wrong. This time willfully and in the light of truth. On the evidence presented no rustic Justice would convict of chicken stealing; the worthlessness of that which was secret is demonstrated by the character of the public testimony. Deliberate infamy is enacted in order that the "honor" of the French Army shall remain unstained! The victim is a soldier!

HALIFAX, Sept. 11. -- J.W. Longley, Attorney General of Nova Scotia, will issue a letter to-morrow in which he vigorously denounces the second condemnation of Dreyfus and urges the nations of the world to join in a general boycott of the Paris Exhibition, Mr. Longley says:

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 11. -- Suit was filed in the United States Court to-day against the Kentucky Distilleries and Warehouse Company by Rudolph F. Balk of this city, former owner of the Melwood Distillery. Evasion of contract is alleged, involving a quarter of a million dollars, and receiver is asked for a valuable part of the property of the trust.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept. 11. -- The schoorer yacht Studio, that has been anchored near the pier here during the Summer, owned by Mrs. Mortimer Thorne, whose stage name is Lillian Gwynne, broke her anchor chains during the southeasterly wind and struck the shoal near the wagon pier.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11. -- It is believed that when Congress assembles there will be considerable agitation of a proposition for this Government to abandon its participation in the Paris Exposition. It is thought that if the conviction of Dreyfus is permitted to stand, there will be very little friendly feeling for France among members of either the House or the Senate.

A deed was recorded yesterday covering the two block fronts on the west side of First Avenue, between Forty-first and Forty-third Streets, old four-story buildings numbered from 725 to 757 First Avenue. This is the property which was sold several months ago by James De W. Cutting, through William M. Ryan, and the buyer of which has kept his name carefully out of the transaction.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Sept. 11. -- The Grand Circuit trotting meeting opened at Narragansett Park this afternoon with disagreeable weather. The track was in good shape, but the time was slow, 2:11 1/4 being the fastest heat. Summary:

RENNES, Sept. 11. -- The Judges of the Dreyfus court-martial signed a formal recommendation for mercy this afternoon. Its object is to eliminate the degradation feature of the punishment. The recommendation will be handed to Gen. Lucas for President Loubet.

Fernando Farley, the North Bergen policeman who shot Otto Overman, and William Schenckerberg on Sunday, Sept. 3, after they had assaulted him, was placed under arrest yesterday, at the City Hospital, Jersey City. The arrest was made by order of Prosecutor James S. Erwin, on complaint of William Overman, father of Otto, who alleges that Farley was the aggressor.

LENOX, Mass., Sept. 11. -- The annual tournament of the Lenox Golf Club commenced to-day, and there was much interest in the match for the cup given by John E. Alexander. Over sixty players are in Lenox to compete for the various trophies. Many of the players to-day had never played on these links before, and probably did not make as good a score as they will later.

Secretary Corwine of the Central Puerto Rican Relief Committee and of the Merchants' Association yesterday gave out a letter from Gen. Davis, setting forth the needs of the inhabitants of Puerto Rico.

GIBRALTAR, Sept. 11. -- Before sailing from here yesterday afternoon for New York. Admiral Dewey and the officers of the United States cruiser Olympia presented u30 to Peppiatt, the gunner of the British battleship Devastation, who, while the warship was firing the salute in honor of the arrival of the Admiral, Sept. 4, had his hand shattered by the exploding of a charge while he was ramming home.
ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 11 -- For the second time within forty-eight hours a waterspout appeared in this vicinity, Absecon Bay being the scene of today's phenomena.

The severe rainstorm which swept over the city yesterday was driven by high winds, which increased in force in the afternoon to a gale of sixty miles an hour. While some trees were blown down about the city and some gardens in the suburbs were injured, there was little serious loss.

ENGLISH, Ind., Sept. 11. -- It has just become known that the English Electric Light and Manufacturing Company has gone under with a crash, involving thousands of dollars. The assignment was made very quietly Saturday evening. W.L. Luckett, the banker, and J.R. Duffin, a prominent merchant, are the assignees and Jerry L. Suddarth the attorney.
JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 11. -- The Democrats of the first Chautauqua Assembly District this afternoon nominated H.W. Flahaven of Ellery.

PRETORIA, Sept. 11. -- The British Diplomatic Agent, Conyngham Greene, has made a representation to the Transvaal Government regarding the recent arrest of Mr. Pakeman, editor of The Transvaal Leader.

President Guggenheimer, Gen. Roe, Gen. Howard Carroll, and Secretary Warren W. Foster held a conference in the Governor's Room of the City Hall yesterday afternoon and decided to call a meeting of the Plan and Scope Committee of the Dewey Executive Committee on Friday at 11 A.M. to consider the objections Gen. Roe has to the route of the parade below Twenty-third Street.

MONTREAL, Sept. 11. -- Sir William Van Horne, Chairman of the Board of Directors of the Canadian Pacific Railway Company, has admitted, what has long been an open secret, that the Canadian Pacific is anxious to establish a fast Atlantic steamship service between Canada and Liverpool, and only awaits the promise of an adequate subsidy from the Dominion Government before putting its plans into execution.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept. 11. -Thomas Braxton of Baltimore committed suicide last night by jumping into the Thoroughfare from a dock. His body was recovered, and this afternoon it was claimed by two women each of whom said she was the widow. One was Rebecca Jones of Trenton, N.J., who said she was married to Braxton some years ago and had been deserted by him.

Richard Armstrong, formerly an employe of the Street Cleaning Department, committed suicide by taking carbolic acid last night at 664 East One Hundred and Fifty-third Street, where he lived with his brother George, who is a foreman in the department. Armstrong had been ill for a year, and yesterday he asked his physician to tell him plainly what his illness was.

LIMA, Ohio, Sept. 11. -- The threatened stoppage of Detroit, Lima and Northern traffic over the Ohio Southern tracks between this city and St. Johns occurred to-day. The Lima and Northern had been ordered to vacate the Southern tracks, but ignored the notice, and to-day the latter company blocked the Lima and Northern trains here by placing an engine on the track.

SCRANTON, Penn., Sept. 11. -- A coal train on the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western dashed into the rear end of a freight train just as it had pulled out of a switch at Nay Aug, five miles south of here, to-night, wrecking the caboose of the freight train and killing two of its seven occupants. The killed are Joseph Parry and Patrick Mullen, both brakemen.

About 6,000 men gathered in front of the Metamora Club, 207 Bowery, yesterday and stood patiently in the rain. The members of the Timothy D. Sullivan Association were about to start on their annual outing to Donnelly's Pavilion, College Point, and to almost every Democratic voter in the Sixth Assembly District, and to voters in some of the adjacent districts, this is an event second to none.
LONDON, Sept. 12. -- The Times publishes this morning a three-column description of the dimensions and construction of the Shamrock.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Sept. 11. -- The public schools of Elizabeth opened today for the Fall and Winter terms. From every indication there will be 1,500 children who will not be able to gain entrance owing to the overcrowding and lack of school accommodations. The taxpayers charge the City Council is to blame for not appropriating enough money to build a new schoolhause.

It is natural that the co-religionists of Capt. DREYFUS should feel deeply outraged by the wrong that has been done to him, but it is a question they may well ask themselves if they do not run the risk of confusing the great and real issue in the concerted action that they have already entered upon to some extent, and which appears likely to assume considerable proportions.

LONDON, Ky., Sept. 11. -- The opening of war between the Griffin and Philpot factions in Clay County began last night. The house of the Widow Chadwell, wife of Evan Chadwell, brother of Deputy Sheriff Dave Chadwell, the leader of the Griffin faction, was fired into from all sides. The woman escaped by throwing herself on the floor.

HALIFAX, N.S., Sept. 11. -- Halifax is to-night the sheltering place of William H. Perot of Baltimore, Md., and his granddaughter, Gladys Perot, the eleven-year-old girl who was abducted from her grandfather's custody by her mother, the latter afterward surrendering the child in England to escape prosecution.

MONTREAL, Sept. 11. -- The first performance of the new opera comique, "Cyrano de Bergerac," by Francis Wilson, at the Academy of Music to-night, passed off with remarkable smoothness, and seemed to satisfy a large audience. The radical departure in method which has been hinted at for some days past was not apparent in Mr. Wilson's performance.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11. -- A cablegram from Gen. Otis to the War Department announces the death of Capt. Charles L. Collins, Company J, Twenty-third Infantry. He died at Cebu on the 7th inst. of appendicitis. Gen. Otis also cables the following deaths:

The constant or even infrequent reader of the reports of United States Consuls in different parts of the world must have become aware of the fact that for at least thirty years those business representatives of the Nation abroad have devoted a good deal of space in their reports to the attempt to instruct our merchants in certain necessary details that must be observed in order greatly and permanently to extend our trade.
PITTSBURG, Sept. 11. -- The Commercial Gazette to-morrow will say:

There is one consideration connected with Mr. CHAMBERLAIN'S bullying procedures respecting the Transvaal which seems to have escaped the notice both of that statesman and his principals, whether these be of the Outlanders of the Transvaal or of the stockholders of the British South Africa Company.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 11. -- William J. Stone, ex-Governor of Missouri and Acting Chairman of the National Democratic Committee, stopped over in this city to-day on his way to Richmond, Ky., where he will make an address to-morrow in the interest of the regular Democratic ticket, headed by Senator Goebel, and in which he will also touch upon National issues.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 11. -- Orders have been received from Washington by which two of the aides of Gen. Shafter, Capt. Robert H. Noble and Capt. Arthur C. Ducat, have been promoted, the first to the rank of Major and Assistant Adjutant of Volunteers and the second to the rank of Lieutenant Colonel, and assigned to duty with the Forty-ninth Volunteer Infantry, now in St. Louis.

VIENA, Sept. 11. -- The Austro-Hungarian and Russian Governments have sent a warning to King Alexander of Servia not to precipitate a revolution by sentencing to death any of the Radical leaders in connection with the recent conspiracy to assassinate former King Milan.

The Aldermanic Committee on Building Department held a public hearing yesterday on the proposed code of building laws that was reported to the City Council last Tuesday. Very few persons appeared either in favor of or in opposition to the tentative code.

The Mazet Committee has summoned RICHARD CROKER to appear before it on Wednesday. Since he was last on the witness stand the Ramapo scheme has been partly exposed and for the time being defeated by the courage and vigor of Controller COLER. It is a big scheme by which private persons would have made much and the cost and loss to the city would have been enormous and inexcusable.
NEWPORT, Sept. 11. -- Mrs. Potter Palmer entertained at Beaulieu to-night with a dinner, followed by a dance, in honor of Prince Cantacuzene and his fiancee, Miss Julia Dent Grant.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11. -- In an interview to-day, W.R. Merriam, Director of the Census, said in reference to the appointment of enumerators:

The streets of Greater New York resounded yesterday morning with the tread of a grand army of the republic. The doors of the public schoolhouses throughout the city were flung open for another term, and 400,000 children marched in, and, with varying degrees of satisfaction or disgust, took up the grind.
Passage of the dividend on International Paper common stock, but declaration of the regular payment on the preferred.

Rear Admiral SAMPSON, we are assured by those who appear to enjoy the confidence of the Bureau of Navigation, was designated to command the Boston Navy Yard because he desired that command, and Rear Admiral SCHLEY was refused the European station because it was not considered necessary to reorganize it and because he asked to have it.

What William Dalton, Commissioner of Water Supply, does and does not know about the Ramapo Company, its proposed contract with the city, and the question of municipal water works in general, was in part revealed before the Mazet committee yesterday. The committee met in the County Court House at 10:30 A.M.

FALL RIVER, Mass., Sept. 12. -- The events of the past twenty-four hours have served to simplify the mill situation here greatly. The owners of stock have now only to choose between the offer of Barrow, Wade Gutnrie Co. and the formation of a local syndicate for the consolidation of the various plants.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Sept. 12. -- "Within one year there will be no yellow pine lands for sale in South Carolina," said a prominent mill man to-day. "The syndicates of Northern capitalists are getting control of millions of acres of the best timber in the State."

The New Yorks and Chicagos broke even in the two games played at the Polo Grounds yesterday afternoon, Carsey, who played at third base, was solely respomsible for the team's defeat. Doyle retired because of injuries received while sliding to second. The New Yorks won She second game through good batting.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12. -- The Cabinet meeting to-day was occupied in the discussion of a form of civil government for Puerto Rico. This matter has been under serious consideration ever since Secretary Root took his place as Secretary of War, and the indications now are that some form of local government will be decided upon and put into operation within the next few weeks at the latest.

Mrs. Fiske achieved a very fair measure of success at the Fifth Avenue Theatre last night in the character of Rebecca Sharp, and while more praise is due to her acting than to its medium, a dramatization of "Vanity Fair" in five episodes by Langdon Mitchell, still that is by no means devoid of merit.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 12. -- An accident, which, but for the prompt action of Coachman Spencer, would have resulted fatally, happened to a pleasure party while driving this afternoon. A carriage containing Mrs. William Utz, her daughter-in-law, Mrs. Eloise Utz, and the latter's two-year-old baby was about to cross the Lehigh Valley tracks just south of Genesee Valley Park when the coachman discovered a passenger train approaching at a rapid rate.

BELLEVILLE, Kan., Sept, 12. -- Belleville citizens stand ready to subscribe $50 toward paying Capt. Thomas Phelan's expenses to London to fight Count Esterhazy, and will double that subscription if he kills him in a duel. Phelan is the Kansas City broadswordsman who yesterday mailed a challenge to the Frenchman.

A.L. Mordecai Son have sold for the Ford estate and for the New York Investment and Improvement Company, to Francis M. Marks, two pieces of vacant property at the northeast corner of Morningside Avenue and One Hundred and Fifteenth Street, which, together, comprise about six and a half lots.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 12. -- Capt. N. Mayo Dyer, who commanded the cruiser Baltimore in the battle of Manila Bay, received a sword of honor to-day as the gift of the City Council and the people of Baltimore. All the ships in the harbor, regardless of nationality, were bedecked in his honor, and buildings throughout the city were handsomely decorated.

The Shamrock hoisted yesterday for the first time the mainsail and clubtopsail that she will use in her race against the Columbia. The yacht did not leave her moorings, but swung half the day with the two sails aloft stretching in the westerly breeze, while all hands offered up thanks for the narrow escape of the green-hulled yacht from destruction during Monday night's terrific squall.

NEWPORT, Sept. 12. -- The song recital given by the Princess Adolphe de Wrede at the Casino this evening was largely attended and excited great interest. The Princess, who is a strikingly handsome woman, has made many friends since her arrival here two weeks ago, and was loudly applauded for all her selections.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 12. -- Upon the arrival of Trainer Walter Christie and several of the football men here to-day interest in Nassau's football plans for the coming season went up a few notches. Mr. Christie expects all the football men here early the first of next week, and practice will begin in earnest on Wednesday.

HALIFAX, Sept. 12. -- A dispatch from Sydney, Cape Breton, says J. Ferry of Paris arrived there to-day on the steamer Propatria from St. Pierre, Miquelon, at which place he is Collector of Customs. He was charged there with being a spy in the pay of the Canadian Government.

CHICAGO, Sept. 12. -- The Tribune says: "According to a cablegram received from Holland to-day, bondholders of the Kansas City, Pittsburg and Gulf Railroad have approved the reorganization plan as prepared by the Philadelphia committee. This means that A.E. Stillwell and John W. Gates will have the control of the road when the reorganization is perfected.
H.B. Chase, a conductor on the Nostrand Avenue trolley line, Brooklyn, living at 257 Twelfth Street, Brooklyn, was arrested last night under peculiar circumstances.

Col. PARTRIDGE, Commissioner of Public Works, has issued a circular to the officials along the line of the canals, calling their attention, on the eve of the approaching campaign, to the provisions of the civil service law forbidding the use of patronage or the promise of it to influence political action.

ROCHESTER, Sept. 12. -- Hundreds of children were turned away from the doors of the public schools here yesterday and today, hundreds of others will be turned away during the remainder of the week. The inadequacy of the public school accommodation is apparent to all, and Mayor Warner, who has blocked all attempts to bring about a better condition, is being severely criticised.

-- Discussion of the street sign problem threatens to go on indefinitely -- possibly because the municipal officials who have the solution of the problem in hand seem to be paying no attention whatever to public opinion, and to be heeding neither criticism nor suggestion. Beyond question the recent twisting about of the signs has annoyed many people, and enraged not a few.

In his letter, which was dated at Washington and addressed to Gen. Daniel Butterfield, as Chairman of the Executive Committee, the President says: Dear Gen. Butterfield:

In response to the article in THE TIMES of to-day, and signed by "West Sider," I would say that the driver of the horse and the man who assisted in the beating should have been punished by arrest for their cruel treatment of the animal, and the policeman should be censured by the Commissioners for not placing the men under arrest.

LENOX, Mass., Sept. 12. -- It was perfect golf weather in Lenox to-day, and a very large and fashionable gallery watched the playing. Several members of the Diplomatic Corps were present, including the Portuguese Minister, J. De Costa Duarte; the Baroness Fava, and Count Starzynski of Russia, who has just arrived from Newport.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 12. -- The news received from New York this morning announcing the sudden death of Cornelius Vanderbilt shocked the cottagers and residents of the city, where he took so important a part socially and otherwise. The first intelligence received came from Senator Depew to his son and niece, Miss Paulding, at Pinard Cottage No. 4.

PARK HILL STATION, N.Y., Sept. 12. -- The opening of the championship tournament of the Hudson River Lawn Tennis Association, which was postponed yesterday because of the rain, was held this afternoon on the courts of the Park Hill Country Club. The association is composed of the Poughkeepsie, Powelton, West Point, Sleepy Hollow, Amakassin, and Park Hill Country Clubs.

BOSTON, Sept. 12. -- Mayor Quincy's experiment in the use of automobiles for the chiefs of city departments is proving successful. Only one carriage has been tried as yet, but it has been in use since the beginning of August, and the driver asserts that it does the work of three horses.

The returns from the various public schools to the Board of Education as to the numbers of pupils registered and in attendance have been slow in coming in, and by last evening twenty schools had not yet been heard from. Thus far, said Superintendent Jasper yesterday afternoon, 221,000 children have been registered and 195,000 have been reported in attendance.

The opening of the Brooklyn Jockey Club's Fall meeting at Gravesend yesterday did not bring out as large a crowd as that present at the openings of this popular track in former years. Probably 5,000 spectators were congregated on the grand stand and in the cheaper seats when the bell rang for the first race, and these enjoyed an ideal afternon's sport.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 12. -- The University of Pennsylvania football players held their first practice this afternoon, thirty candidates responding to Capt. Hare's call. The decision to restrict the preliminary training to the home grounds resulted in a much larger attendance than is usual. At least twenty more men are expected to report to-morrow.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 12. -- The announcement of the death of Cornellus Vanderbilt occasioned expressions of keenest regret here, particularly in university and railroad circles. Mr. Vanderbilt was regarded as a Yale man in spite of the fact that he was not graduated from the institUtion.

Mr. Archbold, in his testimony before the Industrial Commission, stated that "it [the Standard Oil Company] gives to the community at large an opportunity for investment in the business itself which it never could have had in the old system."

BOSTON, Sept. 12. -- Ambassador William 1. Draper denies as absurd a story which was printed here tounight, to the effect that he was about to resign his post in Rome and become the Administration candidate for Governor of Massachusetts.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Sept. 12. -- In regard to the report that an injunction was to be used by Mrs. Voynich in order to stop Stuart Robson from presenting "The Gadfly" as it is now produced, Mr. Dunn, the business manager of the company, stated that something of this nature was expected. Dan Arthur left the city for New York this afternoon.

The Emperor of Germany adopted the precise "psychological moment" for bearing his testimony to the innocence of DREYFUS. Although that evidence was not technically "before" the court-martial which condemned the unhappy and innocent man, nobody doubts that it was known to every one of the Judges, and nobody can doubt that the refusal to accept the volunteered word of the German Government will be bitterly resented in Germany.

John McDonald, twenty-three years old, of 346 East Thirty-first Street, in a spirit of maliciousness deliberately threw a man overboard from the hurricane deck of the excursion steamboat Thomas E. Moore, at the foot of East Thirty-first Street yesterday, and after his arrest, while endeavoring to escape, pushed Policeman David Snechan under a First Avenue electric car.

SANTO DOMINGO, Sept. 12. -- Juan Isidro Jimenes, the aspirant to the Presidency of Santo Domingo, arrived here this morning on board the Dominican warship Presidente. His arrival was the cause of great festivals and expressions of satisfaction. It is not known as yet when the election will take place.

The new Building Code, which was last week submitted to the Municipal Assembly by the commission which framed it, was rushed through the Board of Aldermen yesterday. This was done despite the protestations of the Republican and Citizens' Union members, who denounced the code as a job and a fraud upon the people, and an effort to overthrow the building laws.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12. -- The Panther has arrived at League Island.

Cornelius Vanderbilt died at his home, West Fifty-seventh Street, a few minutes after 6 o'clock yesterday morning from cerebral hemorrhage, the result of a third stroke of paralysis. The first stroke, which occurred on July 14, 1896, narrowly escaped being fatal. The second stroke, which occurred about a year after the first attack, was of a mild character.

LONDON, Sept. 12 -- 4 P.M. -- American securities opened depressed on the lower overnight operations from New York, and prices remained down, with next to nothing doing, the market being obedient to the lead of Wall Street. The dearness of money in New York is held to be mainly responsible for the depression.

Some time ago I had occasion to express in THE TIMES my opinion on the fanatical doings of the Rev Mr. Sanford in the Holy Ghost Society at Shiloh. Dr. Simpson of the Christian Alliance affords another opportunity for criticism.

Winston Churchill, whose story "Richard Carrel" has been one of the most widely read books of the year, was in the city yesterday, staying at the Holland House. He will leave to-day for Windsor, Vt., where he has recently purchased a home. When he arrives there he will at once resume work on a historical novel which he has in hand.

The police boat Patrol has been armed in time to fire a salute for Admiral Dewey. The Patrol, under command of Capt. Elbert O. Smith, left her berth at Pier A yesterday afternoon and made her way to the Brooklyn Navy Yard. When she returned the skippers of the river craft off the Battery failed to recognize her.

What the Post Office Inspectors claim to be the most complicated "green-goods" swindle with which they have had to deal in a long time was first made public yesterday by the issuance of fraud orders by Postmaster Van Cott, in accordance with instructions from the department at Washington, against the firms of Moore Co. of 65 West Broadway and the Bonanza Jewelry Company of 1,822 Park Avenue.
ST. PAUL, Sept. 13. -- Attorney General Douglas of Minnesota will introduce the following resolution at the Chicago Trust Convention;

CHICAGO, Sept. 13. -- The feature of today's trading in wheat was the scramble for September wheat, in which big elevator firms were involved, and which sent the price at one time to a point nearly 2 cents above yesterday's close. It closed at 1 cent advance.

NEWPORT, Sept. 13. -- The news that the Earl of Yarmouth had signed with the Frohmans was no surprise to the cottagers, as they learned of his contemplated adoption of the stage during the Summer. Several of the prominent cottagers expressed themselves as very much pleased at the Earl's securing such an engagement, and they feel he will be a success.

LAWRENCE, Mass., Sept. 13. -- The case of J.Q.A. Johnson, administrator, versus Richard M. Bourne, administrator, and the Newburyport Five Cents Savings Bank, which will be tried here on Friday before Judge Sherman, is ore of unusual interest. Property worth about $60,000 is involved in the suit, which will recall the fatal Windsor Hotel fire in New York on March 17, 1899.

The Mazet Committee continued yesterday its investigation into the Ramapo water scheme. The court room was crowded. Upon the witness stand were the President of the Ramapo Water Company, Silas B. Dutcher, and Frank H. Platt, who is President of the Fidelity and Deposit Company of Maryland, a member of the law firm of Tracy, Boardman Platt, and the son of Senator Thomas C. Platt.

The Association of Owners of Apartment Houses will soon issue a circular with a view to getting together testimony that can be used to support a bill to be introduced in the Legislature for the protection of landlords of apartment houses against irresponsible and dishonest tenants.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 13. -- Mrs. T. Dayton Martin of 108 McWhorter Street, while riding her bicycle on the Seven Bridges Road, near Springfield to-day ran into a farm wagon driven by Charles McMurray, and was instantly killed. The pole of the wagon struck her squarely in the forehead, cutting a terrible gash, and fracturing her skull.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 13. -- Joseph Anderson, Jr., son of the Rev. Joseph Anderson of Waterbury, one of Connecticut's leading clergymen, and a member of the Yale corporation, was married yesterday at Bridgeport without his family or the family of the bride being aware that such a ceremony was to be performed.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, Sept. 12. -- The American schooner Mildred E., from San Blas for New York, stranded here yesterday. She is reported to be a total wreck. The cargo has been salvaged and the crew are going home. Trouble is arising over the wreckers looting the vessel.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 13. -- Bloomfield Co. have purchased from W.P.D. Bush 4,000 acres of land in and adjoining Uniontown. The deal has just been closed and is one of the biggest land sales made in Kentucky in recent years.

It seems to me high time to call a halt to the indiscriminate condemnation of France. Nobody more than I deplores the unjust, aye criminal, decision of the court-martial which has just rendered its verdict of guilty, but has the fact that a revision was brought about not shown that there are still men, good men, in France?

It is now practically certain that the route of the land parade in honor of Admiral Dewey will be changed again so that instead of moving down Broadway and through Union Square to University Place, it will traverse Fifth Avenue, from Fifty-ninth Street to Washington Square, which is the point of dismissal.

PHILADELPHIA, Pa., Sept. 13. -- Gov. Voorhees of New Jersey to-day called on Rear Admiral Sampson, on board the flagship New York, now lying in the Delaware River with the other ships of the North Atlantic squadron, to arrange with him a time for the presentation of the sword which the Legislature of New Jersey, has voted to give to the Admiral.

Yesterday's performance amply justified Tuesday's promises in the stock market. If prices moved a trifle slowly at the beginning it was only that they might get properly in line for a good start. Once applied, the impetus of improvement suffered no halt all day. Closing prices marked high prices in many instances, and in all the two were nearly alike.

PARIS, Sept. 13. -- The Government Commissioner attached to the Council of Revision may possibly finish the report on the Dreyfus case before Monday. In that event the Council of Revision will give a decision regarding the merits of the appeal that day, and on the following day the Cabinet will decide whether measures of clemency are advisable.

SOUTHBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 13. -- News was received here early this morning of a double murder which occurred late last night near the manufacturing village of Fiskdale, about ten miles northwest of this town. John King, about eighty-four years old, and his wife, aged eighty, were killed by their son, Peter, who was crazed from the excessive use of liquor.

WORCESTER, Mass., Sept. 13. -- The Prohibition State Convention to-day morinated the following ticket: Governor -- John W. Baer of Medford; Lieutenant Governor -- James H. Roberts of Cambridge; Secretary -- John B. Lewis of Reading; Treasurer -- Herbert B. Griffin of Winthrop; Auditor -- Franklin A. Palmer of Stockbridge; Attorney General -- Sidney Perley of Salem.
PARK HILL STATION, N.Y., Sept. 13. -- Play was continued here to-day in the championship tournament of the Hudson River Lawn Tennis Association on the grounds of the Park Hill Country Club.
LONDON, Sept. 13. -- The British Association for the Advancement of Science to-day gTanted u1,000 toward the expenses of an antarctic expedition.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 13. -- Two thousand delegates attended the opening session of the National Colored Baptists' Convention in this city to-day, nearly all of the States being represented. The assemblage is a representative one, many of the most prominent colored ministers, educators, and professional men in the land being present.

CHICAGO, Sept. 13. -- The conference on the uses and abuses of trusts and combinations began here to-day with less than half the delegates appointed by the various States in attendance. New York, headed by W. Bourke Cockran, and Wisconsin were most numerously represented.

CHICAGO, Sept. 13. -- W. Bourke Cockran of New York said to-day: "I certainly regard this trust conference as the most important and representative that has yet been held on the subject. If I did not think that it would do any good I should not have come. I do not care to say what attitude I take toward trusts until I hear what the convention says."

Daly's Theatre was opened to the public last night for the first time since the death of its illustrious founder. Few changes have been made in the spacious foyers and richly decorated auditorium. A few heavy pieces of furniture and some of the larger pictures displayed on easels have been removed, but the valuable collection of theatrical portraits still hangs on the foyer walls.

I see that the Plan and Scope Committee of the Dewey land parade is to meet on Friday next to decide on the route. It will be interesting to know what arguments can be presented for turning the line to Broadway from below Twenty-third Street, and, most remarkable of all, below Fourteenth Street to University Place, an unattractive side street with railroad tracks.

The third day's play in the club championship tournament of the Orange Lawn Tennis Club at the South Orange grounds yesterday afternoon reduced the number of players in the championship singles to five. In the semi-final round to-day, young Jay Bramhall will meet Paret, while Hague will play Conway, and the winner will then meet Watson in the other semi-final.

LONDON, Sept. 13. -- Mrs. Brown Potter and Kyrle Bellew are rehearsing a new last act for "The Ghetto," the play so universally condemned. It will not last many weeks, in spite of any changes in an effort to make it more acceptable. A new plot and new characters are necessary.

Considerable interest was expressed yesterday among the broad-silk houses in Greene and Broome Streets about the efforts of the Paterson (N.J.) Broad Silk Manufacturers' Association to form a combination. The local agents of the Paterson manufacturers knew very little about the movement, but it was not denied by any of them, because they are not aware yet of what was done at the meeting of the Paterson association last Tuesday night.

The stories that come to us from South America by the way of Mexico about the fear there felt lest the United States shall pursue a policy of grab toward all the lands south of us are natural enough, and they are plausible enough also to merit some attention from our people.

An old soldier in a Michigan town, who had a leg amputated ten years ago, had it buried in a coffin in the cemetery and funeral services held over it, at which he wept profusely. Ever since then, all through the Summer months he has placed flowers each week upon the grave.

Marking a new era in steam navigation, in marine architecture, and in the history of the ocean ferry, the colossal new steamship Oceanic of the White Star Line came into port yesterday from her maiden voyage. She was accorded a welcome in keeping with her distinction as the giantess of the seas.

The amended dispensary law, which will go into effect on the 1st of next month, is expected to work a partial reform in the present system of free medical and surgical treatment of the poor of this city. The amendment was introduced in the Legislature by Mr. Murphy, and passed on Feb. 24 last.

CHICAGO, Sept. 13. -- The second annual women's tournament of the Onwentsia Club opened to-day with the qualifying round for the Governors' Cup, and, although three additional cups had been added as adjuncts to the main prize, the interest centred in the first four places, the holders of these being the only ones who have a chance at the cup under match play.

After a secret session which lasted until nearly midnight last night, the Central City Committee of the Citizens' Union reaffirmed the principles of the party platform of 1897, and decided not only not to enter into any "entangling alliance" with the regular parties, but also to refuse to confer with representatives of other parties.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 13. -- The Columbus Central Street Railway, including tracks and equipments in this city and seven miles out, and Minerva Park, the suburban terminus of the road, was sold at public outcry at the Court House to-day to W.S. Rowe, Cashier of the First National Bank of Cincinnati, for $1,300,000. The property was appraised at $1,068,680.

LENOX, Mass., Sept. 13. -- The Lenox cottagers were all down to the links again today to see the first and second rounds, match play, for the Lenox Cup. In the morning the sixteen who qualified narrowed down to eight, who played the 18 holes in the afternoon, and the four remaining will play the third round to-morrow morning.

Yom Kippur, the great Day of Atonement and fasting among the Jews, began at sunset yesterday and will continue until the sun drops behind the horizon to-day. The orthodox Jews who have come here from Russia and Polish Austria and Prussia and from Northern Africa observed the fast with all the strictness and austerity of ancient times.

Mrs. Thomas and her two daughters, newly installed tenants in a fashionable apartment house at 347 West Eighty-fifth Street, owned by W.E.D. Stokes, on Tuesday suffered the decidedly unpleasant experience of being locked out of their home at midnight.

FALL RIVER, Mass., Sept. 13. -- The local cotton mill consolidation scheme has attracted the attention of many stockholders who were about ready to turn over their property to the Barrow syndicate whenever an offer would be made to them directly. The members of the committee are now at work trying to interest financiers who are familiar with the productive values of the local properties.

Left alone for a little while yesterday morning six-year-old Bennie Seigel of 142 Suffolk Street decided to have some fun. Bennie's idea of a good time is a fire, and there was no reason why he should not have a nice one. His papa had just gone to work in a near-by sweatshop, while his mother was confined to her bed with her week-old baby.
LONDON, Sept. 12. -- Indignation resulting from the verdict in the Dreyfus case still continues. It is the principal topic.
BELIN, Sept. 13. -- The German Government organs have been quick to issue a warning against the proposal to boycott the Paris Exhibition.

The Electrical Power Company's suit, begun nearly ten years ago, against New York City, the Commissioner of Public Works, and the Board of Electrical Control to compel the restoration of its electric wires and appurtenances, which had then been removed, and $250,000 damages for the destruction of its electrical service in this city, was decided yesterday by Justice Russell in Supreme Court, Special Term.

Again the one topic of discussion wherever the members of the society world assembled yesterday was the death of Cornelius Vanderbilt, and every detail of the arrangements for his funeral to-morrow, of the scenes at his house, and the movements of his relatives published, was read with keen interest.

A big row has been raised in the Post Office over the publication yesterday of a statement by Sebastian Stock, the Secretary of the Greater New York Retail Butchers' Association, that he had mailed in the sub-station at Fifty-second Street and Broadway on Monday afternoon between 700 and 800 circulars, which had all gone astray, not one having been delivered.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Sept. 13. -- The Poe Memorial Association of the University of Virginia will on Oct. 7 unveil Zolnay's bust of the poet. The day will be the fiftieth anniversary of Poe's death. Two meetings will be devoted to the occasion. In the morning Dr. C.W. Kent, President of the association, will present the bust, and it will be officially received by the university. The chief address will be by Hamilton W. Mabie.

WILMINGTON, Del., Sept. 13. -- Several weeks ago the New York banking and brokerage firm of C.H. White Co., being the highest bidders, obtained the award of $24,000 in Wilmington City sinking fund bonds. The bonds were to draw 4 per cent., and White Co. offered $1,936 premium. Their only stipulation was that they should be assured of the legality of the issue, which was not questioned here.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 13. -- John D. Rockefeller this morning ordered the large force of men employed by him in the construction of his new macadam road from his Droperty to the Goring Brook Road to continue the work. He declares that he has the written permission of the Village Trustees to build the road,' and that the work will be completed.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 13. --Mrs. Eugene H. Brientnall was accidentally shot and killed by her husband at their home, 86 Ninth Avenue, this afternoon. Mr. Brientnall, who is twenty-eight years old, is a son of Lieut. Col. R. Heber Brientnall of the First Regiment. His wife was thirty-two years of age.
ISLAND OF BERMUDA, Sept. 13. -- A cyclone swept over this island last night, doing heavy damage to public and private property, but no lives have been reported lost.

Only a few hundred persons saw the game at the Polo Grounds yesterday afternoon, but those who stayed away will have no cause for regret, as the game, after the third inning, was nothing more than a farce. In the third inning the New Yorks landed on Mullarkey's curves with a vengeance, and 10 runs resulted.

While messages of sympathy from all parts of this country and many places in Europe poured into the Vanderbilt mansion at Fifth Avenue and Fifty-seventh Street yesterday the arrangements for the funeral of Cornelius Vanderbilt, who dies early Tuesday morning, progressed almost to completion.

PRETORIA, Sept. 13. -- President Kruger and the Executive Council reassembled here this evening to consider the reply to be made to the British Secretary of State for the Colonies, Joseph Chamberlain. They are still conferring by telegraph with the Orange Free State. The decision is anxiously awaited by the crowds outside the Executive Building.

ALBANY, Sept. 13. -- Willis H. Tennant, as counsel for Herman Sixby and Seth Scriven, to-day filed with Gov. Roosevelt written charges of malfeasance against Thomas Hutson of Mayville, Treasurer of Chautauqua County, who is the Republican candidate for Treasurer for a third term. The charges allege misappropriation of funds.

The offer of Capt. W.F. SHOEMAKER, Chief of the Revenue Marine Bureau of the Treasury, to parade twelve revenue cutters on the day of the naval demonstration in honor of the home-coming of Admiral DEWEY, and a battalion of 400 officers and men for the street procession, if Secretary GAGE will empower Capt. SHOEMAKER to do so, will of course be accepted.

PORT CHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 13. -- The factional fight between the Ward and Burns factions of the Republican Party here was very warm at the primaries. The Ward faction is led by ex-Congressman William L. Ward. The leader of the Burns faction is ex-Senator J. Irving Burns. At the primaries the list of ward candidates for delegates to the conventions were read, and Henry C. Weeks offered a different set.

Alfred Seton, Jr., has sold for A. Lanfear Norrie, to a client, 26 West Forty-fourth Street, 25 by 100.5, now occupied by private stable.
LONDON, Sept 14. -- English indignation against France was strengthened to-day on account of the observance by all Jews of the Day of Atonement.

Nearly twoscore men eminent in railroad and financial affairs assembled in the Directors' room at the Grand Central Station yesterday forenoon to do honor to the memory of Cornelius Vanderbilt. It was a joint meeting of the Presidents and Directors of all of the railroads in the Vanderbilt system and on no previous occasion have so many of the leading men in that great system met together.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14. -- Charles E. Macrum, Consul at Pretoria, in a report on the diamond production of the Transvaal, says that the output in the Pretoria district during 1898 amounted to 11,025 carats, valued at $43,151.25. In December, 1897, the output was 166 carats, valued at $710.51, and for the same month in 1898 the output was 3,100 carats, with a value of $11,626.07.

Otis to enforce the Chinese immigration laws and Chinese Exclusion act against the Chinese in the Philippines. The paper says:

MIDDLEBOROUGH, Mass., Sept. 14. -- Edwin Ray Snow of Yarmouthport was arrested here to-day by State Detective Letteney of Hyannis and Sheriff Chase of Harwich, on suspicion of being the murderer of James Whittemore.

NEWPORT, Sept. 14. -- More than fifty of the cottagers went to New York to-day for the purpose of attending the funeral of Cornelius Vanderbilt in that city to-morrow, while others started this evening. Bellevue Avenue this afternoon looked more like early May than the middle of September, owing to the departure of so many of the cottagers.

If Mr. Moss had sought to illustrate the law of contrasts in the most forcible manner, he could not have found better material for his illustration than these three persons.

LONDON, Sept. 14.--Rudolph Aronson, who is a passenger on the Saale, has secured from the widow of Johann Strauss the American rights to the posthumous operetta "Wiener Blut," which is to be produced in Vienna about Oct.1.

Col. James P. Watson, who says he is a whisky salesman of Pulaski, Va., and a guest at the Gilsey House, and William J. Adams, who says his business is billiards and that he lives at the Martin House, the principals in the shooting affray in front of the Broadway Theatre last Thursday, were prisoners in the Jefferson Market Court yesterday morning before Magistrate Mott.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 14. -- The owners of the thirty-footers have held a meeting and decided to have another week of racing after this one, and the fleet now left for the series of sweepstake races will consist of the Esperanza, Carolina, Asahi, Puck, and Vaquero III. The fleet was diminished yesterday by the departure of the Hera for City Island.

Nine members of the Executive Committee of the Citizens' Union, in the Nineteenth Assembly District, assembled in the Sherman Square Hotel last night and deliberated for nearly three hours over a proposition to oppose the renomination and re-election of Assemblyman Robert Mazet. Joseph M. Price, Chairman of the committee, presided, and Isaac H. Klein took an active part in the discussion.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14. -- The Adjutant General received the following dispatch from Gen. Brooke to-day: "Depot battalions. First and Eighth Infantry, leave for States to-night. The Second and Tenth Infantry will return on McPherson, which left New York Sept. 9; the Fifth Infantry is ready to move as soon as transport arrives, expected Sept. 12."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14. -- James H. Tillman, a nephew' of ex-Senator Tillman of South Carolina, and who served as Lieutenant Colonel and for a short time as Colonel of the First South Carolina Volunteers in the Spanish war, has been promised by the President Captaincy in one of the new volunteer regiments.

CHICAGO, Sept. 14.--Crude petroleum was given another boost of 2 cents a barrel by the Standard Oil Company to-day, the Pennsylvania product being quoted at $1.45 and the Indianapolis at 99 cents. In the last three months the market has advanced 15 cents a barrel, and at to-day's figures was at the highest since 1896.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14. -- A large and promising source of income has been shut off by an order issued by the Post Office Department, to the effect that no more contracts for rural free delivery service will be entered into until Congress meets and makes a further appropriation.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14. -- At the recent Grand Army encampment in Philadelphia the opponents of Pension Commissioner Evans charged that Pension Examiners insulted widows who were applicants for pension by asking them impertinent questions.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14. -- The Navigation Bureau of the navy to-day issued a list of vessels of the United States Navy of all kinds, making the surprising showing of 312 craft. This Includes many small vessels and craft captured in Cuba and the Philippines, but the showing is, nevertheless, remarkable in comparison with the naval list of two years ago.

Trading in the market for outside securities was very limited yesterday, and changes in price were important in only a few issues. Advances were probably more numerous than declines, but business was not active enough to cause much fluctuation in values. Little news was had during the day beyond the announcement of several dividends, and as these had been nearly all fully anticipated, their effect on the several stocks was of no marked importance.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 14. -- The retail butchers of St. Louis are waging a systematic war on the beef trust. They recently organized for that purpose, and the first step in the fight will be the building of an abattoir.

The first meeting after the Summer vacation of the Paint, Oil, and Varnish Club was held last evening at the Down Town Association's rooms in Pine Street. About fifty members of the club were present. W.H. Andrews, President of the club, was in the chair. The meeting was preceded by a dinner.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 14. -- Clearance papers have been allowed the Tartar at Hongkong. It is expected that she will proceed to the United States at once.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 14. -- Finer golf has never been played in this country in an open championship contest than was seen at the Baltimore Country Club links to-day. So intense was the competition among the leading professionals and so close the scores that to-night, with half the contest completed, it is impossible to pick a winner among the score or more who are within fifteen strokes of one another.
NEWPORT, Sept. 14. -- Mrs. Hermann Oelrichs has had her household furnishings stowed away for use next season, and will shortly return to New York and open her house there.

LENOX, Mass., Sept. 14. -- There were comparatively few spectators at the links today on account of the bleak west winds and the cold, although quite a number of the cottagers came down to the five o'clock tea in the clubhouse.

Strength in the financial situation was curiously illustrated in yesterday's stock market. Those who observe that the trading list abounds in minus signs will see how little the changes signify. For the most part they are expressed in small fractions. Declines which involved units affected as few stocks as could well be put into a list.

In calling attention to the latest incident in the rivalry of the banks and the trust companies the other day, we referred to a possible outcome of that rivalry in the common control of both classes of institutions by the same body of capitalists. This, of course, is a remote eventuality, even if it is ever realized.

CHICAGO, Sept. 14. -- The second day's session of the trust conference opened here to-day, with William Wirt Howe of New Orleans in the chair, and a falling off in the attendance of both delegates and spectators.

The destructive fire which raged in the building at 1,301 Atlantic Avenue, Brooklyn, early yesterday morning caused the death of one woman, injury to a number of other tenants, completely gutted the building and badly damaged the one adjoining, and made homeless twenty-two families, numbering in all nearly 100 persons. Many heroic rescues prevented a much greater loss of life.

The State and Brigade rifle matches, gala events in the National Guard calendar, were shot at Creedmoor under clear skies yesterday. Keen "left" winds, cutting across the range all day, however, marred the otherwise perfect weather conditions and made bull's-eyes at the longer distances very rare.

As the result of the statement made by Sebastian Stock, Secretary of the Greater New York Retail Butchers' Association, that the circulars which he had mailed Monday afternoon calling a meeting of the association for Tuesday evening, were not delivered until Wednesday morning, William T. Helm, a negro clerk employed in Postal Station G, at Broadway and Fifty-second Street, was called before Postmaster Van Cott yesterday.

Alderman John S. Roddy of the Twenty-first District was a prisoner in the Harlem Police Court yesterday on a charge of bribery. The warrant was issued by Magistrate Zeller upon the complaint of James Valchos, a Greek fruit dealer.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 14. -- The National Export Exposition was formally opened at non to-day. Hundreds of distinguished visitors from all sections of the country were in attendance, including representaeives of the Diplomatic Corps, officers of the army and navy, scientists and business and professional men.

One of the quickest and most important turns made in Wall Street in recent years, and which this week has been the subject of general gossip, was that of William Alexander Scott, better known as "Farmer" Scott, who, by speculating in the common stock of the Tennessee Coal, Iron, and Railroad Company, has since last December cleared up little short of $200,000, with, as he says, "more in sight."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14. -- Secretary Root has approved the action of Gen. Ludlow in suppressing El Reconcentrado, a newspaper formerly published in Havana. After the paper had been suppressed the publishers appeared in Washington and protested to the Secretary of War that the action of Gen. Ludlow was an infringement on the rights of citizenship.

CHICAGO, Sept. 14. -- A rumor gained currency on Change to-day that the differences between the Weare and Armour people, arising out of a deal in September wheat, and which seemed to threaten an "elevator war," have been adjusted through a private settlement.

HAVANA, Sept. 14. -- All the Havana papers have until of late carefully avoided what the Cubans generally recognize as the most important question. To-day, however, the Lucha says:

McVickar Co. have sold to a client for occupancy the four-story English basement brownstone-front dwelling 110 East Thirty-fifth Street, 16.8 by 98.9. Extensive alterations will be made by the purchaser.

CHICAGO, Sept. 14. -- Mrs. H. Toulmin of the Milwaukee Country Club defeated Mrs. Hobart C. Chatfield-Taylor in the semifinals to-day for the Governor's Cup in the woman's golf championship. Good golf was played by both, and the score was all square at the eighteenth hole, but on the nineteenth Mrs. Taylor, the present holder of the cup, took six strokes, while Mrs. Toulmin succeeded in holding down with five.

LONDON, Sept. 14. -- While the staff of the Foreign Office will maintain continuous communication to-night with Mr. Chamberlain at Birmingham, it is not believed now that the result of the debate in the Volksraad will be received before Friday. A forecast of the Transvaal's reply has been received by Mr. Chamberlain, but its nature is not yet known.

BOSTON, Sept. 14. -- Messrs. Brown Co. have in press a little volume containing two of Emerson's early writings "The Character of Socrates" and "The Present State of Ethical Philosophy," accompanied by a new critical essay by Dr. Edward Everett Hale presenting Emerson the whole man, considering his private and domestic character as much as the aspect visible to the public.

Although Count Tolstoi's new novel, the "Resurrection," has not yet made its appearance in this country from Dodd, Mead Co., it is being circulated in London and presents a curious apparition. It is published over there by the Brotherhood Publishing Company, and has every appearance of being a packet of temperance tracts, the packet being composed of six paper booklets wrapped up in coarse, buff-colored paper and secured by an India rubber band.

NEW HAVEN, Conn. Sept. 15. -- The Hyperion Theatre here was the scene to-night of the first production of Miss May Irwin's new play, "Sister Mary." The house was packed and included a party of several hundred of the members of the Typothetae Convention now being held here.

Controller Coler's recent report to the Board of Estimate on the subject of municipal subsidies to private charitable institutions has led the Rev. Thomas L. Kinkead, Supervisor of Catholic Charities, to make a long reply, in which he contends that the Controller, in some of his assumptions at least, is in error.

CHICAGO, Sept. 15. -- A "model" coal mining town is being built near Pittsburg, in the coal region, by James W. Ellsworth of New York. It will be named after its founder. The inhabitants will be owners of the real estate, instead of tenants; managers instead of mere spectators of the town Government; co-operative partners in its local mercantile enterprises instead of patrons.

LONDON, Sept. 15. -- Whether Nat Goodwin has made a good bargain by going shares with Levenston and Lorillard at the Comedy Theatre is an open question. "An American Citizen" has been going so well it would have been unwise to have shelved it, therefore Levenston's offer of the comedy.
NEWPORT, Sept. 15. -- This evening Mrs. David King gave an informal dinner at her cottage, Kingscote, in honor of Prince Cantacuzene and Miss Julia Dent Grant.

The State Historian, Mr. Hugh Hastings, in his third anneal report, presents material which is both novel and interesting. In the last report were given the muster rolls from 1664 to 1760. In the present volume are to be found the remaining rolls from 1760 to the outbreak of the Revolutionary War. Mr. Hastings states that for the decade prior to 1775 "the number of muster rolls is surprisingly and disappointingly small."
NORWAY, Me. Sept. 15. -- Maine clam diggers have practically decided to form a trust, hoping thereby to control the prices now paid by the wholesale dealers.
